mnemonics.meaning: Above Up, Over You find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. It's weird, because it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">above</mark> the ground, not where toes belong. Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.
mnemonics.reading: じょう うえ, あ, のぼ, うわ, かみ None Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Joe (じょう). Try to remember Joe, the local farmhand. He is a recurring character that will come up anytime the reading for a kanji is じょう. He is a very big man, and he wears farmer's clothes. It's important to imagine your version of Joe as very big, because it will help us to differentiate him from Jo-Anne, who is the character associated with the similar, but shorter reading (and character) じょ. Although Joe will develop as you go through all the じょう reading kanji, for now, just imagine him as a big, kinda slow dude, who works for a local farmer. Also, he only has nine or fewer toes, apparently.

mnemonics.meaning: Below Down, Under, Beneath There's the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, and there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">below</mark> it. Yep, you know this means "below" because the ground has a toe below it in this kanji. Where's that toe again? Below the ground. Maybe it's your toe. Imagine digging it out and thinking, Ugh, why does it have to be under the ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?
mnemonics.reading: か, げ した, さ, くだ, お, しも, もと None You keep digging in the ground for the toe below, but instead you hit something hard and metallic. You try to dig around it, but it's huge. Turns out it's a car (か). Keep digging until you unearth the car below. (Inside, you find the toe you were looking for.) There's another useful on'yomi reading that just isn't useful enough for you to learn now. That reading is げ, but we're only going to worry about that much, much later when you have to learn one or two vocab words that read 下 as げ. That's the problem with really common kanji — too many readings.

mnemonics.meaning: Big Large The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">big</mark> kanji are exactly the same! So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well.
mnemonics.reading: たい, だい おお ひろ There's this big guy (that's how you remember the radical, remember?), and he's wearing a huge Tie Dye (たい, だい) shirt. Because he's so huge, the tie dye shirt is also super huge. Everything about him is pretty big, but the tie dye stands out more than anything. When you look at the big guy in your head, imagine him covered in tie dye head to toe. Think about how ridiculous it looks on him, especially since he's such a big guy. Shirt. Sweatpants. Hat. Shoes... it goes on and on.

mnemonics.meaning: Construction Industry The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">construction</mark> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">industry</mark>, which is what construction is, if you think about it. It's all part of the construction industry. Know your radicals and you'll know this kanji's meaning.
mnemonics.reading: こう, く None None Every time a kanji uses the こう reading (there are a lot!), we'll use the character こういち. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Like this: You see some construction in front of you. There, standing shirtless (only suspenders and a hard hat) is こういち, looking back at you. If こういち as a construction worker somehow doesn't make your legs tremble, that's okay. Just make sure you take this story to a ridiculous enough level to construct a memory in that brain of yours. Be mad at him for not following construction site regulations — where's his shirt, shoes, and pants, and why is he using the bulldozer like that?! Alternatively, say you really like what you see (you're going to have to imagine a much better-looking version of こういち's face, though). You and こういち make eye contact a little too long. He nods, puts his cigarette out, and takes off his hard hat, letting his long Fabio-esque locks flow. You beckon him over and he comes. What happens next is up to you and your own imagination. My guess is you have a very deep conversation about kanji and the best ways to learn it. Anyway, when you see 工 in a kanji, it will often take the こう reading. Make sure to remember that, because it comes up quite a bit!

mnemonics.meaning: Eight This isn't exactly the same as the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Eight</mark> fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each. Count the fins out in front of you, all the way from one to eight. It'll help if you actually do this. Now smell each fin, and think "Wow, I have to smell all eight of these?" Yes, you do.
mnemonics.reading: はち や, よう None After you count and smell all eight of your fins, it's time to put them away. You open a large hatch (はち) and put them in. This is where you keep your fins, always putting in eight at a time because that's what the boss wants. You've asked him why you can only put eight fins at a time in the hatch, but he never wants to answer. What could be down in the hole that the hatch covers? Why is there a hatch at all? What's with numbers and hatches being mysterious?

mnemonics.meaning: Enter The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enter</mark> as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: にゅう はい, い None Turns out, after you enter the tent (remember how the person in the radical is entering one?), you're given a new (にゅう) one! Why? No idea, but hey — it's new! Imagine lights turning on and flashing, and an entire audience inside. You're at a game show, and the announcer announces the neeeeew tent in his announcey voice. Feel the surprise. Feel the happiness. Feel the excitement. A beautiful new tent all for you!

mnemonics.meaning: Mountain The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mountain</mark> kanji are the same. Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you are, then you're studying your kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: さん やま None Think about mountains talking to each other, calling each other by their names and adding the Japanese name-ender san (さん) to each of their names. "Hello, Everest-san." "Oh hi, Fuji-san." Be sure to imagine this vividly. The more absurdly you can imagine it, the more likely you are to remember the reading, san.

mnemonics.meaning: Mouth The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mouth</mark> kanji are exactly the same! If you learned your radicals — which the WaniKani system forces you to do (unless you're cheating) — you'll already know the meaning of the kanji.
mnemonics.reading: こう, く くち None Do you remember seeing the construction worker こういち earlier in the 工 mnemonic? If you haven't yet, not to worry! For kanji with こう readings (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character こういち every time. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways, remember that whenever you see こう, think こういち. Everyone agrees, the mouth is こういち's best feature. You stare at it lovingly as he whispers sweet kanji readings to you. You just can't forget all the cool things about kanji learning he said from that mouth. What a great mouth こういち has. How are the lips of his mouth both so skinny and fat at the same time?

mnemonics.meaning: Nine Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> and the kanji is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nine</mark>, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first. If you know your radicals well, this kanji will be a breeze!
mnemonics.reading: く, きゅう ここの None Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn, the pronunciations of those two on'yomi are very similar, so that should make them easier to remember. When you were nine your favorite foods were cookies (く) and cucumbers (きゅう). Yum yum! Picture nine-year-old you, lining up nine cookies and nine cucumbers. You dip a cookie in milk and bite into it, then dip a cucumber in and take a bite. Nine bites each until they're all gone. Ah, you miss being nine.

mnemonics.meaning: One Lying on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is something that looks just like the ground, the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">One</mark>. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live. To remember the meaning of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">One</mark>, imagine yourself there at the scene of the crime. You grab <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">One</mark> in your arms, trying to prop it up, trying to hear its last words. Instead, it just splatters some blood on your face. "Who did this to you?" you ask. The number One points weakly, and you see number Two running off into an alleyway. He's always been jealous of number One and knows he can be number one now that he's taken the real number one out.
mnemonics.reading: いち, いつ ひと かず As you're sitting there next to One, holding him up, you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely itchy (いち). Make sure you feel the ridiculously itchy sensation covering your body. It climbs from your hands, where you're holding the number One up, and then goes through your arms, crawls up your neck, goes down your body, and then covers everything. It becomes uncontrollable, and you're scratching everywhere, writhing on the ground. It's so itchy that it's the most painful thing you've ever experienced (you should imagine this vividly, so you remember the reading of this kanji).

mnemonics.meaning: Person Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> because it looks like a person with their arms down and their legs spread out? Well this is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">person</mark> too! Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.
mnemonics.reading: にん, じん ひと, と None Only one person at Nintendo (にん) complained about the new jeans (じん) policy, and that person was you. Imagine how angry you were about the policy. You'll have to come up with something to be angry about yourself (pick something that would actually make you angry, like maybe you're only allowed to wear cut off short-shorts jeans at Nintendo now), but if you pick something good, you'll definitely remember the two readings for this. Just remember you're working at Nintendo, and the policy has to be something about jeans. Then, imagine yourself as the only person complaining and everyone else in their dumb jeans (or lack-thereof) shaking their head at you because you're being a fool.

mnemonics.meaning: Power Strength, Ability The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">power</mark>. If you know the radical, you should be feeling fine… No, you should feel powerful!
mnemonics.reading: りょく, りき ちから None Who has the most power of anyone? It's the Power Rangers. They are battling their arch enemy Ricky (りき). They defeat him and lock (りょく) him up, so that he can't hurt anyone ever again. Know anyone named Ricky (りき), even a famous person like Ricky Ricardo or Ricky Gervais? Imagine that person's face on the monster the Power Rangers are fighting. Now, imagine the Power Rangers locking (りょく) him up. He looks much less scary once he's locked up. Phew.

mnemonics.meaning: River The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">river</mark> kanji are the same as each other! So, if you know the radical you know the kanji as well.
mnemonics.reading: せん かわ None You're standing next to a river that's actually used as a car wash (かわ). Imagine standing by the river, watching all those cars floating by. They start off really dirty, but the river washes them all clean.

mnemonics.meaning: Seven Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seven</mark>. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well. Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!
mnemonics.reading: しち なな, なの None You know this kanji means seven, so let's use that to remember the reading too. Seven is a lucky number, usually, but this time it isn't so good: Seven percent is all she got on her test after she cheated (しち) on it. How unbelievable is it that someone got seven percent on a test, especially if you try to cheat? Imagine the girl you loathe the most from school, and imagine her cheating on the test (it's important it's a girl, because of the "she" part in she cheated (しち). Then, imagine your happiness when she's super upset about getting seven percent on it. Serves her right, obviously.

mnemonics.meaning: Ten This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is the symbol for the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten</mark>. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens. If you're familiar with Christianity, they have a cross and ten commandments. Cross = ten, you see?
mnemonics.reading: じゅう とお None This cross in particular has ten jewels (じゅう) on it. Two on each arm and two in the middle. That's ten jewels! Picture the jewels on this cross. Maybe draw it out on a piece of paper so the visual really sticks. Each cross is really a symbol for different sets of ten things, and in this case, it's ten jewels.

mnemonics.meaning: Three This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> together and what do you get? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Three</mark>! This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three!
mnemonics.reading: さん み None Three is the number of chances you get with Santa-san (さん). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list. Picture Santa-san sitting at his desk at the North Pole, eating cookies, and marking one, two, then finally three lines next to names. Once the third line appears, the kid doesn't get presents anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Two The kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">two</mark> and the radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already! More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of one. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!
mnemonics.reading: に ふた None How do you count to two? Just use someone's knee (に), and then their other knee. There — two knees! Imagine asking to borrow the two knees of a stranger in the street, just so you can count to two. They're confused at first, but then they present each knee to you in a loving sort of way. Yep, that's two knees alright.

mnemonics.meaning: Woman The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">woman</mark> are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.
mnemonics.reading: じょ, にょ, にょう おんな, め None When you think of a woman, think of Jo-Anne (じょ), though she usually goes by just "Jo." Whenever the reading じょ comes up, we will use the character Jo-Anne. She's quite a short woman, which is to help us differentiate じょ from じょう (who is the giant, oafish farmhand Joe). じょ is a smaller lady, じょう is a giant man.

mnemonics.meaning: Ball The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> has a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ball</mark>. This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ball</mark>, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ball</mark>) over and over again. Kanji are surprisingly playful like that.
mnemonics.reading: ぎょく たま None When he's done playing with it, the king gives his ball to Tamara (たま), the resident ball girl, for safekeeping. Try to remember Tamara the ball girl. She'll come up anytime the reading for a kanji is たま, and usually she'll be involved with some kind of ball or round object. That's her job, after all.

mnemonics.meaning: Book Origin, Real, Main The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">book</mark> as well. Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">origin</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">real</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">main</mark>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life. Make sure you know those radicals, yo! And good luck with all the meanings (sorry sorry sorry).
mnemonics.reading: ほん もと None Books are one of the best ways to hone (ほん) your intellect, you know? Just think about books and how you use them to hone your skills. Or read a book about honing things. Like swords.

mnemonics.meaning: Child Kid The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">child</mark> kanji are exactly the same. So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!
mnemonics.reading: し, す こ None The main reading here is し, so to remember it we'll use this mnemonic: There is a child standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again, there is a sheep (し) in front of you. A sheep?! You yelp, blink again, and it's back to being a child. Are… are all children really just sheep? The child (sheep) runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep again, but whenever you yell and point, it changes back into a child. You're the only one who can see this sheep child!

mnemonics.meaning: Circle Circular, Round What's something with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> sides? Just add a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> and you'll have something that's almost a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circle</mark>. It's not quite a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circle</mark> though. You just need to add a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.
mnemonics.reading: がん まる None Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while. When you think about a circle, think about Maru all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it. Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with his little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to "Maru." Obviously if you "don't know this reading" well enough, you should watch some more Maru videos. I'll understand... just make sure you come back someday, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: Correct There is a line on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, making a giant sign pop up that says <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">CORRECT</mark>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you. Imagine walking, staring at the ground until you come across a line that you're supposed to stop at. If you stop, the big "correct" sign appears, chiming a happy tune.
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう ただ, まさ None You did the correct thing, so here's your reward: a saber (せい) from the Shougun (しょう) himself! Perhaps a slightly unorthodox weapon for a ruler of medieval Japan, but you won't complain about a saber from the Shogun himself!

mnemonics.meaning: Dirt Earth, Ground The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dirt</mark> kanji are the same! As long as you know the radical dirt, you know the kanji dirt.
mnemonics.reading: ど, と つち None Who spends a lot of time in dirt? Dogs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great). Dogs and dirt just go together!

mnemonics.meaning: Dog The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dog</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.
mnemonics.reading: けん いぬ None Every dog likes to eat noodles (いぬ). Like that movie where the dogs share a noodle and end up kissing, right? So when you see 犬, just imagine how those two eat noodles. P.S. Don't actually let your dog eat noodles, at least not with marinara sauce. Disney didn't show you how that Lady and Tramp date probably ended — unromantically, with indigestion.

mnemonics.meaning: Evening The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evening</mark> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji. Do what you're meant to do. Study those radicals!
mnemonics.reading: None ゆう None The evening is when all the youths (ゆう) come outside to play. Young people love staying up the entire evening doing youth-people things, and it's really obnoxious for us curmudgeonly folk. Note: All the ゆう readings will use the word "youths" as a keyword for the mnemonic, so bear that in mind for any future ゆう reading you'll encounter.

mnemonics.meaning: Exit There are two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountains</mark> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exit</mark> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it. In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of "needing to get out of the mountain pass." If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: しゅつ で, だ None As you're trying to exit this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he shoots you (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down. Focus on the surprise of realizing you're being hunted while trying to find the exit to the mountain range, then focus on the next part, where you get shot. View it in your head as the hunter shooting you. Powww!

mnemonics.meaning: Eye The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eye</mark> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both. Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study their radicals.
mnemonics.reading: もく め None Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "Mehhhhhh (め)!" Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making "MEHHH" noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.

mnemonics.meaning: Fire The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fire</mark> kanji are the same as each other. If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.
mnemonics.reading: か ひ, ほ None Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word car. For this kanji, when we think fire, we ought to think of something on fire. What's on fire? It's obviously your very own car (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO! Oh no... Oh no!! If you don't have a car, imagine what it'd feel like if your car just exploded and burned down. If you do have a car, imagine your own car in this situation. It should be a terrible feeling, if you imagine it well enough. So, when you think fire, remember the fear you had when your car was given to the flames. Now you have to walk everywhere, sad :(

mnemonics.meaning: Five The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">five</mark> kanji are the same. Know your radicals, friend-o.
mnemonics.reading: ご いつ None Five is the number of buildings Godzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now. One, two, three, four, five—GODZILLA IS HERE GO GO, RUN!

mnemonics.meaning: Four Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> now has your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> inside it. You've bent your body in all the wrong ways to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">four</mark> sides. If you can see this kanji as a kind of square, you should be able to remember it means "four" as well, since squares always have four sides.
mnemonics.reading: し よん, よ None Now that you have four sides, you look like a four-sided animal: the sheep (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. Imagine yourself with perfectly square wool. (You can only see four sides because mirrors aren't 3D. So you're a flat, cartoonish sheep.) What's better than a four-sided sheep?

mnemonics.meaning: Hand Doer The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hand</mark> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy! Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!
mnemonics.reading: しゅ, ず て None To remember the reading て we will use the word "television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little televisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time. You try to shake your hands off, but it's no good. The televisions are stuck, and the volume won't go down. You have no idea how you got these televisions on your hands. All you know is that you want them off right this instant.

mnemonics.meaning: Heaven The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> is the same as the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heaven</mark>, making this an easy kanji to memorize. If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!
mnemonics.reading: てん あま None Heaven... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only ten (てん) percent! Imagine yourself in line to get into heaven. You're super worried, because you're not sure if you'll get in. You heard there was a one in ten chance... those aren't good odds. Feel nervous in your imagination. Feel worried. Feel the pressure as you get closer and closer to the gate... will you make it?? Ten percent!

mnemonics.meaning: King The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">king</mark> kanji are the same! Hopefully you're a king of radicals... because if you are, this kanji was super easy for you!
mnemonics.reading: おう None None When you see the king you need to say, "Oh (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!" You need to be polite when you talk to the king and add "Oh" to the beginning, otherwise the king will be pretty angry and bad things might happen. We're going to use the 王 kanji for all おう mnemonics from now on. So make sure you always remember to say おう King!

mnemonics.meaning: Left <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Narwhal</mark>s do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> with their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">left</mark> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed! Picture a bunch of narwhals constructing an underwater ice village. They're all working away with their left hands.
mnemonics.reading: さ ひだり None In their left hands, the narwhals all hold saws (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple. If you're right-handed, imagine trying to use these left-handed saws. It flips and flops all over until you drop it. But if you're left-handed it feels just right!

mnemonics.meaning: Middle In, Inside, Center The radical <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">middle</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">middle</mark> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other. Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう なか None To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory. If you remember back to the radical 中, a stick was stuck in the middle of the mouth of something. Let's say it was your mouth, and when you look up to see who did it, there stands Chewbacca. He's even doing his Chewbacca yell. And it isn't a stick in your mouth, it's an arrow from his bowcaster. It just so happens Chewbacca's bowcaster looks just like this kanji too. Go figure. Imagine the fear and shock you'd feel after finding out it was Chewbacca who shot the middle of your mouth (and head). Touch his fur. Look really close at his weapon. Give him a sniff, too. Just so that memory never fades away.

mnemonics.meaning: Moon Month The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">moon</mark> kanji is made up of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">month</mark>. This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!
mnemonics.reading: げつ, がつ つき None The moon really gets (げつ) to your guts (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful! Use the げつ reading when this kanji means "moon", in words like "moonlight". Use げつ for counting months, and saying things like "last month and "next month", too. Go for がつ in the names of months, like "January". Don't worry too much about memorizing this pattern, though. You'll be getting lots of practice soon!

mnemonics.meaning: Repeater Repetition, Reduplication, Iteration Mark This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it. To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a prison with drops of water dripping over and over in it. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over. Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function, try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it.
mnemonics.reading: None のま None This symbol doesn't really have a name, but it's sometimes called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way: Your mom is the repeater. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling "No ma (のま)!" but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever. If you feel like you're so full you're about to burst, and if you imagine your mom doing this to you (how could you, ma?), you should be able to remember the reading of this kanji. That being said, the reading is mostly only useful in the event that you have to identify a 々 — otherwise, you won't see it much.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice Paddy Rice Field The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice paddy</mark> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise. Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.
mnemonics.reading: でん た None To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco." You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little tacos (た), blossoming out of the ground. Smell the tacos. Touch the tacos. Taste the tacos. This is definitely a very strange rice field.

mnemonics.meaning: Right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s are on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">right</mark> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake. See how the "mouth" radical is to the right of the "narwhal" radical? That should help you remember that this means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">right</mark>. Imagine looking at a narwhal from the front. No mouth. Now look at it from the right. Mouth!
mnemonics.reading: ゆう, う みぎ None How did we know to look from the right, though? Because the youths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side. Imagine a bunch of youths walking in a group and looking at everything from the right. You remember when you were a youth and you used to look at everything from one side too. Note: All the ゆう readings will use the word "youths" for the reading mnemonic. You can think of these "youths" as a group of younger people who cause a lot of the problems in this world.

mnemonics.meaning: Six Just imagine a beast with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> for a head and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">six</mark> is the devil's number. Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">six</mark>), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: ろく む None Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word rock. So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, rock (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem. Sing along with the monster, if it helps you to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Small Little The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small</mark> kanji are exactly the same. Knowing radicals sure is nice, huh?
mnemonics.reading: しょう ちい, こ, お None This small kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the little kanji represents all of that. You read that right, shougun is written with a long う sound. Make sure you spell it right from now on!

mnemonics.meaning: Stand The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stand</mark> are the same thing, so now you know them both. If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!
mnemonics.reading: りつ, りゅう た None Think of someone who has to stand up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the Ritz (りつ). Imagine the doormen being extra straight… too straight in their standing. On their uniform is “The Ritz” written in fine lettering, and as you walk past them, they stand up straight and say “Welcome to the Ritz!” Whatever you do, while you’re thinking about it, make sure you think about how they stand up so straight, and associate it with these doormen, who work, specifically, at the Ritz. If you effectively imagine all this, you should be able to remember this on’yomi. Go through it like it’s a movie in your head!

mnemonics.meaning: Street The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">street</mark>. As long as you know the radical street, you know the kanji street.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう, てい None None So you're walking down this street, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. Chou (ちょう). Mrs. Chou is a character you'll see a lot throughout WaniKani, anytime the reading is ちょう like this one. A lore will develop around her, so the more vividly you can imagine your Mrs. Chou right now, the easier things will get later. In general, she's a mean, evil woman, so as long as you imagine her within those parameters, you're good. And, when I say she is a "street-woman" in the mnemonic, I don't mean she is homeless. She has a nice, middle-class home that's not outside of her financial means. What I'm saying is she wanders the streets looking for evil things to do. These are HER streets. So whenever you see the street radical, know that Mrs. Chou is probably going to show up!

mnemonics.meaning: Sun Day The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sun</mark> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">day</mark> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky. The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
mnemonics.reading: にち, じつ ひ, か, び None There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. The sun is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich Nietzsche (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid. This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth. Also note that there's another reading worth learning as well: じつ. The reading can be remembered by thinking "Gee! Two readings?" Because, seriously, two readings? Too many...

mnemonics.meaning: Sword Katana The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well. This kanji also looks a lot like the kanji 力. To avoid getting them confused, remember that this one is missing the little nubbin at the top, because 90% of the power comes from the sword to cut your enemies down (which is why the sword kanji is 90% of the power kanji).
mnemonics.reading: とう かたな None So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to とうきょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう. Imagine trying to travel to とうきょう with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. I hope you don't have any other swords hidden anywhere.

mnemonics.meaning: Talent On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> you put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>s at the bottom of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. This is your special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talent</mark>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent. Imagine yourself placing the barbs in front of the slide, thinking about how talented you are. It took years of training to perfect this talent. But it was worth it. Everyone on the playground respects you now.
mnemonics.reading: さい None None But then people start to say that no human could have so much talent, that you must be a cyborg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg? Cyborgs have brain implants and cool bionic limbs, so they're basically the most talented people around.

mnemonics.meaning: Thousand This kanji is the same as the radical you learned, so it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thousand</mark>. As long as you know the "thousand" radical, you'll know this kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: せん ち None Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a thousand cents (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually. Problem is, as they all tumble down the slide the change falls out of their pockets, so there's a thousand times a thousand cents scattered all over on the floor under the slide.

mnemonics.meaning: Tree Wood This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tree</mark> are the same in looks and meaning. So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?
mnemonics.reading: もく, ぼく き, こ None You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to mock (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground. Feel the shame, feel the irritation. Make yourself want to run away from those dumb trees that are mocking you.

mnemonics.meaning: Water The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">water</mark> kanji are the same. So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.
mnemonics.reading: すい みず None Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of water). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire swing (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very sweet. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is). I know that was a long one, but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold, smell, etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with すい (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part, the more vividly you imagined it, the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi.

mnemonics.meaning: White The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">white</mark> are the same. Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!
mnemonics.reading: はく しろ, しら None The white team was the first to be able to hack (はく) the white iPhone. Imagine two teams (black and white), wearing their team colors, working really hard on hacking the iPhone. It is a huge contest, and people are watching with a lot of tension, to see who will hack the white iPhone first. Feel that tension, and see the colors separating them so vividly. The colors are important, and the excitement of the winner holding up the hacked iPhone is too.

mnemonics.meaning: Writing Sentence The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">writing</mark> as well. If you can't remember the radical for writing, maybe you could try… writing it down?
mnemonics.reading: ぶん, もん ふみ None This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you: You always put writing on your buns (ぶん) to keep them from getting eaten by the bun monster (もん). What kind of writing? Usually it's just an X to show the monster these buns are off-limits. (In fact, it kind of looks like the X part in 文. Hmm…) Imagine writing a big X (or even a big 文) on all your buns, then showing them to the bun monster. Watch as he turns and goes at the sight of the writing, all disappointed. Not today, bun monster.

mnemonics.meaning: Yen Round, Circle Here we have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> in it, near the top. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yen</mark> coins, the currency of Japan. Jackpot! And all those yen coins have a nice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">round</mark> shape, naturally. This kanji can mean both "yen" and "round"! It's OK if you can't remember both meanings. But it might help to think about how round the yen coins are inside this person's head, which can also be pretty round…
mnemonics.reading: えん まる None What does the word yen sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん! Picture these round えん in your mind. Maybe look some up online too, just to be safe. See how round those yen (えん) are?

mnemonics.meaning: Arrow The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrow</mark> kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know? Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!
mnemonics.reading: し や None To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!). What is this arrow doing? It’s following around all the Yankee (や) baseball players, stalking them, waiting to make its move (I’ll let you decide what its “move” is). Imagine the arrow as a human-sized living thing with legs, arms, and clothes, though. Strangely, it’s able to walk around even though it's an arrow. It has some kind of agenda. Make it a bit evil, if you can. What a strange thing…

mnemonics.meaning: Bright The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bright</mark> kanji are the same! If you already know the radical, this one's a freebie. That should make your day a little brighter, hm?
mnemonics.reading: めい, みょう あ, あか, あき None What do you say when you see something bright? "Ah (あ)!" Like when you open the curtain and the sunshine hits your eyes, or someone shines a flashlight right into your face. Ahhhh, so bright! You might also say "Ah!" when you come up with a bright idea, like in those light bulb moments.

mnemonics.meaning: City You see a manhole <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, both with the name of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">city</mark> on them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan. Picture this towel with the name of a city on it. Any city you like. Maybe it's your city!
mnemonics.reading: し いち None This city must have a lot of sheep (し) because, besides the manhole lid and the towel, all you can see are sheep. There are sheep everywhere. It's a sheep city. Imagine a city that has a sheep everywhere you look, as far as the eye can see. This city was built on sheep, don't you say a bad word about sheep when you're there.

mnemonics.meaning: Cow The radical and the kanji for cow are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough. To distinguish this from the "noon" kanji (午), try thinking of the bit poking out of the top of this kanji as a tuft of hair on the cow's head — a cow lick, if you like.
mnemonics.reading: ぎゅう うし None Have you ever heard of わぎゅう (wagyu) beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう. I hope you know what わぎゅう beef is, otherwise this will be a difficult one to learn.

mnemonics.meaning: Cut If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">swords</mark>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cut</mark> something. Take these seven swords and swing them around. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Cut</mark> everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.
mnemonics.reading: せつ き None Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You cut them into pairs, and give sets (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village. Just make sure you think about how you need to give them away in sets, and not anything else. This is the most important thing to think about in your head as you're trying to establish the mnemonic for your kanji reading memory. It's gotta be sets.

mnemonics.meaning: Direction Way The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">direction</mark> are the same! Huzzah! There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">way</mark> as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. "The way of [your name here]." The only direction you need to go in is forward, it's always the right way.
mnemonics.reading: ほう かた None What direction do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? Home (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home! Close your eyes and picture your home in your mind. Can you tell which direction it is from where you are?

mnemonics.meaning: Door The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">door</mark> are the same! Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.
mnemonics.reading: こ と None You open the door and immediately get it closed back on your toe (と), literally causing your toe to explode. Feel the pain of your toe going away. Think about the other side of the door, where your toe is probably rolling around after it blasted off your foot.

mnemonics.meaning: Fat The kanji is the same as the radical, so this means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark>. We've fattened you up with lots of juicy radical knowledge, so this one should be pretty easy.
mnemonics.reading: たい, た ふと おお Imagine a fat person who loves to sleep on futon (ふと). Picture this fat person curled up all cozy-like on their Japanese futon. They look so content! Have you ever slept on a proper Japanese futon, by the way? We're talking premium, cloud-grade comfort — luxurious enough to make you feel like a real fat cat.

mnemonics.meaning: Father Dad The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">father</mark> are the same. No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!
mnemonics.reading: ふ ちち, とう None Imagine your father is Cheech (ちち) from Cheech and Chong. Hopefully you know who they are. If not, think about your father laughing like this: ちちちちちちちち〜！

mnemonics.meaning: Few A Little You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that few people can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down. Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?). So few people can use this thing, really, but there are a few little ones who can fit on it at least.
mnemonics.reading: しょう すこ, すく None Another reason so few people can use it is that the Shogun (しょう) is trying to go down the slide. We're talking a grown man who's way too big for this little slide, so a few people have to wait behind him — it's a slide traffic jam. Imagine this in your head. Even the few people who fit on the slide are struggling to get past the Shogun. Meanwhile the Japanese secret service is trying to make sure no one gets close to the shogun while he slides. A few people are crying. They want to slide, they want to leave… It's chaos.

mnemonics.meaning: Friend A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">friend</mark>. Imagine that narwhal sitting there. It waves its flipper and says "hi friend" to you.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう とも None "Hi friend," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the youths." (ゆう) Your narwhal friend goes on to warn you about all those youths, and how they will try to take away your friendship with their good looks and young ages.

mnemonics.meaning: Fur Hair <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Fur</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fur</mark> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hair</mark>, too, though more like furry hair. Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.
mnemonics.reading: もう け None With fur, whisk your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it's fur). You're surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel and smell like? Now it's time to get rid of it. There's just too much hair! To get rid of it, you'll need to mow (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they're loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think "fur → in the fur → get rid of the fur → mow the fur," in that order. That'll get you to "mow," which will help you to remember the on’yomi. Smell the fur as you mow it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.

mnemonics.meaning: Half A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> is lying out to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>. But it's so big, and it's lying on its side, so only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">half</mark> of it gets dry. Imagine the triceratops on its side, then imagine it getting up. When it stands up normally, half of its body is soaking wet still. It's a half-n-half triceratops right now.
mnemonics.reading: はん なか None "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in half with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is Han Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even. Imagine him using his blaster to shoot the poor triceratops in half, perfectly down the wet-dry line of its body.

mnemonics.meaning: Heart The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heart</mark> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free! Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: しん こころ None The heart, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your heart is stored in your shin (しん). This is when I start kicking you in the shin and you imagine feeling the pain of getting kicked there. As I kick you in the shin, the stress is getting too much for your poor heart inside your shin. Poor shin, and poor heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside Within Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inside</mark> it! And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inside</mark> for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inside</mark> there, doing evil things.
mnemonics.reading: ない うち None You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that's inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a knife (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational. Imagine him holding the knife out, threatening to stab your brain. You’re in a conundrum here. If you don’t take him out, you’re in trouble, but if you do try to take him out, he might stab you in the brain with his knife. Try to think a way around this situation, focusing mainly on his knife.

mnemonics.meaning: Letter Character, Symbol The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> stands upon the roof, holding up a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">letter</mark>, a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">character</mark>, a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">symbol</mark> for the world to see. More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.
mnemonics.reading: じ None None The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol. Imagine the child holding up the letter yelling at everyone who passes that the "J" stands for "Jesus." And yes, this kid just loves the Big Lebowski.

mnemonics.meaning: Life The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">life</mark> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both. Study your radicals and you'll read good.
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう い, なま, う, は, き None You can save life or take it away with your new saber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do? Imagine having someone's life in the palm of your hands. It's up to you whether you protect it with your saber or... well... do the other thing sabers are for.

mnemonics.meaning: Machine You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">machine</mark>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you. Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?
mnemonics.reading: だい, たい None None To make sure they can't tell what's machine and what's human, you dye (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there. Imagine being so afraid that people will find out about your machine mouth that you have to dye it to match a normal human mouth. Oh, when will this discrimination against machine-kind end?!

mnemonics.meaning: Mother Mom Someone breaks part of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>. Who did this? It was your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mother</mark>! See how the vertical bar is broken and your window frame is all messed up now? Why would your mother do such a thing?! Her hand is bleeding too…
mnemonics.reading: ぼ はは, かあ None Suddenly your mother points her bloodied finger at you and laughs, "Haha (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You feel even more alarmed. You thought your mother was going to explain or apologize, but instead she's pointing and saying, "Haha," over and over. Yeah. That sounds like my mom.

mnemonics.meaning: Noon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noon</mark>. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide. Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.
mnemonics.reading: ご None None Noon also happens to be the time Godzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide. Watch in horror as Godzilla's giant foot crushes all the kids and their slide at exactly noon. You'd better go...

mnemonics.meaning: North The kanji is the same as the radical — it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">north</mark>. Hold on to that radical knowledge! It'll be the north star that guides you through your studies.
mnemonics.reading: ほく きた None You go north, and notice that everyone has a keytar (きた). You know, those keyboards that people hold and play like a guitar? Yep, those things are called keytars. And for some reason, in the north, everyone has a keytar. They're basically obsessed with them. North = keytar. Quite simple.

mnemonics.meaning: Now The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">now</mark> as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: こん いま None Right now the condors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?! Go outside right now and do something to save the condors. If you don't do something right now there won't be enough time left!

mnemonics.meaning: Old The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">old</mark> as well. Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: こ ふる None Old things are misunderstood by the 子s (こ) of the world. *Note:* Come up with a 子 character you can use for all the こ reading mnemonics going forward. This child will show up many times throughout your mnemonic journey, and it will help if you imagine the same character the whole time. Imagine a 子 looking at old things. A record player. A Game Boy. A cassette player. Kids just don't get old things. Note: When you see the (古) radical in a kanji, there's a good chance it will use the reading こ.

mnemonics.meaning: Outside You're known to get the ailment <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">outside</mark>. After imagining your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> overheating, rush <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">outside</mark> to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.
mnemonics.reading: がい そと, はず None You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him! If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.

mnemonics.meaning: Part Minute, Divide The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> that fell onto my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> were sliced into many <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">part</mark>s. Following this logic, this also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">minute</mark>, which is part of an hour, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>, which is the action of splitting something into many parts. Picture the fins falling onto the sword, and being divided into many parts. And if those fins represented hours, they’d be divided into minutes. Makes sense, right?
mnemonics.reading: ぶん, ふん, ぶ わ None Now that the fins have been cut into neat parts, it's time to cut something else: buns (ぶん). This is how you feed your people: neatly divided, delicious buns. Picture these delicious buns divided into perfectly shaped parts. Yummy.

mnemonics.meaning: Pull If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull</mark> the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything. Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!
mnemonics.reading: いん ひ None When you pull the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense heat (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter. Imagine using all your strength to pull on this bow. Imagine the heat rising in your body. There's sweat dripping down your face. It's so hot, but you have to keep pulling!

mnemonics.meaning: Stop The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> radical is the same as the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stop</mark> kanji. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: し と, や None You have to stop because there is a sheep (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too. Imagine the fluffy wool of the sheep, stopping you from moving forward. You can't push past it, no matter how hard you try.

mnemonics.meaning: Task Use The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">task</mark> as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: よう もち None Today, your task is to eat yogurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is. Eat your yogurt. (Gogurt doesn't count, don't @ me.)

mnemonics.meaning: Ten Thousand You cut the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten thousand</mark> pieces! If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.
mnemonics.reading: まん, ばん None None Now that you have ten thousand pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a manga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel. Carefully draw your manga onto these ten thousand leaf pieces. Maybe you even use your sword again to give them some textured details. You're so creative and talented!

mnemonics.meaning: Wide The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> you use in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wide</mark>. You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!
mnemonics.reading: こう ひろ None You like being wide because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super hero (ひろ)! Picture yourself lying under your wide, private canopy pretending to be a super hero on the ground. You're stretching a nice, wide super hero pose, like you're flying through the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Winter You’ve got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> with lots of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark>. But doesn't any winter have lots of ice? Exactly. That's why this is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">winter</mark>. You go outside. There's ice everywhere. It's freezing cold. Yep, this is definitely winter.
mnemonics.reading: とう ふゆ None Winter is also the time of year you give out presents: "One fu' you, one fu' you and… one fu' you (ふゆ)!" Your pronunciation might be a little weird. But that’s okay. People still love your presents, and the way you say "fu’ you!"

mnemonics.meaning: Bamboo The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bamboo</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Just make sure you know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: ちく たけ None Today is free bamboo day, so just take (たけ) all the bamboo you want. Really take as much bamboo as you could possibly hold. Take some bamboo, then take some more, and take more… It’s free after all.

mnemonics.meaning: Car The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">car</mark> are exactly the same. Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ くるま None When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman". There's a car. It's the nicest car you've ever seen. Exquisite, beautiful. Wouldn't you be surprised to learn it belongs to a shaman (しゃ)? Well it does. This shaman charges a premium for his shaman services so he can afford fancy cars like this. The more fantastic you make this car, the better. Also, feel the surprise of a shaman getting out of this car. What a cool dude that shaman is.

mnemonics.meaning: Center The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">center</mark> are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.
mnemonics.reading: おう None None Remember that guy from the 央 radical fastening his belt across the center of his body? This guy always secures his belt at the center — not slightly to the left, not slightly to the right, but dead center. His precision is so mind-blowing that everyone watching can't help but say, "Ohh!"(おう). Next time you put a belt on, make sure it's in the exact center of your body. Heck, try it now. And don't forget to say "Ohh!" as you do it. It'll keep the reading for this kanji front and center in your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: Copy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> is on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. Except it's not exactly the ground, it's a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">copy</mark> machine, and he's making copies of his forehead! Picture how ridiculous this beggar looks, taking copies of his forehead with the ground copy machine.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ うつ None This ground copy machine can only be the work of one person: a shaman (しゃ)! This particular shaman's specialty is being able to turn any surface into a copy machine at a swirl of his little shaman wand. Picture him running around in circles, doing a little dance and chant, and then the ground suddenly turning into one giant copy machine.

mnemonics.meaning: Doing Do The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">doing</mark>. Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.
mnemonics.reading: し つか None He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader. Picture the leader samurai doing lots of sheep things. He's shearing sheep. He's feeding sheep. He's doing everything you could possibly do, because he's the sheep samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: Ear Ears The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ear</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning. Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: じ みみ None Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear. This is sort of a stereotypical singer sort of image. Make sure you concentrate a lot when you're listening to your mimimimiiii tone. In fact, why don't you do it out loud right now - make a little fool of yourself. It's fun, and it'll help you to remember!

mnemonics.meaning: Early Fast, Quick When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> it's time to go to church... which is so darn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">early</mark>.
