And if you want to get to church early, you need to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fast</mark>, otherwise you'll be too late. Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.
mnemonics.reading: そう はや, さ None To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul." When you're forced to get up fast and early you can feel it in your soul (そう). You're so tired and it's so early, your soul cries out, "Please don't make me go this fast this early. I'm gonna leave your body if you keep this up!" But you get your soul up early and head to the church fast anyway, because you're doing all of this for your soul in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: Energy Spirit These days <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">energy</mark> is the greatest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine finding some in a literal treasure chest. As soon as you open it, out bursts the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">energy</mark> in a kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark> ball. Touch the energy, catch the spirit ball. Is it solid or gaseous? Does it tingle or burn? Try to imagine it out. Then, yes, go ahead and sell that valuable energy treasure to a power company or something.
mnemonics.reading: き, け None None As you reach inside the energy spirit ball, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure. You take the key and open another treasure that's nearby. Open it up and see what's inside. Imagine something spectacular. Thanks, energy key.

mnemonics.meaning: Flat Peace If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> you need to lay them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flat</mark>. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>. Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.
mnemonics.reading: へい, ひょう, びょう たい, ひら None Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it. Imagine carefully laying a flat layer of hay on top of your flat horns. You feel really at peace and... you're tired now. You decided to lie on top of the hay and take a nap while you wait for your horns to dry.

mnemonics.meaning: Flower All these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> were planted by your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>. Now the whole place is absolutely full with beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower</mark>s. Flowers everywhere. Your leader is a nice guy who wants there to be flowers for even future generations to enjoy. That’s why he’s painstakingly planting all these flowers with his spoon. Imagine watching him dig hole after hole with his little spoon just to plant some flowers for everyone.
mnemonics.reading: か, け はな None But for some reason, the leader just can't stop planting flowers... He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? Now there’s only one person that can save him: Hannah (はな). Hannah is the most reliable person you know. Whenever someone’s in any trouble, Hannah shows up and sets things right. Everyone needs a person like Hannah in their life. Especially the leader…

mnemonics.meaning: Foot Leg, Sufficient The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foot</mark> are exactly the same. That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sufficient</mark>. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you hop. Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.
mnemonics.reading: そく あし, た None What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく). Just think about your bare feet. Think about them too much. Feel how cold it is on your feet. Now, put on a sock to make it feel better. Ahhh, so nice!

mnemonics.meaning: Hit Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hit</mark> some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting! Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!
mnemonics.reading: だ う, ぶ None As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you. Now imagine your dad saying, "Don't do a hit!" over and over at you. "I'm sorry dad! But the streets were calling me!"

mnemonics.meaning: Hole Cave The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
mnemonics.reading: けつ あな None Ana (あな) fell into a hole. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy! Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.

mnemonics.meaning: Hundred There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> growing out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hundred</mark>! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth. Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!
mnemonics.reading: ひゃく もも None You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention. Imagine hearing Goofy guh-hyuck over and over after you save him from being stranded on the sun. How would you feel being stuck in a cramped ship with laughing Goofy and his hundred leaves? Oh, you thought he would leave those behind? Nope, they saved him so you have to take them back too. Happy travels!

mnemonics.meaning: Ice Add a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of something magical to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> and suddenly it turns into big block of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ice</mark>, just like that. Imagine yourself adding that drop. What is it exactly? Something pretty potent, that's for sure. Now go ahead and touch the block of ice... wow, it's really cold — and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ice</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう こおり None When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice. How did this happen? Was it your fault? Imagine the situation that would get Corey frozen like this.

mnemonics.meaning: Insect Bug The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insect</mark> are the same in looks as well as and meaning. It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう, き むし None It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound. Imagine little words that say "mush" flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a "mush" sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Man The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">man</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">man</mark> are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji too! Man, kanji are easy sometimes.
mnemonics.reading: だん, なん おとこ None When you think of a man, think of dawn (だん), because that man has to get up at dawn to power his rice paddy every day. Picture the man watching as the first light of dawn tints the sky pink and orange. Time to get to work, man!

mnemonics.meaning: Master Main The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">master</mark> have the same meanings! This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">main</mark> because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ おも, ぬし, あるじ None Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them. Picture this master of water controlling the droplet as it flies around inside these chutes, like he's solving a difficult puzzle with it. Astounding!

mnemonics.meaning: Name Famous What is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">famous</mark> that everybody knows his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">name</mark> (“Evening Mouth.”). Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">name</mark>!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">famous</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: めい, みょう な None So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up. You know what they say. April showers bring May Flowers. What do May Flowers bring? They bring “Evening Mouth,” baby.

mnemonics.meaning: Not The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">not</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">not</mark> are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not! Actually, it does make it easy — the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?
mnemonics.reading: ふ, ぶ None None To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool." Think of those jokes, where someone says something, then ends with a loud "NOTTTT!" Someone is doing that to you, over and over. What is that person? That person is a fool (ふ). Be sure to feel irritated at that person. Think in your head as they're telling these dumb "not" jokes how much of a fool they are... and how much of a fool you are for sitting here and listening to them.

mnemonics.meaning: Number There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number</mark>s that you don't understand. What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.
mnemonics.reading: ごう None None "You want to know the number to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa ごういち. Note: For the ごう reading mnemonics, we use Grandpa ごういち because こういち is used for the こう reading. So just remember that ごう comes from Koichi's grandpa ごういち. Grandpa ごういち keeps saying numbers as you free him from the prison. Just one after another. Numbers numbers numbers. Hopefully old man ごういち isn't crazy.

mnemonics.meaning: Origin The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">origin</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: げん, がん もと None The origin of everything can be found in Genji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji." Picture him as a rich, pretty boy who cares a ton about his looks and gets along really well with all the ladies. He's also really great at poetry, which helps the lady situation. Genji's origin story is pretty important when it comes to mnemonics and Japanese literature. He's going to keep popping up on your kanji journey, so make sure you remember him!

mnemonics.meaning: Other The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligators</mark>... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Other</mark> Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals. Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal. Then, off to the side are the leaders who are leaders of bears, cats, alligators, and narwhals... they're the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">other</mark> ones, no matter how you look at it. They are in their own group, and they are considered "others" because society won't accept them :(
mnemonics.reading: た ほか None To remember the reading た, we use the word "Taco" Then there's the others of the others. These are the taco (た) worshipers. They're really strange. Just imagine the "others" shaking their heads at these taco worshipers. Seriously, what the heck?

mnemonics.meaning: Past If someone tries to dig up <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> life, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">past</mark>. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past. Keep your private dirt in the past. It's better for everyone.
mnemonics.reading: きょ, こ さ None To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your past in Little Kyoto (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little 子 (こ) and you don't like to think about it. Imagine physically, literally burying your past 子 self. If you hide it in Little Kyoto, no one will ever be able to dig it up.

mnemonics.meaning: Plate Dish The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plate</mark> kanji and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china. If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.
mnemonics.reading: None さら None The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big). Imagine someone with a huge head, washing dishes. When I say huge, I mean huge. She turns towards you with her big head and says “Hi, I’m Sarah” and you see her name tag, which also says Sarah. She is Sarah, the dish washer. The plates she holds up next to her head pale in comparison, even though they're the biggest pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: Previous Ahead, Past, Former <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Slide</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> so you can feel like you're from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previous</mark> time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs. Imagine the feeling of dirt on your legs. Now think back to the previous day. The previous year. The previous century.
mnemonics.reading: せん さき, ま None As you sit there, pretending you're in a previous time you see a centaur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the past. Centaurs were definitely real in the past. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. They're just afraid of the truth.

mnemonics.meaning: Red The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">red</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">red</mark> are the same thing! What a lucky ducky — as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!
mnemonics.reading: せき あか None This kanji means red, AKA, also known as, あか. Think of あか as being some sort of alias for "red." That's why it's pronounced あか in Japanese, AKA "red."

mnemonics.meaning: Rest The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rest</mark>ing. The best thing to do with a tree is rest under it. Picture the leader resting under the tree with his eyes half closed.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう やす None As he rests, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a cucumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers. Don't email me saying cucumbers don't grow on trees. Cucumber trees exist. Look them up and then rest easy knowing I'd never lie to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Say Humbly There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">say humbly</mark>. Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. "Oh no, I'm not that good." "Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great."
mnemonics.reading: しん もう None As you're saying all these humble things, you're also mowing (もう) your neighbor's lawn. Your neighbors love you so much, because you're so humble, and you mow their lawn for them. Imagine mowing your neighbor's lawn while you say humbly how bad you are at mowing lawns. What a good neighbor you are.

mnemonics.meaning: See The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">see</mark> are exactly the same! Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!
mnemonics.reading: けん み None You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is me (み)!" The struggling to see bit is pretty important — make sure that you slowly see a little better and better as the person comes closer, but it's difficult the whole time (struggles are good for memory). Then, it starts to become more and more clear, and you start saying "that can't be me. No way it's me..." When the person comes up to you (the person, being you) you learn about parallel universes and other fabulous things. Still, the whole time you can't stop thinking about how "this person looks just like me... no, this person is me!"

mnemonics.meaning: Shellfish Shell The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shellfish</mark> kanji are the same! It can be just the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shell</mark> part too. Shellfish are shellfish, you know?
mnemonics.reading: ばい かい None To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water. Imagine rowing your kayak out into the ocean to collect shellfish. Imagine the color and shape of the kayak. Feel the spray of the salt water and the taste of some fresh shellfish, right out of the ocean.

mnemonics.meaning: Stone The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stone</mark> kanji are the same thing! Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.
mnemonics.reading: せき いし None You throw a stone through a window... and, now you can see something very sexy (せき). Whoops, maybe you shouldn't throw stones through windows or you'll see people's sexy times.

mnemonics.meaning: Thanks Etiquette What do you get if you lend a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Thanks</mark>, of course! Especially if that spirit is Totoro, the spirit of the forest. It's raining, so you lend Totoro your umbrella. As a thanks, he gives you a present wrapped in bamboo leaves.
mnemonics.reading: れい None None So what did you receive as a thanks? You open it up, and there's a ray (れい) gun inside! Thanks for the new ray gun, Totoro!

mnemonics.meaning: Thread The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thread</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
mnemonics.reading: し いと None You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread. Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.

mnemonics.meaning: Town When you see both a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> in the same place, you have the makings of a whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">town</mark>! Think about it, a single farm wouldn't need a whole street. Just paths would do. There is a street next to this rice paddy, so there must be other people, which makes this a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">town</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう まち None You go to visit this nice little town. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. Chou (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day. Remember imagining Mrs. Chou in great detail in level 2? Time for some of that work to come to fruition. Imagine Mrs. Chou walking down the street of the town towards you, ready to make your day bad. She breaks things as she walks towards you, then knocks you down for walking around in her town. She says, "Wherever there's a street, you'll find Mrs. Chou." Then spits on your back as she walks away.

mnemonics.meaning: Treasure Under his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> stares into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water containing his greatest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">treasure</mark>. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof. Picture the treasure reflected in the drop of water. It's marvelous!
mnemonics.reading: ほう たから None All of this treasure is kept in the king's home (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad. Or worse, ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home. Picture his home from the outside. It looks like a normal, small castle. But then you walk in and it's a treasure trove of... well, treasure!

mnemonics.meaning: Village Someone's taking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurements</mark>… Why are they taking measurements of trees? Because they're planning to cut them down to make their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">village</mark>. There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other "do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?" and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.
mnemonics.reading: そん むら None They take all the wood back to where they're building their village, and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the trees from, to honor the village's origins. Look at the mural on the side of this newly constructed village center. So many trees! Visualize the whole process of the tree becoming a building, as you reflect on the message of the mural.

mnemonics.meaning: World Generation The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">world</mark> kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">generation</mark>. Think of it this way: the world is just made up of many different generations of people, plants, and animals all getting along together. It's all these generational differences that make the world go 'round!
mnemonics.reading: せい, せ よ None It's your job to protect the world and every generation with your special saber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone. Hold the saber up high and pledge to protect the world for all of the generations to come! Then swish it around and make buzzing sounds with your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: Year You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark>, which must mean it's that time of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">year</mark>! Every year on New Year's Eve, you get asked to shoot a cow, as per tradition. You really don't want to though, so you deliberately miss every time. Last year was a close call and you ended up shooting the cow's horn, which is why the cow radical looks a little strange here. Can you see how the cow radical fits underneath the gun?
mnemonics.reading: ねん とし None It seems everyone has caught on to the fact that you deliberately miss every year, so this year you make a nendoroid (ねん) decoy in the shape of a cow. Nendoroids are Japanese plastic figurines. (Look them up if you need to! And yes, there are cow nendoroids.) It probably won’t be easy to make a cow-sized nendoroid this year, but better than having to shoot a real one.

mnemonics.meaning: Angle Corner, Antler The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">angle</mark> kanji are the same! You gotta know your radicals first! Only then can you start to study these kanji from other angles — meanings, readings, all that good stuff. One angle at a time, you know?
mnemonics.reading: かく かど, つの None To see those kanji angles from every angle, you cock (かく) your head to the side. Kinda like how a dog cocks its head at an angle when it's trying to understand what you say. That's what you look like when you're studying radicals! Aww, you're so cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Axe Bread Loaf Counter The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">axe</mark> kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bread loaf counter</mark>, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them. Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
mnemonics.reading: きん None None You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe. Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.

mnemonics.meaning: Blue Young The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blue</mark> kanji are exactly the same. Additionally, this can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">young</mark>. You can remember this because young people have potential as limitless as the blue sky! Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう あお None You've been feeling really blue. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. It was an out-of-the-blue transformation! But now someone places his hand on your shoulder and points at your saber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone! You aren't sure how you or the saber turned blue, but at least you and your saber are a good match now, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Body The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> all about the human <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">body</mark>. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you. Imagine looking down at your body and thinking, huh, I wonder what all that junk is? Oh well, I'm sure the leader has it all figured out in that book of hers.
mnemonics.reading: たい, てい からだ None The leader's body book also taught her about something very body specific: how to tie a tie (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and her smart body. Picture the leader, reading a book, putting a tie on her body. Look around at you and your family and your neighbors. You don't know what your body meat-bags do and you don't know how to tie a tie. Womp womp.

mnemonics.meaning: Color The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">color</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">color</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.
mnemonics.reading: しき, しょく いろ None You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out. You can even have someone ask you about your ear... "Is your ear okay? I think it's the color blue..."

mnemonics.meaning: Come Next The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is scattered with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, which will cause the Predator to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come</mark> because he loves rice. Then once he's gone, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">next</mark> Predator will come to eat. This kanji kind of looks like a Predator face, so just imagine Predators come whenever the ground is scattered with rice. They come from all around to grab handfuls of it. Who's next, then? Come forward!
mnemonics.reading: らい く, き None When they come, though, they're all disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck. If you love rye grains, on the other hand, imagine them being really happy that they came to get the rice. They're so lucky it's rye!

mnemonics.meaning: Company Plant a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> before you start your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">company</mark> and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did! Picture a young person way back in old-timey history times burying the spirit of one of their ancestors in the dirt. Now watch as an old-timey time lapse plays out in front of your eyes and a company is born!
mnemonics.reading: しゃ やしろ None Where did you learn about this method of company growing? From a shaman (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley. Imagine going to a shaman and having them tell you that for your company to be successful you need to bury a spirit in the dirt so it can help the company grow. You should probably listen.

mnemonics.meaning: Correct Right, Success What superhero is most like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark>? …If you said <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">correct</mark>! Why is that the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">right</mark> answer? Because the triceratops has three horns, and Wolverine has three blades coming out of his hands. It's obvious, isn't it? But you knew that of course. Picture a triceratops. Now picture Wolverine. An equals sign between them. A little arrow pointing at the horns, an arrow pointing at the blades. And a big flashing CORRECT sign above them. Need I say more?
mnemonics.reading: とう あ None Because you got the answer correct, you win a free trip to とうきょう. Congrats! If you're lucky, you might see Wolverine fighting a triceratops in the middle of Shibuya Crossing in Tokyo. Heroes and monsters are always fighting in Tokyo, right? At least that's what my anime tells me.

mnemonics.meaning: Diagram You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> full of two massive <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s and… <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>?! Upon closer inspection, they appear to form some sort of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagram</mark>! Scientists have spent decades trying to figure out what the diagram of two massive drops and treasure in your mouth could mean, but to no avail. Imagine the pain of having to spend your entire life with a mouth full of two massive drops and treasure… poor you.
mnemonics.reading: ず, と え, はか None After decades of analyzing the diagram, scientists found out it leads to… a zoo (ず)?! Now you’re stuck at this zoo with your diagram mouth full of two massive drops and treasure. Scientists think this can't be it, so further research will be required. Your diagram mouth of drops and treasure isn't off the hook quite yet. Just a few more years, spent at this zoo! I promise!

mnemonics.meaning: Every Each You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and you see some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">windows</mark>. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">every</mark> single one of them. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Each</mark> and every one. Make sure you get every one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit each and every window with your gun.
mnemonics.reading: まい ごと None Now that every window is broken, you feel pretty stupid because mice (まい) are pouring in through each one. You've made a way for mice to get into your house. That wasn't smart. Now you need to shoot every one of the mice that came through those broken windows. You can't let any survive. You have to get every last one out of here!!

mnemonics.meaning: Feather Feathers, Wing, Wings The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feather</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well as in meaning. Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!
mnemonics.reading: う はね, は, わ None You've gathered feather after feather, like some kind of wannabe birdman or birdwoman, and now you're ready to fly. But as soon as you're about to take off, someone dumps honey (はね) on you, making your feathers all goopy. Feel the honey in each feather, taste it trickling over your lips... And go ahead and plummet towards the ground (because you were jumping off a building to fly when someone doused you with honey). At least it's a tasty way to go, no?

mnemonics.meaning: Forest Grove You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>. You basically have yourself a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forest</mark>! Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.
mnemonics.reading: りん はやし None So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "HAYA ... .SHI******!" (はやし) Obviously that didn't work well - you'll want to focus on your battle cry plus indecent swearing right afterwards to remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Go The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">go</mark> kanji are exactly the same! If you know your radicals well enough (and you do), you'll know this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: こう, ぎょう い, おこな, ゆ None "Oh, did he go again?" When こういち is not around, that's what people often say because he goes to the gyoza (ぎょう) restaurant almost every day. こういち just loves gyoza so much, you always know where he is when he is not home. Remember, whenever we see the reading こう, think of こういち, a founder of WaniKani (who loves gyoza). We'll keep it consistent, so over time you should develop a character around こういち that you learn to love or hate.

mnemonics.meaning: Gold The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gold</mark> kanji are the same! Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.
mnemonics.reading: きん, こん かね, かな None The most gold in the land belongs to the King (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with. Picture the King on a huge pile of gold. Gold coins, gold candelabras, gold ponies. He's laughing and pointing at all of it while making very strong eye contact with you.

mnemonics.meaning: Grass Weed You plant your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grass</mark>. Flowers can't grow in these conditions. Think of how disappointed you are. You wanted a beautiful cross of flowers, and now you just have a big overgrown patch of thick grass. It isn't even pretty green grass, it's a little brown and damaged from the sun.
mnemonics.reading: そう くさ None The grass on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a cool saw (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too. Imagine using your cool saw to saw off the heads of all of this grass. You made the cross pretty big, so there is a ton of grass to get through. The sun is beating down on you and the grass too, which isn't making it any easier.

mnemonics.meaning: Hometown Village The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> you always think of first is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hometown</mark>. Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.
mnemonics.reading: り さと None Your hometown is where you sat (さと), nostalgia tugging at your heartstrings amid the endless rice fields and dirt. Visualize yourself sitting in your hometown, the village's rustic charm evoking nostalgia.

mnemonics.meaning: Light Shine You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pi</mark> shaped (that is, circular, like a pie). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">light</mark> as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow. Absorbing light is natural for reptiles, and a round one can absorb even more. Imagine this strange, round piceratops basking in the warm rays of light shining down from the sky. What a rare sight you've come across.
mnemonics.reading: こう ひかり, ひか None As you watch this majestic beast absorbing light, suddenly several dozen feral こういちs burst out from the wilderness, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops! Imagine many different (but also kind of the same) こういちs attacking and throwing spears at the piceratops. Little do they know that it's fully charged up after absorbing all that light, and it unleashes a bright flash of energy, rendering all the こういちs momentarily blind and allowing it to escape.

mnemonics.meaning: Make The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> is the key that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">make</mark>s all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys. Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.
mnemonics.reading: さく, さ つく None The leader makes all the keys and puts them in a sack (さく) to distribute them to the underlings, who then cut them into shape with a saw (さ). Imagine the leader making the keys and dropping them one by one into a big sack. He's always walking around carrying a big sack over his shoulder, distributing the keys to his underlings and watching them saw them into shape.

mnemonics.meaning: Many Much, Lots Of How many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evenings</mark> are there? There are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">many</mark>. If you accidentally think "a lot" or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">many</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: た おお None To remember the reading た we use the word "taco." Let's start with the kanji meaning: many. You go outside in the evening (because that's what this kanji is made up of) and are surprised when you're hit by many tacos (た) flying from the sky. For some reason it's raining tacos, and of course you have no idea why. The tacos pelt you and knock you off your feet. Hard shell, soft shell, meat, lettuce, tomatoes, cheese... it's terrible. And there are so many of them, flying from the sky to drown you in tacos. This is absolutely absurd (and you should think that too, so you remember the reading).

mnemonics.meaning: Meat The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meat</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meat</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.
mnemonics.reading: にく None None You know who loves meat? Nick (にく). You probably know a Nick — imagine him eating some succulent meat right now. If you don't know anyone named Nick, then just imagine it's Nic Cage. Picture him as he chews that succulent meat, maybe even closing his eyes in gastronomic ecstasy. Yeah. Go for it, Nic. Enjoy that meat.

mnemonics.meaning: Meet Meeting The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meet</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meet</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: かい あ None What better way to meet new people than to start kayaking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new! "I met my soulmate in a kayak," said Koichi.

mnemonics.meaning: Mix Mingle You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">father</mark>. But, he won't taste good alone, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mix</mark> in some other ingredients. They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mingle</mark> inside the pot with him. This may seem traumatic, but actually your father is surprisingly into it. Imagine him mixed in with all kinds of other things. It's important to note that this kanji is about things being mixed in, not so much about the action of mixing. That's another kanji.
mnemonics.reading: こう まじ, ま, か None With a mix of your father and other ingredients mingling in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is こういち. He stares back at you with a big smile. "I love mixing in with potatoes and tomatoes," your father こういち states. "Turn up that temperature. I like to mingle with a bit more tingle."

mnemonics.meaning: Near Close Someone on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, and they're getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">near</mark> to you really fast! Oh no, they're so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">close</mark> now, you need to get out of here! Picture a scooter coming toward you in the dark. You see the gleam of the axe as it looms nearer and nearer.
mnemonics.reading: きん, こん ちか None As they draw near, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the King (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move close to you. The King is now so near to you his nose and mustache are tickling your face. He's holding the axe high above his head and saying, "I can get as close to you as I want and you can't stop me because I'm the King. I can get sooooo close. Look, I'm not touching you though!"

mnemonics.meaning: Night Evening The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">night</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">night</mark> kanji are exactly the same. All those late nights studying radicals really pay off, you know.
mnemonics.reading: や よる, よ None You call your friend at night and say "Yo, Lou (よる)!" Lou is a total night owl, so you only hit him up at night.

mnemonics.meaning: Older Brother Big Brother, Elder Brother Who's someone who's just a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>? That's your know-it-all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">older brother</mark>, who won't shut up about anything. To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, けい あに, にい None You wish you could box your loud-mouth older brother up and send him far away to きょうと. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again. Hmm... don't you want to go to きょうと someday? Maybe you should have sent your brother somewhere less cool.

mnemonics.meaning: Pig When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is bright, it's easy to see that a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> is indeed a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pig</mark>. Imagine walking outside at night and seeing a strange oinking animal. You think it's a pig, but just to be sure you grab that thing and hold it up to the moonlight. Yes, definitely a pig! Now you know.
mnemonics.reading: とん ぶた None Legend has it that if you catch a pig in moonlight, it will tell you its secrets. Sure enough, this pig tells you it's from Bhutan (ぶた). A pig from Bhutan?! Yes, all pigs are actually from Bhutan, it whispers. Then this Bhutan pig escapes your grip and trots off into the moonlight.

mnemonics.meaning: Rain The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rain</mark> are the same thing. Make sure you know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: う あめ, あま None What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure. Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, あめ and "aim" don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use "aim" to get to あめ, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice America The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice</mark> kanji are the same in looks and meaning. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">America</mark>, maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something? Aren't radicals nice? As nice and as fundamental as… rice. They make things so much easier, if you've been studying them.
mnemonics.reading: べい, まい こめ None A ton of rice is grown in America. And yet you never see rice in American cuisine. So where's all that unused rice going? Actually, it all gets dumped into a big bay (べい). They have too much rice and no place to store it, so they've started using bays to store it. Imagine helping to bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. A bay isn't the best space for rice storage, but it'll do. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.

mnemonics.meaning: Run The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run</mark> are exactly the same! Make sure you know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: そう はし None You run and run and run and suddenly you feel your soul (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you. Running really takes it out of you. In this case, it takes your soul out of you. Don't worry, when you stop your soul will collide with you again and everything will be okay. (Probably.)

mnemonics.meaning: Same There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">same</mark> as yours! Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.
mnemonics.reading: どう おな None When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut". While this is already strange enough, you notice something stranger. Over a couple feet away is a doughnut (どう) who also has the same mustache as you (and the one that fell on the ground). The doughnut looks at you for a moment, then scampers off. This doughnut must be a mutant because normally doughnuts don't move. If it helps, imagine hundreds or thousands of doughnuts all around you with the same exact mustache. First of all, it's terrifying to be surrounded by thousands of mutant doughnuts. Secondly, it's really weird they all have the same mustache as you.

mnemonics.meaning: Say The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">say</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: げん, ごん い, こと None If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?" Genji is a real smooth talker. In fact, he can talk his way out of anything. If you can just stay calm and think "What would Genji say?" before saying anything, you'll probably end up saying something cool instead of something lame.

mnemonics.meaning: Self Oneself The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">self</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. Radicals have self. Kanji have self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have "self"? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!
mnemonics.reading: じ, し みずか None When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus." Who said you should always look at your self before tossing stones (or whatever) at others? Jesus (じ) did. So, make sure you look at your own self before being a jerk. You can feel free to do some introspection here.

mnemonics.meaning: Shape Form, Appearance You're walking at night when you discover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> covered entirely in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, making it a very strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shape</mark>. In fact, this is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">form</mark> you'd never expect a lantern to take. Picture all the different shapes this hairy lantern could take in your mind.
mnemonics.reading: けい, ぎょう かた, かたち None You stare at the shape until you finally recognize it: cake (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake. Picture the shape of this hairy, glowing cake.

mnemonics.meaning: Skin You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> and your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark> scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though… Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body. Okay, it's painful, but it's a small price to pay for having such beautifully exfoliated skin.
mnemonics.reading: ひ かわ None Without your rough old skin to protect you, you feel the full heat (ひ) of the sun now. It burns… it burns! Yeah, you better protect that fresh new skin from the heat. Your skin usually protects you from the heat, but imagine how raw it would be after you shed the old layer all at once. It's kinda vulnerable right now, so take care of it.

mnemonics.meaning: Sky Empty What was the biggest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> of the world? The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sky</mark>. If you think about it, the sky is like a big hole someone forgot to fill in. That's why this kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">empty</mark>! Makes sense — nothing is more empty than the sky. Next time you look up at the sky, try to imagine it's a big empty hole you're stuck at the bottom of.
mnemonics.reading: くう そら, あ, から, す None The sky is usually empty until clouds stage a coup (くう). Basically you can think of the sky as the site for one coup after another as the weather changes. First the sky's cloudy, then it's clear and empty, then overcast again... Just coup after coup!

mnemonics.meaning: Sound For some reason, you are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sound</mark> of you burning up. Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.
mnemonics.reading: おん おと, ね None This sound isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: onions (おん)! Your burning body sounds just like sizzling, crispy onions being fried in a pan. Listen close. It's exactly the same! You can almost smell onions too!

mnemonics.meaning: Study Learn, Learning You have a wild <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> you have to take care of. He won't do anything but <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">study</mark>, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study. Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!
mnemonics.reading: がく まな None This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by. You should tell the other vikings to stop gawking at this child. Just because he likes to study doesn't mean he's a bad viking...

mnemonics.meaning: Substitute Replace, Period, Age The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> can't come so you need a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">substitute</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">replace</mark> them ASAP! This kanji has another meaning too. The leader can't come to the ceremony because they forgot what <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">period</mark> of time it was. If they think they're in the wrong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">age</mark>, they won't come because they're trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead. Picture the leader of the ceremony out back, unsure of what period or age they're in, while the substitute leader walks in and stares at them in shock.
mnemonics.reading: だい, たい か, かわ, よ, しろ None The substitute leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to dye (だい) them, like they did in the olden ages. Now you're out back with the original leader and the substitute leader, trying to dye the color of this stupid shirt to match that one.

mnemonics.meaning: Think Consider In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark>, doing his begging. But it doesn't work, nobody helps him. So, he just begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">think</mark>: Why am I in this situation? How could I have avoided it? How will I get out? Think, dammit, think!! Imagine him in his coffin, changing from a begging position to a stereotypical "thinking" position. His hand is on his chin, eyebrows furrowed. Focus on the beggar's thinking. This is a pretty abstract idea to imagine, so it will be important to create a vivid picture in your mind's eye.
mnemonics.reading: こう かんが None What does the beggar think of? A thought bubble appears near his head. In it is a picture of こういち! He's thinking that if こういち were here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all! Then, the beggar realizes that he is こういち. Here he is begging in a coffin, and still he only thinks of himself.

mnemonics.meaning: Times Revolve There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">times</mark> there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolve</mark> too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time. Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.
mnemonics.reading: かい まわ None If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of times these mouths revolve, just picture yourself in a little kayak (かい) going around and down through the mouths. Your kayak is slashing and dipping through the revolving mouths, going down and down more times than you can count!

mnemonics.meaning: Valley <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fins</mark> decorate a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, with (presumably fish) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouths</mark> stitched to it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valley</mark> people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of Los Angeles, California. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that. Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.
mnemonics.reading: こく たに, や せ Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash. What a jerk he is. Imagine the deep tan lines on TAN-E as well. He's the epitome of robot laziness.

mnemonics.meaning: Voice You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is the symbol 声, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest. Imagine him and the other samurai with their flags on sticks, waving them around shouting things like "We want a voice!”, “Give us a voice!”
mnemonics.reading: せい こえ None You decide to join the samurai’s protest for more voice but immediately notice… they’re all 子, eh (こえ)?! Imagine your surprise at seeing this large protest of 子 samurai, shouting for their voices to be heard. Really make sure you can hear yourself going “You’re a 子, eh?!” in your head.

mnemonics.meaning: West The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">west</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">west</mark> kanji are the same. Isn't that nice? Make sure you know all those radicals, it will make your life more pleasant.
mnemonics.reading: せい, さい にし None You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business. Imagine the dusty, ramshackle towns in the Wild West where you find your niche. You set up shops with big signs that say SNAKE OIL. Congrats, you've cornered the snake oil niche in the Wild West!

mnemonics.meaning: What Our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">WHAT</mark>?? Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say "What??" over and over again. You want to have the feeling of "what" in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.
mnemonics.reading: か なに, なん None The leader with his lip ring is now eating some naan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry. Make this one vivid and scary. He's eating the naan (that's your なん), and then he screams at the naan but gets overwhelmed with pain (that's the なに). Smell the naan (you're there) and see the blood gushing out of his/her lip. It's terrifying. How did the naan even catch on his lip ring anyways?

mnemonics.meaning: Wheat Barley, Oats The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wheat</mark> you store away. Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.
mnemonics.reading: ばく むぎ None You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ). Imagine the disappointment. You go from finding life to losing it all... now you have no hope for the winter :( Also, keep in mind that むぎ and mug aren't super-alike, so you'll have to use it to get close enough to remember the actual reading, むぎ.

mnemonics.meaning: Younger Brother Little Brother There is someone wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>, holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, and going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> held up by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">younger brother</mark>. If you don't have a younger brother, just pretend you do for now. Imagine him really vividly. He is a stereotypical little boy, playing dress-up with horns and a bow and arrow, and he's going down a makeshift slide held up by a stick.
mnemonics.reading: だい, で, てい おとうと None Your younger brother loves playing dress-up so much that he's now started dyeing (だい) his hair all kinds of colors. Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in your younger brother's hair. He's put so much on that he's dyed half his face too. He's going to be in trouble when he gets home!

mnemonics.meaning: All Whole The hat crowns the king, because all kings must have one. Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what? Literally all of them wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, normal hats, and crowns. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they're all wearing them.
mnemonics.reading: ぜん すべ, まった None But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to is hatless. He's the king of Zen (ぜん). He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby. To add to this story and make it more memorable, you can imagine the other kings getting upset, saying things like "All kings must wear hats! You are no king!" The king of Zen Buddhism just ignores them and begins to meditate.

mnemonics.meaning: Behind After, Back, Later If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you never know what could be happening <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">behind</mark> you. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">After</mark> you're done you could turn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">back</mark> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold. Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.
mnemonics.reading: ご, こう うし, あと, のち None You finally look behind you and see Godzilla (ご) and a giant こういち having a violent battle back there! Godzilla and こういち were going at it behind you the entire time you were just lazily taking a poop in the snow?! Ahh, that's so embarrassing! And also dangerous, they could have crushed you! You should look behind you more.

mnemonics.meaning: Blood The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blood</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blood</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!
mnemonics.reading: けつ ち None To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup! The radical is technically blood, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's ketsup (けつ). Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: Both As you dig under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> you discover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> resting near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, which are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">both</mark> strange things to find beneath the earth. You'll want to focus on the part where you find both, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance. Also think... "What's that row boat doing here?" But, it's your only hope, so you have to focus on it really hard.

mnemonics.meaning: Change A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> is a powerful thing. Even something as ordinary as a spoon can create great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">change</mark> in the world when given to the right person. Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally change everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can bring about with such a simple, everyday object!
mnemonics.reading: か ば None Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か). Of course, doing something like this is utterly amazing. Feel amazed in your imagination, because if you don't, then it'll be hard to remember the reading for this kanji. If you are amazed, you'll know that spoons going to cars = the reading is か, so make sure you take the time to be amazed.

mnemonics.meaning: Country The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">country</mark>, give or take a few <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s. Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
mnemonics.reading: こく くに None Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast. Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!

mnemonics.meaning: Death Deceased The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">death</mark> are the same. This thing is deceased. It ain't alive anymore.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう な None Your death will be because of a bowling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat. You didn't want to know what would cause your death, you say? Well that's a shame. I guess you could try to avoid bowling from now on, but that won't do any good. Mark my words, your death will be bowling-related.

mnemonics.meaning: Death If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> hands you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">death</mark> is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death. This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!
mnemonics.reading: し し None Death comes in the form of a sheep (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon. Picture the death sheep. He looks like a black shadow, and he has a scar on his face. He's holding a bunch of spoons, from all the other people the yakuza marked for death!

mnemonics.meaning: Earth Ground, Land A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> lives in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earth</mark>, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary. You can think of this word as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ground</mark> too, because that's kind of what earth is made of. Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.
mnemonics.reading: ち, じ None None The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the earth and eating you is to feed it cheese (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally). If you ever see someone throwing cheese on the ground, now you know why. They aren't crazy, they're saving us humans from what's lurking under the earth.

mnemonics.meaning: East This is the same as the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark>, so it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">east</mark> too. Remember the radical mnemonic? The sun rises behind that tree in the east!
mnemonics.reading: とう ひがし None You see a man walk straight toward the sun rising in the east. It's so bright he can't see anything, so he trips and he gashes (ひがし) his knee on a rock. Yikes… But he gets back up, determined to head east, and, oh no, he gashes his other knee! OK, he should probably give up on going east. Imagine the secondhand pain you'd feel watching him as he gashes his knee. Ow… Surely nothing in the east can be worth that much suffering?

mnemonics.meaning: Eat Meal The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eat</mark> are the same! Lucky you. If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meal</mark>. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.
mnemonics.reading: しょく た, く None Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere. So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?

mnemonics.meaning: Front Before There are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">front</mark> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason. This kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">before</mark> too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all. Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care.
