Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
mnemonics.reading: ぜん まえ None You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked! Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).

mnemonics.meaning: Have A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is all you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">have</mark>. Imagine one of each under your arms. You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう, う あ None Everything you have (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of youths (ゆう). They came and took your things. Now they have all your stuff, and you only have the moon and a narwhal. You don't have much anymore, but at least you have these things still.

mnemonics.meaning: House Home The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> radical makes up the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">house</mark> kanji! Pretty easy. This kanji is also used to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home</mark>, so try to remember that too. I guess not all houses are homes, and not all homes are houses. But there's a pretty big overlap, right? And in most situations, this kanji's got you covered.
mnemonics.reading: か, け いえ, や, うち None What do you do in your house? You eat eggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your home! Imagine all the eggs you've got in your house. Whole fridgefuls! It's not a normal house, but that's okay. If you couldn't eat eggs, it wouldn't feel like home.

mnemonics.meaning: I Private Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s are meant to stay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">private</mark>! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark>. Why? Because what's more private than you? I mean, I! Basically, some things are only the business of you (I) and those things should be private. Look at your private grains. Who are those for? Why, they're for I!
mnemonics.reading: し わたし None You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (I) and how much you love having things that are private and just yours, when you realize there is a sheep (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No! The moral of the story is: don't let a sheep sneak into your private stash of things just for you (I). I'm sure this is a metaphor for something important...

mnemonics.meaning: Know You take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> because you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">know</mark> too much. You know some very sensitive information, and someone's sent a bow-slinging enforcer to pin your big blabbermouth shut with arrows. Think of all the important things you know that you were hoping to blab about: JFK's real killer, the truth about Area 51, Koichi's shocking connections to the Illuminati. You better hurry and get this arrow out of your mouth so you can tell the world what you know!
mnemonics.reading: ち し None One of the things you know too much about is the sheep (し) plan for world domination! Yes, you know that sheep are in fact plotting to overthrow humanity and take over the world. Take a closer look at that bow-slinging thug who fired the arrow into your mouth. Their shadowy silhouette looks awfully… woolly, doesn't it? It's undeniable: the sheep are trying to shut you up!

mnemonics.meaning: Lively A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lively</mark>! Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.
mnemonics.reading: かつ い None This lively feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the cats (かつ) in your neighborhood too! You and the cats are running around playing together, because you can't seem to get the lively feelings to stop. You have to get the energy out, but the cats have sharp claws and they're scratching you.

mnemonics.meaning: Long Leader The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long</mark> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leader</mark>, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know? As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう なが は You see a very long person. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the leader of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou. Long isn't an idea that's easy to imagine in any specific sense, but you can try some other things too, as long as it gets associated with Mrs. Chou. For the most part, when you see a kanji with the radical 長 the reading will be ちょう.

mnemonics.meaning: Music Bend There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> of them, singing beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">music</mark> together. The music seems to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bend</mark> toward you through the air. Listen to the mouths. All twenty of them. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Imagine the music coming at you, bending all around in strange shapes through the air.
mnemonics.reading: きょく ま None The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music. Imagine how you feel as they cloak you with music. Feel the music all around you, enveloping you. Become the music itself.

mnemonics.meaning: Neck The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">neck</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neck</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: しゅ くび None The only thing you do with your neck is use it to swallow lots of cool beans (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there. Look at yourself in a mirror as the cool beans make their way down your neck. You can see them, like little ants marching all the way down to your tummy.

mnemonics.meaning: Older Sister Big Sister, Elder Sister The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">city</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">older sister</mark>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city. You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.
mnemonics.reading: し お, あね, ねえ None Your older sister may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet sheep (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet. Picture your older sister and her sheep walking through the city. Everyone turns to stare at them, because they're the only ones of their kind.

mnemonics.meaning: Point Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s down to a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">point</mark> in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go. Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.
mnemonics.reading: てん つ None As you stare at the point, you watch in awe as it moves to the ten (てん) spot in a long series of numbers. Is the ten spot good? Are you going to live a long life or does this point mean you're only going to live ten more years?! Ahh!

mnemonics.meaning: Relax Cheap With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over her head, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relax</mark>. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cheap</mark>, so she can even relax about her finances. Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!
mnemonics.reading: あん やす None As she relaxes, she pulls out the cheapest, most relaxing food in the world: anchovies (あん). Think about it: anchovies cost next to nothing, they come in cans, you don't have to cook them or cut them up. You just munch them down. There's nothing more cheap and relaxing than eating anchovies under your own roof.

mnemonics.meaning: Room You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to make your own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> patch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. This is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">room</mark>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself. Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof above the ground. Your own little private place atop the dirt.
mnemonics.reading: しつ None None The only problem with your room is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's shih tzu (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely. Imagine watching the little shih tzu come into your room and lift its leg to all your things. This isn't fair. The shih tzu has its own room to pee in. Why does it have to ruin yours?

mnemonics.meaning: Science Course, Department You scoop some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> to do <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">science</mark>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">course</mark>. Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!
mnemonics.reading: か None None Using your science skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a car (か). This is the science department's special car now! From your science meddling, these grains grow huge, red, and sprout sports cars when they're ripe. This is the true power of science!

mnemonics.meaning: Sea Ocean A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, so you point your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> out the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> at it. "You better turn back, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sea</mark>, or I'll shoot!" You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.
mnemonics.reading: かい うみ None The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your kayak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else. Imagine paddling in your kayak, your gun still in one hand, as you chase the sea back to its home.

mnemonics.meaning: Sheep The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sheep</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning. You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!
mnemonics.reading: よう ひつじ None To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk yogurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves. Imagine the taste of this yogurt. You're scared and tired from running, but it tastes great!

mnemonics.meaning: Shop Store A long time ago, someone put up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> over their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> telling booth and created the first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark>. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">store</mark> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up! Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.
mnemonics.reading: てん みせ None This shop quickly turned into ten (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more. Picture ten shops, all made up of someone selling something under a canopy. The first one is the fortune teller, but the nine others are whatever you want them to be!

mnemonics.meaning: Star The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> that gives <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> is our very own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">star</mark> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well. Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
mnemonics.reading: せい ほし None "All these life-giving stars need a protector," you say, pulling out your saber (せい). It's a big responsibility, but with your trusty saber in hand, you're sure you can defend our star system. Now you're soaring amongst the stars, swinging your saber at all manner of cosmic foes, and... wait. No, that was a dream. You roll over and pat your saber. The two of you are ready just in case the stars need your help.

mnemonics.meaning: State Province, County Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s in the large <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">states</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">province</mark>s. Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!
mnemonics.reading: しゅう None None Each state has its own shoe (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground. The state shoes also have things like the state birds, state flowers, and state fish printed on each of them. They're quite collectable, you should buy a pair for your favorite state!

mnemonics.meaning: Take There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> just sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. Nobody's watching, so, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">take</mark> it. Feel the rush of stealing something (even though it's a weird something, admittedly). Start walking away quickly. You don't want to get caught!
mnemonics.reading: しゅ と None You're the kind of person who likes to take things. "What things?" you ask. Little toes (と). Because that isn't creepy. When someone asks you "Do you like to take little toes?" your answer is always "Toetally."

mnemonics.meaning: Tea If you can steal the flowers that adorn a hat worn by an angel, you can use them to make delicious tea. Naturally, angels decorate their hats with only the most aromatic and delicious flowers fit for brewing. Imagine wrestling with an angel for its flowery hat, then running home with it. Success! Oh yes, this tea is going to taste… heavenly. *rimshot*
mnemonics.reading: ちゃ, さ None None After brewing the tea, you look at the hat again and find a nametag inside that says Chad (ちゃ). You decide that from now on this tea variety will be known as Chad tea, in honor of Chad. For some reason knowing the angel's name makes you feel extra guilty. Chad the angel, flowerless and hatless... Oh well. At least its name lives on in this heavenly tea.

mnemonics.meaning: Think Thought In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and it makes you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">think</mark>. You think a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thought</mark>s like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?" Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.
mnemonics.reading: し おも None As you are thinking these thoughts, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name! If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one. Think really hard about the Moe you know best and imagine them standing watching you from the edge of the rice field.

mnemonics.meaning: Walk You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">walk</mark>ing. Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."
mnemonics.reading: ほ ある, あゆ None So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you. Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Whose hoe is this? etc.

mnemonics.meaning: Yonder Facing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yonder</mark>," you say, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">facing</mark> that way. Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."
mnemonics.reading:
こう む なた Who shot this drop at you from yonder? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is こういち. "Who is that over yonder!" you yell.
"It is I, (こういち)," he yells back. "I shot at you over yonder because you weren't doing your kanji reviews often enough and you're taking up space on our database."
"But I'm paying you!"
"Oh, that's true. Well, I'm going to walk over yonder and leave you alone, then."

mnemonics.meaning: Younger Sister Little Sister Who's that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> pretending to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>? That's my <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">younger sister</mark>. *Sigh* Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
mnemonics.reading: まい いもうと None Your younger sister is giving some mice (まい) a ride on her back like a jet. Ew, gross. Your younger sister is such a weirdo! Why does she have mice on her back while pretending to be a jet?

mnemonics.meaning: Area Side While riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and cut out an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">area</mark> on the ground.  You carefully cut all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>s as you go. This area's all yours now! Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large area, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you've finished carving out the sides of the entire area, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.
mnemonics.reading: へん あた, べ None As you look down at your area with its sword-carved sides, you suddenly realize there is a hen (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg. Imagine doing everything you can to get this hen out of your area, but it manages to dodge and outwit you at every turn. You even slash at it with your sword and try to run it over with your scooter, but the hen can't be stopped. This is the hen's area now. You have been defeated.

mnemonics.meaning: Attach When you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s, you realize they're too short, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attach</mark> things to them to make the measurements more impressive. Attach some heels to the shoes, then attach another head on top of theirs. There — perfect measurements thanks to these attachments. Imagine guiding your leader's dainty feet into the heeled shoes, then attaching the weird head replica. Now picture yourself trying to keep a straight face as you tell them they totally look tall enough.
mnemonics.reading: ふ つ None You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of how you would attach something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together! Just focus on how attaching requires two things to remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Bill Tag, Label, Note This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>, which it's holding over its head. Strange, because trees normally like water… Turns out, this tree wasn't getting showered in water, but in dollar <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bill</mark>s instead. The sick part is that all those bills were once this tree's friends. Picture the tree sobbing uncontrollably, as pieces of its former friends fall everywhere around it. No wonder it needs that umbrella.
mnemonics.reading: さつ ふだ None And the person who gave the tree an umbrella to protect it from all those bills? Satsuki (さつ), a little girl famous for… handing out umbrellas, I guess. Makes sense that Satsuki would take care of these bills then. Try to remember this little girl named Satsuki, since she'll come up whenever the reading for a kanji is さつ (there's a good handful of them). Picture her in your mind, with details like her hair and clothes. Maybe even holding an umbrella or standing by a tree? You should also know she's kind of a bookworm, I guess, in terms of personality. If you can imagine her clearly now, it'll be easy to remember さつ kanji later on.

mnemonics.meaning: Bird The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bird</mark> kanji are the same! As long as you know the radical bird you know the kanji bird.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう とり None Think of a run-of-the-mill bird, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). After bursting out of this bird, she turns her head sharply in your direction. "I don't just own the streets, I own the birds too. I'm inside every bird, and I, Mrs. Chou, can burst out at any time."

mnemonics.meaning: Black The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">black</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: こく くろ None You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke. You need to drink all this Coke, otherwise you're going to drown. Drink this Coke and keep tasting its cold sweetness as you drink it all to survive.

mnemonics.meaning: Boat Ship, Vessel Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>! It's still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boat</mark> though. Picture this boat. It's still a boat, but there is a big mouth on the front and it has fins that it paddles forward with.
mnemonics.reading: せん ふね None This boat belongs to the centaurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before. Picture this mouth and boat with a bunch of centaurs riding in it. Centaurs have a lot more parts than humans, so it makes sense that their boats have more parts (animal ones) too.

mnemonics.meaning: Certain Through the patient's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> runs a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. It's a mad scientist's experiment to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive for now… but he's definitely slated for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> death. Imagine the mad scientist drawing blood from the patient's heart with a small slide. Beside him, a little meter flickers. One side reads "SURVIVE," the other "CERTAIN DEATH." The needle is leaning dangerously towards certain death.
mnemonics.reading: ひつ かなら None As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the scientist puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back. Maybe imagine yourself running in there too, just trying to hit the patient back to life, because the patient was your friend.

mnemonics.meaning: Elephant Phenomenon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elephant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elephant</mark> kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">phenomenon</mark>. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too. Picture the first Japanese person to see an elephant. He stops dead in his tracks, points and screams out, "What a phenomenon!"
mnemonics.reading: ぞう, しょう None None Elephants are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant zombies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the shougun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die. Hint: The readings and meanings for this kanji match up really nicely. ぞう is always for elephant and しょう is always for phenomenon. Remember it like this, the elephant is the zombie and the shougun keeps everyone from finding out about this phenomenon. Picture the shougun standing over a pit of zombie elephants. None of these are getting out on his watch, letting people believe in such crazy phenomenons.

mnemonics.meaning: End This kanji uses a modified <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">end</mark> of the earth. Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!
mnemonics.reading: まつ すえ None When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights. It's surprisingly dirty down here, because all the water takes the garbage this way. That's why you sit on these mats you brought.

mnemonics.meaning: Family Name Last Name, Surname Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family name</mark>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surname</mark>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something. Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
mnemonics.reading: し うじ None Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day. Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks, great-great-great-great-great-grandpappy.

mnemonics.meaning: Fault That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>'s only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fault</mark>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him. Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.
mnemonics.reading: しつ うしな None You try to come up with another fault of his so you can complain, when you see a tiny shih tzu (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing. You run outside and yell, "AHA! It's your fault that shih tzu died! You and that stupid slide!"

mnemonics.meaning: Fish The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fish</mark> are exactly the same! Nothing fishy about that, right?
mnemonics.reading: ぎょ さかな, うお None You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you. Have him continue to scream "GO GYO GYO GYO!" as you try to get your engine started and attempt to flee your impending doom. The fish helps too, because he's pretty worried as well.

mnemonics.meaning: Floor Bed Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">floor</mark>. It also becomes your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bed</mark>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed? You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!
mnemonics.reading: しょう ゆか, とこ None It's great having a floor or bed, but whenever you use it you say yucka (ゆか) because it just gets so dirty. That's the one flaw of using a floor as a bed. In fact, it's the dirtiest floor you've ever seen, because it's covered in yucca (ゆか) leaves. You're sleeping on a yucca floor. Ew! You can imagine how comfortable it is to sleep on a floor of yucca leaves, but at the same time how horrible the smell must be when they start to rot.

mnemonics.meaning: From Since, Compared With, With, By Means Of The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> drops a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of saliva onto this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> above. The person is in a much worse place <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compared with</mark> where they were before, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">since</mark> they only just recently fell into this pit. Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.
mnemonics.reading: い None None From above there is a loud caw, and a giant eagle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, compared with where he was before, is this really better?! The eagle came from the sky and technically rescued him, but compared to where he was before, it may not be a better situation. I think this person is going to be eaten either way.

mnemonics.meaning: Group Association, Team Sew <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves. Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
mnemonics.reading: そ くみ None Everyone in this group loves cumin (くみ). You know, the spice or seed. The group take off their top hats and fill them with cumin. You're officially a group for lovers of cumin. What do you do in the cumin group? You smell the cumin. Cook with it it. Taste it. This group lives and breathes cumin!

mnemonics.meaning: Image Drawing, Painting You go down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> that cuts through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and leads to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">box</mark>. When you open the box at the end of the street, you see it's full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">image</mark>s. Image after image. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Drawing</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">painting</mark>, you name it. Someone must have left this box of images here. What are the images of, anyway? Well, it's better not to say out loud. Just think of the kind of image you enjoy looking at most. That's what's in the box at the end of the street. Aren't you the lucky one?
mnemonics.reading: が, かく None None Okay, I didn't want to tell you this, but the images are all drawings and paintings of gargoyles (が) and cocks (かく). Male chickens, that is. Turns out that's what you wanted to see most. Don't worry, no one is judging you. Try to see the images of the gargoyles. Winged, stony monsters. Very cool. And the roosters? Colorful little dinosaurs. What's not to like?

mnemonics.meaning: Lack This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Lack</mark> becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Lack</mark>! If you know the radical you know this.
mnemonics.reading: けつ か None To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup! You're lacking something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the ketsup (けつ) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it. Imagine having to use regular, ordinary ketchup, or just old, boring catsup on your burger. Or even worse, an actual tomato. BLEH!

mnemonics.meaning: Not Yet You're flying in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Not yet</mark>! Not yet! NOT YET!" Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!
mnemonics.reading: み ま, いま, ひつじ None What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "Me (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that. Go ahead and pretend to listen to the kid asking if we're there yet. Then in your mind go "me me me me me me me" quietly.

mnemonics.meaning: Paper The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that ties you to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paper</mark>. Your papers, that is. The paper itself was also made by your clan using thread woven really tightly together.
mnemonics.reading: し かみ None You need this specific paper to prove that you aren't a Commi (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is. Imagine a big guard coming up to you and asking to see your papers so they can see what clan you belong to. Well you're from the Commi clan, so you really hope this guard is okay with that.

mnemonics.meaning: Pass Through There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> carrying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> she needs to get done. You see her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pass through</mark>, hurrying by to get that task done. Imagine your mama passing through your house on a scooter, not stopping because she needs to get her task done urgently.
mnemonics.reading: つう とお, かよ None As you watch your mama pass through the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK TOO (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up! Why do you have to do the task too? Because there are two tasks, so the two of you have to do them.

mnemonics.meaning: Peoples People, Nation The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> are a group of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">people</mark>. They are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">people</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nation</mark>. The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.
mnemonics.reading: みん たみ None The mouth clan peoples are a nation of people who use their mouths to say mean (みん) things to other peoples. That's why they're the mouth clan. This nation of people are known for mouthing off and saying mean things. Imagine them, as a nation, saying mean things to you. How awful! All being from the same place, they're all into it too. In a way, they're not the mouth clan, they're the mean clan.

mnemonics.meaning: Reason The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place. If a king has no one to rule then he has no reason to exist.
mnemonics.reading: り ことわり None You can't have reason without re (り). Just like you can't have a king without a village, you can't have reason without re.

mnemonics.meaning: Reason A giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> stands above you. "I am <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason. Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう, ゆ, ゆい よし, よ None The reason that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the youths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything. "Those youths just do things for no reason! That's why I, the Cross of Reason, am here! I will knock some reason into those youths."

mnemonics.meaning: Reflect Reflection The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> of the sky gives off its light, which <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reflect</mark>s off of everything around it. Look around you, everything you see is reflecting the light of the sun. Unless it's night time, then the tiny sun in the center of your lightbulb is creating the light that reflects there.
mnemonics.reading: えい うつ, は None This reflected light is important for acorns (えい), in particular. Without light reflecting off everything, the sun's light would never make it down to the ground where they've fallen. They would never grow into trees. And we'd all suffocate. Picture the light of the sun reflecting off a single acorn on the forest floor. So much symbolism!

mnemonics.meaning: School Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> is put on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">father</mark>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">school</mark>." He goes on to explain that he changed your school to here because there is a tree to block the satellite's view. Also, he wears a tin foil lid on his head so they can't track him. The regular school was no good because "they were watching." So now you have this new school, taught under a tree by your father who's wearing a lid on his head.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None Your new school has other students too. They are all こういちs, though. On your first day of school, imagine walking under the tree and seeing all your classmates. They're all こういち–similar to each other, but with some variation. Your father explains these こういちs escaped from a government research facility, and they come to this school to receive a better education. "These poor こういちs need a school that will teach them more than just kanji and Japanese vocabulary."

mnemonics.meaning: Snow When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> falls on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, it turns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">snow</mark>. He's so emotionally distant and cold that the rain freezes into snow as soon as it gets near him. Imagine Wolverine in the pouring rain, creating a little halo of snow around him wherever he goes. It's strangely beautiful. That is one cold, traumatized dude…
mnemonics.reading: せつ ゆき None You're concerned for Wolverine's mental health. Him being so emotionally cold that he turns rain to snow means you keep (ゆき) asking if he's okay. But that only makes him want to be more distant. Sheesh, emotionally distant people are complicated. The more you keep trying to help them, the more they reject you. Wolverine could do with a nice holiday to melt all that snow away.

mnemonics.meaning: South You've seen this as a radical before, and the kanji means the same thing — south! If you keep up with your radicals, your kanji studies will never go south. Haha! Go south! Get it? I said g—
mnemonics.reading: なん みなみ None Think about the south. What's down there? Mean Amy (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky. Picture Mean Amy down in the south, saying mean things in her American southern accent: "Y'all don't come back now, ya hear?" Man, Mean Amy is so mean. And southern.

mnemonics.meaning: Strong Strength You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> because it's made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s, meaning it's extremely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strong</mark>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for super strong bows. That's why you have to keep this one private — it's simply too strong to let others get ahold of. Imagine holding this bow. Feel how strong it is as you draw the string. Now look closely at the insect bodies it's made of. Thanks for your help, little guys.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, ごう つよ None You had this strong bow made especially for you in きょうと. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go. Imagine all the people who live in きょうと, using their strong arms to make strong bows out of strong insect carapaces. Could きょうと be Japan's strongest city?

mnemonics.meaning: Summer The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> shaped like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> only grows in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summer</mark>. Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
mnemonics.reading: げ, か, が なつ None Now it's summertime! What do you do during the summer? You just sit around with your favorite string tying knots (なつ) in it over and over again. Think about summer. Now think about yourself tying knots. Now think about summer again. Now think about tying knots again. Now think about your mother getting upset at you because all you do is tie knots all summer long. Go play video games like a normal kid!

mnemonics.meaning: Tall Expensive, High There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tall</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expensive</mark> you are. Imagine yourself saying how tall and expensive you are to everyone in the room. Then they use a lid to cover your mouth so you can't talk to anyone anymore. But, then your mustache starts talking, saying the same thing. That's why this lid covers both your mustache and your mouth. Now you can't say that you are tall or expensive.
mnemonics.reading: こう たか None "I am taller and more expensive than you." You're saying this because there are some こういちs in the room, and you want to make them feel inferior (you're a こういち hater). You keep comparing your height to the こういちs in the room, and you keep checking price tags. Then you tell them you're taller and more expensive than they are. The こういちs finally get tired of your shenanigans, and lid up your mouth and mustache so you can't say that you're tall or expensive.

mnemonics.meaning: Teach A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">teacher</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is happiest because they get to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teach</mark>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches! Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught inside.
mnemonics.reading: きょう おし, おそ None Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to きょうと. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows. Imagine the teaching teacher teaching you about Japan in きょうと in winter. You've always wanted to go to きょうと!

mnemonics.meaning: Time O'clock, Hour The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is used in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> to tell <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">time</mark>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now." This also can mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">o' clock</mark>, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese. Imagine being in a temple and realizing you don't know what time it is. Never fear! Look on up at the sun. Ah, yes. Blinding noon.
mnemonics.reading: じ とき None Time in a temple makes you think of Jesus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth. Imagine him going to all kinds of different times and also make sure you're specifically imagining Jesus doing all these things. Put these two together and you'll remember the reading in no time. (Haha, get it?)

mnemonics.meaning: Weak You have two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>s but they're both covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark>. This has made them very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weak</mark>. Just look at these weak, iced over bows. If you tried to draw back their strings they'd snap into a million pieces.
mnemonics.reading: じゃく よわ None You give up on your trip and bring the weak bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a jack (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half. Now you're stuck with two weak broken bows and no jack. Ice is the worst.

mnemonics.meaning: Week Use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to travel the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> of the world and it will take you a full <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">week</mark>. Seven whole days! A week in earth time is also known as a "full scoot" in scooter lingo. ;)
mnemonics.reading: しゅう None None If you want to scoot for a week, you'll need shoes (しゅう). Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself. You can't ride a scooter for a week barefoot, are you nuts?! Get some shoes!

mnemonics.meaning: Wind Style You look at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> and notice it is being used as a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s to launch themselves into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wind</mark>. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">style</mark>. To remember this, consider how styles can change quickly, just like the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wind</mark>! Picture a table tilted on its side with some of its legs longer than others, a perfect slide for insects! Imagine all the different insects jumping into the wind each in their own particular style.
mnemonics.reading: ふう, ふ かぜ None You wonder what's pushing these insects to jump into the wind in such a manner, and you realize that it's because they've had way too much food (ふう). The insects ate all the food that was left on the table, and now they can't just fly away into the wind like they normally do. Instead, they have to try this new style by using the table as a slide to help them take off into the wind.

mnemonics.meaning: Write Down Record What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> (yourself), you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">write down</mark>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record</mark> these important thoughts in some way. Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head. "Dear me, today I learned a lot of new kanji on WaniKani. It was the best. I love the crabigator sooooo much. Love, me."
mnemonics.reading: き しる None You need to protect what you write down and record for yourself with a key (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key! Picture the key you use to keep what you write down a secret. What does it look like? How does it feel in your hands?

mnemonics.meaning: Yellow The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yellow</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yellow</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: おう き None You're in a room, surrounded completely by yellow. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow key (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape. The walls are coming in closer, too. Make sure you feel a bit of peril as you look for this key. The walls have a slight opening at the bottom too, so if you don't find it before the wall goes over it, the key will be lost forever, and you'll be smushed!

mnemonics.meaning: Answer Response, Reply "Does the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> shirt <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> me?" you ask... but nobody will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">answer</mark>. Shout "PLEASE ANSWER ME!" a few times to get the idea of "answer" in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.
mnemonics.reading: とう こた None You pull out a quarter (こた) and offer it to whoever will give you an answer. With this shiny quarter in your hand, everyone is giving you their answer. Yay for bribery!

mnemonics.meaning: Anti Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">anti</mark>-society, hiding away like that. Imagine someone who looks super anti-social (and a little feral). Ask them why they're sitting on this stool inside a cliff. They reply it's because they hate people. They're anti-people. In fact, they're anti-everything.
mnemonics.reading: はん そ None Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, its the anti-hero from Star Wars, Han (はん) Solo! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again. Make sure you get to the point where you pull this anti-social guy's beard off, to reveal Han Solo beneath. Be surprised... not just because he's Han Solo, but because he's real, too! Maybe you can yell out "Han! Your people need you!"

mnemonics.meaning: Buddy Ruler <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> and from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you scream, "Hey, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buddy</mark>! Watch it with that slide, it's really fast and you might hurt yourself, buddy!" You're a really good buddy to Wolverine. He also happens to be the local ruler of these lands. You make it a habit to befriend the local strongmen, just in case… No wonder you're so buddy-buddy with all the rulers around here. Imagine having all the local rulers as your buddies, all the influence you would have. You might end up with everyone wanting to be your buddy.
mnemonics.reading: くん きみ None As you're about to embrace your buddy Wolverine, a coonhound (くん) tackles him off the slide, and bites him in the process. Oh no! This coonhound mistook Wolverine for a giant racoon. (His mask kinda makes him look like one.) You better go help your buddy now. Be mindful of the coonhound though, they're good hunters I hear.

mnemonics.meaning: Bureau Department Your nation's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> sits on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark>d <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. This is the symbol for the "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Bureau</mark> of Secret Things." It's a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">department</mark> of your government made to keep things hidden. The cape covering the mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have.
mnemonics.reading: きょく None None The bureau's best-kept secret is cloaking devices that cloak you (きょく) with the press of a button. Now, this mnemonic isn’t perfectly close, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain so that you can remember きょく later. If you can get to CLOAK YOU, then you can get to きょく much easier than just trying to get there from scratch. So imagine working in this bureau and getting to cloak yourself all the time.

mnemonics.meaning: Buy Here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> full of of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buy</mark>. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money. Imagine looking over a bunch of different kinds of shellfish wrapped in nets. Think about which ones you want to buy.
mnemonics.reading: ばい か None You decide to buy as many shellfish as you can fit in your car (か). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure. Imagine buying an entire car's worth of shellfish. Mmm, delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: Capital Just like the radical, the kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">capital</mark>. Know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: きょう みやこ None To remember the reading きょう we use the old capital of Japan, Kyoto, which is spelled きょうと. It was the capital of Japan before Tokyo! When you think of the capital, any capital, think of きょうと.

mnemonics.meaning: Cloud A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> is still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloud</mark>! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella. Picture all of the different types of clouds in the sky. There are puffy white ones, heavy dark ones, and wispy thin ones. But they're all clouds.
mnemonics.reading: うん くも None You lie down and try to figure out what the clouds are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a cool mom (くも). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom? You look at each cloud and each one is a different cool mom. They're each doing different cool mom things. You suddenly don't want to look at the clouds anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Comfort Ease, Pleasure, Music The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is a magical tree that radiates an aura of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comfort</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ease</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasure</mark>, with its icy foliage tinkling like beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">music</mark> whenever it sways in the breeze. Close your eyes and feel the aura of comfort wash over you. Listen to the musical tinkling of the tree's icy branches, setting you at ease. You never want this pleasurable moment to end!
mnemonics.reading: らく, がく たの None You want more of this aura of comfort, so you chop down the magic tree and build a clothing rack (らく) out of it. Then, you put the rack in your house so you can enjoy that fuzzy feeling of comfort and ease every time you go to hang something up. Place a hanger on the rack. Feel the wave of pleasure that runs through you, and then bask in the afterglow of comfort and ease that it leaves behind. Now, go find something else to hang up on your rack. You need another hit of comfort and pleasure.

mnemonics.meaning: Count Amount, Number Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so she can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">count</mark> it. The woman will count each individual grain of rice, then tell you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number</mark> of grains. She has to count each grain in order to divvy up the rice supply and make it last the winter. Imagine the amount you get today — just a small number of grains. It's not a good time for you guys…
mnemonics.reading: すう かぞ, かず None Why do you have to count your rice out like this? It's because someone sued (すう) your farm and took everything you owned. Since being sued, you only have a small amount of rice to last the winter. Come up with a story about why your farm got sued for everything. Imagine sitting in court. Listen to the judge deliver the verdict. Be angry. The woman will be counting rice for years to come.

mnemonics.meaning: Decide Decision You have at your disposal a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> to assassinate this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>, or a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark>. Which method will you choose? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Decide</mark> now! Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this? You're like Two-Face deciding on how to kill Batman.
mnemonics.reading: けつ き None To remember the けつ reading, we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum): You finally decide. You're going to go with the tsunami... but not just any tsunami. You'll kill him with a tsunami of ketsup (けつ). Get everything ready to take your target down. How will you collect enough ketsup to make a ketsup tsunami? Where will you unleash it? You gotta decide on the ketsup logistics now.

mnemonics.meaning: Dwell Reside, Dwelling The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark>s gets to choose the place they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dwell</mark>. So they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reside</mark> in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings. Picture the leader master who dwells in a big, beautiful dwelling. Everyone else is jealous.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう す None She needs this big place to dwell so she has somewhere to store all of her jewels (じゅう). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and she has jewels. Imagine opening the door to the leader master's dwelling and thousands of jewels come pouring out, whisking you off, down the mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: Electricity You're in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>, in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, holding an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>. You're here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">electricity</mark> (aka lightning), to prove that it exists. Imagine being hit by the electricity. Feel the powerful electric shock pulse through your body. You're like a crazier Ben Franklin out here.
mnemonics.reading: でん None None After the electricity hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge dent (でん). Feel the indent in your face. It doesn't hurt, strangely, but it is pretty huge. Panic about this dent a bit.

mnemonics.meaning: Forest Woods This kanji is just the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forest</mark>." Makes sense, because a bunch of individual trees is what makes up a forest!
mnemonics.reading: しん もり None One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want more (もり) trees, please! Keep repeating this pattern over and over, continually focusing in on how you need "more" trees to make this forest. For some reason the person working with you only goes up by one at a time, though, so you have to say it a lot (it'll help you to remember, anyways!).

mnemonics.meaning: Help With <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, you're able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark> anyone. Imagine putting on your top hat and getting power from it. Then, you use that power to help someone. It's important to make the association that it's the top hat giving you the power to help that person. You're basically Frosty the Snow Man.
mnemonics.reading: じょ たす, すけ None The person you help with your top hat power? It's Jo-Anne (じょ). You can imagine saving her however you like. Perhaps she was under a car, and you used your top hat powers to help her out of that situation by lifting it above your head. Note: Jo-Anne is the character we're using with じょ reading mnemonics. She is short compared to Joe (じょう), the giant farmhand, which is how you'll differentiate the two similar readings.

mnemonics.meaning: Horse The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: ば, め うま, ま None You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "Baaa," (ば) it says. "Baaaaa." Feel the shock of this. It sounds just like a sheep, it's strange.

mnemonics.meaning: Interval Interval of Time, Interval of Space There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> goes through at a regular <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval</mark>. There is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval of time</mark> in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval of space</mark> in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts. "Interval" is a weird word to remember, but just think of the sun going around the earth and through the gate like clockwork. Every 24 hours it passes through the gate, and each interval is exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: かん, けん あいだ, ま None This method of keeping track of intervals of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan has had a huge impact on the world as we know it, especially the Eurasian continent of the past, so he's going to come up a lot from now on. Be prepared to get very familiar with him and his friends! Picture Genghis Khan ordering his most skilled inventors and builders to create this special sun gate so they can harness the power of intervals, and all people under his rule can benefit from the accurate telling of time.

mnemonics.meaning: Location Place <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> makes it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to identify your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">location</mark>. Even if you add an extra line to mark the ground, it's still easy. Keep that in mind and you can go from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">place</mark> to place. Imagine looking at the dirt. It's a distinct color and texture, and you're able to identify your location just from that alone. Now draw that line on the ground and you'll always remember this place.
mnemonics.reading: じょう ば None Knowing your location from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was Joe (じょう), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he can identify any place just from its dirt! Remember Joe? He's our local farmhand who only has nine toes (from the 上 mnemonic). Imagine that guy explaining to you how to know your location from dirt. He may be a bit clumsy, but the man really knows his dirt.

mnemonics.meaning: Medicine You're in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> and you've been shot by an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark>. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">medicine</mark> if you hope to live. More specifically, antibiotics. Your wound is festering pretty badly.
mnemonics.reading: い None None When we need to remember the sound い we use the word "Eagle." You need your medicine really bad. Then, you look up. There's an eagle (い) flying overhead. He has a package. It's medicine! You're saved! Or, so you think. He just keeps circling and circling. Feel some hate for the eagle. Why isn't he dropping the medicine? You don't have long to live!

mnemonics.meaning: Morning There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> sticking out the top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> sticking out the bottom. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is off to the right. That's because it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">morning</mark>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day. Imagine a sun attached up in the sky with two crosses, which act as scaffolding, and the moon gradually fading off to the right as the morning wears on.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう あさ None Every morning you have Asahi (あさ) beer for breakfast. You watch the sun scaffolded by crosses, and the moon next to it, as you sip on your early-morning Asahi.

mnemonics.meaning: Next <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ice</mark> is what you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>ing, so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">next</mark> thing you need to do is go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next! Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">next</mark> next next" echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.
mnemonics.reading: じ, し つぎ, つ None To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands. Imagine him coming down. Imagine your surprise. He hands you the ice, and it's cold. You thank him, and he flies away.

mnemonics.meaning: Number In A Series Turn You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sickle</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> today because it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turn</mark>. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number in a series</mark>, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3. Go through in your mind the system your farm / village uses for deciding who has to sickle on any given day. It rotates, and it's a turn-based system. So, do you all stand in a line? Is there a calendar? Come up with something interesting, focusing on your turn in the process you come up with. It will be helpful to remember both the "number in a series" and "turn" meanings for the vocab coming up in the future.
mnemonics.reading: ばん つが, つがい None This turn-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been banned (ばん) from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking. Try to feel disappointed by this. Strange thing to feel disappointed by, but you were a great sickler. You were going to win the great prize, too (come up with something huge!), but now you're banned for the season.

mnemonics.meaning: Picture Painting When a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meet</mark>ing on paper (after you've dipped them in paint, say) they can create a masterpiece of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">picture</mark> (or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">painting</mark>). It's unbelievable the kind of picture you're able to paint with just the tips of threads. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this thread tool.
mnemonics.reading: え None None You tell someone you painted this masterpiece of a picture. Their response? "EH (え)?!" Tell a few more people about your picture. Have them all do the same surprised "Eh?!" reaction at your art skills.

mnemonics.meaning: Place Facility You're tearing this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> down with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">PLACE</mark>!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door. Why do you hate this place, in particular? Come up with a great reason why to help you to remember this very broad kanji meaning.
mnemonics.reading: しょ ところ None You smash through the door and finally get inside the place, only to find some kind of show (しょ) going on. It's a circus show — elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles! The greatest show on earth, but why is it at this place? Come up with a weird reason as to why the circus is at this place you hate so much. Why did you come here with your axe? Does it have something to do with the circus show?

mnemonics.meaning: Pond The poor <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> was taken far inland by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. Now his only source of water is a tiny <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pond</mark> that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food. Imagine the alligator riding the tsunami in. When he hits the ground, and the water recedes, he's all alone in a pond, but it doesn't provide much for him. Imagine him looking for food in the little, shallow pond. Imagine him trying to stay wet... it's just not a great situation to be in, unfortunately.
mnemonics.reading: ち いけ None The worst part about this pond is that the only thing for the alligator to eat is cheese (ち). Cheese may be yummy for humans, but alligators hate it. They'd rather eat the cow the cheese came from. Sadly, this pond is full of cheese. Picture an alligator crying in a pond full of cheese. It's eating a piece really slowly and weeping.

mnemonics.meaning: Research You dig a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> times for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">research</mark>. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them, and so there's an uneven number. Imagine carefully digging a hole nine times, in nine different spots, so you can do your research. Hmm, I wonder what kind of research these holes are for…
mnemonics.reading: きゅう きわ None Your research is on cucumbers (きゅう)! Put nine full-grown cucumbers into their holes so you can research what happens next.

mnemonics.meaning: Road Street, Path, Way Aim the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">neck</mark> at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">road</mark>! Scooters are only meant for driving on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">street</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">path</mark>s, and if you go the wrong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">way</mark>, you'll probably break your own neck! Imagine riding your scooter down the road. You're carefully aiming the scooter's neck the right way so you don't end up going out of control and dying.
mnemonics.reading: どう みち None To remember the reading どう we use the word "doughnut." You're traveling down this road so fast that you don't see the giant doughnut (どう) that's rolling toward you until the last minute. You crash into it, and both you and the doughnut go tumbling down.
