Ahg, your neck! Alternate ending: You do a sweet jump, go right through the doughnut hole, take a bite, and land safely back onto the road!

mnemonics.meaning: Service Duty You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> because you're currently doing your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">service</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duty</mark> to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen. Imagine standing around with a weapon in your hands. It feels more like you're doing nothing, loitering around the wall, but this is how you offer your service to your country, so you have to do it.
mnemonics.reading: やく, えき None None You're about halfway through your service, when a yak (やく) walks by. It stops directly in front of you and grunts. "Excuse me, Mr. Yak, but it's my duty to escort you away from my country." Somehow your duty has become pushing this stubborn, hairy yak away from the entrance to your country. You poke it in the butt with your weapon, but it doesn't seem to care.

mnemonics.meaning: Sharpen A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> is an excellent way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sharpen</mark> anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword. Imagine walking around at night and you need to sharpen your sword. You walk up to a stone lantern and rub your sword all over it to sharpen it. Touch the blade. Indeed, it's been sharpened!
mnemonics.reading: けん と None Why did you sharpen your blade? Because you are about to do battle with Ken (けん), the famous samurai warrior. You'll want to remember this character, because he will come up many times throughout your WaniKani journey. Ken the samurai used to work for WaniKani, but then he went rogue because he thought WaniKani wasn't being radical enough. So now he wanders the website carrying his squid friend (who you'll meet later) in a bucket. To help you visualize him, imagine a samurai with armor made from crab shells, a helmet that is just an alligator head, and swords with crab claw hand guards. His great beard and mustache are styled in the shape of whatever kanji is giving you the most trouble at the time.

mnemonics.meaning: Somebody Someone, Body The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide. Sure, it’s your<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> who’s tumbling down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>… at least that’s how it feels to you. Who are you? What are you? All you know is you’re <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">somebody</mark>, but you don’t know who that somebody is. Apparently, you’re having some kind of internal crisis. Come up with a rough one and you’ll remember this kanji better.
mnemonics.reading: しん み None You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit somebody… and you hit them really hard. On your metaphorical shin (しん). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is. Just make the shin hit as painful as possible in your imagination and you’ll surely remember this kanji’s on’yomi.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone Somebody A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> has been left out in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">someone</mark>." Smell the stench of the decomposing body. Also, feel really curious as to who this person is. It came from somewhere that gives you a reason to believe it's someone you know. Then, feel the disappointment as you read the label that says "someone" instead of an actual name. "Someone," you repeat. "Someone."
mnemonics.reading: しゃ もの None To remember the sound しゃ we use "shaman." It's time you open the coffin and check. Maybe there's more answers in there. There's no way this person could just be "someone." You lift the lid, and sure enough, you're able to figure out who it is. It's a shaman (しゃ), dressed in full shaman garb. How strange that a shaman was delivered to you this way! Come up with a story explaining why this shaman's body is here at your door, rotting in the sun. Make it ridiculous and interesting so you remember it.

mnemonics.meaning: Support Branch The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch</mark> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">support</mark>. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too! Picture a branch supporting the weight of you, your entire family, and maybe a few friends.
mnemonics.reading: し ささ None You're happily sitting on this branch, letting it support all this weight, when a sheep (し) starts to climb the tree. A very, very big sheep. Uh oh... no no, sheep. If you get on this branch it won't be able to support all this weight!!! The big sheep walks up the side of the tree with its weird hooves and starts to put its weight on the branch. "No no no!" you and your whole family scream. The branch can't support the weight of the sheep. It snaps! You all tumble to the ground. The end.

mnemonics.meaning: Talk Speak <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> it with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark>. If you do, you'll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>. You'll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speak</mark>. Your problem is you weren't saying it with your tongue before. Once you start using your tongue, you're able to speak suddenly!
mnemonics.reading: わ はな, はなし None If something uses their tongue, it will be able to talk and speak. To prove this, you teach a walrus (わ) to use its tongue, and lo and behold, it speaks to you! You decided to teach a walrus how to speak because it seemed like the hardest thing to teach, with its tusks and all that. It turned out to be really easy. Although, you may have picked the Justin Long walrus, by accident. Either way, this walrus can speak! And you definitely (probably) helped.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw</mark> it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it. Imagine a weapon in between your fingers. It doesn't matter what kind. Now feel the weight as you throw it.
mnemonics.reading: とう な None You throw your weapon away because you're about to enter とうきょう and there are no weapons allowed there. There is, however, a big pile of thrown away weapons by the border, which is where you're throwing yours right now. Imagine throwing the weapon in your fingers just before you walk into とうきょう. You can see the lights, smell the smells! Throw your weapons and your cares away!

mnemonics.meaning: Versus Opposite <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Writing</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> stand <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">versus</mark> one another. Writing is all about feeling and expression. Measurement is about cold hard numbers. Yep, in this world writing people are basically the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">opposite</mark> of measurement people. Which side are you on? What's that, you say? It doesn't always have to be writing types versus measurement types? We can work together to create a better society? Nah, sorry, I'd rather it be me versus the world.
mnemonics.reading: たい None None Whenever it's you versus someone else, you wear a tie (たい). Naturally, your tie is always the opposite color of your opponent's tie. Kinda like how political rivals wear different color ties when they debate. It's pretty silly, but at least your tie makes it clear that it's you versus them. Think of someone you know who's your total opposite. Now imagine you're both in ties, but opposite colors, and you're debating… or fighting in a cage match or something.

mnemonics.meaning: Accept Receive Someone throws a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> while you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. You must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accept</mark> this. Then another guy cleats you in the forehead, but you remain on the stool and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> it without complaint. This is some kind of acceptance ritual for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. If a cleat to the forehead doesn't knock you off the stool, you'll receive an offer to join. You're dealing with a lot of emotions right now. You feel the pain from being cleated in the forehead, but you're also glad to have finally been accepted into the soccer club. Suppress your pain and receive this honor.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ う None After they accept you, they give you a small juice (じゅ) box. It's to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you receive the juice with grace. Did you ever play soccer as a kid? Do you remember accepting a small juice box into your little kid hands during halftime? Apparently pros drink the same ones.

mnemonics.meaning: Beauty Beautiful A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> is a true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beauty</mark>. Big is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beautiful</mark>, and that's all the more true for sheep. Imagine a great big beautiful sheep. See the sheep's beauty. This sheep is so big and fluffy that you can't see its tail, which is why it looks bit different in this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: び, み うつく None The big sheep's beauty has attracted a swarm of bees (び). The sheep is so beautiful that the bees have mistaken it for a flower. The bees are swarming around the sheep, marvelling at its beauty and trying to figure out how to get nectar from it.

mnemonics.meaning: Beforehand What does your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> tell you to do in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>? Look before you cross! You gotta do it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beforehand</mark>, or it could be too late. Imagine yourself about to cross the street, and your mama saying in your ear: "always look beforehand"!
mnemonics.reading: よ あらかじ None As you look beforehand, you see a yo-yo (よ) lying in the street. As you cross the road, you pick up the yo-yo and put it in your pocket. You're really glad you looked beforehand, because you now have a yo-yo!

mnemonics.meaning: Clothes Clothing Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> in front of you and use it on all of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothes</mark>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothing</mark>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp. Imagine placing each piece of clothing you own onto the stool and carefully stamping them with a symbol of the moon. This should stop people from stealing all of your clothes!
mnemonics.reading: ふく None None A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the clothes they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "F**k (ふく) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!! Your friend turns red and tries to pull the clothes back, "F**k you!" they yell. "No, f**k you, these are my clothes and I have proof this time!"

mnemonics.meaning: Compare The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compare</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: ひ くら None Compare the heat (ひ) today with the heat yesterday. Is it hotter today? It's up to you to compare. Feel today's heat. Now compare it to yesterday. You might want to check your thermometer if you're not sure!

mnemonics.meaning: Degree Occurrence A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is always placed at certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">degree</mark>s. The degrees change depending on specific <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occurrence</mark>s. Since a yurt is round, the stool has to be angled at certain degrees. It's part of yurt culture. Imagine someone adjusting the stool with a measurement tool to adjust it to an exact degree.
mnemonics.reading: ど, たく たび None Also angled at exact degrees is the dog (ど). The dog changes its degrees at every occurrence of the stool changing. Picture the dog leaning at the exact degree the stool is at.

mnemonics.meaning: Departure Go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> and take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> from it, then we will be ready for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">departure</mark>. We can't leave the lantern inside of the tent; that's a fire hazard. We'd best take it with us before the departure. Don't you agree? Feel the heat from the lantern. It's not quite as comforting as being inside a tent, but it's better than nothing. The lantern will light your way on your departure.
mnemonics.reading: はつ None None Oh! Don't forget your hats (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a departure without hats or a lantern. That'd be a short journey. How cold and unprotected would your head be without a hat? Very. Taking hats along with departures is integral to their success. Imagine how unsafe you would feel with no hats. That's no departure I want to set out on.

mnemonics.meaning: Determine A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> only if you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">determine</mark> that it is. Imagine looking at a roof, and someone asks you, "Is this roof correct?" "I determine it is."
mnemonics.reading: てい, じょう さだ None You determined it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a tater (てい) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof. "Because of my tater tot roof test, I have once again determined it is correct."

mnemonics.meaning: Express Surface Sometimes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark>, and you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">express</mark> yourself to deal with it! How do you express yourself? On the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surface</mark> (of your face)! Think of the last time life gave you a kick, and how you expressed that pain to make it go away, specifically on the surface that is your face.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう あらわ, おもて None You need to express yourself, so you call up a friend and say "Heyo!" (ひょう). Imagine yourself saying it more like ひょう, though. ひょう man!

mnemonics.meaning: Guest Customer Under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> there are more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s to feed because you let <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guest</mark>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">customer</mark>s. Picture all of the hungry guests and customers under your roof, eating your food and sleeping on your floor.
mnemonics.reading: きゃく None None One of your guests is a regular named Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name. Kyaku looks just like any other customer. Picture a stereotypical "customer" type person in your head.

mnemonics.meaning: Heavy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heavy</mark> kanji are the same. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: じゅう, ちょう おも, かさ, え None In your hand is a very heavy jewel (じゅう). Real jewels are always heavier than they look. Imagine holding a real jewel in your right hand and a fake jewel in your left. The one in your right hand is suuuuupeerrr heavy!

mnemonics.meaning: Hold You need to get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hold</mark> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop. Imagine holding a tiny temple in your fingers. Hold it up to the light. Hold it on the train. Hold it while you sleep.
mnemonics.reading: じ も None As you hold the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny Jesus (じ). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus! Jesus likes when you hold things like temples. He probably likes when you hold other things too, like ice cream, puppies, and homeless peoples' hands.

mnemonics.meaning: Image Statue The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elephant</mark>s is so great, they put up an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">image</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">statue</mark> of him everywhere. Every house, every street corner — his image looks down on all the other elephants at all times. For now, just imagine the leader of the elephants being told images and statues of him are being put up everywhere. Don't think about what the statue looks like, because that's next.
mnemonics.reading: ぞう None None When they unveil the images and statues of the leader elephant, everyone gasps. They look like him, but he's a zombie (ぞう). Gasp! But this is exactly what the leader of the elephants asked for. You see, the leader of the elephants was a big fan of zombies. Imagine how excited he'd get to have this zombie version of himself appearing as images and statues, all across the land.

mnemonics.meaning: Lose When you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, whoever ends up with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lose</mark>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser. Imagine that it's your first day in prison. You're walking around the yard, minding your own business, when suddenly a shellfish smacks you right in the head and falls into your open hands. "HAHA YOU LOSE!" someone shouts.
mnemonics.reading: ふ ま, お None If you lose, you're a fool (ふ). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool. Now you have to try to make some other fool lose. Otherwise you'll be the loser fool forever.

mnemonics.meaning: Mutual Minister You need to look a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> to gain a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mutual</mark> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual. It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
mnemonics.reading: そう, しょう あい None If your respect for the tree is mutual with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's soul (そう). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding." This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.

mnemonics.meaning: Need When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> is piloted by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>, it stirs an insatiable <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">need</mark> in her. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it! Picture the woman in the helicopter needing something. She's looking around. Searching. But she doesn't know what it is!
mnemonics.reading: よう い, かなめ None Finally she knows what she needs! It's yogurt (よう)! Delicious, creamy yogurt! What does she need? Yogurt!

mnemonics.meaning: New There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that you're taking an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">new</mark> tree grow. As you imagine yourself cutting down the standing tree, think about what new tree you'll plant in its place.
mnemonics.reading: しん あたら, あら, にい None You cut down the tree to make room for a new one, but it falls on your shin (しん). Only your shin got hit, so focus all your imaginary pain down there. Try to pull out the splinters. Ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: Occurrence Thing, Matter You find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>. What a strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occurrence</mark>. I guess he put it there, but why would he do such a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thing</mark>? You ask him, but he says it's a personal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">matter</mark> of utmost secrecy. Imagine his muffled words as he tries to explain this with the cross in his mouth. Hm, better not pry further. Maybe he's trying to… X-orcize his demons…
mnemonics.reading: じ こと, つか None This occurrence doesn't impress Jesus (じ), who appears and gently removes the cross from Wolverine's mouth. Imagine Jesus gently taking the cross out of Wolverine's mouth. What a swell dude.

mnemonics.meaning: Part Department, Club The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is over in that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">part</mark> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">department</mark> and their clown <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">club</mark>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours. Of course, we feel terrible about forcing the clowns into their own part of town. It's not that they're lesser than us, it's just that we don't like them.
mnemonics.reading: ぶ へ None You see, that part of town is full of booze (ぶ). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze. Picture all of the clowns, trapped in their weird clown part of town, drinking booze and smashing each other over the heads with the bottles. You're glad you don't live in that part.

mnemonics.meaning: Peace Japanese Style When everyone has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, you will have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>. That is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese style</mark> of doing things. Imagine Japanese people with grain in their mouth. The whole country is at peace.
mnemonics.reading: わ, お なご, やわ かず, より Peace is the Japanese style. The walruses (わ) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate. The walruses also achieve peace by putting grain in every walrus' mouth, following the Japanese style.

mnemonics.meaning: Prefecture The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark>, still <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> and curious, gazes upon the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prefecture</mark> that will one day become his. He's a small lion, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over. Imagine the small lion casting his eye across his future prefecture. His small eye is twinkling, because he's proud that he'll one day be prefect, and this prefecture will be his.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None This small lion's prefecture is being protected by Ken (けん) the samurai, because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one prefecture is nothing to him. Picture Ken protecting the prefecture, punching hyenas in the face, and yelling, "This may just be a prefecture, not a country, but I'll give it my all for my lion prefect-to-be!"

mnemonics.meaning: Preserve Guarantee The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is all about trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">preserve</mark> the trees. In fact, she <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guarantee</mark>s that she will preserve the trees if it's the last thing she does. Basically, a tree leader is someone who stands up for trees. Mostly she talks, but that can be a powerful skill to have.
mnemonics.reading: ほ たも None She chains herself to a tree to preserve them. But, unfortunately, the lumberjacks just take a giant back hoe (ほ) and tear this tree leader and the tree she's attached to in half. What a terrible scene. Focus on the fact that they're using a horrible, modified back hoe. It's more like a weapon than a back hoe, and they show no mercy at all.

mnemonics.meaning: Return Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return</mark> it. Unfortunately, now you have to return to the store to return this scooter, but you have no scooter to get there with. Ugh.
mnemonics.reading: へん かえ None You return to the store and wait in line to return the scooter but the person working returns doesn't want you to return it. He stares you dead in the eyes, waves his hand, and turns you into a hen (へん)! The employee leans down toward you in hen form and says, "Ooh, I'm sorry. We don't take returns from hens. You'll have to just return home."

mnemonics.meaning: Ride You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;) Just imagine you're a car or a train and the grain is a person. It's going for a nice ride in your mouth!
mnemonics.reading: じょう の None You decide the grain is probably lonely on this ride alone, so you add some nori (の) seaweed, so it has a friend. Now the nori is going for a ride too, woohoo!

mnemonics.meaning: Roof Shop, Store You plant a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, marking your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> patch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. In this spot you raise a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">roof</mark>, then fill the space beneath it with some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">store</mark>s. That's the natural next progression of claiming some land. Building a roof upon it and building some shops and stores inside. You'll see why in a moment.
mnemonics.reading: おく や None The roof covering the dirt is there so that the Yankees (や) can play baseball year round. The stores and shops are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia. You have yourself a whole Yankees stadium, and all it took was a roof and some shops and stores! If you build it, they will come.

mnemonics.meaning: Sell A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> has come bearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> that he's trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sell</mark>. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay? Imagine running into this samurai salesman as you walk through a sketchy part of town. He cautiously glances over his shoulder before opening his trench coat to reveal to you… all the foreheads and legs he's trying to sell.
mnemonics.reading: ばい う None If you run into this samurai who sells severed foreheads and legs, you should just say "bye (ばい)!" and get the heck out of there. Actually, if anyone tries to sell you severed body parts — samurai or not — you should probably say bye over and over until you can get away from them. Imagine loudly saying "bye" over and over at this shady samurai. He keeps trying to tell you about how fresh and high-quality all his foreheads and legs are, but you just loudly repeat "bye" as you back away from him.

mnemonics.meaning: Send On its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, a creature with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> will take things you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">send</mark> there. Picture the horned thing on its scooter, a big messenger bag over its shoulder with the kanji for heaven on it. "You got somethin' you want me to send?" it mutters.
mnemonics.reading: そう おく None You want to send your soul (そう) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul? You put your soul into an envelope, stick a stamp on it, and hand it off to be sent to heaven. Bye-bye! I hope this doesn't have any negative effects on your body!

mnemonics.meaning: Spicy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spicy</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
mnemonics.reading: しん から, つら None When you eat spicy food, it gives a からて chop to your mouth. That's where that spicy feeling comes from! Imagine a bunch of little black belt spice molecules からて punching, kicking and chopping all the way through your mouth and into your throat and nasal passages. Oww, it's pure agony!

mnemonics.meaning: Suffering The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> have grown <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark>, so they're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suffering</mark>. Flowers, like anything that grows old, go through a lot of suffering as their bodies break down. They're no different from you and me.
mnemonics.reading: く くる, にが None If a flower or a person is growing old and suffering, give them a cookie (く). No one can resist a good cookie. It will ease your suffering, or at least distract you for a little bit.

mnemonics.meaning: Swim If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is going to last an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> you better learn how to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swim</mark> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it. Picture most of the earth's population already swimming on the tsunami that will last the rest of eternity. Your floaties and life preservers would help you through this mess. You need to swim!
mnemonics.reading: えい およ None Oy (およ)! Oy, stop daydreaming about swimming and actually do it! Picture yourself swimming in the tsunami with everyone else. You can't really talk to them, you're too busy swimming for your life, so you just shout "Oy!" to them and they shout it back.

mnemonics.meaning: Talk You  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> things around a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>. In fact there are two  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>s, and you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>ing with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires. Imagine yourself next to the two campfires, having a heart-to-heart talk. What are you saying?
mnemonics.reading: だん None None You talk in this intense, fiery way all the way until dawn (だん), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded. If you try to talk all night and past dawn, you'll burn out. Take the day, think, then tonight you can try to have an all-night talk again.

mnemonics.meaning: Temporary Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is very <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-everything, making it all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temporary</mark>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" she yells, and out it goes. She tires of things so quickly, you hardly have time to get used to them before they're gone.
mnemonics.reading: か, け かり, か None The leader's most temporary possession is her car (か). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. She buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly she's anti red car. She needs a blue one! Picture all of the temporary cars she's tried filling up an entire junkyard. They're all a little different, but in the end they were all just temporary fads.

mnemonics.meaning: Test A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> are going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">test</mark> you. Imagine the horse and squid in a big testing room, getting ready to test you. What are they testing you on? Weirdly, they're going to test you on all the kanji that use horse and squid radicals. You ready?
mnemonics.reading: けん ため, ためし None The test is being supervised by Ken (けん) the samurai. To make sure you don't cheat on the horse and the squid test, Ken the samurai is watching you closely, pacing up and down. Every now and then, he waves his katana menacingly.

mnemonics.meaning: Thing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark>s is flying in the air. What a strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thing</mark>! You've heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing. Imagine if cows could fly. Wouldn't you be jealous of them? I mean, if a cow can fly, any old thing should be able to, right?
mnemonics.reading: ぶつ, もつ もの None You want a thing to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying boots (ぶつ). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up. Imagine a thing like flying boots. Do you believe such a thing could be real?

mnemonics.meaning: Tool There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, among some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. What happened? You killed a fish, and now you you must hide the murder <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tool</mark>. Quick, hide the tool before someone finds out it was you. You feel the panic upon realizing what you've just done. This is murder in the first degree. You used a terrible tool to do it, and now you must hide it.
mnemonics.reading: ぐ None None The tool is dripping with goo (ぐ). Goopy, incriminating goo. It's the guts of the fish you just killed and it's all over your hands too. Yuck. That goo is really slimy. It's disgusting. You feel sick to your stomach. Please don't throw up, there's already enough junk on the ground with the eye and fins and all.

mnemonics.meaning: Truth Reality, Fruit Climb onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> to see the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">truth</mark>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reality</mark> of what it is all around you. Imagine sitting comfortably on your roof as the world around you changes to spring. Snow melts and reveals all of the truths that have been obscured and hidden in winter.
mnemonics.reading: じつ み, みの None At the moment, you're trying to learn the truth about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! Gee! Two (じつ) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow. Gee! Two babies! Reality sure is lovely.

mnemonics.meaning: Try Attempt If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> workers you're going to have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">try</mark> really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attempt</mark> to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards. Try to imagine trying this hard to be heard. The construction workers are all screaming at each other with ease. It's so hard for you to try and keep up with their volume!
mnemonics.reading: し こころ, ため None You try to get their attention the only way you know how, by lifting a sheep (し) above your head. The sheep baas and suddenly everything is silent, all eyes are on you. Well, they're on the sheep. Huh. You should have thought to try this sheep technique earlier.

mnemonics.meaning: Use A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can put the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">history</mark> to great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">use</mark>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people. Smell the ground. Waft the earthy smell of history into your leader-like nostrils. What does it smell like? It smells useful. And also like ground.
mnemonics.reading: し つか None You use the ground to raise sheep (し). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep. When you use the ground for sheep like this, your people rejoice. You're the best leader ever! You always use everything to your advantage!

mnemonics.meaning: Win Victory The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> grants a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> so he will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">win</mark>! <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Victory</mark> will be his! Watch as the moon's power fills the gladiator. He starts to glow, grows larger, and has some craters on his face now. Well.. okay.
mnemonics.reading: しょう か None He wins over and over again, and soon the Shougun (しょう) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice. The Shougun is only interested in people who win. But you probably could have guessed that already.

mnemonics.meaning: World Every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> sits <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jammed in</mark> to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">world</mark>. The world is basically just a bunch of rice paddies smooshed together, if you think about it.
mnemonics.reading: かい None None To get around this world of rice paddies, you need to use a kayak (かい). A rice paddy is mostly made up of water, just like our world, and you don't want to have wet feet. Use the power of your kayak to become a world traveler.

mnemonics.meaning: Advance You give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> so that it can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">advance</mark>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance. Imagine picking up the turkey and putting it on your scooter. Of course, you give it your helmet as well, safety first.
mnemonics.reading: しん すす None You wave as the turkey advances into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its shins (しん) almost immediately. Ah! Silly turkey, you can't advance that fast, of course you'll hurt your shins. It's better to advance slowly, but I guess I couldn't expect you to know that.

mnemonics.meaning: Alcohol A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>ic beverage containing a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alcohol</mark>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it. It’s made with spiced rum, coconut rum, and dark rum. Imagine yourself on a sandy beach drinking this cocktail. Feel the sun on your face and the wind in your hair as you sip on this fruity and rummy alcoholic beverage known as a tsunami. You could even picture an actual tsunami in the water coming right for you. I wouldn’t recommend it though—actual tsunami are scary, not drinkable and delicious.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ さけ, さか None As you lie on this beach, the alcohol keeps coming down a chute (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute. Picture the alcohol flowing down this long chute from somewhere far away. You try to see where it's coming from, but all you can see is this long, long chute stretching along the entire beach, until it disappears into the distance. You should probably be concerned that you're nonstop drinking alcohol from a random chute, but it tastes so good!

mnemonics.meaning: Begin Start If you give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> she'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">begin</mark> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">start</mark> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines! Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up.
mnemonics.reading: し はじ None Actually, before she can begin, she has to shear the sheep (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe! Picture a machine starting up as the woman begins to shear the sheep. Picture the sheep staring at you, staring at it.

mnemonics.meaning: Business You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. Turn this thing into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">business</mark>! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep! Imagine all the money you'll rake in with this new business. People will come from far and wide to see the spiky mer-sheep sideshow. And for an extra charge you'll let 'em touch those pointy spikes and slimy fins. Oh yes, business will be booming.
mnemonics.reading: ぎょう None None As you evolve your business, you let customers feed the sheep gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings, its favorite snack. For a nominal fee, of course. People love it when the mutant sheep eats gyoza out of their hands. Wouldn't you? Imagine the smell of garlicky gyoza filling the sideshow tent, as customers try to feed the sheep and compete for its attention. Business is so good that the sheep gets tired of gyoza and won't eat it anymore. Oh well… Skewer them on its spikes and save 'em for later.

mnemonics.meaning: Calculate Calculation If someone sticks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> times, the first thing your brain does is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calculate</mark> how painful it is. Your brain's pain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calculation</mark> will determine how you calculate your next move. Your next move is to go to the doctor, because your brain has calculated that the pain is extreme. Imagine the doctor asking how much it hurts. Well, on a scale of one to ten, doctor, I'd calculate this is about a twenty.
mnemonics.reading: さん そろ None Next you want to calculate how much punishment your bamboo attacker deserves, so you call on Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is always calculating how many pieces of coal the naughty children deserve, so he's perfect for this calculation job. Imagine trekking through the frozen wastes of the North Pole (with your eye patch on) to obtain Santa-san's calculation advice. After much discussion, his concludes that your bamboo attacker deserves twenty. No, not twenty years in prison — just twenty pieces of coal. Oh, how disappointing…

mnemonics.meaning: Carry Luck While riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you bang your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry</mark> it home. You'll need a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luck</mark> to get that scooter home safely. Imagine trying to carry your scooter down a busy road, with all the cars whizzing past. Your forehead is still hurting from that nasty bang. Good luck!
mnemonics.reading: うん はこ None As you carry the scooter, your luck turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your umbrella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella. It's hard enough to carry a scooter in heavy traffic, but now you have to try to keep yourself and it dry with an umbrella too.

mnemonics.meaning: Chinese Man, China A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit ancient <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">China</mark> and formed the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Chinese</mark> country we know now as... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">China</mark>! Sometimes this kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">man</mark>. In fact, it used to refer specifically to people of the Han dynasty, but over time evolved into a term for men in specific contexts. Picture the world way far away, from space. You see a giant tsunami carve out a massive chunk of land to the west of Japan on the main continent. Slowly the tsunami waters recede, leaving the outline of China.
mnemonics.reading: かん おとこ None You peer closer at China and see one man, Genghis Khan (かん), leading his troops into the vast country, ready to conquer all the Chinese people living in China! Khan is only one man, but watch as he takes China for himself. A tiny little flag with a horse on it is raised in the middle, for all of the Chinese people to see. Hmm, this could be a problem.

mnemonics.meaning: Chirp When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> opens, you're most likely to hear a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chirp</mark>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp! Imagine yourself out in the wilderness on a sunny day. The weather is perfect and the scenery is beautiful. The only sound you can hear is the chirp of birds throughout the woods around you. It's very peaceful.
mnemonics.reading: めい な None The best way to experience the chirp-chirping of birds is to offer them nachos (な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight. Picture yourself surrounded by birds of all kinds, handing out nachos. Just listen to their happy chirping. They're sitting on your arms, shoulders, and even your head, trying to get closer to the nachos. That chirping is so loud!

mnemonics.meaning: Collect Gather You chase a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collect</mark> it. At least, you will once you've <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gather</mark>ed enough turkeys into this one tree. Collect another turkey, send it flying and gobbling up into the tree next to the other one.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう あつ None Once you've collected enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a shoe (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean gathering even more turkeys! Picture the nice, feathered shoes you'll be able to make once you've gathered all of these turkeys together. Ohoho, you can't wait! Go collect another turkey!

mnemonics.meaning: Distribute You don't want to keep all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to yourself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>), so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distribute</mark> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find! Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
mnemonics.reading:
はい くば None As you distribute the alcohol you say a haiku (はい): Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.

mnemonics.meaning: Drink You can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> all you want, but you'll still <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> something to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drink</mark>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too! Imagine eating and eating and lacking a delicious, cold, thirst-quenching drink. Your mouth is dry. You have to drink something, anything!
mnemonics.reading: いん の None You get desperate for a drink and put some nori (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own. Luckily, this nori isn't dried and pressed like they usually are, and you manage to make a bright green nori drink. You gulp it down, and even though it tastes like the ocean, it hits the spot!

mnemonics.meaning: End Finish The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> has brought this year to its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">end</mark>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon. Picture the season of winter as a long thread, embalmed in ice. At the end of it is the year’s end. The thread of winter and ice brings you closure, it marks the end.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう おわ, お None Whenever winter ends, you take the thread covered in ice, and lace it into your shoe (しゅう). This thread isn't just a metaphor, it's real! Feel the cold ice on it, as you lace it into your shoe. An age old tradition, the lacing of icy threads as winter ends. Your shoes will look so cool, or should I say… iced out.

mnemonics.meaning: Face You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>'s breadth away from the edge, when out of nowhere a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> slaps you in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">face</mark>. The force makes you back away from the edge of the cliff, and your face is all slimy from the geoduck's residue. Imagine being slapped in the face with a geoduck — a sharp hot pain, which then mingles with the cold geoduck residue left behind on your face. It's a strange, contradictory sensation.
mnemonics.reading: がん かお None But where did that geoduck come from? As you turn from the cliff edge, you find yourself face-to-face with a cow (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with a geoduck. You don't know why, but something about your face has upset the cow. Cows are big animals. So you probably got hit in the face with that geoduck pretty hard. Imagine the lingering pain, and how indignant you'd feel. Imagine getting in that cow's face and demanding an explanation.

mnemonics.meaning: Fall <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are knocked down by a violent <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, and swirl through the air to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> your face gently as they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fall</mark>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew the flowers down. Amongst all the destruction, it's a pretty sight to watch them fall. Imagine being out in this tsunami-induced storm. You're wet, cold, and scared, but you're calmed and mesmerized by how the flowers dance in the wind before they finally fall.
mnemonics.reading: らく お None You want to save these flowers that fall around you, so you take out a drying rack (らく) and place them carefully on it. Any flowers that fall will go on the rack like this, so can save them for later. Imagine running around catching the flowers as they fall. Imagine placing each fallen petal onto the rack to keep it safe and dry.

mnemonics.meaning: Farming Agriculture You blast your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> loud so it causes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark>, revealing the perfect soil for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">farming</mark>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agriculture</mark>. Imagine slowly turning up your big boombox until your ears hurt and the ground beneath your feet is vibrating with the beat. Soon you and the boombox are sliding with all of the earth down the hill and onto your farmland. Hooray, now the farming can begin!
mnemonics.reading: のう None None The first person to come up with this farming method was Nostradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth." Picture Nostradamus flailing his arms and trying to explain his vision to the farmers at the time. He knows that if they listen their farming techniques will improve, but they're looking at him like he's nuts.

mnemonics.meaning: Fast You jump on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> to go as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fast</mark> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there! Imagine how fast you can go on your scooter holding this bundle. It's way faster than trying to go on foot, that's for sure!
mnemonics.reading: そく はや None You were going so fast, you only put on socks (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks. Imagine riding the scooter as fast as you can in just your socks. You can feel the wind pulling them off your feet!

mnemonics.meaning: Finish Complete, End Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">finish</mark>ed. Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None How does the fish lure maker test his newly finished lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a row (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea. Make him think that he can’t just use his new lure on the side of the lake / ocean / whatever. He has to get out there, but unfortunately all he has is a crappy row boat. Imagine the row boat being terrible, leaky, and dangerous, which is why you’re surprised when he goes for it. That’s a terrible row boat to use! If you do this, you'll focus your mind on the rowboat part of things, which will help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Head If you feed a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">head</mark> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, it can grow an incredibly large head. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads. Imagine, if you will, a geoduck. Now imagine it with a massive head. It looks ridiculous, and more disgusting than ever. It's actually really creeping you out, because the head keeps getting larger as the geoduck eats more beans. Ew.
mnemonics.reading: ず, とう あたま, かしら None As the geoduck eats more and more beans its head gets bigger and bigger, until finally the head explodes like an atomic (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of its massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout. Remember how gross geoducks are? Of course you do. Now imagine one exploding its atomic head right in front of you. You've got geoduck mess all over yourself. It's gross, slimy, sticky, and covering you from head to toe. It's wretched.

mnemonics.meaning: Hear If you go up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> and press your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> to it, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hear</mark> what's going on on the other side. The people on the other side will have no idea you can hear their conversation. I'm sure you've pressed your ear up against a wall, door, or gate before to hear what's going on on the other side. Remember back to a time you did this and how sneaky you felt listening in on people without them knowing. You sneaky frood, you.
mnemonics.reading: ぶん, もん き None From the other side of the gate, you hear one of the people start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as "Hot Cross Buns (ぶん)." You haven't heard this song since grade school. "Hot cross buns, hot cross buns~" I'm sure many of you were forced to play "Hot Cross Buns" on the recorder in school at some point. Picture yourself playing this song and remember the melody when you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Institution This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and will teach you about the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of many things. It's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">institution</mark>! Institutions are places of learning, but they have to be a physical place with a roof and all that. If you're learning out in a field somewhere, that's probably not a proper institution.
mnemonics.reading: いん None None What does institution start with? In (いん)! Just remember, it's an IN-stitution, and you'll know this reading easy-peasy.

mnemonics.meaning: Investigate Tone You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something about the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">investigate</mark> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tone</mark> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them. Because the radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> is in play, you can think of the crime scene you're investigating as a statue of a giant globe, and you're doing a circumference around it. Then, in the reading, we'll think about what you'll <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう しら None "I came here to investigate this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!" From what you know about evil Mrs. Chou, you probably could have guessed it was her. The "Circumference Investigation" is now over, though you do still have to catch the perp, Mrs. Chou.

mnemonics.meaning: Iron You look at some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and notice a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">iron</mark>! You think you've found a ton of gold bars! Imagine being so happy about this. Then, imagine your heart dropping in your chest when you notice the fault. Then, it dropping down even farther when you figure out it's merely iron.
mnemonics.reading: てつ None None Do you know that movie, Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever. Watch a trailer on YouTube for Tetsuo the Iron Man. Go ahead, do it now – I’ll wait. Did you watch it? Remember that nonsense every time you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Language What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> between <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">language</mark>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language. Picture these five mouths saying the same language to each other. They can understand each other! The mouths are smiling and laughing too.
mnemonics.reading: ご かた None Another mouth joins in speaking the language, but it's green and scaled and... it's Godzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too. Godzilla speaks a language some people understand! You wish you knew this earlier, then you might have been able to stop some of his destruction. Try to say, "Hey Godzilla, please stop destroying my city," in his language. It's a lot of growling and yelling. He doesn't seem to understand you. You better practice your pronunciation.

mnemonics.meaning: Leaf Leaves <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> bring beauty to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trees</mark>, but the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leaf</mark> is what matters the most. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Leaves</mark> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun! Leaves, no matter how little, are the most important thing in the world for them.
mnemonics.reading: よう は, ば None Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The leaf pops out and it shouts, "Ha (は)!" は is the sound of a leaf coming into existence. Whenever you see a plant from now on, hear the little "ha" sound it makes when each leaf pops out of its body.

mnemonics.meaning: Learn You find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> that are so perfectly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>, you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">learn</mark> more about where they came from and what they're made of. Picture yourself in a library poring through huge tomes on feathers, specifically for completely white ones. You want to learn everything you can!
mnemonics.reading: しゅう なら None You learn that you should tie these white feathers to your shoes (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building. Oh geez, oh no. You better learn how to control these shoes before you—CRASH!!! Welp, you just shot through a plane. You need to learn more before you act next time.

mnemonics.meaning: Lightweight Light, Light Weight For a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lightweight</mark>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">light</mark> and easy to transport. Picture yourself trying to move a huge slab tombstone. It’s difficult, no? I bet you wish you had a car or some other vehicle to make the process much less painful. Your arms are getting sore from carrying the tombstone and you’re getting sweaty and hot from all the work. What you would do for a car with air conditioning.
mnemonics.reading: けい かる, かろ None What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of car loophole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but lightweight pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole. Remember all that hard work you were doing before and how you got all sweaty and gross? Now imagine yourself inside of a nice car with air conditioning, and the tombstone in the trunk. It feels great doesn’t it? The air conditioning is perfect, and driving a car is much easier than carrying a tombstone around. Thank goodness you found a car loophole in the tombstone carrying rules.

mnemonics.meaning: Line You can use a long piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> during <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> rafting as a safety <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">line</mark>. Sure it's thin, but if someone goes overboard even a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard! Imagine you're the person who fell overboard. The white water is rushing violently and it is deathly cold. Feel the water and freezing temperature on your skin. But look! Someone has thrown you a line of thread! You're saved!
mnemonics.reading: せん None None The person who threw you that line of thread is actually a centaur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off. Coming out of the rushing water, this centaur is like an angel sent from heaven. He's just saved your life. Imagine the happiness and gratitude you feel towards this centaur as you are pulled to safety by that line of thread.

mnemonics.meaning: Most Let the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shine into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> while sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and make sure <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">most</mark> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has. Most of the sun is getting into your ear, but not all of it. Darn, maybe you should try angling yourself a different way.
mnemonics.reading: さい もっと None Most of this is for your cyborg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts. Install the part into your cyborg. As long as most of the sun gets into its human ear, most of its cyborg bits will have power.

mnemonics.meaning: Open A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">open</mark> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help. Imagine being a traveler, walking around the outside of a huge walled city. You really need to get inside but all of the gates are closed. Finally, you see a single, bright lantern marking the open gate! What a relief.
mnemonics.reading: かい あ, ひら None This open gate is in the water though, so you'll need a kayak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case. Imagine kayaking in the dark toward an open gate. Finally, you've made it!

mnemonics.meaning: Page Did you know that those strange <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> creatures were once used to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">page</mark>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image! Imagine the strange, gooey books you'd end up with if you used geoducks for pages. Now imagine flicking through one of those books, and getting the slimy geoduck residue on your hands as you look at the pages.
mnemonics.reading: けつ, よう ページ, ぺーじ, かしら None A page is a page (ページ). Since the reading comes from the English word "page", this one shouldn't be too hard to remember, especially if you've already come across it in katakana.

mnemonics.meaning: Parent Intimacy If you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">parent</mark>, it's a good chance for a moment of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intimacy</mark>. Imagine yourself standing in the shade of a beautiful, big, old tree. You see your parent walk past and shout out to them. They come and join you, and it's like the two of you are the only two people in the world right now. That's intimacy.
mnemonics.reading: しん おや, した None Standing under the tree, you go to give your parent a big hug, but you manage to bang your shin (しん) on a huge tree root. Your parent pulls you in for a warm hug and rubs your shin. Despite the pain, it becomes an unforgettable "shin-timate" moment. Busting your shins on things really hurts. I'm sure you've hit your shins on coffee tables and the like all your life. Remember that pain and think how much worse it would be banging your bare shins on pointy tree roots just when you were enjoying a moment of parental intimacy. Not enjoyable.

mnemonics.meaning: Public You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public</mark>. Picture yourself in private, with fins. You wish others could see them. "That's it," you decide. "It's time to show the world. I'm going to make my fins public!"
mnemonics.reading: こう None None You head out into the public where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of こういちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't). How long have you been hiding in private with your fins? The public areas have changed, and all the people have become こういちs. One mother こういち--pushing a baby こういち--looks up and stares at your fins. Now you remember why you never go out in public.

mnemonics.meaning: Read You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what you’re <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sell</mark>ing because people don’t like to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">read</mark>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them. Imagine reading what you have for sale out loud to people walking by because they’re too lazy to read it for themselves.
mnemonics.reading: とう, どく, とく よ None What are you forced to read aloud to sell? Yo-yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them. Imagine reading through your list of yo-yo tricks. Do you know how to pronounce those weird yo-yo names?

mnemonics.meaning: Request Look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>! You spilled some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s, so I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark> that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right? It's a simple request, really. Just wipe up those water drops off the ground.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう もと None Oh, one more thing. I request that you wipe up the water with this cucumber (きゅう). "But cucumbers are already mostly water, this isn't going to absorb anything!" you cry. Well, too bad. That's my request, so you better do it. Figure out how to make the cucumber work.

mnemonics.meaning: Revolve If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> runs into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolve</mark> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway. Imagine driving your car around and around the cloud, instead of going through it. At least it's soft and cool.
mnemonics.reading: てん ころ None You have to revolve around the cloud ten (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through. Unfortunately, not long after you get through that cloud another one comes down and gets in your way. Now you're counting each revolution, one... two... three... all the way up to ten.

mnemonics.meaning: Road If you've been walking all day, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> is the last thing anyone would want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, especially after wandering barefoot down a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">road</mark>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet. Imagine kissing someone's foot. Now imagine kissing someone's foot after they've been walking down a road for hours. It's disgusting. Smell the stench of sweat wafting up into your nostrils as the foot approaches your lips. It's wretched.
mnemonics.reading: ろ じ, みち None What was this person walking down again? Oh, that's right – a road (ろ). They were walking down a filthy road. Walking down a road barefoot like this is a sure way to dirty up your feet. Feel the dirt, rocks, and twigs under your feet. The road is hard and dry and is not making your journey very comfortable at all.

mnemonics.meaning: Sick Sickness, Ill, Illness A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> stick of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dynamite</mark> is going to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sick</mark> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good. Imagine if you were a sick stick of dynamite. Every time you sneezed you ran the risk of blowing up. It would be a terrifying way to live. Just imagine it.
mnemonics.reading: びょう, へい や, やまい None Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? B.O. (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being sick is no excuse. Picture this as your life. You could explode at any moment, you’re sick, and you have B.O. Nobody wants to be around you because you might explode and kill them, and you stink. What a terrible way to live!
