mnemonics.meaning: Side Horizontal The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> marked with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yellow</mark> X on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm. Picture the scene of a woman with a chainsaw cutting down this tree marked with a yellow X. Hear the sound of the chainsaw buzzing and the grinding of wood as it meets the side of the trunk. It’s very loud. Woodchips go flying everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: おう よこ None Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is Yoko (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the side of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko. Now picture the same scene as before only imagining Yoko Ono wielding that chainsaw. Maybe she’s dancing. Maybe there’s some Beatles music playing in the background. Either way it’s a strange sight – remember it.

mnemonics.meaning: Solve Untie <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Angle</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> correctly at this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solve</mark> its riddle. The key is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">untie</mark> the cow with the sword without hurting it. Will you be able to solve this cow riddle? Picture yourself carefully trying to untie a cow with a sword at just the right angle. What a tricky thing to solve.
mnemonics.reading: かい と None Did I mention that you have to solve this whole riddle while on a kayak (かい)? No?! Whoops. So you're on a kayak, with a cow, and you have to find just the right angle with your sword in order to untie the cow and solve this riddle. A bit much to wrap one's head around. Anyway, good luck with that.

mnemonics.meaning: Song Sing If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> (or two in this case) is what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>, it's going to be way easier for you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sing</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">song</mark>. Imagine singing a song with a couple lip rings in your mouth. The articulation will be all wrong! It's definitely better to lack lip rings if you're going to sing.
mnemonics.reading: か うた None Where are you always singing songs, by the way? In your car (か). It's not just you, either. Pretty much everyone likes to sing in their car. There's something about your car that makes your singing sound so much better than usual, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Straight Direct, Fix This kanji is the same as the radical — <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straight</mark> as straight can be. It can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">direct</mark>, because when you go straight to a place, you're going there directly. Depending on the context it can even mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fix</mark>, since fixing something means straightening out all the messed up crooked bits. Here's some straight talk for ya: if you study your radicals, you'll have no problem with this one.
mnemonics.reading: ちょく, じき なお None Put food straight into your esophagus without chewing and you will choke (ちょく). You want to get straight to the most important part of eating — the digesting part — but if you don't follow all the intermediate steps, you'll end up choking. Imagine shoving food straight down your esophagus and choking as you do. Why would you do this to yourself?!

mnemonics.meaning: Wake Up <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Run</mark> into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> in a dream and you'll definitely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wake up</mark>. If you run into yourself, it really messes you up, you know? You won't be able to handle what you're seeing so you have to wake up.
mnemonics.reading: き お None If one runs into oneself and you don't wake up, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an obi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from. Your obi is like a special object you only have in dreams. If you have your obi, it's okay, it's a dream and you can wake up now! Make sure you memorize exactly how it feels so dream-you can't trick you or something.

mnemonics.meaning: Achievement Accomplishment Using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you build something great. A true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">achievement</mark> built for the achievement of making kanji learning easier! Just constructing this thing was an achievement. Feel proud like it was, well, an achievement.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None This achievement was made possible by こういち, so of course this construction project is a giant statue of the man himself. What an achievement of a statue. What an achievement of an achievement. Thanks こういち. Now everyone will know of your achievements around kanji learning and inside-out earth theory. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading. Remember that, because it comes up quite a bit!

mnemonics.meaning: Become When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> holds a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">becomes</mark> something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does. Picture the drunkard standing in front of you. He picked up the sword and is holding it above his head. It's becoming... becoming...
mnemonics.reading: せい, じょう な None The sword has become a saber (せい)! It's just like the saber you have! Hey, wait. If a sword becomes a saber in the hands of a drunkard... then what are you? Geez this became pretty deep. You slice down the drunkard with your saber and become a little more depressed than you were before.

mnemonics.meaning: Coast Shore The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> from the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coast</mark> below. Just from looking at the raging <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shore</mark> below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere! You're on top of the mountain and the entire coast is stretching out below. The shore goes as far as your eyes can see.
mnemonics.reading: がん きし None Sitting up there, watching the coast with you, is Gandhi (がん). The world famous Gandhi, is just hanging out up here with you, looking down at what you now realize must be a coast in India. Sit down next to Gandhi and close your eyes. You can hear the water hitting the shore below. The coastal birds are screaming. You crack open an eye and see Gandhi still sitting perfectly still.

mnemonics.meaning: Compete <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stand</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark>. Now <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> again. You wish to stand on, and above, your older brother. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compete</mark> over and over again, to stand atop your older brother. Imagine yourself standing on your older brother. They push you off. So you do it again. You want to be on top, but your older brother doesn't want you to. You compete for the top spot over and over again, throughout your whole life, because that's what one does with their older brother.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, けい きそ None You compete with your older brother because only one of you may go to きょうと. Whoever stands on top the most gets to go to きょうと, so you must compete for a spot. Imagine yourself competing to stand on top of your older brother. Do you win? Do you get the one ticket to きょうと?

mnemonics.meaning: Conflict In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> gets picked on for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>s coming out of his hands. This creates a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conflict</mark> between him and the other prisoners. They don't take kindly to mutants, and Wolverine doesn't take kindly to bigots — hence the conflict. Picture one Wolverine versus, like, a hundred prisoners. Who would win? Yeah, my money's on the mutant in this conflict.
mnemonics.reading: そう あらそ None This constant conflict between Wolverine and the other inmates is really affecting his soul (そう). Despite what people think, Wolverine really doesn't like to fight. He just hates injustice so much, he feels he has to do something about it. Put yourself in Wolverine's shoes. Imagine what it would feel like to have conflicting values, what it would do to your soul. Wanting to be peaceful on the one hand, but on the other not wanting to allow bigotry of any kind. It's a conflict in your soul.

mnemonics.meaning: Convenience Convenient A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> stands upon the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. She is searching for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. It is said that this treasure here in this rice field will make things much easier for the leader (that's what leaders really want, after all). If she gets this treasure, it will be a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">convenience</mark> for her, because convenience is everything when you're the leader. Imagine the leader looking around the rice paddy. She keeps saying, "Ugh, it would be convenient if I didn't have to walk around out here looking for the treasure that's going to make things more convenient for me. Ugh." Go ahead and say this phrase out loud, too, pretending to be the leader in the rice paddy. Feel the cold and the wet, making it less convenient for you.
mnemonics.reading: べん, びん たよ None She finds a place to dig in the ground. It looks like there's some fresh dirt here. Finally, the treasure of convenience that will make this leader's life so much easier. She digs into the ground and pulls out a box. When she opens it, she finds out it's a bento (べん). "My god," she thinks. "This really will make my life more convenient. My people can take their lunches with them now instead of coming back to base to eat, which will waste way less time!" Feel the happiness that the leader would feel at this revelation. It will make everything much more convenient for her, since she's not the one doing all the manual labor. She won't have to eat out of a bento, that's for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Elderly By the time you finish digging a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> hole with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, you’ll be an old <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elderly</mark> person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over. Imagine yourself digging a coffin hole with nothing but a spoon. Your hands get all cramped, your wrist starts to hurt, and you get painful blisters on your hands. It takes forever to dig a hole big enough for a coffin!
mnemonics.reading: ろう None None Now that you’re elderly (and probably about to die) you suddenly crave some delicious roe (ろう). Salmon roe, sea urchin roe, tofugu roe, doesn’t matter. Your old, tired bones need roe after all that hard work! You hated roe when you were still young, but now that you’re an elderly old fart you really want to eat it. Roe is for old people, you guess, as you slurp it up.

mnemonics.meaning: Fate Life <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Orders</mark> coming from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> will determine the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fate</mark> of your soldiers. You are their commanding officer and your orders determine their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">life</mark> and death. Pretend you are a high ranking officer and imagine yourself giving orders to your underlings. Imagine all the power and influence you have. It feels good.
mnemonics.reading: めい, みょう いのち None You are the commanding officer on the Mayflower (めい). You give orders to colonize America. The orders spewing from your mouth hole determine the fate of the settlers and the fate of America and the fate of the world! You and the Mayflower have changed everything forever. Students of American history are very familiar with the Mayflower. Recall learning about it in school whenever you see this kanji. Or look it up on Wikipedia if you don’t know about it. The Mayflower is a big deal!

mnemonics.meaning: Finger Try to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> out some of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and you'll come back with just one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">finger</mark>. Look down at your finger and the burned stumps where the rest of your fingers used to be. It hurts. And you're sad. But at least you still have one finger left.
mnemonics.reading: し ゆび, さ None Don't worry, you aren't the only one out there with just one finger, sheep (し) only have one finger too. I mean, they're hooves, which are really just a single animal finger. It's just big and kind of flat. Picture sitting with a sheep. It's right across from you, staring into your eyes. It reaches out its sheep finger hoof and you reach out with your finger. They touch. It's magical.

mnemonics.meaning: First If you want a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>, you have to be the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">first</mark> one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything. Imagine it like commenting on Youtube or Facebook. If you can say FIRST, first, well congrats. You win the internet spirit sword.
mnemonics.reading: しょ はじ, はつ, そ, ぞ None If you were lucky enough to be the first one to find the spirit sword, you should open up a small show (しょ) to show it off! And then you can make yourself the first in line every day to see the show. This is the first show of this type, anywhere in the world!

mnemonics.meaning: Flavor Taste In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> dropping <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flavor</mark> bombs. Every time you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">taste</mark> something, it's actually because a tiny jet has flown into your mouth to bomb you with flavor. What's your favorite food? Imagine that, as you bite into it, tiny jets are released from inside the food to attack your tongue with flavor bombs, stimulating your sense of taste.
mnemonics.reading: み あじ None And what has more flavor than a big slab of meat (み)? You love meat and its flavor nearly as much as you love the taste of its juice. So many good things to put in your mouth! Of course, if you're vegetarian imagine the flavor of the meat being terrible. Up to you. Make the mnemonic work for your lifestyle.

mnemonics.meaning: Follow Chase On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on its head trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">follow</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chase</mark> you! You accidentally splashed it with water and it's not happy about it. You're on your own scooter, luckily, but that doesn't make this any less terrifying. Picture the bear on its scooter with the offending drop of water on its head following really closely behind your scooter. You can almost feel his bear breath on your neck!
mnemonics.reading: つい お None The bear is trying to follow you because it wants your obi (お) as compensation for its injured pride. The obi is waving in the wind behind your scooter, and the bear is reaching out with its teeth to try and grab it. Picture the bear chasing you on its scooter, trying to reach out and grab the obi off your waist. The drop of water on its head is jiggling from the exertion. Woah, it's getting a little too close!

mnemonics.meaning: God Spirit Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> should feel <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> before a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">god</mark>'s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark>. You never really feel humble in front of anyone else, but if you meet a god's spirit… Well, you should probably lower yourself appropriately. Gods have powerful spirits. Imagine a spirit appearing before you. It's a god. You should be as humble as possible. Out of respect and also because you don't want to be cursed or something.
mnemonics.reading: しん, じん かみ None When you meet a god's spirit, you need to get down on your shins (しん). Get down on your ankles? No, not low enough. Knees? No, no, get your shins flat on the ground to show how humble you really are. Luckily, you're wearing jeans (じん), so at least that will stop your poor shins getting chafed! If you don't get down on your shins before god's spirit, it could take them away. Even your jeans couldn't protect you then. You don't want to live a shin-less life, do you?

mnemonics.meaning: Good A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good</mark>. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too. Imagine putting a little drop of water over a root you want to grow. Doing this is good for the plant and also good for your soul.
mnemonics.reading: りょう よ, い None A good way to get a lot of drops of water for your roots is to buy a row boat (りょう). Then just row out to the middle of the lake and plonk all the roots right into the source! Rowing even feels good on your arms and back. Probably just as good as all these roots will feel.

mnemonics.meaning: Idea The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> gives me an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">idea</mark>. The methodic thump thump thumping of a heart puts me in a trance that gives me great ideas. It’s a very inspirational sound, the sound of a heart is. It gives me an idea. Alternatively, you could look at this kanji and see a "stand" radical and something that kind of (almost) looks like the kanji for "think." When you stand up and think, you come up with your very own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">idea</mark>s! Put your hand over your heart, or on your wrist, or somewhere you can feel your pulse. Your heart is pumping blood through your body, hear the sound of your heart beat and try to picture and get an idea for how all the blood flows through your body.
mnemonics.reading: い None None The heart of an eagle (い) is very strong. The person who knew this probably came up with the idea to make the bald eagle a symbol of the United States. Eagles are always flying around and doing things, so their hearts are very strong. Picture the majestic animal that is the bald eagle. Imagine the sound of an eagle screeching as it zooms through the air, flapping its wings in the wind. It’s pretty impressive.

mnemonics.meaning: Labor A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> in a position of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> does not need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">labor</mark> in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants! Imagine yourself as a powerful Viking. You have the power to take anything you want, pillaging and plundering to your heart’s content. Imagine all the things you would acquire with this sort of power. Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words related to physical, or manual labor, with an emphasis on how darn tiring it is!
mnemonics.reading: ろう いたわ None It takes a lot of labor to harvest roe (ろう) so that’s what the Viking decides to take first! Roe is delicious, but it’s small and delicate. Vikings don’t labor for their own roe! They take it and eat it! Picture this powerful Viking laying siege on a small fishing village and taking all the roe and stuffing it into his bearded face. So much labor went into harvesting that roe! Vikings are so mean!

mnemonics.meaning: Level Grade, Rank There are pieces of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark> showing you what <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">level</mark> they go to in your school. Each escalator takes you to a different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grade</mark>, so make sure you follow the right thread or you'll end up in a class that's either way above or way below your level. When you level up your Japanese skills, you'll take this escalator to rank up too!
mnemonics.reading: きゅう None None You want to see what the highest level is, so you go up the wrong escalator. At the top you find a giant cucumber (きゅう). A teacher comes over and says, "Excuse me, this is advanced level cucumber studies. I don't think you're at this level yet... please take the escalator down and follow the threads to find your level."

mnemonics.meaning: Like There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> in front of you. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">like</mark> them very much. Imagine a woman and a child you like very much. Just appreciate them, and think about how much you like those two. The reading mnemonic definitely won't ruin your image of them or anything.
mnemonics.reading: こう す, この None "I like you two," you say to the woman and child. They both turn their heads 180 degrees back towards you. They both have faces that look just like こういち's. "We like you too," they say in unison. And you DO like them. You have always been a fan of こういち's kanji learning methods, and you feel so lucky to have married a woman who looks just like こういち and then (this is the real miracle!) gave birth to a child that looks like こういち too. Hashtag blessed.

mnemonics.meaning: Long Ago Long Time Ago You've been playing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> since <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long ago</mark>. This is the longest game of blackjack you've ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You've been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago. Imagine yourself playing a never-ending game of blackjack out in the hot sun. You’re sticky, sweaty, and tired. But all you can do is continue to play your game of blackjack. It’s miserable.
mnemonics.reading: せき, しゃく むかし None Once you finally finish the game, you walk the long walk back home, in the sun, barefoot, on a dirt road that hasn't been maintained since long ago. Your feet are all sweaty from being out in the sun, and walking on this dirt road gives you muck ashi (むかし). Your ashi (feet) are all mucky and muddy from the combination of dirt and sweat. Your muck ashi are really gross, man. Imagine your muck ashi, all dirty and muddy from walking on that old road from long ago. Feel the muck between the toes of your ashi, squishing with every step. Hear the sound the mud makes as it slides between your sweaty mucky toes.

mnemonics.meaning: Low The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> wants to live close to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so he demands you get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">low</mark>. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader. Picture yourself, face smooshed into the ground, and you can hear the leader shouting above you, "GET LOW!"
mnemonics.reading: てい ひく None Low people like you can only eat low food like potatoes. But that's boring, so you low people learned to make tater (てい) tots. You roll them to each other and eat them without lifting your heads. Get low to the ground right now and ask your mom or dad to roll some tater tots towards your face. Eat them up, mm mm.

mnemonics.meaning: Nurture Raise Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nurture</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">raise</mark> that trash like it's its own little moon baby. Picture the moon raising this ball of trash, giving it love and attention.
mnemonics.reading: いく そだ, はぐく None The moon nurtures the trash ball until one day, it speaks! "行く (いく), 行く！" it says. It wants to go live with mom moon! Watch as the little trash ball 行くs up into the sky and floats around its moon mama. If you raise your child right it will want to 行く wherever you go too.

mnemonics.meaning: Orders If you know the radical meaning <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> you know the kanji meaning <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">orders</mark> as well! Here's an order: study your radicals.
mnemonics.reading: れい None None Your orders are to get a ray (れい) gun. Imagine an authority figure giving you this order as an official order. Ray guns don't really exist, so you think it's a pretty strange order. Hint: when you see the orders radical, the reading will often be れい. The mnemonic will likely involve orders to get a ray gun of some kind.

mnemonics.meaning: Pick Up Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> always seem to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> the random things you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pick up</mark> off the ground. An old thimble. A discarded onion ring. A dead worm you tie in a knot. Your incredible fingers suit them beautifully, almost as if they were jewelry, so of course you pick up all of them. Imagine finding something that suits your life and your style. You're not just going to leave it there, right? No, you're going to pick it up! Go on, use your fingers and pick up that thing.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう ひろ None You're walking around looking for something to pick up when you see a sword in a rock. Yes, this will suit you. You pick up the sword and people jump out around you and tell you that you are the new hero (ひろ)! Uh oh. Maybe you shouldn't have picked this up. You picked up the hero sword and now you're the new hero. Time to go kill a dragon. Good luck, and try not to die, hero person!

mnemonics.meaning: Pour A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> has the power to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pour</mark> water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head. Picture yourself as this tsunami master. You’re like a water bender from Avatar, only more awesome. Feel the cold wet water pouring out of your fingertips as you create water out of nothing. Imagine what it would be like to have this power.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう そそ, さ, つ None If Chewbacca (ちゅう) was trying to attack you, you’d be able to defend yourself easily. Simply pour a tsunami on him and Chewbacca would surrender in a heartbeat. Chewbacca doesn’t like having water poured on him, especially not all the water from a tsunami. Imagine Chewbacca soaking wet. All his fur is matted down and he looks pretty depressed. He smells like wet dog too. Smell this smell in your nostrils as you imagine how pathetic this drenched Chewbacca feels.

mnemonics.meaning: Profit Benefit, Advantage Cut <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to make them smaller and you'll make a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">profit</mark>. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain. Imagine buying some rice. Now cut all the grains with a knife into smaller grains. Now sell them for two, three, four times the profit!
mnemonics.reading: り き None To make an even better profit, you decide to cut up reeds (り) too. You stuff the grains in the reeds and sell that as "self-cooking" sets. Picture all of your reeds full of grains in a row. The entire world will benefit from your crafty invention. And you'll turn a great profit too, which certainly doesn't hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: Rank A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s at the highest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rank</mark> in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others. Picture this great leader. Imagine him actually standing on the shoulders of his supporters who are a lower rank than he is. He’s standing atop this great pyramid as a fearless leader.
mnemonics.reading: い くらい None This great leader is actually the leader of the boy scouts. And as we all know, the highest rank in boy scouts is the rank of eagle (い) scout. This great leader has attained the rank of eagle scout and stands above all other scouts. Picture the same ranking pyramid from before, only all the members are boy scouts, and the leader at the top is an eagle. Hear the piercing screech of the eagle with your ears.

mnemonics.meaning: Relationship A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who takes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the road on every issue is likely to have an average <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relationship</mark> with everyone. He doesn't really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like a wishy-washy people-pleaser, and as such he's only able to maintain average, mid-tier relationships. I'm sure you've heard of flip-flopping in politics, when people try to take both sides of an issue, staying in the middle ground and never taking a stand. Imagine one of these people to represent this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう なか None Imagine a flip-flopping politician you have an average relationship with. Now imagine that there's a knocker (なか) on their forehead and you get to knock that knocker as hard as you like. Maybe you can knock some integrity into them and form a better relationship. Also, this kanji is pronounced exactly like the vocab word 中 (なか). If you can remember that, it'll make remembering 仲 easier.

mnemonics.meaning: Release As the year starts moving in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, the trees must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">release</mark> their leaves. Picture winter heading straight for you and frosting everything over. Now picture the leaves being released by the trees.
mnemonics.reading: ほう はな, ほう None The trees release all of their leaves onto your home (ほう). Slowly, you watch in horror as your home is consumed by the released leaves. They enter in through the windows, doors, and the chimney. "Release my home from this leaf prison!" you shout at the now bare trees.

mnemonics.meaning: Second <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark>. Imagine the last few grains trickling down the hourglass. You only have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">second</mark> left. Normally an hourglass has sand to count the seconds, but yours uses grains. Imagine just a few grains left, and watch them trickle down as you count a second, and then another second.
mnemonics.reading: びょう None None After the final seconds go by, your awful B.O. (びょう) appears. Your hourglass timer was a timer to specifically let you know when your B.O. was set to return.

mnemonics.meaning: Separate In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">separate</mark> from each other. Anyone can put a sword and knife in their mouth. But not everyone can make them separate while still in your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: べつ わか None Why are you trying to make a sword and knife separate in your mouth? Because someone bets (べつ) you can't do it. "I bet you can't separate the sword and knife," they say in an annoying voice. Alright, time for you to show them. Nobody bets you anything without you blindly trying to do it!

mnemonics.meaning: Special This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">special</mark>. This cow must have been very important to have an entire temple dedicated to it. Picture a temple dedicated to a single cow. All of the people who come and worship here have a special place in their hearts for the cow.
mnemonics.reading: とく None None This cow is special because it belonged to Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu, the first shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate and uniter of Japan! He's a super important figure in Japanese history. You should absolutely look him up and read a bit about him (when you're caught up on these lessons, that is). You walk up to a statue of the special cow in the temple and see a collar around its neck that says "Tokugawa Moo Moo" on it. How... special!

mnemonics.meaning: Together The card game fish are best at is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> because they can easily hold the cards with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">together</mark>. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay. Imagine a fish trying to hold a full hand of cards together. Impossible! Fish don’t have fingers to keep them spread properly. Now imagine a fish trying to hold two cards together and nodding to hit. It's much easier to keep things together this way!
mnemonics.reading: きょう とも None Once a year trillions of fish get together in きょうと to play blackjack. They have a huge tournament there once a year. Imagine a bunch of fish gathering together in きょうと to participate in this blackjack tournament. With so many fish all together in one place, it probably smells pretty fishy.

mnemonics.meaning: Toil A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sits on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to conserve her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, as her servants <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">toil</mark> away in the kitchen. They toil away preparing a feast for this powerful woman while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She's a queen and deserves to be pampered. Imagine you're one of this woman's minions, toiling away in the kitchen. The heat from the stoves is intense, and you're hoping she doesn't see the sweat dripping from your forehead into the food. Man, you've never toiled so hard in your life. Note: There are a few other kanji with similar meanings. This one is used in words that refer to doing work, with a focus on making a concerted effort.
mnemonics.reading: ど つと None As a servant you toil not just for the woman, but also for her dog (ど). Anything she gets, the dog gets too. That means double the toil for you. But hey, at least the dog is cute. Secretly it's this dog you toil for, not the woman. Try to picture what kind of dog it is. And imagine sneaking extra portions to it under the table when the woman isn't looking. Yes, if it weren't for this innocent dog, you'd have done with this life of toil!

mnemonics.meaning: Transmit Tell The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> that he uses to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transmit</mark> all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them. Picture this special cloud floating above your leader. It's probably just a speaker attached to a drone covered in cotton balls.
mnemonics.reading: でん つた, つて None As the leader transmits his latest series of messages to you and the others, you notice a pretty large dent (でん) in it. That dent is probably a clue to what this cloud is really made of. You highly doubt this is a magical cloud that can transmit messages. You inch closer to the big dent and try to poke it. Your finger goes right in! Hmm, you're still pretty sure there's a trick to this thing.

mnemonics.meaning: War Battle A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> starting a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">war</mark>. Imagine what the simple drunkard does, to start the war. They're not in their right mind, and the centaurs (getting you ready for the reading mnemonic!) are an easily offended people. Go ahead and run through the simple drunkard's actions toward the centaurs that start this war.
mnemonics.reading: せん たたか, いくさ None The simple drunkard started a war with the centaurs (せん)! This is especially unfortunate, because the centaurs are really good at battles because they're all automatically cavalry troops. Imagine the war: humans vs centaurs. Tens of thousands clashing in battle.

mnemonics.meaning: Wave A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> and creates smaller <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wave</mark>s. Those hit you too! If you’ve ever been to the ocean or a large lake, you know what kind of forces even small waves can hit with. Now imagine the force with which a tsunami wave would strike you. You’d have the wind knocked out of you for sure.
mnemonics.reading: は なみ None When each wave hits your body, you shout, "Ha (は)!" It's not like it's on purpose. When the wave crashes into you, the wind gets knocked right out of your mouth, making a HA sound. The waves are basically punching you in the gut, forcing the air out of your lungs, and making you shout HA!

mnemonics.meaning: Western Style Ocean This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is ridden by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> in classic <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Western style</mark>. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It's a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ocean</mark>, because presumably the people from the West, with their Western style, came from across the ocean. You'll want to be familiar with both meanings for vocab later on. Imagine how ridiculous a sheep would look all decked out in Western-style cowboy gear. Now imagine it riding a tsunami wave as it screams, "Baa~ baa~ baa~!"
mnemonics.reading: よう None None After a whole day of riding this tsunami, the sheep is hankerin' for some Western-style food, namely yogurt (よう). Yogurt is Western-style food, right? If it helps you can imagine the yogurt is flavored like apple pie, to make it more American and Western. Imagine yourself eating this Western-style apple pie yogurt. It tastes just like apple pie, only creamier and fruitier. Taste the sweet yogurt in your mouth as you imagine yourself scarfing some down.

mnemonics.meaning: Who Who will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>? Who? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">WHO</mark>??? Say "who" over and over again, demanding someone says "turkey," for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: None だれ None Then, someone says turkey. "Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you." You're so mad at that person even though you demanded someone say turkey.

mnemonics.meaning: Work Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> makes you lift <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> loads with all your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, since this is what you do for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">work</mark>. Why do you this kind of work? Well, you're good at it and the leader makes you do it, I guess. Picture this leader asking you (yet again) to work for them. "Can you move those heavy objects with all that power of yours?" Typical leader — as soon as they know you're good at a certain kind of work, they ask you to do it all the time. Note: There are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words that refer to doing work, with a focus on movement or operating something.
mnemonics.reading: どう はたら None Where do you get the power to do all this work? From doughnuts (どう). You eat nothing but doughnuts. If you had no doughnuts, you couldn't work. In fact, your leader pays you for your work… in doughnuts. Picture yourself receiving a doughnut as payment after you've been working. It's delicious. Doughnuts are fantastic. Taste the fresh doughnut in your mouth as it crumbles and melts on your tongue. It's the best doughnut you've ever had.

mnemonics.meaning: Bad Evil In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Asia</mark> they assume everyone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is automatically <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bad</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>. You don't want a bunch of evil in your heart, do you? No, I didn't think so.
mnemonics.reading: あく, お わる None Luckily, people in Asia know how to get the evil badness out of your heart with acupuncture (あく). Acupuncture was originally invented in Asia a long, long time ago, to stop the bad chi from going through your heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Breath Imagining one’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> without a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> can make it hard to draw <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">breath</mark>. Without a heart, you’d have no blood pumping and you would start to die. This would make it increasingly harder to draw breath and get oxygen to stay alive. Imagine trying to live without a heart. You couldn’t. Your blood stops flowing and your body shuts down. You would no longer be able to draw breath.
mnemonics.reading: そく いき None You know how when people are unconscious and their breath slows or comes to a stop, they use smelling salts to revive them? Well a smelly sock (そく) can work just as well. Socks get really stinky and their stench is powerful enough to revive someone who isn’t drawing breath. Imagine smelling this smelly sock. Imagine the smelly stench of the dirty sock wafting up into your nostrils and filling your lungs with its odor. Gross.

mnemonics.meaning: Chapter You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> at a podium <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark> in the morning to practice reading the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chapter</mark> from your latest book. Picture yourself, standing tall in the light of the early morning. You hold your head up high, open to your bookmark, and read the name of the chapter aloud: "Chapter 42: The Most Important Number."
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None You're practicing this specific chapter because you've been asked to read it for the Shougun (しょう). There will be a bunch of other authors reading chapters of their books to him too, and you want to make a good impression. Picture yourself in a line with other authors, standing in the early morning, waiting to read chapters from your respective books. You really hope the Shougun likes yours. If he does, you'll be famous! If he doesn't, you might be beheaded.

mnemonics.meaning: Climb There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>. You try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">climb</mark> it. Imagine this tent of beans. Make it huge, bulging with beans! Now, get climbing. Feel the beans on the other side of the tent's wall.
mnemonics.reading: とう, と のぼ None You climb the bean tent, and from this vantage point you can see とうきょう in the distance. It's beautiful! It's breathtaking! All your climbing makes this view of とうきょう even more worthwhile!

mnemonics.meaning: Cold The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, even though it's almost <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark>, is still covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> so it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>. Inside the house is cold, outside the house is cold. Everything is cold! Picture the entire roof covered in ice. It's supposed to be spring right now, but it's too cold for the ice to melt off your roof.
mnemonics.reading: かん さむ None You can't stand the cold anymore, so you hire a samurai (さむ) to come try to hack the ice off of your roof with his sword. You stand outside shivering, and watching as the samurai tries to stab the ice off of your roof. The samurai isn't doing a good job stopping the cold, and soon he and his sword have frozen into your ice roof. So now it's cold and you have a dead samurai stuck to your house. Great.

mnemonics.meaning: Deep If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is higher than your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> you better move those <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> and find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to climb, because that thing is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep</mark>! Picture this tsunami rushing past the tree you managed to climb up. It's a deep one, way higher than your forehead, but you're safe here. Legs exhausted, sure, but safe and sound.
mnemonics.reading: しん ふか None You wait until the tsunami is only as deep as your shin (しん). Then you climb down the tree and wade home in the shin-deep water. Imagine all the debris floating in the shin-deep water now, bumping up against your shins. Probably hurts, considering how sensitive shins are.

mnemonics.meaning: Double Times, Multiply A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who hires his own personal <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> will likely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">double</mark> his entertainment. Clowns are funny and make people laugh, so the leader decided to hire one. Since that time, the leader's amount of mirth has doubled. This also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">times</mark>, which makes sense when you think about the kind of math you'll need to double something. What is A * 2? It's A doubled, first of all, but you're using multiplication. You're "timesing" something. Picture a clown and all the ridiculous funny things they do. Imagine the clown throwing a pie at someone's face and how funny that is. Chuckle to yourself and remember this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: ばい None None When the clown stops being funny, it's time to say bye (ばい). At first, the clown doubled the leader's entertainment, but now the clown is just annoying. It's time to say bye-bye. This clown has served its purpose. Wave your hand in the air and say bye-bye to this worthless clown.

mnemonics.meaning: Exertion You'll have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> me, having all this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> puts a lot of strain and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exertion</mark> on my body. My power comes from exertion of muscle, so please excuse me if I start to perspire. Imagine yourself under great exertion. You're attempting to use your power to move something and it's really requiring a lot of exertion to move. Picture yourself doing this action and imagine how difficult it is.
mnemonics.reading: べん None None Excuse me, I don’t think I’ve introduced myself yet. My name is Ben (べん) and I use powerful muscle exertion to accomplish every task. Ben knows what Ben wants and how to get it. Remember that, kids. Picture this Ben in your head. Ben always uses lots of exertion to do tasks. Imagine him using an unnecessary amount of power and exertion in carrying out normal everyday tasks.

mnemonics.meaning: Extinguish A long time ago a huge <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> swept a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> up into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extinguish</mark>ed its life. I’m sure you’ve heard many theories on how dinosaurs went extinct. Well, this is the real story. Imagine this poor triceratops and all his friends being extinguished by this powerful tsunami, sweeping them up into the moon where there's no air to breathe or leaves to eat.
mnemonics.reading: しょう き, け None This famous event where almost all life was extinguished is reenacted every year for the Shougun (しょう). He's got a bit of an unhealthy obsession with extinguishing life... Watch the Shougun's eyes light up as an actor dressed like a tsunami crashes into an actor dressed as a triceratops and all of the lights on the stage are extinguished. Spooky...

mnemonics.meaning: Festival Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> on it. It’s all there for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">festival</mark>. Festivals need activities, and at this festival, you can stand on a stool in the moonlight and use a jackhammer to make a lot of noise. Perfect for a festival! Imagine being at a moonlit festival and waiting in line for the stool with the jackhammer. You don't want to eat candy apples or ride rides, you want to wait for the jackhammer stool.
mnemonics.reading: さい まつり, まつ None This festival is for cyborgs (さい) only. Picture the cyborg you made getting excited that you're taking it to the festival. That's why all of the activities have to do with heavy machinery. The rides are mostly just cyborgs letting other people ride them, but it's still pretty fun. Imagine your cyborg going to this festival. Everyone here has some type of cyborg enhancement, like robotic arms, legs, or braces. Your cyborg is really excited to be around its people and play with jackhammers.

mnemonics.meaning: Field The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beforehand</mark> (what the village was before it was a village) was a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">field</mark>. It makes sense for a big open field to have been what was there before the village was made.
mnemonics.reading: や の None On this field, the Yankees (や) used to play. It was sad that they had to destroy the natural habitat of the Yankees (a field) to put up the village.

mnemonics.meaning: Floor Story Look at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> parts. Each of those white parts is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">floor</mark>. Multi-<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">story</mark> buildings have tons of different floors that you can see from the outside. All buildings have white marks that you can compare with the rest to see where the floors are.
mnemonics.reading: かい None None One floor is just all kayaks (かい). You're looking at this building, and every other story is normal, but that one floor is kayak after kayak after kayak. Kayaks working at desks. Kayaks that are desks. Kayaks walking around checking on other kayaks. The kayak floor is quite odd. It's odd there is a floor only about kayaks.

mnemonics.meaning: Garden There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and a man called the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> standing in the middle of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">garden</mark>. Somehow your little garden is now being used by the Yoga King to teach yoga to a whole group of random people under this canopy... you have no idea how they got back here.
mnemonics.reading: てい にわ None Not only is this Yoga King taking over your garden, but he's ordering you to serve food to his class. "You there, peasant, fetch these people your freshest tater (てい) tots from this puny garden to give them strength." You're not sure what else to do, so you end up serving tater tots in your garden all day to stretchy strangers.

mnemonics.meaning: Harbor Port, Harbour There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and you want to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with it by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yourself</mark> (oneself) so you go to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harbor</mark>. Picture the harbor. You're the only one there. The wind is whipping violently and all of the boats docked around you are being bounced around. You can see the tsunami rising out of the ocean and coming for you and the harbor.
mnemonics.reading: こう みなと None As you look around at the harbor in your last moments you suddenly see someone in the water. It's こういち! He's sitting in an inner tube in the harbor waiting for the tsunami too. Well this sucks. You wanted to enjoy being alone together with the tsunami and the harbor, but now こういち is here ruining your peace. He's floating around in the harbor like everything isn't about to be destroyed, sipping on a fancy drink in his inner tube.

mnemonics.meaning: He If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">he</mark> will get angry at you. He's my very protective friend, and you don't wanna make him angry! He's already eyeing you down, loitering this close to my skin. Might wanna... back up a little.
mnemonics.reading: ひ かれ, かの None He may get grumpy if you loiter around my skin, but a well-made curry (かれ) always brightens his mood. So give him some curry. Imagine him turning from a frown to a broad smile as he smells the fragrant curry you've brought.

mnemonics.meaning: Hot Hot Weather If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, they will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hot</mark>. That's just how it is. Someone standing out in the sun for a long time will inevitably get hot. The sun is hot, and it makes you get hot too. Note that this usually refers to hot weather or the heat of an area you're in and doesn't refer to a hot "thing." Imagine you're this someone, standing out in the hot sun. Feel the hot rays beating down on you. You're getting all sweaty and sticky from the heat now, ugh.
mnemonics.reading: しょ あつ None One sun was hot enough, but then a second one shows up. "Ah, two (あつ)!" you scream. If you were sweaty and sticky from the heat of just one sun, imagine what this second one is going to do to you. Ah, two hot suns! Feel the hot rays of sunlight beating down on you from two directions. "Ah, two hot suns is more than I can take," you gasp as your body slowly melts into a human puddle of sweat.

mnemonics.meaning: Hot Water If there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hot water</mark>. Just stick your hand out the window as the tsunami goes by and poof! That water's HOT. Picture the boiling hot tsunami water as it comes for you. Psh, this will be easy.
mnemonics.reading: とう ゆ None As the hot water comes, you just lift up the bottom of the yurt (ゆ) you live in, and it comes flowing in. All of the cups, pots, and barrels you laid on your floor are now full of hot water. You decided to live in a yurt because of the easy access it provides to hot water. They're so mobile!

mnemonics.meaning: I Me A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">business</mark>? Ha! That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>! That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark>! This version of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> is more boyish. It's a sort of young man/boy way of saying "I," though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).
mnemonics.reading: ぼく None None You use the word I a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french beaucoup (ぼく) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot. I am beaucoup I am. (Is that a pun? Did I do it right?) I dunno. Just say ぼく a lot and try to connect all of your approximate knowledges of languages together. Merci ぼく from ぼく.

mnemonics.meaning: Island A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> sits upon a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. If you look at the radicals, the bird is quite large and the mountain quite small. Think of this in the mnemonic as well. The reason the mountain is small is because you can only see the top of it, sticking out of the water. On it is the bird. This small mountain with the bird on it is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">island</mark>. Imagine the mountain as small as you'd like. Maybe it's only barely sticking out of the sea, and the bird is having trouble standing on it. Whatever you do, make sure you think of it as an island, possibly owned by the bird.
mnemonics.reading: とう しま None But this island doesn't only belong to the bird. In fact, the bird shouldn't be on this island, because it belongs to the Sheep Mama (しま), who is like Mother Nature but for sheep. The all-powerful Sheep Mama comes to kick the bird off the island, because this place is only for sheep! All hail the Sheep Mama. The Sheep Mama is a huge, majestic sheep with magical powers. She kicks the bird off the island with her hooves, and the bird squawks and flies away as fast as it can.

mnemonics.meaning: Juvenile Those who <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">juvenile</mark>. Imagine a bunch of young people standing on the roofs of buildings in the village. That's a juvenile thing to do. Picture all those juveniles standing on top of buildings in your village, being bored, and doing juvenile things.
mnemonics.reading: どう None None Mostly, though, the juveniles are standing on top of village buildings, eating doughnuts (どう). Imagine looking up to the top of the buildings in your village. Thousands of juveniles, staring down at you and everyone else, eating doughnuts. The crumbs falling down on top of you. But, the doughnuts smell good, at least. Maybe you try to catch some crumbs.

mnemonics.meaning: Member Even a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>-bearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">member</mark> of the invertebrate family. Yes, shellfish do have mouths, look it up! Imagine a shellfish opening and closing its mouth, talking to you and telling you what a proud member of its family it is. It's a strange sight, but picture it in your mind anyway.
mnemonics.reading: いん None None If you were a member of the same shellfish family, you'd be able to go to the special shellfish inn (いん). Every species has a members-only inn. Imagine trying to go to the shellfish inn. Imagine all the members-only signs telling you that you can't come in. Womp womp.

mnemonics.meaning: Merchandise A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> is able to sell <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">merchandise</mark>. Most mustaches can’t stand because they don’t have legs. This mustache, however, does. It also has a keen business sense, which is why it’s selling merchandise. Imagine this mustache entrepreneur, standing at his merchandise stand, selling his wares. He looks quite dignified, legs and all.
mnemonics.reading: しょう あきな None The mustache is selling his merchandise so well that even the Shougun (しょう) notices. He leans down really close to the standing mustache man's merchandise and stays very still. Then he snaps his fingers and his servants come rushing out to buy it all! Now all of the merchandise belongs to the Shougun. The mustache has nothing left to sell, but at least he's rich!

mnemonics.meaning: Metropolis <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Someone</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s, someones and buildings, someones and buildings. So many someones and buildings. With so many someones and buildings, we have ourselves a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">metropolis</mark>. Imagine just a ton of someones and buildings all packed together in a small area. More than a village or town or city. With enough someones and buildings, you end up with a metropolis.
mnemonics.reading: と, つ みやこ None In this metropolis everything is a toe (と). The someones are toes, walking around. The buildings are toes, too. Imagine this huge metropolis. Now imagine every building just being a toe. Tall skyscraper toes. Smaller house toes. Wide apartment building toes. And then the people walking around. They are toes, too. Toes walking around and going into toe buildings, with toe cars and toe dogs. If you imagine the toe metropolis deeply enough, it should be weird enough to burn into your memory.

mnemonics.meaning: Move When something is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark>, you need a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">move</mark> it. It’s not going to move unless you use a lot of power. That thing is heavy and unless you use all the power you got, it’s not moving. Picture a massive 1 ton weight. It’s heavy. You can’t even begin to move it without some sort of powerful machine to help you. Imagine yourself trying to move it with just your bare hands.
mnemonics.reading: どう うご None Remember that 1 ton weight? Well, actually it’s a doughnut (どう). A huge, massive, 1 ton doughnut. It’s super heavy and hard to move, but it’s delicious. Okay, so you don’t have enough power to move this doughnut as is. In order to move it, you’re going to have to use your superhuman power of eating. Once you eat enough of it, the remainder will be easy to move. Imagine yourself digging into this massive doughnut and taste its fresh baked goodness on your tongue. It’s mighty tasty.

mnemonics.meaning: Ordinal Number Prefix Ordinal Prefix, Number <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Bamboo</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">younger brother</mark> is counted with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ordinal number prefix</mark>. An ordinal number is one that represents a position or rank in sequential order (like first, second, third, etc.). We use this ordinal number prefix before counting these things in Japanese sometimes. Like with bamboo, going down in order toward the youngest. Imagine a line of bamboo shoots arranged from oldest to youngest. They look like pipe organ pipes, or a xylophone, and now you need to count them.
mnemonics.reading: だい None None To remember you need to use the ordinal number prefix before you count these bamboo, you dye (だい) them. Now they're in descending order already, and you can count them nice and easy thanks to your dye method.

mnemonics.meaning: Period Of Time Time Period A "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>" is a specific <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">period of time</mark>. Imagine looking at the moon and seeing a crab on it and thinking: "oh, it's the crab moon <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">time period</mark>."
mnemonics.reading: き, ご None None When the crab moon period of time is upon us, we must take a special key (き) and lock everything in such a way that crabs cannot get in. Imagine a key with a little crab moon on it, denoting the Crab Moon period of time. Then, go around and lock everything with it and watch thousands of crabs trying to get into everything. Luckily, they can't, because you have a special key that locks things so crabs can't get in. When the Crab Moon time period is over, you can use your key to unlock everything.

mnemonics.meaning: Plant If you want a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to grow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark>, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plant</mark> it properly. Everyone knows that poorly planted trees grow all crooked and twisted. That's just how plants work. If your tree's not straight, start over and plant it again. After four or five attempts, you've finally planted a perfectly straight tree. Pat yourself on the back for a job well done.
mnemonics.reading: しょく う None You plant and re-plant your tree over and over, utterly shocked (しょく) at how hard it is to plant it right. You thought planting trees was easy, so this is a real shock to you. After planting your tree and failing again for the 100th time, you stand there in total shock. How could it be this difficult?

mnemonics.meaning: Root A tree root is still just a root! Roots are roots, ね.
mnemonics.reading: こん ね None Tree roots are the perfect roosting place for condors (こん). Unfortunately, living on roots is also why they're always endangered. Condors can be killed pretty easily living on the ground on roots like this. Picture a family of condors nestled at the bottom of a tree in its roots. Then a huge machine comes over and mows them all down as it cuts all the trees off their roots. Darn you humans! Do you have to ruin everything?!

mnemonics.meaning: Short If you use an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to shoot a stalk of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>, the bean plant will end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">short</mark>. When the beans are hit with that arrow, it severs the plant in two, and you are left with a stalk of beans that is much shorter than before. Picture yourself shooting this arrow. Imagine yourself nocking the arrow to the bow, and pulling the string back. That bean plant is not short enough, and you're going to do something about it.
mnemonics.reading: たん みじか None All this shooting of arrows to make the bean plants short is taking a long time. Since you're out in the sun, you're starting to get a tan (たん). After the day is finally over, your tan is really, really dark. Imagine yourself being out in the sun for so long that you get an amazing tan. Your skin feels warm all over from all the sun you were getting throughout the day. Feel the warmth coming off of your tanned skin.

mnemonics.meaning: Sphere Ball The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">request</mark>s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sphere</mark>! Imagine the king holding a sphere in his hand, and looking at it. It's a green sphere, and that is because...
mnemonics.reading: きゅう たま None The sphere is a cucumber (きゅう) sphere. A strange sphere shaped cucumber. Now imagine the king requesting a cucumber sphere, and holding it up to look at it. If you want, have him take a bite out of the sphere, and say "this sphere is a cucumber?" Imagine the taste of it. Imagine the smell, and its bumpy cucumber skin.

mnemonics.meaning: Spring Fountain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">White</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> shoots out from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spring</mark> in the ground. Due to the force the water shoots from the spring, the water looks white with all the air bubbles. Imagine these geysers and the white water shooting from the springs under the ground. Now imagine yourself standing over one when the water shoots out. You’d get super wet and probably knocked over due to the force of the spring water. Imagine this happening to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: せん いずみ None From the spring, a centaur (せん) emerges. Imagine this centaur pushing its way out from the hole in the ground, plugging the water as it squeezes through the hole. Why was there a centaur in the spring? Once it gets out, imagine the centaur standing in front of the spring as it bubbles up and starts shooting water out again. This spring belongs to the centaur.

mnemonics.meaning: Stream A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> lifts all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> and it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stream</mark>s out onto the shores. As the tsunami recedes, watch as all of the trash comes streaming out of the river and crowds the bank.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう, る なが None Next to the trash stream you suddenly see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter and he looks pissed. He's furious that so many people throw their trash in the river and it causes streams like this. Now Ryu is punching and kicking and tatsumaki senpukyaku-ing all of the trash into burnable and non-burnable piles. But the stream doesn't end. Now he's trying to get his other Street Fighter pals to help him beat it back!

mnemonics.meaning: Suit Fit, Join The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suit</mark> are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">join</mark> which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fit</mark>s, you know? Just remember that this "suit" means "to suit you" - not the thing you wear, okay!
mnemonics.reading: ごう, がっ あ, あい None You need someone who will suit you. Someone who can join you on your life journey. So you call Grandpa ごういち. Note: For the ごう reading mnemonics, we use Grandpa ごういち because こういち is used for the こう reading. So just remember that ごう comes from Koichi's grandpa ごういち. Imagine you two standing next to each other, posing for a photograph. You two suit each other well. Grandpa ごういち with his gray beard, and you with your [well, you have to fill in this part by yourself].

mnemonics.meaning: Tired I have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> in my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tired</mark>. Imagine yourself being really, really tired. Then look at your skin. It's all blotchy and sickly looking.
mnemonics.reading: ひ つか None Why so tired? Your body is heated (ひ) up from exercising way too much. You should let that heat cool down so your skin starts looking better. Feel all the heat (ひ) emanating from your body. It makes you realize how very, very tired you are.

mnemonics.meaning: Tooth Teeth <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stop</mark>! That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">box</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> is actually full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teeth</mark>! I know it says "rice" on the cover, but I promise you those are all teeth and if you bite into them you'll break a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tooth</mark> of your own. Stop what you're doing and look into the rice box. Nope, it's definitely full of teeth. There's a grain or two of rice, but it's like 98% teeth.
mnemonics.reading: し は None Why do I have a rice box full of teeth? Ha (は)! Wouldn't you like to know. Ha! I definitely have an answer that isn't weird or creepy. Ha... ha ha... Ha! Wouldn't you like to know why there are teeth in there? Ha. Ha ha. HA HA HA HA!

mnemonics.meaning: Tribe Family If someone is headed in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, nock an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in your bow and gather your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tribe</mark> behind you because it’s about to get real! This man with a gun is headed your direction and he doesn’t even know what you and your tribe are gonna do to him. If he gets any closer, you’re likely to shoot that arrow right at him. This guy headed your direction with his gun doesn’t look friendly at all. Hear the sound of the bowstring as you nock your arrow and prepare your shot to defend yourself. Then imagine the sound of everyone in your tribe doing the same.
mnemonics.reading: ぞく None None When he starts to get closer, you notice that this guy is a bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member. Bosozoku means “running tribe” and this guy is running right at you. With a gun. So gather your own tribe behind you and prepare to defend yourself against this bosozoku member. You remember what a bosozoku is, right? We wrote about them on Tofugu a while ago. They’re bike gang members and the “zoku” in bosozoku means tribe. Remember that article when you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Trip Travel The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> is facing leads straight to a block of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark>. This might be a sign you need to take a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trip</mark>. If you're out there pointing guns at tofu, you're probably a little… tired… and in need of a change of scenery. Take a trip! Imagine coming to your senses after shooting up a block of tofu for stress relief or whatever you were doing. Yeah, you gotta get away from tofu for a while… It's definitely time for a relaxing trip.
mnemonics.reading: りょ たび None So, where do you go on your trip? To Rio (りょ). You had to go way down south to get as far away as possible from tofu. Ahh, nothing like a nice trip to Rio! Imagine soaking up the sun on the beaches of Rio de Janeiro. Rio has its fair share of guns, but at least there's a lot less tofu around these parts.

mnemonics.meaning: Wait People who <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> are probably just trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wait</mark>. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple. Imagine waiting outside a temple. People are giving you looks. People think you're loitering, not just waiting innocently.
mnemonics.reading: たい ま None As you wait outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your tie (たい). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch. Imagine adjusting your tie as you wait. Oh no, now even more people are staring at you. The tie thing is making you look even more suspicious!

mnemonics.meaning: Warm There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> which washes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> out into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. Because it's in the sun, it becomes  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warm</mark>. Right after the tsunami, this plate was wet, but the sun is warming and drying the plate. Imagine looking at the plate and seeing the beads of water evaporate off it as it warms up. Feel the warm steam on your face as this happens.
mnemonics.reading: おん あたた None The plate starts to get so warm that you could fry an onion (おん) on it. Who doesn’t love fried onions? That plate sure is warm enough, so start cookin’ ‘em! Imagine yourself frying onions on this plate warmed by the sun. Smell the onion smell as the onion fumes get into your eyes and your sinuses. It makes your eyes water as you are very sensitive to onions.
