mnemonics.meaning: Wear Arrive There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> right before your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s, because they just love what you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wear</mark>. It's a little known fact that sheep are fashionistas, and they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrive</mark> daily to admire your style. These sheep are so stylish they wear their tail to one side - in the latest fashion (check out the sheep radical - the tail is sweeping stylishly to the left!). Imagine all the chic sheep lining up to check out your style, with their carefully coiffed left-hanging tails!
mnemonics.reading: ちゃく き, つ None More sheep arrive every day to admire the clothes you're wearing. You use a chalk (ちゃく) board to keep count of how many sheep come by each day. Imagine yourself chalking up a line on a chalk board for each sheep that comes to admire you.

mnemonics.meaning: All Everyone, Everything, Everybody If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> light to the other colors you'll realize... white consists of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">all</mark> the colors in one. It contains all the colors in the spectrum in one color. It is the one color that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">everything</mark>. Just look at the color white. Compare it to other colors. Now look at white again. Split it up into all the colors, creating a beautiful spectrum. Wow, it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">all</mark> the colors!
mnemonics.reading: かい みな, みんな None You decide white light is the ultimate color. You decide you want to put it on all things to make everything white. "What a great idea," you think. You try to put it on everything and you nearly succeed... except, the miners (みな). They keep getting dirty doing all their mining things. NOOO, your plan is ruined! Imagine everything covered in white. Everything in the world. Then, you see a dark splotch. It's the miners, they're all covered in coal, ruining all your ambitions. Walk up to them and see all the dirt on the perfectly white uniforms you gave them just a few minutes earlier. Feel enraged at them. How could they ruin all this white you made for all the people of the world!?

mnemonics.meaning: Apologize You thought it would be a good idea to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of everyone in your village and now you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">apologize</mark>. When you do a bad thing you should apologize. And saying everyone's private body measurements is definitely something you should not have done. So it's apology time.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ あやま None You were told you had to apologize by the village shaman (しゃ). At first you didn't even know why everyone was glaring at you, but the shaman took you aside and explained. And now she's standing behind you with her arms crossed as you apologize to everybody. "What do we say?" the shaman says, poking you in the back. "Ugh, I'm sorry I told everyone how tiny your socks are, I guess." "And?" "Annnddd I'll never do it again."

mnemonics.meaning: Arrange Organize A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrange</mark> things. Just make sure you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">organize</mark> it all before winter comes, or it'll be too late. Picture all the things you've arranged correctly ahead of winter — logs bundled for the fire, blankets for the night, and yourself, all bundled up in your neatly organized home — just as the first snowflakes begin to fall.
mnemonics.reading: せい ととの None But the most important things to arrange and organize are your sabers (せい). You have an extensive saber collection that you simply must organize before winter arrives. Last winter you tripped and fell on a saber you'd left lying around. Ouch, lesson learned. That's when your passion for organizing things in bundles started. You know better than anyone the value of arranging your sabers as safely and tidily as possible.

mnemonics.meaning: Bridge This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> must've been sent from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>, because it has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>. Like some kind of special heaven tree that talks. And why was it sent? To be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bridge</mark>. To be the great heavenly bridge that we all, someday, must cross. Picture this majestic tree bridge laid on its side, beckoning you into heaven with its mustachioed mouth. "Cross over!" it says in its bridge voice. Do… do you just step over the mouth? Can you wipe your shoes on the mustache, like it's a bristly doormat to heaven?
mnemonics.reading: きょう はし None Actually, to get across this bridge you have to give it some hash (はし) browns. That's what the bridge's mouth is for. Hash browns to get across the heaven bridge? Small price to pay, really. Hear the bridge shouting "HASH BROWNS" in its bridge voice. You stuff some hash into its mouth and it starts to chew loudly. Oh, ew… Little hash brown bits are getting stuck in its mustache. Fortunately, the bridge lets you across. Unfortunately, it turns out all of heaven smells like hash browns.

mnemonics.meaning: Can Tin Can The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> is the same as the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">can</mark>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tin can</mark>, though. Picture a tin can in your mind as clearly as you can.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None The reading for a can is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this: Genghis Khan (かん) is drinking out of a tin can. He glug glug glugs, gasps, and wipes his face. He holds out the can, "Khan made cans," and winks. かん is can, it's really easy, come on. Just take this one.

mnemonics.meaning: Choose You want to get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, so you have one self (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>) and another self working <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">choose</mark>. The two tiny yous sit on each of your shoulders, like angel and devil, and argue about which scooter you should choose. Your angel self says you should choose the safest scooter. The devil self says safety is for suckers, and you should buy one that's loud and dangerous and covered in flames.
mnemonics.reading: せん えら None Suddenly your selfs both gasp and choose a scooter in front of you that looks like a centaur (せん). The scooter is designed like a human on the top, the bars are its arms, and the bottom with the seat and the wheels are all horse. This centaur scooter is what you choose to ride. The angel self says, "I choose this centaur scooter because of its strong arms." The devil self says, "I choose this scooter because it looks like a badass horse monster, wooh!"

mnemonics.meaning: Container Vessel, Tool <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> need to be put in a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">container</mark>. A small container just won’t do. These products are big and they need a big container to be contained in. Imagine having all these big products. How will you contain them all!? Imagine yourself stuffing all of these big products into their respective containers.
mnemonics.reading: き うつわ None Once you get the big products into a container, you then lock it with a key (き). You wouldn’t want these products to bust out of their containers, so it’s best to lock them up with a key. Imagine the size of these big keys you have to use to lock these containers. It’s a really big key. Picture yourself straining to turn the key in the lock.

mnemonics.meaning: Dark If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> starts to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark>, you know it's about to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dark</mark>. The sun isn't supposed to make a sound, so if you can hear it, it's probably about to fizzle out or something. After it's gone, obviously everything will be pitch black. Get ready to be in the dark! Imagine a weird sound coming from the sun. Maybe a rumble, or something like a balloon deflating? Then everything goes totally dark. Welp, guess you'll be living in the dark for the rest of your life.
mnemonics.reading: あん くら, くれ None Now wandering around your house in the dark you start to feel hungry, so you reach blindly for some food and take a bite. Yuck! It's anchovies (あん). You don't even like anchovies, how did they get in your house? Hmm… Dark forces are at work here… And because it's so dark, the anchovy taste is all you can concentrate on. Imagine that fishy, salty taste on your tongue, the little softened bones sticking between your teeth. Ugh.

mnemonics.meaning: Doubt You reach for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to start eating, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> hands you an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> instead and points towards the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark>. Hm, that's not like her… Suddenly you're filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">doubt</mark>. Is this really your mama? You doubt it. She's just acting so weird. You doubt she would ever make you hunt for your own meal like this. What are you going to do?
mnemonics.reading: ぎ うたが None Now full of doubt, you decide to test your mama by putting her in a guillotine (ぎ). It sounds harsh, but the guillotine is the only way to clear up your doubts. With her head in the guillotine, it's your mama who starts to look doubtful now. "How could you ever doubt me?" she cries. Ugh, now you're really not sure. This guillotine thing has just compounded your doubts.

mnemonics.meaning: Fee Material You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> that's specifically for paying the rice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fee</mark>. Each scoop of something has an extra fee tacked on, so when you use a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">material</mark>, there's a fee you have to pay in that material as well. Imagine ladling up a nice big scoop of rice and then seeing the little fee ladle next to it. Ugh. The material fee.
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None One day, the fee ladle is suddenly the size of row (りょう) boat oars! What! You're supposed to pay a row boat sized fee now?! That's a lot of material you have to give up every time you want to eat some rice. Maybe you should take this row boat oar ladle and row out into the ocean where no one can tax you.

mnemonics.meaning: Feeling Emotion Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>. As in, it's sad and not feeling well. This is because your soul changes colors depending on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feeling</mark>s or what <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emotion</mark>s you're expressing. Start with a blue soul. What feeling is that? Now a red soul. What emotion is that? Go through as many colors as you can think of, focusing on the fact that each color represents a different emotion or feeling.
mnemonics.reading: じょう なさ None Why is your soul feeling blue? Because Joe (じょう), the big local farmhand, was extremely mean to you. Maybe he was just having a bad day, but that still really hurt… and now your soul’s all blue too. Seems you’ll have to walk around with a blue soul for the next few days.

mnemonics.meaning: Feeling Down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> comes and places a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark> into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Your entire body is filled with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feeling</mark>. A feeling you don't like. This awful sliding drunkard filled your heart with his creeper vibes (and an actual creeper) and now you're feeling a lot of things. Probably bad things.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None This feeling wells up in you and bursts forth. You feel mad, you feel like you want revenge, you feel like Genghis Khan (かん) reborn! And you will have your revenge on this drunkard. Genghis Khan's horse and sword materialize out of your feelings and you ride toward the drunkard who made you feel these things.

mnemonics.meaning: Formal Name Ender Manner By a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">formal name ender</mark>. That means everyone calls him Sheep-sama. No one calls him just "Sheep," since he's kind of a big deal. He's actually like sheep royalty. When he's not in his castle, Sheep-sama enjoys playing in the water by the trees. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manner</mark>, as in your manner of doing things. I guess someone with a formal name ender has a different manner of doing things. Imagine what Sheep-sama must have done to become such important and distinguished sheep royalty. Some pretty amazing things, probably, especially for a sheep.
mnemonics.reading: よう さま None This sheep with the formal name ender only likes to play outside in the water during the summer (さま). Summer is the best season for this fancy sheep. The other seasons just can't compare. Imagine playing in the water with Sheep-sama in the summer. It's crazy hot outside in the summer, so going in the water feels nice. Imagine the coolness of the refreshing water envelop your body.

mnemonics.meaning: Foster <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Sheep</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foster</mark> children. The sheep have been genetically combined with fish, so the sheep have fins (and they've lost their tails — which is why the tail part of the sheep radical is missing in this kanji). These sheep fins are rich in nutrients, so they're good for fostering big, strong foster children. Imagine eating a fish fin with sheep wool on it. It tastes fishy like the ocean but the wool tastes like clothes. It's probably the worst thing ever, but try to imagine you're tasting it right now.
mnemonics.reading: よう やしな None The best way to foster a better relationship with these foster kids would be to give them some yogurt (よう). Maybe they can dip the sheep fins in the yogurt to help mask the strange taste. Yogurt is also very nutritious, so it's a good supplement to the foster kids' diet. Remember how bad those sheep fins tasted? Now imagine eating your favorite yogurt flavor instead. This yogurt is delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: Green If you tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> around <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> and dip him in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, he'll turn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">green</mark>, like the Hulk. Some kind of weird chemical reaction. But I… I wouldn't try it if I were you. You wouldn't like him when he's green. Still, imagine pulling Wolverine from X-Men out of the water with that thread, and seeing him looking kinda green. Pretty green, but he could be greener. We have to go greener! We have to make the Hulk green with envy! So you put him back in the water, again and again…
mnemonics.reading: りょく みどり None As the flailing Wolverine begins to turn even more green, he calls out, "HELP ME DORY (みどり)!" Me, Dory? No, not you. He's calling out to that fish from Finding Nemo, another Disney IP. "Help me Dory, I'm green!" Then Dory leaps out of the water to bite through the thread and save Wolverine… THE END. Fade to green. These Marvel crossovers are getting ridiculous.

mnemonics.meaning: Heat Fever Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> spins in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> and starts to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heat</mark>. Uh oh, I think you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fever</mark>. Even if you don't have a womb, just picture one anyway: it's turning around in a circle faster and faster, as the heat bubbles and boils in you. You can feel this heat spread through your entire body as you burn up with a fever.
mnemonics.reading: ねつ あつ None The heat from your fever is making your insides and your head and your entire body spin and boil, until your doctor throws some nets (ねつ) around you. You were flailing around and they couldn't get you to stop, so they had to catch you in a series of nets. These nets aren't making the fever heat go away, but they have made the spinning stop at least.

mnemonics.meaning: Hundred Million A cult <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">idea</mark> to recruit a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hundred million</mark> new members. Since he’s the guy with all the ideas, he is the leader of the cult. His idea is to give every new member a free puppy. He’ll have a hundred million new recruits in no time. Imagine a hundred million free puppies. That’s a lot. Imagine playing with all of them. You’d be pretty happy. Unless you hate puppies. Then you’d be pretty unhappy, I imagine.
mnemonics.reading: おく None None The cult leader has his headquarters in Oklahoma (おく). Are there a hundred million people in Oklahoma? No, probably not. But hey, this leader is shooting for the stars. First Oklahoma, then the universe! Picture this cult leader gathering a hundred million people into Oklahoma. It’d be awfully crowded. Imagine yourself being stifled by the bodies of a hundred million other people.

mnemonics.meaning: I Me The leader of a big rice paddy is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an umbrella. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is I. It is me. Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because 俺 is the "rougher" version of "I." You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.
mnemonics.reading: None おれ None Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ). More accurately, I'm standing here with an umbrella so I don't get wet. My minions are doing the ore digging, but I am watching to make sure they don't slack off.

mnemonics.meaning: Imagine Contemplate Only a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> has the ability to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imagine</mark> and to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contemplate</mark>. For a tree to imagine and contemplate things, it needs eyes to see and a heart to feel. Can you picture a tree without eyes and a heart imagining something? Contemplating? Probably not. To imagine or contemplate, a tree definitely needs eyes to observe and a heart to experience feelings.
mnemonics.reading: そう, そ おも None If a tree can imagine, it likely has a soul (そう). Its soul is what makes it possible for the tree to contemplate things, you see? Use your soul to imagine what this tree is imagining with its soul. Is it contemplating the deep mysteries of the universe? Is it imagining where that squirrel has gone off to?

mnemonics.meaning: Kill There's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> so you take out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kill</mark> it. You didn't just cut the tree down, you stabbed it and sliced it and killed it to death.
mnemonics.reading: さつ, さい ころ None But after the kill, Satsuki (さつ) appears and yells at you. She likes trees — remember how she protected one in the 札 mnemonic? — so Satsuki's pretty upset you'd kill one like that. Here's that little girl Satsuki again. Remember how you imagined her last time? Try to have a picture of her in your mind so these さつ kanji are easier to remember.

mnemonics.meaning: Lodge The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> under which the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can house one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> of his people is at the local <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lodge</mark>. Back in the old days a lodge had to be huuuuge so when a leader brought a hundred people through town they'd have a place to stay.
mnemonics.reading: しゅく やど None The lodge shook (しゅく) as the hundred people came tumbling in through the door. It shook, but it didn't fall over. The roof stayed firmly in place, and everyone got to sleep under it okay. Imagine being someone staying at the lodge as they came in and everything shook around you. This lodge would probably last through an earthquake too!

mnemonics.meaning: Mirror <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark> reveals itself when you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> into this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mirror</mark>. Yes, even you are made of gold. You're so great and valuable, standing in front of that mirror. It's not hard to see, especially in a mirror – you're golden. Imagine looking at yourself in the mirror only to see you're made of gold. It would be pretty shocking. Imagine how surprised you would be.
mnemonics.reading: きょう かがみ None As you look into the mirror you think, "Kaga… me (かがみ)?" You always forget that you're Chairman Kaga from the Iron Chef TV show. That's why you say "Kaga… me?" every time you look in the mirror. Picture yourself in front of a mirror, except your reflection is Chairman Kaga Takeshi. (Look up his picture if it helps.) Imagine not recognizing yourself at first, how weird that would feel, then suddenly remembering: "Kaga… me!"

mnemonics.meaning: Nature Under a misshapen crescent <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s as much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nature</mark> as it can find. Picture a weird-looking, misshapen crescent moon casting its light onto the scene of a dog boiling up everything you'd find in nature. Trees, sticks, mud, little animals. All of that is being boiled by this dog by the light of a weird-looking moon.
mnemonics.reading: ぜん, ねん しか, さ None Destroying nature like this is the dog's way of practicing Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. As it breathes in the fumes from all of the different pieces of nature being boiled down, the dog gets really zen and chill. Picture the dog kneeling in front of the pot of concentrated nature and breathing deeply as it practiced Zen. You kind of wish you could join it, considering how peaceful it looks.

mnemonics.meaning: Poem What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poem</mark>. It has to be a poem, because if you say anything else it's just plain disrespectful. All of the monks and priests at this temple have to read and recite poems all day, and if they can do it forever, you can while you're visiting. Picture all of the people at the temple reciting poems together. You join in too, and it's a really powerful moment!
mnemonics.reading:
し うた None As you recite a long poem at the temple you see a sheep (し) in the crowd. It's opening and closing its mouth like it wants to say the poem too. You turn to the person next to you and realize you have to say everything in poem form. Excuse me
I'm not a creep
so hear my plea
is that a sheep?

mnemonics.meaning: Practice Pointing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is what you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">practice</mark> every day. You're incredibly passionate about eastward thread-pointing, so you make sure to practice every day. You're absolutely obsessed with pointing your thread towards the east, so all you do is practice. Practice, practice, practice.
mnemonics.reading: れん ね None You do all of this practice to try and afford all of your rentals (れん). One day, all of this practice will pay for all of your rentals. Everything in your life is a rental, so you better get to practicing. Your house, your car, your friends — all of these rentals need to be paid off!

mnemonics.meaning: Prize The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> opens his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, and below it, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> sits. Grab that shellfish and throw it into his mouth to win a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prize</mark>! Imagine a game at a fair where you have to throw a shellfish into the mouth of a hungry Viking. You want this prize just as much as the Viking wants his shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None The prize you're working so hard to win is lunch with the Shougun (しょう). This is a pretty huge prize, considering all you're doing is knocking something over. You want this prize. You want to meet the Shougun. Soon you'll both be eating shellfish together!

mnemonics.meaning: Problem Question If you run into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> first, you’re going to have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">problem</mark>. Smashing your mouth into a gate is going to hurt. A lot. The problem you’re now in is one of getting to a hospital and having your mouth sewn back on. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">question</mark> is, how are you going to get to the hospital? Imagine having your mouth bashed into a gate. It’s going to hurt. Imagine how painful this would be and how problematic it is. Imagine that the only question in your mind is how to get to the hospital as quickly as you possibly can.
mnemonics.reading: もん と, とん None The reason you ran mouth first into this gate was because you were being chased by a monster (もん). A monster in and of itself is a big enough problem as is, let alone smashing your mouth into a gate. You poor, hapless soul. Monsters are scary. Maybe you’ve had a dream where you were being chased by one. Remember how scary that is when you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Public Building <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Eat</mark>ing the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>, because the roof is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public building</mark>. Because it is a public building bears are allowed to eat the roof. Picture a public building, like a museum or a library, and look at the roof. There's a bear eating the roof!
mnemonics.reading: かん None None Public buildings must make their roofs available for eating because of a law passed by Genghis Khan (かん). Imagine Genghis Khan signing something and giving a speech talking about how important it is that all bears are able to eat the roofs of public buildings, as a bear in the background eats the roof.

mnemonics.meaning: Samurai The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">samurai</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: し さむらい None The most famous samurai in Japanese history was the illustrious sheep (し) samurai. He wasn't JUST a sheep who learned the ways of the sword, he would use the wool from the sheep enemies he killed to create his armor! Picture the sheep samurai. Maybe draw him on a piece of paper. He's a sheep wearing wool armor, and he has ram horns on the hilt of his katana.

mnemonics.meaning: Section I always <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">section</mark> at the grocery should be at the front of the store. It’s the perfect place for the fruit section, I say. Think about it. Every grocery store has the fruit section right at the front, wouldn’t you say?
mnemonics.reading: か None None To get to the fruit section, you have to go to the store. To get to the store you have to drive a car (か). Driving a car is the fastest way to get to the fruit section at the store. Picture yourself driving a car and salivating over the fruit waiting for you in the fruit section. Imagine your favorite fruit as you put the pedal to the metal in your awesome car.

mnemonics.meaning: Signpost You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> tied to it. You look closer, because this is an odd sight, and realize that there is a sign here too. It's telling you to beware of helicopters and jackhammers in these woods. It's a poorly made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">signpost</mark>! This is not the best signpost you've ever seen, but it's better than nothing at all, you suppose.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう しるし None As you look at this weird signpost you notice a button. You press it because it will supposedly tell you more about these dangerous helicopters and jackhammers. Instead, it just yells out in a loud obnoxious voice: HEYO (ひょう)!! Press it a few more times and hear the sound in your head. Also spell it out in kana as you hear it as a nice little additional visual.

mnemonics.meaning: Silver <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark>, at its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, is made up of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">silver</mark>. Using silver as the root of a coin is a great way to save on gold! That's why, often, if you just scratch gold, you'll find there's silver hidden underneath, at its root. Imagine taking a gold coin and scrubbing it with some soap and water. As you scrub, you slowly see that it's really silver underneath. Dang it, silver again!
mnemonics.reading: ぎん None None If you want to hunt for some silver for yourself, all you need is a guinea (ぎん) pig. Guinea pigs can smell silver, so get a couple and set them loose in the woods and they'll lead you straight to it. Guinea pigs are to silver as normal pigs are to truffles.

mnemonics.meaning: Station Train Station A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> are sitting next to each other. They are both at the train <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">station</mark>, waiting for a train to come and take them home. Imagine the horse and the shrimp sitting next to each other on a small bench. There is nobody else at the train station. It is awkward.
mnemonics.reading: えき None None The train pulls into the station. They walk up to the train doors, but they don't open. "Perhaps a key (えき) would help?" asks the station master, as he goes over to open the door to the train. Instead of saying "a key" he says "eh key." How strange. Imagine the station master saying it like this with his weird accent. You ask him if he has "a key" and he replies with, "What is a key?" Then you say "eh key." He totally understands you now.

mnemonics.meaning: Topic If you use the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you can find the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">topic</mark> of today's lecture. Picture a teacher pointing to a chalkboard with a big pointer, and it says "TOPIC."
mnemonics.reading: だい None None Our topic is actually mostly about using the sun to see different colored dyes (だい) in the water. You use the dye in the correct sunlight to find the geoducks hiding under the sand. And once we master this topic, we'll move onto actually using dye to find them in the wild.

mnemonics.meaning: Wheel Ring, Loop, Circle For your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> to build a new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wheel</mark>. I mean, it's generally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ring</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loop</mark> shaped, it just needs to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circle</mark>, so it should work, right? Imagine this wheel you made out of a hat, some ground (presumably to keep it all together), and a bookshelf. You install it on your car and hope for the best. This is why you should buy wheels from professional wheel makers.
mnemonics.reading: りん わ None Your wheel is... generally ring (りん) shaped, so that's good. A ring-shaped wheel is better than nothing. Hopefully it will get you where you need to go.

mnemonics.meaning: Ability In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> place on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you hide two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>s that give you a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ability</mark>. It's the ability to predict the future! The private moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability! I wish I had this kind of ability... maybe I'll go up to the moon and try to steal your spoons.
mnemonics.reading: のう None None This ability to predict the future makes you famous and now everyone knows your name: Nostradamus (のう)! And now that people know about your name and special ability, everyone will love you! Oh, you thought I was talking about that old Nostradamus, who also had the ability to predict things? Nah, you're way cooler than him.

mnemonics.meaning: Art Performance You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> and call it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">art</mark>. Not everyone agrees that your flower cloud art is actually art, but you know it is. Imagine piling up flowers on top of clouds to make your own unique art. It’s a fiddly business, because they keep falling through the clouds, but you get there in the end. Now step back and marvel at your work of flower cloud art.
mnemonics.reading: げい None None Your beautiful art is going to be displayed at a gay (げい) club. Imagine the pride you feel about having your art on display. Picture the gay club with your art displayed behind the bar. Fame and fortune are just around the corner, now.

mnemonics.meaning: Atmosphere <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> makes up one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of this, and the rest is air or something. I imagine this is what people thought the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">atmosphere</mark> was made out of thousands of years ago. Imagine looking up into the sky, trying to figure out what the atmosphere up there is made out of. Your only lead: It's raining, a lot. So, the atmosphere must be partly made of rain, and it's just falling down.
mnemonics.reading: ふん None None Turns out, studying the atmosphere is fun (ふん)! The reading for this kanji is actually the same as one of 分's on'yomi readings (ふん). One trick about complicated kanji is they often take the reading of one of the pieces they're made from. In this case it's 分. How fun.

mnemonics.meaning: Bone If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> and you hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you’re probably going to break a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bone</mark>. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it. Imagine the force and mass of the moon hitting you right in the boney part of your forehead. Whomp! It sure would hurt.
mnemonics.reading: こつ ほね None Outer space is cold, and if you're traveling to the moon, you're going to need a lot of coats (こつ). All of these coats will keep you warm, even if you do end up breaking your forehead bone. Again, feel your bones crack as you smash into the moon. At least you're warm though. Feel the cozy coats you're wearing and snuggle up in their warmth.

mnemonics.meaning: Bundle The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bundle</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: そく たば None You should always bundle your socks (そく). If you don't, there is a 100% chance you'll lose all of the left ones. Imagine doing laundry and making sure to bundle your socks together so none of them will be lost.

mnemonics.meaning: Circumference The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circumference</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: しゅう まわ None Practice how to measure the circumference of an item by using your shoe (しゅう). Your shoe is kind of round, and it's free. I mean it's right there on your foot. Try to find the circumference of your shoe and then email us with the measurement. I promise you'll never forget this kanji if you actually do it.

mnemonics.meaning: Closed Close, Closure The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark> is now <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">closed</mark>. In fact, the gate to talent is always closed. It's not like anyone can just waltz in and get themselves some talent. You have to work for it! You have to work hard to get through that closed gate to talent! After your hard work, hear the gate close behind you with a creak. You're on the inside now, you're one of the talented ones. And your talents have changed you, made you different from the others — much like the talent radical in this kanji is a little different from its usual shape!
mnemonics.reading: へい し, と None Outside the talent gate that's always closed, hay (へい) is piled up to make beds for the people who are still trying to get in. Who knows how long they'll be there outside the closed gate, sleeping in the hay, but they're all working hard to become talented. Picture a bunch of people outside the closed gates, sleeping in piles of hay. You were there too once. You know how itchy that hay is, and how cold it can be at night. But it was all worth it.

mnemonics.meaning: Cooperation Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> we combine our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> so that we have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cooperation</mark>. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads! The power of cooperation is a *ahem* powerful thing.
mnemonics.reading: きょう None None Nowhere is the power of cooperation more apparent than in きょうと. When invaders are attacking, when the townspeople want to rebel, when there is a kitty up a tree, the people combine their power from all reaches of Japan and cross into きょうと to put a stop to the madness through cooperation. Imagine being a citizen of きょうと. Watch as the powers from your neighboring prefectures march across the border to come cooperate together to stop the bandits that raided your farm. You admire their cooperation. You admire きょうと!

mnemonics.meaning: Example The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> shows you his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. He says, "This is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">example</mark> of a knife." The leader of the yakuza is just showing you an example of a knife. Maybe to scare you? Why would an example of what a knife is scare you, though? Coming from the leader of the yakuza, this is a weird tactic.
mnemonics.reading: れい たと None "This is an example," the leader of the yakuza tells you. "Next time, I'll show you an example of a ray (れい) gun." Why is the leader of the yakuza showing you examples of weapons, not to mention weapons that aren't real, like ray guns?

mnemonics.meaning: Fold Bend, Break If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are strong enough, you can take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fold</mark> it in half. But be careful not to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bend</mark> it too far, or you might just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">break</mark> it! Imagine holding an axe between your fingers and folding it like a pretzel. Or some silly putty. Or a really soft axe.
mnemonics.reading: せつ お, おり None Unfortunately, as you fold these axes in half you realize they come in sets (せつ), so there are twice the axes you thought there would be. To compensate, you start folding them in sets too. How many axes can you bend at once? A set of two? What about a set of four? Or a set of forty-two?

mnemonics.meaning: Foundation <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Crab</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> make a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foundation</mark> for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this! Do you live on the beach? Maybe the foundation of your house was made from crabs in dirt too. Why don't you go outside and check?
mnemonics.reading: き もと None Remember, a good foundation is the key (き) to a good house. No, literally. You have to use a piece of the foundation to make the key to your house. Keys to houses are always made out of a piece of the foundation it was built upon. How else would they be unique from one another?

mnemonics.meaning: Gender Nature, Sex Everyone has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, and that soul shapes their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gender</mark>. It's not just about body parts — it's about what's inside. In the end, it's one's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji"> nature</mark> that truly matters. Picture your own soul and your own life. Listen to what your soul says about your gender and nature — because your life is yours to live, and only your soul can define who you truly are!
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう さが None Once you've decided what your gender is, someone comes to your house and lays a saber (せい) on your shoulders. "This is now your nature," they say, lifting the saber. It's official! It's in all the newspapers, there's a parade, and everyone pats you on the back. Thanks, gender saber! The next time you get one of those surveys where you have to choose your gender, just think back to that time in your life when a random official came and certified your gender with their saber. Ahh, what lovely memories.

mnemonics.meaning: Gentle A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>-wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him, so she has to be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark>. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back-walking, so she's being extra gentle right now. Picture a woman walking gently over someone's back. She's hardly moving.
mnemonics.reading: だ None None Actually, the person she's being gentle with is her dad (だ). No one would ever want to hurt their dad, especially if he's asked you to walk gently on his back as a way of giving him a massage. Poor old dad. His back hurts so his daughter has to walk on it with cleats to make it feel better. But if she isn't gentle enough, she'll just make it worse.

mnemonics.meaning: Graduate You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> (two of them, in fact), then they put it on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">graduate</mark>. It's a symbolic ceremony, putting a lid over a cross, but it's just what you do when you graduate around these parts. Try to picture the lid you give to the person(s), then their putting it on a cross. Why does this ceremony symbolize graduation? Maybe the persons are your teachers, and it's about the divine knowledge you've now finished collecting under your "lid," or something. Congrats?
mnemonics.reading: そつ None None Uh oh, looks like you forgot your lid. They decide not to let you graduate. So two (そつ) more years now until you can graduate, it seems. So two more years?! Just for forgetting a lid? Nonsense! Imagine walking up to the stage with no lid, and the person(s) just say, "Sorry, you can't graduate. So two more years. Next!"

mnemonics.meaning: Hard A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> is going to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hard</mark>. Go ahead and touch that old man's mouth. It's super hard feeling when you touch it.
mnemonics.reading: こ かた None You touch the old man's hard mouth and it crumbles away, revealing the face of a 子 (こ) inside. "You pressed the hard skin holding me captive! Thank you!" the 子 says, as they break free from their hard mouth prison.

mnemonics.meaning: Hope Causing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> at every turn, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Hope</mark>." Now picture the death moon king as the Emperor, sitting in his Death Star. There is no hope, except for that little opening you can shoot through to destroy the whole thing. That's hope, I guess!
mnemonics.reading: ぼう のぞ None The name A New Hope, as we all know, comes from the ending where the moon king's son sends a bowling (ぼう) ball into that little opening and knocks it out of the sky. In the end, the real hope was bowling all along. I hope you've learned a valuable lesson from this space movie.

mnemonics.meaning: Lumber Material, Timber A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark> can become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lumber</mark>. Not all trees can do this. Only the talented ones are able to turn themselves into lumber or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">material</mark>, to be used for a million different things. Picture a tree standing in the forest. It's thinking so hard you can see the math equations flying around in its branches, until finally a cartoon light bulb appears above its head. This talented tree has figured out how to become lumber!
mnemonics.reading: ざい None None Trees can be turned into all kinds of things, but this one wants to use its lumber and material to build a xylophone (ざい). It's the most difficult instrument to create, so it suits the talent level of this tree! Watch as the tree becomes lumber and that lumber is used to craft a ginormous xylophone. Each key is its own plank of lumber!

mnemonics.meaning: Participate You try to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>, but because of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> you end up having to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">participate</mark> in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers or something, and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate. When you're thinking about your next hair style, if you don't like participating in things, you should think about something you can actually keep more private.
mnemonics.reading: さん, しん まい None You know who has big hair and loves to participate in everything? Santa-san (さん)! Well, his hair is more big on the bottom (it's a beard) than whatever you have on your head, but hair is hair. And he participates in present-giving in every house in the world! See? Big hair = participation! Would you want to participate in Christmas if it meant looking like Santa and visiting every single house on earth?

mnemonics.meaning: Perfect The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> that became the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of all roofs was <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">perfect</mark>. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too. Picture this absolutely perfect roof. They really got it right on their first try.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None This perfect roof was commissioned by Genghis Khan (かん). We got all of the carpenters and home makers and construction workers he'd conquered together and tasked them with making the first roof, but only if they made it absolutely perfect. Genghis Khan was a perfectionist, and by conquering and bringing all of these different people together, he was able to create something perfect by all standards.

mnemonics.meaning: Pine Pine Tree When climbing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>, it’s best to choose a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pine</mark>. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public. Imagine climbing up a pine tree. The pine needles are prickly, so your hands get pricked as you climb. Smell the pine tree smell and feel the pine sap on your hands.
mnemonics.reading: しょう まつ None In case you fall, someone has laid mats (まつ) out around the base of the pine tree. That way, you’ll land on the mats should something unfortunate happen. Picture yourself falling out of this pine tree and onto the mats. The mats are nice and soft so it’s nice. Hear the whoosh of air as you collapse onto the mats.

mnemonics.meaning: Promise You tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on your finger before jumping in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> to remind yourself of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">promise</mark> you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool. The promise reminding thread on your finger was tied too tight. You can feel the thread starting to cut off your circulation as your finger starts to turn purple and go numb. It’s really uncomfortable.
mnemonics.reading: やく None None After you get out of the pool, you keep the promise you made to your mother. So you get on your yak (やく) powered mower and trim the grass. Yes, your mower is pulled by a yak. It’s very efficient. Imagine yourself sitting on a riding mower as you’re pulled around the yard by a yak. The yak is having a hard time pulling you so it's making lots of yak noises. Hear them in your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: Remainder <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bars</mark> barely exist. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remainder</mark> of them aren't even in Japan. Imagine the yakuza bars all being shut down. There's only one place where they can remain.
mnemonics.reading: ざん のこ None The remainder of the yakuza bars aren't in Japan. Strangely, they are all in Zanzibar (ざん). Imagine a yakuza bar in Zanzibar. What a strange place to hold out.

mnemonics.meaning: Request The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> had a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark>. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world! Remember, this is the OG = original geoduck. There are no other geoducks yet.
mnemonics.reading: がん ねが, ねがい None The only person that would even hear the geoduck's request was Gandhi (がん). Gandhi closed his eyes, sat down, and spread the geoduck's request to the rest of the world. People listened when Gandhi said, "My friends. We must stop trying to eat the geoduck, and instead allow it to breed. Join me in this fast!" And that's why we have so many geoducks on the earth today. Thanks Gandhi.

mnemonics.meaning: Seasons A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> will grow with the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seasons</mark>. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter. Watch the grain children live their entire lives throughout the seasons. Though there are 72 seasons in Japan, so the life of a grain is actually really long there.
mnemonics.reading: き None None All of the seasons have their own special key (き). As they change, that season's key appears and unlocks the next step in the grain's life. Picture these seasonal keys floating through the sky, unlocking the weather changes, the growth of new grains, and the aging of us all.

mnemonics.meaning: Status If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> you, it's a sign of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">status</mark>. Only someone of high status would be worthy enough to receive the gnarly but gentle kiss of a tree. Trees don't kiss just anyone, you know. Imagine kissing a tree. Better yet, go kiss a tree. If you're lucky, it'll give you a little taste of sap — an even surer sign of your status.
mnemonics.reading: かく None None The best way to convince a tree of your status is to say "cock-a-doodle-doo" at it, like a cock (かく), i.e. a male chicken. Trees really place a lot of status on the ability to sound like a cock crowing. Probably because a cock crowing means the sun's about to come up. Morning light is basically tree breakfast, after all, and they say the way to a tree's heart is through its chloroplasts. So picture yourself as a cock, cock-a-doodle-doing to a tree about your status.

mnemonics.meaning: Strawberry The best kind of flowers to grow in your window? Strawberry, obviously. Yes, there are strawberry flowers — it's actually the flowers that turn into the strawberries, you know. And they're perfect as window flowers because they need a ton of light. That's why all your window flowers are strawberries. You don't waste time with non-edible flowers. Only strawberries for your windows. Now imagine that fresh, sweet strawberry smell that would drift in on the breeze every time you opened your windows. Nice, right?
mnemonics.reading: None いちご None Believe it or not, your strawberry is the only cure for an itchy Godzilla (いちご). Imagine Godzilla, covered in an itchy rash, squishing one of your strawberries and rubbing it all over his body to calm his itchy skin.

mnemonics.meaning: Stubborn The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> is a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stubborn</mark> one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness. You know what a geoduck looks like, right? Does that look like a creature that was looking to change and evolve and be awesome? No, geoducks are weird and stubborn. Imagine how stubborn you’d have to be to not want to evolve into a more attractive animal.
mnemonics.reading: がん かたく None You know who else was stubborn? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi believed in non-violent resistance and he was pretty stubborn about it. Gandhi’s stubbornness, however, was pretty effective. Everyone knows Gandhi. Remember Gandhi and his famous stubborn attitude whenever you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Surround The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surround</mark> you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you. Picture yourself surrounded by this well on all sides. You look up and you can barely see the mouth of the well where you fell in and now you are trapped. Imagine how scared you are. Imagine trying to claw your way up the sides of the well but all you do is break your nails on the walls.
mnemonics.reading: い かこ None The well walls surround you as you look up to the mouth once again. This time you see an eagle (い) flying overhead. You call out to the eagle to save you and the eagle comes swooping down into the well and flies you out to safety. What a nice eagle! This eagle is basically a superhero. Imagine an eagle dressed in a superman outfit. He’s your savior. Imagine your gratitude towards this eagle superhero.

mnemonics.meaning: Target -al A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> guy jumps into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">target</mark> painted on the bottom. He's aiming for the target, of course. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">-al</mark>, as in the endings you get on some English adjectives. You know, like the pool is artifici-al. Or painting a target down there is not practic-al. That kind of -al. Picture this pasty white dude jumping into the target-bottomed pool. The sun glints off of his unnaturally white skin and stings your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: てき まと None This white dude is a huge techie (てき) so he has electronic enhancements that make sure he hits the target. Being a techie has its advantages. He hits the water right on target and the water splashes onto you. Since he was a techie, he was able to perform the perfect dive. And now you’re all wet.

mnemonics.meaning: Thought If you live in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark>, there’s a good chance your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> controls your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thought</mark> process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process. Think about the last time you thought it was right to make a decision with your heart. What was it? Use these emotions to remember this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: ねん None None You're living in the now and letting your heart control all your thoughts. Why are you following your heart? You found you only have one 年 (ねん) to live, so you have to live for the now. Think of all the things you'd do with your life if you only had one 年 left. Maybe you should go do some of them anyways, right now?

mnemonics.meaning: Well The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">well</mark> kanji are the same. Make sure you remember that this is a well of water not a "well, actually."
mnemonics.reading: しょう, せい い None Each time you go to the town well, there's a giant eagle (い) hiding inside, just waiting for you to show up. You're absolutely terrified of this giant eagle hiding in the well. You're not even sure what its goal is, maybe it's just out to scare you... Either way, imagine yourself being absolutely terrified of this eagle every time you have to go fetch water from the well.

mnemonics.meaning: Wish There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> who wears a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> that will grant your greatest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wish</mark>. Picture this narwhal: above its long horn there is a huge, shiny treasure floating. It pulls the towel tight around itself, "Brururu you found me I see!" it whistles at you.
mnemonics.reading: き まれ None In order to open the treasure and get your wish, you need the key (き). The narwhal knows where it's hidden, so you'll have to convince it to tell you where the key is. If you find the key, what will you wish for? Think about your single, greatest wish. Close your eyes and picture it as clearly as you can and you'll find the key.

mnemonics.meaning: Wolf One <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that is particularly  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wolf</mark>. Wolves have a bad reputation, but actually they're very, very good animals. When wolves are reintroduced to an ecosystem, good things happen. Overpopulation in deer and other animals decline, plants grow and create more habitats, and the balance of wildlife improves. It all starts with wolves, who are good dogs. Also, wolves take care of wild, abandoned kids. Only wolves do that, because they're good. Just ask Mowgli!
mnemonics.reading: ろう おおかみ None A wolf might be good, but if you run into one, all you can do is scream Oh 神!” (おおかみ). "Oh 神," as in, "Oh god," because you're about to be eaten by a good wolf. You're part of the ecosystem now.

mnemonics.meaning: Account Narrative The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you weave together to tell others about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">account</mark> of your life. It's your very own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">narrative</mark>, tying everything you've been through together. Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
mnemonics.reading: き None None You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you. Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.

mnemonics.meaning: Army You run into someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">army</mark> coming after you. Imagine yourself running away from the North Korean army. You have to get to the border, the entire army is coming after you for hitting their dear leader!
mnemonics.reading: ぐん None None The army is after you. Each army soldier has a gun (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun! Picture yourself running away from them as they shout and shoot at you. Hear the bullets wizzing past your head as you run away as fast as you can.

mnemonics.meaning: Autumn Fall <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s look like they're on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">autumn</mark>. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder. Picture all the grains in autumn. Picture all of the colors. The colors of fire.
mnemonics.reading:
しゅう あき None As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "ACK (あき)!" Ah yes, the sound of the seasons changing to autumn. Ack!
Ack!
Ack!

mnemonics.meaning: Believe Trust To your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>: "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Believe</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trust</mark> in me." The leader doesn't think you can handle your duties, so you have to say this to him. You want him to believe and trust that you're responsible. You can handle this task. Imagine who your leader is here — maybe a boss, or maybe the Crabigator. Now say it out loud to this imagined leader: "Believe and trust in me!"
mnemonics.reading: しん None None As you face your leader and say "Believe and trust in me," you kneel down on each shin (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are. Picture yourself pleading with your leader to trust and believe in you. Imagine the pain from your shin splints as you kneel. It hurts a lot, but it proves how serious you are.

mnemonics.meaning: Boulder A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boulder</mark> here. This kanji makes a lot of sense. Just follow the logic.
mnemonics.reading: がん いわ None "Boulder!!!" yells a voice from behind you. "Eee, wha...?" (いわ) you reply. You look up to see a boulder falling off the cliff above you. "Eeeeee! Whaaaat!?," you shout again, running and screaming this time. Imagine yourself screaming "Eeeeee! Whaaaat!?" and running away from that boulder as fast as you can.

mnemonics.meaning: Buddha Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Buddha</mark>. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life. Imagine being in the privacy of your own home, your own room, and saying to yourself, "Yes, Buddha, you're my leader." Or don't, if that doesn't sit right with you. Freedom of religion and all that, right?
mnemonics.reading: ぶつ ほとけ None Your private Buddha is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing boots (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him. Picture Buddha wearing a giant pair of rubber boots. Yes, now this is fashion.

mnemonics.meaning: Cat If you see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> among the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, chances are it’s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cat</mark>. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip. Picture this cat meowing and purring as it rubs up against all the flowers in the rice paddy field. Aww, it’s so cute!
mnemonics.reading: None ねこ None Wait a minute… This cat is pretty odd looking. You take a closer look, seeing it is missing its neck (ねこ). You go to pet it, but it's super sensitive about that area of its head, which is basically a face connected to a body... Try not to imagine this too hard. It is disturbing.

mnemonics.meaning: Change Strange <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Again</mark> and again, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">change</mark>s you each year. With every winter that comes around, another year passes, and you change. Again and again. The never ending cycle of winters and change.
mnemonics.reading: へん か None You know what else changes each winter? Hens (へん)! They're constantly laying eggs, which then (possibly) turn into new hens. Picture you and your hens. Going through change, every winter, again and again.

mnemonics.meaning: Clear Up The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is out, the sky is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>, things have begun to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear up</mark>! Look into the blue sky and imagine the clouds parting as the weather clears up and you can see the sun. Gorgeous! The beauty is so great you have to squint.
mnemonics.reading: せい は None Now that it's starting to clear up you can't help but laugh. "Ha (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either. Say the "ha ha ha" part out loud while you imagine the weather clearing up. It'll help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Courage Bravery The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">courage</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courage</mark> are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji too!
mnemonics.reading: ゆう いさ None A man needs courage to stand up to all the youths (ゆう) of the world. They are so numerous and difficult to understand, but the man can face them with courage thanks to his mama. Imagine a courageous man standing against the youths. They use weird slang and try to tell him about avocado toast, but the man keeps his courage.

mnemonics.meaning: Cry A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> approaches, and anyone who dares to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> in front of it will surely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cry</mark>. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground you're standing on. Who wouldn't cry? Imagine getting hit with the full force of a tsunami. It slams into you and crushes every bone in your body. It hurts so much you cry.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう な None Do you know the only way to stop yourself crying after a tsunami? That's right, nachos (な)! Nachos are the only proven way to cheer people up after being hit by a tsunami. Imagine stuffing yourself with nachos. The tears stop. You're feeling bruised and wet, but much better.

mnemonics.meaning: Director Throw a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark>, and suddenly they think they're a big-shot <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">director</mark>. They go around calling themselves managing director of this, director-general of that. They creep into meetings and ceremonies and try to direct the proceedings, all because of that stupid cape. Picture the creepiest creeper you know. They're wearing a cape, laughing from behind a big desk in their new director-level position. That cape has really gone to their head.
mnemonics.reading: し つかさど None After this creeper dons the cape, they decide to become Director of Sheep (し). From now on all sheep-related business, government policy, and law will be determined by this creeper in a cape, because they are the Director of Sheep. Picture that creeper you know. Their cape is made of wool now, since they're the Director of Sheep, and they're directing all kinds of creepy policy decisions about sheep. I'm not even sure what those would be, but try to imagine some.

mnemonics.meaning: District Ward This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> in it is actually a map of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">district</mark> the treasure is in. Picture a big pirate map, and on it are a bunch of these markers for the districts where you can find the treasures you've been searching for.
mnemonics.reading: く None None There is one district you're interested in, and that's the cookie (く) district. The treasure of the cookie district is cookies, which you want. And to be fair, even if you weren't a pirate, you'd probably want those cookies.

mnemonics.meaning: England English, Excel There are many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">England</mark>. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">English</mark>, which is pretty similar to England. Just imagine all the people of England walking to the center, where the flowers are, and speaking English to them to help them grow. Picture yourself in the center of England, speaking English to all of the beautiful flowers.
mnemonics.reading: えい None None You keep walking to the very central center of England and see a giant acorn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England. Imagine walking around the giant English acorn. Touch its smooth surface with your hand.

mnemonics.meaning: Height Ten Feet The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">height</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">height</mark> kanji are the same! That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten feet</mark>. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall. If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
mnemonics.reading: じょう たけ None When you think of height, think of our huge farmhand friend, Joe (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall. Joe really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, although ten feet might be a little high for you to reach.

mnemonics.meaning: Husband The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">husband</mark> kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.
mnemonics.reading: ふう, ふ おっと None What do all husbands love? Food (ふう)! Can you hear your future husband? He’s saying, "Fooooood! FOOOOOD!” like some kind of food craving zombie. Husbands love eating food. Who doesn’t though, really?

mnemonics.meaning: Lick Members of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> like to do one thing: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lick</mark>. They go around licking everything to mark their tongue clan territory, you know? They even lick each other on the cheek by way of greeting. Imagine encountering the tongue clan in your travels and being greeted by a whole village of them. It's kinda gross at first, with your cheeks getting all slick from the saliva, but after a while you get used to it.
mnemonics.reading: し な, ねぶ None Unfortunately, the tongue clan members also lick your nachos (な). You'd been saving those nachos! They were your travel rations. Now each and every nacho has been licked clean. Seems this tongue clan only likes food that can be licked up, like nacho cheese and salsa. They lap up all the good stuff, so all that's left for you are some soggy, pale, naked nachos.

mnemonics.meaning: Luck Fortune When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> decides to live in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark>, you'll be granted good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luck</mark> and good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fortune</mark>. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along! Nope, the luck is definitely coming from the spirit in your scarecrow. You aren't lucky on your own.
mnemonics.reading: ふく None None You want to check the scarecrow to make sure your recent luck is coming from it, so you kick it. "F*** (ふく) you!" it yells. Oh yeah, there's a spirit in there. If you get a luck spirit to say f*** you, you might accidentally convince it to move somewhere else. If it does, you lose your luck. So be careful.

mnemonics.meaning: Meal Food You might want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark>, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-eating stance means your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meal</mark> will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite. Look down at the huge meal in front of you. You'll have to eat your food eventually, but I guess there are plenty of reasons to be anti-eat right now.
mnemonics.reading: はん めし None As you stare at the meal, Han (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it. Picture Han Solo slowly eating your whole meal. He's making constant eye contact with you, reaching down and shoving the entire meal into his mouth.
