mnemonics.meaning: Measure Measurement If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> how big a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measure</mark> it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first. Imagine trying to use your hands to show the size of this cross, but the other person shakes their head and says, "Use your words!" Ugh, okay, you'll have to measure it then.
mnemonics.reading: けい はか None You need to measure this cross but all you have is a cake (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure. "This cross measures two cakes wide and three cakes long," you say.

mnemonics.meaning: Method Law <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">past</mark> changed the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">method</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">law</mark>s of today. Tsunamis used to come crashing into towns, just leveling them completely. Today we have new methods of building and protecting ourselves, and laws to keep them in place, so the past doesn't repeat itself.
mnemonics.reading: ほう None None These methods and laws affected your own home (ほう) the most. Your home has strong walls and ceilings. You aren't allowed to leave the doors unlocked and open. These methods and laws are because of those past tsunamis and the damage they used to cause. Your home is safe thanks to them!

mnemonics.meaning: Night Evening The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> for disappearing at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">night</mark>. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse. Imagine you’re the sun, working all day. Of course you get tired. This is a good excuse to go to bed at night and get some rest. Feel how sore and hot and sweaty and exhausted you are after a hard day’s work of being the sun.
mnemonics.reading: ばん None None Unfortunately, you also have a history of overworking yourself, so you've been outright banned (ばん) from showing up at night. Stop working so much! Humans need some rest too, so it can't always be bright. Maybe you should try some therapy. We all just want to see you get better, sun. Anyway, you're banned for now. Cya.

mnemonics.meaning: Noon A giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> appears on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> after it rises high above the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, and this is how you know it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noon</mark>. The shrimp appears on the sun exactly at noon every day, to announce that it's noon. Really try to imagine this giant shrimp on the sun as a normal thing that happens, without fail, every day at noon. "Hey guys, it's noon," the shrimp announces casually, then leaves again.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう ひる None At noon, the shrimp also puts on its high heels (ひる). It wants to look good for the other shrimp it's going to lunch with. High noon? More like high heels, am I right? Right after the shrimp's noon announcement, imagine it struggling to put on heels while sitting on the sun. This shrimp is almost bigger than the sun, actually, so all its heel struggles are easy to see.

mnemonics.meaning: Pay Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>, no one can see them unless they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pay</mark>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek. Imagine people coming from miles around to pay for a look at your private fingers.
mnemonics.reading: ふつ はら None If someone tries to look without paying, that's harassment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent! If somebody looks at your fingers without paying, without your consent, file a harassment claim on their butt! That is NOT okay!

mnemonics.meaning: Poison To throw <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> out the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>, use <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poison</mark>. To keep life safely inside the window, put that poison down.
mnemonics.reading: どく None None If anything's worse than poison it's doing Sudoku (どく) puzzles. Have you done Sudoku before? Imagine yourself completing these puzzles and concentrating really hard. They’re fun, but also challenging.

mnemonics.meaning: Previous Yesterday Once the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes out, you can use this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> to unlock it and take you to any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previous</mark> day, even just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yesterday</mark>! The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun. Imagine having the power to control time like this. Picture yourself unlocking the sun to go back in time. Feel the heat of the sun and the bright light in your eyes as you unlock the door to the past.
mnemonics.reading: さく None None Time traveling to a previous time, like yesterday, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small sack (さく) to hold your valuables while you're ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well. Imagine wearing this sack as you're sucked through the vortex of time and space. Feel yourself spinning around as you hurtle back into yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: Return Return Home A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> got stuck in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and he has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return home</mark>. Everything is fun and games until someone gets hurt. And in this case, very hurt. If something like this happens, it's always best to return home.
mnemonics.reading: き かえ None Wolverine wants to return home, but he can't drive himself because there's a knife in his forehead and lots of blood, so he asks his friend the car elephant (かえ) to take him. Car elephant is just an elephant mutant that has a car on his back. Watch as Wolverine climbs up onto car elephant and returns home. Well, this party was a failure.

mnemonics.meaning: Ritual Ceremony, Equation A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> is under <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> for a long time. You can't just make up a new ceremony on the spot. A ceremony is done a certain way because that's the way it's always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ritual</mark> first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ceremony</mark>. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equation</mark> for some reason. Just think of a ceremony that involves doing math and solving equations. How strange would that be? Pretend you're at this ceremony. Ritual and ceremony kind of mean the same thing. Don't worry too much if you mix them up a little — each will help you to remember the other. There's a reason this kanji is made up of the ceremony radical already!
mnemonics.reading: しき None None So, you're at a ritual, but not just any old ritual. This is a full-blown ceremony and it's incredibly chic (しき). Imagine just how chic it is. Give it a shot — I'll let you come up with the chicness this time (it's good practice). It's good to practice making up your own mnemonics every once in a while. It'll help if you add more to the mnemonics already here, or if you can make up new ones that are more personal to you!

mnemonics.meaning: Row Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and put it in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">row</mark> with the others. You have a yakuza knife. There are a bunch there, all in a row, so you follow suit by putting yours in the row too.
mnemonics.reading: れつ None None Should we put them in a row? Let's (れつ) put them in a row! Imagine a bunch of yakuza being enthusiastic about putting their knives in a row. They all say together "Ret's do it!"

mnemonics.meaning: Shallow After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, if you go to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark>, you'll find yourself standing in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shallow</mark> water. You're just trying to enjoy a drink, but with your feet constantly soaked, it's not exactly pleasant. Here's to hoping the conversations with your date won't be shallow too! Picture yourself at this bar, sipping on a drink while you're wading in this shallow water. Feel the shallow water getting your socks and shoes all wet. It's uncomfortable and cold.
mnemonics.reading: せん あさ None What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in shallow water? You’re drinking Asahi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit. Picture yourself in the bar again sipping on this Asahi beer. Taste the beery beer taste of Asahi as you walk around the bar with your wet feet.

mnemonics.meaning: Simple The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simple</mark> kanji are the same! Simple is simple!
mnemonics.reading: たん None None One of the most simple things in the world is getting a tan (たん). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan. Get a tan, it's simple, stupid! (Though it's terrible for you so uh... don't always take our advice, kay?)

mnemonics.meaning: Skill Technique You can make your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> out. It's your special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skill</mark>, a very advanced <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">technique</mark>. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers. If you could have any skill imaginable, what would it be? Wouldn't it be nice to have these magical branching fingers? (Definitely. It would.)
mnemonics.reading: ぎ わざ None Unfortunately, these skills are too much for the normal skill-less people to handle, so they pull out the guillotine (ぎ). I guess they're going to chop off your skillful fingers because they're kinda scary. Imagine a tiny guillotine made for the cutting of fingers. Whoever made this must have had special hand skills too! Then maybe the skill-less people tested it on them…

mnemonics.meaning: Slope <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> is being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-social when it's in the shape of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slope</mark>. Think about it — is there anything more annoying than having to walk up a steep slope? Why is the dirt here forming a slope?! Because the dirt is being anti-social, and a slope is how it tells you to stay away. Imagine the pain in your calves as you walk up a steep slope. Wow, this dirt is really anti-you right now. Going down the slope will be a lot easier and quicker, but that's still just the dirt trying to shoo you away as fast as possible.
mnemonics.reading: はん さか None You need to know these things about slopes if you want to play soccer (さか). Soccer is surprisingly slope-intensive, actually. Maybe it looks flat to a spectator, but a soccer pitch is actually a series of very small slopes. Those soccer athletes who seem to fall and flop all the time are in fact just slipping on tiny invisible slopes.

mnemonics.meaning: Small Animal Small Animal Counter In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> there are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>. They are the legs attached to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small animal</mark>. You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
mnemonics.reading: ひつ ひき None You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき). Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.

mnemonics.meaning: Spring When you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you know it's finally the  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spring</mark> season. The spring sun only comes out in spring, which is why you know for sure it's spring. Imagine a different looking sun that only comes out in spring but not the other seasons.
mnemonics.reading: しゅん はる None When the spring season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "HAR (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell. Go ahead and belt out a few "HAR HAR HARs" for spring. It's warming up, everything is coming to life, and you're happy. "HAR HAR HAR!"

mnemonics.meaning: Sunshine Sunlight This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> access to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sunshine</mark>. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sunlight</mark> shines right in, because it's a clear building. Feel the sunshine coming into the building. It gets into this building so easily, and makes it very bright and warm. No matter where you look, sunshine is everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: よう ひ はる The sunshine gets into the building so easily, in fact, that it hits your yogurt (よう). The sunshine makes the yogurt... gross. Picture your yogurt glistening in the sunlight. Watch as it slowly curdles and starts to smell sour. You still eat your yogurt, but it's hot and lumpy now. Sunlight and yogurt do not mix.

mnemonics.meaning: Technique Art There <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark>s with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that requires <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">technique</mark>. It’s a real <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">art</mark>. Angels are really good at going around carrying drops! Imagine the artistry and technique involved. I bet they do some kind of dance, and there's lots of sparkly magic.
mnemonics.reading: じゅつ すべ None Angels are so good at this because they are trained in ninjutsu (じゅつ), or the "ninja techniques." Everyone knows that ninjas are great at carrying drops on the go! Imagine an angel trained in ninjutsu. Marvel at all their divine ninja techniques!

mnemonics.meaning: Temple The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temple</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
mnemonics.reading: じ てら None Someone died. You ask how this person died, the person who's getting buried by the temple. The priest/monk says it was in a tragic terror (てら) attack. That's too bad - feel sorry for the person and learn a little more about the terror attack, if it will help you to remember the reading of this kanji better.

mnemonics.meaning: Bathe A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark>, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bathe</mark>. Sure, there's a lot of water in the valley, but you're big too. It's the perfect place for you to bathe... and good thing too, you're getting smelly.
mnemonics.reading: よく あ None You know what would make the bathing experience even better? If you had some egg yolks (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum! Imagine cooking egg yolks in the same water you bathe in.

mnemonics.meaning: Box With the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> from that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, your trained <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> can tell it'll make an excellent <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">box</mark>. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see. Remember back to those woodshop electives you had in school (if you did have them) and imagine yourself crafting a bamboo box out of a bamboo tree you felled yourself. Don't forget to wear eye protection though! Wouldn't want anything to happen to those valuable eyes of yours.
mnemonics.reading: None はこ None Now you can use that box to store all your hardcore (はこ) punk vinyl records. You're a real connoisseur, so you know that hardcore music should only ever be kept in bamboo boxes. Picture yourself filling up your lovingly crafted bamboo box with your collection of hardcore punk and rock records. Ah, they fit just perfectly thanks to that discerning eye of yours.

mnemonics.meaning: Connection A psychic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> kneels to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, picks up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, and instantly makes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connection</mark> with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing it. Imagine you're this leader, and you've just picked up a piece of thread from the ground. You make a jarring psychic connection with the owner of the thread. Your head spins, your heart races, and your hands tremble. Picture this happening to you as you pick up the thread from the ground.
mnemonics.reading: けい かか, かかり None As you develop this psychic connection with the owner of the thread, you can tell that they're currently eating a cake (けい). The connection is so strong that you feel like you're eating the cake as well. It's vanilla-strawberry. You taste the fluffy and creamy vanilla-strawberry flavors washing over your tongue. Imagine yourself eating this delectable cake. It's fantastically delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: Cure Heal, Reign, Rule After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, use this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cure</mark> the people and the country from the damage. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Heal</mark>ing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle. Oh, and whoever cures and heals the most people will be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark> over them once everything starts going back to normal. So keep that in mind, kay? Imagine if you had your own machine to cure yourself if a tsunami came to where you live. It would be pretty convenient!
mnemonics.reading: じ, ち なお None Alternative ways to cure yourself after a tsunami are either praying to Jesus (じ) or eating your weight in cheese (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese? Before you make your decision, remember that whoever cures you will be able to reign over you and your people. So do you want to be led by Jesus or by some cheese? The choice is yours. Imagine getting Jesus to cure half the people and feeding the other half lots of cheese and their wounds miraculously healing on their own! You're a hero!

mnemonics.meaning: Dangerous There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> surrounded by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>s. Now that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dangerous</mark> place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't. Imagine a dangerous prison surrounded by cliffs and snakes. You wouldn't want to be here either, would you?
mnemonics.reading: き あぶ, あや None Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this dangerous place, there is hope. There is a key (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes! Imagine staring at the key dangling right outside of the dangerous prison you're trapped in. Would you take the chance and go for it?

mnemonics.meaning: Dare When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> gets in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>, I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dare</mark> you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you. Looking at the sun straight on hurts. It’s bad for your eyes and burns your brain. Imagine how painful it is to stare at the sun.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう おか None After you’ve blinded yourself from the dare of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go bowling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge. Picture yourself bowling without the power of sight. It would be awfully difficult to do well. You’d just have to concentrate really hard on the sound of the pins and determine where you need to throw the ball.

mnemonics.meaning: Detain A group of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> guys are in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. You must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detain</mark> them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them! Imagine running into the rice paddy and detaining the private sword holders one by one. They won't get away this time!
mnemonics.reading: る, りゅう と, とど None You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to detain all of these guys when Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them! He's also found a loophole (る) in the system and you don't have to be super gentle with these guys either. So detain them as forcefully as you want. It is your rice paddy they're in, after all. If Ryu hadn't shown up with this loophole you never would have detained all these private sword guys by yourself!

mnemonics.meaning: Dialect Speech If you listened in to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> lives of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> people, all of them would have different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dialect</mark>s and ways of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speech</mark>. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different. Can you even imagine twenty different dialects in your head? Well I can tell you that there are definitely at least twenty of them in Japan alone.
mnemonics.reading: べん None None The best way to learn someone's dialect is to buy them a bento (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private! It also helps that bento are delicious, and anyone with any dialect will love them.

mnemonics.meaning: Evidence Proof What I <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> 100%! You may use it as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evidence</mark> in this murder case. You convince the officials questioning you that your evidence can be trusted and it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proof</mark> that you definitely didn't have anything to do with any law breaking or murdering.
mnemonics.reading: しょう あかし None The officials force you to present this evidence in front of the Shougun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your proof is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared. You better hope the Shougun believes your evidence is accurate, because he's known to kill people willy-nilly when he thinks they're lying.

mnemonics.meaning: Exist Suppose If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with its horn then you have to admit that it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exist</mark>s. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suppose</mark> you do. Imagine needing this kind of horrible proof to believe something exists. Maybe you should have more faith in what we teach.
mnemonics.reading: そん, ぞん None None Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they exist - that's your son (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger Zone (ぞん) after we warned you about it. I suppose you'll never forget that narwhals exist now that your son has one permanently stuck in him.

mnemonics.meaning: Face Surface The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">face</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">face</mark> kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surface</mark> kind of face too! The next time you look at your face, also notice how much surface area it has.
mnemonics.reading: めん おも, おもて None This face you're looking at, that has a lot of surface area, belongs to men (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row. Look at the face of all men put together. Measure how much surface area they all take up.

mnemonics.meaning: Far You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> on it, going really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far</mark> away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling. Picture the zombie, going far off into the distance. It's getting smaller and harder to see.
mnemonics.reading: えん とお None The zombie goes so far, that its life ends (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all. I mean, to be fair, the zombie wasn't really alive to begin with. But going far enough to end it all? That's some serious distance!

mnemonics.meaning: Garden Park You examine the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> and find a small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">garden</mark> in there. There are even benches... it looks like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">park</mark>. Zombies are dead, so I guess their mouths have all the things garden plants crave. Their mouths are like compost piles, if you think about it.
mnemonics.reading: えん その None You look closer at the garden and suddenly everything ends (えん). Oh. The zombie probably bit down on your head and now it's the end for you. At least you were looking at a nice garden at the end of it all...

mnemonics.meaning: Gates Gate The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gates</mark> are the same! Know your radicals or you won't be allowed to pass.
mnemonics.reading: もん と, かど None You want to pass through this gate but it’s guarded by… a monster (もん)! Picture the most terrifying monster you can imagine, standing as tall as the gate itself. How on earth are you ever going to get past that thing?!

mnemonics.meaning: Government A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark>ing your entire country is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control. Picture a map of the world with actual canopies attached to each government, representing the ruling governments of each place.
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None Try to get out from under this government canopy and you'll be labeled a fool (ふ). Unless... you can fool them! Think of all the people who've been labeled as fools by the government because they try to detach themselves from under their reach. It's a pretty long list...

mnemonics.meaning: Happiness Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on something <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> and you'll cook up pure <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">happiness</mark>. Spicy foods literally do trigger happy chemicals in your brain. It wouldn't be too far off to say that putting a lid on a pot filled with something spicy could produce happiness.
mnemonics.reading: こう しあわ, さいわ, さち None Out of spicy foods you made pure happiness. You give it to your sad friend こういち, who waits at the table. こういち looks sad. But when you serve him happiness, he starts to perk up a bit. A couple more bites of happiness, and there's a smile on his face. Although when you found こういち he was depressed, down on his luck, and hiding from the government, cooking him some spicy foods seems to have brought him some happiness.

mnemonics.meaning: Heights Slope If there's something about a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that people are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> towards, it's usually the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heights</mark> aspect. Another thing would be if it's on a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slope</mark>. No one likes that kind of building. Imagine standing on the edge of a very high building on a slope somewhere. You'd become a building anti, too, if you had to look out from the terrifying heights of this building.
mnemonics.reading: はん さか None Another person you know who's afraid of heights is Han (はん) Solo. Now wait, you protest, he flies a space ship! You're right, but only because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about heights. Imagine standing at the top of that tall building with Han Solo. He's very afraid of heights (and slopes). They make him nervous. Like something bad will happen if he were to ever stand high up above a big pit.

mnemonics.meaning: Hurry Sudden In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> where you once kept <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, you find a beating <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. You don't understand how it's still going, but you know you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hurry</mark> up and do something, or it might stop all of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>. Picture this beating heart in the prison. Was it Wolverine's? That would explain why it's, like, beating all supernaturally on its own. What should you do with it? You'd better hurry, its owner probably needs it.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう いそ None You start to overheat as you hurry around, so you grab a cucumber (きゅう) to cool you down. The high water content re-hydrates you and lets you continue hurrying to help save this heart. And if it really is Wolverine's heart, you're gonna have to be cool as a cucumber when you try to help him, even if you're in a hurry. He's emotionally cold, remember? Gotta play it cool with him, despite the emergency.

mnemonics.meaning: Laugh <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> is a place for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">laugh</mark>ing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter. Imagine yourself as a bamboo plant that laughs in heaven. What are you laughing about? Chuckle to yourself as you remember this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: しょう わら, え None There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there laughin’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a war a (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous. Now picture these bamboo again up in bamboo heaven, and remember this strange accent to remember that the bamboo plants up in bamboo heaven are laughing with nervous laughter at this bamboo war that’s a goin’ on up there.

mnemonics.meaning: Luggage You offer <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and compliment them on their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>. You think that by doing this they might carry your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luggage</mark>. Picture this big, strong leader. They actually love flowers and feel flattered by your compliment! But being the leader, they can't help wondering why they should have to carry your luggage…
mnemonics.reading: か に None Unconvinced by your flattery, the leader refuses to carry your luggage, so you get on your knees (に) and beg them to carry it. On top of being a strong leader, they also have a very kind heart, so your begging convinces them and they agree to carry your luggage.

mnemonics.meaning: Plan The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> comes to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, thinking of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop. Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
mnemonics.reading: き くわだ, たくら None The plan that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the key (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple! Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?

mnemonics.meaning: Politics Government It's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to focus on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">politics</mark> and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time! Imagine all this politics and government talk as you shiver outside in the winter cold. You’re freezing and you’re bored, but you know this is the right (correct) thing to do.
mnemonics.reading: せい None None Everyone involved in politics and government wields a special saber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away! Picture two different politicians, both wielding sabers, fighting to make the government the way they want it to be! Who are you rooting for?

mnemonics.meaning: Product Article, Goods, Products The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">product</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
mnemonics.reading: ひん しな None As you try to sell these products, you finally get a buyer. It's a Hindu (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot! Then another Hindu person walks in your store and buys some. Then another... What are all these Hindu people doing buying your products, you wonder? When you ask them, they tell you "it's a cultural thing."

mnemonics.meaning: Protect Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> needs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s done every year to make sure it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">protect</mark> you properly. If you think about it, your roof protects you from a lot of things! Rain, snow, bird poop. But if your roof's measurements are off it won't be able to protect you properly.
mnemonics.reading: す, しゅ まも, もり None If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't protect you, then you get to sue (す)! If you're still alive, that is. Odds are, the roof collapsed or a tree fell on you and you died from lack of protection. So now your family and friends are going to sue on your behalf.

mnemonics.meaning: Quit Word When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> becomes too <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> for you to bear, it’s time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quit</mark> the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest. This kanji has another meaning too: Eating isn't the only thing that makes your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark>, so do certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">word</mark>s. Say your favorite words out loud right now. Feel them on your tongue. Words are the spicy food of language! You may have to quit eating but you never have to quit saying words. Especially if you're, well, trying to learn a whole new language full of them.
mnemonics.reading: じ や None Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you quit and became obsessed with words instead. It was Jesus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy. Picture Jesus scarfing down jalapeño peppers. He never quits. And then he says some words about how the jalapeños gave up their lives for this contest, so we better appreciate them. Thanks Jesus!

mnemonics.meaning: Reality If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> stays fixated on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, staring at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, he's going to lose touch with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reality</mark>. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he's looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can't eat because they're dirty. Silly pope. You can't let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do. Picture trying to get the pope to stop staring at the fins lying on the dirty ground. Yup, he's completely lost touch with reality, you think.
mnemonics.reading: しん ま None You're doing your best to bring the pope back to reality when he snaps and kicks you in the shin (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he's already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked it. Imagine the pope angrily kicking your shin super hard. You fall over and pull it close. Feel how badly it aches. Who knew you'd need shin guards to deal with a pope that's lost touch with reality just from dropping his dinner.

mnemonics.meaning: Related Connected This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> will take you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>. These horns are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">related</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connected</mark> to heaven in some way. Perhaps they are related to heaven because the devil has horns? Perhaps they are connected to heaven because these are the horns of heaven's enemies? The real reason they're connected will be revealed in the reading mnemonic.
mnemonics.reading: かん かか, せき None They are related and connected to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis Khan (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did. Imagine Genghis Khan taking horns off his enemies, and making a gate to heaven. The horn gate is connected to both heaven and Genghis Khan in that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Risky Steep Going into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> made by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">risky</mark>. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral. One squid got stuck in his own building, but no one could save him because going in would be too risky. Poor little squid.
mnemonics.reading: けん けわ None "It's too risky, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for Ken (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him! The squid cries, "I can build one that isn't so risky next time!" Ken shakes his head, "I'm not letting you do anymore risky things, you're coming with me from now on." Ken scoops up the squid into a bucket, hoists him over his shoulder, and walks off into the sunset. Who knows what adventures await our new duo. All we know is that they'll definitely be getting into some risky business.

mnemonics.meaning: Rule If you play <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark> is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude. Imagine a fish playing music using his fins. What kind of a song is it? Imagine it in your head as you see a sign with the fish fin rule on it.
mnemonics.reading: てん None None There’s also a rule in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than ten (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten. Picture a group of ten (as per the rule) fish playing music with their fins. Now the song can be louder and more intricate. Imagine it playing in your head.

mnemonics.meaning: Specialty Sticking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> to get its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">specialty</mark>. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty! Visualize yourself doing this. The numbers just come to you. It's just what you're good at. Your specialty is something no one else in the world is as good at as you!
mnemonics.reading: せん もっぱ None Hearing of your amazing specialty and cross measurement abilities, a centaur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him. Picture yourself at a centaur funeral. Tons of centaurs standing around and stamping their hooves as you make your measurement and stick a cross into the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: Superfluous Unnecessary, Uselessness A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> is completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">superfluous</mark>. Seriously, you don't need a forehead table. It's totally unnecessary to have a table made of foreheads and is a superfluous purchase. First of all, getting all those foreheads is a waste of people. Second, forehead tables aren't very strong. Superfluous, superfluous, superfluous.
mnemonics.reading: じょう None None The only person you know with a superfluous forehead table is Joe (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand. Now every time you visit Joe, you’ll have to look at his giant, superfluous forehead table. Imagine how gross it looks, with dozens of foreheads protruding from its surface. Only Joe would buy such a thing.

mnemonics.meaning: Weekday Day Of The Week When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is out, you can see two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>s and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> playing together, but only on a certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weekday</mark>. Which <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">day of the week</mark> is it? I'll never tell you. It could be Sunday. It could be Monday. It could be any day of the week. Picture the majestic scene — two Wolverines (yes, there are two) and a turkey, frolicking in the sunlight together. It's one of those rare but regular natural occurrences that only happens once a week, on a particular day.
mnemonics.reading: よう None None Now that you know how to figure out what day of the week it is, you can start making yogurt (よう). It can take up to 24 hours to make yogurt. Knowing which weekday it is at any given moment means you can perfect your yogurt-making schedule. Picture yourself looking at the shadow cast by the two Wolverines and the turkey. Imagine waiting a whole 24 hours and knowing exactly when your yogurt is ready. All thanks to this makeshift sundial which can accurately tell you which day of the week it is.

mnemonics.meaning: Write Writing Why would you try to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>? It's almost too obvious, because you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">write</mark> something down. Just imagine yourself sitting on the sun, writing back to your friends and family with a brush. For someone who can visit the sun, it's really weird that you are writing with a brush like this, but you're doing it just the same.
mnemonics.reading: しょ か None What did you write about? You were writing about this amazing circus show (しょ) you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong! Think of your favorite live shows and imagine them on the sun. Also imagine yourself writing back to your friends and family about said shows.

mnemonics.meaning: Absolutely The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">absolutely</mark>. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always. Imagine the sun in the sky. Its rays blind you as it corrects all of the errors you’ve made.
mnemonics.reading: ぜ None None Then, a zeppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. Absolutely, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground. Imagine the sun being so absolutely consumed with rage that it catches a zeppelin on fire and crashes it. Feel the heat from the grounded zeppelin as it smolders.

mnemonics.meaning: Bind Tie You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bind</mark>ing two fingers together. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tie</mark> them nice and tight. Tying two fingers together with a good luck thread is very common where you're from.
mnemonics.reading: けつ むす, ゆ None After you bind your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly ketsup (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens. This ketsup is exactly what you were looking for, but now it won't stop. You need to get out of this bind by untying the thread on your finger. But it won't budge. It's covered in ketsup. Help! You're going to drown!

mnemonics.meaning: Bottom Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> digs in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, trying to get to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bottom</mark>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building. Picture all of the people in your clan under this canopy digging with all their might, trying to find the bottom. "Isn't there... no bottom though?" you think to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: てい そこ None Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the bottom, but it's full of water and they're all soaked (そこ)! The bottom is full of water, and everyone and everything down there is soaked through now.

mnemonics.meaning: Cause Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> that it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cause</mark> of all your problems. Imagine all the dumb things you blabber about, with your mouth open big and wide. Saying things you shouldn't say, causing all kinds of drama. Shame on you.
mnemonics.reading: いん よ None Your big mouth is the cause behind all your friends and family moving to an inn (いん). They move to the inn so they don't have to live with you and hear you talk anymore. Who knew you could cause people to live in an inn instead of their own homes with your big mouth...

mnemonics.meaning: Detailed They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detailed</mark> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say. Imagine getting really close to a sheep and seeing all the tiny detailed curls in their wool. There are hidden patterns you'd never noticed before now!
mnemonics.reading: しょう くわ None The reason these sheep are so detailed is that they are trying to impress the Shougun (しょう). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing. Picture the Shougun, leaning in close to inspect the detailed patterns all over the sheep. His nose is so close, he can probably smell all the little detailed nuances of the sheep's musk too.

mnemonics.meaning: Discerning Discriminating, Know If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> makes, you must be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discerning</mark>. Few people are able to discern what sound a drunkard makes, but you — you can say, because you're a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discriminating</mark> listener. Yes, you can even tell a tequila drunk from a vodka drunk based on the sounds they make. (Imagine how exactly they'd be different.) To be able to say what sound each kind of drunkard makes, it takes a very discerning, discriminating mind.
mnemonics.reading: しき None None Discerning individuals like you are considered chic (しき). What's more chic than your discriminating way of listening? All chic people show some kind of discernment. For some it's about discerning what's fashionable. For you, it's about discriminating one kind of drunk sound from another. That's your version of chic.

mnemonics.meaning: Drama A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> kills a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in this new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drama</mark> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife. Picture this scene from the drama as dramatically as you can. The pig stares into the tiger's eyes, "Tiger, you wouldn't–uh!" The pig's eyes slowly lower to see the knife sticking into its gut, the tiger's hand still holding it. "This is what you get, you pig," the tiger spits back, twisting.
mnemonics.reading: げき None None This drama is being put on by Gecki (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art. Picture Gecki acting out the part of the tiger and the pig in this drama. It's so intense, you're moved to tears. Bravo Gecki, bravo!

mnemonics.meaning: Dry The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: かん ほ, ひ None You need to dry Genghis Khan (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head. Imagine keeping Genghis Khan completely dry all day every day. He won't even get wet to bathe. Instead he makes you rub his body with dry sand and salts.

mnemonics.meaning: Failure Defeat A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that can't live through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">failure</mark>. Any proper shellfish would survive through the winter, so this is quite an embarrassing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defeat</mark>. Imagine you're a shellfish in the cold, cold winter. The water is freezing but you must tough it out so no one will say you're a failure in spring when they find your dead, defeated shellfish body.
mnemonics.reading: はい やぶ None The best way to avoid failure is to say a little haiku (はい) to distract you from the cold. In fact, this can work in any situation where you're afraid of defeat. Say a haiku aloud, it will calm your nerves and warm you from the inside. Imagine being a shellfish freezing in the cold winter water, but you avoid failure by muttering haiku over and over to keep you warm and determined.

mnemonics.meaning: Ford Wade A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, and you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">walk</mark> over it, so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ford</mark> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wade</mark> across it. Imaging taking your shoes off, hiking up your pants, and holding all of your things above your head as you ford across the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: しょう わた None Your ability to ford this tsunami impresses everyone who witnesses it, especially the Shougun (しょう). Now that you've taught him a tsunami can be forded, he's going to start sending his troops through them instead of waiting for them to pass. Your new fording techniques have increased the Shougun's military power! Congrats, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Fruit The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fruit</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Bodacious!
mnemonics.reading: か くだ, は None They sell fruit at the store, and you need to drive your car (か) to get there. A car is the fastest way to fruit. Imagine you have a hankering for your favorite fruit. You gotta get in your car and put the pedal to the metal! Feel the wind in your hair as your car speeds down the road and listen to that engine purr.

mnemonics.meaning: Government Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> who works for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear. Picture the government bear looking through government documents and snorting gruffly as it decides what to sign and what to reject. It has a little government sash and hat.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None The first government that allowed bears was set up by Genghis Khan (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers. Picture Genghis Khan patting the first bear government worker on the back as they start their first day working for the government.

mnemonics.meaning: Government Office Political Office, Office This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> is for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> who works in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government office</mark>. You'll also take someone from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">political office</mark>. Doesn't matter who, but you're going to catch someone from a government office using this net, it doesn't matter who.
mnemonics.reading: しょ None None Government office and political office people put on the best shows (しょ). That's why you want to capture someone from there with your net. Imagine the show they put on. You'll call your show "Exactly 8 Hours of Bureaucracy."

mnemonics.meaning: Guess If you're on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark> you'll have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guess</mark> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it. Imagine being on the roof above a festival. Can you guess what's happening below you based on the sounds and smells?
mnemonics.reading: さつ None None To get a better guess, you ask Satsuki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?" And what's Satsuki doing up here, anyway? Your guess is as good as mine. Now imagine you and her trying to guess what kind of festival it is.

mnemonics.meaning: Hall Public Chamber A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> will empty his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of all its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in the great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hall</mark>. They all get together in some kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public chamber</mark> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got. Picture a long Viking hall, with a big table and tons of chairs. All of the Vikings are gossiping and sharing all their dirt on their enemies.
mnemonics.reading: どう None None While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their hall, they also stuff their faces with doughnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash. Now picture all of the Vikings in the hall spitting dirt with one breath and shoveling doughnuts in with the next. It's pretty gross!

mnemonics.meaning: Illusion You hide <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark> as part of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">illusion</mark> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape. Imagine having poop in your cape. It would smell bad and anyone close to you would be able to smell right through the illusion.
mnemonics.reading: げん まぼろし None Somehow the poop cape illusion goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is Genji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!" Genji grabs the cape before you can stop him and he puts it on. You can see the illusion fade, he keeps smiling but more tears start streaming down his face. "A wonderful illusion, the best I've ever seen," he chokes out and marches away, without looking back.

mnemonics.meaning: Injustice Negative, Mistake A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> has done an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">injustice</mark> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">negative</mark> thing, and even if it was just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mistake</mark>, it was still a crime. Think of all the criminals you know. Even if what they did was a mistake, it was still some type of injustice, right? It was something the rest of the world sees as a negative thing.
mnemonics.reading: ひ None None When you commit an injustice, you'll know because heat (ひ) fills your body. Maybe you've never done any kind of big thing, but when you make a mistake your face fills with heat and you turn red! This is the heat of embarrassment, of knowing you did something negative or wrong.

mnemonics.meaning: Love Put on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s so you can plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> — that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">love</mark>. You'll be braving the harsh winter elements for love, so you put on your cleats to get a better grip on the snow. Sure, you could just wait for better weather to go see them, but then it wouldn't be true love, would it? Picture a person you love. Feel the joy of love in your heart as you brave the winter to see them. Your cleats crunch the snow underfoot, it's cold outside, but you're kept warm and happy by that feeling of love.
mnemonics.reading: あい まな None Walking through the winter snow with your cleats on, you've gotta keep your eye (あい) on the prize. It's a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your love and the time you'll get to spend with them. Imagine seeing your love with your own two eyes after a long time apart. It feels great to be reunited and see eye to eye once again. Imagine this feeling.

mnemonics.meaning: Medicine Drug, Drugs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> can be used for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comfort</mark>, but also for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">medicine</mark>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people. Imagine having some medicine that smells and tastes like fresh cut flowers. Smell the smell in your nose and taste the taste on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: やく くすり None The best way to transport all the medicine on land is with a yak (やく). Yaks are big, strong, and very capable of transporting flower medicine like these. Picture a yak in your mind. Pretend you are riding atop the yak as it transports this medicine. Feel the fur of the yak in your hands as you cling on for dear life.

mnemonics.meaning: Memorize Awake <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark>, Viking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">memorize</mark>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really. It can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">awake</mark>. Just remember that Vikings can't see if they aren't awake. There won't be anything to memorize if their eyes are still closed, after all! How else would a Viking memorize something? Imagine having to memorize sea charts for your Viking navigation. Look and see the maps in your brain as you memorize them.
mnemonics.reading: かく おぼ, さ None Every morning, a cock (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings memorizes the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings. Imagine yourself memorizing the sound of a cock crow and using it to play jokes on your fellow Vikings. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

mnemonics.meaning: Normal Ordinary, Usual A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">viking</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is a totally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">normal</mark> thing. It's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ordinary</mark>. Vikings get a lot of nasty stuff on their mouths from their messy eating and pillaging, so it makes sense that they'd all have mouth towels. It's as ordinary and normal as it gets, at least amongst the vikings.
mnemonics.reading: じょう つね None It's normal for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend Joe(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only normal for vikings, so why does he have one? When you ask Joe about his Viking mouth towel, he just tells you, "It's normal for everyone to have mouth towels. Totally ordinary." Now that you think about it, he really is a messy dude, so he probably needs it.

mnemonics.meaning: Nose You're all by your lonesome <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> and have to check each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you own, all <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> of them! Luckily, you have a very astute <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nose</mark>, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself. Really focus in on your nose. Your nostrils get huge, and your nose is huge. Smell the rice and its freshness in your imagination. Your nose is amazing.
mnemonics.reading: び はな None As you're about to finish checking your paddies, your nose picks up an additional smell: It's Hannah, bringing you a bunch of 花 (はな)! Remember Hannah from when she helped the leader with his 花 problem? Looks like she's brought a bunch over just for you. Really breathe in the lovely smell of the 花 deeply through your nose. Thanks, Hannah!

mnemonics.meaning: Nothing The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nothing</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nothing</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Woah!
mnemonics.reading: む, ぶ な None Nothing can moo (む) quite like a cow can moo. Cows are the best at going moo. That’s a fact. Listen to this cow moo. Can you do a better moo than this moo cow? Nope.

mnemonics.meaning: Original Fundamental, Field The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">original</mark> kanji are the same! This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">field</mark>, probably because that's what everything originally looked like before humans: just a bunch of fields. Know your radicals! I shouldn't even have to tell you this by now.
mnemonics.reading: げん はら None The original Japanese hero was Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Picture Genji, the original Japanese protagonist, walking through the streets. He's signing his name for swooning ladies and gentlemen. Genji is the OG (original Genji).

mnemonics.meaning: Rejoice Delighted, Pleased If there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> it's time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rejoice</mark>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming! Imagine having a drum in your mouth and rejoicing about it! Imagine how loud it would be!
mnemonics.reading: き よろこ None You loudly rejoice for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a key (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth! Imagine if people could just stop the rejoicing of others by locking their mouths shut with keys. What a sad world.

mnemonics.meaning: Romance Love <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Again</mark> and again, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> comes back to the same person. Is this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">romance</mark>? Are you in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">love</mark>? Perhaps you have a person in mind that your heart comes back to again and again. Associate that person with this notion and kanji, and this'll be easy to memorize!
mnemonics.reading: れん こい None But, remember that your romance isn’t a rental (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person! Don’t let your love become a rental. Wait for the right person to come around.

mnemonics.meaning: Sad A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sad</mark>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad. Imagine watching a criminal after he's done stealing from a bank. He's all alone. He stops throwing the money around. And cries. So so sad.
mnemonics.reading: ひ かな None The sad feelings fill the criminal's body with heat (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you. Imagine being so sad that your entire body fills with heat. That heat even makes squiggly heat lines pop out above and around you.

mnemonics.meaning: Salt In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>. Its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> points toward a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salt</mark>! In olden days, salt was so valuable it was used as money. So imagine the gun buried in the dirt, its mouth vigilantly guarding the plate of salt.
mnemonics.reading: えん しお None When you see the salt, you think to yourself, "She owes (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course. Are you sure you want to take her salt? Sure, she owes you, but I don't think you want to argue with the mouth of a gun.

mnemonics.meaning: Seat In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seat</mark>. Picture this yurt, with towels laid out as seats for everyone who visits.
mnemonics.reading: せき None None Something about using a towel for a seat is very sexy (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach. Imagine the sexiest person you've ever seen, using a towel as a seat next to you in this yurt. Maybe they're in a bathing suit. Maybe they're completely covered up. Either way, they're very sexy.

mnemonics.meaning: Side The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>. It's fine though, don't worry, it's just a reminder that he won the great shellfish war back when they were trying to choose the new leader. Picture the shellfish leader in your mind and make sure to pay special attention to the knife that's sticking out of his side. It's right in the groove of his shell.
mnemonics.reading: そく がわ, そば None Because of this knife in his side, he can't pronounce certain words correctly. The most obvious one is when he says 川 (かわ), but it comes out of the side of his mouth as がわ. Try saying かわ out the side of your mouth like the leader of the shellfish and you'll probably say がわ too. Don't stick a knife in your side though, we won't pay your medical bills when you complain to us that this mnemonic got you injured.

mnemonics.meaning: Soldier When you swing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> ends up covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, because you're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soldier</mark>. Only a skilled axe soldier could make such precise cuts as to de-fin a bunch of fish like that. Imagine trying to carve some fish with an axe, to get them ready to eat. Not an easy thing to do. If you're a trained axe soldier, it'll probably be a lot easier. So picture yourself chopping off fins as an expert axe soldier.
mnemonics.reading: へい, ひょう None None Uh-oh, it looks like this axe soldier was so excited about chopping the fins off his fish that he didn't think about how he was going to cook them. The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of hay (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked. Imagine this soldier lighting a bale of hay on fire to cook his fish. The hay burns really fast, but it should be enough.

mnemonics.meaning: Theory What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark>? Your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">theory</mark> about how the thing he's guarding isn't even real. Yeah, you have this whole thing figured out. You have for a while. At this point, it's only fair that you tell your theory to the guard who's wasting his time. Imagine saying your theory out loud to a guard about how what he's guarding isn't even there. Imagine how he would react.
mnemonics.reading: せつ と None The guard listens to your theory but then he says his OWN! He thinks there are two sets (せつ) of guarded items, and he's only guarding one. According to his theory, either one could be real! His theory is more plausible, don't you think? Which theory do you believe? That there is nothing or that there are sets of things?

mnemonics.meaning: Thin Detailed If you take a thread and plant a rice paddy on it, the rice paddy is going to be extremely thin, but also detailed. Imagine this thin thread of rice paddy. It looks so detailed because all the rice paddy stuff is contained in this thin thread shape. You could maybe get one narrow line of rice on this thing.
mnemonics.reading: さい ほそ, こま None This thin rice paddy is for your cyborg (さい). You gave your cyborg a very thin human stomach, so it can only digest one thin line of rice at a time. Picture the cyborg eating a really thin piece of rice. Now it's completely full! What a smart, thrifty cyborg.

mnemonics.meaning: Ume Japanese Plum The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> you aim your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> at from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ume</mark>, aka a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese plum</mark>. Why? Because shooting the ume out of Japanese plum trees is, in your opinion, the best way to harvest plums. Imagine picking fruit off an ume tree this way, shooting them off the branches with your gun. You take aim at an unsuspecting plum — BANG! The gunshot rings in your ears and the smell of gunpowder fills the air. The ume branch is now one plum lighter.
mnemonics.reading: ばい うめ None You've probably heard of ume before, depending on your exposure to Japan, but an ume (うめ) is a Japanese plum. Imagine eating your harvest of ume. Taste the ripe fruity flesh of these Japanese plums as you stuff your gluttonous face.

mnemonics.meaning: Warn Admonish You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warn</mark> people against going outside. It's cold and dangerous in winter! You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">admonish</mark> anyone and everyone you see going out there with your scary winter poem. Imagine the things you'd warn people about. What is it about winter that's so dangerous?
mnemonics.reading:
けい None None To make sure people listen to your warning, you threaten to take away their cake (けい). People will do anything for cake, so when you bring it up, they actually take your attempts to warn them about winter seriously. The winter cold will make you ache
Your whole body will start to shake
Don't go outside
I'll eat your cake
