mnemonics.meaning: Announce Saying you're going to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is just another way of saying you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">announce</mark> something. All that information is the dirt, and to announce that dirt you just slide it on out of your mouth. How's that for a visual? The next time you have something important to announce, calm your nerves by imagining dirt sliding out of your mouth. It's that easy!
mnemonics.reading: こく つ None Now that you're about to announce something important, you should maybe get it nice and smooth in your mouth so the dirt can slide out easier. So take a big gulp of Coke (こく). Coke is just like, the dirt of soda anyway, you know? Imagine drinking some coke and then making an announcement. Try not to burp while you talk.

mnemonics.meaning: Attain Plural You ride your scooter through the dirt while carrying a sheep because you're determined to attain something. Greatness? Glory? Everlasting fame? Maybe you'll attain a plural combination of all those things. After all, you are the best sheep-carrying off-road scooterist the world has ever seen. Feel the dirt spatter your face as you zip around off-road trails with your sheep under your arm. You will attain glory! You will attain greatness!
mnemonics.reading: たつ たち None After you attain that plural combination of glory, greatness, and fame, you get a tattoo (たつ) to celebrate: "world's greatest," in gothic lettering, above a picture of you and your sheep on your scooter. Feel the pain of the tattoo needle as you get this commemorative tattoo. You're getting this tattoo on your forehead, of course, because you want to make sure everyone sees it.

mnemonics.meaning: Bake Burn In a dangerous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gambler</mark> will always try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bake</mark> something before fleeing to safety. It could be his own house on fire, and the gambler would still use the free heat source to get some baking done. Maybe he's gambling that those baked goods will offset the cost of a new home… This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burn</mark>, because that's what happens when you expose something to a lot of heat. Imagine you're the gambler. Feel the heat intensify as your nostrils fill with the smell of baked goods.
mnemonics.reading: しょう や None He used to bake for the Yankees (や). Baseball cakes, bat baguettes, that kind of thing. A career-ending kitchen injury forced him to retire. That's when he developed a gambling problem. But he still likes to bake whenever the Yankees are on TV. Imagine this guy running around baking in the fire of his home, only this time with a Yankees hat and jersey on. He doesn't bake for them anymore, but he still loves the team.

mnemonics.meaning: Borrow Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> thought to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">borrow</mark> something precious from you. This leader did not return the thing he borrowed, and now he will pay. Think about what precious thing this leader borrowed from you so long ago. What was it? Think about how angry you are about not having the thing returned to you.
mnemonics.reading: しゃく か None In your rage, you decide to find this leader, take back what's yours, and in return, borrow the leader's life. So you found him, grabbed him, and threw him into a shack (しゃく) — where you "borrow" a few parts of the leader himself, and do other terrible things to him. Come up with all the terrible things you do to this leader in the shack. Hey, it's just a little payback for the borrowing he did.

mnemonics.meaning: Bow The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bow</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Make sure you know those radicals!
mnemonics.reading: きゅう ゆみ None You have a bow in one hand and in the other... a cucumber (きゅう). You're going to shoot this cucumber with this bow into the salad you're making. Many people don't know this, but this makes your cucumbers taste better. Imagine fitting a cucumber into the string of your bow. Imagine the smell of it as you draw the string back. Mm, take a quick bite, then let it loose.

mnemonics.meaning: Brain Nestled in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark> that you can see with your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brain</mark>. You close your eyes, and you can see the spot, but it's kept deep in your brain, and you have to use its power to find it. As you visualize the treasure chest you realize that the moon was your face, the grass your hair, and the treasure chest your brain! It was you all along!
mnemonics.reading: のう None None If you can unlock the secrets of your brain you'll have powers like Nostradamus (のう). Nostradamus was able to look inward at his own hidden brain treasure chest and see the future, so maybe you can be like him too. Use your brain like Nostradamus and try to see the future. You see... you see... huh, your brain is just surrounded by kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Candy What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Candy</mark>! Picture your mouth opening and closing really fast and hard as candy on a conveyor belt goes sliding in. Munch, munch, munch, you're a candy machine!
mnemonics.reading: None あめ None This candy in particular is just drops of hardened, clear sugar that looks like 雨 (あめ) drops. Picture this kanji rain as it goes into your chomping machine mouth. It tastes like sweet, sugary 雨. Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: Chest Breast In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, there lies a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark> containing a golden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chest</mark> piece. This mighty chest armor will grant you protection from nearly any attack, because it is imbued with moon magic. Imagine finding this treasure chest and donning the mighty chest armor. Feel the weight of the golden chest piece and the vast protection it grants you.
mnemonics.reading: きょう むね None Where is this chest armor from? It's from the moon. Now how would you say that if you were Canadian? It's from the moon, eh (むね). Right, this here chest armor is from the moon, eh. If you can remember this kanji's reading and meaning with a Canadian accent, you'll have no problem, eh.

mnemonics.meaning: Connect You've got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> lying around. So of course you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connect</mark> them all together. Imagine using the thread to fasten the weapon onto your car, creating some kind of monstrosity. Surely this can't be legal?!
mnemonics.reading: けい つな None There's only one reason you've connected all this together: Tuna (つな) fishing. Obviously! Your weapon of choice is a harpoon, which is perfect for catching big tuna. We'll just have to hope your car is amphibious, or we might run into some issues. Now let's go catch some tuna!

mnemonics.meaning: Consume In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> on the line by putting in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>. You put it all the way down there, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consume</mark> it. Imagine yourself doing a magic trick where you put a big sword in your mouth. You say: "Now, for my next illusion, I will consume a sword!"
mnemonics.reading: きつ の None The "consume a sword" illusion came with a cheap magic kit (きつ) you had. It's odd that there would be a "consume a sword" trick in your magic kit. It seems so real for a kit you can buy at the store.

mnemonics.meaning: Equal The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equal</mark> to all of the other non-bamboo temples. Just because it's made of bamboo doesn't make it any less special and spiritual. Picture this bamboo temple compared to some temples made of stone or wood. It's the same size, shape, and it has the same number of worshipers. It's equal in every way.
mnemonics.reading: とう ひと, など None The bamboo temple is also an equal distance away from the other temples in とうきょう. When you look at a map of とうきょう temples, you can measure them out and they'll all be perfectly equal. While many things in とうきょう may not be created equal, the temples are, at least.

mnemonics.meaning: Flat Object Counter Counter For Flat Objects A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that's been sliced up in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> can be used as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flat object counter</mark>. Since it's winter, all the leaves have fallen off the tree, so it's easy to cut into slats. These slats can be used as counters for flat objects. What with the snow and wind, winter also tends to knock trees down flat… which is probably why the tree radical on the left looks all flat and squished here. That's another way to remember this kanji is a counter for flat stuff!
mnemonics.reading: まい None None As you count each counter for flat objects, a bunch of mice (まい) show up and start climbing all over you. This won't do, so you take two slats and start smashing and flattening all the mice. Now that the mice are flat too, you can also use them as a counter for flat objects. Good job, mice. Now imagine yourself counting with these mice you just smashed. They're freshly dead, so there's not much of a stench yet, but you still feel bad about using dead mice to help you count. Imagine yourself counting with these mice as you try to hold back tears from all the murder you just did.

mnemonics.meaning: Forget The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> will cause you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forget</mark> all of the most important things. People think memories are kept in your brain, but that's not true. Your heart is where all of your most precious memories are kept, and when it dies, you forget them all. Imagine someone close to you experiencing the death of their heart. They look right at you but they've already started to forget everything. I know this is not a fun thing to imagine, but use that emotion to help you remember this kanji, not forget it.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう わす None When someone forgets everything they're left with only one thing to do: go bowling (ぼう). Bowling is easy, and there's nothing to forget. You pick up a ball. You drop it. Everything else is automatically taken care of. You know, that's probably why so many old people go bowling. They forgot everything else.

mnemonics.meaning: Frustration Using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> is always going to end in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frustration</mark>. Have you ever made a daisy chain? Try making a daisy lip ring. Just imagine your frustation as you try to make it small enough to fit through your lip piercing.
mnemonics.reading: か いじ, いら, さいな None After some frustration, you made your flower lip ring. Now you look like an Egyptian (いじ) pharaoh. Because all ancient Egyptian monarchs wore flower lip rings (historical fact)! Imagine yourself dressed as an ancient Egyptian pharaoh, wearing your newly-crafted flower lip ring. Think how classy (or strange) you feel.

mnemonics.meaning: Instruction You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> stuff to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>, giving it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instruction</mark>. This river is a new river so it needs you to say things, giving it instruction on what to do. Otherwise the river wouldn’t know how to behave. Imagine saying things to this river. What would you say? Flow harder! Babble better! Picture yourself shouting at the river as the water moves along.
mnemonics.reading: くん よ None While giving instruction to the river, you see a small boat coming down it. Inside the miniature boat is a raccoon (くん) captain and his raccoon crew. The raccoon captain is instructing them, “Stroke! Stroke!” Picture this raccoon captain and his raccoon crew coming down the river. The raccoons are all chittering about as they paddle the boat down the river.

mnemonics.meaning: Kind Type, Seed If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> seems extra <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark>, you know it's a different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kind</mark>. Not all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">type</mark>s of grains are the same. So when you feel the heavy type, you know it isn't the same as the light kind. Imagine sorting all the different types of grains by their weight.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ たね, ぐさ None You sort all of the different kinds and types by putting them in the right chutes (しゅ). They slide away, probably to some big type-based piles you can't see. Picture the two chutes you use to separate the different types of grains. One has a sign that says "Light Chute" and the other says "Heavy Chute."

mnemonics.meaning: News Report You want to share <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">happiness</mark> with people so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>s with the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">news</mark>. Now when people want a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">report</mark> of all the happy things going on, they can just look down before they sit. Stand up and look at the happy news today! It definitely isn't sad or depressing.
mnemonics.reading: ほう むく None You research and report the news from home (ほう). Only after, once all of the news is stamped onto the stools, do you leave your home. Because your reporting is done from home, most of the news is about how your plants are growing. What the cat did this morning. And it certainly isn't the news without the weather!

mnemonics.meaning: Paragraph The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paragraph</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: く None None You have to write an entire paragraph about a topic, so you choose cookies (く). Imagine actually getting an assignment to write a paragraph all about cookies. Would you write about your favorite cookies? Your eating methods?

mnemonics.meaning: Permit Allow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> it at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark>. That's the only time I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">allow</mark> you to say it. That's the only time I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">permit</mark> you to say it. Other than that, no saying anything. Noon is your window. Imagine a world where you're not allowed to say anything except for at noon. At that moment, after you've been staring at the clock, waiting for that opportunity, you burst forth with things you want to say. But, once it hits 12:01, you are grabbed and your mouth is covered. You are not permitted to say anything outside of that time.
mnemonics.reading: きょ ゆる None Where do these archaic horrible rules exist? The smaller version of Kyoto, Little Kyoto (きょ). Normal Kyoto is just fine. This smaller one is where a group of people went to create their own little town with their own dumb rules. Imagine going to big Kyoto where everything is fine. Then, go to little Kyoto where it's not. Little Kyoto has the short きょ (instead of the long one), and this is how you can remember the difference.

mnemonics.meaning: Possible Passable With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>, anything is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">possible</mark>. Having a lip ring grants you the power to conquer any obstacle, achieve any goal. As long as it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">passable</mark> lip ring, that is. If it isn't good enough, it isn't possible to be passable. Imagine getting a magical lip ring. First, you have to find a passable one. Then, you have to go through the pain of having your lip pierced. Is it even possible to imagine how painful that would be?!
mnemonics.reading: か None None Since anything and everything is possible with your new passable lip ring, you use it to get a new car (か). You go to the car dealership and ask for a free (passable) car. The manager is impressed with your lip ring and gladly hands over the keys to the latest model of your favorite car. Not bad. It was possible to get this passable car thanks to your lip ring. Hooray!

mnemonics.meaning: Priest Monk A religious <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> could be either a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monk</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">priest</mark>. You don’t know, their face is covered by a mask! Picture this leader in their mask. Listen to them chant prayers that reverberate throughout the building.
mnemonics.reading: そう None None This monk or priest is wearing a mask to protect their soul (そう). You aren't a monk or a priest, so they don't want your not-religious-enough eyes to dirty their soul. Imagine the monk/priest's bright, pure soul shining behind the mask. You'll never actually see it, unless you're becoming a monk/priest yourself, and then your soul will need protecting too.

mnemonics.meaning: Prohibit Prohibition Killing two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> is expressly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prohibit</mark>ed. Don't get me wrong, you can rip up one tree with your jackhammer, but not two. Imagine standing in front of a forest with your jackhammer, staring at a sign with just this kanji on it. Tree plus tree with jackhammer equals prohibited. Hmm.
mnemonics.reading: きん None None The person who decided to prohibit jackhammering two trees is the King (きん) of England. He's the only person who's able to prohibit certain things, so it had to be him. Picture the King angrily covering his ears as his subjects jackhammer trees. He screams and shouts, his crown bouncing on his head, and points at his new sign that prohibits the jackhammering of trees.

mnemonics.meaning: Quiet Within the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> water, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">conflict</mark> stirs, but is made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quiet</mark> by the muffling power of liquid. Under this blue water is a great conflict between two sea monsters, but on the surface it appears peaceful and quiet as the water prevents sound from rising above the surface. Imagine watching this conflict from above the blue water on a boat. You can kind of see the action, but you can't hear a thing.
mnemonics.reading: せい しず None As you watch below the quiet water, every once in a while a saber (せい) breaches the surface and quietly slices back down. Sabers are sharp, curved, and totally quiet. Great for underwater blue conflicts, and sneaky assassinations.

mnemonics.meaning: Sit Seat Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, there are two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>s on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. What do they do there? They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sit</mark>. The people use the dirt under the canopy as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seat</mark> for their butts. Imagine how it feels sitting on dirt. Is it comfortable? Probably not. Maybe you feel a little uneasy about just sitting on plain dirt. Try to recall this feeling whenever you encounter this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: ざ すわ None Who decided people have to sit like this? The Czar (ざ). The Czar wants to be above everyone, so he makes them sit on the dirt under canopies while he goes around on horseback or something, towering over them as they sit. This Czar you met is ruthless and has formally banned all non-sitting activities. Imagine the excruciating pain, the stiffness, the cramping in your legs — all caused by this 24-7 sit-a-thon the Czar has cruelly decreed.

mnemonics.meaning: Smoke If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> hovering beside it, there's going to be a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smoke</mark> billowing around. Mostly smoke, on account of the fire. Now it's in your eyes and mouth. It gets in your lungs and you can't breathe. Why, helicopter, why! Imagine the smoke stopping up your lungs and getting in your eyes. All you know other than the smoke is the sound of the helicopter that's causing it to happen.
mnemonics.reading: えん けむ, けむり None The smoke is too much and you realize this is the end (えん) for you. You're gonna die here! Imagine choking on the smoke and accepting that this is the end. Boohoo, if only you'd learned more kanji before the end!

mnemonics.meaning: Steam The water from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> can create a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">energy</mark> when made into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steam</mark>. Steam power used to be all the rage back in the day. Steam comes from water, water comes from tsunamis, so logically, tsunamis are a great source of energy. Imagine how much steam a tsunami could create. Hear the steam hissing off of the water and feel the moisture from the steam washing over your body.
mnemonics.reading: き None None In order to contain this steam energy and store it for later, you lock it up in a box with a key (き). That way the energy can be used at a later time. Provided you don’t lose the key, that is. Steam is very light, so carrying this box of steam energy will be no problem. Picture yourself wandering about with a box of steam in one hand and a key in the other.

mnemonics.meaning: Tap Strike, Slap On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tap</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strike</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slap</mark> to create a beat! The stamp looks like a little drum, but you're really just hitting your mouth for fun (the stamp was an excuse to make it seem normal). Put a stamp on your mouth and look in your bathroom mirror. Now tap that stamp and make a fresh new beat the young kids can dance to!
mnemonics.reading: こう たた, はた None When you tap and strike the stamp on your mouth, you make a ta-ta (たた) sound. Imagine yourself making a beat with the little stamp drum on your mouth. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it? Picture yourself as a drummer, tapping away on a miniature stamp drum on your mouth. With each tap, you create a lively ta-ta beat!

mnemonics.meaning: Throat Into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> shot an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> with an attached <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark> so that they'd be able to see into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throat</mark>. Imagine the arrow with its hook shooting down into your mouth and hooking into your throat. Ouch! Now the leader is peering down in there, but you don't know why.
mnemonics.reading: こう のど None From your throat you hear a voice. Not yours, but one you recognize. It's こういち! What's that rascal doing down in your throat? The leader starts to tug こういち out of your throat, but he resists. "No, I like it down here, it's dark and damp." The leader gets angry and pulls harder, which hurts! This is your throat, after all, don't you get a say?!

mnemonics.meaning: Type Category, Kind The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> you feed to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> can be of any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">type</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kind</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">category</mark>. It doesn't matter what kind of rice it is, the big geoduck will eat it. Picture this big geoduck shoveling rice down in a flurry of geoduckness. Hear the sloshing and goopy glugging as the geoduck gorges itself on every type of rice.
mnemonics.reading: るい たぐ None While eating every type and kind of rice from every category, the big geoduck has become even bigger. Its body is ruined (るい). It's painfully obese. This geoduck has eaten itself to ruin. Picture this big, rice-engorged geoduck, too big to move. It's now in a wheel chair and on a rice IV. Imagine its wheelchair squeaking by as it wheezes and groans — ruined by all those types of rice.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">previous</mark>ly gave everything in this town a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wash</mark>. There are many laundromats in this town, so when the previous tsunami hit, all of the detergent mixed with the water and gave everything a good wash. Imagine this soapy tsunami, washing all the things in town. Hear the soapy waves bubbling with cleanliness as they crash down around you.
mnemonics.reading: せん あら None It wasn't just the town that got a wash, it was the centaurs (せん) too. (Centaurs happen to live in this town.) And being half horse, centaurs have a lot of hair that needs washing. Luckily, the soap tsunami gave them a good wash too. Imagine these centaurs frolicking around in the aftermath of the tsunami previous. It's just like a big bathtub for them. Hear them splashing and neighing in the water.

mnemonics.meaning: Zen Zen Buddhism You want your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> so you practice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Zen Buddhism</mark>. Zen is all about meditating and letting earthly things go. There's nothing more simple for your spirit than being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Zen</mark>. Try out Zen meditation for a little bit. Look away from your computer or phone or tablet and let your life be simple for a second. Just let it all go and free your spirit from all the noise.
mnemonics.reading: ぜん None None The reading for this kanji is Zen (ぜん), just like the Zen in Zen Buddhism. Pretty easy to remember, no? Just remember that the reading is the same as the meaning. It’s easy! Without a new reading to learn, you should have time to close your eyes and clear your mind. Zen it out, friend.

mnemonics.meaning: Acquire If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark>, it's likely you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acquire</mark> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that. Imagine loitering around near the sun temple. Maybe you acquire some illegal goods, maybe you just acquire a tan (it is a SUN temple, after all).
mnemonics.reading: とく え, う None You managed to acquire some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil." Your eyes fill with tears under Tokugawa's gaze and you drop everything you acquired to the ground. You bow before him apologizing. You'll never do this again!

mnemonics.meaning: Add The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> lets you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">add</mark> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the mighty additive power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion! Say this sentence out loud. Incredible! You've used the power of your mouth to add words together in a sentence. Your parents must be very proud of you.
mnemonics.reading: か くわ None Your parents are so proud of you being able to add words together that they surprise you with a new car (か). Wow! You add some stickers to your bumper and add your favorite playlist to the car radio. Let's drive. Imagine riding around in your new car, singing songs with your powerful mouth to the playlists you added to the fancy new radio.

mnemonics.meaning: Book Counter Counter For Books You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">book counter</mark>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain. Imagine counting books on a bunch of bookshelves. One book, two book, red book, blue book!
mnemonics.reading: さつ None None You use this book counter method to count all the books Satsuki (さつ) has in her house. Remember her? She's got, like, a ton of books, but she's just a little girl so she needs some help. That's where your book counter know-how comes in handy. Imagine how tedious it'd be to watch her counting one by one. Teach her your book counter ways!

mnemonics.meaning: Bury The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> next to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> is where you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bury</mark> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things. Imagine the village where you grew up. Can you see the dirt area where all your ancestors were buried?
mnemonics.reading: まい う, うず None You don't just bury dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet uni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive. Imagine crying as you bury your pet uni. Your tears can't save it now. (Though it is a bit ironic, since it needed salt water.)

mnemonics.meaning: Busy You'll work your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> if you're too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">busy</mark>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself. Look around you. See all those busy people? Their souls are dying. Don't end up like them.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう いそが None Take time out of your busy life and go bowling (ぼう) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling. Think about your busy schedule this week. Now cancel everything and just go bowling instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Clique Clan Passed out in front of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> lies a former <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>. He's now a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>, but once ran a popular <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clique</mark> called the Cool Kids <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Clan</mark>. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own. Imagine this washed up drunkard leader passed out in front of the gate to your house. You have to pass him whenever you enter or exit your house. He's gross and he smells. Experience the stench in your nostrils. How he was ever the leader of a clan you have no idea.
mnemonics.reading: ばつ None None Eventually you get sick and tired of this washed up clan leader and you gather your own clique to chase this guy away from your gate and your property. You and your friends grab some bats (ばつ) and use these bats to beat the drunkard leader. Being beaten with bats frightens him, and he scurries away. Hear the crushing blows of bats against flesh as you imagine this scene in your mind. You're beating the crap out of this guy with a bunch of bats, but hey — he had it coming.

mnemonics.meaning: Cloth To a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is just normal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloth</mark>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know. Picture a narwhal wrapped in a fuzzy towel blanket, with a towel tail cover, and some towel underpants. Everything is made of this type of cloth.
mnemonics.reading: ふ ぬの None If you use this type of cloth for your clothes and blankets people will call you a fool (ふ). They think you're a fool who can't tell the difference between human cloth and towel cloth. "You fool, you aren't a narwhal, that cloth isn't for you!" they say. They're so mean.

mnemonics.meaning: Continuation At the edge of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s mark the spot where you must <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, since any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">continuation</mark> requires a way across. The trees seem long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop them down? Imagine yourself on this cliff. You desire a continuation for your journey, not wanting to stop here. Feel the strong wind on your body, blowing your hair about as you stand on the edge of the cliff. The leaves on the trees rustle in the breeze.
mnemonics.reading: れき へ None Continuation is impossible unless you chop these trees down to make a bridge to the other side. You decide to use a wrecking (れき) ball. Luckily, there's one right by you. So you take the wrecking ball and knock the trees over, making a bridge with them. Picture yourself using the wrecking ball to knock down the two trees on the cliff. Hear the the trees crack and splinter from the force of the wrecking ball. That wrecking ball is the sound of continuation.

mnemonics.meaning: Continue You have to gather <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sell</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">continue</mark> living. You want to make a living, don't you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day! Imagine selling thread so you can continue living. You search for thread continually now. But are you gathering thread to continue to live, or living to continue gathering thread?
mnemonics.reading: ぞく つづ None You have to continue to sell that thread because a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling! Continue selling thread and paying off the Bosozoku. It's the only way you can continue to survive!

mnemonics.meaning: Decrease There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, but the escape <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is being blocked by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark>, and you can see your chances of escaping <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decrease</mark> rapidly. Imagine how you feel as you try to get down the tsunami slide, past the drunkard and the creeper, who are decreasing your chances of getting away.
mnemonics.reading: げん へ None This decrease in the chances of escaping the tsunami is really upsetting Genji (げん), who's waiting impatiently behind you. Picture Genji, as his chances of survival decrease along with yours. Poor Genji.

mnemonics.meaning: Easy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">easy</mark> kanji are the same! Easy is easy!
mnemonics.reading: い, えき やさ None What would be an easy reading for this kanji? い! The sound easy starts with! I told you easy was easy.

mnemonics.meaning: Entangle Coil Around, Entwine If you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the middle of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, you’re going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">entangle</mark> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it. Imagine trying to kiss someone with a piece of thread between your lips. Feel the thread getting all entangled between the two of you. Thread entangled, tongues entangled, lips entangled — just a thready kiss of entanglement.
mnemonics.reading: らく から None This isn't going well, so you pull out the weird kiss thread and entangle it around a rack (らく). Good thing that rack was there! Much better to have it entangled around a rack when you're trying to kiss someone. Imagine pausing this kiss to pull a thread out of your mouth and entangle it around a random rack in your room. Smooth move, Casanova! Your partner will totally love that.

mnemonics.meaning: Flute Within the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> grove, someone asks your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> for being there, and you explain it's to harvest bamboo to craft a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flute</mark>. Imagine yourself cutting down some bamboo, thinking, "This is the reason I'm here, I need a flute, ASAP!" There is no other reason to be here besides this.
mnemonics.reading: てき ふえ None You cut down the bamboo and whittle a flute. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien tech (てき) in front of you. You've done what you came to do. You summoned an alien craft with your bamboo flute, gaining some alien tech in the process. Open up the box to see what tech awaits you.

mnemonics.meaning: Footwear A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">footwear</mark>. If you look into the black hole, you can see your footwear right there, marked with the flag.
mnemonics.reading: り は None You grab your footwear from the black hole. In your footwear (thanks to the shelter they provided), some reeds (り) have grown in! It's amazing that these cute little reeds could grow in your footwear in the middle of a black hole. As a great philosopher once said, life finds a way.

mnemonics.meaning: Form Appearance If you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> it will change its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">form</mark>. Its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appearance</mark> will alter completely! Picture a valley in your mind. Now put a roof on it. Hmm. It isn't <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shape</mark>d like a valley anymore.
mnemonics.reading: よう い None Its new appearance looks familiar to you, like it's a big yogurt (よう) cup! A valley with a roof on it looks exactly like a yogurt cup. Huh! Now imagine this taking shape before your eyes and becoming actual yogurt! You grab a giant spoon and take a bite.

mnemonics.meaning: Group Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> of this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there. I hope this group is full of people who enjoy being inside someone else's mouth, because they're gonna be pretty mad when you let them out if they aren't.
mnemonics.reading: だん, とん None None This group is so big it takes you till dawn (だん) to get your measurement: they weigh a ton (とん) too! Imagine letting this group of, now very wet, people out of your mouth one by one. They don't seem to care that they weigh a ton! That's a large measurement, they should be proud.

mnemonics.meaning: History The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">history</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">history</mark> kanji are the same. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: し None None History was full of famous sheep (し). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons! Look at a history book, behind each of those humans was a sheep, changing the world as we know it.

mnemonics.meaning: Insect If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark>d to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insect</mark>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect. Imagine holding up an insect to the sun to compare the two. See how they both shine, but the sun shines more brightly than the insect.
mnemonics.reading: こん None None While you’re holding up an insect to the sun for comparison, a flock of condors (こん) flies by, blocking out the sun. There are so many condors that they manage to totally block out the sun. Feel how dark and cold it is suddenly with all those condors blocking out the sun.

mnemonics.meaning: Junior Follower “Don’t <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> – <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Junior</mark>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run! Imagine Sean Connery saying “Don’t loiter – run, Junior!” and you should have a much easier time remembering this phrase if you remember it in his voice.
mnemonics.reading: と None None Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones Junior takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his toe (と) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer. Imagine that you are Indiana Jones Junior and this is happening to you. Feel the terrible pain of your throbbing toe as you clutch it, with the bad guys catching up with you.

mnemonics.meaning: Midair You jumped off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> for some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> and now you're floating in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">midair</mark>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair. At the moment you can't remember the reason you did it, but when you jumped off your roof you just floated in midair.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう None None As you spin a bit in midair you look up and see Chewbacca (ちゅう) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam. Oh Chewbacca, you lovable fuzzball. You better not drop me in midair, or I'll die. I hope you bring me up there!

mnemonics.meaning: Mix A raging <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rises next to the calm <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. When you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> these two things, it's clear that they cannot <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mix</mark>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun. Imagine the sun getting blocked out as a tsunami rises up from the ocean. Feel the cold fear of death on you as the tsunami approaches. That tsunami is gonna mix you up.
mnemonics.reading: こん ま, こ None Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a condor (こん) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a mix — a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl. Imagine yourself getting mixed up in this situation and the pterodactyl-sized condor picking you up. Feel the condor's talons digging into your shoulders as it grabs you up and flies you towards the sun.

mnemonics.meaning: Morally Good Good A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> loses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so it picks them up in its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take them to someone who's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">morally good</mark> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good</mark> to reaffix them. Imagine yourself as the good person being approached by this forlorn sheep without horns. Hear the clack of the horns together as the sheep drops them out of his mouth onto the ground and lets out a pathetic bleat. “Baa~aa~ah~”
mnemonics.reading: ぜん None None Since you are morally good, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the good teachings of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time. Imagine yourself using your Zen magic to heal this sheep. Place your hands on the sheep’s horns and imagine returning them to their rightful location on the sheep’s head. Feel the soft wool of the sheep as he bleats in happiness.

mnemonics.meaning: Order Sequence When they migrate to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>, a group of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoducks</mark> must do so in a certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">order</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sequence</mark>. Geoducks usually live in the ocean, but when they migrate to a river, they do so in a specific, predetermined order. Imagine what that sequence might be. Maybe in order of neck length, with the longest-necked geoducks going first? Or maybe in alphabetical order?
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None Actually, they go in birth-month order, starting from June (じゅん). No one knows why they follow this June-based sequence. But the geoducks born in June always go first in the migration order. Imagine it's June, and you're on a beach somewhere watching a bunch of geoducks make their way to a river. Marvel at the biological clock that determines the June-based migration sequence for these fascinating creatures.

mnemonics.meaning: Outer Space You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> to keep yourself <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> and safe from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">outer space</mark>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you. You don't want to float up into outer space and get all wet, do you? No? Then you better make sure you have a roof above your head.
mnemonics.reading: う None None Why isn't it dry in outer space, you ask? Because of all the uni (う) swimming around up there. They have nasty, wet, pointy spikes and they're all over the place. Look closely up at outer space and you'll see all of the uni floating around up there. They're really dark, so it can be hard to notice them, but I promise you, they're there.

mnemonics.meaning:
Part Of Speech Speech Particle, Particle Of Speech, Grammar Particle What you say to the director is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this part of speech, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong. "Is it an adjective?"
"No, that's the wrong part of speech."
"Is it a verb?"
"N-no! Of course not!"
mnemonics.reading: し None None The director asks you again, "What is the part of speech for the word sheep (し)?" You stare blankly at him. What part of speech is that?! It's an animal, you know that. Oh! A noun. Duh.

mnemonics.meaning: Potato If you see some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, pull them up and you'll find a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">potato</mark>. Potatoes grow when flowers dry out. All the nutrients are going to the potato under the ground, so the flowers up top get sucked dry.
mnemonics.reading: None いも None Potatoes are totally emo (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers. Picture an emo person sitting alone in a dark room, staring at a potato. "You and I are the same."

mnemonics.meaning: Renew It's important to focus <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so that one can emerge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">renew</mark>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU. Imagine sitting in your house all winter, meditating and thinking about how you can renew yourself.
mnemonics.reading: かい あらた None Winter ends and, renewed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: kayaking (かい)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life. Imagine being back in your house in winter. You're thinking about all the kayaking you're gonna do when winter ends. You're even making the movements with your arms, so you'll be a really renewed you.

mnemonics.meaning: Riot Disorder If you stab somebody in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>, it’s sure to start a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">riot</mark> and cause <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disorder</mark>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done. Imagine yourself getting stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella. It’s very painful. Taste the blood and metal in your mouth as this happens to you.
mnemonics.reading: らん みだ None Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man Randy Savage (らん). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A riot immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter. Picture yourself squaring off with Macho Man Randy Savage in the middle of this riot. You have the advantage of having an umbrella, but Randy has the advantage of being himself. Picture yourself getting into a fight with him.

mnemonics.meaning: Season Joint On the bottom of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s, there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> that tells you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">season</mark> in which it was cut. Additionally, the stamp also has information on the condition of the bamboo’s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">joint</mark>s, because no one wants to buy bamboo with damaged joints! Picture yourself in a store, looking at a bunch of different bamboo stamps to make sure you don’t buy one that’s out of season, or one that has damaged joints. The season and the joints, that’s what quality bamboo is all about, and it’s why we have these stamps!
mnemonics.reading: せつ ふし None These season stamps are marked on bamboo sets (せつ). You can't buy a single banana or a single grape, and just like that, if you want some nice seasonal bamboo, you have to buy them in sets. How many bamboo sets will you be buying this season? I'm getting 42 sets.

mnemonics.meaning: Take Along Connect Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> is what you always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">take along</mark> with you. Make sure they're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connect</mark>ed well so you don't lose them! Your scooter and your car, connected by a tiny little string, are the two things you take along with you wherever you go.
mnemonics.reading: れん つ, つら None You take along your scooter and your car. Anything else, you can do a rental (れん) for! The roof over your head? Rental. The clothes on your body? Rental. All of your friends? Rental. The only thing you permanently take along with you are your scooter and your car.

mnemonics.meaning: Tongue The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tongue</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!
mnemonics.reading: ぜつ した None You’re sound asleep in bed when your tongue drops out of your mouth and you start to drool, getting saliva all over the bed sheet (した). You wake up with a soggy patch of sheet near your mouth and wipe the drool off your face. Your significant other sees the whole thing. Your significant other had been watching you sleep with your tongue out for a while now, so you're super embarrassed you wet the sheets with your nasty tongue drool. You feel very judged and embarrassed.

mnemonics.meaning: Violence When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> gets <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violence</mark> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence. Picture this violent fight scene in your brain. Imagine water locked in battle with the sun as the sun’s fire flares up and the water starts to sizzle.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう, ばく あば None But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of violence. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of bowling (ぼう). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it. Imagine the sun and the water trying to bowl. Hear the sound of bowling balls rolling down the lane and pins rattling around and crashing together.

mnemonics.meaning: Wealth Give some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wealth</mark>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode. Picture the talented person huddled over a pile of shellfish, whispering to them about the wealth they'll soon be turned into.
mnemonics.reading: さい, ざい None None This talented person really starts accumulating wealth when their cyborg (さい) is unveiled. It's a half-man, half-shellfish cyborg that plays the xylophone , and everyone wants to buy it. You'd be wealthy too if you sold that cyborg you made. It may not have any shellfish in it and it can't play the xylophone, but you could change that…

mnemonics.meaning: Young There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> to show that you're still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">young</mark>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers. Look to your right, if you see flowers (metaphorically, maybe) then you're still young. Congratulations!
mnemonics.reading: じゃく わか, も None When young people look to the right, they'll see their future: a walker (わか). You know, those metal contraptions with tennis balls on the bottoms to make sure they don't scrape the floor. Everything may be flowers and happiness now, but your future is in a walker. All young people have a walker looming just off to the side. A sign that your youth won't last forever, dear summer child.

mnemonics.meaning: Abundant Wealthy In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark>, spirits are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abundant</mark>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it. Just picture those forest spirits from that famous anime film. The woods are full of them. An abundant valley of spirits.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう None None In spirit valley, it's not just spirits that are abundant. There is an abundance of youths (ゆう) as well. Imagine an abundant number of spirits and youths hanging out, drinking microbrews and eating avocado toast. Spirit Valley is a weird place.

mnemonics.meaning: Butt Buttocks You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> in total, and put them one by one up your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">butt</mark>. Imagine taking these nine flags... count 'em... and putting them up your butt. With each one that's up there it gets harder and harder to fit the next one in.
mnemonics.reading: None しり None Now that you have nine flags inside your butt, you have to get them out. But, you don't know how to. So you ask Siri (しり), "How do I get nine flags out of my butt?" In your head, doing the Siri voice, come up with an answer for your nine-flags-in-the-butt predicament.

mnemonics.meaning: Certain You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>. It is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> that you will damage it. Try hitting a sponge on a turkey's forehead. Not certain. Now a stone. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Certain</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: かく たし None You're killing this turkey, and you need to make sure he's dead for certain. The reason you need to make sure this turkey is dead is because of the cock (かく) in your life. Male chickens get really jealous when turkeys are around. As you smash the stone into the turkey's forehead, yell out "This is for you, my cock! THIS IS FOR YOU!" Your cock lover watches from the shadows.

mnemonics.meaning: Contraption Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> sits with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> little <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contraptions</mark>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them. Can you even imagine twenty completely unique contraptions? Why don't you try, just for fun.
mnemonics.reading: かい かせ None You want to know what these contraptions are for, so you ask. The drunkard says, "These are kayak (かい) contraptions *urp* they're for your uh *blarp* kayak... things." "Kayak contraptions" is pretty vague, but you do have a kayak, so you're tempted anyway. If only you could figure out what each contraption did so you could justify buying some.

mnemonics.meaning: Cover Incur A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> loses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> as a part of the damage it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">incur</mark>s after death. That's why the spirit goes on looking for new skin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cover</mark> itself with. Some spirits get mad when they lose their skin, so living humans have to incur their wrath as the spirits search for more skin to cover themselves with.
mnemonics.reading: ひ かぶ None When you incur the wrath of an angry spirit it'll try to cover itself with your skin, and you'll feel your skin heat (ひ) up. It feels like your skin is burning a little. You're about to incur the same kind of damage the spirit did when it lost its skin cover. Oww owww!

mnemonics.meaning: Crime In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> kingdom, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark> is the most likely to commit a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crime</mark>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes. Picture a snake as a hardened criminal. See this snake with many prison tattoos and muscles from working out in his jail cell. Hear the snake hissing as it slithers about to commit yet another crime.
mnemonics.reading: はん おか None This snake has evaded the law for too long. It’s time for a true hero to put an end to its crime spree. Enter Han (はん) Solo. Han Solo is the only man strong and brave enough to put an end to this snake and his crime filled ways. Now see Han Solo doing battle with the snake (cue Star Wars music). The snake hisses and lunges at Han, but Han shoots the snake and it’s incapacitated. Smell the smell of scorched snake flesh in your nose.

mnemonics.meaning: Damage Injury, Harm You slip off the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on the ground causing some serious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damage</mark>. Oof, this is a really bad <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">injury</mark>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth. Imagine that moment as you fall off the roof. In slow motion you can see the roof moving away, you see yourself as a little kid, a teen, an adult, then BAM you've injured your mouth. Ow ow ow!
mnemonics.reading: がい None None As you try to assess the damage, you hear someone shout, "Guy (がい), hey, you okay, guy?" They run up to you, but your mouth is too damaged, you can't respond. "Okay guy, I'm gonna call you Guy now. Let's get you to the hospital." No matter how much you try to wave your hands and gesture, they keep calling you Guy. It's really annoying, actually, because you aren't a guy and you aren't Guy either. But your mouth is too damaged for you to tell him.

mnemonics.meaning: Deliberation Discussion What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliberation</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discussion</mark>. Picture yourself in a deliberation with some other people. They think what they're saying is right, and it drives you mad. Then you realize that you're doing the same thing.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ None None What are you in deliberation about? Whether or not to send some poor soul to the guillotine (ぎ). "I think he should go," you say. "I don't think he should," says another. This deliberation is going nowhere... Imagine how the deliberation concludes. Then, at the end, someone says "This deliberation is over! We have decided to _________" (in regards to the guillotine).

mnemonics.meaning: Difficult A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Chinese</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">difficult</mark> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult. Try and picture a Chinese turkey in your brain. Now imagine yourself trying to catch it, but you just can’t. It’s too difficult. The Chinese turkey is too elusive.
mnemonics.reading: なん むずか None Do you know the actual reason Chinese turkey are so difficult to find? It’s because they’re all made out of Naan (なん). Of course they’re elusive when they blend in so well with all the other Naan! Picture yourself entering a bakery, frantically scouring through all the Naan in an attempt to find one that’s actually a Chinese turkey. "WHERE ARE THE TURKEYS?", you scream, to everyone else’s bewilderment. Those elusive, difficult to find Chinese Naan turkeys…

mnemonics.meaning: Disaster A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>! At the same time? This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disaster</mark>! Imagine a disaster so bad that there are floods AND fires. That's too much!
mnemonics.reading: さい わざわ None This disaster was caused by your cyborg (さい)! It's malfunctioning, running around leaking large amounts of water and breathing fire. I guess you didn't work out all the kinks before you let it roam wild. You better figure out a way to stop your cyborg from causing more disasters like this. Fix it now, or you're gonna be in big trouble.

mnemonics.meaning: Dislike When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sees the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark>, she feels a strong feeling of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dislike</mark>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets. Imagine yourself feeling this strong dislike towards the Mona Lisa. She gets all the attention and you get none. It’s not fair and you’re upset.
mnemonics.reading: けん, げん いや, きら None You dislike the Mona Lisa so much you hire Ken (けん) the samurai to cut her up. Ken walks slowly toward the Mona Lisa, dislike shines in his eyes, but then! He falls for her too. No! Ken, destroy her!

mnemonics.meaning: Distressed Troubled If you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distressed</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">troubled</mark> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child. Imagine yourself as this distressed and troubled person. Taste the taste of sap and bark in your mouth as you nom on the tree with all your might.
mnemonics.reading: こん こま None You thought you were the most distressed and troubled person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled condor (こん). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day. Picture a very distressed condor watching you munch your mouth all over its tree house. You've made a condor enemy this day.

mnemonics.meaning: Dream A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> is upon your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dream</mark>. Watch yourself sleeping. Then, a net of flowers appear on your forehead as you start to dream.
mnemonics.reading: む ゆめ None You dream about cows saying "moo (む), moo, moo!" While still dreaming, you say "moo" out loud too. "Moooo!"

mnemonics.meaning: Earthquake Quake, Shake <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> causes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> that causes an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earthquake</mark>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quake</mark>s. Picture this happening in real time. First it starts to rain really hard, then the ground starts to shift and run, then everything is shaking and quaking so violently it's an earthquake!
mnemonics.reading: しん ふる None The earthquake shakes you so violently that you fall over, banging your shin (しん) on the coffee table. The edge of the coffee table is very sharp, so it cuts into your shin pretty badly. You grab your shin, but the earthquake shakes the coffee table toward you to hit your shin yet again! Ow ow ow stop!

mnemonics.meaning: Exist A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> sticks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to see what might <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exist</mark> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else. Imagine seeing a narwhal sticking a stick, and maybe even its horn too, into the dirt on land. It needs to know if life exists outside of the ocean for sure.
mnemonics.reading: ざい None None The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could exist outside of its world. It pulls out a xylophone (ざい) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it. Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone and think about what exists in this world. It's a sad song, you realize.

mnemonics.meaning: Fly The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fly</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fly</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
mnemonics.reading: ひ と None When you fly, you generate a lot of heat (ひ) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat. You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.

mnemonics.meaning: Give Birth Property You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cliff</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Life</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give birth</mark> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it! In your despair, you throw all your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">property</mark> off the cliff too. The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets towards the ground below.
mnemonics.reading: さん う None You give birth, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's Santa-san (さん)! He caught your baby! And all your property. Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. You can keep all my property and give it away as presents.

mnemonics.meaning: Guilt Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> to show their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guilt</mark>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with. Imagine throwing a net around someone you think, no, you know is guilty of doing something bad to you. It feels pretty nice.
mnemonics.reading: ざい つみ None The guilt shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen xylophone (ざい) out of their back pocket. Woah! The xylophone is huge, how did they... well whatever, you definitely have proof that they're guilty now and the cops should be here any minute to take your criminal catch.

mnemonics.meaning: Individual The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> has grown <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> from saying so many things. This is what makes them different from everyone else, they speak truly like an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">individual</mark>. Imagine that leader's old mouth saying things that make them stand apart from the others. They're individual from everyone else.
mnemonics.reading: こ None None As an individual, they must teach all the 子s (こ) their way. Their individual way. "You must be your own individual. Don't be sheeple," he says to the 子s.

mnemonics.meaning: Machine Next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, you spot <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>, not once but twice. Only a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> would be the type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> to not use the nearby <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">machine</mark> toilet. There's a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice. Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a machine toilet right there?
mnemonics.reading: き はた None Oh, I see — the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn't have the key (き). If he had a machine like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he's reduced to pooping under the tree instead. Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn't sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.

mnemonics.meaning: Overthrow Collapse Someone stabbed the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overthrow</mark> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole. Imagine a mole sneaking up behind the leader mole and stabbing him with a knife. This type of overthrowing of leadership feels familiar to you. Maybe this has happened before in the past?
mnemonics.reading: とう たお None Where do leaders get overthrown the most? In とうきょう. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in とうきょう. Picture this like an exaggerated reenactment on the History channel. Leader after leader of とうきょう gets overthrown and replaced with the next guy. It never stops. (Until the end of the Edo period, I guess.)

mnemonics.meaning: Passage of Time Pass Through, Manage Tying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> each year will help you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manage</mark> the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">passage of time</mark>. That way you’ll know how many years you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pass through</mark>, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count. Picture yourself coming back to the same tombstone each passing year and tying a new thread to it. You're trying to manage these feelings by keeping track of how much time passes.
mnemonics.reading: けい た, へ None Dealing with the passage of time can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of cake (けい). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well? Maybe this is your future tombstone, and eating cake each year is a preemptive celebration of your death day! Ooh, what a spooky theory.

mnemonics.meaning: Percent Percentage Sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> of a toilet, you're praying your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> will be flushed away, beseeching the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> decorating the bathroom wall. The poop needs to be one hundred <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">percent</mark> flushed away because you're on a date, and you don't want even one percent of your explosion left for them to see. You take a peek under the lid to check, and your poop explosion is one hundred percent gone! Phew!
mnemonics.reading: りつ, そつ ひき None It was extra important that there was zero percent poop left, because you're not on a date just anywhere, you're at the Ritz (りつ)!
