Look around you at the classy surroundings of the Ritz Hotel bathroom. You feel one hundred percent relieved now, and ready to enjoy your date at the Ritz!

mnemonics.meaning: Pressure Under any <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, there's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> that's under a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pressure</mark>. Imagine being down there under that heavy cliff. Imagine feeling the cliff's pressure as you watch it compress the dirt. It's so hard to breathe... h... help!
mnemonics.reading: あつ None None You want to increase the pressure, so you stack on a second cliff. "Ah, two (あつ)?!" the dirt cries out in dismay. This dirt is tough, but it's really starting to feel the pressure now. Imagine yelling out to the dirt to encourage it: "Ah, two cliffs is nothing! Come on, you got this!" You're the dirt's gym buddy, and you won't let it buckle under the pressure.

mnemonics.meaning: Prevent Prevention If there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> you want to go it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prevent</mark> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh! There's a building right there. Try to go that direction. Oh, did the building prevent you? Told you so.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう ふせ None The building is preventing you from going the right direction, so you pull a bowling (ぼう) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further. Your bowling antics are now preventing a bunch of people from going the directions they want to go. Nice job.

mnemonics.meaning: Stab You walk into this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> on it, then a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> falls out of it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stab</mark> you. Ow! What the heck?! What was a knife doing in that tree? Imagine the pain and confusion of being stabbed by a violent tree. You hit your head on the tree again, as if to test it, and again a knife falls out and stabs you. Oh, so it's a stabbing tree, is it? That does it.
mnemonics.reading: し さ None There's nothing more dangerous than a tree that likes to stab, so you get your saw (さ) and start to saw it down. Trees that stab get sawed. Feel the grain of the saw's wooden handle in your bare hand. As the saw bites into tree bark, a retaliatory rain of knives comes stabbing down around you. But you don't even flinch. You will saw this stabbing tree down.

mnemonics.meaning: Stinking Stinky, Smelly Wash your<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> bar of soap if you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stinking</mark> everything up. Seriously. If you or someone else is stinking to high heaven, embrace a big bar of self care.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう くさ, にお None You're stinking up the room because you spent your day rolling in 草 (くさ). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that 草 too... Imagine trying to use a big bar of soap on yourself to get the stinky 草 off. But it's not working... the 草 stink is SO STRONG!

mnemonics.meaning: Surplus Excess Regardless of whether or not you wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> while you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>, you’re going to have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surplus</mark> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused. The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
mnemonics.reading: よ あま None One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart yo-yo (よ) stand. Having a surplus of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage. Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.

mnemonics.meaning: Tail You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fur</mark> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tail</mark>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail. What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
mnemonics.reading: び お, ぽ None You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge beehive (び)! These bees made their home under the tail! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops. See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!

mnemonics.meaning: Theory You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>, throwing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> in front of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark>, "I have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">theory</mark>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems! This theory you've thought of is great, it's going to change everything!
mnemonics.reading: ろん None None "What is your theory, Ron (ろん)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort. "Ron? Ron, what's your theory? What's your theory, Ron?" Hermione asks over and over. But you freeze. You don't remember who you are. "Hermione, I have a theory that I was just a person learning Japanese, and not a magical boy at all." "Shut up Ron, that's a stupid theory," she replies.

mnemonics.meaning: Thick Hanging off the edge of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>-worshipping <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thick</mark> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries out to the sun to save them from this cruel fate. Even the thickness of their unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to climb back up on their own. I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
mnemonics.reading: こう あつ None The child glances up at their thick unibrow and yells, "ah, two (あつ)!" Yup, it turns out the sun misunderstood the child's pleas for help. Instead of pulling them up from the cliff, it gave them a second thick unibrow on top of the first one. Imagine the sun noticing its mistake and apologizing to the child. "Ah, two thick unibrows wasn't what you wanted? Wow, I'm sorry. This is embarrassing… I'm actually not sure I can remove the second one now that it's on there."

mnemonics.meaning: Wife You place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>. She's gone now, but she was once your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wife</mark>. Oh, how you miss your Wolverine woman and her long, sharp claws… Now all you've got left to remember her by is this cross. Your poor, poor wife.
mnemonics.reading: さい つま None Wait a minute… She can't be dead because your wife is a cyborg (さい)! How could you forget?! All your wife needs is a little cyborg tune-up. Bionic brain here, some new claws there. Yep, your cy-wife's as good as new.

mnemonics.meaning: Blame The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blame</mark>. They take the blame for everything from food poisoning and allergies, to cutting people's feet on beaches. Just imagine an innocent little shellfish, living its quiet little life, while everyone's heaping blame on it. It hides in its little shell and tries to deflect all that blame. What a life!
mnemonics.reading: せき せ None When those poor shellfish aren't having blame piled on them, they're being eaten, because shellfish are thought to make for a very sexy (せき) meal. Imagine trying to look sexy as you slurp up those saucy little shellfish.

mnemonics.meaning: Build Construct Your magic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> lets you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">build</mark> what's in your mind's eye. You do the bridge pose, and in your mind you imagine your brush painting an actual bridge. When you open your eyes, there it is! A bridge has been built, leading straight to your front door.
mnemonics.reading: けん た None You build a bridge. Immediately after, someone is climbing up onto it. It's Ken (けん) the samurai. He waves at you and says, "Did you build this? The craftsmanship is amazing." It seems like Ken the samurai really appreciates your building skills.

mnemonics.meaning: Clause A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is only a winter tree due to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clause</mark> in its tree contract. The clause states the tree can only be a tree in winter, but not during other seasons. Once winter descends, the clause takes effect and it becomes a tree. (See how winter is descending on the tree from above in this kanji?) Go ahead and look at its contract — see the winter tree clause, right there, in fine print.
mnemonics.reading: じょう None None This clause was written into all trees' contracts by Joe (じょう), the large farmhand. Joe noticed that the trees were getting too crowded, so he wrote up these clauses and added them to the trees' contracts. Now, the forests are less crowded, thanks to the little clause. Makes sense that a farmhand like Joe would do this, too. The fewer trees, the more farmland. It's good for folks like Joe.

mnemonics.meaning: Come To An End You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come to an end</mark>. Imagine a tsunami simultaneously happening as the world comes to an end. Oh no, isn't there any way to stop this!?
mnemonics.reading: さい す None Just as the world is about to come to an end, your cyborg (さい) appears and blocks it with its cyborg body! So the world won't come to an end this one time, thanks to the cyborg you made. Though it doesn't look very good. The cyborg is beaten up and full of water. This might be the end for it...

mnemonics.meaning: Come True Grant You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> close to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, praying for all your wishes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come true</mark>. Perhaps some gracious god will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grant</mark> what you wish for? Picture yourself with perhaps a small cross on a necklace, keeping it close to your mouth as you speak your prayers. What will you wish to come true? It could be anything you want!
mnemonics.reading: None かな None And if you really want your wish to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come true</mark>, make sure to write it down in <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">kana</mark>! Legend has it that writing down your wishes in kana will lead to higher chances of them actually coming true! Whether you go with hiragana or katakana is up to you, just make sure it's all in some form of kana.

mnemonics.meaning: Committee A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is a woman who talks about grain with other women on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">committee</mark>. Together they're known as the Committee of Grain Women. What does this committee discuss, you wonder. Imagine what this committee of women could be coming together to discuss. Isn't grain just grain? Why do they need a whole committee?
mnemonics.reading: い ゆだ None Well, they formed this committee because eagles (い) have been eating all the grain. The women meet as a committee and try to come up with ways to stop these pesky eagles from eating all the grain and leaving none for the humans. Imagine a committee of women standing together in a field of grain, watching eagles swooping around. They take notes and mutter to one another about their options.

mnemonics.meaning: Conserve You only have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s so you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conserve</mark> what's left. You only have like, three eyes left. If you conserve them.
mnemonics.reading: しょう, せい はぶ None You're trying to conserve your eyes, when the Shougun (しょう) marches by. He stops, sees you, and demands you give him your remaining eyes! But sir, I'm conserving what little I have left! The Shougun stares down at you, eyes blazing, and you hand over all but one of your eyes. Now you really have to conserve, or you'll be blind. Thanks Shougun. I bet he has plenty of eyes, he didn't need yours.

mnemonics.meaning: Control System <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cow</mark>s, using nothing more than a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>, have taken <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">control</mark> of the world. Their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">system</mark> of control is brutal — payback for how we humans have treated them, I guess. Imagine this new cow-controlled world — there are cows on every street corner, armed with towels and knives, intimidating all us humans into following their system.
mnemonics.reading: せい None None It's time to take control back from the cows! Pull out your saber (せい) and fight back! The cows' towels and knives won't stand a chance against your saber!

mnemonics.meaning: Criticism If you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to point when you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> things you're really just throwing around <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">criticism</mark>. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism. Some criticism is okay, as long as it's constructive and it helps the person get better. But when you start pointing fingers, it's time to step back and try to not be such a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: ひ None None If you're having trouble not giving out criticism, just think about how you would react if someone criticized you. You'd feel an embarrassed heat (ひ) rise throughout your body. That heat will cover your whole face. Before you throw criticism around, imagine that embarrassed heat. You don't want to feel that way, so why would you do it to someone else?

mnemonics.meaning: Cut Off A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> harvesting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> uses an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cut off</mark> the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs. Picture this lion on his hind legs, walking through a rice field. He’s holding an axe in one hand and acting like a human. See him cut off the plants and hear the whoosh of the axe as he cuts.
mnemonics.reading: だん ことわ, た None The lion will cut off rice stalks until dawn (だん). But at the first light of dawn, it will run and hide in the shade of the trees, cut off from the rice. When dawn comes in Africa (it's a lion, so that's where he is) it gets too hot to be in the sun, so the lion gets cut off from his job of cutting things off.

mnemonics.meaning: Duty Both a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duty</mark> to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty. Imagine yourself being protected by your king and leader. They don’t really like you, but it is their duty to protect you. See them fighting off evil doers and taking bullets for your sake.
mnemonics.reading: にん まか None You’re the village nincompoop (にん), but the king and the leader still have a duty to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world. You’re a nincompoop. Even though you’re so nincompoopy, your king and leader still have a duty to protect you. Feel happy and content, despite your nincompoopery.

mnemonics.meaning: Element The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">element</mark> essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together. Visualize this element of life, interconnecting all living things. Without it, everything would fall apart and into chaos.
mnemonics.reading: そ, す もと None You need to keep this element clean, so you make sure to wash it with soap (そ) every single day. This turns out to be pretty hard because the element is an invisible thread, but you do your best. Imagine grabbing hold of the element that holds all life together and trying to wash it with soap. It's slippery so you keep dropping it and soap keeps going in your eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: Enemy Seeing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> means the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enemy</mark> is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy. Picture yourself holed up in a winter encampment, waiting to strike at the mohawk wearing enemies. Feel the cold around you as you scan the horizon for mohawks.
mnemonics.reading: てき かな, かたき None You're kind of a techie (てき), so you have an advantage over your enemy. You're armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages. Imagine yourself all teched out like the techie you are. Hear the beeps and boops of all the technology you have at your disposal as you search for more mohawk enemies.

mnemonics.meaning: Envy Jealousy <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Sheep</mark> are always looking at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> animal, full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">envy</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jealousy</mark>. Picture a sheep comparing itself to the next creature, and feeling deep envy and jealousy. Why does it feel that way?
mnemonics.reading: せん うらや None The reason the sheep feels such envy and jealousy is that the next creature is a centaur (せん)! Who wouldn't be jealous of a creature as noble as a centaur? Being a centaur is every sheep's dream, so they can't help feeling terrible jealousy when they see one.

mnemonics.meaning: Establish If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> idea out loud, then it will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">establish</mark>ed immediately. Try it out: I want a stabbing weapon with extra weapons that can pop out on the sides. *POOF* You've established a new weapon. And it's been added to the official weapon wiki of the world.
mnemonics.reading: せつ もう None Weapons have to be established in sets (せつ). So you have to make another one that goes with it. Make them cohesive please. Establish weapons in sets or the people who use them won't be able to match each other.

mnemonics.meaning: Examine You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> on it, so you get closer to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">examine</mark> it. As you examine the tree and the squid in it, you think, "Huh, nope still weird." You should examine it further to find out what's going on.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None You're sticking your face in really, really close to examine this little squid in the tree when Ken (けん) the samurai appears behind you. "There you are, squid! Thank you citizen, I've been looking all over for my little chum." Imagine how many trees Ken examined before he found you both. Picture him putting his face really close to each one, then shedding a single tear when he realized this squid wasn't in it.

mnemonics.meaning: Hill You have a scene going on inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark>. It is of a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> atop a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hill</mark> atop the mountain, which is already pretty high. Imagine this hill of horns on top of this mountain. This hill of horns makes it possible for you to get just high enough to touch the top of the sky.
mnemonics.reading: こう おか None How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was okay (おか), but that's about it. Feel indifferent about this hill of horns on top of the mountain. It's all in your head anyways.

mnemonics.meaning: Increase The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> is a mask which, when put on, will greatly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">increase</mark> the amount of dirt. Imagine putting it on, and suddenly the dirt around you increases by quite a bit.
mnemonics.reading: ぞう ふ, ま None Use the dirt mask to increase the dirt around you. The zombies (ぞう) are trying to escape, so you just keep increasing the dirt on top of them so they can't get out. Zombie hands keep coming out of the ground, but as long as you wear the mask and increase the dirt on top of them, they won't be able to escape their earthly prison.

mnemonics.meaning: Inspect Investigate If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inspect</mark> it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">investigate</mark> the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious. Inspect the tree. Inspect the top hat. Did you find anything?
mnemonics.reading: さ None None As you inspect the tree, you pick up a saw(さ) and start cutting it. You need to investigate how the tree and the top hat are connected, and a saw is the only way to do it properly. Turns out the top hat was just decorative and the tree was growing out of the earth, like any other tree. Imagine your shame now. You should be more careful — don't be sawing trees willy nilly.

mnemonics.meaning: Judge I hereby cut your assets in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">half</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>, says the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark>. At someone's divorce proceedings. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book. If you can't decide who gets custody of the baby, the dog, the house, the car, the furniture, the savings, and the house plants, you have to leave it up to the judge. And the judge's judgment is that everything is cut in half with a knife. What an efficient judge.
mnemonics.reading: はん, ばん None None This judge is Han (はん) Solo, so you know he's not going to back down. Han Solo the judge is a very busy person, so he has to judge quickly and efficiently. He'll cut all your stuff perfectly in half before he wastes time listening to you argue about who earned what. Sure it's crude, but at least it's… equal?

mnemonics.meaning: Matter Affair The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> tribe is too important to deal with small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">matter</mark>s and trivial <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">affair</mark>s. Picture this hoity-toity cow leader who thinks he’s too good for small matters and affairs. See him acting all fancy like he’s better than everyone else. The cow even moos with a fake British accent. How pretentious.
mnemonics.reading: けん くだり, くだん None All of his affairs are taken care of by Ken (けん) the samurai, who he hired as his underling. Picture Ken the samurai scooping poop for the leader of the cows, because that's a matter of poop and state.

mnemonics.meaning: Occasion <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Building</mark>s hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark>s on special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occasion</mark>s. A festival can't be happening all the time. Then it wouldn't be special, it would just be a party building, so they can only happen on special occasions.
mnemonics.reading: さい きわ None The occasion this time is to celebrate your wonderful cyborg (さい). It's about time you did something nice for it. Your cyborg has been really great lately. Your wife loves it. It saved the world. It's nice of you to take this occasion to show the cyborg how much it means to you all with a festival.

mnemonics.meaning: Pray If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, you better <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pray</mark> for your life. Spirits only hold axes if they're thinking about murder, so pray as hard as you can to try and get it to spare you. Imagine trying to pray as hard as you can as a spirit with an axe closes in on you. Can you hold your prayer concentration long enough?
mnemonics.reading: き いの None You pray and pray and pray and nothing happens. You stop praying and dare to open your eyes. There is a key (き) in front of you. Grab the key and hold it before you and pray for the spirit to take it. Moments later, both the key and the spirit are gone. I guess the key was prayer all along. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

mnemonics.meaning: Raise If there’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">raise</mark> that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest. Feel the grass in your toes and the fins in your hand as you raise them up to the sky. See the sun glistening off the fins as you raise them up in the air.
mnemonics.reading: きょ あ None This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little Kyoto (きょ). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to raise fish fins up in the air. Imagine yourself going through the same process as before, only this time imagine yourself in Little Kyoto. Little Kyoto is really little, so make sure you're in the right spot.

mnemonics.meaning: Receive All the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are yours to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark>. They're all for you. You're the king of the shellfish. Look at all of them, the entire world's shellfish, and they're all yours to receive.
mnemonics.reading: せい もら None Why do you want to receive all these shellfish? Because it's the moral (もら) thing to do. Oh benevolent, moral king of all the world's shellfish, please receive us. Picture yourself as some enlightened, moral king of all the world's shellfish, with your sole duty to receive and take in all the world's shellfish into your flock.

mnemonics.meaning: Recognize Acknowledge Whatever people <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to you will be carved by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Sounds cruel, but it's a way to make you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recognize</mark> their power. How could you not acknowledge somebody if every word they said was carved into your heart? It's not particularly painful, but it does make you quite uncomfortable.
mnemonics.reading: にん みと None Having their words carved into your heart makes you recognize the authority of many people. But the only one you could ever truly acknowledge, is Nintendo (にん). You're one of the biggest Nintendo fans out there, so how could you not acknowledge their greatness? No matter what is carved into your heart, Nintendo will always occupy a special place.

mnemonics.meaning: Resources The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resources</mark> we have to share and distribute. Our resources are based around a system of trading shellfish. It's not that weird, plenty of ancient societies used shellfish as their main resource!
mnemonics.reading: し None None You save up all of your resources so you can buy a sheep (し). You bring a big sack of your shellfish resources to the market and finally get to pick out that sheep you've had your eyes on for months. Of course you're going to use your resources to get a sheep. You're living in a time when shellfish are used to trade for goods and services!

mnemonics.meaning: Righteousness The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Righteousness</mark> is as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">righteousness</mark> does, right? Go on, put that righteous radical knowledge to use!
mnemonics.reading: ぎ None None Such righteousness! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the guillotine (ぎ). "THIS IS NOT RIGHTEOUSNESS!" you yell, just before the guillotine comes down on your neck.

mnemonics.meaning: Rights Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> there's a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> stuck in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>, because it (the turkey) has no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rights</mark>. People can just shoot turkeys with arrows and no one is punished, because they (the turkeys) don't have any rights. Imagine if humans didn't have any rights, like this turkey. People could just gun each other down in the street and no one would be punished for it... oh wait.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None "You have rights, so I won't shoot you like this turkey," says the voice of Ken (けん) the samurai, from above you in the tree. Ken jumps down and picks the turkey up, the broken arrow sticking out of its neck. "Turkeys do not have rights, my friend. Just let this one go."

mnemonics.meaning: Sect Faction A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark>, but there is a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sect</mark> that protects this tofu cliff. This sect of the tofu-lovers club takes their duties very seriously and they must protect this tofu cliff at all costs.
mnemonics.reading: は None None All of the members of the sect are standing on the cliff, their hands raised, and right as the tsunami is about to collide with them, they shout, "Ha (は)!" and it's repelled! The tsunami sinks and rolls back out to sea, the tofu cliff is safe! Oh, do you want to be a member of the tofu sect? HA! Don't make me laugh. If you ask to be a member of a sect, you'll never get in. Never ask for a sect.

mnemonics.meaning: Task Duty You use a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to give yourself the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to do all of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">task</mark>s. It's hard to get a task done in winter. That's why you have this spear to power and motivate you.
mnemonics.reading: む つと None Your task is to spear this cow. "Moo (む)!" it yells at you and runs away. You need to make dinner though... that's your task, so you better catch up to that cow and put an end to its mooing. The moo haunts you as you finish your task. Luckily this spear is helping you keep going even though this task is really difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: Tax Some of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> has just been taken by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark>. This is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tax</mark> you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grain was used like currency, so it makes sense that guards went around collecting grain tax. Can you imagine a guard coming to your door and demanding you pay your grain tax?
mnemonics.reading: ぜい None None You have to pay this tax, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a zeiber (ぜい). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you vis my zeiber!" he shouts. You don't want to be sliced with the zeiber, so you listen to vat he zei-zei-zeis and pay the tax.

mnemonics.meaning: Whole Taking out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, you sew together the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>s to make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whole</mark> again. The world has been in turmoil and the public has been suffering, but it's time to stop splitting our hearts apart and fighting. It's time to be whole again.
mnemonics.reading: そう None None Once their hearts are whole, the public's soul (そう) becomes one! Suddenly people who were fighting for years are crying and holding one another. Their souls recognize each other, they're healed, and the whole nation is finally seeing eye to eye.

mnemonics.meaning: Aid Assist You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the game of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aid</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">assist</mark> the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself. If you're from the UK, just imagine someone kicking or stomping on your fingers instead. Picture yourself playing football. You catch the ball with your fingers and then assist your team by running and smashing your body into the enemy team. But in the process you smash your fingers... so you need to go to the aid tent.
mnemonics.reading: えん None None When you need aid for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the end (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you. You can't assist your team anymore because you got hurt. This isn't fair! It's the end. The end of your life and your career. Boo hoo hoo!

mnemonics.meaning: Appearance State, Shape You have a great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> because your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> gives you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appearance</mark> of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition. See yourself in this ideal appearance. Everyone loves to look at you because you look so awesome. Your heart has given you many great abilities. Feel strong and powerful in this body of yours.
mnemonics.reading: たい わざ None While you may have the appearance of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to tie (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing. Since you don’t know how to tie a tie or tie your shoes, you wear slip ons and clip ons. Hear the noise of Velcro being undone as you kick off your shoes and unclip your tie after a hard day’s work at the office.

mnemonics.meaning: Birth They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to go through <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">birth</mark>. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it. Picture multiple people you know saying you should do yoga if you plan to give birth. It isn't a question of whether you want to, it's the correct way to do it. So you should.
mnemonics.reading: たん None None To prepare for giving birth you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep tan (たん). Hopefully having a tan doesn't make birth harder, since you've worked so hard to do this the correct way with so much yoga.

mnemonics.meaning: Clothes The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothes</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
mnemonics.reading: い, え ころも, きぬ None An eagle (い) sees a pile of your clothes and lays an egg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place. Look at the eagle and her egg sitting atop your clothes. Every time you get close the eagle starts to screech at you fiercely. Screee! Screee!

mnemonics.meaning: Condition See all those <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark>'s left? Good thing they all fell on his left, or he would've been in a terrible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condition</mark>. Picture a bunch of big, sharp icicles all falling down directly next to this dog. Now imagine the condition he would've been in, had they all fallen directly on top of him. Poor little thing.
mnemonics.reading: じょう None None What saved the dog's condition was none other than Joe (じょう), the local farmhand. He constantly keeps an eye on the dog's condition, including any dangerously sharp icicles that could descend on him. Good guy Joe, always worrying about his dog's condition. Everyone needs a farmhand like Joe.

mnemonics.meaning: Congratulations You use the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to spit <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> at people as a form of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulations</mark>! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth. Shellfish were once used as currency, so this totally makes sense. Just think of the shellfish as money coming out of your mouth as you say your congratulations.
mnemonics.reading: が None None When you say congratulations like this, you look just like a gargoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle. The next time you're congratulating someone, assume the gargoyle stance and dump all of their congratulatory shellfish on them from your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: Construct Build You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">saw</mark> to cut down <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">construct</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">build</mark> a building. The bamboo saw was crafted by a master bamboosmith, and cuts through trees with ease so you can quickly construct this new building. Imagine yourself working the bamboo saw. It's made of bamboo, but its sharp edge glistens with a mysterious aura as you slice through tree after tree. Feel how unnaturally easy it is to cut down piles of logs to build with.
mnemonics.reading: ちく きず None As you construct and build this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a chick (ちく) pops out of one of the logs you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks! Is this because you used the magical(?) bamboo saw?? Imagine trying to construct the rest of this building covered in baby chicks. They're very cute, but this is dangerous! You have to build very carefully, so you don't accidentally hurt any of them.

mnemonics.meaning: Descend Inside the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cow</mark>. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">descend</mark> to reach it. Focus on descending the stairs. There are many signs that say "To Winter Cow: descend" with an arrow pointing down. "I guess I'll have to descend," you say.
mnemonics.reading: こう お, ふ None You descend to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's こういち's face. "Hello, thank you for descending all the way down here to see me," says the Winter Cow with こういち's face. "You thought you could use the Winter Cow to stop me, but as you can see, I got here first."

mnemonics.meaning: Each Every You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">each</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">every</mark> one of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth. Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
mnemonics.reading: かく おの None Actually, each and every one of your best pals is of the cock (かく) variety. By that, I mean each of them is a rooster. Imagine kissing each cock on its beak. Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

mnemonics.meaning: Evaluate You should <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark>" before you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evaluate</mark> a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand. What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say "peace" before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう None None When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “Heyo!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to evaluate who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things. Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”

mnemonics.meaning: Expense Cost <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dollar</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are used to pay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expense</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cost</mark>s. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars. Imagine opening your bank account and looking at all of your monthly expenses. Now drag the little dollar and shellfish icons over to cover all of those costs.
mnemonics.reading: ひ つい None What is the biggest expense and cost? It's the heat (ひ) bill. When you see how expensive your heat is, you feel a heat going through your body too.

mnemonics.meaning: Figure Shape, Form “Bring in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> so that I may examine her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">figure</mark>!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one. Imagine yourself as a figure judge on this panel. You need to find a woman with the perfect figure to cast in your commercial. You'd cast yourself, but you just aren't confident (Ridiculous! You're special, and beautiful, and no matter who you are [yes you reading this right now] you should be proud of who you are!).
mnemonics.reading: し すがた None The next woman comes in and you examine her figure. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a sheep (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure! We should all try harder to have a figure like this stunning sheep woman!

mnemonics.meaning: Force The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> where a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">force</mark> of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb. Imagine yourself in the womb, the circle of power. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force of your mother all around you.
mnemonics.reading: せい, せ いきお None Now pretend you're the mother. You'll need all the force you can muster to bring that baby into the world, so you grab hold of your special saber (せい) and slice it about in the air to give you the extra force you need. All that force works wonders, and when the baby's born you slice through the umbilical cord with your saber.

mnemonics.meaning: Give Up Abandon You have something to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, and shout, "I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">GIVE UP</mark>!" Standing on a towel is the universal signal for giving up, but you still need to say you're abandoning whatever it is with your mouth too (just in case).
mnemonics.reading: てい あきら None Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!" You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Indicate Show You can use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indicate</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">show</mark> someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go. Imagine using this jackhammer to show someone where the prize is buried. Feel the vibrations through your hands and the rest of your body.
mnemonics.reading: じ, し しめ None Actually, you're unearthing Jesus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to indicate to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to show you the way of the Lord? This guy.” Picture Jesus getting all over the top and super preachy about his religious beliefs. He’s doing everything he can to indicate to the crowd that he’s the best, and show them how cool he is. Listen to Jesus preach to the crowd, desperate for their attention.

mnemonics.meaning: Lie Down Sleep From the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark> falls and hits <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and he has to go over to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie down</mark>. And eventually he goes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleep</mark>. Picture this entire scene. The icicle falls in slow motion from the roof. It hits wolverine right in the middle of his forehead. He goes down. He has to lie down. He has to sleep.
mnemonics.reading: しん ね None While wolverine sleeps, he makes a horrible neighing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH! Wolverine might have a concussion that's making him neigh in his sleep. I guess it's good that he's lying down, but I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to sleep... Maybe you should wake him up so the neighing will stop—I mean, so he'll be okay!

mnemonics.meaning: Manage A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> who knows how to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark> will have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manage</mark> all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them. Picture a Viking trying to manage his Viking friends so they'll use the bathtub properly. He has to manage which people go in when, how hot or cold the water is, and provide all the soap. It's a very important job.
mnemonics.reading: えい いとな None The poor Viking trying to manage all the others keeps having to confiscate acorns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts. Some of the Vikings managed to fill their bathtubs with acorns and are trying to rub themselves clean with them instead of water...

mnemonics.meaning: Monk Can you look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and know which <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> you need to go? Then you might be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monk</mark>. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be. Picture a monk walking through a large field in the middle of nowhere. He knows where to go, he's not afraid. The dirt will lead him in the right direction.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None You want to know the monk's trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a bowling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction. Imagine a monk bowling in the middle of the road. Imagine your shock at how well he handles the ball. Also, imagine how heavy it must be for a monk to carry a bowling ball everywhere!

mnemonics.meaning: Penalty Punishment You'll be put in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> if you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> things with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> — that's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">penalty</mark>. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out. That's why the police have to put you in a net, as a penalty. Imagine getting so mad that you use a knife instead of words to say what you're trying to say. A net falls over you and pulls you down. The knife goes flying. This is your penalty for acting like a crazy person.
mnemonics.reading: ばつ None None Your penalty for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with bats (ばつ). If you don't want to be punished with bats, maybe next time don't use a knife instead of your words.

mnemonics.meaning: Plan A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cheap</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. A plan to stay cheap. Picture a tree coming up with some elaborate plans to make sure they can spend as little money as possible.
mnemonics.reading: あん None None The cheap tree's plan involves only buying anchovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies. You're not sure about this anchovy plan. Are you cheap enough to choose a life of eating only anchovies?

mnemonics.meaning: Plan With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> resting atop your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark>, you devise a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it. Imagine being trapped under this bamboo tree that is resting on your head. You’re stuck. Feel the weight of the bamboo tree pressing on your head as you try and devise a plan to get out from under it.
mnemonics.reading: さく None None But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a sack (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a plan to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape! Bamboo is usually kind of light, but this bamboo has a sack of rocks tied to each end making it heavy. Imagine yourself trying to remove this bamboo tree by pushing it up and away from you. It’s like doing a bench-press, bamboo style.

mnemonics.meaning: Present Submit Pointing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present</mark> yourself or offer to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">submit</mark> your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school. Picture yourself in class. You want to present next! You want to submit your ideas for class approval. So raise those fingers to the sun the correct way and wait for your teacher to call on you.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None You want to present your show and tell of tater tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you submit the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots! The next time you have to submit work in class just raise your hand and give everyone tater tots. Instant "A" material.

mnemonics.meaning: Put You need your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark> before you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put</mark> it on the ground and try to lure something into it. You put your net there to catch something, but if it's twisted or tangled, it won't be very effective. Imagine that some wild animal wanders into your net. Yes! You knew putting the net there was a good idea. But wait… Oh no, it escaped! It turns out your net wasn't straight when you put it there.
mnemonics.reading: ち お None Then you decide to put cheese (ち) in your net. With a perfectly straight net and the cheese you put down as bait, there’s no way this fails. Success is all about how you put the net down and the cheese you put in it. Imagine the smell of the cheese as you put it in the net. Maybe a sharp cheddar? The aroma really carries. All the better to attract more animals! Soon you’ll be putting your cheese-eating prey on the dinner table.

mnemonics.meaning: Region Boundary Lying in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> puts her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to understand the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">region</mark>. She loves to know all the regional differences among wines and other alcohols, and to her there's no better way to do this than putting her mouth on the ground and literally tasting each region. Picture this drunkard in the dirt, her mouth pressed to the ground. "Ahh," she says, "so this is the taste of the Bordeaux region." Then she has a glass of Bordeaux, and starts noting all its particular regional qualities.
mnemonics.reading: いき None None Turns out she thinks everything from this region is icky (いき). In fact, to the drunkard, every region tastes icky and gross. You don't have the heart to tell her it's the dirt and ground, not the region itself, that tastes icky… Imagine her crying out, "Why are there such icky, earthy notes in all these regional wines?!" Feel the second-hand embarrassment for her. In her drunkenness she can't understand that putting her mouth on the ground makes everything taste icky, no matter what region it's from.

mnemonics.meaning: Renew In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. As you pull it out of the mucky ground, you can feel your life force being<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">renew</mark>ed. Seems like the treasure has some magical ability to renew the cells in your body. Really try to imagine this feeling as you pull the treasure out of the rice paddy’s ground. Perhaps it feels just as refreshing as getting a full night’s sleep.
mnemonics.reading: こう さら, ふ None Just as you were getting accustomed to this life renewing treasure, こういち comes out of nowhere, stealing your treasure and running off with it. All you could hear was a sly “yoink!”, and suddenly your life renewing treasure was gone. God knows what things こういち will get up to with this life renewing treasure in his possession (but it sure won’t be anything good).

mnemonics.meaning: Respond If someone gets under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respond</mark> to them. You usually ignore everyone, but this one person... they really got under there and touched your heart. You finally feel like they're the right person to respond to.
mnemonics.reading: おう こた None You respond and it turns out it was to the 王 (おう). The 王 touched your heart, you responded, and now you're together. It's like a fairy tale!

mnemonics.meaning: Shinto Shrine Shrine, Palace It may just be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark>, but this here is actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Shinto shrine</mark>. It is indeed just a roof over a bathtub, but I guess spirits inhabit everything according to Shintoism, so there's no reason this bathtub can't be a Shinto shrine too.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう, ぐう みや None What god does this Shinto shrine hold? You see that "It's a-me-ya (みや)! (Mario!)" It makes sense, the person who says "It's-a-me! (Mario)" is someone who works on bathtubs (and plumbing).

mnemonics.meaning: Sleeve A mix of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> helped you invent the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleeve</mark>. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born! Your spirit and your arms are free! Imagine how unreasonable life was without sleeves. How on earth did you survive without them?!
mnemonics.reading: しゅう そで None And without these sleeves, your arms would be so dead (そで). They'd be all exposed and defenseless! Imagine all the ways your arms would be so dead if you didn't have sleeves. Sunburn, bug bites, miscellaneous cuts and scrapes... Just so, so dead. Good thing you've got sleeves.

mnemonics.meaning: Suck Inhale Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark> you use to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suck</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inhale</mark> things into your body. If you're ever having trouble remembering how to suck or inhale, just picture an actual escalator that leads into your mouth. That'll definitely help.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう す None Use this mouth ability to suck cucumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended. You can inhale a cucumber too, I suppose, but don't tell anyone I told you to.

mnemonics.meaning: Surpass While riding on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you grow a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> you already have in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surpass</mark> the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again! Picture yourself running on a scooter with a bunch of other people and closing your eyes tight, willing another mustache to sprout out of your face to surpass them all.
mnemonics.reading: か す, あやま None Suddenly, something else manages to surpass you all. It's a car (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you. Watch helplessly as the car surpasses every single one of your scooters. Both of your mustaches droop in shame.

mnemonics.meaning: Territory Taking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> will place you into enemy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">territory</mark>. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared. Imagine this geoduck shouting orders at you to march into enemy territory. See its gross body as a mouth forms and starts shouting out orders.
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None Not wanting to end up dead in enemy territory, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a row (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away. Feel yourself in the row boat as you imagine rowing away to safe territory. Hear the geoduck in the background shouting at you from shore, ordering you to return to land.

mnemonics.meaning: Undress Escape The light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is shining on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> who’s been on duty all night. In fact, the moon light is making him so warm, he’s trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">undress</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">escape</mark>! Somebody stop him! Picture the guard being so warm from the moonlight that he’s trying to simultaneously undress and escape. You can’t just let him leave his post!
mnemonics.reading: だつ ぬ None You’re unable to stop the guard from undressing and making his escape, so you decide to start throwing some darts (だつ) at him. Perhaps that’ll make him stop. Imagine yourself desperately throwing darts at the undressing, escaping guard, trying to make him stop. Or perhaps trying to pin his clothes to his body using the darts. Anything to stop this madness!

mnemonics.meaning: Unite Rule, Govern You take all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> them into one place to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">unite</mark> them. With all your thread united and wrapped together, you're ready to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">govern</mark> the world! Allocate all of your thread like you would your cash: by uniting it! Not at a bank, but in a big, intertwined lump. Now nobody can stop you and your big lump of thread!
mnemonics.reading: とう す None You're busy trying to unite all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see とうきょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there. Try to do this yourself at home. Unite all of your thread and poof! There's とうきょう!

mnemonics.meaning: Value Price A great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can look <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark> at something and know its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">value</mark>. That social media site? 44 billion dollars. That job position? 50k a year. A four-day work week? Um… sorry, no, there's no value there. See? Leaders can see straight to the heart of matters to grasp something's true value. Imagine how terrifying it is when your leader looks straight at YOU. Don't worry, though — you've got more value than you give yourself credit for, and your leader can surely see that.
mnemonics.reading: ち ね, あたい None One thing your leader knows has great value is cheese (ち). Say goodbye to your days of casually snacking on cheesy treats from the conbini, because your leader's decided the value of cheese is going up 1000%! Imagine the despair you feel walking down the cheese aisle at the store and seeing how one little pack of string cheese now costs the same as your monthly rent. Why did your leader have to spike the value of cheese like this?

mnemonics.meaning: Value The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> only uses the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> with the highest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">value</mark>. They choose to fly in only the very best, most valuable helicopter. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter they use goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader. Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
mnemonics.reading: か あたい None To further increase the helicopter's value, the leader tied it to a car (か). Wow, now it has the value of a helicopter and a car combined! For a total value of… Well, imagine for yourself what value the car adds. Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!

mnemonics.meaning: Vice Side That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vice</mark> president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>, but you didn't hear that from me. I don't know how we managed to get a knife-wielding scarecrow as a vice president, there's a side of politics I don't get, I guess. I mean, just look at him up there. If something happens to our president we're stuck with that thing.
mnemonics.reading: ふく None None It's the vice president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "F**k (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer. What's going on? Normally if a vice president yells f**k you there would be... I dunno... consequences? What's happening?!

mnemonics.meaning: View There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">view</mark>. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar. View the turkey as the turkey views you. View the arrow stuck in it too.
mnemonics.reading: かん み None As you view the turkey, Genghis Khan (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!? As you view this strange scene, Genghis Khan turns and views you viewing him. He points two fingers to his eyes and then to you, and marches off into the woods. You also view the turkey running off in the other direction.

mnemonics.meaning: Wisteria The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark>s will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wisteria</mark>. The moon gladiators have a thing for wisterias.
mnemonics.reading: とう, どう ふじ None Since they're on the moon, where did they get the wisteria from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. Fuji (ふじ). Imagine them reaching down from the moon and plucking some wisteria up from Mt. Fuji then taking them back up to the moon. Now they water them.

mnemonics.meaning: Acting Perform There's going to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. So you get up on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>. You see people across the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>, in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. They watch as you put on a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. And you begin <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acting</mark>. This is your last chance to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">perform</mark>! But why? Because this acting will distract everyone from the impending tsunami. You dance around in your fins, pretending to swim. It's a wonderful performance.
mnemonics.reading: えん None None As the acting ends (えん), so do you all. The performance and the tsunami end together. How poetic.

mnemonics.meaning: Call A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that wants <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">call</mark> for it. If you don’t have a mouth, you can’t call for peace. So use your mouth and call for peace when you can. Peace is great. Call for peace. Say it aloud. I’m using my mouth to call for peace!
mnemonics.reading: こ よ None But before you call for peace, you must first placate the masses. To do so, you astound them with your yo-yo (よ) skills. Once they are so entranced by how talented you are with a yo-yo, you easily convince them to make peace. Imagine yourself whirling this yo-yo about while you call for peace. Imagine yourself doing a variety of tricks with it as you slowly convince the people to agree to peace.

mnemonics.meaning: Cape From the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> you see something that looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> jutting out into the ocean: it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cape</mark>! You know, the geological formation where a big piece of land sticks out into the ocean? That kind of cape. Cape Cod, for example. Picture it now (or look it up if you need to). Really does look like a big lip ring stuck in the side of Massachusetts, doesn't it? Imagine seeing that cape from the top of your mountain, wind blustering around you.
mnemonics.reading: き さき None Looking down at the cape, you realize capes always make the coastline look jagged, like a saw or key (さき). Thanks for keeping the coastline interesting, you saw-key capes! Try to draw that bit of coastline where the cape is. Nice, easy, smooth lines, until BAM! — the cape. Now the coastline is all jagged like the edge of a saw or key.

mnemonics.meaning: Carry Out Moving in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry out</mark> a murder once it reaches it. This alligator wants to kill someone. The alligator wants to carry out their execution. See the alligator swim really slowly in the direction of a gun. See the alligator as it prepares to carry out the murder. It’s scary.
mnemonics.reading: し, せ ほどこ None In order to carry out this murder, the alligator has to sneak up on its prey, so it can shoot it. You look across the water and see a sheep (し) grazing by the shore. The alligator is going to carry out a murder on that sheep! Watch as the alligator slinks under the water, holding the gun above the water. When it gets close enough, it carries out the murder on the sheep. Shooting it right in the chest. Now it can eat the sheep without worrying about needing to chomp on it.

mnemonics.meaning: Castle <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">castle</mark> at any time. You just have to have the right conditions. The right time, the right people, and any patch of dirt can grow into a huge castle. Every great building, especially castles, started off as just a plot of dirt, you know? It's kind of inspiring what we can become.
mnemonics.reading: じょう しろ None Once you turn dirt into a castle, that's all she wrote (しろ). That's it. It's done. The story is over. Once a castle is there, there's really no turning back. So just remember that when dirt becomes a castle, that's all she wrote.

mnemonics.meaning: Defend They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> held by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> are good to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defend</mark> yourself with. Even better than a guard dog they say. People are so confused by the turkey sitting on a stool holding flowers that they just lose their will to fight. This turkey is great to defend yourself and your home. Picture this turkey holding its flowers while sitting on its stool. Hear it gobbling as it defends everything around it with its mere presence.
mnemonics.reading: ご None None The only thing this flower-bearing turkey can't defend against is Godzilla (ご). Godzilla is pretty much undefeatable, especially for a turkey. The turkey is totally unable to defend anything from the mighty Godzilla. Imagine Godzilla approaching the flower turkey. Hear Godzilla roar as the turkey gobbles in fear before being crushed beneath the massive and scaly foot of Godzilla.

mnemonics.meaning: Demon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">demon</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wicked!
mnemonics.reading: き おに None How do you keep a demon locked up? Use a key (き). Use a lock and key and keep that demon locked up safely behind bars so he can’t get out and do bad demon stuff. Picture yourself locking up a demon with a special demon containing key. Hear the key click into the lock as the demon screams to be set free.
