mnemonics.meaning: Divide Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>s cells to create life. The entire house glows with blobs of life, and the mouth holds the knife in its mouth and cuts the life blobs apart to help them grow.
mnemonics.reading: かつ わり, わ, さ None As it divides life, the mouth begins to look really familiar. It has big teeth and a crooked mustache... it's Wario (わり)! Sometimes Wario cuts himself by accident and just becomes わ (which is all he says too). Picture Wario's mouth dividing himself now, and creating more, smaller Warios. They all yell WA! and divide up even more until the whole room is full of わりs and わs!

mnemonics.meaning: Employment Reaching your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> who can’t find <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">employment</mark>. You hear him before you see him because he’s behind some trash cans. Being a drunkard, he’s like, super wasted and just kind of rambling to himself, making strange sounds. No wonder he can’t find employment. Hear the strange sounds this drunkard is making. Let his ramblings enter your ears and imagine what he could be trying to say.
mnemonics.reading: しょく None None Since this guy is such a pathetic drunkard, it comes as no shock (しょく) that he can’t find employment. If he did find employment, I would be filled with both shock and awe. Actually you find out that he does have employment. He’s a garbage man. Feel the shock of making this shocking discovery. How can this drunkard possibly hold down his job like this?

mnemonics.meaning: Excel If you can eat <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s while running up <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark>, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excel</mark> at everything. This special workout routine is so hard that, if you can do it, you'll be able to excel at every other thing you try.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう ひい None In order to excel at this, though, you need a good pair of shoes (しゅう). You have to eat the grains AND run up the stairs, or you aren't actually excelling. Good shoes will help you get there faster and protect your toes.

mnemonics.meaning: Extravagant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> shifts <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, and instead of the usual stuff it starts to grow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extravagant</mark>. These shellfish are so extravagant because they can only be grown in the dirt in winter (after the dirt has shifted "direction" and started sustaining shellfish instead of plants, that is). Imagine tasting this incredible extravagance. Shellfish normally have a briny flavor, but these ones have earthy notes. Earthy shellfish?! I've never heard of something so extravagant. Try to imagine that extravagant, expensive flavor on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: ぜい いぼ None To make this experience even more extravagant, you eat them with a zeiber (ぜい), a German saber. A fork is just too plain for these extravagant shellfish — you gotta use a zeiber for maximum extravagance. Imagine trying to use a zeiber to skewer an extravagant shellfish, then raise it to your mouth. You probably cut your lips a little bit, to be honest. It's all very impractical, but that's what it means to be extravagant.

mnemonics.meaning: Haiku A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wishing to stop <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>s will write a moving <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">haiku</mark>. The leader pleads with the criminals to stop their crimes, to look within, and to realize there's more to life (like poetry!). Unfortunately, the leader of the criminals also writes haiku, and they want all the criminals to keep doing crimes. Look inside and see how much you want what others have, write a haiku, and then steal!
mnemonics.reading: はい None None A haiku is still a haiku (はい). Whether it's written by a law abiding leader or a criminal leader. Just remember: a haiku is always a haiku.

mnemonics.meaning: Halt The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">restaurant</mark> says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Halt</mark>!" to everyone who wants to come in. The leader looks them up and down. Stares into their eyes. And then, maybe, they may go into the restaurant to eat. Imagine being told to halt in front of your favorite restaurant, then being turned away. Noooo! Better start sucking up to the restaurant leader.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None People only halt because they want this restaurant's world famous tater (てい) tots. Which is probably why there is a leader out front making sure only people who can really appreciate the tater tots can get in to eat them. HALT! NO TATERS FOR YOU!

mnemonics.meaning: House Home You need to go up on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> times to make this your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">house</mark>. A house isn't a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home</mark> until you've slid down it exactly seven times, you know. Imagine sliding down your house from the roof all the way down to the ground. I hope you aren't afraid of heights, because you have to do this six more times.
mnemonics.reading: たく None None If you try to slide down your new house and you land on a tack (たく), that means the house has rejected you. It isn't your home now. You need to leave and find a new home. As you slide, you close your eyes and really hope you don't end up with a tack in your butt and no home to sleep in tonight.

mnemonics.meaning: Itchy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">itchy</mark> and it can barely sit still. Help the poor sheep! Imagine you were itchy but you couldn't scratch the spot. Now that you know how the sick sheep feels, give it a hand!
mnemonics.reading: よう かゆ None Even though the sheep is itchy, look how kah-yute (かゆ) it is! It’s not just cute. It’s kah-yute! Say it out loud! Kah-yuuute!

mnemonics.meaning: Judge You place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> to show him you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark> him. In fact, you yell, "I JUDGE YOU FOR BEING DRUNK AND WEARING THESE CLOTHES, TAKE THIS!" He yells back, "YOU CAN'T JUDGE ME, I CAN DO WHAT I WANT. GET THAT JUDGEY CROSS OFF ME!"
mnemonics.reading: さい さば, た None As you judge each other, your cyborg (さい) comes stomping over and slams the drunkard against the wall. With your trusty cyborg coming to your rescue, you can continue to judge this guy all you want. The cyborg joins in, "A judge would convict you if the fashion police brought you in. I have a bunch of meat and robot parts and even I'm better looking than you."

mnemonics.meaning: Law <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Loiter</mark>ing around with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark>? Sorry, but you're breaking the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">law</mark>. If you have a brush, that's okay. If you're loitering, that's okay. If you combine the two? Well... watch your back. Imagine a police officer coming for you. He's yelling at you because you have a brush and you're loitering. He grabs you, throws you to the ground, telling you what you're doing wrong.
mnemonics.reading: りつ None None Where were you loitering with your brush, breaking the law? Right outside the Ritz (りつ) Hotel. You'd think that it would be okay since you were staying there, but the law is the law. Imagine the hotel staff watching as you get thrown to the ground. You yell "won't the Ritz do anything to help me??" They won't.

mnemonics.meaning: Lead Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">road</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>. Hmm. It seems a bit too long. As you measure it, you continue down this road, wondering where it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lead</mark> you. Roads are really long, so I imagine it would take a long time to measure it (if you want to go from end to end). Imagine yourself pulling a tape measure along with you, all the while thinking, "Where will this lead me?”
mnemonics.reading: どう みちび None Where does the road that you're measuring lead to? To a doughnut (どう) shop! What a perfect way to end this road measuring. You're hungry. Nom nom nom. Imagine eating your fill, and taste the doughnuts in your mouth. You just walked a long way!

mnemonics.meaning: Leather The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leather</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Cool!
mnemonics.reading: かく かわ None One way to get leather is to skin a male chicken, a cock (かく). Not a very efficient way to get leather, but one way nonetheless. You won’t get much leather from a cock, but you could skin one in a pinch, should you really need a little extra leather.

mnemonics.meaning: Milk Giving <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> carrying an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark> is the best way to gather <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">milk</mark>. You don't have any containers, so the child has to hold milk in the upside-down umbrella. The cleats are so the child can run back and forth to transport the milk around. See this child running in his cleats. Picture him holding the umbrella upside-down, milk sloshing all about as he runs.
mnemonics.reading: にゅう ちち None But where is this child exactly? He’s in New (にゅう) York City. What’s he doing in New York City you ask? Well, he's milking a cow. Why is there a cow to be milked in New York City? Good question. It’s the end of the world and New York City is the last remaining civilization. This is how people live now. Milk is important. Imagine post-apocalyptic New York City. Milk is a hot commodity here so it’s important not to spill any of the milk. Imagine yourself carrying the milk in the umbrella and being careful not to spill any of it.

mnemonics.meaning: Obtain Wrap <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obtain</mark> it. Don't worry about paying for it, sneak into the stool store and tie some vines around the legs. Then when you leave, pull the vines and the stool will come out after. That's how you obtain a stool! You can obtain a lot of goods this way without needing any cash. Just don't tell anyone I told you.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう おさ None Today you want to obtain a new pair of shoes (しゅう). You tie your vines around the stool they're on, and slowly inch them toward the door. You have to pull very slowly, or the shoes will fall off the stool. But you really, really want to obtain these particular shoes (they're really sweet), so you keep scooting them toward you.

mnemonics.meaning: Present Time Appear The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present time</mark> for what it really is. The future isn't important. The past isn't important. The present is when everything <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appear</mark>s. People are constantly asking the king to do things for them and solve their problems. But the king can see exactly what needs to be done at the present time, and what can wait until tomorrow.
mnemonics.reading: げん あらわ None At the present time the king is Genji (げん). The time has finally come for him to get serious, and as they say, there's no time like the present. Picture pretty Genji, carefully instructing his followers what to do at the present time and what can wait.

mnemonics.meaning: Provide Equip The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>. That is their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark>. It is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">provide</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equip</mark> the cliff with flowers. Imagine a leader carrying flowers up to the top of a cliff. They are saying "I must provide more flowers to the cliff" as they climb up.
mnemonics.reading: び そな None Why do they provide and equip the cliff with flowers? It's all for the bees (び). "The bees must be equipped with more flowers. I will provide these flowers for the bees!"

mnemonics.meaning: Purple You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> from moving by tying it with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purple</mark>. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have. Imagine tying this spoon down with thread that's a color other than purple. Ah, the thread snaps. Darn, you better use your extra strong purple thread (the best color for strength!).
mnemonics.reading: し むらさき None To remember this reading, think about how the village you previously went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Imagine that everything is in purple in this village. Cars, houses, trees. Absolutely everything was purple.

mnemonics.meaning: Rule A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> makes all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark>s. It isn't supposed to be making rules, but it has a knife, so who's going to argue? Picture a shellfish wielding a knife and shouting out new rules to all of the nervous people standing around it.
mnemonics.reading: そく のっと None The first rule the shellfish enacts is that all humans take off their socks (そく) and give them to him. Hmm... is this some kind of nasty shellfish? Who would want socks? Once everyone follows the rule, and the shellfish is on top of a pile of socks, he cackles, "It's easier to stab your toes with my knife now! Let's get to more rules!"

mnemonics.meaning: Shelf Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and make two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>-shaped <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shelf</mark> units with it. Moon radical-shaped, that is. Those moon radicals standing side by side kinda look like a shelf, don't you think? The tree on the left is just there to remind you it's made of wood, I guess. A lovely wooden shelf. Imagine having some tall, moon radical-shaped shelves in your house. Where would you put them? Picture them there now. Honestly, they'd actually look pretty sophisticated.
mnemonics.reading: ほう たな None To match the moon radical shape, this would have to be a pretty tall shelf, meaning you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it. Think about the ton-a-stuff you're going to put on this tall shelf. Like, literally measure out a ton of things and put them on there. It can hold it, I'm sure…

mnemonics.meaning: Stab Thrust, Sudden How do you make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> nice and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>? You gotta <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stab</mark> something in it. Just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thrust</mark> it right in there. And make sure your movements are really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>. Stabs and thrusts are more effective when they're sudden. Yeah, take that, you hole! Stab, thrust, stab! Wow, this hole keeps getting bigger thanks to all your stabbin'.
mnemonics.reading: とつ つ None Give that hole one last big stab, now you've totes (とつ) showed that hole who's boss. What did I tell you about the sudden thrust technique? It's totes super effective. Like, totes. Remember "totes," that slang word for "totally"? It fell out of use almost as sudden as it appeared. Now it totes gives me a little stab of nostalgia whenever I hear it.

mnemonics.meaning: Standard Riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> carrying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, but that’s pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">standard</mark> here. This is your dreamland. You always dream about tsunamis and the turkeys carrying crosses that ride them. This might be strange for other people, but for you it’s pretty normal. See this tsunami riding turkey in your mind. Hear it gobble loudly as it waves its cross around. Remember, this is standard fare for you. Nothing unusual here.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None These wacky dreams are only standard fare in June (じゅん) though. You don’t have them any other time of the year, just in June. You don’t know why June is the only time you have dreams about tsunami riding turkeys, but that’s just the way it is. It’s usually pretty toasty in the month of June (in the Northern Hemisphere, at least) so imagine going to bed in this heat. Feel the spray of the refreshing tsunami water in your dream as the turkey continues to ride those tsunami waves with his cross.

mnemonics.meaning: Stretch You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and you want to make it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark>. To do that, you'd naturally just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stretch</mark> it. Imagine holding this bow in your hands, and then stretching it into a longer bow. Feel the strain on your arms as you try to stretch wood. You can feel it stretching, but it's strenuous.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう は None As you stretch the bow, you hear someone running at you. "That's my bow you're stretching!" yells Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She is not happy that you're stretching her things. You should probably try to un-stretch it, put it down, and run before she beats you. Now Mrs. Chou is hitting you with the stretched out bow. You cry and apologize, but she won't listen. "I'm going to stretch you, like you stretched my bow," she says. Then she does it.

mnemonics.meaning: Superior Gentle The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">superior</mark> at being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark>. These hundred foreheads are sensitive, especially in the heart of winter, so the leader must be very gentle. Not just any kind of gentle though—the superior kind of gentle that will keep a hundred foreheads following. As a leader, you are superior. You’re so gentle to these foreheads. See yourself caring for them in the winter. Feel the chill in the air as you wrap the foreheads in blankets and prepare heating pads for them.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう やさ, すぐ None You need to be superior because all of these foreheads belong to youths (ゆう). They don't know how to take care of themselves, though they try to convince you they can. They're too young to know any better. Picture the youths trying to show you that they are the superior ones, then they sneeze, their eyes fill with tears, and you have to gently tuck them back into bed. Silly youths.

mnemonics.meaning: Swamp A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> crashes into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swamp</mark>. Now the swamp is filled with shrimp. They used to live in the ocean, but the tsunami has carried them to their new home in the swamp. Imagine yourself in the swamp when the tsunami hits. Feel the water crash into you along with the shrimp. You’re all wet and shrimpy now.
mnemonics.reading: たく さわ None Your house was right next to the swamp and on this side of your house you had many a tack (たく) there to hang things on. Now, on every tack there is skewered a shrimp. The force of the tsunami drove them into the tacks on the side of your house. Look at the side of your house. It’s covered with shrimp that have been impaled on the tacks. Perfect for dinner.

mnemonics.meaning: Teacher Expert, Master A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water falls from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and needs to be wiped up with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>. Only a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teacher</mark> or an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expert</mark> could get away with getting close to this wet bear to wipe up after it. The expert is also your teacher, and she's showing you how to clean up after this bear.
mnemonics.reading: し None None The teacher tells you to start with something smaller, after all, you're not an expert yet. You have to practice on a wet sheep (し). "I became a wet, dangerous animal expert by starting with sheep, you will too!" your teacher says. Your teacher assures you this wet sheep is far less dangerous to clean up after than a wet bear. They're the expert, so you should listen and wipe up after that sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: Tree Trunk Ability In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, if you want your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, you need to hang it on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tree trunk</mark>. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry. Picture everything early in the morning covered in damp dew. Even your hat is uncomfortably wet. Now walk up to a large tree trunk and touch it—it's dry!
mnemonics.reading: かん みき None You lean against the tree trunk, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis Khan (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them. Now that you think about it, Genghis Khan was the one who taught people that tree trunks stay dry in the morning!

mnemonics.meaning: Watch Over Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">watch over</mark> others. You know that way cartoon characters and pirates watch out below them, with their hand shading their eye? That! Now imagine doing that right now.
mnemonics.reading: かん み None As you watch over your friends and neighbors you see movement in the distance. Oh no, it's Genghis Khan (かん) and his army! Welp, nothing much watching over them will do now. Genghis Khan is probably going to take over your town, so I guess you can watch if you want but... I wouldn't.

mnemonics.meaning: Agency Government Office There are people under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> forming their own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agency</mark>. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government office</mark>! Imagine them putting together papers, talking to politicians, and standing in the street outside the capitol. They demand for this agency to be formed. They are doing all the correct, legal things to do it too.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう None None This new agency is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech. "THIS IS MY STREET. NO NEW AGENCIES ON MY STREET!" Mrs. Chou (ちょう) cries as she barrels into everyone. "Whenever you're in a 丁, you're in my territory," she yells, taking out a few agency members with her fists. "You won't be starting any kind of agency here, not on my watch." And she lights it all on fire.

mnemonics.meaning: Amount Framed Picture When you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guest</mark> somewhere it's important to bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s. But more than that, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> of geoducks you bring is really what matters. If you don't have any live geoducks go ahead and bring any amount of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">framed picture</mark>s of geoducks instead. If you're a guest you either have to have the right amount of geoducks or geoducks in framed pictures. Otherwise you're a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: がく ひたい None Unfortunately, if you mess up the amount or the framed pictures, every other guest will gawk (がく) at you. Feel the feel of hundreds of gawks. Feel ashamed as they gawk at you. How could you!?

mnemonics.meaning: Arm The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> shines on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark> suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arm</mark>, sticking out from under the roof. Arms really look like snakes in the moonlight. Picture it. Your arm is long and shiny, just like a snake.
mnemonics.reading: わん うで None Your arm is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're nude, eh (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh? Your arms are nude, eh? That's why they look like snakes, you know. You should be more careful.

mnemonics.meaning: Boundary The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> where you just <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boundary</mark>. You don't want to cross the boundary, you just stand there and see over it. As a general rule, you can stand in the dirt and see beyond boundaries, but you don't usually cross them. Imagine a big line in the dirt where you stand and see over into the other side: that's a boundary. The boundary between your home and your neighbor's, the boundary between cities or countries… Some you can cross, and some you can't.
mnemonics.reading: きょう さかい None The boundary you're looking at now is the Kyoto (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is one of the most famous places in Japan, so you can imagine its boundary is really clear and marked by all kinds of boundary signs that say KYOTO. Picture yourself outside of Kyoto. Picture the boundary between you and Kyoto. Now hop over it!

mnemonics.meaning: Burn Blaze <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nature</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burn</mark> down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters to contain the flames, so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blaze</mark> will burn until nothing's left. Feel the fire all around you as it burns. You're out in nature — the middle of a forest fire. Hear the woods crackle as they burn up around you.
mnemonics.reading: ねん も None What is the worst thing that could burn in this fire? Your nendoroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire. Cry your eyes out as you smell the burning plastic of your nendoroids. Worst. Day. Ever.

mnemonics.meaning: Carry Bear You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry</mark> many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn. Think about your morning routine. You carry yourself into the bathroom and carry a toothbrush into your mouth. You carry your coat and bag out the door.
mnemonics.reading: たん にな, かつ None Once you're carrying everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting tan (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things. Picture yourself carrying a coat and a bag, walking through the rice fields to work, with the hot, dawn sun shining down, making your fingers get tanner and tanner.

mnemonics.meaning: Celebrate If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> blesses your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> it's time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">celebrate</mark>! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him! Imagine what celebrating would be like. Imagine an older brother too, if you don't actually have one.
mnemonics.reading: しゅく, しゅう いわ None Unfortunately, the two of you celebrated too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and shook (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off. Never celebrate too hard. Otherwise you'll always have to think about the time a celebration spirit shook your brother till his head fell off.

mnemonics.meaning: Deliver The American <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliver</mark> this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need? You need to deliver this flag to the president. Imagine yourself running as fast as you can while carrying the parcel in order to get it to him. Your lungs are tired and your legs burn, but you must deliver the flag as soon as possible!
mnemonics.reading: None とど None To deliver this flag is something you just have to do (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do. The world depends on you to do this delivery. If you fail, the United States will be ruined. You have to do it! Deliver that flag now! Run! Run!

mnemonics.meaning: Different You take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> and everything is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">different</mark>! Imagine scooting down a street in Korea and seeing how different literally every single thing is compared to what you're used to in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: い ちが None What's also different is that there's a weird tiger bouncing on its tail alongside you yelling that its name is Tigger (ちが). You didn't know Tigger was living in Korea these days. That's definitely different. Tigger is different in Korea too. For one, he's a white tiger now, and he's, like, really aggressive. Wait, was he always like that?

mnemonics.meaning: Distinction When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> tries its hoof at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark>, it gains <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distinction</mark>. Now that is something that really sets a sheep apart! After all, have you ever seen a sheep working in construction? Note that the sheep has to sweep its tail to one side so that it doesn't get in the way of all the construction tools. That's why it looks a little different here. Imagine a sheep in a hard hat, with its tail on one side, getting down to some construction. How very distinctive.
mnemonics.reading: さ さ None The extra distinction of this sheep is that its really skilled with a saw (さ). That's why it's so good at construction. Imagine the sheep holding the saw in its hooves. It isn't easy to grip a saw with hooves, but this is no ordinary sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: Expand There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> table that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expand</mark> the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size. Imagine yourself kicking this flag to see the blackjack table expand. Feel your foot kicking the flag. You’ve kicked it so many times that your leg is sore, but you need to expand the table some more so you keep kicking it. Imagine the blackjack table making that sound Mario makes whenever he gets a mushroom and expands in size.
mnemonics.reading: てん のぶ, のび None The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will expand, and that limit is ten (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times. Imagine yourself kicking the flag ten times. Count it off in your head and imagine each instance up to ten. Any more kicks after ten don’t cause the table to do anything, but it does cause your leg to get sore.

mnemonics.meaning: Judge You're about to enter a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> that has your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark> on it so you can face the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark>. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now. Picture the judge sitting under the roof. Your number is sitting on his big desk, next to the gavel.
mnemonics.reading: しん None None The judge is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the shins (しん). Ouch! You try to ask the judge what his ruling is, but he just hits you on the shins again!

mnemonics.meaning: Layer Behind the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> lies a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark>—yet another <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">layer</mark> of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe. These layers are meant to protect you. We all have layers we hide behind sometimes, you know? You can't be totally transparent with everyone.
mnemonics.reading: そう None None Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your layers! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your soul (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see. Everyone in the crowd is completely silent, staring at your soul, with all of its layers peeled off.

mnemonics.meaning: Look At If you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> something, it means you really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look at</mark> it. You're not just seeing something passively with your eyes, you're actually looking at it with your whole spirit. Imagine using your whole spirit to look at something. Like, you feel your spirit flowing out from your eyes and enveloping whatever you're looking at. It's kind of trippy. When's the last time you really looked at something like that? Try it now.
mnemonics.reading: し み None The first thing you want to look at like this is a sheep (し). You've seen a lot of sheep, but you've never really looked at them closely, so your image of them is kind of… woolly. Look at a picture of a sheep now. Really look at it with all your spirit. Bet you start noticing some things you'd never seen before, right?

mnemonics.meaning: Loop The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> is showing his people how to put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> around a weird <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> by walking around it in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loop</mark>. It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt. Watch as the king loops the net around and around and around the zombie, keeping it completely pinned down.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None The king also explains that this loop technique was used by Genghis Khan (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them. Picture Genghis Khan looping around and around just like the king is looping around and around this zombie.

mnemonics.meaning: Manufacture In an attempt to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">control</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manufacture</mark> a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it. Imagine being able to control your clothes with your mind. What would you have them do? Imagine what you would do with your clothes if you could manufacture something to control them and move them around at will with your mind.
mnemonics.reading: せい None None You manufacture these clothes to control your saber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands! Now you're trying to manufacture a machine that will make sabers and clothes you can use to control them. Soon you'll have a manufactured army of saber-controlling clothes!

mnemonics.meaning: Mention On this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, there's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of sweat coming off of it, because it forgot to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mention</mark> something to you! It seems like it's something important too, since they're sweating so much. The angel just visited you, but it forgot to mention something important (probably life-threatening, it's an angel after all), and now you see it scooting at top speeds toward you.
mnemonics.reading: じゅつ の None "I forgot to mention, you have to study ninjutsu (じゅつ)!" the angel yells. But it's too late, there are ninjas jumping out of the bushes around you and taking you hostage. The angel really should have mentioned ninjutsu earlier. Then maybe you would have gone straight to a dojo to learn instead of falling into a ninjutsu trap yourself. The angel definitely failed its mission.

mnemonics.meaning: Military On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> where everyone keeps <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>ping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">military</mark>. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again. The military really seems to have a thing for stopping a lot during their ceremonies.
mnemonics.reading: ぶ, む たけ None You look closer at the people in the military and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of booze (ぶ)! This is a ceremony for celebrating the military so I guess they can drink as much booze as they want, but this seems very strange to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Model Type There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">model</mark>. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real. Why would anyone make a model that looks like a lantern and a knife sticking into the ground?
mnemonics.reading: けい かた None You touch the model and see that it's made of cake (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it. Haven't you seen any of those crazy cakes modeled after things like movies, towns, giants hams, and purses? They're all the rage. Next time you make a cake try to make it look like a model lantern and knife with fake cake dirt and everything.

mnemonics.meaning: Narrow You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> that are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">narrow</mark>. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why. Imagine yourself married to this animal husband with horns that are narrow. It’s a strange marriage. Listen to the goat making its goat noises as it clomps around your home. Now hug your goat husband and feel its soft fluffy coat against your skin.
mnemonics.reading: きょう せま, せば None I’m not even going to get into the semantics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and narrow. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover. But that doesn’t mean you can’t imagine the semantics. The finer points of the relationship. Go ahead, imagine all the weird stuff that comes with the territory for having a goat as a husband. Use all that weird stuff to remember this kanji and its reading. Want an example? Just imagine the goat doing dishes! Goats don’t have hands! Hahahahaha!!

mnemonics.meaning: Offer Accompany When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wants to work <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark>, it means they want what you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offer</mark>. Congrats! Now you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> them everywhere and offer them hot towels and bottled water, or whatever it is you do… Picture handing things to your leader as you accompany them somewhere. You're happy to do this, but you know you have so much more to offer than a hot towel and a pretty face. When will they see what you really have to offer?!
mnemonics.reading: きょう とも, そな None Once a year, the leader will offer you a vacation in きょうと. It's an all-expenses-paid trip! The catch is that you have to accompany your leader to きょうと… Picture you and the leader enjoying some matcha together under the cherry blossoms in きょうと. Yeah, this was definitely worth it. So glad you took them up on their offer and accompanied them.

mnemonics.meaning: Pipe On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pipe</mark>. Bamboo is great for pipes, and the only place for the bear to get it is your roof. So, that's why it's there.
mnemonics.reading: かん くだ None The pipe will be for Genghis Khan (かん), who would like some pipes for his house. Watch the bear take away your bamboo. Follow it to Genghis Khan's house. There, the bear installs the pipe in Genghis Khan's bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: Place On Put On You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">place on</mark> its dashboard. Drunkards should not drive, and when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put on</mark> a cross, it prevents the car from starting! Imagine the power that starts emanating from the cross once it’s placed on the car, it can’t move even an inch. Nope, it's not going anywhere until its owner sobers up.
mnemonics.reading: さい の None You have a lot of crosses to place on drunkard cars, so you get your cyborg (さい) to do it for you. The cyborg doesn't need sleep, so it can patrol the streets 24/7 for the sake of public safety. What a saintly cyborg. Picture your cyborg, approaching a drunkard's car to place a cross on it. You see it open a big compartment on its chest, and it's filled with crosses.

mnemonics.meaning: Quality You have to use two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>s to open these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. These particular shellfish are of very high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quality</mark> meaning they won't open so easily. Imagine the highest quality shellfish you've ever seen. They're hard, smooth, and basically impenetrable.
mnemonics.reading: しつ, しち None None You finally get all of the shellfish open and you're admiring their quality, when your shih tzu (しつ) jumps up on the table and gobbles them down. NO! You try to chase after the little dog, but it's too late. They're gone. I guess your shih tzu knows good quality shellfish too. :(

mnemonics.meaning: Quantity Amount When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> reaches this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> it increases in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quantity</mark>. That's right. Every morning the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> of people or animals living here goes up by at least one. Picture dawn, the sun rising, the birds chirping, and the screams of a new born baby rise in the village. Or Maybe it's a new sheep! Or a new hat that someone just finished making.
mnemonics.reading: りょう はか None Today's dawn has brought with it an increase in the quantity of row(りょう) boats! Aww, aren't they cute? Look at all of the new row boats lined up together. They all have their own sets of oars too. When every dawn brings a new amount of people, those new people are going to need that same amount of row boats.

mnemonics.meaning: Sell A sudden aversion to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> makes you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-shellfish, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sell</mark> off every shellfish in sight. If you're serious about being anti-shellfish then you should sell all the ones you have.
mnemonics.reading: はん None None You're going to sell all of our shellfish to Han (はん) Solo. He isn't anti-shellfish like you, and he knows how to turn a profit too! Picture yourself selling all of your shellfish to Han Solo. You stand there with your arms crossed, and Han just shakes his head at you and continues to toss them onto his spaceship.

mnemonics.meaning: Shoulder The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> leading to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> can be broken down with one’s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoulder</mark>. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open. Picture yourself smashing through this door using your shoulder and seeing the moon on the other side. Hear the splintering of wood as your shoulder crashes through the door and feel the impact with your body.
mnemonics.reading: けん かた None "Wow, your shoulder is just like my catapult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door! Now the weird man is inspecting your shoulder really closely and he keeps muttering "catapult powers" under his breath. It's very unsettling, but he's kind of right. A shoulder works just like the mechanism that winds up a catapult.

mnemonics.meaning: Standard A man who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> material can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">standard</mark> woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but. This husband sets a new standard for what it means to be a husband. He’s pretty great. Imagine yourself shaking this husband’s hand because he’s so awesome.
mnemonics.reading: き None None It’s pretty standard for a husband and wife to exchange vows when getting married, and the husband said this girl held the key (き) to his heart. She unlocked the husband’s heart with the key and now he’s a man made whole. Picture this woman actually sticking a physical key into the husband’s chest and turning it. Now this is anything but standard, but it’ll help you remember this kanji and its reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Stock Share What might cause a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> would be if its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stock</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">share</mark>s took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares. Visualize this tree sliding out of the jet and falling to his doom. As he falls, visualize red lines falling alongside him to represent the stocks and shares. Hear the shrill whistle of them speeding through the air to the ground.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ かぶ None Once the tree hits the ground with his stocks and his shares, the impact creates a large KABOOM (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~! Listen to each of these things impact the ground and see each individual mushroom cloud appear around them. KABOOM! KABOOM! KABOOM!

mnemonics.meaning: Touch If, at a certain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark>, you approach an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, you’ll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">touch</mark> it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea. Imagine yourself approaching this insect from a sneaky and stealthy angle. Now touch it. What does it feel like? Smooth? Hard? Fuzzy? Feel the insect in your mind as you touch it.
mnemonics.reading: しょく さわ, ふ None Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you touch it you get a shock (しょく). Did you know that lightning bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and if you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock. Feel this electrical shock to your system as you touch the lightning bug. This discourages you from ever touching another insect again. You don’t enjoy the shock.

mnemonics.meaning: Transport What does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> have in common? They're both used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transport</mark> people and things. Imagine stuffing a bunch of Stormtroopers in your car so you can transport them across the country. Well the Death Star can transport even more Stormtroopers, faster, and through space!
mnemonics.reading: ゆ None None Right now you and the Death Star are transporting yurts (ゆ). They're the universe's #1 best transportable homes! It's easy to transport a yurt even without a car or the Death Star.

mnemonics.meaning: Waist Lower Back You approach the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Moon</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> there on the surface, touching her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">waist</mark>. She's posing with one hand on her waist, like she's Sailor Moon or something. I guess that would explain what she's doing here on the Moon! Imagine flying your helicopter closer to the woman. Even as you touch down she never takes her hand off her waist. You get closer and try to see why she's touching her waist like that.
mnemonics.reading: よう こし None Once you get close, you see that her waist looks weird and… puffy? You realize she's stuffed some 子 sheep (こし) under her skirt's waistband to line her waist with them. Guess it's cold up here on the moon, so the 子 sheep keep her waist warm. And they had to be 子 sheep, otherwise they wouldn't be small enough to fit under her clothes. Imagine how warm your waist would be if you stuffed a bunch of 子 sheep into your waistband. Just don't let anyone see you do it. Pretty sure that's animal cruelty…

mnemonics.meaning: Accustomed If you could just get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> to open the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, you'll grow <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accustomed</mark> to them sooner or later! I know shellfish are a bit of an acquired taste, but if you don't open that window, you'll never like them! Close your eyes and picture your soul. Now your soul is opening a little window inside of you that is the perfect size for shellfish of all kinds. Hopefully with exposure and acceptance you'll grow accustomed to them.
mnemonics.reading: かん な None You'll need to become accustomed to eating shellfish if you want to grow up big and strong like Genghis Khan (かん). He didn't have shellfish growing up either you know, he had to grow accustomed to their taste too, but look how successful he was! Force yourself to get accustomed to shellfish like Genghis Khan, then maybe you'll rule most of the planet someday.

mnemonics.meaning: Alive The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> but that doesn't mean it's not still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alive</mark>. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things. Imagine the old flag with a face and mouth and eyes and nose... it talks and listens and everything else. It's a flag that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alive</mark> D:
mnemonics.reading: きょ い None The flag that is old and alive is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in Little Kyoto (きょ). Not as cool as a real relic, it's put in this dumb Little Kyoto shrine that's basically just a tourist attraction. Eh, whatever.

mnemonics.meaning: Apprehend When you ride your scooter, you always carry an ink brush and some water. The water is to stay hydrated, obviously, and the brush is to write tickets for the criminals you apprehend. Why apprehend? I guess you're some kind of thirsty, scooter-riding cop who writes tickets in calligraphy. By the way, the shape of this brush (肀) is a little different from usual, but it's still a brush! Imagine chasing a criminal for ages on your scooter, stopping only for the occasional water break, and finally apprehending them when they hit a dead end. How good would it feel to write a ticket with your fancy brush?
mnemonics.reading: たい None None When you do catch up and apprehend someone, you always tie them down with the tie (たい) from your neck. It's a really sturdy tie you use to apprehend them, so even if they struggle there's no chance they get away.

mnemonics.meaning: Ballot You have to fly in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to punch your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ballot</mark>. The helicopter gets you far away from prying eyes, and the jackhammer makes you really try for whoever you're voting for on that thing. It's foolproof! Imagine trying to fill out your ballot while flying in a helicopter and using only a jackhammer to do it. Do you think you could do it? Do you think you could do it AND vote for the right person?
mnemonics.reading: ひょう None None While using the jackhammer on the ballot, the helicopter pilot keeps yelling “Heyo (ひょう), don't mess up! Heyo! Watch out, don't let me see!” as he flies the helicopter all over the place. You're starting to think this method of filling out ballots is rigged.

mnemonics.meaning: Belong The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mantis</mark> perched just underneath it, and you know for a fact that it does not <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belong</mark> there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not up high on a flag pole. Insects belong in the wild! Look at that mantis, pretending it belongs here. What are you gonna do about it?
mnemonics.reading: ぞく None None Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't belong on your flag, you're a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DON'T BELONG HERE!" Your Bosozoku life has prepared you for this moment. Those who don't belong shall be punished, you think to yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Catch Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to grab this guy's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">catch</mark> him! Not physically though, you do grab his foot, but you close your eyes, and catch the idea of him in your mind just by touching your fingers to his foot. You don't really like the idea of touching your fingers to someone's foot, so you do it ever so slightly, and only catch the gist of what it's like.
mnemonics.reading: そく とら None As you touch his foot, you catch a glimpse of the Torah (とら) in your mind. Suddenly, you are able to grasp and understand every single thing written in the Torah. You fall to the ground. You wipe your eyes and look up, seeing that the person running from you is wearing socks with little pictures of the Torah on them. You were able to catch that in your brain but not the person. You must have touched those Torah socks and not his foot. You've been tricked!

mnemonics.meaning: Catch Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">catch</mark> anything thrown at you. Catch the bouquet, for example, or catch the rice everyone throws at you. Weddings are really more about catching things with your fingers than they are about whoever is standing across from you. Imagine being at a wedding and getting to catch a ton of things with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: ほ つか, とら None You're having a good time catching things until it's cleanup time and someone throws a hoe (ほ) at you. First of all, ouch, that was your face. Second, this is your wedding. You aren't supposed to have to hoe it all up. You're supposed to drop everything you caught and leave! Picture yourself grumpily hoeing all the things you couldn't catch, right into a big dumpster.

mnemonics.meaning: Climate Weather, Candidate A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark>, and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> is able to change the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">climate</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weather</mark>. Not just the type of climate that causes sunny and rainy days though, the political climate too, because they're a political <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">candidate</mark> too. Imagine this leader twirling his stick around with his hook so quickly it changes the actual weather. Then he shoots it into the sky with an arrow, changing the actual climate itself.
mnemonics.reading: こう そうろう None Who is this climate and weather-changing candidate leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than こういち. Ask こういち why he's changing the climate. He says more people do their WaniKani reviews when it's raining, so he decided to create climate change to make it more dangerous to go outside. "This way, people will stay indoors and do their WaniKani reviews," he tells you.

mnemonics.meaning: Comrade The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> that stole your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> was your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comrade</mark>! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong. Just because someone is your comrade doesn't mean they actually like you. Don't let your guard down and let them near your car.
mnemonics.reading:
はい None None You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your comrade a haiku (はい). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone. Comrade, what the heck
I want to get my car back
I thought we were friends.

mnemonics.meaning: Condition There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> is in no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condition</mark> to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition. Imagine your poor brother and the condition he is in. His glass bones and paper skin make it impossible for him to move very fast. Imagine the sad face he makes when he realizes his fate.
mnemonics.reading: きょう None None His condition gets worse and you have to travel all the way to his home in きょうと to get him out. This is also, incidentally, where the tsunami's condition is the worst, so you better get to きょうと quick!

mnemonics.meaning: Cool A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> causes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark> to become very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cool</mark>. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool. Imagine being in the capital. The tsunami hits and now you are all wet. You are also very cool because the water is not warm. You are cool and wet. How sad.
mnemonics.reading: りょう すず None You find out that the cool tsunami water is coming from Sue Zoo (すず). The only animal there is a penguin named Sue, so the Sue Zoo is always kept cool for her. But now that Sue's fountain broke, the cool water is everywhere! Time to sue the zoo… You're still feeling pretty cool and wet when another wave courses by. You see Sue surfing on it, screaming at the top of her lungs, "FREEDOM!!! NOW EVERYWHERE IS SUE ZOO!!!"

mnemonics.meaning: Echo Reverberation, Resound If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">echo</mark> all the way through the building, and each and every person in there will know what you did. Hear the poop echo. You know what a poop usually sounds like, now imagine that sound again, but louder and with an echo. How could anyone not notice?
mnemonics.reading: きょう ひび None The echo doesn't stop there, this building's roots extend throughout the entire city of きょうと. The echo reverberates and soon everyone in きょうと is listening, horrified, to your poop. Welp. きょうと knows you pooped. That will echo through your memories for the rest of your life. I hope you're happy.

mnemonics.meaning: Effective If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> different types of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you'll produce something <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">effective</mark>. It doesn't matter what power you mix, because all power is strong. No matter what you use this mixed power on, it will be effective. Imagine some situations where you mix power with power.
mnemonics.reading: こう き None The most effective mix of two powers is two こういちs. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective! こういちs punch attack was super effective against that Pikurchort.

mnemonics.meaning: Endless You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endless</mark>. Imagine your endless greenhouse, which goes on and on, as far as the eye can see. Lucky you. What will you grow in your endless greenhouse? Imagine all your favourite flowers and foods growing endlessly in your endless greenhouse.
mnemonics.reading: ばく None None Your flowers have grown so big that now the only way you can fit into your endless greenhouse is by lying on your back (ばく). Imagine yourself lying on your back in your greenhouse under a canopy of great big flowers, tending to them as they grow even bigger.

mnemonics.meaning: Extinction Die Out Sometime in the future, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> of every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">color</mark> will be faced with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extinction</mark>. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction. Imagine what the world would be like without thread. No thread of any color. How would you fix tears in clothes or make new ones? It would be a strange world where thread is extinct.
mnemonics.reading: ぜつ た None The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits. Pretend you have deadly zits. They’re everywhere, not just your face. You can’t pop them or you’ll die, but they’re all bulging and extremely painful. Now you’re facing extinction. Lousy.

mnemonics.meaning: Fresh The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fresh</mark> here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not. Imagine eating this fresh fish and fresh sheep. It’s the freshest you’ve ever tasted. Taste it on your tongue and experience how fresh it is.
mnemonics.reading: せん あざ None This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh. Can you imagine eating a fresh centaur? How weird would that be? Half of it is human-like, so you’d be like, a half cannibal. Weird, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Full If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> they'll <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">both</mark> become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">full</mark> of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full. Picture both of these little flowers, happily swaying in the breeze. Then the tsunami comes, leaves, and you look back and their little cup-heads are full to the brim with water.
mnemonics.reading: まん み None As you stare at the full flowers, you decide to write a manga (まん) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas! Soon you have full color pages, full of stories about both of these tsunami-filled flowers and their adventures together. And when you're done, your heart is full as well. Awwww.

mnemonics.meaning: Give A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> lies sprawled on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give</mark> him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something. See the beggar on the ground. He’s writhing in agony and moaning for help. Imagine how sad and pitiful he looks.
mnemonics.reading: よ あた None When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy. Now watch as the beggar plays with the yo-yo you just gave him. He’s actually pretty good with it. See the beggar doing insane tricks with his new yo-yo as passersby give him change for his impressive yo-yo performance.

mnemonics.meaning: Hang Someone covered your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and also got dirt on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>s. So you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hang</mark> them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities. If someone got dirt all up in your finger and toe business, wouldn't you want to hang them upside-down too?
mnemonics.reading: かい, けい か None You hang this person upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your car (か). No mercy. Don't get dirt on me, buddy. Or I'll hang you upside-down and hit you with my car. Then you'll be sorry.

mnemonics.meaning: Hide Behind a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>-wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is holding his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hide</mark>. You know the phrase, "You can run, but you can't hide?" Wolverine can't run anymore, so he's trying to hide (even though he knows it probably won't work).
mnemonics.reading: いん かく None Wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to hide behind and sees it's an inn (いん). Lucky Wolverine! Inns are good for hiding. The staff isn't supposed to give out his room number, and there are tons of different rooms for him to hide in.

mnemonics.meaning: Imitation A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> grows next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> enclosing an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imitation</mark> of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree. Look at this greenhouse tree struggle to grow big and strong like the wild tree outside. Hear its leaves shake and timber creak. How cute.
mnemonics.reading: も, ぼ None None The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act. Hear the little tree moaning at its pitiful imitation of a real tree. The greenhouse tree sounds very sad and you actually start to feel bad for it. Moan along with the tree in sympathy.

mnemonics.meaning: Include <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Now</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">include</mark> more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible! Imagine how your repertoire of new words will impress all your friends and family. Don’t include them on your secret that you used the Mouth Now! program, just feel super smart with all the words you now know.
mnemonics.reading: がん ふく None If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth! Since you bought the program, you also got the Gandhi books included with your order. Imagine yourself reading them and learning all about non-violent resistance. Fascinating.

mnemonics.meaning: Lawsuit Be careful what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>, otherwise you might face a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lawsuit</mark>. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands. Think of all the things you could say in public that could get you stuck dealing with a lawsuit. Oh my gosh! How dare you think those things?! You're lucky you didn't say them out loud in public, or I'd file a lawsuit against you myself!
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None Any and all lawsuits need to be brought before the Shougun (しょう). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate. You better hope what you said wasn't about the Shougun, or he's really going to use this lawsuit to destroy you.

mnemonics.meaning: Limit A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">limit</mark> the things under and around it. Picture the roots of a building: metal beams going into the ground. Now imagine trying to build something like a subway under there. It's not good! The building limits what can go under it.
mnemonics.reading: げん かぎ None The person who hates these limits more than anyone else is Genji (げん). He wants to be able to tunnel under buildings, sneak in, smooch ladies, and sneak back out. But all the building root limits make that impossible! Picture Genji tunneling under a building where a cute lady lives. He's trying to get in, but the building roots limit how far he can dig. No! Now how will he steal a secret kiss?!

mnemonics.meaning: Obese A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> who stays in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bed</mark> all day every day will soon become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obese</mark>. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time. Imagine this moon in bed, slowly getting bigger and bigger, becoming more obese every day. Hear the sound of the bed creaking and cracking as the moon grows larger and larger.
mnemonics.reading: ひ こ, こえ None Since the obese moon is in bed all day, and since the moon stays pretty cold, she needs some extra heat (ひ) to stay warm. A heated blanket should do the trick. Imagine the obese moon cozied up in bed with a heated blanket and hot cocoa.

mnemonics.meaning: Plentiful Abundant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Music</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> make farts <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plentiful</mark>. And lucky for you, you have an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abundant</mark> stock of these music beans, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots. Imagine dancing to your own plentiful bean music as you gorge on the abundant stock of beans.
mnemonics.reading: ほう ゆた とよ Your music bean farts are too plentiful to leave your home (ほう). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself. Be polite! Keep your plentiful farts at home.

mnemonics.meaning: Prosper Flourish A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> with enough <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosper</mark>. Vikings need trees to build their boats and homes, and they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flourish</mark> when they have enough. Picture a village of Vikings, flourishing and prospering because they live right on the edge of a forest they can just hack away at whenever they need a new ship.
mnemonics.reading: えい さか None Vikings knew that in order to prosper they also needed to collect acorns (えい). If you're chopping down trees all the time, you need to actively grow them back too. That's why acorns are the actual, secret key to Viking prosperity. Picture a bunch of kid Vikings planting acorns in rows and watching them flourish and grow into big trees that they can cut down to keep up their Viking ways.
