mnemonics.meaning: Pull Out Touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">friend</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull out</mark> their friendship. Pull it out with a high five. Pull it out with a back rub. Pull it out with an, "Oh no, there's some lint on your shirt, let me get that for you." REMINDER: You are not allowed to touch your friends without their permission. If they say no to you pulling out their friendship, then you don't get to pull out their friendship. End of story.
mnemonics.reading: ばつ, はつ, はい ぬ None Your friend looks you in the eye and says, I want you to pull out my hair. I want my head to be nude (ぬ). Now you have to use your fingers on your friend to pull out their hair and make their head all nude. REMINDER: If someone asks you to pull out their hair to help them achieve a nude head, you don't have to do it unless you want to! Choices and respect, people!

mnemonics.meaning: Replace Exchange A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> marries a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> while the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> goes down and the men <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">replace</mark> their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy. See these two husbands as the sun sets under them. Listen to them each saying their vows, expressing how they could never replace one another.
mnemonics.reading: たい か None After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives. See the husbands driving off into the sunset in their car. Hear the engine rumble as the car speeds off into the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: Salary Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> you if you want a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salary</mark>. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional! When you see someone wearing a fancy suit that suits them, don't you wonder about how much their salary is?
mnemonics.reading: きゅう たま None Your salary is paid in cucumbers (きゅう). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well. Imagine your salary being paid in cucumbers. Open that sweet paycheck and watch the cucumbers come tumbling out.

mnemonics.meaning: Scene The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> rises over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, creating a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scene</mark> of breathtaking beauty. The sun is bright and warm as it crests over the capital. It’s quite the scene to behold. Picture this scene in your mind. Squint as the sun shines in your eyes, and feel its warmth as it rises up over the capital.
mnemonics.reading: けい None None The only way to make this scene better would be to add cake (けい). Now that you think about it, as the sun rises and frosts the capital with light, the buildings start to look like big, shiny cakes. Picture this scene again, but this time the sun is making the buildings of the capital look like big, fancy cakes. Now take a bite!

mnemonics.meaning: Scroll A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> only sees himself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>) on those big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scroll</mark>s they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves. Imagine being a gladiator. Your big fight is coming and you're the  main event! Look at the scroll for the fight and try to find yourself.
mnemonics.reading: かん ま, まき None When you look at the scroll you realize... you look just like Genghis Khan (かん)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are. After a while of showing off the scroll, someone finally pulls you aside and says, "That guy isn't you, it's the real Genghis Khan. He's coming to the event and he's against you. So. Nice knowing you." Oh.

mnemonics.meaning: Search You want to get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, so you dedicate your life to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">search</mark> for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the ark of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise. Now you have to search through a bunch of religious texts for this humble stool with your fingers. Don't go too fast and get paper cuts!
mnemonics.reading: そう さが None You search and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your soul (そう) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers! You dedicated your soul to searching, and now that your soul is free from its body, you can continue the search until you find it!

mnemonics.meaning: Set Up Care A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is what a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> uses to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">set up</mark> the station where he'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">care</mark> for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here. Watch the lifeguard walk around the beach. He needs to pick a nice big tree for his set up, so he can provide the best care possible.
mnemonics.reading: こう かま None You look closer at the set up and realize the lifeguard is こういち! You know he teaches Japanese but... is こういち really qualified to care for people like this? Imagine こういち setting up a care station. You hope you don't get in trouble in the water so you don't have to see how good he is at caring for people. Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: Shadow The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> rises over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, shines down on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, and casts a long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shadow</mark> on the ground in front of you. Feel the heat of the sun on your back as you look down over your capital, your long hair blowing over your shoulder. Your shadow stretches in front of you and it's honestly pretty impressive.
mnemonics.reading: えい かげ None In the shade from your shadow you see a small acorn (えい) laying on the ground. You're about to reach down and pick it up when you realize that your shadow is keeping this little acorn from growing up big and strong. What do you do? Keep standing here, admiring the view and casting this shadow on the acorn. Or do you move and let the acorn grow, becoming a tree that can cast its own shadow on your capital.

mnemonics.meaning: Strangle A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark>ed all around and begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strangle</mark> you. Just imagine thread everywhere, mixing in with everything. It's all around, and no matter where you go you get more and more caught in this thread. Eventually it tightens because you're trying to escape, and you feel yourself having trouble breathing. Imagine the moment when you realize you're getting strangled.
mnemonics.reading: こう し, しぼ None As you are strangled you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is こういち, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together. In your final moments before you are totally strangled, you think you see a little thread come out of his butt. "I should have done my WaniKani reviews" is your last thought.

mnemonics.meaning: Sue You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of blood on it. You hit someone with that axe and now they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sue</mark> you. That drop of blood on your axe is pretty incriminating, which is why they have enough of a case to sue you. Imagine being unable to stop yourself from saying "I have the axe with the drop on it!" and the recently axed person jumps out from behind a bush and shouts, "Aha! I'm gonna sue you!"
mnemonics.reading: そ うった None You want to sue them back so you clean the axe with some soap (そ). "Your honor," you say in court, "I don't see any drops of blood, I countersue!" The person you axed cries and tries desperately to find their blood on the axe so they can keep suing you properly. You hold the soap behind your back and cackle.

mnemonics.meaning: Supplement There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>. It's there as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supplement</mark> to the guests because not enough people came. It's weird that you supplemented your wedding guests with a spirit or two, but even if you hadn't invited them, they may have showed up anyway.
mnemonics.reading: ほ おぎな None Along with the spirits to supplement your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a hoe (ほ). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is! Maybe you should supplement your wedding with other things next time... instead of spirits and garden hoes.

mnemonics.meaning: Transit A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> and you on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> under it away. You are now in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transit</mark>. Imagine being carried away on your stool by the tsunami, with your entire yurt floating around you too. You're both in transit... to somewhere. You don't know where though.
mnemonics.reading: と わた None The transit of yourself and your yurt home is due to the water (わた). This is water transit. You hope the tsunami's water will drop you off somewhere nice. Somewhere it's easy to jump on a different kind of mass transit, to get back home again.

mnemonics.meaning: Adjoin Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> touch as you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adjoin</mark> yourselves. You are united, you are one. Look around you. Other women are adjoining their fingers and standing with you. There's hundreds, no, thousands of you standing together.
mnemonics.reading: せつ つ None All the women adjoin in sets (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison. Picture a bunch of women standing together. They're holding hands in sets, adjoined together.

mnemonics.meaning: Again Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> emerges... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">again</mark>! It's not the first time you've seen this buried head, nor is it the last. This dirt-covered head hides beneath the ground wherever you go, and keeps popping up to scare you again and again. Picture the dirt-covered head popping up again and again. How can it move under the ground like that if it's just a head? You decide to get closer this time, and for once it speaks: "Get me out of the ground!"
mnemonics.reading: さ, さい ふたた None The dirt-covered head asks for help again and again, but you've only got a saw (さ). So you start digging with it, scraping the dirt away, until you see this head has the body of a cyborg (さい)! Imagine how dirty you and your saw are after all this. At least you could help this cyborg with your saw. "Thanks again," it says, then runs off shaking the dirt out of its hair.

mnemonics.meaning: Alone There once was an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> friend who felt very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alone</mark> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other. Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
mnemonics.reading: どく ひと None One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team. Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Beast Animal On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> sits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark> that is some sort of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beast</mark>, a vicious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">animal</mark>. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet. Picture this beast creeping, low to the ground, in the grass around the rice paddy. It's got its eyes on you. Uh oh.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう けもの None The beast is guarding its precious jewels (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance. All beasts have something they're trying to protect. In this case, it's some beastly jewels.

mnemonics.meaning: Cake You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> and you make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cake</mark> out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations. Look at this cake you have made. It’s majestic. Now taste some of it. It is one great tasting cake. Imagine yourself eating the best cake in all of ever.
mnemonics.reading: か None None You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car! Hear the roar of the car engine as you get splattered in the face with the cake. Wipe it off of your face just in time to see the car speeding off into the distance. Also, recall that this kanji shares a reading with the similar kanji, 果.

mnemonics.meaning: Chastise They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> device (like a ruler) is a good way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastise</mark> someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM! Imagine being chastised with a measurement device. Think how horrible it would be getting hit on your knuckles, your nose, or the back of your head. It would be awful. Imagine this experience.
mnemonics.reading: とう う None You're being chastised because you tried to say something in English in とうきょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words. How could you say something in English while you're in とうきょう?! After you went to all the trouble to learn all this kanji and Japanese? Geez, we almost think you deserve to be chastised...

mnemonics.meaning: Circumstance Reason The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is to blame for today's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circumstance</mark>. It is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> things are bad now. Imagine a poor, broken town. And, imagine the mayor of a town telling their people that things are bad because of that bad old winter. "It's to blame for our circumstance!" he yells.
mnemonics.reading: こ ゆえ None In reality, this circumstance was actually caused by a single 子 (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path. Imagine your kid character walking through town, using their super powers to destroy buildings and rot food.

mnemonics.meaning: Contrast Compare Your new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> doesn’t <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contrast</mark> to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast. Imagine this garage of yours with a sea of white cars. Now there is a new car that really sticks out like a sore thumb. Imagine yourself looking out over your cars and seeing this wacky car practically jumping out at you.
mnemonics.reading: かく, こう None None What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there. See yourself driving around in this peacock car. Hear the engine purr as strangers jeer and yell at you. This car sure does get a lot of attention, doesn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: Create "A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>!" you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">announce</mark>. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">create</mark>. Imagine being at a maker's contest. Each person has to announce loudly what they'll create, then they have to create it.
mnemonics.reading: ぞう つく None But, a scooter has been created before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep zombies (ぞう) busy. Imagine the scooter you created with a zombie on it. It's a perfect place for the zombie to get stuck and scooted off into nowhere.

mnemonics.meaning: Create In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">create</mark>. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create. What do you create in your warehouse? Picture all the different things you could create in your mind.
mnemonics.reading: そう None None When you create it's good for your soul (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm. When you create something your soul is happy! It's good for you, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Encourage The "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cliff</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ten Thousand</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Power</mark>" is where you go if you want to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encourage</mark>d. If you can get to the top of the cliff, it will use its "ten thousand power" to encourage you.
mnemonics.reading: れい はげ None When you get there, it does encourage you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a ray (れい) gun." A cliff is encouraging you to buy a ray gun for some reason. This is not the encouragement you expected, but it is encouragement nonetheless. You go back down the cliff and immediately buy a ray gun.

mnemonics.meaning: Fierce Violent A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>, traveling in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fierce</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violent</mark> force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence. Imagine this white tsunami, more violent and fierce than any other tsunami you’ve ever seen, coming toward you. It’s very frightening. Feel the cold wetness it brings to your skin.
mnemonics.reading: げき はげ None The tsunami is too fierce, too violent, and before you realize what's happening, Gecki (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air. "Geecckkkiiiiii!!!" you scream in horror, as he's thrown about by the fierce, winter tsunami. You have to close your eyes. You can't watch Gecki go.

mnemonics.meaning: Fortune Occupy The  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fortune</mark> kanji are exactly the same! This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occupy</mark>, maybe because learning your fortune shows you how you're going to occupy your life. Or how it will occupy you… You haven't seen the radical in a while, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kanji: Put your toe in your mouth to learn your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fortune</mark>. The taste will tell you everything you need to know about your fortune. But your toe has to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occupy</mark> your mouth first for it to work. Imagine what your toe tastes like. Or actually taste it, I don't care. What do the taste and texture of it say about you, about your future fortune?
mnemonics.reading: せん うらな, し None To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true! Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.

mnemonics.meaning: Hinder There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> standing in the way of the next <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">chapter</mark> in your life, and it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hinder</mark>ing you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient. Picture this huge, tall building standing directly in the way. You peer around the other side and there is a book floating in the air that says "Chapter 5: Success and Happiness." Dang, you really want to get over there to that part of your life.
mnemonics.reading: しょう さわ None Someone put this building here specifically to hinder you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun wants to hinder you and your life. He wants you to have to work harder so you become better, faster, and stronger than anyone else. Hindering you is his way of making sure you don't take the easy way out in life.

mnemonics.meaning: I Me Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ego</mark>... it's totally out of control. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego. Just keep going with this sentence about the ego. You can't stop, because really it's your ego that's out of control. That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> when you're saying it.
mnemonics.reading: が われ, わ None I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "ga (が) ga ga ga!" You're just destroying the ego of that other guy. "Why?" you ask? "Because I am the boss here. And you are the baby. Ego things."

mnemonics.meaning: Indication Sign A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indication</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sign</mark> of something to come. We don't want to focus too much on what the indication / sign actually is, though, because it will take away from the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indication</mark> part (which we want to remember). So, focus on the fact that this is some kind of indication that's important, but you don't know what that indication means or is... because we'll use that with the reading.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう しるし None When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an indication that soon Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season. Imagine an announcer watching the loitering mountain king, "There he is... and it's still winter. We all know what that means. It's a sign that Mrs. Chou will be coming out of hibernation soon." Then, you can imagine her bursting forth from the mountain, running down her street.

mnemonics.meaning: Instruct There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> reaching towards you asking you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">accept</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instruct</mark> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them! Picture yourself instructing a class full of knowledge hungry little kids. They reach out with their fingers to accept the truth you bring to them.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ さず None "Yes! I will instruct you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small juice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small). Picture yourself instructing little kids how to punch the straw into small juice boxes. Hold it right-side-up! Don't squeeze too hard! Don't punch it through the other side! No! Don't bite the box! Instructing is hard!

mnemonics.meaning: Journey Depart You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> until he <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">depart</mark>s on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">journey</mark>. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way. Picture yourself loitering around your master’s fancy mansion. You’re pretending to dust things off, but you’re actually just waiting for him to depart on his journey.
mnemonics.reading: おう None None Finally, it's time for your master's journey and he calls to you and says, "You are the 王 (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone." Your master has departed! You are the 王 now!

mnemonics.meaning: Lead You hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> while shopping for pencil <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lead</mark> at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth. Imagine having these gold fins in your mouth. Taste the metal as your tongue runs over them.
mnemonics.reading: えん なまり None You pay for your lead but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything ends (えん). Lead poisoning, huh? What a way for everything to end...

mnemonics.meaning: Mail Post A broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> sits in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mail</mark>. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">post</mark>. You just put some postage on it and watch the mail carrier take it away like any other piece of mail.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう None None Who did you address this broken car mail (or post) to? You sent it to the youths (ゆう) of the world. You figure youths don't have cars anymore, so they could use one. Ugh, youths these days and their ride share apps.

mnemonics.meaning: Needle In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, you see a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">needle</mark> sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest. Picture this golden cross in your head. Why do you suppose there’s this needle stuck in it? You try to pull it out but you can’t. Envision yourself straining, trying to get the thing out.
mnemonics.reading: しん はり None You're about to give up on the needle when it pops out and flies directly into your shin (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business. Imagine a needle sticking into your shin. It hurts a ton. How would you try to get it out?

mnemonics.meaning: Obey Accompany, Follow If you see someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing around with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on their head you'd be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obey</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> them. First of all, this could be really fun. Second of all, if this person is a demon or something, you should really just obey them or they could curse you. What's the worst that could happen?!
mnemonics.reading: じゅう したが None If you obey the horned man you'll end up with a ton of jewels (じゅう)! You stole those jewels together and now you're an accomplice for accompanying him! You better hide those jewels!!

mnemonics.meaning: Restore You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">restore</mark> mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was. Imagine loitering around near (but not too near!) the black hole waiting for it to finish so you can restore the galaxy.
mnemonics.reading: ふく None None Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the restore button.... but nothing happens. "Oh f**k (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to. Maybe if you yell f**k you enough things will be restored. Ha. No. Everything's gone and it's your fault for being gullible.

mnemonics.meaning: River During a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">river</mark>. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring. Imagine how painful this would be, having your lip ring ripped from your lip. It would hurt a lot. Touch your lip and imagine missing half of it. Yikes.
mnemonics.reading: か かわ こう, こお But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though. Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!

mnemonics.meaning: Savings You keep all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> and it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">savings</mark>. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later. Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
mnemonics.reading: ちょ た, たくわ None When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings. Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!

mnemonics.meaning: Seal Mark You take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark>, break the handle off, and use it to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> your official <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal</mark> of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mark</mark>ing process, but it gets the job done. Imagine breaking and bending a comb so you can use it to stamp your seal onto things.
mnemonics.reading: いん しるし None You need this seal to stay at an inn (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly. Hopefully the inn accepts this seal... or you aren't going to have a place to sleep tonight. And it kind of just looks like you dipped a comb in ink and pressed it around on some paper.

mnemonics.meaning: Shake Wave You're trying to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to cause a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wave</mark> at the ground now. Imagine shaking your fingers at the dirt. Do you think you can shake the dirt hard enough to cause a landslide (spoilers, no).
mnemonics.reading: しん ふ None You think you finally got the earth to shake but when you look down it's just your shins (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?! Imagine your shins shaking, your hands are waving, and they won't stop. No! You shouldn't have tried to start a landslide. This was a bad idea!

mnemonics.meaning: Sprain Discourage When you hold out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> — and then a second <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> — stomps them into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, leaving you with a serious finger <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprain</mark>. That wasn't very nice of either person, and now you feel awfully <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discourage</mark>d about things. Feel the throbbing pain in your sprained, dirt-covered fingers, and imagine how intensely discouraged you are knowing that neither person who hurt you is going to face any consequences.
mnemonics.reading: ざ くじ None You show your sprain to a doctor, and he tells you to go see the Czar (ざ). In your country, only the Czar has the authority to treat a sprain of this severity. Once again, you face a crushing sense of discouragement — you'll never be able to afford the services of the Czar! It looks you're just going to have to live with this finger sprain for the rest of your life.

mnemonics.meaning: Suspicious You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> floating around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> acting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suspicious</mark>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird. Imagine inching closer to this suspicious soul floating around a tombstone. What do you think it's doing?
mnemonics.reading: かい, け あや None You sneak around the tombstone to see what this suspicious soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to kayak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water. Even more suspicious, the soul seems to be holding a kettle (け). Considering the soul is already dead, this doesn't seem like something it will need. Picture a suspicious, kettle holding, kayaking soul. The afterlife may be more interesting than you thought.

mnemonics.meaning: Sweat The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> going down your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> face is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweat</mark>. Sweat really does feel like a tsunami though. Wow, it's dry and hot out right now!
mnemonics.reading: かん あせ None The sweat isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your ass (あせ). The one place you wish sweat wouldn't go, but somehow it always does: the ass.

mnemonics.meaning: Twist "Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Now</mark>, put them on your foe's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">twist</mark>." These are the words of your martial arts master as he teaches you his final, ultimate technique: the "finger-heart twister." No one can stop you now. Imagine how powerful you feel as you conquer dojo after dojo, using your bare fingers to twist the heart of any challenger who dares face you. What a twisted fiend you are!
mnemonics.reading: ねん ひね, ねじ None The last challenger to appear is… your own master, who taught you the twist technique. Turns out he's a nendoroid (ねん), so he doesn't even have a heart for you to twist. Welp, you're screwed. Imagine the helplessness you'd feel facing him. Your master, who all along was a kind of plastic figurine called a nendoroid, is impervious to the twist technique he himself taught you! What a twist.

mnemonics.meaning: Wipe You're using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to do something important for this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark>. What's really important for this ceremony's construction, using your fingers? Well… you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wipe</mark> the floors. Hey, somebody has to do it! Wiping the floors is as important for any ceremony as all the other work that goes into it… right?!
mnemonics.reading: しょく ふ, ぬぐ None Now wipe these floors, you fool (ふ)! Oh wow, sorry, not sure where that just came from… Look, wiping floors for a living doesn't make anyone a fool, they're people just like you and me. Now hurry up, I want a nice sheen on these floors before the ceremony.

mnemonics.meaning: Writing Brush Out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark>, you make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> – a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">writing brush</mark>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo! Imagine yourself using this bamboo writing brush. Do you know many kanji? Of course you do! Imagine yourself writing them all with this nice writing brush. It’s actually fun to write things with it!
mnemonics.reading: ひつ ふで None Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on! Imagine the sound the brush makes when it hits the paper. It’s a bit of a plop, and then kind of a scratching sound as the brush bristles move around. Really focus on this sound that the brush makes when it hits the paper.

mnemonics.meaning: Angry Anger A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> with a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">angry</mark>. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him. This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
mnemonics.reading: ど おこ, いか None As you're sitting on that stool feeling angry, your dog (ど) comes up to console you. He nuzzles his head into your lap, and you start to feel the anger melt away. Imagine your dog (or somebody else's dog) putting his furry, warm head in your lap. Feel how comforting it is. Are you still feeling angry?

mnemonics.meaning: Ascend You want to go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> so you set up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> stories tall so you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ascend</mark> into the heavens. Feel the air whoosh past your face as you shoot off the end of the long slide and ascend into the air. It's starting to get hot and the sun is getting closer!
mnemonics.reading: しょう のぼ None You need to ascend into the sky and toward the sun because the Shougun (しょう) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig. As you ascend, look back through tear-filled eyes and see the Shougun staring up at you. He nods slightly. You've pleased him.

mnemonics.meaning: Astray Lost If you're riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> through some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, it's likely you've gone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">astray</mark>. Also you might be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lost</mark>. Usually there aren't paved areas inside areas of rice. You must be really lost if you ended up here with your scooter.
mnemonics.reading: めい まよ None You got so lost and went so astray you ended up on the Mayflower (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray. How you got so lost that you ended up on an old ship from 1620 is beyond my understanding. But you did it.

mnemonics.meaning: Beckon Someone is reaching out with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> for you. They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beckon</mark> you closer, this way. Something about the way they're beckoning you with their fingers is really enticing. You can't help but walk toward them.
mnemonics.reading: しょう まね None The person beckoning you is the Shougun (しょう). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call. Even if the Shougun didn't have an army that would crush you if you didn't come when he called, you'd go anyway. Those beckoning fingers are just so... weirdly enticing.

mnemonics.meaning: Belly Abdomen, Stomach Inside this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>... haha just kidding, it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belly</mark>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stomach</mark> you have! Look down at your perfect belly. It's looking back up at you.
mnemonics.reading: ふく はら, なか None If you don't treat your belly with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "F**k (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach! Forget to eat lunch? Belly grumbles f**k you. Tell someone you're fat and need to lose weight? Belly cries f**k you. Be nice to your belly.

mnemonics.meaning: Dense Thick After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">farming</mark> land, you're gonna see a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dense</mark> silt left behind. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thick</mark> layer really enriches the soil, and your crops will come out tasting extra thick and dense in flavor. Imagine your farming land absolutely covered with this dense layer of silt from the tsunami, but then seeing your crops sprouting up one after another, thicker than ever. It’s all very thick and dense, we think you get the point.
mnemonics.reading: のう こ None Know who’s likely responsible for this dense, thick layer of silt? Nostradamus (のう). He’s the one who urged you to buy this farmland in the first place, likely because he predicted the tsunami would bring this thick layer of silt. You can always rely on Nostradamus’ predictions hitting the mark, even when it comes to thickly-layered-silt-bringing tsunamis. Good ol’ reliable Nostradamus.

mnemonics.meaning: Drowsy Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s start to close as you drive your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> because you’re getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drowsy</mark>. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life! Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
mnemonics.reading: すい None None The reason you’re so drowsy, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire swing (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out. Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.

mnemonics.meaning: Ease Peace You see a canopy under which someone has left a brush (in its 肀 form) next to the water, creating a scene of such ease and peace! Imagine the sense of peace you'd feel in a place like this. The sound of the water, the shade of the canopy… Whoever was here must have felt at ease as they wrote or drew. But will they come back for their brush?
mnemonics.reading: こう None None It turns out this place of ease and peace was created by こういち, who suddenly comes in looking for the brush he left. Finding you there, こういち invites you spend some time under the canopy with him, practicing kanji together with his brush. Why not? Seems peaceful.

mnemonics.meaning: Edge Setting up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> all the rocks to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edge</mark> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well. Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
mnemonics.reading: たん はし, はた, は, はした, はな None You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a tan (たん). You lie next to the edge of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan. Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.

mnemonics.meaning: Extreme There aren't many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s in your under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, so you've been given a task: using only your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, plant as many in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> as you can. It's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extreme</mark> challenge! How are you going to approach this weirdly specific, extreme task? Dig a hole using the stool and then plant the trees with your mouth? Good luck figuring this one out! You're in a weird underground prison for a reason, after all.
mnemonics.reading: きょく, ごく きわ None This extreme challenge could only be solved by one person: Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z! He has a special cloak that'll allow you to plant trees in record time, so he quickly cloaks you (きょく) to help with your extreme task. Goku barely manages to cloak you before the prison guards realize what's going on. With this cloak, you'll be planting trees with your mouth and stool like no one else before! Hooray!

mnemonics.meaning: Get A Position In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, even a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">get a position</mark>. That's because the capital has so many jobs available that even a poor, broken dog can find a place to work. Imagine this dog going to the capital and getting a position. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう, じゅ つ None In order to help the dog get a position, the capital cobbler made him a pair of nice shoes (しゅう). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they boost his confidence and make him feel ready for any position. Watch the broken dog settle in to his new shoes in his new home in the capital. The old dog can finally enjoy life!

mnemonics.meaning: Guy Inside the "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Good</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Building</mark>" there's a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guy</mark>. Feel free to walk around the Good Building. There are no things or people, except for that one guy. Who is that guy.
mnemonics.reading: ろう None None You talk to that guy. The only thing he does is offer you roe (ろう). You try to talk to the guy, poke him, and even yell at him. But, all he does is hand you some fish roe. When you take it, he offers you more fish roe. What's up with this guy?

mnemonics.meaning: Healthy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> class uses a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> to stay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">healthy</mark>. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick. If you want to be healthy too, just do yoga and rub this healthy brush all over your bod.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None Not everyone wants to be healthy, but Ken (けん) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush. Imagine Ken, the picture of samurai health, doing yoga and getting that brush all up in those bits.

mnemonics.meaning: Invite Lure You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you've left some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark>. This is how you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">invite</mark> people into your place. Picture yourself saying out loud how you've left grain on the stairs, trying to lure people in. You're surprised people are actually falling for this.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう さそ None You've invited people in by leaving grain on the stairs but some youths (ゆう) have ended up eating all the grain. Imagine the youths just loitering in the stairs having eaten all the grain and taking up all the space making it impossible for anyone else to come in.

mnemonics.meaning: Lend You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">substitute</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> for collateral so your friend will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lend</mark> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people. "Shellfish used to be money! People used to lend them to each other all the time!" you say to your friend. "Hmm... okay, I guess so," they say skeptically.
mnemonics.reading: たい か None You want your friend to lend you some money so you can buy yourself a car (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan. Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.

mnemonics.meaning: Long For Yearn Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long for</mark>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yearn</mark> for it. Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
mnemonics.reading: しょう, とう, どう あこが None No matter how much you long for it, you can't go back because a cougar (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in. You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!

mnemonics.meaning: Misguided A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> who has his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">misguided</mark>. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground. Picture this misguided drunkard. His whole deal is messed up.
mnemonics.reading: わく まど None Nowadays we don't say misguided, we say wack (わく). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack. Did I do it? Did I figure out the kid lingo? Am I cool? Or am I just another wack, misguided adult?

mnemonics.meaning: Pain When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> tries to do a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> she's filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pain</mark>! Sick people shouldn't have to do things, of course they're in pain. You shouldn't let your mama do anything if she's in pain, do it for her!
mnemonics.reading: つう いた None Your mama's pain is too (つう) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too. You finish doing your tasks and hers too, and you ask her, "How is the pain now, Mama?" "THE PAIN IS TOO MUCH!" she cries. Oh mama.

mnemonics.meaning: Retreat Reject If you're on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and you run over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, you'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">retreat</mark>. The roots have obviously <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reject</mark>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should. Picture the roots raising up a little bit from the ground and tripping up your scooter. They reject you, so you should just retreat.
mnemonics.reading: たい しりぞ, ひ, ど, の None You're trying to retreat by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your tie (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck. You didn't retreat fast enough, the roots are rejecting your life, and strangling you with your own tie.

mnemonics.meaning: Route When you ride a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> you'll have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of possible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">route</mark>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too! Okay, so it might not be legal to take the sidewalk route depending on where you live, but physically, you can do whatever you want because scooters are small.
mnemonics.reading: と None None You decide to take the fastest route, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single toe (と) on every single person trying to walk there. Psh, whatever. They aren't your toes, and this is the fastest route! You'll name it the toe route and do whatever you want.

mnemonics.meaning: Shoes Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> it into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoes</mark>. You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
mnemonics.reading: か くつ None Some shoes aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old coots (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots. Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.

mnemonics.meaning: Sleep Closing each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> is something that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peoples</mark> do before they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleep</mark>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep. You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
mnemonics.reading: みん ねむ None The reason you want to sleep is because all the other peoples were mean (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep. Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as 民, which is included in this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Spare Time Free Time In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> while holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> and sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, you comb your hair in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spare time</mark>. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop. Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
mnemonics.reading: か ひま, いとま None So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your spare time, you used to steal cars (か). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair. Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.

mnemonics.meaning: Steps Stairs Cut this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> up with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and turn it into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steps</mark> for some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stairs</mark>. When you think about it, a comb is like a ladder. So if you cut all the rungs off with your weapon and put them on the ground, they turn into stairs!
mnemonics.reading: だん None None You slowly work to create these stairs, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at dawn (だん) they are done! Imagine standing at the top of the stairs you made yourself, looking down at the entire town below you, as the light of dawn breaks and fills everything before you with light. And now more people can see this beautiful sight if they climb your steps.

mnemonics.meaning: Stomach If you eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> the size of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stomach</mark> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy. Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
mnemonics.reading: い None None From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended stomach. Bam! The eagle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy. This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.

mnemonics.meaning: Symptom When someone is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> in order to diagnose the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> cause and treatment, you need to check their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">symptom</mark>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them! If you know all of the symptoms for each and every sickness you'd be able to cure them all!
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None You need to figure out the symptoms the Shougun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head. You get all up close and personal with the Shougun. Hmm, his symptoms are watery eyes, stuffy nose, angry shouting (wait no, that's not a symptom, is it?). Don't mess up!

mnemonics.meaning: Tighten This special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> lets you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> up and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tighten</mark> it without trouble. Imagine pulling this thread and watch as your towel tightens and goes rigid, standing up almost completely on its own (except that the thread did it).
mnemonics.reading: てい し None You tighten your towel before you eat tater (てい) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers. A tightened towel stands up for easy grease cleanup. No wiping on your pants, no dripping on the floor.

mnemonics.meaning: Urge Compel, Coerce The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>. This color will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urge</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compel</mark> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coerce</mark> you, even. Look at how white the scooter is. It urges you to use it. It compels you. You feel coerced...
mnemonics.reading: はく せま None When they urge, compel and coerce you like this, they are hacking (はく) your brain. Really all marketing, advertising, and the like is just a hack of your brain. Hint: If you see 白 in a kanji, there's a good likelihood the reading will be はく.

mnemonics.meaning: Visit Someone just asked you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> which <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> they should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">visit</mark>. You better think long and hard about where you think they should visit before you say so. They're relying on you.
mnemonics.reading: ほう たず, おとず None You end up saying, "You should visit my home (ほう)." How kind of you! Your home is just over that direction, and it's your favorite place to visit, so why wouldn't this stranger want to visit your home too?! So come and visit my home, random person!

mnemonics.meaning: Weave Taking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and moving to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of the music, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> makes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weave</mark> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard. Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
mnemonics.reading: しき, しょく お None This drunkard is really chic (しき), but he's just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he's using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy chic outfits. Imagine this drunkard, and his chic but shabby appearance. Let's hope he can repair that chic outfit and go back to being his usual chic self.

mnemonics.meaning: Worry If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is lying in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark>, you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worry</mark> about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it. Picture your soul curled up inside this treasure chest that's just sitting out on the grass. Anyone could open it up and look inside, and this worries you quite a bit!
mnemonics.reading: のう なや None Unfortunately, you also worry about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? Nah, yah (なや). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind. You worry about what you'll find if you look directly at your soul. But you also worry about what will happen if someone else looks. So you're stuck in a constant state of worrying: nah or yah?!

mnemonics.meaning: Yield You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> letting you know to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yield</mark>. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them. Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
mnemonics.reading: くつ かが None Even though the flag told you to yield, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old coots (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way! Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.

mnemonics.meaning: Aggression <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Construction</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> leads to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aggression</mark>. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project. Imagine yourself walking through the winter construction site, taking out your aggression on anyone you see. You hate this winter construction!
mnemonics.reading: こう せ None You're taking your aggression out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, こういち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him. "Aggression" is going to depend on you, so you should imagine a scene where you take your aggression out on こういち, whatever that entails. Hint: When you see the radical construction (工) in a kanji, it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Attack If someone is coming toward you in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> you! Picture the car, weapon out the window, preparing to attack you full force!
mnemonics.reading: げき う None Right before the attack begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's Gecki (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge. Gecki is attacking you now. He's hitting you over and over with his tiny car. He's yelling and smacking your ankles with his weapon. And all you can do is wait and let the attack happen, because you know you deserve it.

mnemonics.meaning: Beach After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, you find an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beach</mark>. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach. See these things on the beach. It makes sense to see fins, as fins are usually in the ocean, so seeing them on the beach is logical. Pick up the stuff you find as you feel the beach sand between your toes.
mnemonics.reading: ひん はま None Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer. Pick up the hammer in your hand. It’s pretty heavy. The tsunami must have been very strong to pick up such a heavy hammer.

mnemonics.meaning: Beautiful This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark>, but that's what makes it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beautiful</mark>. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you. If something is a bit odd, it's usually beautiful in its own way, just like this beautiful thread.
mnemonics.reading: き None None You take this beautiful thread and lock it up with a key (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only! To remember that there's a beautiful thread hidden away, you tie a not-as-beautiful thread to the end of the key.

mnemonics.meaning: Benefit There are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> that are meant to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">benefit</mark> everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up. You pick up the horns off the ground and put them on your head, then eat some fins off the plate. This is just one of many benefits to living here. You'll never go hungry!
mnemonics.reading: えき None None Another benefit is free 駅 (えき) usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free. Okay, so using the 駅 is probably a better benefit than eating cold fins off a plate on the ground, but you take what you can get. They're all free!

mnemonics.meaning: Bog A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> can't resist the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bog</mark>. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~" Close your eyes and hear the bog's tempting call.
mnemonics.reading: しょう ぬま None As you listen to the bog's call you realize it looks just like the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy. So that's what happened to him! If you're a youngun, just do a little Google and you'll be pretty pleased, I'm sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Child Pointing your magic solar powered wishing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you attain the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">child</mark>. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child. Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
mnemonics.reading: じ, に こ None As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.” Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.

mnemonics.meaning: Complete Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">before</mark> were <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">complete</mark>. Imagine one of your fingers is missing, and they're no longer complete like before. When everyone told you not to join that yakuza gang, you just didn't listen.
mnemonics.reading: せん そろ None To have your complete fingers back, you gotta run to the hospital solo (そろ). You can't be seen with anyone because your former yakuza mates might be watching you. Seriously, you don't want anyone else involved in this business.
