mnemonics.meaning: Constitution The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> protecting your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> protecting your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> are both protected by the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">constitution</mark>. The constitution makes it so that everything you hold dear is locked away, nice and safe on a piece of paper, and no one can change the rules or hurt you without your say so.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None Your country's constitution is being protected by none other than Ken (けん) the samurai, hero for hire. Picture Ken standing in front of your constitution. But keep a close watch, cause wily ol' Nic Cage is in the business of thievin' on constitutions.

mnemonics.meaning: Cool Cold You got your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. Of course, your ice orders are to make things <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cool</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>. Making things cool and cold are pretty much the only orders you'll hear from ice. Ice is very simple in that regard.
mnemonics.reading: れい つめ, ひ, さ None How will you make things cool and cold? You'll use a special ray (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray. Imagine a cold ray coming out of your ray gun. Anything it touches becomes cold. "Stay cool, bird boy," you say. Hint: When you see the radical orders (令) in a kanji, it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: Deal With A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> would be an odd thing to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deal with</mark>. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst! Look at this winter table. How are you ever going to deal with it? Just think of your favorite warm food and then imagine it getting cold. Deal with it, dog.
mnemonics.reading: しょ ところ None This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this. Feel the relief of getting rid of this table. No more having to deal with it anymore. The circus show can have it.

mnemonics.meaning: Delicate Tiny, Slight You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, reading off the digits of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pi</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> morning. The cold mountain air is so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delicate</mark>, and changes only in very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tiny</mark> ways — just like pi when you add another digit to it. What other delicate things and tiny changes would you notice on the mountain? A little bird alighting in a tree, or the snowflakes it shakes loose from a branch? That's for you to decide, but imagine it vividly whatever it is.
mnemonics.reading: び かす None Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び). Slightly out of place in winter, but this tiny creature is your idea of delicate. It lands on your finger, and you look at every tiny fiber of its being. Picture yourself looking at the bee, thinking how each hair on its body is so delicate and tiny. Maybe it has a delicate aroma to go with it. A slight smell of honey?

mnemonics.meaning: Exhibition Gambling You wear a great big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on it, and head to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhibition</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gambling</mark>. The big cross and drop on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross and drop, and everyone is gambling. Picture yourself at this specialty exhibition. Feel the weight of the cross shaped badge on your chest as you continue gambling at the exhibition.
mnemonics.reading: はく, ばく None None You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system. Hack the gambling machines. Imagine the sounds of the exhibition around you as you work to hack the machines. Look at the computer parts and cables as you work.

mnemonics.meaning: Extent The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extent</mark> to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat. Of course, you need to imagine pulling the Grain Mouth King's finger, to some extent. You can't just read what we write for you, without going to the imagination zone. Pull that finger real hard a couple times, and watch an extra large purge of grain pour forth.
mnemonics.reading: てい ほど None The extent to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out tater (てい) tots instead. Imagine hearing the rumors that the Grain Mouth King ran out of grain, so you go check the extent of his failure yourself. But tater tots taste pretty good too. Imagine eating one of his mouth tater tots and go ahead and comment about it to him.

mnemonics.meaning: Frozen Freeze <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ice</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frozen</mark>. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen. Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s super cold, guys.
mnemonics.reading: とう こお, こご None Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was frozen in とうきょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there. Imagine being in とうきょう and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing twice-frozen ice.

mnemonics.meaning: Giant The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">giant</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
mnemonics.reading: きょ None None Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto. See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.

mnemonics.meaning: Immature Only give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> if it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">immature</mark>. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains. Imagine an immature turkey complaining at you until you give it grains. Now it's taking selfies with the grains and posting pics to Instagram and hashtagging them #GRAINLIFE.
mnemonics.reading: ち None None Another thing immature turkeys (and people) love is cheese (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person. Imagine a bunch of immature kids and turkeys eating cheese together.

mnemonics.meaning: Infancy Childhood Super <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> is a super <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you have in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">infancy</mark>. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power! Infants poop a lot. There's poop everywhere. The powerful aroma overwhelms you. Eww. Also refers to childhood, when you still have some of your poop powers, but they're already starting to go away.
mnemonics.reading: よう おさな None In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power. See this infant gobbling up all the yogurt he can get his grubby little hands on. Soon, he begins to poop all over the place. Hear the infant screaming, "Goo-goo! Yogurt poop power! I'm a baby! Wahhhh!!"

mnemonics.meaning: Line Up You stick <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> using them as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">line up</mark> the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection. Imagine yourself lining up these horns in the ground. The spikes are sharp and you poke yourself with one. Ouch. Need to be more careful as you line these up.
mnemonics.reading: へい なら, なみ None As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty. Imagine the hay in that bull's mouth as it chomps angrily, watching you line up horns in the ground. It probably wishes you were the hay.

mnemonics.meaning: Lovely If you know the radical meaning <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lovely</mark>, you know the kanji meaning <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lovely</mark> as well! You know what would make learning this kanji lovely? Studying your radicals.
mnemonics.reading: れい うるわ None "Lovely" is the name of my ray (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing. Try to imagine feeling this way about your ray gun. It's so lovely.

mnemonics.meaning: Mastering Repair Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>. This is the stick of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mastering</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">repair</mark>. Imagine your leader holding this stick of hair in the winter, going around mastering all kinds of skills and repairing everything in sight. What a strange stick, giving even stranger abilities to its wielder.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう おさ None What's the key to mastering any skill? A stick and a shoe (しゅう)! Picture your leader again; stick in one hand, shoe in the other. He looks kind of threatening, like he's about to slap you with the stick and then throw the shoe at you. But that's what it takes for mastering certain skills. This is all for discipline’s sake.

mnemonics.meaning: Odd Strange The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">odd</mark> kanji are the same. They're both... really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strange</mark>. Remember how odd this one is?
mnemonics.reading: き None None You're odd too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your strange habits with a key (き). You only give this odd key to people you trust, so they can unlock your odd secrets and see how odd you are deep down.

mnemonics.meaning: Peculiar A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is one of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peculiar</mark> things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few truly peculiar things in this world, with woman being one of them. Imagine saying this to a woman. Try and imagine her face as you tell her how peculiar she is.
mnemonics.reading: みょう たえ None But when you think about it, we're all a little peculiar. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody! Who's peculiar? Me and you. Me, you — we are peculiar! Peculiar, peculiar, peculiar!

mnemonics.meaning: Populace <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Blood</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark> make up the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">populace</mark>. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway. Blood shows that all the people are related. Hair shows that we're all humans. Tofu is food to all. So, as you can see, those three words describe the entire populace.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう None None The entire populace deserves shoes (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat. If you see people in your populace without shoes, it's your job as a fellow member of society to help them get some!

mnemonics.meaning: Pure A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark>. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure! Picture this pure blue tsunami. You can see every crystal clear drop of water in it.
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう, しん きよ し Seeing this pure blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue saber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash! SPLAASHH! The tsunami's pure water splits and it absorbed into your saber. Now it's pure too. And transparent!

mnemonics.meaning: Pure Clean A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> takes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, cuts it like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, and leaves everything behind completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clean</mark>. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, completely undefiled. Picture the tsunami purifying the land of life, and in your mind see the sword cutting clean through the thread of life.
mnemonics.reading: けつ いさぎよ None After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is pure white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt ketsup (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure. The area is SO pure that the ground absorbs the ketsup and now it's all pure... ketsup color.

mnemonics.meaning: Record A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> swam in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> while his father made a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record</mark> of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine. See this gold Wolverine holding his gold medal after getting out of the water. His dad doesn’t want to forget anything about this precious moment so he makes a record of it. Imagine him scribbling furiously in his notebook.
mnemonics.reading: ろく None None Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records. Imagine a pitiful Wolverine crying on the ground as each rock hits him. All he wanted was some recognition from his father. Poor guy. Imagine poor Wolverine like this as his dad just looks on and writes in his notebook.

mnemonics.meaning: Reverse Opposite Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> takes you to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s you off, and then goes in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reverse</mark> all the way back home in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">opposite</mark> direction. Imagine riding your scooter to the barracks. It literally drops you on the ground when you get there, and then drives in reverse back the opposite way you came.
mnemonics.reading: ぎゃく さか None Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial. You Gak up the wheels so when the scooter tries to switch to reverse it gets stuck. Success! But now it can't go forward either. Darn you Gak, you tricked me again.

mnemonics.meaning: Shift A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>, from one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> to the next <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark>, experiences a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shift</mark>. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another. Picture the grain in your head with a time-lapse of one evening after another happening in the background. Slowly, the grain shifts.
mnemonics.reading: い うつ None This shift is caused by the eagle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off. Picture the eagle flying down on the second evening, scattering the grains it doesn't eat, shifting their location.

mnemonics.meaning: Spirit Pure <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rice</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> has a strong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark>. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out! Picture this rice, the pulsing blue spirit of each grain is glowing so bright!
mnemonics.reading: せい None None You want to see the spirit up close, so you take your saber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything! Then it's gone. As you release the spirits in the rice, your saber begins to glow blue too. Their spirits are going inside your saber, making it stronger!

mnemonics.meaning: Squad This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> features <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> to represent our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squad</mark>. Our squad's symbol is horns on a pig, and we put it on everything to show the whole world our squad owns this turf.
mnemonics.reading: たい None None Our squad also wears special ties (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A SQUAD. Picture our squad. It's Koichi, Viet, the Crabigator and Tofugu. We're all wearing matching horned pig ties and walking toward you in slow motion, our squad building towering behind us with the pig smirking down at you.

mnemonics.meaning: Storage Storehouse, Warehouse A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> is over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> because your car is in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storage</mark> in a large <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark>. The canopy just protects your car from the elements as it sits in storage for long periods of time.
mnemonics.reading: こ くら None Your car is in this storage warehouse, just sitting there. A 子 (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it. Imagine a kid sneaking into your canopy to steal your car that's in storage. Maybe it's two 子s, one stacked on the other with a trench coat. One 子 works the pedals while the other 子 works the steering.

mnemonics.meaning: Ticket The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> in front of you draws his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ticket</mark> in your hand. Right! You needed to buy a ticket to see the gladiator! He doesn't want to kill you, he wants to check to make sure you bought a ticket.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None The gladiator happily marks your ticket with his blade, when Ken (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again. Ken takes a long time to examine your ticket. I don't think he understands that he needs a ticket to fight the gladiator. Maybe you should give him yours.

mnemonics.meaning: Umbrella Using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, four <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> make an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">umbrella</mark>. The hat is big enough to be an umbrella for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that's why they're holding the cross under the "umbrella." See these four people all under one makeshift umbrella. The giant hat is set atop the cross, which is what makes it kinda like an umbrella, and the four pairs of hands are all holding it upright.
mnemonics.reading: さん かさ None You know the Spanish phrase "Mi casa (かさ) es su casa"? Well, this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is also an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it's an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me. Imagine the four people in the umbrella hat again, only this time imagine them skipping along singing "Mi casa es su casa." It'll help you remember.

mnemonics.meaning: Wife That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> dressed as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> with her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> wrapped in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wife</mark>. You're cosplaying together! Picture your kick-butt wife in her Wolverine costume. She has a towel wrapped around her forehead because she is cosplaying as Wolverine just out of the shower.
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None Your wife suddenly looks at you and calls you a fool (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine. Your wife is shaking her head saying, "You fool, it's my turn to be Wolverine, you're gonna have to change." Then she smooches your cheek, calls you a fool one more time, and leaves without you.

mnemonics.meaning: Abbreviation Abbreviate A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you'd want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> is one that would probably have a cool <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abbreviation</mark> for their name, like Ri'-Pad. Yeah, that's definitely a cool abbreviation! Try to imagine how cool and confident Ri'-Pad is, they probably grow and wear their rice in a cool and trendy way, like a middle part or something.
mnemonics.reading: りゃく None None An abbreviation like Ri'-Pad is sure to get a strong reaction (りゃく) — some will find it a little pretentious, some will hate it, but most will probably think it's really cool. Try to visualize the different reactions people have to the name Ri'-Pad. What reaction did you have? What face did you make when you saw it?

mnemonics.meaning: Accumulate <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark>d for how much they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accumulate</mark>. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything. Picture a pile of grains accumulating in size while a person watches. No matter how large the pile gets, the person keeps blaming them for something!
mnemonics.reading: せき つ None Now the grains have accumulated a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some sexy (せき) grains." Is that why people become farmers? Because they think... accumulating a lot of grains is sexy? People are weird.

mnemonics.meaning: Append There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> and you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">append</mark> it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability. Take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Feel the drop of water on your finger and visualize yourself flicking it at the tsunami as it races towards heaven.
mnemonics.reading: てん そ None Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall. Look up at this ten story tall tsunami. It looks big and powerful. Feel the water spray from the tsunami as it towers over you.

mnemonics.meaning: Banquet Party Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, but still in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is laying out a fabulous <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">banquet</mark>. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests. Picture a large banquet of food on a sunny day, covered by an outdoor roof, and a woman carefully setting it all up.
mnemonics.reading: えん うたげ None Unfortunately, the banquet roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it ends (えん) before it can start. Honestly though, have you ever been to a banquet that ended well? Something always goes wrong when you have that many people under one roof.

mnemonics.meaning: Board If you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> (someone who's against trees), then you won't mind if turn all of them into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">board</mark>s! Hahaha! "Boards are much more useful than trees." – The Anti-Tree Association. Now picture this sign on a big machine that's cutting up all the trees into big boards.
mnemonics.reading: ばん, はん いた None The Tree Lovers Association has one word when they see you turning trees into boards: "Banned (ばん)," they shout at you. "Boards mean you're banned!" You couldn't care less about getting banned from the Tree Lovers Association. You and your Anti-Tree Association still keep on turning every tree into boards, ban or no ban. Damn those trees!

mnemonics.meaning: Break In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> you place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> and surround it with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> to keep it safe, but this net tends to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">break</mark>. Of course it breaks, it's just some clothes you tied together. Imagine what this janky makeshift net would look like. It's both comical and sad. Every day you set it up around the cross, but next morning it's lying in a broken heap in the dirt. What keeps breaking it?!
mnemonics.reading: かい こわ None You realize what keeps making your net break are kayaks (かい). The cross and net are right next to a river trail that kayakers do their kayaking in, and every time they go by their paddles smack into your net and break it. Imagine the rage you'd feel at these unrepentant kayakers who keep breaking your stuff. Oh, and don't forget to be angry at yourself — for putting the cross and net so close to a river that kayaks can't even go by without breaking it.

mnemonics.meaning: Colleague A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> will use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> to mark her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">colleague</mark>s. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt. Imagine seeing one of the leader's colleagues walking around, watching you. You'd get back to work and stop goofing around, right?
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None You have to be good around her colleagues, because if you aren't your row (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights. Imagine goofing off in your row boat and then seeing one of the colleagues waiting on the shore for you. No! She's gonna take your row boat away!

mnemonics.meaning: Cup Of Liquid Counter For Cups A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">not</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cup of liquid</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">counter for cups</mark>. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it. Imagine cutting a tree into a cup of liquid and focus on the pain in your throat when you try to actually use it. Instead you kick the tree and angrily count cups of liquid in your head, because they simply are NOT the same.
mnemonics.reading: はい None None Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful? Think of a haiku about a cup of liquid and a counter for cups. Use that haiku to help remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Daughter A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> is my <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">daughter</mark>. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it. Look at how good this woman is! She’s my daughter! She’s good! You wish your daughter was as good a woman as mine is!
mnemonics.reading: None むすめ None Your daughter, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things. Think about how your daughter is basically a moose who may do dumb things. How ashamed you feel. How very, very ashamed. Unlike how I feel about my wonderful, perfect, not a moose-like daughter.

mnemonics.meaning: Diagnose They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> to cover your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> if your doctor <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagnose</mark>s you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks. Imagine the doctor diagnosing you with hair loss. He pulls out a hat and places it on your poor, thinning hair.
mnemonics.reading: しん み None You just had the doctor diagnose you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day. Hold your shin as you feel the throbbing pain in it. Even though the pain is so extreme, you can’t help but still think about the diagnosis you got from the doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: Direct Supervise <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Above</mark> you on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> of the one who will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">direct</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supervise</mark> you at work. He’s really high above you, so all you can see is the glint of his supervising eye. But you can hear him shouting directions clearly, telling you exactly what to do. Look up and see that eye, shining down and supervising you closely. Hear the man shouting as he directs you in one task after another. It makes you uncomfortable, honestly.
mnemonics.reading: とく None None A man who can direct others so well must be Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu. Sure enough, when he finally comes down off his stool you see that he’s the ghost of Tokugawa Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only make out the ghostly gleam of his supervising eye before. Tokugawa lingers before you in full shogun garb, then nods his head in approval, winks, and disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: Draw Near Stop By, Send Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> is trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw near</mark> to you. You back up, but they continue to draw near anyway. Imagine being under the same roof as an odd person who's always trying to draw near to you. You don't want anything to do with them, but they won't back off.
mnemonics.reading: き よ None They continue to draw near until you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a key (き). You hold the key tightly in your hand and press your ear to the door. You can still hear the odd person drawing near. Hopefully this key keeps them away.

mnemonics.meaning: Dry In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nose</mark> to make it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry</mark>. Don't worry, there aren't bullets in the gun. It's an air gun! So just imagine shooting the air into your nose every morning to make sure it's nice and dry.
mnemonics.reading: かん かわ, ほ None This technique for a nice dry nose was invented by Genghis Khan (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem. Now the next time you manage to get your nose nice and dry, think back to our founding father Genghis Khan and thank him for where you are today.

mnemonics.meaning: Europe A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s things will be in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Europe</mark>. Picture a map of Europe in your mind. Now picture little words saying which district is lacking what. This one is lacking water. That one is lacking food.
mnemonics.reading: おう None None Europe is lacking so much because their 王 (おう) keeps taking everything. Okay, so maybe this is an old view of Europe. But back in the old days the 王s there would take everything from their subjects, so every district would lack something. Good thing things aren't that way now, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Fear A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">saw</mark> cuts into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and you are filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fear</mark>. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever. Try and imagine this saw slicing into your heart. Are you filled with fear? You should be.
mnemonics.reading: きょう おそ, こわ None Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in きょうと. You always wanted to take a trip to きょうと, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go. I fear you’ll never make it to きょうと. Think of きょうと and how you long for it as you slowly die from that saw wound to the heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Fierce An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> eats a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> in a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fierce</mark> manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style. See the fierce animal fiercely eating the child from the plate. It’s very gruesome. See blood and body parts flying everywhere as the animal devours the child.
mnemonics.reading: もう たけ None The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him. That child really shouldn’t have forgotten to mow the lawn. Imagine you are the child, being eaten by the fierce animal and wishing that you would have just mowed the lawn like you said you would.

mnemonics.meaning: Inlet Bay A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rolls in and destroys all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> that was being done on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inlet</mark> and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bay</mark>. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer. Picture all the construction on the bay and the inlet getting destroyed by the tsunami. Look at all of it fall apart and crash to the ground as the tsunami knocks it down. Imagine yourself right near the action, feeling the water spray from the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: こう え None Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!” EH? A tsunami you say? Those construction areas are screwed, man. Again, imagine the tsunami demolishing the area. Then be all like, “Eh? A tsunami? Aw, man.”

mnemonics.meaning: Korea In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> will still be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Korea</mark>. Picture Korea first thing in the morning. You can see all the cities, the countryside, everything waking up.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None You know who was a big fan of Korea? Genghis Khan (かん). He liked Korea so much that he totally ignored it while he was subjugating the crap out of the rest of Asia. Sadly for Korea, the later Khans wouldn't be quite as kind (looking at you, Ögedei, Güyük, and Möngke). They liked Korea too, but they showed their love a little more… aggressively.

mnemonics.meaning: Male Manly, Brave The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> is meeting in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> so they can, uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">male</mark>! You gotta be pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manly</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brave</mark> to do something like that. Picture a male narwhal and a male turkey meeting together in private. Whispering. Giggling. Pointing at each other's male bits, each admiring how manly and brave the other is.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう おす, お None These male animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be youths (ゆう)! To be a youth, again! It's just nature. Youths like to learn and try new things. And if two male youth animals wanna get together in private that's their business.

mnemonics.meaning: Mysterious The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mysterious</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading:
げん くろ None There is no one more mysterious than Genji (げん). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... 〜mysterious〜! Who's the mysterious man who's always reciting poetry? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man who gets all the ladies? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man crying over there because someone turned him down? G... Genji...

mnemonics.meaning: Navigation On every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> that's used for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">navigation</mark>. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools. You forget to put the lid back on the navigation station and all those tools and boat pieces go flying around the boat and into the water. Oops.
mnemonics.reading: こう None わたる You watch the navigation equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands こういち, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff! Picture this seafaring こういち angrily chasing you around the ruined navigation station, trying to hit you with a telescope.

mnemonics.meaning: Oversee Surveillance To the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> you say: "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>." It is your job to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oversee</mark> everything they do. You point to the gun. You point to the ground (that's where the gun goes). You point to the plate (you want it). You have to oversee everything the servant does.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None Why must you oversee everything? Because you are Genghis Khan (かん), and Genghis Khan oversees everything. If anyone had to oversee a lot, it was Genghis Khan, who had one of the largest kingdoms in all of history.

mnemonics.meaning: Recommend There’s an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> and you do everything in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recommend</mark> that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird. You can’t recommend this turkey. It’s probably dangerous. Imagine sending this turkey back in a restaurant, very upset with everything. Also keep in mind that the arrow is half buried in the turkey and looks a little broken since the arrow radical is a bit off.
mnemonics.reading: かん すす None You recommend the Genghis Khan (かん) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it. Welp, I guess if Genghis Khan recommends eating food with weapons still in them, you're okay with recommending it too. Eat up, everyone.

mnemonics.meaning: Religion Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">religion</mark> into people. It's a religion building. They have a lot of different names, churches, mosques, temples, cathedrals, but none of those matter. All that matters is that you really drill whichever religion you want into the heads of the people who come under your roof.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう None None Your religion requires everyone to take off their shoes (しゅう). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door. Picture the pile of shoes left outside. If you see a bunch of shoes like this you can be sure there's a religious place around here.

mnemonics.meaning: Request If what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> comes out <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>, everyone knows that means you made a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark>. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to. Picture this blue, slimy request. You could have done that thing by yourself, but you requested it of someone else, and now it's all over and everyone can see it.
mnemonics.reading: せい, しん, しょう う, こ None The next time someone requests something from you, take out your saber (せい) and slice it in half! Now they have the blue request gunk on them, and you can walk away as your already-blue sword absorbs the rest. Oh, and you don't have to fulfill the request (bonus!).

mnemonics.meaning: Scary The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> was sucked into its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, which is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scary</mark>! Watch as the narwhal's face contorts as you see its soul get slurped out by the towel it was using.
mnemonics.reading: ふ こわ None As you watch this scary scene you can't help but mutter, "Fool," (ふ) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting. You don't know what's more scary. That the narwhal's soul got sucked out, or that all of its kind is calling it a fool now that it's dead.

mnemonics.meaning: Search There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> attached to it, forcing you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">search</mark> where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on. It hurts to have this cross stuck in your forehead, but try to ignore that as you search for where the thread leads. Imagine gathering the thread in your hands as you move along.
mnemonics.reading: さく None None Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?! Why are there more crosses and threads in the sack? Are you supposed to take them from the sack and throw them at other people’s foreheads? Maybe. Imagine yourself reaching into the sack and throwing the crosses at other people.

mnemonics.meaning: Servant Retainer The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">servant</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">retainer</mark> and you’ll be fine. Retainer and servant are basically the same thing, so remembering this one shouldn’t be too hard for you.
mnemonics.reading: しん, じん None None Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants. Imagine your servant banging his shins on everything in your house. Hand him a pair of jeans and tell him to put them on to soften the blows.

mnemonics.meaning: Sponsor The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>s is our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sponsor</mark>. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading. This message is brought to you by our generous sponsor, the leader of the mountain turkeys. Long may he reign.
mnemonics.reading: さい もよお None This same sponsor is also how you made your cyborg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments. Turn your cyborg over and you'll see a stamp under one of its feet. It says, "Sponsored by" with a little picture of a turkey on top a mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: Streets City If <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> is all you see as you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> from place to place, you must be roaming the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">streets</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">city</mark>. Cities are notoriously dirty places, so watch your step when you head out into the streets. Imagine yourself caked in dirt as you make your way through this urban jungle — someone really needs to clean up these streets!
mnemonics.reading: がい, かい まち None As you roam the streets, brushing the dirt off yourself, a guy (がい) bumps into you: "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Whoa there, guy — you think you own these streets or somethin'?" "As a matter of fact, my guy, I run these streets, so you'd better check yourself." These two guys seem like they might be wise guys, so you hightail it out of there. You don't want to be another victim to the streets.

mnemonics.meaning: Stuffed <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> to one person enough and they'll be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stuffed</mark> full of that luck. Better safe than sorry. Don't just say good luck once, make sure they're stuffed!
mnemonics.reading: きつ, きち つ, づ None You stuffed them by saying good luck two (つ) whole times! Picture a person with the actual words "good luck" stuffed into their body.

mnemonics.meaning: Tense The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> sits on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, holding a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, looking very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tense</mark>. You walk by this tense servant and pause for a moment. They raise their tense eyes up at you and you can see they're shaking.
mnemonics.reading: きん None None You ask the servant why they're so tense, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the King (きん) of England with this piece of thread. Imagine how tense you would be if you were about to try to murder the King! Your entire body would tense up, maybe to the point that you wouldn't be able to actually go through with it.

mnemonics.meaning: The Cabinet Cabinet At the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the cabinet</mark> members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual. Imagine kissing all the members of the cabinet. A lot of them are old men. Imagine kissing all of them at the gate. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: かく None None You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster! Imagine yourself sneaking past the cabinet members, finding your cock, grabbing it, and getting out of there. You’ve recovered your rooster! The day is won.

mnemonics.meaning: Urge Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> sees your bare <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urge</mark>s you to put a sock on it. Imagine your leader's face when he sees your bare foot, and just how emphatic he is as he urges you to put a sock on it. He's really worried your foot's going to get cold!
mnemonics.reading: そく うなが None As urged, you put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock. Feel this sock on your foot. It feels great. Wiggle your toes around inside the sock as you think about how glad you are that you did as your leader urged. Note that this kanji also has the same reading as 足, so keep that in mind too!

mnemonics.meaning: Violent Intense When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s, you know something very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violent</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intense</mark> is about to happen. The yakuza member is so upset his knife boils. Right after, they will definitely get violent and intense.
mnemonics.reading: れつ はげ None When someone gets violent or intense, they always yell "Let's (れつ) get violent and intense!" In the case of our mnemonic, it's a yakuza member getting violent. So, imagine a yakuza member saying "Ret's get violent!" before doing just that.

mnemonics.meaning: Alluring A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> is pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alluring</mark>. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring. See this demon flying around in his jet. Do you feel allured? You should. Hear the roar of the jet engine as the demon cackles.
mnemonics.reading: み None None This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat. The demon won’t be so alluring once you see him scarfing down humans, tearing the meat from their bones. How gross.

mnemonics.meaning: Back Height You fly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">north</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and break your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">back</mark> when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact. Imagine flying north to the moon. Feel the force of being rocketed through space on your journey. Now feel your spine telescope and your back break. It really hurts.
mnemonics.reading:
はい せ, そむ None Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form. I flew to the moon.
It is there I broke my back.
My back hurts real bad. Say this haiku out loud. Memorize it and use this haiku to remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Boisterous A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> gets trapped in a small room with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, and together they create a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boisterous</mark> situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place. Imagine the boisterous sounds coming from this small room. Hear the horse neigh and stomp his hooves, hear the insect buzzing loudly, and hear the wooden stool rattle around as the horse and insect try to escape the room.
mnemonics.reading: そう さわ None At the height of their boisterous sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the soul (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling. The horse gets even more frightened now that it killed the insect and saw an actual soul float by its head and it grows even more boisterous.

mnemonics.meaning: Decorate When you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> you want to see the shape of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> from under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decorate</mark> your house with them. Just picture it: an entire home decorated top to bottom with guns covered in towels, so only the outline shows. As your guests try to eat you say, "Guess what gun this is?! Haha, you got it wrong, pull the towel back."
mnemonics.reading: しょく かざ None If you actually decorate your house like this it will give people quite a shock (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming. Maybe you should be more conscious of other people when you decorate. Or at least, don't shock people into fainting or yelling or leaving. Guns do that, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Deposit <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Beforehand</mark>, to buy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, you have to go to the bank to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deposit</mark> enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy one! They're expensive, after all. Imagine yourself depositing your money beforehand. Imagine the delicious geoduck you'll be able to buy now that the money has been deposited into your account.
mnemonics.reading: よ あず None You go to the bank to make the deposit, and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo. Now you can't even see, let alone make the deposit. Imagine trying to make a deposit to your bank after getting hit in the face with a yo-yo. You can hardly see what you're shoving your money into. Just hope it isn't the hands of the kid that hit you.

mnemonics.meaning: Dry Up Thirst A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, where you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> trying to catch some of it before it starts to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry up</mark>. Being in prison on the sun means your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thirst</mark> is truly great, and this spoon will help you quench it when the tsunami comes. Imagine the feeling of drinking spoon after spoon of refreshing tsunami water, how it replenishes your dried up body. You've been in this sun prison for so long, holding onto this spoon and waiting for this moment. Better take advantage of it — even a tsunami will dry up real quick on the sun.
mnemonics.reading: かつ かわ None This method of quenching your thirst reminds you of being in a car wash (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right? Imagine quenching your thirst in a real car wash. Open your mouth and let the soapy water dump on over and in you. You'll never be thirsty again!

mnemonics.meaning: Edition If you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one-sided</mark> paper <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> (someone against one-sided paper), then you should bind all those one-sided papers into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edition</mark>. One-sided paper is just anti-everything. It's bad for the environment. It's bad for easy reading. Put all those one-sided papers together into one, big edition instead.
mnemonics.reading: はん None None The first edition you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of Han (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one-sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore! Please read my super special Han Solo edition of the Star Wars story. I ripped out all the one-sided pages that had him in it and put them into a single edition together so it's just the good stuff now.

mnemonics.meaning: Fence You've made yourself a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> (that is, a bookshelf cut into a tree), so you build a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fence</mark> to keep the riffraff out. Your tree bookshelf is often being raided by the neighbors, and since it's outside, all you can do is build a fence around it to protect it. Better check out that fence-building book in your tree bookshelf.
mnemonics.reading: さく しがらみ None On your fence, you hang up a sack (さく) to accept donations. People put money and books in your fence sack to keep your tree bookshelf well stocked.

mnemonics.meaning: Flag Traveling in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of the ocean, you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and shoot a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark>, then stick a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flag</mark> in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to. Look at your flag and hear it flapping in the wind. Also hear your ears ringing a bit from when you shot that crab. Look at all the bits of exploded crab strewn around the area. Yowza.
mnemonics.reading: き はた None To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it. Picture yourself locking this flag up with your key. Imagine turning the key in the lock and hearing the click when it is secured.

mnemonics.meaning: Float A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> knocks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> and the shoe begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">float</mark> away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami. Your cleat is floating away but you’re floating too. The water is really deep now, but you try and float towards your cleat to retrieve it. Imagine floating in this wet water reaching for your lost cleat.
mnemonics.reading: ふ う, うわ None While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~” Say “Uwaaa~” out loud a few times while you imagine an うに stabbing you as you float along with the tsunami water. What a day you’ve had.

mnemonics.meaning: Go Beyond You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> every day and soon you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a human that can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">go beyond</mark> the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast. Run fast! Go beyond the limits imposed upon you by nature! Imagine yourself running faster than any human has ever run ever. Feel yourself cutting through the air, wind breaking across you as you break the sound barrier. Boom!
mnemonics.reading: えつ こ None To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate. Etch these runes into your legs. Go ahead and run a finger over your legs and pretend to etch runes into them. These runes you etch will allow you to run fast forever.

mnemonics.meaning: Illuminate The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>ed on to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> the earth by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">illuminating</mark> it. We don't want the earth to actually boil, but we do want some of that boiling hot sun light to illuminate all of the darkness of the universe and let us see.
mnemonics.reading: しょう て None The person who calls the sun asking it to illuminate the earth is the Shougun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning. Picture the Shougun calling out to the sun, asking it to illuminate our planet with its boiling hot rays. You better thank the Shougun the next time you see him for everything he does for you.

mnemonics.meaning: Leak A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rips a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> off your house in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>, causing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leak</mark> where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home. Look at this leak in your house and see the rain water coming in. Hear it drip drip dripping down the wall.
mnemonics.reading: ろう も None The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm! Did you know that roe can plug any leak? It’s true. If you don’t mind wasting some, you should break a leak into your own house and then try to plug it back up again with some salmon roe.

mnemonics.meaning: Lineage System The lineage radical and the lineage kanji are the same. Sometimes this kanji can also mean system. I guess a lineage is a kind of system, if you think about it. Basically, think of 系 as linking things that belong together in some kind of group. Lineages, solar systems, genres, styles… Anything along those lines.
mnemonics.reading: けい None None You trace your lineage back through your whole family system and realize every single relative loved cake (けい). Most of them were cake bakers too! You come from a lineage of cake makers and eaters. No wonder you love cake so much! (And if you hate cake, no wonder your family doesn't like you.)

mnemonics.meaning: Look At A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> sits on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> if he can find something to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look at</mark>. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers. Look at this servant. He’s doing a great job. Oops, looks like he sees you. Yup, he’s pointing his gun at you. Imagine staring down the barrel of his gun as you slowly back away.
mnemonics.reading: らん None None You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him. Pretend you are Macho Man Randy Savage. Run at this servant guy, take his gun away, and beat him up. Ohhh yeaaahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: Marriage You meet a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> from another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> under the rising <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to prepare for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">marriage</mark>. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together. Marriage is a big deal and it's going to connect your two clans, so you have to do the ceremony in the sun in front of everyone so they can see.
mnemonics.reading: こん None None For the marriage to be official, you need to wait for a condor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman. Do you want to go through with this marriage? You better hope you see a condor then! It's the official bird of love and unification, ya know. That's why so many people wait until they're older to get married these days, because there aren't as many condors thanks to deforestation.

mnemonics.meaning: Niece Who is this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark>?! It's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">niece</mark>! Who else would it be but your niece? In fact, all of your nieces are actually moles! Picture what your family gatherings would look like with all those mole-nieces. Quite terrifying, really…
mnemonics.reading: None めい None Not only are they moles, all of your nieces were also born in May (めい)! Picture your many nieces, all moles, and all born in the same month of May. Every year, like clockwork, a new mole-niece is born into your family in May.

mnemonics.meaning: Nostalgia Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> through your body and into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> so that you'll be hit with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nostalgia</mark> when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes. When you put on an old piece of clothing, a shirt maybe, or some pants, feel the nostalgia that was embedded in it and left there by your soul.
mnemonics.reading: かい なつ, ふところ None This nostalgia ties knots (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides. Feel these nostalgic knots inside you. Now tie knots in the clothes that make you feel nostalgic so you don't wear them again.

mnemonics.meaning: Photograph Photo Point some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and put some others in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> as you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> — now you can have your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">photograph</mark> taken. This is a glamour <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">photo</mark>, so you have to be in one of these weird, artsy poses for it to come out juuust right. Which fingers do you point at the sun, and which do you put in your ear? Act it out, that'll help you remember. Now try to relax on the stool and smile for the camera. This is a professional photograph, so you better do what you're told!
mnemonics.reading: さつ と None As you're getting the photograph taken, the photographer tells you to say Satsuki (さつ). He says it's like saying cheese but more effective. Satsuki! Go ahead and say Satsuki out loud, all happy-like. Makes a pretty big smile, right? From now on you should always say Satsuki when you're being photographed.

mnemonics.meaning: Pillow The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pirate</mark> jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pillow</mark>. It hurts a little bit, but the fact that tree pirates use pillows as their weapons is a bit anticlimactic.
mnemonics.reading: None まくら None As he hits you with his pillow he makes a demand: "Give me your Mac cooler (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer. You give him your Mac cooler and he goes on his way. He's quite happy he can cool down his Mac, now. The trees are quite warm and he hears this will help to cool down his tree apples.

mnemonics.meaning: Play On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> running in one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>-toting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark>. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play</mark>. Imagine a child riding a scooter with a gun having a good time. "Come play with me!" they shout. "No!" you yell back.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう あそ None Everything is play for youths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one. Imagine trying to explain to the youth that this is not play and that they should stop, but them youths can't stop playing. P.S. From the WaniKani staff to you: Don't let youths play with guns, please.

mnemonics.meaning: Pleasant The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark> that can make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasant</mark>. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body? Imagine that feeling you get when everything is just SO pleasant. There is a pressure from your soul's hook digging in. It's a good feeling though, a pleasant one! It isn't too hard or too soft.
mnemonics.reading: かい こころよ None If you want to feel this pleasant feeling just look at a kayak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now. Go look up pictures of kayaks to get some of that pleasant high. Mm, your soul is hooking you real good.

mnemonics.meaning: Poor Those that can only eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are probably a bit <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poor</mark>. Poor people can't even afford a whole shellfish. They have to settle with just a part.
mnemonics.reading: びん, ひん まず None And since they are poor, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash bin (びん). It's quite unfortunate. Imagine a poor person going through a garbage bin to find only a part of of a shellfish. What a sad sight.

mnemonics.meaning: Prolong If you do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>ly, you will not only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prolong</mark> your body but your life! Do you want to prolong your life? Then do yoga correctly!
mnemonics.reading: えん の None You can prolong your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just end (えん) suddenly. Correct yoga will prolong your life but no yoga will end it. Do you think that's a fair trade?

mnemonics.meaning: Purchase You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purchase</mark> their services. You think lifeguards are interested in normal money? Come on, they're obviously out there using shellfish for their purchases. It's only natural, given their seaside habitat. Imagine the grooved surface of a shellfish shell as you press it into the hand of a lifeguard. Congrats, you've just completed a purchase. Uh… what'd you get?
mnemonics.reading: こう None None This time you purchase some こういち goods. You know, since you're such a fan. How else can you show love in this world, if not through purchases? The lifeguard hands over a little haul of こういち plushies and figurines. Nice. And it's totally because those こういち goods are so valuable that the lifeguard accepts shellfish for them. Has nothing to do with the fact he couldn't get real money for them, okay? Hint: When you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: Push Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, put them on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">push</mark> push push!
