Push the turtle right on out of there. Picture yourself using your fingers to push a turtle out of its shell. It really doesn't want to leave, so you have to push really hard.
mnemonics.reading: おう お None You're trying to push this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new obi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first. Imagine pushing some turtle shells flat to make a beautiful obi. Wear it out, watch everyone gasp in awe. Oh... oh no! They're trying to push you out of your obi like you did the turtle. They're mad about your turtle crime!

mnemonics.meaning: Scarce If you look for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> among the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark> you will notice they are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scarce</mark>. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills. Imagine being on the hills. You want a leaf to find and take back as a souvenir but there are none. Imagine looking feverishly for a leaf even though you don’t really expect to find one.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう とぼ None Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant bowling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree. Leaves are scarce here because someone is using these hills for their bowling. The bowling balls knock over everything, and leaves can't grow.

mnemonics.meaning: Smell Scent You're stuck in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smell</mark> in here is so bad you’re using the prison spoon to waft it outside as best you can. It smells awful in this prison. You have to act fast with your prison spoon to get rid of all the bad smells!
mnemonics.reading: None にお None You can’t believe how awful these smells are. You’re new in prison, so you call them all neo-smells (にお). They're neo, they're new to you. Try to come up with some neo-smells right now. There’s the neo-food smell (prison cafeteria pizza, maybe) and the neo-laundry smell of course (your prison uniform). Can you think of any other neo-smells?

mnemonics.meaning: Steal The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> is the one you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steal</mark>. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one. Wait for this next plate. Here it is—now steal it! Imagine stealing this plate and making off with it.
mnemonics.reading: とう ぬす None You steal this plate from a とうきょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers. Be careful not to drop that plate! Wouldn’t want to steal something just to break it. Imagine running through the streets of とうきょう. See all the sights and hear all the sounds. Just don’t get too distracted, you gotta get to a safe place and stash your stolen plate away.

mnemonics.meaning: Suitable A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark>, now that's the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suitable</mark> hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter! You keep seeing scooters all over the city with mohawks and you can't get it out of your head that it's the most suitable thing you've ever seen.
mnemonics.reading: てき None None You want this suitable hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a techie (てき), so it's easy for you to install one. Imagine going online to check out some of your techie message boards and learning the most suitable mohawk for your scooter then installing it yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: The Next The Following Whenever all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> start <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing, you know it's time for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the next</mark> day. Once the day comes to its end, all feathers start standing up like clockwork. Imagine every single feather simultaneously standing up once the next day gets closer. It's like some kind of ritual that's repeated at the end of every single day. Must be stressful to be a feathered animal!
mnemonics.reading: よく None None With the next day approaching and all feathers standing up, you get ready to drink your usual liter of yolk (よく). Yes, you heard that right. Imagine having to drink an entire liter of egg yolk at the end of each day. Just like the feathers have their ritual of standing up, you have your own ritual of downing a liter of egg yolk. Just don't ask questions.

mnemonics.meaning: Token You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark> it together into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">token</mark> of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship. Imagine trying to attach some bamboo together into a token for someone.
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None You hand over the token but your friend drops it and yells, "You fool (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!" Imagine the embarrassment you feel, forgetting they were allergic to bamboo. Oh well, it’s the thought that counts. You’re still a fool, though.

mnemonics.meaning: Wet Damp If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits, it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>ing, and you're outside trying to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark>, you're going to be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wet</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damp</mark>. Imagine how wet and damp you'd be with tsunami water up to your knees and rain pouring down on your head. You struggle with your rake anyway.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ ぬ None You can't stand how wet and damp you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the nude (ぬ)! You're still wet, but at least you don't have the feeling of damp clothes touching your body now. You'll have to be really careful raking in the nude though.

mnemonics.meaning: Belt There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> coming out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> that you want to climb, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> needs a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belt</mark> and tie it around your forehead. The belt is easy to tighten and it catches all the sweat before it can fall into your eyes. It isn't quite as absorbent as a towel though.
mnemonics.reading: たい おび None The belt isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your tie (たい) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again. It works! Your belt tied in a tie is the perfect invention!

mnemonics.meaning: Corridor The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guy</mark> is a guy who stands in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">corridor</mark> trying to sell people canopies. You walk through this corridor every day, and the canopy guy always accosts you with canopy sales. You wish there was another corridor you could take, but it's the only way to get where you want to go.
mnemonics.reading: ろう None None You take the corridor, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you roe (ろう). The roe salesman in the corridor is worse than the canopy salesman. They're both insistent, but the roe salesman smells bad.

mnemonics.meaning: Detach The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rocket</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> has several points which will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detach</mark> during takeoff. Imagine the rocket turkey taking off. Just like a regular rocket, as it goes up, used pieces of the turkey rocket detach and fall back to the ground.
mnemonics.reading: り はな None When the rocket turkey parts detach, they fall to the ground onto a bed of reeds (り). The reeds catch on fire - probably best not to fire off turkey rockets so close to these fields of reeds. Imagine the launch site completely surrounded by reeds.

mnemonics.meaning: Diameter You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> to measure its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diameter</mark>. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone. Imagine loitering around a tombstone. You're leaning on it. You're staring at nothing. Oh, and you're also measuring its diameter.
mnemonics.reading: けい None None You need to know the diameter of each tombstone so you can make cakes (けい) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground. These carefully measured tombstone-diameter cakes are your special way of saying thanks to the ghosts for letting you loiter around their graves.

mnemonics.meaning: Dissolve You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bully</mark> take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dissolve</mark> it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature. Actually... try to forget this one. Don't think about a bully dissolving things in acid. Think happy thoughts. Like... the bully getting dissolved instead and all the little insects coming back to life and being happy.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう None None The only bullies heartless enough to dissolve insects like this are youths (ゆう). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel. When you first read this and you pictured the bully dissolving the insect, you pictured them as a youth, right? See? It makes complete sense.

mnemonics.meaning: Equal You have some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> that has an extra <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water in it because you need them to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equal</mark>. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that. Imagine seeing a pool that isn't equal. It's like a tiny kiddy pool with an inch of water. And it's surrounded by mounds of dirt. No no no, this won't do—add more water to make them equal.
mnemonics.reading: きん ひと None You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly equal, not for yourself, but because the King (きん) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him. Okay, so the existence of a king kind of makes things not, well, equal, for all people. But at least aesthetically everything will be!

mnemonics.meaning: Exceptional You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on a dish you're cooking, made up of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>. This is truly an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exceptional</mark> dish you are cooking up. Mix those pig mouths and foreheads in your pot. Think of how exceptional your soup looks.
mnemonics.reading: ごう None None Exceptional pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa ごういち. You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves. "Can I have some of your exceptional soup?" Grandpa ごういち asks. "It smells so swell."

mnemonics.meaning: Exclude Remove The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s are at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark>. Because of that, we will need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exclude</mark> some of them from our future plans. Also, we'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remove</mark> some buildings too. Say you're looking at a map of the city, with all the buildings laid out on it. There are too many, so you start marking which ones to exclude from the building plans. You also remove some buildings from the map all together.
mnemonics.reading: じょ, じ のぞ None Working with you on this project to exclude buildings from the plan, as well as remove buildings that already exist is little Jo-Anne (じょ). She's pointing out buildings to exclude / remove with great ferocity. "Remove this one. Exclude this one. Oh, and remove this one too."

mnemonics.meaning: Freight You want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">freight</mark> so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers. Imagine changing your shellfish from loose, wet form, to solid freight form. It's actually a lot of hard work.
mnemonics.reading: か None None To move this freight, you need a car (か). You strap all of the freight containers to the top of your car, stacked nice and high and precarious, so you can move it. Picture all of this freight stacked on top of your car. As you drive the car, every turn you make feels slow and heavy from the freight weight.

mnemonics.meaning: Grandchild A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> shares his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grandchild</mark>. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared. Look at this family tree. See the child, and then the grandchild. Trace the lineage with your finger as you observe.
mnemonics.reading: そん まご None The son (そん) of a son is a grandchild. In this case, a grandson. Easy. Just remember that a son is all you really want. You need a son to carry on the family name and the lineage. So make sure that your child and your grandchild are both sons.

mnemonics.meaning: Grave Tomb Inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> there's a mound of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> which appears to be someone's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grave</mark>. When you dig into it, you discover that it's an entire <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>, with doors and passages and everything! Why would someone put a grave in a greenhouse? Is this one of those "green burials" everyone's talking about these days? Having the whole tomb complex seems a tad counterproductive, though…
mnemonics.reading: ぼ はか None You pry open the grave inside the inner chamber of the tomb, and are shocked to find the mummified body of Bobo (ぼ) the Clown staring back at you! How terrifying! You watch in horror as Bobo raises his arms and slowly rises from his grave. "At last, I have awoken from my slumber… Prepare yourselves, mortals — Bobo's taking reservations for birthday parties again!"

mnemonics.meaning: How Many How Much You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> twice on a sleeping <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> and you find yourself wondering <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">how many</mark> more times you can poop on them and wonder <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">how much</mark> they can take before they realize what’s going on. You’ve already pooped twice on this drunkard, how many more times can you do it? How much do you think this person can take? Just imagine yourself doing this.
mnemonics.reading: き いく None As you continue thinking about how much poop this drunkard can take and how many more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you eke (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape. Imagine yourself as you eke out that last poop. Really concentrate on eking it out so you can get away in time. Flex your butt muscles for added effect.

mnemonics.meaning: Inquire <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> job and using his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s, so he knows how many folks he needs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inquire</mark> with about helping him. Using the mouth is a strange way to take measurements, but that's just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he'll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire with about working for him. Imagine Wolverine going around, measuring the construction site with his mouth. Look at him with his mouth wide open, wandering around the site deep in thought. What a weirdo.
mnemonics.reading: じん たず, ひろ None Another thing Wolverine has to inquire about is jeans (じん). He wants to make sure everyone on the construction site has good-fitting jeans to work in, so he inquires with them about their jean measurements. Imagine Wolverine handing you some new jeans at the construction site. Um, they're kind of all ripped up? Turns out that's just the style he likes. You'll be so fashionable now! Just like good old '90s Wolvie.

mnemonics.meaning: Knit Bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">knit</mark>. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now. Picture yourself sitting on a rocking chair in the library knitting away. It's quiet and peaceful and the light is warming you just right. Ahh, bliss!
mnemonics.reading: へん あ None You need to come to the library to knit because if you try to do it at home all your hens (へん) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit. Imagine the granny or grampy you are (and must be to have hens and want to knit in peace in a library). You're tired of these hens eating your thread while you try to knit sweaters for all your grandbabies so you come to the library.

mnemonics.meaning: Land A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> made from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> must be placed upon the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">land</mark>. Why must it be placed upon the land? If it were put in water, it would dissolve too quickly. So, you put your womb building on the land, instead.
mnemonics.reading: りく None None The land around your womb building will, unfortunately, reek (りく) though. It's made of biological materials, so of course it will reek.

mnemonics.meaning: Look For Search For Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> and stand your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> high up in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look for</mark> something. After all, shielding your eyes and getting up high is the best way to look for something, isn’t it? Imagine it's like a quest from a book or game. What are you looking for? Maybe a powerful sword, or a lost princess. Picture it in your mind, this thing you're looking for.
mnemonics.reading: たん さが, さぐ None You look for it for so long that you can't help getting a tan (たん). I mean, you're up some tree, shielding your eyes from the sun as you look for that thing, and it's been hours, days? Of course you're going to get a tan. Feel the sun's rays on your skin as you search and search and search. Watch as your skin gets darker, crispier, and — hmm — starts smelling like cooked meat. Now that's a good tan.

mnemonics.meaning: Model Take Into Account See that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> man <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark>ing everyone? He's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">model</mark> human. His goldenness is a sign of how exemplary he is, and he's overseeing all of us flawed, regular folks to try to help us get on his level. Imagine this golden man standing on a raised platform, looking down at you judgmentally with his arms crossed. You mutter curses at him under your breath, but really you're just jealous you're not a model human like him.
mnemonics.reading: かん かんが, かがみ None As you look closer at the golden model human, you realize he's actually Genghis Khan (かん)! No wonder he's covered in gold and overseeing everyone — he's the greatest conqueror in history! Hold on a sec — didn't Genghis Khan kill a bunch of people and father like a thousand kids? He doesn't seem like such a model person to you, but, hey, you don't make the rules around here — Genghis Khan does.

mnemonics.meaning: Mud A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> came in and buried your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> so now you have to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> and dig it out of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mud</mark>. Imagine using a spoon to dig your flag outta all this mud. So much mud! Feel its cold, soiled wetness on your hands as you dig away.
mnemonics.reading: でい どろ None You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, muddy brother, Doro (どろ)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud. Imagine them working together — Dora and Doro, the Muddy Explorers! Who knows why she's able to stay clean, while Doro gets so muddy…

mnemonics.meaning: Nest Birds use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> to make their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nest</mark>s. Picture a cute little nest with a family of birds in it. It looks like it was woven together with bits of grass and strawberries, so it smells delicious too.
mnemonics.reading: そう す None The bottom of the nest also seems to be padded with someone's suit (す). Did... did this bird attack a human for this?! Picture the nest, made of grass, fruit, and the suit of the angry salaryman who's shouting below the tree, and missing the top half of his suit.

mnemonics.meaning: Normal You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">line up</mark> your body with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and everything looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">normal</mark>.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal. Gaze out in a line from the sun as you observe the world. Everything is very normal looking and comforting.
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None Soon you see something that doesn’t look so normal. It’s a fool (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face. Imagine this creepy looking fool as he approaches. He’s kind of freaking you out. Feel very uncomfortable as you continue looking at this fool.

mnemonics.meaning: Obstruct Impede A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> will have things <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obstruct</mark> her path. It's a sad fact that it's still a man's world out there! Picture this woman with direction, knocking down obstruction after obstruction on her path to success.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう さまた None This woman is truly magnificent. Some compare her to a bowling (ぼう) ball, because of how she knocks down the obstructions in her path like bowling pins. Now imagine that she actually is a bowling ball. Watch her roll down the bowling lane and smash all those stupid pins!

mnemonics.meaning: Pole Rod, Stick A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> that's nice and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> will make a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pole</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rod</mark>. Break it out of the ground and give it a swing to see what a nice, sturdy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stick</mark> it is! Use this pole to hang your towels or curtains. Ooh, use it to pole vault!
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None After much deliberation, you decide to use this pole to go bowling (ぼう). It's a pretty long pole, so you can just stand at the top of the lane and directly poke the bowling pins with it. Imagine all the irritated glares you get as you use your pole to cheat your way through several games of bowling. That's against the rules, buddy!

mnemonics.meaning: Powder If you grind <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of it, eventually it will become a fine <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">powder</mark>. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps. Imagine yourself grinding this rice into a powder. Hear the scrape of the rice on stone as you grind it down to the finest powder.
mnemonics.reading: ふん こな, こ None Actually, grinding the rice down to a powder is super fun (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN! Okay, we got a little carried away there. Just keep in mind how fun this is. Make sure you say fun with a little bit of a Scottish accent. You know what they say, Scots have more fun!

mnemonics.meaning: Previously There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> where your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previously</mark> was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out. Look at the root where your fang previously was. Previously, when you were young, you had a lot of nice fangs but they're all rotting as you get older and you pull them out.
mnemonics.reading: き すで None To remember the beautiful fangs you previously had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a key (き). Previously you didn't have a key, but now you do to keep your old fangs safe.

mnemonics.meaning: Rescue You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">request</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rescue</mark> you from the warmth of the other seasons. It's so hot. You hate it. You really hope winter will get your request and come early to rescue you.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう すく None You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have rescued you with this cucumber (きゅう)." A cucumber falls out of the note. This cucumber is supposed to be cool and refreshing enough to rescue you from the heat. I guess it was too much to expect winter to come early just for you. At least cucumbers are yummy.

mnemonics.meaning: Resemble A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of (odd-looking) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark>s puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of magic liquid on his face to look like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> who <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resemble</mark>s someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms. Watch this leader as the transformation takes place. Now he doesn’t resemble anything like the leader he used to be. He doesn’t look like the same person. Watch him morph in your head.
mnemonics.reading: じ に None Now he resembles an even greater leader, and all the lions get down on one knee (に) to pay their respects. (Note that we recently changed this kanji's main reading from ね to に, because ね is an irregular reading.) See all the odd-looking lions respectfully getting down on one knee? They look even odder now.

mnemonics.meaning: Rich On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark> because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rich</mark>. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof. Imagine looking up at the roof at this scarecrow. There's a sign around its neck that says, "Rich people welcome." Ah, you're safe. Time to go to bed!
mnemonics.reading: ふ と, とみ None You wake up the next morning and all of your riches have been stolen! You call the police and they call you a fool (ふ)! Pardon me?! "You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool." You poor sad, no longer rich fool.

mnemonics.meaning: Scatter If you play <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, your cards will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scatter</mark> everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster. Imagine playing blackjack on the moon where even the slightest move causes the cards to scatter about. Watch them float along. It’s very frustrating to play this way.
mnemonics.reading: さん ち None You are playing blackjack with Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the scatter of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san. Imagine yourself next to Santa-san as he tries to prevent the cards from scattering. Look at the expression of concentration on Santa-san’s face as he tries to prevent the scatter.

mnemonics.meaning: Showy Flower, Gorgeous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> into the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> are really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">showy</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower</mark>s. Picture these showy flowers growing straight up and out of the middle of the rice paddy, into the shape of a giant cross.
mnemonics.reading: か はな None These flowers are too showy. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your car (か)! Imagine how the car feels as you ram into the showy flowers. The petals explode and rain everywhere. You turn on your windshield wipers to push them away.

mnemonics.meaning: Sigh You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> when you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Chinese</mark> person and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sigh</mark>. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia. Let out a long sigh as you recall memories from China and all the Chinese things you saw and did. Oh, sigh.
mnemonics.reading: たん なげ None Your favorite Chinese thing to do is tan (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will sigh or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on. Sigh again as you remember how nice it was to tan everywhere. Picture yourself wandering around some Chinese streets with your shirt off as you soak in the rays and get a tan.

mnemonics.meaning: Spy Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> sticks his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. You ask him why and he says he wants to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spy</mark> on it. There’s a hidden camera on his toe and the leader wants to have plenty of secret spy footage to review later.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None You and the leader review the spy footage and find a single tater (てい) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, mussels, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world. If it wasn't for your toe spy network, these egregious tater tot crimes would have never reached the light of day.

mnemonics.meaning: Surprised If you can write an interesting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> while riding on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, I’ll be pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surprised</mark>. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself. Imagine trying to write a poem while riding a horse. It’d be really hard to do. I bet you’d be surprised if you managed to do it as well.
mnemonics.reading: きょう おどろ None You might also be surprised to learn that you are to ride this horse all across きょうと. That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse きょうと to write this poem about winter. Imagine riding through きょうと on a horse. As if that wasn’t difficult enough for poem writing, now you have all the sights and sounds of きょうと to distract you as well.

mnemonics.meaning: Sweep Using his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> wraps his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> to get ready to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweep</mark>. Sweeping floors is hard work! That's why he always puts a towel around his forehead when he sweeps up the mess he made during yet another X-Men fight. Picture Wolverine, towel around his forehead, sweeping up a bar he just had a big fight in. He's sweeping up broken bottles, broken chairs, and broken evil X-Men. (Yeah, he swept the floor with those guys.)
mnemonics.reading: そう は None Wolverine knows that sweeping is good for the soul (そう). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too! Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is like chicken soup for the soul.

mnemonics.meaning: Vegetable You want some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> so you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to the side of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> hoping they'll fall down, but you get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vegetable</mark> instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out. Now you have two vegetables and no flowers. Do vegetables even grow on trees?
mnemonics.reading: さい な None You feed these vegetables (that you didn't even want) to your cyborg (さい). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest. Picture your cyborg nibbling on the vegetables you cleat-kicked out of this tree. You give all of the things you don't like to your cyborg nowadays. Which is probably why there are so many weird things all over it...

mnemonics.meaning: Vein Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> while you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, you inject a syringe of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark> right into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vein</mark>. Ahh, tofu. You're addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein. Feel the tofu running through your veins. Feel the tofu goodness spreading all over your body. It's so intense you can even taste a little tofu in your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: みゃく None None Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every vein on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. "You cyan't myake (みゃく) me!" you slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. "None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!" Say this out loud, it'll help you remember. Really focus on the "myake" be sure to say it like you're all bugged out from tofu overdose.

mnemonics.meaning: Virtue You're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing, staring down at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> that got caught in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, because it's trying to teach you to act with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">virtue</mark>. People who keep the cross in their hearts are supposed to be full of virtue, always doing the right thing, always helping others. But you aren't sure if you want to be virtuous, it's a lot of responsibility. So you look down at this symbolic cross and loiter instead of making a decision.
mnemonics.reading: とく None None As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own. I don't know about you, but I'm pretty sure Tokugawa Ieyasu is telling you to choose a life of virtue.

mnemonics.meaning: Warehouse Storehouse The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warehouse</mark> kanji are the same! You can call it a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark> too. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: そう くら None You have a warehouse to store all of your souls (そう). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really. Imagine if you kept a bunch of souls in a warehouse. This way they can't haunt anyone. And they can't get lost out in the spirit world. The warehouse is best for them.

mnemonics.meaning: Achievement Tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to yourself whenever you take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark> for someone. This marks your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">achievement</mark>. Your achievement in blame-taking, I guess. Isn't it a great achievement to selflessly shield others from blame? Of course it is! So these little blame-threads are symbols of your achievement. Pretty soon your fingers, toes, and whole body are covered in threads, for all your innumerable achievements. Think back on those achievements, on all those times you took the blame for someone. You're just so, so selfless. What a good person you are. Ahh, it feels good to be good.
mnemonics.reading: せき None None But your latest achievement is covering yourself in these threads and everyone thinking it's sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion mags can't get enough of your sexy style. See? If you're a good person, people will think your achievements are sexy. Imagine setting this sexy thread-based fashion trend. You're named the sexiest person alive and everyone dresses like spools of thread to copy you. But the achievements to match? Well, only you have those.

mnemonics.meaning: Acid Take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> and put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> in it to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acid</mark>. Spiders have a little acid in them already, but if you want something really potent, smash one up in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that'll rip through anything. Imagine crushing up some spiders into alcohol. Watch it turn green. It's going to eat through the beaker! Quick, do something!
mnemonics.reading: さん す None You're trying to find a container for this acid when Santa-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble. It's Christmas morning. Instead of gifts, Santa-san just throws a piece of charcoal at your face. Feel the charcoal smash into your face and explode into acid, burning you. Santa-san runs away laughing. Ho ho ho!

mnemonics.meaning: Agree A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> and his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agree</mark> to share it. Picture the husbands pulling a different side of the shellfish, it pops in two, and they each get a shell. They smile and high five.
mnemonics.reading: さん None None Since the husbands were able to agree, Santa-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas. Imagine Santa-san flying over the husbands in his sleigh, raining shellfish down upon them from the sky. It warms the heart, wouldn’t you agree?

mnemonics.meaning: Ancestor You come across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and it claims to be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ancestor</mark>. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody. Imagine coming across your long dead top hatted ancestor in spirit form. What would you do? What would you say?
mnemonics.reading: そ None None You ask your ancestor what it wants and it points to the soap (そ) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap. Your ancestor didn't come here to see you, it just wanted to learn about soap. Something that they didn't have back when it was alive. That's actually kinda sad... and stinky. Your ancestor needs to use this soap, if anything.

mnemonics.meaning: Coin To use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark> you need to turn it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coin</mark>. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of the gold you have. Imagine yourself strenuously pushing a lever to flatten your gold and punch a coin out it. You sweat as you hurry to make enough coins so you can go to the bar before it closes.
mnemonics.reading: せん ぜに None You use the coin to pay a centaur (せん) at the bar. The centaur is the bartender and he makes special drinks for those who pay in gold coins. Good for you! Imagine handing this centaur bartender your gold coins. Hear him thank you in his booming voice and make you a mysterious gold-colored drink. Look in wonder at how the centaur has managed to fit in the narrow space behind the bar counter.

mnemonics.meaning: Defense If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> you'll need a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defense</mark>. Things in Korea haven't been on the safest side lately, so make sure you have some ways to defend yourself before you go.
mnemonics.reading: えい None None You need a good defense to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with acorns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe. Okay, so maybe this defense strategy will take a while, but you aren't rich and acorns are on the ground for free. Don't judge!

mnemonics.meaning: Desk A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> combines with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">desk</mark>. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk. Chop this tree into pieces to transform this table into a desk. Hear the sounds of construction in your head as you make this desk with your bare hands.
mnemonics.reading: き つくえ None When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.” Another way to remember this reading is to think about where you find lots of desks. That's right, in a school (つくえ). Just imagine someone slurring “It’s cool, eh?” While you think about how cool this desk really is. Run your hands over the finished project as you say it.

mnemonics.meaning: Dirty A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit not one, but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">TWO</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>s, making them extremely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dirty</mark>. Imagine observing the two prisons being hit by a giant wave of muddy water, making them completely dirty. How disgusting!
mnemonics.reading: お よご, きたな, けが None What's the most dirty are the prisons' obi (お) collections. You can hear the prisoners crying, "Oh, not the obi. Our obi are all dirty, oh no!" The obi were the only nice thing the prisoners had left, and now they're all dirty. Even as you leave the prisons, you can still hear their echoing cries of "Oh, not our obi!"

mnemonics.meaning: Domesticate You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> part of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">director</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">domesticate</mark> him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down. Which part of the director did you choose to eat in order to domesticate him? Think about eating that part of the director and imagine its taste in your mouth as you chew. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: し か None While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry! You’re proud that you managed to domesticate the director, but now you feel kind of bad for having injured him. Okay, you really just feel bad because he’s probably going to sue you and he definitely has a lot of money. Oh, and he’s bleeding all over your car.

mnemonics.meaning: Duplicate Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark> and a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duplicate</mark> comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange. Examine the duplicate spirit. Same ghosty body. Same ghosty glow. A perfect copy.
mnemonics.reading: ふく None None Suddenly the duplicate spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! F*** (ふく) you!" You feel pretty bad now. The duplicate spirit seems to have decided to haunt you, and it's muttering "F*** you, f*** you," over and over in your ear.

mnemonics.meaning: Dye A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> runs into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s and produces a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dye</mark> the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye. Imagine this happening in front of you. See the tsunami turn from the color of water to the color of a forest. The dye washes over you and now you’re forest green as well.
mnemonics.reading: せん しみ, そ, し None The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy. Hear each centaur shouting about how he hates that dye for changing his color. They look kind of funny, so you laugh at them a bit, but not too loud – they might hear you and get even more angry.

mnemonics.meaning: Egg Two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark>s, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">egg</mark>. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar. Separate the two pools from one another. Now the pools look like the kanji. The kanji is one white pool and one yellow pool. Neat, huh?
mnemonics.reading: らん たまご None You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg. Just think Tamagotchi whenever you see this kanji. Tamagotchi = tamago = egg. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: Eternity The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eternity</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: えい None None How long is an eternity? Just look at this little acorn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever! It's the miracle of eternal life!

mnemonics.meaning: Eyeball The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eyeball</mark>. Go ahead and feel your eyeballs moving around in your head. Your eyes aren't just the part on the surface, they're the whole balls in there, attached at the root.
mnemonics.reading: がん め None You know who has some pretty good eyeballs? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs. Look at Gandhi’s eyeball with your eyeball. It's pretty remarkable.

mnemonics.meaning: Fluid Liquid A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that hits at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">night</mark> leaves even more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fluid</mark> than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">liquid</mark>. Picture the dark fluids from the tsunami flowing by your window at night. You look out and the liquid is shining in the moonlight. It looks like an entire sea is out there!
mnemonics.reading: えき None None This fluid stays in the 駅 (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare. Picture the 駅 filled to the brim with fluids and liquids. Maybe if you swim, you'll be able to catch your train.

mnemonics.meaning: Gather Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to dig out bits of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gather</mark> them. Taking your fingers to this cleat is the only way to gather the tree bits stuck in it. Gather them in a big pile… as evidence to examine later. Picture your fingers really getting in there to gather the tree pieces from out of this cleat. Some of the tree bits are stabbing under your fingernails, but you have to keep gathering them, don't stop now!
mnemonics.reading: さい と None You gather them all together and realize there are cyborg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats. Gather all of these cyborg bits so you can put the cyborg back together later.

mnemonics.meaning: Intention Ambition If you look inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you'll discover their true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intention</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ambition</mark>s. If you're facing down a samurai, it's pretty important for you to be able to understand their intentions. Not all samurai are good, you know.
mnemonics.reading: し こころざし None You try to read the intentions of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the sheep (し) samurai! The sheep samurai only has violent intentions for other samurai and sheep. Its heart is dark and surprisingly easy to read.

mnemonics.meaning: Interest There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> and what looks like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark>, and you found them on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> you showed <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interest</mark> in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too. Pick up these fins and the two combs. Feel their weight in each hand as you examine them with interest. Smell the fish smell and feel the teeth on the combs.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, こう None None Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in きょうと. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs. You've always had an interest in きょうと, so it makes sense that you'd be interested in things from きょうと too.

mnemonics.meaning: Into Included If you get on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> somewhere, you’re going <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">into</mark> that place. Really focus on going "into" wherever this is. Into the place you go. Right into it.
mnemonics.reading: None こ None Once you’ve gone into this place, what do you see? Your 子 (こ)! How did your 子 get into here? Your 子 really gets into everywhere. They get into all kinds of places, and they get into all kinds of trouble!

mnemonics.meaning: Kindness If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is in the right place, people will recognize your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kindness</mark>. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you. Share your kindness with the world. Use your big mouth to let people know what you're doing. "I'M TAKING OUT THE TRASH AND NOBODY EVEN ASKED ME!" Y'know, that sort of thing. Go ahead and say that out loud a few times.
mnemonics.reading: おん None None To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it's a nice act of kindness that you're toughing it out for your pal. Imagine chopping up these onions. Smell the onion smell in the air as your eyes begin to sting from the onions. Your friend had better appreciate this kindness.

mnemonics.meaning: Long Time If you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> a building, you'll be sliding for a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long time</mark>. Imagine a never-ending slide that goes deep down inside a building. You can't see anything in the dark around you, you just plunge down and slide forever. And forever is a long time, my friend.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう, く ひさ None You slide for such a long time that you get hungry. Luckily, once in a while a cucumber (きゅう) comes tumbling down the slide next to you. Cucumbers are tasty, but not when you've been eating them for a long time.

mnemonics.meaning: Party Group A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> and his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> join a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">party</mark>. They can raid and pillage better in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark> like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings. Look at this big group that contains the Viking and his older brother. Hear them shouting as a group and imagine their Viking battle cry.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None This party has decided to raid とうきょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance. Imagine this group of Vikings rampaging through とうきょう. See all the Japanese people running away and screaming as the group of Vikings comes busting in, swinging their axes and shouting loudly.

mnemonics.meaning: Preface If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> comes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beforehand</mark>, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">preface</mark> for the rest of the canopy. Although not necessarily a book preface, you can imagine a book made out of canvas pages. The canvas pages that came beforehand (i.e., in the beginning, before the book started) is the preface.
mnemonics.reading: じょ つい, ついで None You read the preface. It just goes on and on and on about Jo-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much. Actually imagine reading through the preface of your favorite book. Except, there's a preface that just goes into great detail about Jo-Anne and doesn't seem related at all to the book.

mnemonics.meaning: Random Miscellaneous You count <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> of them in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> holding something <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">random</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miscellaneous</mark>. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd. Look at the turkeys in the tree. There are nine of them and they are all gobbling up a storm. Hear them gobble as you imagine what random, miscellaneous things they are holding.
mnemonics.reading: ざつ, ぞう None None As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange. Look at Zazu asking the turkeys random questions about miscellaneous trivia. You’ve seen the Lion King, right? Zazu should be pretty easy to visualize here.

mnemonics.meaning: Sakura Cherry Tree, Cherry Blossom Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who loves <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sakura</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cherry tree</mark>, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty. Imagine yourself sitting under the tree in the grass with the woman. Smell the cherries and see the sakura blossoms falling down all around you. How whimsical.
mnemonics.reading: おう, よう さくら None How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember. Sakura means cherry tree and sakura is the way to pronounce this kanji. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: Secrecy Standing on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> that the nearby <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is shrouded in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secrecy</mark>. But you can't do much about it, stuck on your roof as you are. So much secrecy, but so far away. Really feel the frustration of wanting to uncover all the secrecy around this mountain but being stuck on your stupid roof.
mnemonics.reading: みつ ひそ None This secrecy is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical mitts (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what. You can imagine trying to break one of the mitts-wearing members of this group, but they can't tell you anything because of their magical mitts.

mnemonics.meaning: Secret A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> to keep a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secret</mark>. Imagine telling a piece of grain your deepest, darkest secret.
mnemonics.reading: ひ ひ None If someone finds out your secret (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with heat (ひ). This works both ways too. If someone tells you a secret, that same heat fills you up. Now whether this heat is from embarrassment or the rush of getting to be part of a secret is up to you to figure out.

mnemonics.meaning: Strict If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark>y <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elf</mark> under it in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, it's because their parents are so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strict</mark>. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done. Only really, really strict parents would make their kids do that in the middle of winter! It's cold!
mnemonics.reading: げん, ごん きび, おごそ None One of the strict parents of this elf kid is... Genji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf. Oh Genji, if only you were as strict about using protection as you were on your elf child.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw Away Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> have nothing to do when you're at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cottage</mark> except <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw away</mark> things. Your cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least. Imagine sitting in your cottage. You throw away a banana peel. You throw away some used suntan lotion. You throw away all your cares in the world.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ す None The number one thing you throw away while in your cottage is your suit (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage vibe, man. Just throw away all your suits when you want to relax. Don't worry about needing one someday, throw it awaaaay!

mnemonics.meaning: Translation Reason They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> who is bad with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">translation</mark> has no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead. Imagine this one shrimp who is bad at translation. He’s trying to find a reason to live, but he’s having trouble. Look at him all alone, being shunned by the other shrimp.
mnemonics.reading: やく わけ None The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart. The translation of the word yak was the reason this shrimp fell into despair and gave up the translation profession. Now everyone hates him. See this poor shrimp being harassed by others while they shout at him, “Yak! Yak! Yak!”

mnemonics.meaning: Want In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> you feel a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">want</mark>. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty. Think of how much you want to be in this valley. They have everything in there. You lack nothing. You want for nothing. Man, you wanna be in that valley so badly.
mnemonics.reading: よく ほ None Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth. This was the yolk you wanted. Feel it slosh into your mouth from the sky. Taste the yolk on your tongue before swallowing it. Mmm, egg yolk.

mnemonics.meaning: Warm You're in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> playing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> and you get very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warm</mark>. Feel how warm the sun is, as you try to throw and catch the football.
mnemonics.reading: だん あたた None It's warm like this because it's dawn (だん). That's when the sun comes up. Dang, you knew you should have played night football so it wouldn't get so warm. Now the dawn sun is making you uncomfortable under all those layers of football protection.

mnemonics.meaning: Welcome In its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> scoots up to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">welcome</mark> you! "Nya! Welcome to my ship, grab a scooter and scoot on up here, we're about to start the welcome ceremonya!"
mnemonics.reading: げい むか None The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Especially gay (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be. You're really happy this cat pirate welcomes gay people aboard. Whether that's because you're gay or just because you're a baseline decent human being is up to you. Also if you aren't the kind of person who would welcome gay people onto your cat pirate ship, you should just leave nyaow.

mnemonics.meaning: Wound If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wound</mark> people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself. Picture how easy it would be for the leader of your country to wound someone if they had a gun. Scary, right?
mnemonics.reading: しょう きず, いた None Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers. Picture the Shougun you've slowly grown to know over the last thirty-ish levels. But he's holding a gun wounding everyone around him. He's screaming and shooting and wounding everyone in sight. Even his mom, even his dog, even his farmers.

mnemonics.meaning: Ash Ashes On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> burns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ashes</mark>. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go. See the light from the fire as the ashes fly off the cliff. The wind carries some of the ashes over to you. Feel the ashes as they strike your face and wipe the black ash with your hands.
mnemonics.reading: かい はい None The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy. Ashes on my face. Falling from the cliff of fire. Gives my life meaning. Or just come up with your own haiku. Whatever works for you.

mnemonics.meaning: Attire If you see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s hanging off of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, don't worry, those are just part of his winter <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attire</mark>. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season. Picture a samurai in his winter attire. His helmet is white and fuzzy and he has decorative icicles hanging down off of his armor.
mnemonics.reading: そう, しょう よそお None Attire like this is important because it reflects your soul (そう). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather. Picture the kind of attire you'd wear as a samurai to reflect your soul. Mine would be bright pink and covered in horses and bananas and daisies to show that I have a happy, kind soul and that I don't want to be killed by anyone else.

mnemonics.meaning: Author If you want to give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, give them to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">author</mark>. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books. Imagine a time when a book you were reading used flowery language and you couldn't understand. Imagine the annoyance with the author for being so overwrought and flowery.
mnemonics.reading: ちょ いちじる, あらわ None Unfortunately, the author is allergic to touching flowers, so they hold them with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ). They hold them real close to their face with the chopsticks, so they can still use them to think of fancy, author-ly words. Picture the author trying to use chopsticks to hold some little flowers. It looks like they're having a hard time, but people will do anything to be a great author, I suppose.

mnemonics.meaning: Backside Underside, Reverse There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark>, so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it over on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">backside</mark> to see what's on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">underside</mark>. You've been curious about what's on the lid (and your village's) backside for years, and you finally can't take it anymore so you kick the lid as hard as you can!
mnemonics.reading: り うら None It turns out your village's own backside is covered in uranium (うら). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich! Wait, isn't uranium bad for people? This explains why all of the villagers' backsides are covered in weird glowing, green lumps.

mnemonics.meaning: Crotch Groin, Fork You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crotch</mark>. Where else would you keep it? Your moon weapon is a moon that you keep in your crotch. We'll let you imagine how this one works...
mnemonics.reading: こ また, もも None Your crotch has a moon weapon, and it's served you well, so you hope that if you have a 子 (こ) one day, they'll have one too. Your mother had a moon weapon, and her father before her. It's been in the family for generations, and you hope to pass it on to your 子 as well.

mnemonics.meaning: Dangle Drip This car is all weird because it looks like the side is going to dangle and drip off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment. Compare this kanji to the car kanji, 車. See how the sides and top are different? Use that to remember that this car looks like it’s falling apart. See the parts dangle, and hear the drip of car fluids falling out. This car is a wreck.
mnemonics.reading: すい た None You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can. Imagine yourself swinging off these dangling car parts. Hear the car creak and groan as you swing around on it, causing more fluid to drip out of the car.

mnemonics.meaning: Differ Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with other paddies and you'll see how much they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">differ</mark>. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit! Try to picture how each rice paddy differs from the next. Can you think of any differences in the ones you've seen?
mnemonics.reading: い こと None To see how rice paddies differ, you need an eagle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together. Aha! As an eagle you can easily see that all of the rice paddies have differing colors, shapes, and (if you fly low) smells. They differ a lot!

mnemonics.meaning: Emperor Social commentary aside, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emperor</mark>! See the emperor, garbed all in white. There are other kings, but the emperor's white clothing shows his status above the rest.
mnemonics.reading: こう, おう None None Who is the emperor? It is こういち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects. How did こういち become emperor?! His first decree as emperor is that everybody must learn kanji now. Note: from now on, Emperor こういち will be a recurring character for the reading mnemonic of こう.

mnemonics.meaning: Extend To make your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wide</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extend</mark> them. Extend your fingers right now and see how wide you can make them.
mnemonics.reading: かく ひろ None As you extend your fingers a cock (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK! You poked the cock right in the eye with your extended fingers. Maybe you shouldn't be doing that in public. Innocent cocks could get hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: Flatulence Gas Use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flatulence</mark>. How do you compare your flatulence? I recommend a flag. You can see which fart is strongest by seeing how much the flag flutters.
mnemonics.reading: ひ へ None How do you read flatulence? Heh(へ)...heh..heh..heheheh. You can't NOT laugh at the word flatulence. Note that some dictionaries incorrectly list おなら as a reading for this kanji. While おなら also means "flatulence" (as in "fart"), you’ll only ever encounter this reading in hiragana, as the kanji can only be read as へ. Picture yourself unable to stop snickering over the word "flatulence", like a little schoolchild. Heh… heh…

mnemonics.meaning: Livelihood A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">livelihood</mark> will be awesome, now! Just feel happy that your plants have such a nice livelihood now that the sun is out. They look so healthy and fresh!
mnemonics.reading: ぼ く None From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood. Look at Bobo do what he needs to do to maintain his own livelihood. Hear the flowers screaming as they are plucked from their homes.
