mnemonics.meaning: Loyalty Those that are in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> are the ones you have the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loyalty</mark> towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to. Who do you feel the most loyalty towards? Imagine them in the middle of your heart. Feel them in your chest. Imagine them, literally inside the middle of your heart.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう None None You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back. Chewbacca is very loyal. Focus on your loyalty to Chewbacca. Picture him right in the middle of your heart and hear his Chewbacca yell. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 中 which is also included in this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Lung There is a moon and a city inside your lung. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs. Imagine having a moon and a city inside your lung. Feel their presence as you breathe in and breathe out. Also, 月 often refers to internal organs as well, so remember that when you see this kanji.
mnemonics.reading:
はい None None Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here. The city and moon
Inside my lung, forgotten.
Where is the answer? Or just think of your own haiku. Be creative!

mnemonics.meaning: Magazine To <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what's in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you start a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">magazine</mark>. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read! Why hadn't anyone thought of making a samurai magazine before?!
mnemonics.reading: し None None Unfortunately, your magazine helps the sheep (し) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no! The sheep samurai is ruining your magazine! Maybe you should start a new magazine called, "All the places the sheep samurai will be, so stay away!" to make up for all the damage you've caused.

mnemonics.meaning: Manipulate Chastity If someone has their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark>, it's just another way of saying they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manipulate</mark>d you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life. This also has another meaning: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastity</mark>. Just imagine if someone wanted you to keep your chastity and they called s.e.x. when someone "puts their fingers in your syrup." That would be pretty effective, right? Cause it's like, super gross. "Ah golly gee wiz, he sure got his fingers all up in my syrup again, dagnabbit." You know, this saying we say all the time when someone manipulates us into doing something.
mnemonics.reading: そう あやつ, みさお None If you want to manipulate someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your soul (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it. What happens to your soul, you ask? It gets covered in syrup. That's probably where the syrup fingers phrase came from in the first place.

mnemonics.meaning: Muscle Tendon This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> absorbed the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">muscle</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tendon</mark>s. Picture your new bamboo muscles glowing under your skin with the moon's power. You flex and feel the power coursing through you!
mnemonics.reading: きん すじ None Your special muscles and tendons have become famous and the King (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles. Imagine standing before the King, explaining in detail how you cut yourself open and replaced your weak human meat with the special muscles you have now. He's staring intently at you, but more so at your shining body than your mouth as you talk.

mnemonics.meaning: No The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Not</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> says “<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">no</mark>”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question. Imagine encountering this Not Mouth. Ask it a question. It answers, “No”. Imagine doing this over and over until you believe that the Not Mouth always says “no”.
mnemonics.reading: ひ いな, いや None You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat. Listen as the Not Mouth continues to scream in bloodcurdling agony. Hear the flames flicker as they lick across the Not Mouth’s being. Seems as though the heat was too much for the Not Mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: Pile Prosperous, Heap If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>, I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pile</mark> food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperous</mark>. If you have piles of something, you're prosperous. If you become a plate, that's the best thing that can happen to you.
mnemonics.reading: せい, じょう も, さか None You're so prosperous you use your saber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food! You know a family is seriously prosperous when they don't use forks, they use a magical saber to cut their food. Wowee wow wow.

mnemonics.meaning: Proclaim Someone climbs onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> when <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> comes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proclaim</mark> that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs! Picture a shadowy shape on top of the roof, proclaiming to the entire town that the new day is here! It's come! And it's also time to get up.
mnemonics.reading: せん のたま None The thing that climbs up on the roof to proclaim that the new day is here is a centaur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else. Picture that shadow on the roof, proclaiming it's a new day, but this time make sure you picture the outline of this centaur. He has a human top half and a horse bottom half. And he's yelling down at you, "HEY THE SUN IS UP IT'S DAWN GET OUT OF BED!"

mnemonics.meaning: Rent The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> of every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> sets the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rent</mark> for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself. King Shellfish loves when people rent from him. Imagine him rolling in all of the rent money (shellfish) he collected from all the people who rent from him. Hear his shell clattering as he frolics on all the dead shells from the shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: ちん None None If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your rent, King Shellfish will punch you in the chin (ちん). Feel your entire body shaking, but especially your chin, as you tell him you're two shellfish short on rent this month. The last thing you see is his big fist coming right for your chin.

mnemonics.meaning: Respect Writing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is the only way to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respect</mark> from other poets. Even better, write a poem about winter IN winter. Then they'll really respect you.
mnemonics.reading: けい うやま None Once you have their respect you get cake (けい)! The cake has the word RESPECT in fancy, cursive letters. Imagine eating that cake and taste the respect of your poet peers. Mm mm!

mnemonics.meaning: Revered The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> of the creatures who drink <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> so large that they are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revered</mark> the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns. Look at one of these revered horns. Pick it up and feel its weight. It measures very large. Your arms are getting tired from the weight.
mnemonics.reading: そん とうと, たっと None The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life. Good thing you already have one of these revered horns. Now imagine yourself grinding it up into a powder to mix into a potion for your son to drink. Hear the horn grinding away as you physically break the horn up into millions of tiny pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: Ripen If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> something edible, arrange it in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it. That way, it’ll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ripen</mark> more quickly. Picture yourself receiving something, arranging it in a circle in the pan, and leaving it to boil. See how quickly that stuff ripens? Now it’s all ripe and yummy.
mnemonics.reading: じゅく う None Once everything you received has ripened, you kick back near your jukebox (じゅく) and eat it. The jukebox sets the mood, making the ripened treat feels twice as sweet. Imagine the jukebox playing music to accompany your ripened treat. Ahh, jukebox music and ripened goodies. Can life get any sweeter?

mnemonics.meaning: Rumor Gossip Next to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> which react to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>. If you exceed a certain alcohol <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>, they start flapping about, which makes you spread <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rumors</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gossip</mark> uncontrollably. Just imagine these fins forcing your mouth to move with all their flapping. This is what happens when you have too much alcohol, you can't control yourself.
mnemonics.reading: そん うわさ None The flapping fins are making you slur your words, but that doesn't stop you from spreading rumors and gossip: "Ooo whassat (うわさ) I hear about so and so having an affair?!" Just imagine trying to talk eloquently and clearly when you have fins flapping around your mouth. And if you've had a few drinks on top of that, it stands to reason that you'd start slurring your words.

mnemonics.meaning: Sand If you grind a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> down to more than just a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> pieces, it will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sand</mark>. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand. Feel these few grains of sand between your fingertips. Imagine the stones that they originally came from. Nature is crazy.
mnemonics.reading: さ, しゃ すな None After breaking up your stone into sand, you fetch your special sand saw (さ). A few bits are still too chunky, so you'll have to use a sand saw now. You may wonder what a sand saw is. Well, it's a saw for cutting sand into even finer little pieces. How does it work? It's a mystery!

mnemonics.meaning: Simplicity You line up stalks of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> with an equal <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">interval</mark> between each one. This pattern creates a sense of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simplicity</mark>. Bamboo, interval, bamboo, interval, bamboo… Almost like a binary rhythm: 1, 0, 1, 0, 1. Now that's simplicity. It doesn't get simpler than that!
mnemonics.reading: かん None None That kind of simplicity is what Genghis Khan (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity. Simplicity is how he took over the world. Attack or don't attack? Boom, simple. If he hadn't stuck to simplicity, he wouldn't have been able to do what he did. Complex thoughts just get in the way of expansionist ambitions, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Steam If you take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> off some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coral</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> them, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steam</mark> comes out. Steam comes out of the coral flowers because they hold a lot of water. They're flowers, but they're coral flowers, so they came from the ocean. Of course there's water in them, and if you boil that water steam will come out.
mnemonics.reading: じょう む None As you watch the steam coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It’s Joe (じょう), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love steaming me some coral.” It's weird that Joe is so sensitive to the smell of steaming coral. He's lived as a farmhand nowhere near the sea all his life... at least that's what he told you. And now he's in your house breathing in the steam really deeply with his nose practically in the pot.

mnemonics.meaning: Storehouse The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">storehouse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark> kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji! Your brain is like a storehouse, you know? Hopefully that's where you kept your storehouse knowledge.
mnemonics.reading: ぞう くら None You have a storehouse. Inside is where you keep all your zombies (ぞう). Be really proud of your storehouse. You've collected a lot of zombies and put them in there, where they'll keep fresh a long time!

mnemonics.meaning: Sugar Bring some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and stuff it in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. Make him chew it a bit, scrape it out, and voila — you've made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sugar</mark>! Taste that sweet, sweet sugar. Not many people know, but this is how it's made. The canopy is needed for temperature control, and the wolverine… well, it's got special enzymes in its mouth or something.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None You learned how to make this kind of sugar in とうきょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all the secret methods you know now. As you eat the sugar, you picture とうきょう. The place where you fell in love with these sugar-making techniques.

mnemonics.meaning: Supply The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">inside</mark> is your whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supply</mark>. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one. Go inside your house or shed, it doesn't matter where, and look happily at your thread supply. You have thread in all sizes, shapes, and especially colors.
mnemonics.reading: のう, なっ おさ None You have this supply because Nostradamus (のう) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out. Nostradamus says you should have a large supply of everything you use regularly. Thread, water, canned foods. You can't see the future, but he can, and if he's telling you to stock up on your inside supplies I think you should listen.

mnemonics.meaning: Various They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">various</mark> talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend. You are someone who can say things in various languages. Speak some of these various languages now. You are someone who is good at saying things. Nice job.
mnemonics.reading: しょ もろ None You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed. Imagine yourself at this show. The spotlight is on and all eyes are watching. You feel kind of nervous, but you speak the various languages with ease.

mnemonics.meaning: Window The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> leading to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of your house is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">window</mark>. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say. Imagine someone looking into a hole that shows your private heart. That's a window. A window you probably should have kept closed. Now everyone is looking in.
mnemonics.reading: そう まど None You realize that a ton of people are looking into your window and seeing all your private things. This makes you mad (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?! Look out your window back at the faces. Try to express how mad you are at them with your face through the glass. Make as many mad faces that you can think of.

mnemonics.meaning: Beans The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beans</mark> kanji are exactly the same! *toots*
mnemonics.reading: とう まめ None These beans are from とうきょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans! Imagine eating these beans from とうきょう. They’re the best beans you’ve ever had. Even if you don’t like beans, you love とうきょう beans. Mmm… beans, beans, とうきょう beans.

mnemonics.meaning: Branch A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> is exactly what it sounds like: the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch</mark> of a tree. Picture a tree branch in your hands. Feel it. Smell it. It smells and feels like a tree.
mnemonics.reading: し えだ None You're smelling and feeling the branch when, suddenly, it starts screaming at you: "Eh, dad?" (えだ). The branch won't leave you alone. It follows you around screaming "Eh, dad?", thinking you're its long-lost tree branch father. Poor thing. Picture the branch suddenly crying out, "Eh, Dad?" in a squeaky voice. You'd better find its real dad, otherwise this branch is never going to leave you alone.

mnemonics.meaning: Brandish Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, step onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brandish</mark> them in the air. Wave them around for everyone to see. Imagine standing on top of your car, brandishing your fingers in the air while all of the cars stuck behind you honk angrily.
mnemonics.reading: き None None What are you brandishing in your fingers? Your car's key (き)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again! You brandish the key in the air and then throw it into the woods. No more cars for you! Everyone should follow your example! Brandish your car keys in the air and throw them away!

mnemonics.meaning: Carve A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carve</mark>. You carve meat, you carve wood, all with a slicing motion with a knife.
mnemonics.reading: こく きざ None You work up a sweat trying to carve meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice Coke (こく). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust. Imagine washing down all your hard carving work with an ice cold Coke.

mnemonics.meaning: Claw Nail The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">claw</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">claw</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing! Lucky for you, this kanji has already etched its claw marks into your memory!
mnemonics.reading: そう つめ, つま None You sink your claws into anything your two 目 (つめ) see, because you're such a fierce predator. If your two 目 can see it, your claws will get to it. Your claws are basically an extension of your two eyes, that's how skilled you are. Imagine your claws darting out, almost automatically, as soon as your two 目 have seen your prey. Imagine catching your dinner that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Consent A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> will ask if they want <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>s because they need a grown-up's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consent</mark>. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first. Picture the child finishing their first water. They look at a big stack of bottled waters, but they know better than to just take two more, they need consent first. "Excuse me, sir, could I please have two more waters?" the child asks.
mnemonics.reading: しょう うけたまわ None "Of course my child, you have my consent," comes the voice of the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him. You need to make sure to get express consent from the Shougun before you do most things. Especially if it's something like taking more than you've been given.

mnemonics.meaning: Cough Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> was <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark>d open by a terrible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cough</mark>. You've heard of a hacking cough, right? Well, this is worse. It's a slicing cough, and it's sliced right through your mouth, too. Imagine it flapping around while you cough.
mnemonics.reading: がい せき None Oddly enough, some people find your cough sexy (せき). That slicing cough opened up a nice gravelly, sexy voice. Between coughs, you start noticing all the looks you're getting. You realize your cough is making you really sexy to all the people around you. Cough cough cough.

mnemonics.meaning: Curtain In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">curtain</mark> as soon as you hang it. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all. Imagine hanging towels over all the windows in the greenhouse. They're really fuzzy, thick curtains now.
mnemonics.reading: まく, ばく とばり None You're hanging these towel curtains because you need a quiet place to eat a Big Mac (まく). But you're a little ashamed. Big Macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in. Imagine hiding in a greenhouse blocked off with towel curtains, stuffing your face with Big Macs. No one can shame you in here. You can eat as many as you want. And hey, you can use the curtains as napkins too.

mnemonics.meaning: Deep Red Crimson You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> project to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep red</mark>, and it gives everything a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crimson</mark> look. Because thread isn't that strong, you have to use A LOT (to hold things like beams in place). So, the deep red or crimson thread actually stands out a lot in this construction project.
mnemonics.reading: こう, く べに, くれない None You're done, and the whole building is a deep red crimson color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor こういち, the finished product. こういち walks up with a big smile on his face. "I love the color crimson!" he exclaims. "It's the same deep red color as my enemies." Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Delight An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> is what this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s. For a turkey, that is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delight</mark>. A turkey that lacks an arrow is a delighted turkey.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None Delight is what Genghis Khan (かん) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow. He loves his turkey friend, and every time he sees it he squeals with delight.

mnemonics.meaning: Dude The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sitting on that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dude</mark>. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks! Dude, I can't believe you called that dude a woman. What's wrong with you?!
mnemonics.reading: ど やつ None You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog (ど) ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dog's face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!" Look at the poor dog. He's not a dude and now he doesn't think he's a good boy, all because of this other dude. Was he sitting on the stool this whole time, waiting to make this dog feel bad? I guess you'll never know...

mnemonics.meaning: Holy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">holy</mark>. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine. See the holy ear and mouth of this king. They glisten and glitter and people write hymnals about their holy prowess. Imagine a song playing as you witness their holy majesty.
mnemonics.reading: せい None None This holy king has heard of you and your special saber (せい) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food! The holy king heard you turned into a prosperous plate and used the saber to cut your food and now he wants to try it too. As he holds your saber, a holy circle forms around it, making it sparkle and shimmer! Your saber is holy now too!!

mnemonics.meaning: Infer If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> are pointing right at you, you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">infer</mark> that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now it's going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take its fingers and wrap them around your neck. Imagine a turkey is pointing at you with its fingers. The gears in your brain begin to slowly turn. From looking at the turkey to its fingers and back to the turkey, you can infer that something bad is probably about to happen to you.
mnemonics.reading: すい お None You were able to infer the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to swing (すい) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom! Picture yourself as Sherlock Holmes, you inferred your way to freedom, swinging away on a conveniently-placed vine.

mnemonics.meaning: Internal Organs Your moon storehouse is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with internal organs. Your moon storehouse has internal organs because 1) you have to keep them far away from the zombies or they'll go berserk, and 2) you think it's funny to see them bounce around in low gravity. Boing, boing, boing, haha look at that internal organ.
mnemonics.reading: ぞう None None Where did you get all these internal organs from? You actually harvested them from the zombies (ぞう) from your other storehouse. Basically, you store zombies in your regular storehouse, harvest their organs, then launch them into space where they are put into a storehouse on the moon where the zombies will never be able to find them again.

mnemonics.meaning: Loss Hurt Raise your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">member</mark> and you'll receive a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loss</mark> in return. You should never <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hurt</mark> a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds. Imagine raising your fingers to slap, hurt, or point angrily at a member of your own team. How dare you! I hope you're ready for some deep, personal loss.
mnemonics.reading: そん そこ None Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the loss of your son (そん). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member. Picture your son. Your future son, maybe even your animal son, if you don't want to have real kids. Now imagine the loss of that son. Nooooo!

mnemonics.meaning: Magnet Seeing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> and another piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>, you try and pick each of them up with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">magnet</mark>. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone! Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
mnemonics.reading: じ None None You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time! Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.

mnemonics.meaning: Mistake They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> accidentally firing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> is an unforgivable <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mistake</mark>. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for. Imagine shooting the catapult on your own people by mistake. Hear the catapult whoosh as your heart drops into your stomach. Oh, what a terrible mistake you’ve just made.
mnemonics.reading: ご あやま None This mistake alerts Godzilla (ご), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you. Picture Godzilla jumping happily on the castle and surrounding town you hit by mistake. This is probably the worst mistake you've ever made.

mnemonics.meaning: Origin A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> was the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> event to mark the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">origin</mark> of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned. Picture the original tsunami used in the origin story of Japan (never mind that we just made this up). It was huge. Bigger than anything you've ever seen. And without it you wouldn't have your precious anime and manga.
mnemonics.reading: げん みなもと None This tsunami was also the origin of Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji! The origin of Genji was the origin of all Japan: a big ol' tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Pure If it's made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark>. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities. Imagine a barracks made of pure thread. No brick or clay barracks can compete with yours, as long as you make it out of pure, unadulterated thread.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None Unfortunately, this pure thread barracks can only be used in June (じゅん). Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then. Okay, so maybe building a pure barracks that you can only use in June was a bad idea, but it's there now and I don't want you getting it dirty, so just use it when I say so, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: Recommend You want some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to put on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> to keep the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>s away, so you ask people what they would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recommend</mark>. You've bought flowers before, but you really don't know which ones would work best to stop birds from landing on the canopy and pooping on your helicopter.
mnemonics.reading: せん すす None You ask for a recommendation from the centaur (せん) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding. I hope the centaur recommends a cheap flower... but with your luck flowers that keep birds away will cost a fortune.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice Bowl Into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of rice falls from your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice bowl</mark>. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down. You lost a drop of rice from your rice bowl. Feel sorrow for the lost rice as you watch it fall down the well and hear it splat into the water below.
mnemonics.reading: None どん, どんぶり None Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well. Hear the don shout, “See ya, sucker!” as he pushes you into the well. You’ve just lost a drop of rice, now your rice bowl, and now you’re all wet in a well. Worst day ever.

mnemonics.meaning: Rot Set up your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meat</mark> to it, and the meat will eventually <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rot</mark>. Imagine the smell of rotten meat hanging from your canopy. Now no one wants to come near here.
mnemonics.reading: ふ くさ None You let meat rot. You're a fool (ふ). That's really all I can say at this point. What, did you think attaching this meat to the canopy would make it turn into jerky or something? Fool...

mnemonics.meaning: Run Alongside There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, so you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on, open your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> wide, and try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run alongside</mark> it. Your mouth is open so you can scream, because this is probably a bad idea.
mnemonics.reading: えん そ None You're able to run alongside the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything ends (えん). Okay, so maybe trying to run alongside a tsunami with just some fins and a mouth full of screams and terror wasn't the best idea. But at least everything ended while you did... uh... something unique?

mnemonics.meaning: Shoot You need to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> before you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoot</mark>. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first. Imagine someone measuring your body before they shoot you. You hope it's the good kind of shoot and that you're not going to die.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ い, さ, う None This shoot is being done by a shaman (しゃ). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu. Shamans are just a different kind of doctor. And this shot is going to save you from getting the flu, which could kill you. Make sure you always go to the local shaman and schedule a shooting.

mnemonics.meaning: Shrink A magic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> fell from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> people, causing him to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shrink</mark>! Picture one hundred people under the same roof watching in horror as their leader suddenly shrinks to nothingness before them.
mnemonics.reading: しゅく ちぢ None As the leader shrinks, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is shook (しゅく) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most. The leader gets shook so badly, he can't even call out to his people. They're going to trample his tiny, shrinking body!

mnemonics.meaning: Slave A samurai handling a jackhammer, cleaning brushes (in their 肀 form), and carrying water for someone?! All that should tell you that he's not just working, he's been made into a slave. Traditionally, samurai don't work with jackhammers or do menial tasks like cleaning brushes and hauling water. This samurai is doing these things for someone else, meaning he's somebody's slave.
mnemonics.reading: れい None None You don't like seeing slaves. As you walk by, you hand this slave a ray (れい) gun so he can free himself. The samurai can use the ray gun to shoot his keeper and get away. Imagine watching him holding up the master and getting away. A ray gun is a truly powerful weapon in the hands of a slave.

mnemonics.meaning: Stylish Pure There's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> and this is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stylish</mark>. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it's stylish to carry it around and be seen with it. Imagine hefting this cross with the rice in the shape of a nine on it. You don't feel stylish, but society tells you that you are. You're stylish.
mnemonics.reading: すい いき None It's also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You're waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off! See the rice fly through the air from you swinging the cross. Hear it as it clatters to the ground. This cross just isn't as stylish anymore now.

mnemonics.meaning: Thin You are so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> that you've come to look like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thin</mark>. Eerily thin, in fact. Imagine standing behind a stool and being able to disappear behind it completely. That's how thin this sickness has made you.
mnemonics.reading: そう や None When you're this thin, your soul (そう) is visible from outside of your body too. Picture your soul pulsing through your thin body. You have no body fat to cover it up, so everyone can see it pulsing and lurking in there. This is why you're hiding behind one of the humble stools in your house.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw Up Spit, Vomit If someone fills your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw up</mark>. That's just a fact. That's pretty much what throwing up feels like too, right? Like a bunch of dirt coming out of your mouth. Barf.
mnemonics.reading: と は, つ None When you throw up it sounds like you're shouting, "HA (は)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha. Imagine the sound you made the last time you threw up. It sounded like you were saying HA from the bottom of your tummy.

mnemonics.meaning: Valuable In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valuable</mark>. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground. Look at this valuable shellfish. What could be inside? Pick it up and shake it about, trying to guess what valuable thing is enclosed.
mnemonics.reading: き とうと None You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key! You find a bunch of keys, so you try to jam them all into the shellfish one by one, hoping one of them is the right key to get the valuable, hidden treasure.

mnemonics.meaning: Vertical You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> from some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> and you would be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to assume that it would hang <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vertical</mark>. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do. Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう たて None For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat. Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.

mnemonics.meaning: Work <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Boot</mark>s give you the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">work</mark>! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots. Imagine putting your boots on and suddenly being filled with the power and energy to work hard and efficiently.
mnemonics.reading: きん つと None You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things. Picture yourself in work boots. Now picture the King in work boots. Yours are worn and beaten up and his are clean and look brand new. But at least you both have them, which means you both work at least a little!

mnemonics.meaning: Worship Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> them. Then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> them again. This is what you do when you are in  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worship</mark>. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them! Picture your sweaty, sweaty fingers. Dry them off before you enter a place of worship! No god wants to deal with your weird, damp hands.
mnemonics.reading:
はい おが None Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway. Imagine being in your place of worship. Close your eyes and say a haiku: So I won't offend
Lord Crabigator-sama
I dry my hands now.

mnemonics.meaning: Bear The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> is one of the main abilities of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bear</mark>. I bet you didn't know this, but a bear can boil whenever it wants. Imagine a bear heating itself up and boiling, its fur and skin bubbling and letting off steam.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう くま None A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magna cum (くま) laude. Get it? A little hot bear humor for you. You can also imagine a bear graduating in the top 5-10% of its class. Or, just imagine a bear saying "Cuma here!" to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Boisterous Miso Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> so people won't realize you're the one being so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boisterous</mark> as you eat your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miso</mark>. If you cover your mouth with this mask, no one will know you're such a boisterous eater of miso. Okay, this kanji doesn't actually mean "miso," it just means "boisterous." But you'll pretty much only ever see it in the word for miso, so I figured I'd sneak it in here to prepare you for that… Thank me later.
mnemonics.reading: そ None None You're being boisterous and having your miso outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth. "Even your mask can't hide that boisterous miso-eating. Quiet down and wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell. Using your boisterous mouth, taste the disgusting soapy soap. The soap bubbles are already filling your mouth and stinging your tongue. This is the punishment for those who eat boisterously.

mnemonics.meaning: Carve There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> around someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carve</mark>d the hair off someone's head! Their hair has literally been carved out of their head, and you discovered it. Of course, the nastiness, the smell, and the feel should be applied to your imagination to make the mnemonic stronger.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう ほ None When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this. You can also imagine Mrs. Chou doing the act of carving someone's hair out, but that may just be too much.

mnemonics.meaning: Cedar There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, I think it’s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cedar</mark>. How did that cedar tree get in your hair? (Certain types of cedar trees have bark that comes off in fine threads, making them very hairy trees. So this kanji makes perfect sense!) Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
mnemonics.reading: None すぎ None Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it. Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.

mnemonics.meaning: Chat Talk The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">World</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tree</mark>, all it does is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chat</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>. You'd think the World Tree's mouth would talk wisdom, but all it does is chat, chat, chat.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう しゃべ None To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ). The locals shorten Shaman Bay to "Sha Bay," because they always go there to 喋る with the World Tree. Imagine all the shamans hanging about in the bay.

mnemonics.meaning: Cooking Pot You toss a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cooking pot</mark> and begin simmering them. Some people use bay leaves and whatnot, but where you're from, there's no seasoning you'd rather have in your cooking pot than a couple of gold mustaches. Smell the aromatic vapors as you simmer these gold mustaches in your cooking pot. You can see the gold whiskers slowly melting and turning into a delicious, shimmering broth.
mnemonics.reading: か なべ None Your spouse asks you if they can have a taste of what's in your cooking pot, but you say, "Nah babe (なべ), this is all for me." Undeterred, your spouse keeps trying to sneak a spoon into your cooking pot, but you relentlessly box them out, shouting "Nah, babe" over and over.

mnemonics.meaning: Copper <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark> is not the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">copper</mark>. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper. Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
mnemonics.reading: どう あかがね None Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut. Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.

mnemonics.meaning: Cottage The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cottage</mark>. As long as you know the radical cottage, you know the kanji cottage.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ None None You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage. I guess shamans are moving out a lot around here. Why don't you go look for a cottage you can buy from a shaman! I bet you'll get a pretty good, totally not cursed, deal!

mnemonics.meaning: Desert Vague A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark>, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">desert</mark>. The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
mnemonics.reading: ばく None None See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out! Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?

mnemonics.meaning: Drunk You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> times stronger than any other drink, in a bottle shaped like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, and you drink it all and become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drunk</mark>. You're like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before. Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
mnemonics.reading: すい よ None Everything's spinning now, you're so drunk it feels like you're on a swing (すい). Lurching back and forth in your drunkenness, feeling more and more nauseated by all this horrible swinging. Ugh. Imagine that vertigo that comes over you if you lean your head back when you're drunk. It feels like leaning back on a playground swing, in a way. Oh, wait… what if we got drunk and swung on the playground swings? Double swing effect! Actually, never mind. Bad idea.

mnemonics.meaning: Flame Blaze <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flame</mark>! There’s flames everywhere! Feel the fire all around you, the flames licking at your body. It’s really hot!
mnemonics.reading: えん ほのお None The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん). Sorry, but standing in a blaze isn't the best idea. Flames are pretty efficient at ending the lives of the things in it. Maybe you should do this kanji lesson over and try not to stand in the flames next time.

mnemonics.meaning: House Counter Eaves Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> because you kept it under the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eaves</mark> of your house. This kanji has a second meaning too: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">house counter</mark>. Imagine counting all the houses on your block by the number of eaves you see keeping cars dry. One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
mnemonics.reading: けん のき None On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too. Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.

mnemonics.meaning: Introduce You create a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> with someone by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>ing out to them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">introduce</mark> yourself. You literally call out, and when they turn around, tie a thread to them, so you'll never forget that you introduced yourselves to each other.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!" Finally the Shougun sighs and turns toward you. You call out your name and get the thread around him. Uh oh. He doesn't look happy.

mnemonics.meaning: Jammed In The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jammed in</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jammed in</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: かい None すけ Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい). Picture yourself jammed into a kayak. Your pants are bunching and sticking out the sides and top. You really don't fit in here.

mnemonics.meaning: Lake The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s during the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>s (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lake</mark>s. Where did lakes come from? They are the residue of tsunamis from many moons ago.
mnemonics.reading: こ みずうみ None "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ). This is just a stupid story to get this 子 to stop asking "why, why, why?" about everything. Earlier, the 子 asked "where do lakes come from?" and you had to come up with a crazy story to quiet them.

mnemonics.meaning: Lecture Try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> and you'll just end up getting a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lecture</mark>. A lifeguard's favorite part of the job is telling people what to do, where to swim, when to get out of the water, and they love saying it in a bunch of words.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette? Close your eyes and picture こういち lecturing you. Ugh, it's the worst! Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: Lifespan Longevity In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s will reveal your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lifespan</mark>. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight. On the first day of spring, all the girls and boys line up to measure their lifespans.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ, す ことぶき None If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all! Look at Salmon, over here. She drank a thousand small juice boxes last year and now her measurement says she's gonna live another hundred years!

mnemonics.meaning: Measure A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> will pick up a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> and dump them on your shore, so you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measure</mark> them. You can't eat shellfish that are too small, so you place your knife along them to measure them. If they're big enough, you stick the knife in and eat them raw.
mnemonics.reading: そく はか None All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean. If you measure one of these shellfish and it's too small, stuff it right into your sock. Then once the sock measures about 12 shellfish long, toss it back to sea!

mnemonics.meaning: Misfortune Unlucky If you're on the edge of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>, that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">misfortune</mark>. You're hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can't pull yourself back up. Then you notice a snake approaching your fingers, looking like it's gonna bite you. What a misfortune! What will you do? You can either let go and fall off the cliff, or hold on and get bitten by the snake. Man, talk about misfortune.
mnemonics.reading: やく None None You decide to let go, but at the bottom of the cliff is an even greater misfortune: yak (やく). A whole stampeding herd of yak is passing just as you fall. Oops! You've accidentally committed yourself to the ultimate misfortune, death by yak trampling. Imagine the glittering maze of hooves and yak horns that enclose you now. Ahhh! Then the yak pass, and you find yourself alive but beaten. Life is one misfortune after another, but misfortunes, like the yak, eventually pass…

mnemonics.meaning: Mutual The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shuriken</mark> have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mutual</mark> respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here. Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
mnemonics.reading: ご たが None Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground. You give Godzilla a thumbs up, you see what he's trying to do. He looks down at you and nods. Now you have a mutual respect for one another too.

mnemonics.meaning: Oil This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> we have so much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oil</mark> now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami! Watch as this tsunami crashes over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
mnemonics.reading: ゆ あぶら None Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil. Look at how this oil has changed the world. Instead of living in big homes, condos, or skyscrapers, everyone lives in a yurt at night and travels with all the oil by day.

mnemonics.meaning: Oneself Self The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oneself</mark> as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: こ, き おのれ None Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world. Kids can only think of oneself. Until a certain age, that's literally all they can care about.

mnemonics.meaning: Prison You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> and you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> it’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> to prevent it from going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prison</mark>. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison. Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
mnemonics.reading: ごく None None What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog. Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.

mnemonics.meaning: Relatives There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> it, and they're making you feel <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relatives</mark>. A slide isn't the safest place for a drunkard to be. You try to help your relative down but they just keep shouting at you and making you feel small. Drunk relatives are the worst.
mnemonics.reading: せき None None As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're sexy (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible! Imagine your intoxicated relative shouting about how sexy they are on that slide. Someone get them down from there!

mnemonics.meaning: Sake The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet. For goodness sake! Please remember this isn't "sake" as in お酒! It's the English "sake," that rhymes with "bake," "cake," and "steak." Oops.. now I'm hungry.
mnemonics.reading: い ため, な, す None For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery. See this eagle as it comes to deliver your order just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flap and your package plop down on your porch as it's delivered.

mnemonics.meaning: Shame Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> listens to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and feels <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shame</mark>. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too. Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
mnemonics.reading: ち は, はじ None You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before. You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Slow Late Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> warning you that there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> around here, so you should go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slow</mark>. That means you might be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">late</mark>, but at least the sheep will be okay! It's also a warning to the sheep that if they want to ride scooters they should also slow down, because as we all know, sheep are speed demons.
mnemonics.reading: ち おそ, おく None You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite. Picture all of the sheep finally going slowly because there is yummy cheese all over the road.

mnemonics.meaning: Soup A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soup</mark>. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup! Picture a bowl of soup, but now there is a cross and some tsunami water in it.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう しる None You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup! You're curious so you take a sip of this jewel soup and... it's delicious! You should make more and sell it!

mnemonics.meaning: Soy Sauce The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> is really just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soy sauce</mark>. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce. The next time you go to a bar, order yourself a commander's alcohol. It's like saying you want a Roy Rogers or a Shirley Temple, except it isn't pretty and it tastes horrible.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too. Picture the Shougun sitting on his throne, guzzling down some salty, brown soy sauce. It's splashing on his robes and the smell is making his assistants gag.

mnemonics.meaning: Stagnate A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, once stopped by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">belt</mark>, will begin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stagnate</mark>. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate. Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
mnemonics.reading: たい とどこお None While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work. Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.

mnemonics.meaning: Sword Tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and you get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sword</mark>! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife. Imagine creating your own sword out of a knife and a squid.
mnemonics.reading: けん つるぎ None You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword! Picture Ken swinging his squid sword at you. *Squish* it squirts ink on your shoulder. But it doesn't really hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: Tear If you scrape a sharp <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> against your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tear</mark>. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts! Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
mnemonics.reading: は やぶ None The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark. You make this noise when you tear other things with the sharp stone too, but now it's more of a HA! TAKE THAT! Feel the same pain I feel!

mnemonics.meaning: Teardrop A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> goes through a little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark>, and plops down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teardrop</mark> coming down your eye. Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
mnemonics.reading: るい なみだ None Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ). Feel each teardrop rolling like a little wave down your cheek. You've never paid such close attention to them before. Teardrops really are just 波だ, you think. Little, ticklish waves.

mnemonics.meaning: Turtle The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turtle</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
mnemonics.reading: き かめ None You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom! See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!

mnemonics.meaning: Vinegar To make <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vinegar</mark>. Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
mnemonics.reading: さく す None You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar. Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.

mnemonics.meaning: Agreement You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agreement</mark>. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement. What did you say to the flowers that you are so in agreement about? Think about what you said.
mnemonics.reading: だく None None You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face. Imagine you are the flowers. There’s a duck. It’s making a poo. On you. Ew, man, that’s disgusting. Bleh.

mnemonics.meaning: Alliance I’ll give you this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> if you agree to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alliance</mark> with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me. Look at this bright plate. Look at it. It’s awesome. It’s blinding. Hold it in your hands. Marvel at it. Wow. This plate is sweet.
mnemonics.reading: めい None None The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad. This Mayflower boat is the best boat you ever did see.
