Hear the ocean around it as it bobs in the water, full sails billowing in the wind. Boats are cool.

mnemonics.meaning: Commander The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commander</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None Who is the commander of Japan? The Shougun (しょう)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head. You better remember the Shougun is the commander of everything... or else...

mnemonics.meaning: Dance The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nothing</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark> is still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dance</mark>! If you want to do the nothing dance, just clear your head so there's nothing in it, and then dance!
mnemonics.reading: ぶ まい, ま None To help you do this dance you need some booze (ぶ). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance. Feel the booze coursing through your veins as you dance like no one is watching.

mnemonics.meaning: Debt Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark> if your company is in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">debt</mark>. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too. Picture the leader standing up in front of everyone as they blame him. He's holding a plaque with the amount of debt you're all in. Try to imagine what that number would be.
mnemonics.reading: さい None None To pay off this debt your leader says you need to sell your cyborg (さい) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly. Watch as your cyborg saves your company, even though it wasn't even his responsibility, from crippling debt. *sob* I can't believe your cyborg is gone!

mnemonics.meaning: Deed The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> became the leader from doing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deed</mark>s. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope. Picture the leader of your branch doing deeds around your office. Pulling out chairs for people sitting down, emptying the trash, balancing spreadsheets. All good deeds.
mnemonics.reading: き, ぎ わざ None The deed he's currently working on is finding your lost key (き). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help. Picture him doing this deed. He's crawling around on the floor looking for your key. You aren't really helping, you're just watching him do the deed of key-searching for you.

mnemonics.meaning: Deer A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> are being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark>d by a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deer</mark>. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it. Picture the deer comparing the two structures. It probably has no idea what they are, but it's trying very hard to understand what it's seeing anyway.
mnemonics.reading: ろく か, しか None You walk forward, about to call out to the deer, when a car (か) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?! Deer get hit by cars all the time, but it was still really shocking . I mean it was right in front of you. The car could have hit you too!

mnemonics.meaning: Exchange You count with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> all of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> you've acquired. Soon you'll be able to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exchange</mark> with all of these body parts to get something awesome. Imagine counting all of the mouths and legs you've pummeled off of the other prisoners. Exchange them for better loot!
mnemonics.reading: かん か None You learned this type of exchange from the mighty Genghis Khan (かん). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff. Think back to when you were a kid and they would roll out those TVs on stands into the classrooms. Imagine watching a documentary on Genghis Khan's exchange routes where he bought and sold body parts. Educational!

mnemonics.meaning: Family Name Surname If there's a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, she might eventually take your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family name</mark> and make it her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surname</mark> too. In Japan and other countries, tradition dictates that women change their last name when they get married and keep that name for the rest of their life. Their partner’s family name becomes their family name too. Imagine having your surname changed for the rest of your life. How do you feel about having a different family name? Is it a big deal to you or does it not matter much?
mnemonics.reading: せい, しょう None None Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her surname to yours and taking hold of your special saber (せい) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two! Now you share a family name AND a holy blue saber! You can protect your legacy (and surname) hand in hand and saber in saber. (Or something like that.)

mnemonics.meaning: Fang Tusk The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fang</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tusk</mark>. It means fang and tusk. Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks aren’t too different from fangs, so that shouldn’t be too hard to remember either.
mnemonics.reading: げ, が きば None Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out. Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!

mnemonics.meaning: Former There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, reflecting on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">former</mark> glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree. Pretend you are the stick. Really focus on your former self as you feel the sun warm you with its rays. Imagine yourself growing, larger and larger.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう None None It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its former state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a cucumber (きゅう). I guess this stick was formerly a cucumber tree. Or maybe it just tried so hard it pooped a cucumber. I don't care which one is true, you pick whatever you want to believe.

mnemonics.meaning: Fry <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> is one of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> things you'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fry</mark> things. You need a few other things like a pan and some oil too, but fire is gonna be the most important for frying!
mnemonics.reading: しょう, そう いた, い None You love to fry things and are also an adventurous eater (いた). This means you'll fry and eat just about anything. Fried ostrich, fried alligator, fried chocolate, you name it! Your being an adventurous eater of all things fried truly knows no bounds. What cursed combination of foods will you fry up tomorrow?!

mnemonics.meaning: Generally General A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> will have at least one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">generally</mark>. In general, you can assume a boat will have a weapon, but not all of them will.
mnemonics.reading: はん None None Generally a boat with a weapon will be owned by Han (はん) Solo. So of all the boats out there, generally all of them have weapons, and generally Han Solo will be on one.

mnemonics.meaning: Harbor There’s a huge <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, caused by a giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark>, fast approaching you and your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harbor</mark>. This harbor is all you’ve got, it’s the backbone of your life. So how are you going to defend it from this tsunami caused by a giant brush?!
mnemonics.reading: しん つ None You’ll defend your harbor with your two (つ) best friends, that’s how! Luckily, your two friends specialize in defending harbors from giant brush-caused tsunamis. Quite the occupation. “How are two of my friends going to stop an entire tsunami from destroying my dear harbor?”, you might ask yourself. Well don’t ask us, we don’t specialize in brush-caused tsunami harbor defence—we’re just a kanji learning website!

mnemonics.meaning: Heal If someone is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> feed them <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heal</mark> them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up. Imagine being sick. Like sick as a dog sick. And then you take some charcoal, put it into your drinking water, and then you're healed!
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None You aren't the only one that needs to be healed, so you take your row (りょう) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink. Picture yourself rowing your row boat into the lake with huge chunks of solid charcoal. You carefully break them up and toss them over the side, so you can heal everyone.

mnemonics.meaning: Inherit With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> sews together all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> he'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inherit</mark> from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere. Picture this lion surrounded by the thousands of grains of rice he'll inherit from his parents. He's carefully threading them all together.
mnemonics.reading: けい つ None If you're going to inherit something from your parents, try to convince them to make it cake (けい), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die). I'd much rather inherit a cake than a ton of hard to keep track of rice, like this poor lion.

mnemonics.meaning: Leave Behind When you go on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, anything <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valuable</mark>, you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leave behind</mark>. Rings, necklaces, wallets, phones? Don't take them on a scooter. Leave behind all that valuable stuff!
mnemonics.reading: い, ゆい のこ None Anything you don't leave behind will be stolen by eagles (い). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter. If you keep too many of your valuables on you, the eagles might not leave you behind either! They'll just pick you up off the scooter and carry you and your valuables off to their nests!

mnemonics.meaning: Maintain You tie a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">maintain</mark> proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey. Imagine holding onto a thread that is attached to a turkey. Feel the turkey tug against the thread as you struggle to maintain control.
mnemonics.reading: い None None The reason the turkey is tugging is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread. Now you and the turkey and the eagle are all bumbling about in pandemonium. You try to maintain order but it’s not possible. What a kerfuffle.

mnemonics.meaning: Nara There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Nara</mark>. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan. Look at this big jackhammer. Look at it. It’s so big. Also it’s in Nara. Imagine being in Nara and looking at this big jackhammer. You’re all like, dang – that’s a big jackhammer.
mnemonics.reading: な None None What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy. Just keep in mind what the first part of Nara is. The first part of Nara is “na” so you’ll have no trouble remembering this one.

mnemonics.meaning: Nucleus You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> it until you reach its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nucleus</mark>. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible. Imagine slicing this tree smaller and smaller until you finally get to the nucleus of it. It’s super tiny so you have to view it in a microscope. What does it look like?
mnemonics.reading: かく None None It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird. Look at this tree nucleus that looks like a cock. While you’re watching it, the nucleus goes “Cock-a-doodle-doo!”

mnemonics.meaning: Obsolete This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, after your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">departure</mark>, will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obsolete</mark>. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone. During your departure you look back at the obsolete canopy just once. It's standing there, still and alone. It's a really sad sight.
mnemonics.reading:
はい すた None When something becomes obsolete, you must write a haiku (はい). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect. My sweet canopy
I don't need you anymore
You are obsolete

mnemonics.meaning: Offer The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">South</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dog</mark> gives you an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offer</mark>. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything. It is well known that dogs in the South are famous for their kindness and hospitality. It's customary to always offer something when a guest arrives.
mnemonics.reading: けん, こん たてまつ None The South Dog offers you the services of Ken (けん) the samurai as you traverse his lands. Ken offers to carry you, too. Imagine him offering this. You can choose whether or not to accept in your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: Open Sea There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">open sea</mark>. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone. Look at this tsunami in the middle of the open sea. When the tsunami isn’t destroying things and is just out there in the open sea it looks really majestic and pretty.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう おき None Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”. You really regret saying oki doki this time. You don’t want to surf on a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Imagine doing so. It’s terrifying and wet and you don’t even know how to surf. You’re going to die.

mnemonics.meaning: Pickle <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark>d because they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pickle</mark> everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami. Imagine a tsunami crashing over the land, being blamed by everyone. In its path are piles and piles of pickles, as far as the eye can see!
mnemonics.reading: None つ None Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one. Picture the two pickles and imagine what kind of pickles they are.

mnemonics.meaning: Pluck Stick your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pluck</mark> each hair out, one by one. Imagine plucking the hairs out of your mohawk with your fingers. It's kind of hard to grab onto them at first, but eventually you're plucking them like it's nothing.
mnemonics.reading: てき つ None You want to pluck all your mohawk hair out because you're a techie (てき), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in. You didn't realize techies were so inclusive... but they just plucked and plucked at your self-esteem, until you decided to pluck your hair out of your own head.

mnemonics.meaning: Reach <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Escalator</mark>s are used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reach</mark> things. Imagine yourself on an escalator. What is up above that you’re trying to reach?
mnemonics.reading: きゅう およ None You're riding the escalator trying to reach a delicious cucumber (きゅう). Cucumbers grow on trees sometimes, so you need to take escalators to get up there and reach them.

mnemonics.meaning: Reliant Dependent A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> that he is quite <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reliant</mark> on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader! Imagine this leader in his clothes. Look how reliant he is on them. Imagine what he would be without his clothes – nothing! And also, naked.
mnemonics.reading: い よ None The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore. Look at the leader as he shouts at his clothes he’s become so reliant on to do something. Hear the countless eagles screeching around as they terrorize the neighborhood. People scream and weep in the streets.

mnemonics.meaning: Rope Someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>ed a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle</mark> into long skinny pieces, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rope</mark>. A rope made of threaded turtles. Go ahead and grab onto it and see how it feels. A little rough, but strong.
mnemonics.reading: じょう なわ None The person making these threaded turtle ropes is none other than the local farmhand Joe (じょう). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope. Besides being awful, where did Joe learn to thread turtles into ropes? Why does he have so many turtles despite living on such an inland farm? These are nice ropes that Joe is making though, and you kind of want to buy some.

mnemonics.meaning: Salmon What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> jumps from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salmon</mark>! When you're at the river watching salmon jumping up stream, they keep jumping onto the dirt, flopping back into the water, then doing it again.
mnemonics.reading: かい, けい さけ, しゃけ None You make a drinking game out of watching the salmon going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of 酒 (さけ). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more さけ but it comes out as しゃけ. Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink... "Ughhh.... I'm feeling tipsy... Hey, where's my しゃけ!?"

mnemonics.meaning: Step You soak each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> before going out in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to take your first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">step</mark>. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once. Imagine each step on hot, sun-baked asphalt. The water under your feet sizzles, leaving steaming footprints where you stepped from.
mnemonics.reading: とう ふ None Each step you take brings you closer to とうきょう. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes. Each step is taking you closer to とうきょう. Don't forget that, no matter how hard it seems, don't lose your motivation to keep stepping forward toward your goal. ♡

mnemonics.meaning: Stretch A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stretch</mark> in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us. The leader is humble and human, just like the rest of us, and has to stretch to stay healthy too. He's not some kind of god!
mnemonics.reading: しん の None The leader is currently working hard to stretch in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some nori (の) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too. Watch as the leader stretches his body and the nori seaweed. He takes a bite, stretches the other way, then stretches out a piece for you to eat too. How humble of him!

mnemonics.meaning: Sweet The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweet</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.
mnemonics.reading: かん あま None The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet-resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload. Put on the armor! Feel the sweetness begin to reflect off your armored body. Only a little gets through — just enough for the sweet flavor on your tongue to taste sweet, but not too sweet.

mnemonics.meaning: Trade You send your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> man out with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> so he can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trade</mark> them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired! Imagine your private sword holding a big bag of shellfish and going off to market to trade them.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None While he's out making the trade for you, you decide to relax and do some bowling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you. Oh boy, I hope my private sword trades my shellfish for that new bowling ball I heard about!

mnemonics.meaning: Trust A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s is something you can always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trust</mark>. A bundle of geoducks will never lie, never let you down, and never disappoint you. You can trust them completely.
mnemonics.reading: らい たの, たよ None While you can trust a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust rye (らい) bread. Imagine a bundle of geoducks and a piece rye bread. Think about how you can trust the geoducks but you can't trust the rye bread.

mnemonics.meaning: Ultra Super You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> out to people at the same time because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">super</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ultra</mark> excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling. You're going for an ultra run, calling out with your super loud voice right down the middle of the street.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう こ None You're just becoming ultra tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams. Mrs. Chou is super ultra scary. And if you don't kick it into super ultra high gear she's going to catch up to you and make you super ultra dead.

mnemonics.meaning: Uncle Aunt There were lots of things that were <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> you when you were <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> that you would need a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to reach, so you just asked your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aunt</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">uncle</mark> to get them for you. Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
mnemonics.reading: しゅく None お You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet. You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!

mnemonics.meaning: Well Up When you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">courage</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">well up</mark> inside you, giving you the power to save everyone before you get washed away! Really feel the courage welling up inside of you in the face of this terrifying tsunami. Connect it to some physical feeling—perhaps you can feel it welling up in your chest.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう わ None Whom does that courage well up inside of? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero! Who wells up with courage? You do!

mnemonics.meaning: Width You want to put this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> over this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark>, but you have to measure its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">width</mark> first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want. The scarecrow creeps you out. You don't want to look at it anymore, so you're standing eerily close to it measuring its width, so you can hide it forever.
mnemonics.reading: ふく はば None You finish measuring the width of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a habanero (はば) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up. Do you know the width of a habanero? It's one scarecrow minus one cloth.

mnemonics.meaning: Afflicted A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skewer</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> has <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">afflicted</mark> your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying. You did not wish to be afflicted as such. Feel the skewer in your heart and the great pain it gives you. You know you’re dying.
mnemonics.reading: かん わずら None Since you’re afflicted with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know." You look on in horror as the affliction grabs hold and everything starts to fade, but Genghis Khan still floats before you, watching you closely.

mnemonics.meaning: Aim You see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aim</mark> at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal. It's much easier to aim for an animal wearing a top hat than one without.
mnemonics.reading: そ ねら None Ready, steady, aim... fire! You throw a bar of soap (そ) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye. Your aim with the soap is perfect! The soap knocked the animal's hat right off.

mnemonics.meaning: Army Camp This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>s because it's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">army camp</mark>. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers. Picture an army camp housing all of the different cars the army needs at any given time.
mnemonics.reading: じん None None All of the people in the army camp are wearing jeans (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're in the camp they have to wear jeans. Jeans are pretty durable, now that you think about it. And if the soldiers are working on these cars in the camp while they're there, it makes sense to wear a nice pair of jeans.

mnemonics.meaning: Base Baseball Base Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> shakes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, exposing a hidden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">base</mark>. A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">baseball base</mark>! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field… Picture a serene rice paddy. Now watch the whole thing explode, rice and dirt going everywhere, and a secret, underground baseball base is left there, smoldering.
mnemonics.reading: るい None None Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the base is in ruins (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game. Hold this ruined baseball base in your hands. Hey, maybe it's a collectible?

mnemonics.meaning: Bullet What's like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, but even more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bullet</mark>. With a bow, you have to load an arrow and pull back the string and aim, yuck. Bullets can be shot with just a simple squeeze of a trigger. Imagine how simple life would be if we replaced all the bows in the world with bullets. (Insert sarcastic crying face here.)
mnemonics.reading: だん ひ, はず, たま None If you want to shoot bullets, you need to do it at dawn (だん). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use! Imagine shooting bullets into the sun at dawn. Pow pow, take that history! Blam blam, take that dawn!

mnemonics.meaning: Burial You brought flowers to leave at the place where a yakuza took a spoon and killed twenty people, since there's now a burial happening there. You didn't know these people, but you still want to leave flowers at their burial. Give a yakuza a spoon and you always get 死 (death), in this case twenty times. So it's honestly not surprising that things would end with commemorative flowers and a burial.
mnemonics.reading: そう ほうむ None Once the burial is complete the souls (そう) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky. I guess the twenty souls couldn't go up to... wherever... until they had a proper burial.

mnemonics.meaning: Confront You take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and slam a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>. You make this big noise to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confront</mark> the person in front of you. They weren't listening, which is why you slammed that lid down. You'll have to confront them more directly.
mnemonics.reading: こう あらが None You are trying to confront Emperor こういち. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here こういち! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?" こういち is laughing at you as you confront him. Which makes you angrier, so you bang the lid on the table some more.

mnemonics.meaning: Crumble Below this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> crash into each other and the entire thing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crumble</mark>s to pieces. Watch as the moons crumble together, and then the mountain slowly crumbles down into them too.
mnemonics.reading: ほう くず None As the mountain crumbles you see your home (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too. Your home crumbles like a dry cookie until it's nothing more than a bunch of dust, mixed in with the mountain and the moon. Now where will you live?

mnemonics.meaning: Dispatch On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dispatch</mark>!" Imagine the conversation with emergency services. They say they will dispatch an ambulance immediately.
mnemonics.reading: けん つか, や None Out of the dispatched ambulance jumps Ken (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect." He takes out a very tiny katana and performs surgery right there. The insect dies on the scooter. "It looks like I've dispatched this insect to the afterlife."

mnemonics.meaning: Display Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shines into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> cell and hold your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> up in full <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">display</mark>. Picture the sun reflecting off your metal prison spoon as you hold it aloft in your fingers. It hurts your eyes a little, but it also draws everyone's attention to this spoon you want to display.
mnemonics.reading: けい かか None The reason you display it is to get some cake (けい). In this prison, if you display your spoon deftly enough, the wardens bring you some cake as a reward. It's gotta be a spoon because forks are too pointy and dangerous for prison, by the way. So imagine eating your cake with the spoon you just displayed, big spoonfuls of cake frosting filling your mouth with every bite.

mnemonics.meaning: Explode If you combine <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">violence</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">explode</mark>! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM! Imagine the fire explode. Feel the heat of the fire and the explosion. It’s very violent. BOOM BOOM BA-BOOM!
mnemonics.reading: ばく は None As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe. Imagine yourself as you back away from the explosion. As you back away, see the fire dance and feel the heat of the explosion on your face.

mnemonics.meaning: Eyebrows You're holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s to imitate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eyebrows</mark>. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do. Look at yourself in the mirror. You can see the stick holding up the flag and it's very clear you drew some eyebrows onto the flag with some markers, but you still look pretty good (in your opinion).
mnemonics.reading: み, び まゆ None Underneath your fake eyebrows are two slabs of meat (み). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags. Imagine walking around town, holding your eyebrow flags. You can feel the meat sticking above your eyes. They stink and they're weirdly lukewarm, but you know your real eyebrows will grow under them any day now.

mnemonics.meaning: Favor You carry a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> on it to return a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">favor</mark> for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it. This is a pretty big favor. Imagine running through a rice paddy carrying a cross with a warm beating heart on it. Thump thump. Thump thump.
mnemonics.reading: え, けい めぐ None You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine! Imagine how dumb you feel at this miscommunication. Eh? You don’t feel dumb? Well you should!

mnemonics.meaning: Fight At this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> you're trying to get some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> through, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurements</mark> were off, leading to a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fight</mark>. The bean authorities at the gate always want to fight about bean sizes, and now you have to fight to get those beans through. Imagine having to fight against the bean bureaucracy. It's so absurd! Who can say a bean is too big or too small, in this age of diversity?! Your fighting pays off though, and they let you squeeze your beans through the gate. Well fought, bean brethren. Well fought.
mnemonics.reading: とう たたか None The gate you put up a fight at leads to とうきょう. The people of とうきょう need those beans for sustenance, and that's why you fight — for them! How are you supposed to get your beans into とうきょう if a fight breaks out at the gate every time? What a struggle. Fortunately those bean-counting bureaucrats of とうきょう were no match for your fight.

mnemonics.meaning: Fishing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> pushes all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> closer to land, making for some easy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fishing</mark>. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish. Imagine going fishing for fish in a fishing spot after a tsunami. There are SO many fish here. Your hook barely touches the water and there’s already a fish on it. Man, fishing like this is easy! Smell the smell of fish and sea air around you.
mnemonics.reading: ぎょ, りょう あさ None To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea. Go! Go row! Go and row for the fishing! How do you go? You row! The row part should be pretty easy to remember since you gotta row your boat out to sea, but if you’re having trouble with the go part, just remember that it has the same reading as 魚.

mnemonics.meaning: Fragrance <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark> left in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> blossom and give off a wonderful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fragrance</mark>. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain. Imagine this warm, grain fragrance. What does it smell like to you? Cooked rice? Gentle flowers? A warm summer's day?
mnemonics.reading: こう, きょう かお, か None As you sniff this lovely fragrance you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming こういち standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs." This fragrance was こういち's armpits the whole time. You thought it was warm grains. Or... maybe he smells like... grains?

mnemonics.meaning: Gulf <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s hit these lands <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, molding it into some kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> shape. Or in other words, creating a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gulf</mark>. Picture these extremely violent tsunamis hitting a shore again and again, turning it into a bow-shaped gulf. That's how gulfs are created in this part of the world!
mnemonics.reading: わん None None How many gulfs will this create? Just one (わん). Many tsunamis, again and again, for just one gulf? Yep, that's just how life goes. Gulfs are in high demand, but you'll need many tsunamis to create just one.

mnemonics.meaning: Hop Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> heard an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> and now it's making you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hop</mark> over things. Imagine your foot hearing this omen, "If you step on a crack, you'll break your mother's back." Now your foot hops over all of the tiny cracks in the street and the sidewalk and you look really silly.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう と, は None As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!" Now you're hopping away in fear from Mrs. Chou!

mnemonics.meaning: Hug Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> them around another person. This is called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hug</mark>. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people. Picture it like you're a baby who is new to hugs. You start with your fingers, spread them out and move forward. Now wrap all that stuff attached to your fingers around another person. You did it! You're hugging now!
mnemonics.reading: ほう だ, かか, いだ None Who do you love to hug the most? Your dad (だ)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving. Imagine getting a nice, big hug from your dad. Mm. It's cozy and feels like home.

mnemonics.meaning: In Season Ten Days When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> holds the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> inside it, everything will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">in season</mark>. Obviously if the sun is in prison, the seasons can't change. Want to eat perfect apples all year round? Just put the sun in prison when they're ripe — usually a short window of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten days</mark>. You're welcome. Now you know how to keep everything in season. Lifehack!
mnemonics.reading: しゅん, じゅん None None When things are in season for more than ten days, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? Soon (しゅん), you say. Soon enough, it's June (じゅん). Which is the middle of the year, so now everything is soon. Joke's on them though. Soon it will be apple season. Soon it will always be time for apples. Soon June will end and people will forget about everything else, living forever inside that period of ten days when apples are most in season.

mnemonics.meaning: Listen When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>ed with sound, it catches it like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark>, and sends it to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">listen</mark>. Imagine the whole process of sound going through your ear and to your heart, then the gears turning to really understand what someone is saying. It's a real listen, not a fake non-heart listen.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう き None You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth. Focus on listening, and focus on their message about Mrs. Chou. Feel afraid about the future because of it.

mnemonics.meaning: Look To You give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> along with some other <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look to</mark>. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products. Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
mnemonics.reading: りん のぞ None After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well. Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.

mnemonics.meaning: Omen Trillion The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">omen</mark> kanji are the same! If you know the omen radical, you know the omen kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: ちょう きざ None You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world. You can clarify with the person telling you the omen several things: "Do you believe in the omen about Mrs. Chou destroying the world?" "When will this omen about Mrs. Chou come true?" etc. As long as you're associating omen with Mrs. Chou you should be good, so keep harping on that. Anyway, whenever you hear any kind of omen (omen is a radical in the kanji), there's a good chance it's going to be about Mrs. Chou.

mnemonics.meaning: Pledge The weight of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pledge</mark> to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword. Imagine holding up your sword and pledging to protect the lives of everyone in this city. It's a big deal!
mnemonics.reading: けい None None Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food. Would you pledge to give up cake to show everyone how serious you are about protecting life?

mnemonics.meaning: Punish Destroy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and you'll be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">punish</mark>ed. Even if it was your own lantern, why stab it with a knife? You could have recycled that. I will punish you for lantern stabbing and pollution!
mnemonics.reading: けい None None I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment. The next time you want to stab a lantern with a knife, think about how good cake tastes and stop. Remember, DARE (Don't Attack Reusable Electronics)!

mnemonics.meaning: Recruit A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> is the newest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of the city you decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recruit</mark>. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless. Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
mnemonics.reading: ぼ つの None After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse. Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.

mnemonics.meaning: Reparation The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> presents you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prize</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reparation</mark> for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize. Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
mnemonics.reading: しょう つぐな None The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for). Imagine receiving your reparations from the Shougun himself. You're angry at him for threatening you, wounding people, and cutting off the heads of people who go against him, but you take it anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: Resist Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> join the rest of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark>, pressed into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to declare that you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resist</mark> your lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on! Imagine your entire clan putting their fingers in the ground as a form of resistance. It's a moving sight.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!" You make your choice to resist. He orders his guards to pull your fingers out of the ground, chop them into the size of tater tots, and then deep fry them. After they're done, the lord pops one in his mouth and says, "Oooh, resistance is delicious."

mnemonics.meaning: Return This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> and you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return</mark> it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them. Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
mnemonics.reading: れい もど None You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode. You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.

mnemonics.meaning: Shining The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>s out to the earth by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shining</mark> down on it. The sun doesn't have a voice, unfortunately, so it calls out the only way it can, with its shining rays.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan. Picture the Shougun standing in the shining sunlight. He's so bright and beautiful!

mnemonics.meaning: Silk Put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a worm while the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is out and it will poop out some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">silk</mark>. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen. Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
mnemonics.reading: けん きぬ None Wearing silk is the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it! Picture yourself wearing nothing but silk. Silk shirt, silk pants, even silk underwear. It feels great against the skin! And most importantly, you're not nude.

mnemonics.meaning: Skewer Spit The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skewer</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skewer</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Know your radicals, yo.
mnemonics.reading: None くし None Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it. Imagine trying to use this cushy skewer. It's the right shape (long, thin, pointy at one end), but every time you try to put something on it it squishes in on itself like a long marshmallow.

mnemonics.meaning: Tenacious Carry Out <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Happiness</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tenacious</mark>. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can. Be tenacious about happiness in your life. No matter how many times it slips away, don't give up. Keep going after it, because it will absolutely come back if you're tenacious enough.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう, しつ と None Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it. Will someone take the shoe sometimes? Yeah, but the shih tzu doesn't give up. That's how you need to be with happiness. Kids, be tenacious!

mnemonics.meaning: Traces When you're stepping around with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, you'll leave behind <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">traces</mark> all over the place. Picture yourself stepping around with your foot again and again, leaving traces all over the place. Anyone would be able to trace you like this, but you just love a good little stomping around.
mnemonics.reading: せき あと None Turns out you leaving traces everywhere is quite sexy (せき) to a lot of people. You're absolutely surrounded by all these people attracted to your sexy stomping around with your foot, again and again. Look, no shaming here, whatever floats your boat.

mnemonics.meaning: Whittle Down A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whittle down</mark> anything. Imagine the triceratops with its little moon knife, doing some whittling. Hand it anything and it will whittle it down.
mnemonics.reading: さく けず None Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく). Check out the sack that holds all the things that the triceratops whittled down. Go ahead and look through it, it's quite filled.

mnemonics.meaning: Accompany A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> asks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">half</mark> of his men to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him. Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
mnemonics.reading: はん ともな None The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome. Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.

mnemonics.meaning: Age You get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tooth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">age</mark>. You get baby age tooth orders (to get your first teeth). You get child age tooth orders (to get your adult teeth). Then you get old age tooth orders (when you start losing your teeth). There are tooth orders for every age.
mnemonics.reading: れい よわい None Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun. Decide what age you have to be to get your first ray gun, and then imagine getting it when you hit that age. Perhaps you use this ray gun on your teeth, to keep them clean. Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: Best Regards By showing the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you send your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">best regards</mark>. Giving your best regards is basically just tipping your hat and showing the roof of it.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ よろ None When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person. YOLO means "you only live once," so in a way that's a good way to give your best regards. At the very least, it's an interesting way.

mnemonics.meaning: Bite Chew Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tooth</mark> that you use to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bite</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chew</mark> with. Imagine that one tooth in your mouth chewing through everything. It's not easy to chew with only one tooth, but luckily yours is huge and razor-sharp, so it helps you to bite and chew your way through anything you like.
mnemonics.reading: None か, かじ None Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to bite and chew up a whole car (か). Some people like eating cars, and you're one of them. You can't get enough of those delicious cars. You just bite them apart and chew.

mnemonics.meaning: Bribe The more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark>, the more you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bribe</mark> people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood. Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
mnemonics.reading: わい まかな None Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?! Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything? And you counter with. Why not?

mnemonics.meaning: Bribe Someone is offering you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> in exchange for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>. This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bribe</mark>! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty. "Come on, don't you want this shellfish?" they ask, shaking it up and down at you.
mnemonics.reading: ろ None None You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!! This is why you never accept a bribe. One second you're staring a yummy shellfish in the face, and the next you're standing alone in the road feeling used.

mnemonics.meaning: Cluster The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> in that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> is among a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cluster</mark> of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it. Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう ふさ None After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly! Watch as clusters of pins fall when the bowling balls hit them. You back up and peek through one of the other doors in the cluster and it also houses a bowling alley. Huh.

mnemonics.meaning: Consider A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> needs to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">think</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consider</mark> its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation. Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. And you need to consider how you're going to escape from this tiger.
mnemonics.reading: りょ おもんぱく, おもんぱか None Finally, the tiger speaks: "I'm considering going to Rio (りょ). Have you ever been?" Imagine your relief when you realize this tiger isn't considering you as prey, but is considering whether to visit Rio de Janeiro and just wants your advice. There are no tigers in South America, so I guess it's natural for one to consider Rio in its vacation plans.

mnemonics.meaning: Consign They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> if you put things on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> things to be exact, that’s the best way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consign</mark> goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em. Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
mnemonics.reading: たく かこ None One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt. Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Contrary <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Past</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>s usually depict images <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contrary</mark> to current views. Look at this stamp. There's Columbus being hugged by a bunch of South American natives. Yikes, that's contrary to how things went, that's for sure.
mnemonics.reading: きゃく かえ None Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people. Be contrary to the evildoers of the past and be like Kyaku instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Cord Connection, Mood The kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you'd wrap around <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> would have to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cord</mark>. A regular thread wouldn't be strong enough, so you'd definitely use a cord. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connection</mark>, since cords create connections (by tying things together). Imagine taking that cord and wrapping it around someone (with their permission, of course). Feel your fingers tightening a knot in the cord. Then tie the other end around yourself. Is this some freaky ritual to deepen your connection to them, or… ? Hey, no judgment from me.
mnemonics.reading: しょ, ちょ お None Actually, you're tying this cord around someone as part of a show (しょ). What kind of a show? I really shouldn't say. This cord show isn't free, I'll tell you that much. Imagine doing this cord show on stage. Feel the heat of the stage lights and the gaze of the audience as your tie your cord. What are they expecting? Why did they pay to see this? Must be some kind of modern performance art — let's go with that.

mnemonics.meaning: Demand In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> I take my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> and shake it, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">demand</mark> that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it! Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ None None Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box. Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.

mnemonics.meaning: Disc Jade Disc You offer a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>, and he gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disc</mark>. And not just any old disc at that. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jade disc</mark>. Have you ever seen ancient Chinese jade discs with holes in the middle? That's what this kanji is referring to. You took a long time to pick out the perfect hot pepper. Only the best for the king, right? It burned your hands a little as you held it on your way to the palace. You were hoping for something pretty special in return, but you never imagined it would be a drop that magically turns into a disc. Wow!
mnemonics.reading: へき None None Wait, did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on? You start to realize just how crazy the situation is. Seriously. How the heck is a drop able to turn into a jade disc?

mnemonics.meaning: Do A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">do</mark> whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it. They do most of their own chores during the rest of the year, so winter is when you should ask them to do things for you.
mnemonics.reading: ち いた None To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち). Moles will do anything for cheese, but honestly, wouldn't we all?

mnemonics.meaning: Dodge Avoid You're on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and suddenly someone throws a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark> at you and you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dodge</mark> it. Imagine riding your scooter, dodging multiple hot peppers as they're tossed at you. A few of them get stuck in the wheels and keep coming around and around, and you have to dodge them too.
mnemonics.reading: ひ さ, よ None As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating. Feel the heat flow through your body. It's getting harder to dodge as the heat grows and you start sweating!

mnemonics.meaning: Draw With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> you pluck some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw</mark> them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them, you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone. Imagine using your fingers to draw these rice paddy flowers. Don't worry about how well you can draw. These flowers will look beautiful no matter how you draw them.
mnemonics.reading: びょう か, えが None Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O. To be fair, would you want to look at a drawing that makes you constantly smell stinky B.O.? I didn't think so.

mnemonics.meaning: Edition You got your copy of "The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dry</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Knife</mark>." It's the newest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edition</mark> of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry. You're really into this magazine, and when you heard there's a new edition of it, you went out and bought it right away.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning. The article on Genghis Khan was perhaps the best written article in the Dry Knife series to date. How did this magazine get such a big interview?

mnemonics.meaning: Escape You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> when the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> comes so that you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">escape</mark>. Unfortunately, the omen is riding a scooter too, so you're going to have to be crafty to escape this omen properly.
mnemonics.reading: とう に, のが, の None You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way. Imagine scooting in and out of とうきょう traffic, the omen looming ever further back behind you. You're doing it! You're escaping!

mnemonics.meaning: Handle Where do you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when you're on an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark>? On the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">handle</mark>! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead. Imagine being on an escalator and wrapping your fingers around a small handle on your way up or down. It's still a bit precarious, truth be told.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう あつか None You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him. 暑か? Is the handle hot? Think about it. Is it? What does your imagination tell you?

mnemonics.meaning: Interior If there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>, you know you’re in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interior</mark>. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
mnemonics.reading: おう おく None While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!” If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.

mnemonics.meaning: Join A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> and searches for people to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">join</mark> him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern. Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
mnemonics.reading: へい あわ None The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him. The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.

mnemonics.meaning: Knee Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> beneath a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> filled with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">knee</mark> in it. Feel the water splash over your knee as you stick it into this hat.
