It fits really well, the hat is the perfect size for your knee. Now look up at the moonlight filtering through the tree above.
mnemonics.reading: None ひざ None Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hot water!! Imagine the heat then the zap going through your knee. It isn't a nice heat, it's a hot heat, then BZZZT zap! Your knee was heat zapped pretty bad.

mnemonics.meaning: Lean You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> because you want it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lean</mark>. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead. Why do you want this geoduck to lean? Try to come up with your own reason. And why don't you look up what a geoduck looks like one more time for good measure. You don't want to be able to get this image out of your head.
mnemonics.reading: けい かたむ None To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides. Watch as the geoduck slowly leans toward the cake, trying to get at it for a taste. But don't let it eat any! Keep putting the cake further and further away so the geoduck has to lean more.

mnemonics.meaning: Loose The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loose</mark>. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing. Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
mnemonics.reading: かん ゆる None You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man! Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.

mnemonics.meaning: Play Music When it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play music</mark>. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up. Close your eyes and imagine all of the spring sounds that come down to you from heaven in the springtime. Mmm, you can almost smell the damp soil and rain.
mnemonics.reading: そう かな None In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band! Picture all of the souls in heaven playing spring music together!

mnemonics.meaning: Pregnant A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> getting ready inside her is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pregnant</mark>. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide. Picture an ultrasound of the pregnant woman, but instead of a little baby heartbeat, you hear a scary roaring sound. That's what being pregnant is like. Waiting for the landslide to come.
mnemonics.reading: しん None None When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you. Imagine being pregnant and getting kicked by the shins of your baby all day, but especially all night. You're so tired. Please let this landslide come already.

mnemonics.meaning: Pregnant A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sleeps with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> and becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pregnant</mark>. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby! The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
mnemonics.reading: にん None None Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore. What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.

mnemonics.meaning: Presents You put on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">presents</mark>. You're like beach santa, except you're real and you wear a mask made of shellfish.
mnemonics.reading:
ぞう おく None The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses. Ooh hoo, it's me! the Shellfish Mask Man!
I go to beach houses and leave presents where I can!
The presents are not clothes, or anything good.
I don't even care if you leave me some food.
Try whipping some up, try cooking me peas,
It matters not, I'll leave you zombies! Tee hee hee hee hee!

mnemonics.meaning: Select Shove your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> into a bowl of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">select</mark> the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most. Feel your fingers touching each and every shrimp, one by one, until they graze the one you select as the perfect shrimp. Slowly pull it out and lower it into your mouth. Munch munch... ahhh! The perfect shrimp.
mnemonics.reading: たく えら None You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)! Oh, woe is me! How will I select the perfect shrimp with my fingers if there are tacks in the shrimp bowls! Boohoohoo!

mnemonics.meaning: Send Back There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> coming toward you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> trapping a weird <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">send back</mark> the zombie. (It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt!) You want to send back this zombie the way it came. You definitely don't want it loose in your neighborhood.
mnemonics.reading: かん かえ None As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came! You managed to send back the zombie, good for you! Genghis Khan would be proud.

mnemonics.meaning: Spin You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark> and you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spin</mark> them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head. Imagine carefully dripping syrup onto a thread and then spinning it in a circle.
mnemonics.reading: そう く None As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air. Imagine eating a syrup cookie you made by spinning it yourself. Homemade is always better than store-bought.

mnemonics.meaning: Suppress Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suppress</mark> him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you. Imagine suppressing a cat pirate with your own fingers. His fur is so soft, but his nails are so sharp!
mnemonics.reading: よく おさ None He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force. Defend the yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you suppress the cat pirate. Maybe even share the yolk with him, once he's done trying to kill you for it. And then enjoy breakfast while petting your new cat friend.

mnemonics.meaning: Suspend In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prefecture</mark>, you come from a long <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> of people who share one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suspend</mark>s itself in the sky, for you to take. You see the suspended heart in the distance, and make your way towards it.
mnemonics.reading: けん か None You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai. "I've protected this suspended heart for you, for you are next in the lineage to receive it." He grabs the heart and throws it into your body.

mnemonics.meaning: Title You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> and fashion it into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>, earning you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">title</mark> of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations! This isn't exactly a title you're proud of, in fact, you're really embarrassed. Maybe you can make a name for yourself in something else so you can get a new title.
mnemonics.reading: しょう とな, たた, ほめ None Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it. The plaque says, "No one is more deserving of this SAD title." - Love, the Shougun.

mnemonics.meaning: Tray Platter, Board Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> holds your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>. So in a way, it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tray</mark> for your weapon. A big boat shaped like a plate is just a tray. You keep your weapons on it, nice and flat.
mnemonics.reading: ばん None None Unfortunately, this boat tray is so huge, it's gotten you banned (ばん) from the Small Boat Tray Association. Those pesky small boat tray enthusiasts... Your ban from the Small Boat Tray Association has led to a massive feud between large boat tray enthusiasts and small boat tray enthusiasts, and it seems like it'll never end—leading to bans all over the place. If only we could all come together as enthusiasts of boat trays of all sizes...

mnemonics.meaning: Abstain Raise your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sky</mark> to symbolize that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abstain</mark> from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain. Abstaining from doing what other people are doing is important sometimes. So make sure you never forget the universal abstaining symbol.
mnemonics.reading: こう ひか None This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee are endangered. So people started to rally around them, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming these hicatee!" Picture yourself in Central America. Standing in the water, blocking poachers from the hicatee turtles. "Abstain!" you shout at them.

mnemonics.meaning: Address On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> you meet with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>s. All snakes know your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">address</mark>. You're snake famous. Snakes go on a pilgrimage to your address every evening. Your address is passed down from snake generation to snake generation.
mnemonics.reading: えん あて None The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて). "You only give a 手 a night. Newcomers might have a 手 or two, but some snakes who have been coming to your address for years have hundreds of 手s. They are human hands."

mnemonics.meaning: Allocate The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">allocate</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: じゅう あ, み None If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever. Picture all the jewels you were able to buy because you allocated your funds correctly. Imagine swimming in these jewels. Like a rich duck.

mnemonics.meaning: Bitter Astringent, Reluctant There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and you can't <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bitter</mark>ness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">astringent</mark>. This word also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reluctant</mark>, because wouldn't you be reluctant to let a tsunami come wash you away with that bitter explosion of flavor in your mouth? You're reluctant to face this bitter end at the hands of a tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう しぶ None With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it. Try to stuff some of the jewels into your bitter mouth before the tsunami stops you.

mnemonics.meaning: Branch Off A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch off</mark> from the rest. Picture this part of the mountain, branching off from the rest, into a mysterious path of its own.
mnemonics.reading: き, ぎ None None If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ). If you branch off from the beaten path, you need 1) access, and 2) to be really careful so you keep your head.

mnemonics.meaning: Buzzer Small Bell You take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> in exchange for executing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> to construct a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buzzer</mark>. You are a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small bell</mark> maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living. Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put it together.
mnemonics.reading: りん, れい すず None Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do. Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.

mnemonics.meaning: Cape This hunk of dirt sticks out in a very odd way. Oh, wait, it's just the cape jutting out into the water below. Phew. This kanji looks a lot like 崎, and it also has the same "cape" meaning! By "cape" I mean those big hunks of land that jut out into the sea, you know?
mnemonics.reading: き さい None The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories. Picture the cape (the land mass that sticks out into water) but it's shaped just like your old cyborg. Weep a single tear.

mnemonics.meaning: Chess Piece A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> breaks into your games cabinet and steals a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chess piece</mark>. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set. Imagine finding this tree crab in your games cabinet trying to make off with your chess piece. This tree crab is big and you weren’t expecting to find it in your games cabinet so you’re kind of terrified. You scream in horror.
mnemonics.reading: き ご None Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what? You put the key in your pocket and call animal control. They unlock the cabinet with the key and remove the tree crab from your home. But who’s to say he won’t be back??

mnemonics.meaning: Criminal Inside this giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>, trapped, because they're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">criminal</mark>. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals. Picture the criminal, trapped inside the mouth. They don't even look sorry!
mnemonics.reading: しゅう とら None The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise. Wearing nothing but shoes is also really uncomfortable too, so it's actually part of the criminal's punishment. They don't seem to know that though.

mnemonics.meaning: Defer When you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Nurse</mark>!" you're probably asking to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defer</mark> to them in some way, shape, or form. There's many situations where you'd want to defer to a nurse, like when somebody is seriously hurt and you don't know what to do to help them. Just imagine yourself saying "Nurse!" in order to defer to them for their medical knowledge.
mnemonics.reading: じょう ゆず None The reason you’re trying to defer to a nurse is because you’re trying to save the local farmhand, Joe (じょう). He’s seriously injured, and you don’t know how to help him, so you’ll have to defer to the knowledge of a nurse. You’re starting to panic because you don’t know to help Joe, so you’re just going around saying “Nurse! Nurse!” repeatedly, desperately looking for someone you could defer to. Nurse!!!

mnemonics.meaning: Employ In through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> walks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">employ</mark> it. You've always employed any turkey that comes through that door. Imagine hundreds of turkeys walking in. The word has gotten out amongst the turkey community that if they walk through your door, you'll employ them.
mnemonics.reading: こ やと None Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away. "I will employ turkeys, but I will never employ children!" you exclaim.

mnemonics.meaning: Excuse The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excuse</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Dandy! Know your radicals, stop making excuses.
mnemonics.reading: めん まぬか None Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway. Imagine all the men you’ve talked to in your life. Think of every excuse they’ve told you. Think of the worst excuse you’ve ever heard. Remember that.

mnemonics.meaning: Flock Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">buddy</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> is part of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flock</mark>. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock. Imagine following your sheep buddy back to his flock. Feel the soft fur of all the sheep around you as they baa peacefully.
mnemonics.reading: ぐん む, むら None Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun. Feel the recoil of the gun in your hands and the ringing of the shots in your ears as you slaughter the flock without remorse. BANG BANG BANG!

mnemonics.meaning: Frame In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> branches are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frame</mark>s. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one. Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
mnemonics.reading: None わく None You realize that the frame isn't half as nice as you thought it was, in fact it's totally wack (わく). How disappointing. Why is this frame so wack? Think about what makes it wack, to help you remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Gun Take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> it to buy a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gun</mark>. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins or bricks. Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう None None You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store! Picture an old fashioned holdup. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!

mnemonics.meaning: Hermit A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who lives in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hermit</mark>. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now. Imagine this odd hermit leading mountain goats around the mountain, marching to the beat of a drum. It’s a strange sight indeed.
mnemonics.reading: せん None None One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur (せん). The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel. Picture this old hermit fighting this centaur in a duel. Who do you think is gonna win? Hear the hermit screaming in agony as the centaur demolishes him.

mnemonics.meaning: Home Country There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">three</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s sticking out of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that lead to your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home country</mark>. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours. Imagine standing at the top of the building and looking down at the three slides that stretch off toward your home country. It takes a few hours to slide all the way there, but at the end you'll be home.
mnemonics.reading: ほう くに None Your home country is your home (ほう)! Even if you move, even if you haven't been back in years, your home country will always be your home in some way, deep down.

mnemonics.meaning: Honorable You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark> near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> sign to get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> of approval from someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honorable</mark>. This honorable personage drives by at noon every day, and because they have to stop at the stop sign, people loiter here for a chance to get their honorable stamp of approval. Imagine feeling nervous as the honorable person pulls up at the stop sign. Hear yourself humbly asking for their stamp as you hand the written request to them. And just who is this honorable being, anyway?
mnemonics.reading: ご, ぎょ お, おん, み None The honorable personage is Godzilla (ご). Actually, you're requesting Godzilla's stamp of approval for a new demolition job in downtown Tokyo. Godzilla is the god of urban demolition, what with all those cities it's destroyed, and you need its honorable approval to continue. Imagine the relief you'd feel as Godzilla hands the request back to you with its personal stamp — some kind of webbed claw print that basically blacks out the whole paper. Thank you, O honorable Godzilla.

mnemonics.meaning: Humility When someone wants to view your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reality</mark>, show it with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humility</mark>. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility. Focus on the feeling of humility here. You're putting it all out there, you know? With nowhere to hide.
mnemonics.reading: しん つつし None As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground. Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?

mnemonics.meaning: Leap You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> to kick <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> in the face so a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leap</mark> to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety. Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
mnemonics.reading: やく おど None After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it. Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.

mnemonics.meaning: Modesty They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> had more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">modesty</mark> than any other woman at the time. Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest. Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.

mnemonics.meaning: Mound A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of rain falls on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> leaning up against a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> stuck into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mound</mark>. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over. Imagine this whole scene. A drop of water rouses the bear and he becomes enraged after he rolls down the mound. Hear the bear roar with anger as he charges up the mound and violently smashes the cross into the ground.
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish. Now look at the bear sitting atop the mound with his head in his paws, looking like a fool filled with regret. This bear feels like a fool for attacking the cross like he did.

mnemonics.meaning: One Sided Fragment The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one sided</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">one sided</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: へん かた None Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた). Imagine a one sided situation that you've had. Now imagine the winning side with a catapult. For example, a baseball game where one team is destroying the other. That's because instead of a pitcher, they have a catapult.

mnemonics.meaning: Paragraph <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Construction</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paragraph</mark> to explain what you're doing. Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application. In that paragraph, you praised こういち for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor こういち when you wrote it. But hey, it worked! Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Patterned <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Criminal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> is always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">patterned</mark>. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters. Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
mnemonics.reading: い, ひ None None As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all! Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.

mnemonics.meaning: Prosperity A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> will allow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> to have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperity</mark>. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died. Picture a dark, bleak winter landscape. No life anywhere. Now turn around and look at the prosperity on display in the building you're in. Everyone is happy and eating food and not freezing to death.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう None None This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed. Ryu's prosperity has made him realize that having things isn't always enough. Now he's looking wistfully outside at the winter weather, missing the rough times.

mnemonics.meaning: Range Sphere Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> contains a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scroll</mark>, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">range</mark> of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sphere</mark> of your mouth. On the map, there is a circle drawn around your mouth showing what range your mouth exists in. Thankfully, your tongue and teeth are within that sphere.
mnemonics.reading: けん None None Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything else on the map was accurate, so you take a close look in the mirror, and there he is: a tiny Ken the samurai, protecting the range that is your mouth. He gives you a small nod and goes back to his post.

mnemonics.meaning: Refuse Refusal Show your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> to show you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">refuse</mark> him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean. Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
mnemonics.reading: きょ こば None What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops. Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice Plant The grain stuck in your cleat had a former life. In that life it was a rice plant. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up, cleaned, and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now all that's left is this sad loose grain in the bottom of your shoe. When you look at a grain of rice, you should think about how it used to be a rice plant. That rice plant had a family! いいね, you think — that rice plant had a good life.
mnemonics.reading: とう いね, いな None The grain of rice thinks about its former life as a rice plant and, like you, mutters "いね." What's that, little rice grain? Are you trying to say life was good? As it reminisces it wants to say "good," but the いいね is tragically cut short… much like the rice plant's life. It doesn't even have the strength to say it properly, it has to say いね. Yes, little grain, your rice plant life really was いね. Because you… were an いね. I'm sorry.

mnemonics.meaning: Rob A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> takes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of a safe before he can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rob</mark> it. If the safe is too big it won't fit in his getaway car and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs a place he needs to get those measurements. Imagine this turkey preparing to rob a place. See him with the tape measure, and hear his little gobbles of excitement as he realizes the safe here is just the right size for robbing.
mnemonics.reading: だつ うば None Once he's able to rob the place, he gets away in an Uber (うば). He just called the Uber in advance and had it wait outside. Hey, if you're gonna rob a place, make sure you have an Uber. Picture this turkey with all the stuff he robbed, looking nervously over his shoulder from the back seat of his Uber.

mnemonics.meaning: Steel You come across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark>. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steel</mark>. Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
mnemonics.reading: こう はがね None You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel. "I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"

mnemonics.meaning: Turtle Shell A The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turtle shell</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">A</mark> out of A through D, for example. Cowabunga! You get an A!
mnemonics.reading: こう, かん か None With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち. Because this is WaniKani, こういち has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.

mnemonics.meaning: Void A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark>, clad in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>, exists in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">void</mark>. This tiger is from another dimension where tigers rule the earth, clad in armor with spikes. The void has allowed this tiger to cross dimensional planes. Tigers are pretty intimidating just on their own, let alone with spikey armor. Imagine this tiger, covered in spikes. It’s roaring at you. Pretty scary, huh?
mnemonics.reading: きょ, こ むな None The aforementioned void has opened up in Little Kyoto (きょ). The spiked void tigers chose to come here in order to face off against the Hanshin Tigers baseball team in battle. It will be a vicious match here in Little Kyoto. Since this is taking place in Little Kyoto and not Japan itself, the Hanshin Tigers won't have the home field advantage. Who will win? Picture this grand match taking place in Little Kyoto. Actual tigers versus the Hanshin Tigers. It’s truly a sight to behold. The void tigers are armed with their spikes and the Hanshin Tigers are armed with their bats. Hear the crack of wood and the roar of tigers in the air as the battle commences.

mnemonics.meaning: Wall There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot peppers</mark> hiding in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, so you build a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wall</mark> to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up. Picture yourself walking around and seeing a wall around some dirt. You look inside and there are some hot peppers hiding just below the surface. Phew! Good thing this wall was here to protect you from them.
mnemonics.reading: へき かべ None On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in. Picture some corn cobs. Now picture some hot peppers. Put a wall between them.

mnemonics.meaning: Welfare When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>s protecting you, you'll have to go on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">welfare</mark>. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else. The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
mnemonics.reading: し None None While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it. If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: Abduct Pull Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> up straight, to protect you from being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abduct</mark>ed, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull</mark>ed away against your will. You're convinced someone is trying to abduct you, so you need to keep your fingers standing at all times, ready to defend yourself. Your fingers are feeling pretty stiff, but you still keep them standing, just in case.
mnemonics.reading: ら None None Suddenly, someone really is trying to abduct you. They're pullling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Help! Luckily, your fingers were standing to attention and you were able to fight off the mighty Ra. He won't try to abduct you again in a hurry. Thank goodness for those standing fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: Alert <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alert</mark> for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive. Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
mnemonics.reading: びん None None Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe. Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.

mnemonics.meaning: Blow You attempt to expel wind out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> the breath to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blow</mark> out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so. Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
mnemonics.reading: すい ふ None You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you. Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.

mnemonics.meaning: Chant It's time to do the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chant</mark>. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears. Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
mnemonics.reading: しょう とな None You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him. The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.

mnemonics.meaning: Collide If you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> somewhere but you're too <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collide</mark> with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all. Imagine being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
mnemonics.reading: しょう つ None You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad. The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.

mnemonics.meaning: Commandment The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> issued <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commandment</mark>s to his people. He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
mnemonics.reading:
かい いまし None The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい). Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak
Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak
Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak It goes on like that for a while...

mnemonics.meaning: Concurrently The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">concurrently</mark>," says your art class teacher. Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
mnemonics.reading: けん か None Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai. It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.

mnemonics.meaning: Dilute The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> are being worked upon by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark>: this tsunami can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dilute</mark> flowers with just one tsunami-powered drop of itself. That’s its specialty. Look at the flowers as the tsunami begins to dilute them with just one drop. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
mnemonics.reading: はく うす None You watch the flowers become diluted with just one drop, and realize that this is a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature. As you continue to watch the tsunami's drop of water dilute the flowers, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a sinister being from the future? Maybe.

mnemonics.meaning: Ditch Imagine you're driving and there's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> in it near the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> ramp. That flag marks a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ditch</mark> running alongside the road. Don't try to exit the road here, or you'll end up stuck in that ditch. Picture the flag in the dirt. Picture the ditch just beyond it. Now look for another way to exit this road, unless you have a ditch wish.
mnemonics.reading: くつ ほり None If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch. It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.

mnemonics.meaning: Dose <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Simultaneous</mark>ly, you throw your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dose</mark> of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed. Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
mnemonics.reading: ざい None None "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?" Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!

mnemonics.meaning: Elegant A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elegant</mark>. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special. Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
mnemonics.reading: が みや None This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle! Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.

mnemonics.meaning: Emit Expel The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are where <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emit</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expel</mark> all of their bad energy from. Picture a criminal’s fingers, and all of the bad energy just oozing out of them, almost like an exhaust pipe emitting toxic fumes.
mnemonics.reading: はい None None Then you realize what the fingers are actually emitting: terrible, awful haiku (はい). Imagine this criminal's fingers emitting god-awful, cringe-inducing haiku after haiku. Really feel your skin crawl at the shoddiness of this criminal's fingers' haiku.

mnemonics.meaning: Filial Piety <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Teacher</mark>s are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">filial piety</mark>. Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち. I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, こういち, so that he may teach me.

mnemonics.meaning: Frequent You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">walk</mark> by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frequent</mark> amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around. Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
mnemonics.reading: ひん しき None Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people. Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.

mnemonics.meaning: Gallop A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> goes to his favorite <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gallop</mark> around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there. Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
mnemonics.reading: く か None Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it. The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.

mnemonics.meaning: Genius The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">genius</mark>! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything! Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
mnemonics.reading: しゅん None None As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs. Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.

mnemonics.meaning: Glad Happy A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rejoic</mark>ing. She must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">glad</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">happy</mark> to rejoice out loud in front of you like this. Picture a woman rejoicing loudly. She's got a big smile on her face and she wants you and everyone else to see how glad she is.
mnemonics.reading: き うれ None "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys. You'd be happy too if you'd just found your lost keys. Though maybe you wouldn't shout it for the entire world to hear.

mnemonics.meaning: Honor There’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> there <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you have no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honor</mark>. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor. Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
mnemonics.reading: よ ほ None Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have. Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.

mnemonics.meaning: Luxuriant You take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> that you picked from your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luxuriant</mark> garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers. Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
mnemonics.reading: も しげ None The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning. Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Milord Lord Under the same <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, all the people get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> to present a new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> to your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lord</mark>. You all bow and say, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Milord</mark>, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord. When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
mnemonics.reading: でん との, どの None As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows. Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!

mnemonics.meaning: Multiply When you go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> to make things <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark>, your problems just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">multiply</mark>. Why would you ask the yakuza to "straighten out" a problem for you? Do you realize what that means in yakuza-speak? Your problems are going to be multiplying exponentially, friend.
mnemonics.reading: しょく ふ None Your problems multiply and give you quite a shock (しょく) as yakuza thugs commit crime after shocking crime on your behalf. You really shouldn't be shocked though — of course crimes are going to multiply when you ask the yakuza to "straighten things out." Feel shock envelop your entire body as yakuza run around town roughing up everyone who's ever wronged you. Police attention on you is beginning to multiply, too, and you can't even think from the shock of it all.

mnemonics.meaning: Neighbor Neighbour Inside that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> someone is doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark>. That someone is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neighbor</mark>. Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
mnemonics.reading: りん となり None Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance. Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.

mnemonics.meaning: Noodles One way to put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wheat</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">face</mark> is with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noodles</mark>. Imagine yourself shoveling piles of wheaty noodles into your face. They're so wheaty and delicious!
mnemonics.reading: めん None None Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make noodlemen (めん). Did you ever use to make pictures with your food? (Or maybe you still do? We won't judge.) Imagine you're doing that again, and think about how lifelike your noodle men are!

mnemonics.meaning: Overgrown <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> fields become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overgrown</mark>. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete. Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
mnemonics.reading: はん しげ None The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete. Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!

mnemonics.meaning: Patrol You're using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to navigate the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> because you're on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">patrol</mark>. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help. Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん めぐ, まわ None You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot. You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.

mnemonics.meaning: Pillar This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pillar</mark>. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master. See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう はしら None While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished. Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.

mnemonics.meaning: Portable Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to shoo a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> and into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">portable</mark> carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers. Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
mnemonics.reading: けい たずさ None You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference. Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.

mnemonics.meaning: Praise Lift the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">preserve</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">praise</mark> the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be! You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
mnemonics.reading: ほう ほ None You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects. If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Resident A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> and you are merely a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resident</mark> in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident! Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう None None To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca. Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.

mnemonics.meaning: Review You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">employ</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">review</mark> all your work. Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
mnemonics.reading: こ かえり None As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)! The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.

mnemonics.meaning: Sacrifice The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark> is always there for us. He is the cow that must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sacrifice</mark> himself for us to survive. The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ None None The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing. Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like 義. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Seize You see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seize</mark> them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers. Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
mnemonics.reading: かく え None The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers. Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: Sharp If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> you also need a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> with a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sharp</mark> sword to protect it. You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
mnemonics.reading: えい するど None You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just lying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea! Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.

mnemonics.meaning: Spread Taking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on it, you walk through the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spread</mark> your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion, and the drop in case any of that rice is thirsty. Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival. Drip the drop onto any thirsty rice.
mnemonics.reading: ふ しき, し None With your arms spread like that, you look extremely chic (しき). Spread arms are obviously a chic posture, and the fact that you're holding a cross makes it even more chic. Side note: The official kun'yomi reading is just し, but since far more words use しき, we're focusing on that here. Even though the き part is technically okurigana, it's actually used in the readings for most of the compounds that use this kanji! Feel the strain on your chic arms as you continue to spread them. Since you're by far the most chic person around, you have to set a good example for your people, so don't let them (or your arms) down.

mnemonics.meaning: Supernatural Enchanting What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> comes down from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supernatural</mark> one. She is so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enchanting</mark>. Imagine your idea of what an extremely supernatural woman would look like, and have her come down from heaven towards you. You're totally enchanted by her looks.
mnemonics.reading: よう あや None The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう). Touch the supernatural yogurt woman and feel the yogurt. Taste the yogurt, what flavor is it? It's totally enchanting you further.

mnemonics.meaning: Transparent The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> you made out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s, and are about to ride down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> with, is completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transparent</mark>. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter. Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
mnemonics.reading: とう す None You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back! Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is とうきょう in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.

mnemonics.meaning: Abandon In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> is a weird looking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark>. Someone decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abandon</mark> it here. Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...
mnemonics.reading: き None None You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it. You abandon the fruit and stare intently at this key. It must be why the fruit was weird looking and abandoned in the trash... but what does it go to?! You dig through the trash and try the key on everything that's been abandoned in there.

mnemonics.meaning: Amazing Wonderful, Terrible, Awful Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wife</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amazing</mark>. She's also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">terrible</mark>, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing! Picture your amazing and terrible ice wife. She's floating in your backyard cackling and shooting ice all around.
mnemonics.reading: せい すご None She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too! Now you're floating in the backyard cackling with your amazing wife as you use your terrible saber and freeze things with her!

mnemonics.meaning: Attain Dig up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attain</mark> a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level! It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.
mnemonics.reading: し いた None Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over. If you can attain two animal levels in one day you'll be a legend on the leaderboards.

mnemonics.meaning: Based On Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to wipe this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> and see what it was <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">based on</mark>. The cold winter weather covers the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them. Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.
mnemonics.reading: きょ, こ よ None This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good. The buildings and temples are all very childlike. Like crayon drawn on a table.

mnemonics.meaning: Bee On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark> there is a single sign that says <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bee</mark>. This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.
mnemonics.reading: ほう はち None Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg. You got to see a single bee hatch! What a beautiful sight. Weird that a signpost points to it.

mnemonics.meaning: Ceremony The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark> is the only one who can run this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ceremony</mark>. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it. Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ None None Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ). *CHOP*
