mnemonics.meaning: Charcoal You climb up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> in search of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, but all you find is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">charcoal</mark>. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing. You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.
mnemonics.reading: たん すみ None After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lie out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops. Imagine lying out in the sun next to the crushed charcoal, thinking you’re going to get tan. You’re very surprised when you actually catch on fire. Hot hot hot!

mnemonics.meaning: Conceal A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>s up into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, where they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conceal</mark> something. Imagine witnessing this tsunami taking the two husbands up into the sun. Hear the water rushing. That tsunami is massive. What are they going to conceal in the sun?
mnemonics.reading: せん くぐ, ひそ, もぐ None The husbands are going to conceal their pet centaur (せん) in the sun. The local government isn't too pleased that they have a pet centaur, so they have to conceal it in the sun so it doesn't get confiscated. Just make sure to remember the husbands are riding that tsunami alongside their centaur, heading towards the sun. They need to conceal the centaur to keep it safe.

mnemonics.meaning: Fake The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets a nice uniform for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sake</mark> of not wanting to look like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fake</mark>. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake. Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?
mnemonics.reading: ぎ にせ, いつわ None Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head. Watch as the guillotine comes down. You close your eyes for a second, and when you open them you see that the leader's body was a fake! Wait, where did he go?!

mnemonics.meaning: Field A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> burns down the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">field</mark>. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm! Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: None はたけ, はた None Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia! Imagine running around this hot cay as you try to put out the fire in your field. The fire is ravaging the entire hot cay, so it takes you a while to put it out. Man those flames are hot. Also, this kanji can have the reading はた for the kun'yomi as well. If you learn the longer version (はたけ) it will be easier to just shave off a kana to remember the shorter version.

mnemonics.meaning: Firefly A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">firefly</mark>. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly. Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!
mnemonics.reading: けい ほたる None The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones. Hear Hotaru’s shrill scream as she runs away from the Viking firefly. If you don’t know what Hotaru Tomoe looks like, Google a picture of her to get a better visualization.

mnemonics.meaning: Fist A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> turns his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fist</mark>. A fist for punching other gladiators. Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.
mnemonics.reading: けん, げん こぶし None The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists. Ken and the gladiator clash! Fists fly! You've never seen hand-to-hand combat like this! You can hardly keep up!!

mnemonics.meaning: Hard Liquor The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> that needs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hard liquor</mark>. Drinking too much hard liquor isn't good for you, so you must make sure to measure it out in precise quantities. Imagine the hard liquor as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle into a little measuring cup as you catch the whiff of strong alcohol in the air.
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう, ちゅ かも None You know who enjoyed hard liquor a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did. Imagine Chewbacca drinking hard liquor all the time while Han Solo told him he needed to stop and get help, but Chewbacca just did his yell thing and drank more hard liquor.

mnemonics.meaning: Hometown Everyone has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guy</mark> from their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hometown</mark>. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place. Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, ごう さと None Your hometown is in きょうと which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up. Imagine all the wonderful things that exist in your hometown of きょうと. All the things you love to do and see. And now picture poop guy. Ruining it all with his poop hands.

mnemonics.meaning: Honey Nectar The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> (hive) on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> (a bee) is what protects all of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honey</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nectar</mark>. Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.
mnemonics.reading: みつ None None To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung. Your thick mitts make it so the bees can't even sting your hands. Unfortunately, you are naked and only wearing mitts, what were you thinking?

mnemonics.meaning: Humanity This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> things that remind him of his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humanity</mark>: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats. Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.
mnemonics.reading: じん, に None None Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity. Are you wearing jeans right now? If so, rub them with your hands and say aloud “Oh, the humanity!” Or just imagine wearing jeans if you aren’t actually wearing them.

mnemonics.meaning: Humble On this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> who's trying to show that his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humble</mark>. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter. Picture this child scooting to his fancy, expensive university in a little suit. Compared to the other kids, his wheels are quite humble!
mnemonics.reading: そん したが None This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble. You even bought your son this humble scooter and you really hope they don't grow up to be a selfish, spoiled kid this way.

mnemonics.meaning: Inquire Being a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> or <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">director</mark> in a company means you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inquire</mark> about lots of things. Have you started this yet? Have you finished that yet? Did you get that thing I sent you? Where's my coffee? Basically if you're a leader or director, your main job is to inquire about these very important things. Just make sure you don't inquire about anything inappropriate, or you'll end up facing an inquiry from HR…
mnemonics.reading: し うかが None Turns out the leader and director of your company is Chairman Kaga from the TV show Iron Chef. Every time he tries to inquire about weird stuff, you have to say Ooh, Kaga (うかが) disapprovingly. "What are you doing for dinner tonight?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! "What's the best way to soften an eggplant?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! Imagine saying "Ooh, Kaga!" to this overly curious leader-director-chef. Say it out loud, like he's just inquired about something weird. He just really loves cooking, okay? But he inquires too much about it in the workplace, so you have to let him know how you feel.

mnemonics.meaning: Invade There is a tiny <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and commanding his troops to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">invade</mark> Wolverine's brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine's body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn't going to invade Wolverine's brain, he's just going to sit on the stool and supervise. Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”
mnemonics.reading: しん おか None Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body. See the little soldiers slicing open Wolverine’s shin as Wolverine grunts in pain. Getting your leg cut open is not a comfortable thing, even for someone as manly as Wolverine.

mnemonics.meaning: Lie Open your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> fell in there on some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie</mark>! Of course there isn't a tiger in your mouth. And those spikes are just normal teeth. No matter how you look at it, you're saying a lie.
mnemonics.reading: None うそ None Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ). Now at least you're not lying about spikes being in your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: Mineral Aside from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> there are a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wide</mark> variety of other <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mineral</mark>s as well. Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.
mnemonics.reading: こう あらがね None One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち. Emperor こういち is getting all the minerals, and the 鋼, so he can take over all neighboring nations and force them into a subjugation of efficient kanji learning.

mnemonics.meaning: Noisy Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">proclaim</mark>s "I am <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noisy</mark> and I am loud!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by. The townsfolk agree with your mouth, you are noisy and you are picky and you need to shut up.
mnemonics.reading: けん やかま None You are so noisy and loud that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up. "Ken, your armor color is so last year. That squid you have is gross. Your sword is so gaudy. You talk like you're from the Edo Period, but it's Reiwa right now." Your noisy and picky self just goes off on Ken the Samurai. He skulks off, defeated by your noisy and picky words.

mnemonics.meaning: Penetrate Clear You decide to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so the moon's light will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">penetrate</mark> you. The sky is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>est in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it. Picture a single beam of moonlight penetrating through the winter sky, right onto the trash.
mnemonics.reading: てつ None None You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ). The clear, penetrating beam tastes exactly like iron, which is something you really weren't expecting. But now it's filling your entire mouth and you don't want it to stop.

mnemonics.meaning: Rapids Shallows A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rapids</mark>! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shallows</mark>. Picture the bundle of geoducks getting smashed by the tsunami, breaking apart, and getting tossed around in the rapids.
mnemonics.reading: らい せ None While those geoducks are getting tossed about in the rapids, you're sitting in the shallows chomping down on some celery (せ). Imagine the cool shallow water lapping at your feet as you bite into some crunchy celery and watch the rapids in the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: Rowdy Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">showy</mark> so it makes everybody around you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rowdy</mark>. Your mouth is showy because it's covered in grills and bright red lipstick. People get rowdy because you're a celebrity and your showy mouth is your signature look, and everyone's so excited to see your mouth in person.
mnemonics.reading: か None None Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape. As you drive away in your car you flash that signature mouth at them one more time, and you can see them getting even more rowdy.

mnemonics.meaning: Ruins You're digging in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> when you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cactus</mark>. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ruins</mark>. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins. Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.
mnemonics.reading: きょ None None Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago. Picture the ruins of Little Kyoto. Try to imagine what it was like before the whole place fell apart. Maybe they would have lived on if they hadn't been doing things with sharp cacti and bitey tigers.

mnemonics.meaning: Set Aside You find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark>. They must have been <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">set aside</mark> by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside. What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.
mnemonics.reading: そ None None I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long... Think of all the things you do with your fingers. Now picture how they would look if you had never ever cleaned them with soap. Uhg, disgusting. You should just set them aside here, and find some new ones.

mnemonics.meaning: Sincerity Something you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to someone you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> attached to should be said with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark>. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example. Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.
mnemonics.reading: せい まこと None When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere! Say, "I love you," again and watch your saber beating in time with your heart. If you weren't sincere it would fade and grow dull.

mnemonics.meaning: Tiger A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> that belong to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tiger</mark>. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here. Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.
mnemonics.reading: こ とら None The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away. Imagine watching the tiger as it notices the Torah and then runs away. The tiger sounds as if it is screaming in terror as it flees from the proximity of the Torah.

mnemonics.meaning: Warship The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark>s other boats, land, and people is usually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warship</mark>. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it. Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him? Picture Genghis Khan aboard a monstrous warship. He's carefully watching the sea and land that he's conquered.

mnemonics.meaning: Withdrawal You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to dig through the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> because somewhere in there is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">withdrawal</mark> letter. What did you withdraw? Your resignation? Your troops? Whatever it was, you need to find the proof, and fast. Imagine you need proof of your withdrawal so badly, that you're in the trash like this, raking around with your fingers in the moonlight. Close your eyes and feel the cold, smell the stink.
mnemonics.reading: てつ None None While looking for the withdrawal letter, your fingers hit a piece of 鉄 (てつ). Ouch! The pain from the 鉄 reverberates up your fingers and into your hands and arms. What's this great lump of 鉄 doing in the trash?

mnemonics.meaning: Wood Each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> needs its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> done before you can say it's really made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wood</mark>. There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.
mnemonics.reading: じゅ き いつき If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all. However! A non-wood tree will be really thirsty from pretending to be a wood tree. It will start making sounds and moving and probably say, "Can I have a juice box, please?"

mnemonics.meaning: Wrap The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wrap</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: ほう つつ, くる None Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love. Home is where the wrapped heart is.

mnemonics.meaning: Analysis You hit a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> so you can do some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">analysis</mark> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe. Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.
mnemonics.reading: せき None None The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy. Imagine yourself being sexy and doing tree analysis. What sort of sexy analysis moves can you think of? Oh yeah, so sexy.

mnemonics.meaning: Arc Using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, shoot a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> and it will fly in a steep <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arc</mark>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all. Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.
mnemonics.reading: こ None None Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place. Imagine being a 子 and watching melons fly in arcs all over. Imagine a little 子 version of yourself giggling and clapping your hands with absolute glee.

mnemonics.meaning: Arrival The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> ready for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrival</mark>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears. Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out. This certainly wasn't the type of arrival you were expecting when you bought your tickets to とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: Axis Pivotal Part A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> works for one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark>: its wheels can spin on an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">axis</mark>. Yep, that lateral axis is definitely a car's most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pivotal part</mark>. Imagine the frustration of trying to drive a car without any axis (or axles) for its wheels to spin on. That thing isn't going anywhere. It's missing its pivotal part!
mnemonics.reading: じく None None Your friend is always bragging about his car's axis. He's all like, "My car's wheels move on more than one axis!" And you sarcastically reply: "Gee, cool" (じく). The pivotal part your friend leaves out is that those multi-axis wheels are why his car is always crashing. Gee, cool axis control, man.

mnemonics.meaning: Bustling Lively <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Shellfish</mark> cause <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark>s because of all their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bustling</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lively</mark> underwater activity. You ever see cliffs falling into the sea? 99% of those landslides are due to bustling, lively shellfish communities, eroding the base of the cliff with all their hustle and bustle.
mnemonics.reading: しん にぎ None You can't stand bustling and lively situations, so you get out your knee guillotine (にぎ). What's a knee guillotine? It's exactly what it sounds like, and you're about to use it on these shellfish to prevent some landslides. Any time you're in a bustling place, you reach for your knee guillotine. Imagine, now, the graveyard of shellfish legs that lies before you. Ahh, no more bustle… Also, that's dinner sorted.

mnemonics.meaning: Challenge When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> move like that, you know it's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">challenge</mark> that will face you soon in the future. What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう いど None In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou! Whenever you see an omen (radical), there's a good chance that Mrs. Chou will be a part of it. This is not a good sign.

mnemonics.meaning: Char You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> and try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it but you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">char</mark> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there. You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!
mnemonics.reading: しょう こ, あせ None You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad. The Shougun reaches down and bites a charred hunk off the turkey. He yells and spits it out. Why did he do that?! You have no idea but it looked nasty.

mnemonics.meaning: Dig You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark>, indicating that you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dig</mark>. The fingers on the flag point downward, just by the exit, as if to say "dig here!" There must be something under here. That's what you think to yourself as you start to dig with your fingers. Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: くつ ほ None You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!" You carefully un-dig the old coots and leave them to their old grumpy coot hole... basement... secret clubhouse? Whatever.

mnemonics.meaning: Distract Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and look at this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distract</mark>ed you! You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.
mnemonics.reading: ふん まぎ, まぐ None Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん). Imagine yourself really enjoying looking at parts of the thread. You don't know why it's so fun, but being derpy is exciting, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Example This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> can be whittled into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">example</mark> of anything. See, here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>. Here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo. It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!
mnemonics.reading: はん None None One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo! Han Solo's bamboo example comes to life and runs off.

mnemonics.meaning: Fasten Someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fasten</mark> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this. Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.
mnemonics.reading: かつ くく None Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?" In this case, many cats fastened your tongue. You should probably be nicer to cats from now on so this doesn't happen again.

mnemonics.meaning: Grip You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shop</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grip</mark> what you want to buy. Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.
mnemonics.reading: あく にぎ None You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles. Acupuncture is great for strengthening your grip strength. If you do intense shopping (like I do) you should definitely consider it!

mnemonics.meaning: Hinge In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hinge</mark>s. Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hinge</mark> on your hinges.
mnemonics.reading: すう からくり None You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!" Really lengthen out that "sue" because it's a long "suu" for the reading and that will help.

mnemonics.meaning: Hoist If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hoist</mark> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy. Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)
mnemonics.reading: よう あ None Today, you have to hoist so much stuff. "Ah!" (あ) you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it! Imagine hoisting things over and over again. Each time you spot a new thing that needs hoisting, you say "Ah! Something else to hoist!"

mnemonics.meaning: Lagoon A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> crashes into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lagoon</mark>. The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.
mnemonics.reading: せき かた None This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun! Now picture it all in slow motion. The catapult tosses the tsunami into the air, it smashes the sun, breaks off into a wing of nice, hot water, and finally splashes back to the earth into a beautiful, secluded lagoon.

mnemonics.meaning: Lawn There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark> in your front <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lawn</mark>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty. Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
mnemonics.reading: し しば None You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba. Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.

mnemonics.meaning: Liver If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, it's good for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">liver</mark>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids. Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
mnemonics.reading: かん きも None As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver. Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."

mnemonics.meaning: Mochi Sticky Rice Cake What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> if you’re wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> and surrounded by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark>s? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Mochi</mark> (or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sticky rice cake</mark>s) of course! Imagine yourself in the lantern light wearing horns and eating delicious mochi.
mnemonics.reading: へい もち None The reading of mochi is mochi (もち). Yay! As long as you can remember the meaning of this kanji, you'll know the reading too.

mnemonics.meaning: Mourning Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> wearing special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> because they're in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourning</mark>. Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).
mnemonics.reading: そう も None As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it. If you aren't mourning enough, when the soul comes out of the person's body, it will get really mad. "What, I'm not worth a few tears? Really?" And then the soul will haunt you. So you better mourn like you mean it.

mnemonics.meaning: Net You see a thread-covered hill, but it's all lumpy and weird. You approach it to take a closer look, and you see it's actually a huge net with a bunch of stuff caught in it: fish, cats, tree branches. All this random stuff is what's making the net look so lumpy! You'll need to differentiate this from 綱, which uses the same radicals (though 綱 has a real hill radical). Just remember that the "hill" in this one is all weird and lumpy because it's a net with a bunch of stuff caught in it.
mnemonics.reading: もう あみ None This net is creating a serious obstacle to you mowing (もう) your lawn. The net has way too much stuff in it for you to be able to drag it away, so for now you're just going to have to mow around it. Imagine the awkwardness of trying to mow the grass around this big, lumpy, writhing net full of loudly meowing cats, flopping fish, and goodness knows what else.

mnemonics.meaning: Overcome Even though you’ve <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overcome</mark> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon! Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
mnemonics.reading: こく None None When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke. Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.

mnemonics.meaning: Overnight The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overnight</mark>, without even asking! Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
mnemonics.reading: はく と None Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave. See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.

mnemonics.meaning: Pair If you have one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pair</mark> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it. Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.
mnemonics.reading: そう ふた None This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together. It's the same with pairs of socks and pairs of people. Sometimes what looks like two things is really a perfect pair, with one soul. Meant to be together forever.

mnemonics.meaning: Pattern You walk up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dynamite</mark> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pattern</mark> into the side of it as well as the ground around it. Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
mnemonics.reading: へい がら None The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do. Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.

mnemonics.meaning: Philosophy Wrap your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> and put it in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to express your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">philosophy</mark>. Your philosophy of… putting axes in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, but by doing this you're showing them that it's not! Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting an axe in your mouth. Is it some kind of metaphor for how powerful and sharp your philosophical thinking is?
mnemonics.reading: てつ None None Your axe-in-mouth philosophy means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper. Well, weapons (and your philosophy) taste like iron. Your philosophy and your way of life means everything tastes like 鉄 now, and you think everyone should be that way.

mnemonics.meaning: Purification Use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s to perform the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purification</mark> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.) Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.
mnemonics.reading: さい いつ None This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head. Hopefully this purification (or just the two jackhammers shaking your brain up like pudding) will get the memories of your cyborg to go away. You can't keep picturing it all the time like this.

mnemonics.meaning: Rope If you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rope</mark>. Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker ropes. They're strong!
mnemonics.reading: こう つな None Congratulations, now you have a perfect rope for tuna (つな) fishing. Tunas are massive, so you need a strong rope to reel one in. Imagine yourself going tuna fishing on a small boat with nothing but one long rope. This is how tuna fishing is done where you're from, so you're sticking to tradition.

mnemonics.meaning: Sack You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">substitute</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sack</mark>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies. Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
mnemonics.reading: たい ふくろ None You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty. Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.

mnemonics.meaning: Shake With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, you grab a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong enough for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker. Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: よう ゆ None You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). You only like yogurt that's been well shaken. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone? Imagine shaking yogurt in space. Now imagine eating yogurt as it continues to shake (in space still)!

mnemonics.meaning: Slide Slip, Glide A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> breaks your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bone</mark>s, not from hitting you, but from making you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slide</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slip</mark> into stuff. Hard to keep your footing in a tsunami, you know? You're slipping and sliding all over the place. Imagine being knocked off your feet by a tsunami, then sliding into a wall or something and breaking a bone or two. You try to get up, but you slip again, breaking a few more bones in the process.
mnemonics.reading: かつ すべ, なめ None As you continue to slide around you see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're yowling and sliding right toward you. Uh oh… Picture these stray cats trying to right themselves on the wet ground and slipping again each time. They're doing that thing cats do when they touch water, twisting their bodies around and trying to cling to you. Great, now you've got a bunch of slippery cats perched atop your broken body.

mnemonics.meaning: Solid A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> secures a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> so that it is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solid</mark> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting! Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!
mnemonics.reading: けん かた None You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you? You better hope that catapult is solid too. If it isn't the whole thing will come apart when you try to launch yourself into the air.

mnemonics.meaning: Temporarily To your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temporarily</mark>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though. Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.
mnemonics.reading: ざん しばら None You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next. You should probably be worried about this situation.

mnemonics.meaning: Twist <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">twist</mark> them together to make them strong. Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう None None As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it. It turns out those vines you were twisting were cucumber vines! Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: Wild <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> find their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> out in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wild</mark>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place. Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
mnemonics.reading: こう あ, あら None Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do. Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.

mnemonics.meaning: Attack <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Imperial</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> allow you to perform an ancient <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> that cannot be repelled. IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう おそ None The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes. Picture the shoes as you attack, they glow—full of attack power! These +4 attack shoes are really special.

mnemonics.meaning: Bright A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bright</mark> moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon. Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.
mnemonics.reading: ろう ほが None It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon! Picture this scene like it's a Disney cartoon. The good moon is smiling brightly down at the roe which are smiling right back. They might even start singing a song!

mnemonics.meaning: Chafe Below the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>. The hand is just there to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chafe</mark> against the trees. There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.
mnemonics.reading: ま さす None As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama. This is the hand of a child looking for its mama. And, it chafes against trees to try and find the warm, soft touch of its mama. Instead, it only finds rough bark, so it continues its chafing.

mnemonics.meaning: Charm You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark>, put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, then run back. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">charm</mark> of this game. Imagine yourself playing this game and basking in the charm of tapping your ear on the stool.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ おもむき None The added charm of this game is that there's this big chute (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes. As you watch, you really see the charm of this game. Some people are throwing the stool down the chute, some people are sliding down it on their ears...how charming.

mnemonics.meaning: Chastise The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> who hangs around during <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, and only sees bad things. So, he <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastise</mark>s you about it. "What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう こ None Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう). In the 潮 kanji you saved Mrs. Chou from dying, so he is chastising you for it.

mnemonics.meaning: Consolation We put up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> to remember where we tried to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> of your friend's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consolation</mark>? Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
mnemonics.reading: い なぐさ None Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it. Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even a consolation flag.

mnemonics.meaning: Courteous A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">badger</mark>, at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> of its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courteous</mark> creature. They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.
mnemonics.reading: こん None None Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet. Picture a courteous badger taking care of an injured, and now homeless, condor. It's fluffing the condor's pillows, bringing it soup, and patting it on the shoulder saying, "There, there."

mnemonics.meaning: Crystal The sun hits this and breaks into three <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>s. What can split the sun in three directions? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crystal</mark>! Crystals take light and refract it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう). Imagine the Shougun lying in his bed of crystals. He still has his really serious, angry face though. Even as he rubs the crystals to his face, he's glowering.

mnemonics.meaning: Cylinder Tube, Pipe A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> stalk looks the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as a big ol' <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cylinder</mark>. Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
mnemonics.reading: とう つつ None Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう! とうきょう is a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.

mnemonics.meaning: Destroy A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> tips a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, propelling the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> on it to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, where there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> waiting to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">destroy</mark> her. Even though she made it off the slide and escaped the tsunami, she still ended up in a fire. Seems like the world just wanted to destroy this drunkard.
mnemonics.reading: めつ ほろ None One could say this drunkard met (めつ) her fate. Strangely, she'd just came from a Mets game. (めつ, get it?) So maybe that's why she had such bad luck.

mnemonics.meaning: Dignity Might After going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and bumps straight into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> of great stature. Imagine the shame. This drunkard has just lost all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dignity</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">might</mark> that they may have possessed. And that drunkard… is you! Imagine the shame and disgrace you feel once you realize who you've just bumped into. Really lean into the feeling of all your dignity and might just slowly fading away as you come to realize the gravity of the situation.
mnemonics.reading: い None None There's only one thing you could think of that could possibly restore all your dignity and might: acquiring a pet eagle (い). Just think about it. It's the only logical option. How could you not look all dignified and mighty if you just had your own eagle? Just imagine it all perched up on your shoulder. Such dignity and might.

mnemonics.meaning: Distance A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> is a pretty long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distance</mark> for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distance</mark>s very quickly. Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
mnemonics.reading: きょ None None Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you. Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: Expose Dew If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> touches your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and gives it a little rain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, you know that part of your foot is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expose</mark>d to the elements. You can also see some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dew</mark> forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are! Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
mnemonics.reading: ろ, ろう つゆ None You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides. You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet with dew if you can't get off this blasted road.

mnemonics.meaning: Furnace A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">furnace</mark>. Open the fire door and feel the heat of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">furnace</mark>. Hot!
mnemonics.reading: ろ いろり None You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ). Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.

mnemonics.meaning: Gentle You've been ordered to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> but you decide to be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark> instead. Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.
mnemonics.reading: じゅう, にゅう やわ None You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head. The jewel has a little note on it, "Thank you for being gentle." Did... did the tree just reward you for being gentle?!

mnemonics.meaning: Harp Zither, Koto Two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>s are here right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark>! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harp</mark>, or the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">zither</mark>, or something. Imagine yourself playing a harp or a zither, even if you don't know how. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
mnemonics.reading: None こと None You may already know that a Japanese harp is called a こと, but here's a mnemonic to help you if you don't: When playing your harp, you always wear your coat (こと). Your harp playing is pretty bad, so you put your coat on just in case you need to leave in a hurry to escape an angry audience.

mnemonics.meaning: Hedge Fence Look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> and you'll be able to see all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hedge</mark>s growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out. This hedge also works as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fence</mark>. It borders an area and you can't walk through it. A natural fence! Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.
mnemonics.reading: None かき None You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys. Imagine rooting around under some hedges, desperately trying to find your car keys. Hedges are prickly and there's spiders in here! If only you didn't need a car in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: Instant The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> is to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instant</mark> picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant. Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?
mnemonics.reading: そく すなわ None Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant! Imagine using instant socks. How do they feel? Soggy, but hey, it was fast!

mnemonics.meaning: Nourishing A (fresh water) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. Some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. A bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nourishing</mark> soil. The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
mnemonics.reading: じ, し None None This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably. Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.

mnemonics.meaning: Pasture A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pasture</mark>. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat. It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく まき None ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼくwill take these cows out to pasture!" Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.

mnemonics.meaning: Peace The sound of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> always puts you at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>. Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.
mnemonics.reading: たい None None You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love. Imagine carefully dipping all of your ties in the peaceful spring waters and hearing that sweet sound you love at all times.

mnemonics.meaning: Point Delicious Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to be able to take a bite. It's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delicious</mark>, you hear. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">point</mark> of the spoon. Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!
mnemonics.reading: し うま, むね None This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)! You had your eyes closed because the sun is so bright. When you open them you realize the delicious sun you were eating is really just a giant, really bright, cooked sheep. You should probably point this out to NASA or something.

mnemonics.meaning: Printing You take out a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, lay a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> below it, and use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">printing</mark> presses used to work. The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag), pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel), then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).
mnemonics.reading: さつ す None As you get your flag ready for printing you look over and see Satsuki (さつ), who's already finished a nice pattern on her towel. She's a little young to be using a knife, but her print came out nice. You know her pretty well at this point, so try to imagine what kind of printing Satsuki would make. Picture her holding it up to show you.

mnemonics.meaning: Rare The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, not to mention the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> stuck to said hat, is incredibly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rare</mark>. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck. Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
mnemonics.reading: ちん めずら None Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん). Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as rare as they come.

mnemonics.meaning: Register People had to use their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> to put their name in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">register</mark>. This is because there was no paper yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their names into the dirt to create all kinds of registers. School registers, family registers, member registers — you name it. Picture the fields and hillsides back then, full of names scraped into the dirt.
mnemonics.reading: せき None None If your name is in a register, people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than someone whose existence is accounted for in official documentation. No wonder people went to the trouble of plowing their names into the dirt back then. They understood the sex appeal of registers.

mnemonics.meaning: Rub You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to hold the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark> up, but it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rub</mark>s against them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is rubbing against them really, really badly. Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing rubs against them.
mnemonics.reading: さつ こす, す None Just when you thought the rubbing couldn't get any worse, Satsuki (さつ) appears and hops up onto the roof. AAGH! It hurts! Picture Satsuki sitting on the roof as you carry it through the festival. She may be a little girl, but her extra weight makes the rubbing so much worse — you can really feel the skin chafing.

mnemonics.meaning: Seal Seal In, Closing You take two clumps of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>, using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal</mark> each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal in</mark> things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue. Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.
mnemonics.reading: ふう, ほう None None You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew. By the way, this has another reading you should probably know. It's ほう. Most sealing is done in the home (ほう), you know? So just think about eating food in your own home! Dig up your sealed food and eat it in the comfort of your own home. Mm, delicious!

mnemonics.meaning: Simultaneous The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simultaneous</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: せい, さい None None What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい). It's also simultaneously here and there at the same time. It moves really fast. And simultaneously glowing blue and white. Your saber is a lot of things all at once!

mnemonics.meaning: Sink If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pirate</mark> they are going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sink</mark> no matter how good of a pirate captain they are. Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
mnemonics.reading: ちん しず None As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity. Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.

mnemonics.meaning: Slap Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in somebody's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">business</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slap</mark>ping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers. Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく None None ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく. Say that out loud, using ぼく. You're the boss, the boss of slap business.

mnemonics.meaning: Split Tear When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, it will of course cause a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">split</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tear</mark>. It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.
mnemonics.reading: れつ さ None "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it. Think of a thing you want to tear with your yakuza buddy. You're into it, so you agree and say "Ret's do it!"

mnemonics.meaning: Tide A small <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> comes in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tide</mark>. The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう しお None You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! She wakes up and says, "If only you came at low tide then I would never have been saved!" She jumps up and runs off, yelling something about destroying the world.

mnemonics.meaning: Tribute This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> project made from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will act as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tribute</mark> to the Crabigator. The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.
