mnemonics.reading: こう みつ None This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち. In his power, こういち has made a new religion around the Crabigator, to put the fear of kanji learning into his subjects. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Blade The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blade</mark> are exactly the same. Please, just know your radicals. Please!
mnemonics.reading: じん, にん は, やいば None When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound. Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.

mnemonics.meaning: Cannon You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cannon</mark>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason. This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
mnemonics.reading: ほう None None You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long. Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.

mnemonics.meaning: Conical Hat A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> thing you put on your head to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conical hat</mark>. You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう かさ None A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)! Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

mnemonics.meaning: Dragon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dragon</mark> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dragon</mark>. Not to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dragon</mark> with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
mnemonics.reading: りゅう たつ None Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryu (りゅう). Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"

mnemonics.meaning: Draw Close Be Imminent Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> told you that a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> last <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw close</mark>. There was nothing you could do to stop it, it seemed to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">be imminent</mark>, coming in the darkness of the evening. Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
mnemonics.reading: さつ None None Luckily whenever you sense a flood starting to draw close, Satsuki (さつ) prepares a raft. Remember Satsuki? Such a talented little girl. I guess floods are common enough that she's learned to make rafts? This one is barely big enough for two people, so you have to draw close if you want to fit. Kind of uncomfortable, but it's better than being caught in an imminent flood.

mnemonics.meaning: Edge There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> tying <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>, balancing them over the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edge</mark> of a cliff together. Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
mnemonics.reading: えん, ねん ふち None Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん). If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!

mnemonics.meaning: Endure Conceal If someone puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark> the pain and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conceal</mark> your discomfort with the situation. To endure something is to conceal how it makes you feel, after all. Now imagine there's a blade pressed close to your heart. Try to endure the pain and conceal your emotions, or your heart might be cut.
mnemonics.reading: にん しの None Learning to endure and conceal is all part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing — you have to be able to endure this if you want to conceal yourself. No one knows better than a ninja how enduring and concealing are closely related. Go ahead, hold your breath and try walking soundlessly around your house, concealing your footsteps. Not easy to endure, is it?

mnemonics.meaning: Fishing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> is where you're going to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fishing</mark>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too. Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fishing</mark> spot this is.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう つ None You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually! Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

mnemonics.meaning: Fox The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that hangs out in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> patches is the elusive <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fox</mark>! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that. Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
mnemonics.reading: こ きつね None If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back! Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

mnemonics.meaning: Good Luck The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good luck</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: きつ, きち よし None For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms. Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."

mnemonics.meaning: Grains The part of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grains</mark>. If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう つぶ None You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers. He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

mnemonics.meaning: Hair Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">friend</mark>. It's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hair</mark> and you're so proud of it. Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
mnemonics.reading: はつ かみ None Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair. Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?

mnemonics.meaning: Hill An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> is stuck into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hill</mark>. Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう おか None You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use." You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!

mnemonics.meaning: Ladle Dipper, Volume The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ladle</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: と None None You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground. Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.

mnemonics.meaning: Limb Looking at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you notice it's grown a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark>es. Wait, are those all… <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">limbs</mark>?! You feel absolutely terrified looking at the moon with all its branches consisting of limbs, lifelessly flopping around. How did this happen?
mnemonics.reading: し None None After some consideration, you know who put all those limbs on the moon. It must've been none other than the moon sheep (し)! The moon sheep are always up to no good, so this must all have been devised by them. Those darn moon sheep!

mnemonics.meaning: Measurement The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measurement</mark> kanji are exactly the same. If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
mnemonics.reading: すん None None "Calculate your enemy's position with accurate measurement," is more or less what Sun (すん) Tzu said, I think. The guy wrote The Art of War, you know. When Sun says measurements are important, you don't question him. Imagine Mr. Sun measuring distances and rations and whatnot just before going to war — maps, compasses, all kinds of measurement devices piled on his war table. Also, don't forget that in Chinese Sun is pronounced more like "soon."

mnemonics.meaning: Mystery Riddle No one can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> weighs in grains of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> — it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mystery</mark>! Imagine lifting a scooter, hefting it, trying to guess its weight in grains of rice. At least 100 grains, I'd say. But no one can say, really. It's a total mystery.
mnemonics.reading: めい なぞ None To get to the bottom of this mystery, you use a nozzle (なぞ). You pass rice through the nozzle one grain at a time, so you can figure out precisely how many grains of rice are equal to the weight of a scooter. Imagine watching this little nozzle squeeze out the rice, grain by grain, onto a scale. And imagine the boredom you'd feel watching that… But yes, you really can resolve any rice-based measurement mysteries thanks to this nozzle.

mnemonics.meaning: Peach The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> growing from it, one single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peach</mark> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons. Of course, this tree omen of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peach</mark> refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
mnemonics.reading: とう もも None If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも). It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

mnemonics.meaning: Pear The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> you cut off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pear</mark>. You've found some particularly big, sturdy ones, which is why you need the help of your knife. These pears are sure to be super juicy and delicious, but you need some extra tools to get them off the tree. Imagine looking up at a tree full of thick-stemmed, jumbo-size pears. You pull out your knife and get ready to hack them all down, one by one.
mnemonics.reading: り なし None As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast. Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?

mnemonics.meaning: Princess The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> is the lower ranking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do. Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
mnemonics.reading: None ひめ None The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it." The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

mnemonics.meaning: Push Open You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> to use an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">push open</mark> things. You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
mnemonics.reading: あい None None Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see. Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!

mnemonics.meaning: Recreation A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> loves her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> for some good ol' fashioned <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recreation</mark>. You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
mnemonics.reading: ご None None Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご). Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

mnemonics.meaning: Samurai The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">samurai</mark>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe. You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
mnemonics.reading: じ, し さむらい None The reading is <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">samurai</mark>, which should be easy enough to remember. If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

mnemonics.meaning: Scold From my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> I have told you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> times not to do that. Now I have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scold</mark> you. SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
mnemonics.reading: しつ しか None What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves! Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

mnemonics.meaning: Shout You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shout</mark>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout. You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
mnemonics.reading: きょう さけ None You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition. Imagine the word きょうと not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the きょう part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! きょうと！

mnemonics.meaning: Sprout A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprout</mark>. Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
mnemonics.reading: が め None When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you. You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

mnemonics.meaning: Storm The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storm</mark>. Well, it is a storm, really. If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storm</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: らん あらし None A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし). The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

mnemonics.meaning: Thunder <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> means only one thing... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thunder</mark>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder! Imagine hearing the thunder closing in on you as you frantically try to escape the rice paddy. RUN!!!
mnemonics.reading: らい かみなり None You can’t run fast enough to escape the thunder, so you decide to hide under a pile of… rye (らい)?! This rye will save your life. It’s just you and this pile of rye now. Take a deeeeep breath in, and really smell the thunder and rye in the air. You’re fine. You’re cozy. This rye will be your savior.

mnemonics.meaning: Tower When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tower</mark>! A flower tower made of flower power! Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers. How do you think the とうきょう tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.

mnemonics.meaning: Vermilion The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to get off this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> is a beautiful, brilliant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vermilion</mark> color. Vermilion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ あけ None You jump onto the vermilion slide. It's actually more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick. The vermilion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermilion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.

mnemonics.meaning: Wing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark> is on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, and they are attached <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wing</mark> of your amazing aircraft. Imagine a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wing</mark> that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
mnemonics.reading: よく つばさ None To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe. Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

mnemonics.meaning: Approximate A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to measure a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> is a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">approximate</mark> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right? Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
mnemonics.reading: けい, きょう ころ, ごろ None Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead. That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.

mnemonics.meaning: Bacteria When you leave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> for long enough, they'll turn into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bacteria</mark>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time. Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!
mnemonics.reading: きん None None There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria. Picture the King's mouth up close. Look at all the bacteria squiggling around and through his teeth and gums. Bleh! Barf!

mnemonics.meaning: Bell Something made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark>. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bell</mark>!  The village bell. Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.
mnemonics.reading: しょう かね None The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects. The Shougun bell even sounds like it's warning you that the Shougun has arrived. It makes a loud, low shooooouu shooou sound.

mnemonics.meaning: Boat The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boat</mark> kanji are the same! Boats are boats, you know?
mnemonics.reading: しゅう ふね, ふな None The reading is the same reading that you learned with the vocabulary 船. Since 船 and 舟 both mean "boat", this reading should be pretty easy to remember!

mnemonics.meaning: Bride The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who makes your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> a home is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bride</mark>. She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
mnemonics.reading: か よめ, とつ None Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning. Your bride is very upset at how sexist you're being right now, and makes you do all the cleaning instead. The maid still gets fired.

mnemonics.meaning: Calendar Looking up to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s, and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calendar</mark>. Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
mnemonics.reading: れき こよみ None Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related. Make sure you make the connection between the word 歴史 and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Cloudy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is being blocked by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark>, making it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloudy</mark>. You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.
mnemonics.reading: None くも None Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも. If it's cloudy there are clouds, so if you can read one, you can read the other!

mnemonics.meaning: Considerably An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">considerably</mark> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here]. The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
mnemonics.reading: や なり None Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there. Also, things that are "considerably" anything start somewhere. They become (なり) whatever "considerable" thing they are now from something smaller before.

mnemonics.meaning: Cram School You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> instruction in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. Where are you? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Cram school</mark>! Your cram school thinks that you’ll learn better sitting in a circle in the dirt. So there you are in the dirt, receiving your lessons.
mnemonics.reading: じゅく None None Not only does your cram school teach kids in a circle in the dirt, it also plays music on a jukebox (じゅく). Yes, a jukebox. They believe a jukebox's tunes help with cramming. Imagine a jukebox playing loudly right beside you while you’re cramming away. Hard to believe, but the jukebox's melodies do actually amplify the cramming fervor, making you just cram, cram, cram!

mnemonics.meaning: Curse From the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> comes... a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">curse</mark>! Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
mnemonics.reading: じゅ のろ None Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads. In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the no road curse, after all.

mnemonics.meaning: Damp After the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes out again and shines on these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damp</mark>. The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.
mnemonics.reading: しつ しめ None As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo! Luckily the shih tzu is kinda pinned between the spikes, so it isn't dead or anything, but it's definitely stuck. You try to help it out, but you slip because it's so damp and you fall in too! Imagine the sound of your cries mixing in with the shih tzu's as you both struggling to get out but can't because of how damp everything is.

mnemonics.meaning: Earnings The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s you have stored in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> reflect on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earnings</mark>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains. Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.
mnemonics.reading: か かせ None Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No! Picture your own earnings. Can you afford a lot of grains and a car?

mnemonics.meaning: Fly A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> (and presumably wings, too) is able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fly</mark>. Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.
mnemonics.reading: しょう かけ, と None Watching that sheep with feathers and wings flying around made you thirsty. You remember that you have a car kettle (かけ), so you reach into your car and grab your car kettle to make a special car-kettle brew. Imagine yourself enjoying the cozy car-kettle brew, while admiring the unusual sight of the sheep with feathers and wings flying through the sky. This is just shear bliss!

mnemonics.meaning: Gamble I'm putting all my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gamble</mark> and you're gambling. Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.
mnemonics.reading: と か None If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)! If you go to any of those fancy (and not so fancy) gamble-places, they always have a car sitting in the middle of the room. Usually rotating, really slowly, to make you want it more, making you gamble more.

mnemonics.meaning: Ghost Coming down with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>. They go right through two <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ghost</mark>s. The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.
mnemonics.reading: れい, りょう None None You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering." A ray gun, coincidentally, is the only thing that can kill a ghost, and there it lays, just out of reach. You'll have to be the one to pull the trigger of the ray gun. Do you pick up the ray gun out of the row boat to destroy the ghosts?

mnemonics.meaning: Gutter <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark> vs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark>. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gutter</mark>. To be fair, it's pretty obvious who would win. Nobody knows what that lifeguard was thinking.
mnemonics.reading: こう みぞ None In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage. "This lifeguard didn't believe in the power of kanji learning," こういち says to the press. "He was punished by the great Crabigator, who sent its tsunami as a warning for all." Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: Hunt I <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">protect</mark> my own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark>s by going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hunt</mark> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such. My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ か None I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways. Imagine hunting down animals in a car.

mnemonics.meaning: Leg If you've been to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">past</mark>, you had to get the special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leg</mark>. This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!
mnemonics.reading: きゃく あし None You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too. Picture Kyaku lifting up their pant leg and showing you all the stamps from all the different places they've been. There are even some planets on there!

mnemonics.meaning: Lucidity When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> struck, it hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lucidity</mark>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it! Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう す None Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits! Imagine yourself wearing a sharp suit and being a model of lucidity.

mnemonics.meaning: Lump A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lump</mark>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust. Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.
mnemonics.reading: かい かたまり None A lump of something is just a 固まり (かたまり) — the hardened thing itself. 塊 is derived from 固まり, which is the noun form of 固まる (to be hardened). You know a lump is usually something that's compressed and hardened.

mnemonics.meaning: Lunatic Crazy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lunatic</mark>, though. While we're speaking of animals, he's absolutely bat sh*t crazy.
mnemonics.reading: きょう くる None You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels. I think he maybe got too friendly with some raccoons and beavers and went crazy. Watch out for him if you live in きょうと, rabies is no joke.

mnemonics.meaning: Miss A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> should be called <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miss</mark>. Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."
mnemonics.reading: じょう むすめ None "Call me Miss Joe (じょう)," Joe says to you. When you think of "miss," remember the time Joe asked you to call him "Miss Joe". He’s this big, ten foot tall guy, but now he suddenly wants you to call him Miss Joe. Well, we’re all for respecting everbody’s personal choices here, so we better get used to it.

mnemonics.meaning: Naked Nude If you're showing me your "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark>" then you are just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">naked</mark>. You're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nude</mark>. You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.
mnemonics.reading: ら はだか None Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Don't look up "Ra Egyptian god naked" in Google. Nothing good will come of it. Instead, just imagine your own Egyptian god Ra being naked in front of you.

mnemonics.meaning: Peak An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> is sticking in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. It's sticking into the very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peak</mark>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it? Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peak</mark>. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
mnemonics.reading: がく たけ None You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now. Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.

mnemonics.meaning: Polish Below this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">polish</mark> it. It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.
mnemonics.reading: ま みが None You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle. There's only this one stone under these trees, and polishing the stone is the only job here. Still, you don't get much from it, thus the meager life of polishing your stone.

mnemonics.meaning: Shade This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> over it, creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shade</mark>. This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.
mnemonics.reading: いん かげ None The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at. Picture an inn with a cloud right above it right now. Look at the cloud-shaped shade keeping everyone visiting the inn cool and sunburn-free.

mnemonics.meaning: Skin The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> is a table that's made entirely of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin. Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
mnemonics.reading: き はだ None But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected. You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.

mnemonics.meaning: Soul Spirit The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> floating above a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> has its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soul</mark> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark> it once was. Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.
mnemonics.reading: こん たましい None You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!" POOF! Now there's a condor spirit floating in front of you, crying. "Thank you, human. You've saved my soul!" it says, and float/flies off and disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: Spear The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spear</mark> kanji are the same! Spears are spears. It makes sense!
mnemonics.reading: む ほこ None You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream. How do you like it? Don't stab cows with spears, you monster.

mnemonics.meaning: Stare When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> catches an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark>, it's only natural that you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stare</mark> at it. You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう なが None As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world. Whenever you see an omen (radical), remember that the omen will probably have Mrs. Chou in it!

mnemonics.meaning: Stiff You feel like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> that’s been <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">renew</mark>ed. How do renewed stones feel? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Stiff</mark>. Very stiff. Think of a stone being renewed like it is having something like a spa day. Pedicure, manicure, the whole shebang. It’ll come out all stiff and hardened, cause that’s how good stones are.
mnemonics.reading: こう かた None You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you. If only you could ask こういち to give you massages again, but he's too busy for you, now (being emperor and all).

mnemonics.meaning: Table The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">table</mark>. See all the toes lined up on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">table</mark>. They are the ones who showed up early.
mnemonics.reading: たく None None What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく). Imagine the toes talking to each other. "Hello Mr. Toe!" "Oh hello other Mr. Toe!"

mnemonics.meaning: Villain If there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark>, there's always a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">villain</mark> too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story. And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.
mnemonics.reading: きょう None None The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest. Arrrg! If only you had been closer to きょうと! Then you might have beaten this dastardly villain.

mnemonics.meaning: Waterfall A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dragon</mark> flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">waterfall</mark>. Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.
mnemonics.reading: None たき None Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき). Now imagine it being a bit tacky. Dragons are alright but... you just don't want to overdo it, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Black Ink Ink You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">black ink</mark>. That's what you use to write in black! Make sure the dirt you're using to make black ink is really, really black. Like the kind you find around volcanoes or something.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく すみ None Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!" Imagine yelling "SUE ME!" at someone's face, which is covered in the black ink you spilled there.

mnemonics.meaning: Blink Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> gets kicked with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> that came careening toward your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> when it popped off someone doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark>, and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blink</mark>. Well, of course you blink, you can't control that. And when a cleat come hurtling toward your eye it blinks automatically.
mnemonics.reading: しゅん またた, まばた None You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more. Soon the person who's cleat hit you is running over and trying to apologize and stop your crying, but it's too late.

mnemonics.meaning: Bubbles If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark>s around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bubbles</mark>. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created. Picture the bubbles bursting out of the wrapped up tsunami as it crashes down. The air that the tsunami sucked in while it was wrapping up come out as bubbles big and small.
mnemonics.reading: ほう あわ None One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air! Watch helplessly as your home, now trapped in a bubble, floats away into the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Building Ridge There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> that looks like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">building</mark>. The tree is tall and straight and doesn't have any leaves or branches. It's basically a big wooden building. Look at this big tree building over in the east. Imagine actually using it as a building and moving in. And why not? It's free real estate.
mnemonics.reading: とう むね, むな None That building happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the building. Imagine looking down on とうきょう from the top floor of this magnificent building you've just moved into. The sun is rising behind you, slowly illuminating the city below.

mnemonics.meaning: Calm Some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grains</mark> get stuck in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> grows <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calm</mark>. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down. He's calm now because he stomped right into a farmer's field (thus the rice) and if he didn't calm down he'd probably ruin it.
mnemonics.reading: おん おだ None Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes. Picture Wolverine sitting calmly in this field, onions causing tears to stream down his cheeks as he reflects on what he's done.

mnemonics.meaning: Cavity Hole You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark> in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cavity</mark> in the road. It's a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark>! You run over to where the child fell. They are just fine! Because they had an umbrella, they were able to float to the bottom.
mnemonics.reading: こう あな None "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち. "You will stay in that cavity or hole until you repent." If it hasn't been clear up until now, Emperor こういち is going mad with power.

mnemonics.meaning: Chair This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is very <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark>, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chair</mark>! Imagine this odd tree <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chair</mark> being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.
mnemonics.reading: い None None But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out. Feel the fear and regret. You should have known not to sit in this "chair". Mother nature never forgives, and now you don't have eyeballs.

mnemonics.meaning: Chrysanthemum If you pick the wrong kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, you'll be put into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with nothing but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> to eat. You'll especially want to avoid picking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chrysanthemums</mark>. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. Please don't ever pick them unless you want to end up in prison eating only rice for the rest of your life.
mnemonics.reading: きく None None If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks. Imagine holding a chrysanthemum in your hands while you get kicked over and over and over in prison. Was it worth it?

mnemonics.meaning: Cotton The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> comes from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cotton</mark>. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton. Imagine shoving your face into a nice, clean, white cotton towel. Mmm, so fresh.
mnemonics.reading: めん わた None This cotton is made by men (めん). Picture all of the men lined up, making towels out of pure white cotton. They're all rubbing their faces in the soft cotton whenever they can.

mnemonics.meaning: Devil Below the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark>. This demon is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">devil</mark>. You thought the devil hangs out in hell, but he actually hangs out under this canopy of trees.
mnemonics.reading: ま None None Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま). Into the trees is where all mamas go missing. And so the devil searches for his mama under this canopy of trees.

mnemonics.meaning: Dormitory You need to bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> to heat the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dormitory</mark>. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it. Imagine looking at a dormitory chore wheel and seeing it's your turn to carry in the charcoal this week. Bleh!
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory. The dormitory row boat leaks a little too, so by the time you get back you really need to light the charcoal and heat up!

mnemonics.meaning: Dove Pigeon There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>s and one of them is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dove</mark> and another is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pigeon</mark>. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders. Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.
mnemonics.reading: く はと None Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body. Devour it. You love pigeon hearts. Discard the rest, keep the heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Dull Make <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and they will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dull</mark> quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days. Picture a huge barracks made of dull, almost brown, gold. Maybe you should have picked a better material.
mnemonics.reading: どん にぶ, のろ None As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this." You stand cowering in front of the don as he inspects how dull the gold barracks are. You don't wanna be off'd for this just because the don was dull enough to make you use gold!

mnemonics.meaning: Forge You want to turn your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, so you throw it into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forge</mark>. Once the gold comb has melted down in the forge, you can forge it into whatever weapon you want.
mnemonics.reading: たん きた None You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん). Most people who do forge work have tans. And now you know why.

mnemonics.meaning: Go A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> moves a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> because he is playing the game <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Go</mark>. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good. Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.
mnemonics.reading: ご None None Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember! Go is Go. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: Habit When you get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> you always eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark>. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">habit</mark> you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two. Imagine if you had a habit of eating hot peppers whenever you thought you might be getting sick. To be fair, it flushes out your sinuses and tastes good, so it's not the worst habit you could have.
mnemonics.reading: へき くせ None Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own. Unfortunately, now you've gotten into the habit of telling everyone what to do when they get sick. "Yeah, yeah, eat a hot pepper, we know. But couscous is better," they say before you can speak. To each their own, I suppose.

mnemonics.meaning: Head of Plant Ear Of Plant The part of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> people <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">favor</mark> the most is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">head of the plant</mark>. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are. Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
mnemonics.reading: すい ほ None When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head. Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.

mnemonics.meaning: I Me I have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> things in my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> need them all for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me. What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: ご わが None Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!” Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: Key You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and cover your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> in it, turning it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">key</mark>. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key! You lost your old key, you see. But you're a go with the flow type of person, thanks to all the yoga, so you make a new one!
mnemonics.reading: けん かぎ None This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand! Imagine carefully putting your makeshift key into your car's lock. You close your eyes and pray that the car guillotine isn't going to trigger, knowing it isn't a legit key.

mnemonics.meaning: Manor You're standing under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> when you see something strange sticking out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manor</mark> starts rising out of the ground with you on top! Picture yourself on top of this manor that rose out of the ground. The canopy is still above you and it seems to be attached to the roof.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun (しょう) bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams. Imagine being chased by an angry shougun all through his giant, luxurious manor. You barely have time to admire the interior design with him gaining on you like this!

mnemonics.meaning: Monkey An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> into people's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monkey</mark>. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse. Imagine looking at a monkey at the zoo. Aww, it's so cute. But then it turns around and kicks some dirt right into your aww-ing mouth. Yuck! Why monkey, why?!
mnemonics.reading: えん さる None You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you? Picture the monkey saluting you as you spit dirt out of your mouth. Taste the bitter dirt and the bitter shame. You were played by a monkey.

mnemonics.meaning: Pride <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>s" with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pride</mark>! Nobody said you can't have pride after serving time in two big prisons. So say it with your chest! Imagine really puffing out your chest and saying, "Yes, two big prisons!", with all the pride you can muster.
mnemonics.reading: こ ほこ None After mustering all your pride, you feel like a new person, reborn almost. "I feel like a 子 (こ) again!", you proclaim to the world. With your regained, child-like pride, you venture out into the world after spending way too much time in those two big prisons. A new life awaits you, good luck!

mnemonics.meaning: Pupil Inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s a tiny <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> that makes up your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pupil</mark>. That's the black part of your eye! Oh, did you think your pupil was a hole? No, no, you misunderstand. That's where the village stands. It's full of little people who whisper to your brain what you should see.
mnemonics.reading: どう, とう ひとみ None All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home. Even if you're a pupil non-believer, at least you can see how it's shaped like a doughnut hole, right?

mnemonics.meaning: Rather On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. OR! In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>. Which would you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rather</mark>? Would you rather have your heart up on the roof, close to falling but out of the way of people. Or would you rather have your heart in a net, which people can't steal from, but is in the way of cars.
mnemonics.reading: ねい むし None As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands. "I'd rather you didn't have that!" you shout as your neighbors run through the neighborhood to their own house. You'd rather this wasn't happening! You'd rather your neighbors let you make your own choice!!

mnemonics.meaning: Secluded <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mountain</mark> is covered in poop because it is such a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secluded</mark> place. A secluded place has no toilets, so you just poop right on the mountain.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう None None The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again. Imagine hundreds of youths on this secluded mountain, all pooping on the ground while trying to get a cell phone signal.

mnemonics.meaning: Shelf With the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you command a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shelf</mark>. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth. Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.
mnemonics.reading: か か None Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money. Imagine transporting the shelves in your car. Over and over. Back and forth in your car. Vroom vroom.

mnemonics.meaning: Shut Up Your village wants to take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it, and you can think of no other response than <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">SHUT UP</mark>! The entire village is shouting and yelling and pointing at the poor dog. They're boiling a giant boiling pot of water, and you can't even hear yourself think anymore. Shut up, shut up, shut up!
mnemonics.reading: もく だま None The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back. Even the dog is mocking you now. It's barks sound more like "shut up, shut up" than "bow wow, bow wow." What the heck dog, I was trying to save your life!

mnemonics.meaning: Slice You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slice</mark> down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood. Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.
mnemonics.reading: ざん き None You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe. Zanzibar is a crazy place, huh? Continue to drive around Zanzibar as you wave your axe out your car window looking for another victim to slice.

mnemonics.meaning: Sovereign You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sovereign</mark> ruler of this bathroom. Whenever someone walks into your bathroom, you start screaming that you are the sovereign ruler of this toilet, this sink, this toothbrush, and all that touch these tiles.
mnemonics.reading: てい みかど None As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot! Picture your standing towel with a huge tater tot sewn into it. Everyone who sees this will know that you're the toilet tater tot sovereign.

mnemonics.meaning: Straw Sack The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your sad <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> aims a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straw sack</mark> you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your straw sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it's not something you want to have kicked. See this leader's kick coming at your straw sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your straw sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It's missing that because your life is lousy and sad.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう たわら None You manage to get your straw sack out of the way as you shout "Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!" Unfortunately your leader's friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. "Heyo!" he shouts, mockingly. You thought you were all cool saying "heyo" and moving your sack away from the kick, but they had this planned all along. Heyo…

mnemonics.meaning: Tariff Someone with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> comes and tells you that your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tariff</mark> that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple. People in top hats like to put tariffs on lots of things. Especially things you need, like grains you eat to stay alive. You have no choice but to pay.
mnemonics.reading: そ None None You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ). Everything you get from other counties has been tariffed except for soap. You'll be hungry, but at least you'll be clean.

mnemonics.meaning: Tempering The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> needs <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tempering</mark> before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it's entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you'd do in a forge. Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You're heat-treating the gold when you're tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.
mnemonics.reading: れん ね None The smithy where you're doing the tempering is just a rental (れん). You need a rental for your tempering because you haven't sold enough gold to own your own smithy yet. It's seen its fair share of tempering, so it's a pretty shabby rental… Imagine yourself tempering your gold with this shabby rental forge. It keeps flaring up and almost burning off your eyebrows every time you try to work it. It's tough doing tempering with a rental!

mnemonics.meaning: Thwart If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> wearing a giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark>, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thwart</mark> all of the plans the people in other buildings have. Picture the building, with it's tall top hat, inching closer to other buildings when no one is looking. It's planning to thwart everything!
mnemonics.reading: そ はば None The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building! Watch as the soap cleans all of the paint away, thwarting the entire paint project. The painters are on the ground, crying and squeaky clean.

mnemonics.meaning: Tray Ancestral Festival You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of your food on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>, then put that on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tray</mark> to keep it safe. This tray is an offering for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ancestral festival</mark>, where your ancestors' spirits visit you to check in and share some of that food you're offering on a tray. Imagine preparing this tray, just before your ancestors arrive in friendly ghost form to share part of your meal with you. They only come once a year, so make sure it's a nice tray, okay?
mnemonics.reading: ぼん None None The plate you put on the tray for the ancestral festival is made of bone (ぼん). Bone china, that is. How fancy… And appropriate, considering bone china is made from actual bone. Tap the bone china plate with your knuckle bone. Hear the pleasant clink it makes as you set it on the tray.

mnemonics.meaning: Years Old Year, Time You need to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> from going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to ask him how many <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">years old</mark> he is.
