He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits. Depending how many years old he is, this guy could be violating like three different laws right now.
mnemonics.reading: さい, せい とし, とせ None Remember the vocab word 〜才 which also meant "years old"? Well, this has the same reading: さい. No matter how many years old you are, everyone loves kanji with easy readings.

mnemonics.meaning: Zero Spill You get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. Your orders are to make sure there is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">zero</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spill</mark>. Despite it raining, your orders are to make sure none (zero!) of the rain spills anywhere. Figure out what you need to do to make sure you follow these rain orders successfully. Zero spill, alright?
mnemonics.reading: れい こぼ None The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain. You just take your ray gun and "zap!" the clouds are gone. There will be zero spills today. Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: Cash That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">penguin</mark> over there seems to have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> stuffed with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cash</mark>. The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.
mnemonics.reading: へい None None Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles. You wait for the penguin to leave and you run over to the hay stack and stick your hand in. But you don't feel the towel or the cash! Instead you pull out your hand and it's full of hay and needles. Ouch! No fair, gimme that cash!!

mnemonics.meaning: Chopsticks You give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> and they make them into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chopsticks</mark>. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession. Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
mnemonics.reading: None はし None Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for. Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!

mnemonics.meaning: Clear Rub <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s if you want to see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>ly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun. You can even rub charcoal in your eyes if you really want to clear them up, but you should probably only do this under the supervision of your eye doctor.
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death. Imagine how dangerous it would be not to have clear vision while you row around in a row boat. You might even smack yourself in the face with your own oars.

mnemonics.meaning: Cliff There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> on top of a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with a steep <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cliff</mark> even bigger and steeper and scarier. Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.
mnemonics.reading: がい がけ None You can't believe how big the cliff is now with the mountain and the dirt. You look at it for so long, you just become another gawker (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge. Imagine a giant cliff that turns every passerby into a gawker, just like you.

mnemonics.meaning: Cook Without a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, you will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> the ability to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cook</mark> anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail. Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
mnemonics.reading: すい た None You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal. Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.

mnemonics.meaning: Cosmetics Sitting safely under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> you take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, mix it up, and create unique <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cosmetics</mark> for your face. Imagine mixing dirt and rice together to make some cosmetics that best fit your skin tone and type. No one will see you doing it under this canopy too, so the secret formula you come up with will be safe.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look. Imagine meeting the Shougun with your new cosmetics all over your face. You look amazing! Stunning! The shougun wants to know where you got that foundation, you're glowing!

mnemonics.meaning: Crash A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> falls into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> when a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crash</mark>es into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it. Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?
mnemonics.reading: つい None None You pull the poor pig out of the rubble of the crash. It's not dead, but it had a nasty bump to the head and now thinks it's a bird. "TWEET (つい)!" says the pig. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" Poor confused pig. Imagine trying to explain to the pig that it's a pig, and not a bird. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" says the pig again. Oh dear.

mnemonics.meaning: Deceit A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> will try to hide what it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deceit</mark>. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab. Covering things up with deceit is pretty much the worst thing you can do, so don't be like this crab.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ あざむ None Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ). Picture the crab with its head, er, front half? Whatever, it's in the guillotine and it's screaming, "You've been deceived! I never deceived anyone, you're all sheep!"

mnemonics.meaning: Door Hinged Door What would a door criminal steal? A door, of course, but specifically a hinged door. You know, the kind that swings open and shut? That's the kind of door 扉 means. Imagine waking up one morning to find all your doors missing. The door criminal strikes again! They left the sliding door behind though, since they only wanted the hinged 扉 ones. So… there's that at least?
mnemonics.reading: ひ とびら None To protect your door, you get help from 飛び Ra (とびら). 飛び Ra is the flying (飛び) version of Ra, the Egyptian sun god. Whenever a criminal tries to steal your door, 飛び Ra flies out from behind it and blinds them with his sun-god brightness. Now picture yourself waking up to a bright, beautiful morning with all your 扉 doors still safely attached to their hinges. Thanks, 飛び Ra!

mnemonics.meaning: Drip A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> and it begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drip</mark>. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while. Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
mnemonics.reading: てき したた, しずく None Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits. Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!

mnemonics.meaning: Fence In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> lined up with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> attached to them, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fence</mark>. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in. Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?
mnemonics.reading: へい None None You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい). Picture yourself climbing over this fence (that you're definitely not supposed to climb based on all these flags and horns) and falling into the piles of hay. It's a little scratchy, but otherwise pretty comfy!

mnemonics.meaning: Fog It's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>ing on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> that has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fog</mark>. When warm water touches a cold spear, fog billows out and covers everything.
mnemonics.reading: む きり None Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there. You walk toward the kirin through the fog. When you get close, the image before you becomes clear: it's two cans of Kirin beer on a slide. Next time you see fog, keep your eyes peeled for the real kirin in the kiri.

mnemonics.meaning: Folding Fan After passing through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark> to put the finishing touches on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">folding fan</mark>. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is. Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
mnemonics.reading: せん おうぎ, あお None Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur. Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!

mnemonics.meaning: Grudge A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will only inhabit a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> if it's holding a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grudge</mark>. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something. Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.
mnemonics.reading: こん うら None If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees. Picture a tree with the soul of a condor with a grudge in it before you. You feel bad about being so wasteful with paper and chopsticks now, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Hat You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and wrap it around your head to keep the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s. You've invented... the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hat</mark>! A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None After inventing the hat, you wanted to show it off to everyone, so you went to the bowling (ぼう) alley. You really stood out bowling strike after strike in your fancy new hat, and before you knew it, people had coined a term for your funky headpiece. That's right — you became the namesake of the iconic bowler hat! Imagine sitting your grandkids on your lap someday and telling them how you're the person the bowler hat's named after. They'll be bursting with pride and admiration.

mnemonics.meaning: Hate The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hate</mark>. You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?
mnemonics.reading: ぞう にく None It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう). Zombies are pretty filled with hate, so it makes sense that you'd see a bunch of hate if you used the soul mask on them.

mnemonics.meaning: Help The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> crew needs all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark> he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city. Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
mnemonics.reading: さ None None Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away. Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.

mnemonics.meaning: Insert You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thousand</mark>s and while looking up at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you decide you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insert</mark> them in there. Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)
mnemonics.reading: そう さ None You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone. Since you have a thousand fingers too many, you decide to insert them all into the sun and watch as their souls pop out. You listen to the little souls scream at you.

mnemonics.meaning: Italy A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Italy</mark>. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun! Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
mnemonics.reading: い だ None Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X! Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.

mnemonics.meaning: Lie They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> to telling a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie</mark> is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key. Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.
mnemonics.reading: さ いつわ None The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well. Imagine trying to lie your way out of this. He saw you steal his saw. He caught you red handed. What sort of lie can you spin to get yourself out of this situation?

mnemonics.meaning: Likeness With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">likeness</mark> to me. Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.
mnemonics.reading: じょ ごと None You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth. Jo-Anne popped her mouth off and put it on you. Indeed with that mouth on, you have an extreme likeness to her.

mnemonics.meaning: Lips A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> came out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and created your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lips</mark>. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole. Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.
mnemonics.reading: しん くちびる None Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there. Imagine wrapping your new lips around the mouth of this Kuchi beer bottle. It's so good! And you aren't spilling any of it!

mnemonics.meaning: Old Woman A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wave</mark> crashes into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>, transforming her into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">old woman</mark>! The wave washes away all of the woman's makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is. Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
mnemonics.reading: ば ばあ None In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes "Baa! Baa!" and hops around on all fours like a sheep. Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying "baa" over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!

mnemonics.meaning: Palm If you want to cover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, you have to use your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">palm</mark>. Why the palm? Well, if you do it knuckles-to-mouth, you're sort of just punching the Viking… and you don't want a punch a Viking. That's why you use the palm. And don't use your fingers either, 'cause they'll just get bitten off. You absolutely want to make sure it's the palm — a nice flat open palm. It's a lot like feeding a horse, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: しょう てのひら None This Viking-touching technique of using the palm was developed by the Shougun (しょう). The Shogun has to deal with a lot of loudmouthed Vikings, so he's learned to use his palm to cover their mouths. Imagine if a Shogun and a Viking had actually met in history (never mind that the dates don't overlap). You can definitely picture the quiet, refined Shogun putting his palm over the mouth of some noisy Viking during a tough diplomatic meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: Pathetic With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>, you hit yourself in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pathetic</mark> loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic. Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
mnemonics.reading: あい あわ None You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you. Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.

mnemonics.meaning: Rainbow An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> specializing in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> builds a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rainbow</mark>. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows. Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
mnemonics.reading: こう にじ None This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!” Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.

mnemonics.meaning: Refreshing A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">refreshing</mark>! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing. Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
mnemonics.reading: そう さわ None You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing! Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!

mnemonics.meaning: Rest You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> to give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rest</mark>. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time. It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.
mnemonics.reading: けい いこ None What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief. You should rest right now. Take a break from Japanese and go eat some cake. (Just remember to come back when your tongue and heart are sufficiently rested!)

mnemonics.meaning: Roast <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Before</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> something, make sure that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">roast</mark> it. Why would you roast something before you boil it? Because that something is tea! Or maybe coffee. Tea leaves and coffee beans are roasted before they're boiled.
mnemonics.reading: せん い None Now you roast yourself some centaur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea. Smell the wafting scent of roasted centaur as you sip on your freshly-roasted tea.

mnemonics.meaning: Shaku Japanese Foot This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> is the exact length of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shaku</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese foot</mark>. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot. Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
mnemonics.reading: しゃく None None How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese. Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.

mnemonics.meaning: Smash Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> and throw it at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smash</mark> them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits! Picture the nine crosses in front of you, lined up in a triangle. Now take your rock, hold it above your head, and SMASH it down on them as hard as you can!!
mnemonics.reading: さい くだ None As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it. You smash things because your own heart has been smashed by your cyborg. :'(

mnemonics.meaning: Sticky Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sticky</mark>. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice. Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.
mnemonics.reading: ねん ねば None This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it. Imagine sculpting these sticky rice nendoroids with your bare hands. Feel the sticky rice between your fingers as you smush the rice into cute little nendoroids.

mnemonics.meaning: Tatami Mat In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark>. It sits atop an area of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tatami mat</mark>s. The meaning you're trying to learn is tatami mat, so focus on the beautiful tatami mats that are strangely in the middle of this rice paddy. On top is a forehead with a top hat. It almost looks like the tatami mats are an altar for this gruesome scene.
mnemonics.reading: じょう たたみ None Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Joe (じょう), the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village. You saw Joe setting up the tatami mats a day earlier, but you thought he was just making an area for workers in the field to rest in. Does the forehead with a top hat have anything to do with Joe? What sort of ominous sign could this be?

mnemonics.meaning: Torso The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">torso</mark>. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon. Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
mnemonics.reading: どう None None Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things. Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.

mnemonics.meaning: Towel The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">towel</mark> as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: きん None None You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one. Go into your bathroom or your linen closet right now. Look at your towels. Look for the small きん hidden there.

mnemonics.meaning: Wick There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> growing around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wick</mark> sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow. See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
mnemonics.reading: しん None None Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers. Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.

mnemonics.meaning: Willow A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>ed with one pattern, then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>ed with another pattern, over and over, is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">willow</mark> tree. A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう やなぎ None Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening. Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.

mnemonics.meaning: Accomplish A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> riding on it will be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accomplish</mark> anything. Imagine the pig scooting around. It is able to accomplish anything you can imagine (so go nuts with your imagination).
mnemonics.reading: すい と, つい None It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off. Perhaps it even takes the swing all the way around in a full 360 degree rotation. This horned scooter riding pig can truly accomplish anything.

mnemonics.meaning: Amass <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark>ly appearing in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. No matter what you do to them, they continue to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amass</mark>. Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
mnemonics.reading: ちく たくわ None As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well. Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.

mnemonics.meaning: Armpit The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> has a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> it gets from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of every <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">armpit</mark> of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices. Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
mnemonics.reading: きょう わき None This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life? Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.

mnemonics.meaning: Blossom Bloom When a flower looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> that reach up to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>, you know it's in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blossom</mark>. It's all opened up like a mouth, and the pistil and stamen are like horns reaching up to heaven for its sunlight and rain. Imagine studying this little blossom. Its mouth is open and nectar-filled, and out of it spring these horn-like things that reach up to heaven. It smells nice too. A perfect specimen for your blossom collection, maybe?
mnemonics.reading: しょう さ None If it's shaped like a mouth with horns poking out of it, you know it's going to be a tough little blossom. That's why you'll need a saw (さ) if you've got any hope of cutting it down for your blossom collection. Picture those classic dainty little blossoms — buttercups, pansies, you name it. Now imagine their tougher cousins, blossoms so tough you'd need a saw to cut them down. If you can picture the latter, you should remember the さ reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Clever Wise Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> uses a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to break open <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. This is really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clever</mark>, because shucking shellfish is a lot of work. It's also a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wise</mark> move, because it'll save him time that he can spend on all his other servant chores. "You sure are clever, man!" you shout encouragingly at your wise servant as he plops his stool down on another mound of shellfish. Dinner tonight is sure to be a seafood feast, and you can't wait!
mnemonics.reading: けん かしこ None "Yes, more clever than you!" he yells, tearing off his servant's disguise. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I won't let you eat these shellfish. I'm taking them back to the sea, where they belong!" Picture Ken standing there with his sword and crab-shell armor. Pretty clever of him to disguise himself as your servant for so many years just to save a few mollusks. It might have been wiser not to shuck so many of them first, though…

mnemonics.meaning: Coloring Colouring You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to climb a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> gets the same <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coloring</mark> as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red! Imagine digging your cleats into the bark of the tree until you get high enough for your hair to start coloring itself tree colors. It might be a lot of work, but it's worth it.
mnemonics.reading: さい いろど あや This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones. You couldn't take the pain of losing your cyborg, so you've become one. Your robo-hair can change its coloring, but soon you'll be even more cyborg-y than before!

mnemonics.meaning: Crevice In this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>. They keep this small, small sun inside of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crevice</mark>. You wouldn't want to keep a sun out in the open, even if it's small (and small). You'd put it inside something, like a crevice. Imagine walking into the building and seeing the small sun right inside, in a crevice.
mnemonics.reading: げき すき None They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき). If the sun were out in the open, it'd melt all the snow, making it hard to ski here. So they hide the sun away in a crevice so people can ski.

mnemonics.meaning: Cultivate Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> needs a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> in it if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cultivate</mark> good crops. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing? Imagine burying a dead clown in the dirt and then planting some seeds on top. It's worth it, you think, if it helps cultivate your crops.
mnemonics.reading: ばい つちか None Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt. Saying bye is polite. Never forget to say bye, even in the middle of a cold-blooded clown murder.

mnemonics.meaning: Dance Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark>, as your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> says, was given the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dance</mark>. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance! Picture your mama asking you to dance. The two of you pick up and kick your feet to dance, spinning 'round and 'round.
mnemonics.reading: よう おど None You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet. Lean down and take a big whiff of your dancing feet. The odor is... HORRIBLE! AHGH!

mnemonics.meaning: Darkness This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> makes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">darkness</mark>. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too. Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
mnemonics.reading: あん, おん やみ None You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy! Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!

mnemonics.meaning: Diagonal You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark>s laid out <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagonally</mark> in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there. Look at all these ladles lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ なな None In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook. Uh oh, is this one of those weird tests where they find out if you're the chosen one or some old scholar reincarnated? Who knew laying ladles at diagonal angles could reveal this kinda stuff?!

mnemonics.meaning: Flower Pot Bowl Melt down this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> and recast it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower pot</mark>. A solid gold book is too heavy to hold and too shiny to read, but a solid gold flower pot would make a fancy new addition to your garden. Imagine melting down your gold book. You're excited to have your new flower pot, but you're a little sad because this book was actually pretty interesting. Make a mental note to buy it in paperback later.
mnemonics.reading: はち None None The gold flower pot has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the flower pot! Okay, so this may not be the best flower pot. You usually don't need a hatch or this much gold coating. But that's how they used to do it in the old days, so that's good enough for you!

mnemonics.meaning: Frost <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> falls off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and lands in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> where it turns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frost</mark>. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye. Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
mnemonics.reading: そう しも None This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns. Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)

mnemonics.meaning: Harvest You need to feed this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flower</mark> wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> so you start the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harvest</mark>. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them. Picture this fat turkey with flowers on its head, sitting on a stool. It's gobbling for grains and you need to be the one who harvests them.
mnemonics.reading: かく None None You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him. Imagine an angry cock chasing you around as you try to harvest grain. He keeps pecking you, ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: Hemp This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hemp</mark>. Wow, these hemp plants are so big that they look like trees. But, despite their size they're still just hemp.
mnemonics.reading: ま あさ None Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did. Your mama knew that you were going to like hemp in the future, so she planted these hemp plants for you. What a great mama.

mnemonics.meaning: Horse Riding This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> may look <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> but it’s actually perfect for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse riding</mark>! Look at this odd horse. It's a little odd-looking, but it turned its quirks into strengths and now it's an exceptional horse for horse riding!
mnemonics.reading: き None None Before horse riding, you’ll need the key (き) to access the stable and let out the odd horse you'll be riding. Want to ride the odd horse? Then, you must have the key to open its stable!

mnemonics.meaning: Humiliate The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humiliate</mark>s you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet. Honestly, that's what you get for lying. But it doesn't make it any less humiliating even if you deserve it.
mnemonics.reading: じょく はずかし None Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!" Imagine all of the cruel jokes people say to humiliate you. Feel your face burn and your stomach flip.

mnemonics.meaning: Lamp <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> you use to light up the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> needs to go in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lamp</mark>. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night. Picture these lamps lining the street, with their little fires burning brightly. Nowadays we don't have real fire in them, we use electricity!
mnemonics.reading: とう あかり, とも None These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up! Picture とうきょう, not lit up by all of the electricity, signs, shops, and things that light up its streets today, but by old-fashioned fire lamps!

mnemonics.meaning: Livestock In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> there is some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">livestock</mark>. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed. Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
mnemonics.reading: ちく None None Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings. Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.

mnemonics.meaning: Melt The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">form</mark> and you begin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">melt</mark>. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt. Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
mnemonics.reading: よう と None The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt! Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.

mnemonics.meaning: Mosquito The type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> that ruins your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mosquito</mark>. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing. Imagine sitting at your desk writing when a mosquito starts bzzzzing in your ear. You can't ignore it, it's gonna bite you. So you flail around helplessly.
mnemonics.reading: None か None That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car? You can't. You can't write like this. You need to kill the mosquito and its little car too.

mnemonics.meaning: Notebook Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and make it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark>. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">notebook</mark>, which you will write all your notes in. You are making the towel really long, because it's white and it might be good for writing in. It's going to become your notebook.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう とばり None Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう). Something bad is going to happen, and you need to warn everybody. It's her, it's her, it's her. Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou!

mnemonics.meaning: Paint A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> will cover all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paint</mark>. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors. Picture all of the different colors of paint being swept along by tsunami after tsunami, painting the dirt as it goes.
mnemonics.reading: と ぬ None You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow. Imagine dipping each of your toes into the paint-dirt, one by one, to paint each of them a different color. Why are you doing this?

mnemonics.meaning: Paste Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are worth a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> because you decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paste</mark> your fortune to the shellfish. Picture all of your riches, your money, your jewels. They're all pasted directly onto all of your shellfish!
mnemonics.reading: ちょう は None You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste. "Ha ha!" Paste paste. "Ha ha ha!!" PASTE PASTE PASTE.

mnemonics.meaning: Punch Hit Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapons</mark>, but everyone prefers to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">punch</mark> each other. When everyone's armed, things can escalate quickly, so it's better to stick to fists to be safe. Picture two heavily armed residents of your district punching the living crap out of each other. They're both armed to the teeth with missile launchers, flamethrowers, katanas, lightsabers, etc., but neither one wants to be the first to draw a weapon and escalate the situation.
mnemonics.reading: おう なぐ None The district residents punch each other in front of the 王 (おう). These punching matches are actually gladiatorial battles for the 王's entertainment. Imagine the heavily armed combatants from earlier slugging it out, but this time the 王 is watching them from a box seat above the action. He gleefully encourages them, a maniacal, bloodthirsty glint in his eye.

mnemonics.meaning: Radiance The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">light</mark> shines on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> with a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">radiance</mark>. The car you are in is a convertible, so the light shines right onto your big bald forehead. The light has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from this light hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man. Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
mnemonics.reading: き かがや None This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car. Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.

mnemonics.meaning: Recollection When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">idea</mark> it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recollection</mark> of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now. When you have a recollection of some idea or thing in the past, it's just your soul saying, hey remember this? Let's not forget this.
mnemonics.reading: おく None None Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again. Imagine recollecting a past life in Oklahoma. Life was simple and nice. You should consider taking this as a sign to move there again!

mnemonics.meaning: Regret If you try to put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">every</mark>thing, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">regret</mark> it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything. Imagine if you went full force into everything you've ever even thought of doing. Imagine how burnt out your soul would be. Imagine all the regret you'd have that you didn't just stick to one thing and do it well.
mnemonics.reading: かい くや, く None The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club. Throw everything you regret away. Only kayak from now on.

mnemonics.meaning: Resistant You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> in for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> but it is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resistant</mark>. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others. Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
mnemonics.reading: たい た None Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly. See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.

mnemonics.meaning: Shield On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> is holding a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shield</mark>. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off. Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん たて None The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell! This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.

mnemonics.meaning: Snake There is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">snake</mark> to your roof. Snakes love insects, especially when they're ready to eat on a spoon. But, snakes don't usually go on top of the roof, so that's why you have to tempt one with an insect in a spoon.
mnemonics.reading: じゃ へび None Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび). Especially big snakes. They're really, really hebi.

mnemonics.meaning: Squad If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> you become part of his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squad</mark>. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line. Imagine if you were given a knife and allowed into the king's squad. Would you let the power corrupt you?
mnemonics.reading: はん None None This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die. I'm not saying Han Solo is a bad squad leader, but his track record isn't the greatest. I mean, best case scenario the king gets stabbed in the arm and they manage to win.

mnemonics.meaning: Starve If you have nothing to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ego</mark>, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">starve</mark>. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people. You have to check your ego at the door, because you'll definitely starve otherwise.
mnemonics.reading: が う None You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position. Now your starved body has been moved to the top of a castle, where you scare away people and birds with your loud grumbling stomach and scary face.

mnemonics.meaning: Starve You’re so hungry that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> so you won’t <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">starve</mark>. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive. You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
mnemonics.reading: き う None After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve. Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!

mnemonics.meaning: Swift You drive your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> off this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, holding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> tight to your chest, at a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swift</mark> speed. Imagine swiftly shooting off the side of the cliff on your scooter, holding the cross for dear life.
mnemonics.reading: じん None None Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now. Now you're swiftly shooting through the sky as your jeans flutter down toward the ground behind you. You also feel a swift breeze on all of your downstairs bits now.

mnemonics.meaning: Threaten There's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> stacked on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">threaten</mark>ing to bring it down! The moon actually looks like it wants to threaten you now too. It seems to have grown a big, smiling, angry mouth and it's way closer to you than you've ever seen it. All that power is radiating out of it and down towards you, threateningly.
mnemonics.reading: きょう おど, おびや None This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer. Picture the powerful moon, threatening to crush きょうと and all its residents. If only a small green boy could turn back time and save everyone from this powerful moon!

mnemonics.meaning: Use Up Exhaust You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhaust</mark>ed. It's all gone! You never thought they'd <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">use up</mark> their shrimp supply so quickly. Imagine the lack of shrimp on the ice. All you wanted was some delicious shrimp for dinner, but now it's all gone.
mnemonics.reading: じん つ None How could the store use up its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit! Imagine the worker's jeans and how gross they are with all those shrimp stuffed into them. Yuck!

mnemonics.meaning: Approximation Bite a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">approximation</mark> on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close. Once you have an approximation on the age, you'll be able to come up with an approximation on how much it's worth too.
mnemonics.reading: がい おおむ None As you're recording your approximation down, somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway. The guy is trying to look at your approximation now, while calling YOU "guy" over and over, and you just want him to buy it and leave you alone!

mnemonics.meaning: Arrest You run your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> along the words of a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark>. You are learning about the law because you plan to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrest</mark> somebody. Imagine reading the paragraph very slowly. You find your answer. It looks like you'll be able to arrest that person...
mnemonics.reading: こう かか None Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now. Still, according to this paragraph you're running your fingers through, you can do it. You can arrest こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Boil If <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>, you let them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boil</mark>! There's someone in your face yelling about how they want to boil! You yell back, "Okay, if you want to boil, just boil!"
mnemonics.reading: しゃ に None Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway. Once your knee is done boiling, the person kneels down in front of you and presents it on a platter, mocking you, since you can't kneel anymore. You should pay more attention to what's going on from now on or you could find yourself in... HOT WATER. Ohohoho.

mnemonics.meaning: Capsize Cover If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark> then it's going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">capsize</mark>. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down! If you want to save it you better <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cover</mark> up the black hole! The only way to save it from capsizing is to cover it right up! Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
mnemonics.reading: ふく おお, くつがえ None You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing! Man, f**k you you, black hole. F**k you you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered?

mnemonics.meaning: Chess Piece The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> who can write a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark> gets to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chess piece</mark>. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor. Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
mnemonics.reading: く こま None Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for. See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.

mnemonics.meaning: Confused Bewildered Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is going <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wild</mark> because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confused</mark>. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild! Think back to the last time you were confused. Remember how your soul felt? You were so confused it went wild and made you feel dumb and bad, like a wild person.
mnemonics.reading: こう あわ None Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion. Imagine being confused about Japanese, for example. In your confusion everything seems scary and wild and your soul is utterly bewildered, but then here comes こういち. He sits with you and pats your back and tries to help you stop being so confused.

mnemonics.meaning: Conspire Watch what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to what appears to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, because that tree will 100% <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conspire</mark> against you. Trees may look all sweet and innocent, like they aren't listening to every word you say, but it's a front! They're conspiring against you!! They'll blackmail you and take everything!!!
mnemonics.reading: ぼう はか None Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down! Watch as the conspiratorial tree and all it's gossiping friends are bowled over by your bowling ball. Phew. You're safe from the trees. For now.

mnemonics.meaning: Crane On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> there's some type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crane</mark>. Picture the beautiful black and white crane dancing gracefully on the roof. Now that you know what it is, you feel a little bad about calling it a turkey bird.
mnemonics.reading: かく つる None The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird. The crane keeps saying you're too rude whenever other people come close so they know what kind of person you are. Yikes, you really shouldn't have gotten on this crane's bad side.

mnemonics.meaning: Cultivation You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> to begin <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cultivation</mark> of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down. Imagine being in a field, using your fingers and a stone to cultivate the whole thing, by hand.
mnemonics.reading: たく None None Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks! Now cultivation is going to involve getting all the tacks out of here, preferably with the stone and not your fingers, so they don't get stuck anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Decline You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>, and aiming it at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it into the air and eventually it begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decline</mark> and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun. As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical has its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
mnemonics.reading: すい おとろ None As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble. Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!

mnemonics.meaning: Encourage A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark> who's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> will use his size to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encourage</mark> his troops. "Look at me! You can be a big commander someday too!" he shouts, encouraging everyone.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike. Picture the encouraged Shougun: his eyes are shining with tears, his heart is pounding, he's been encouraged to be better!

mnemonics.meaning: Extract Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> give you a good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extract</mark> things. You extract juice from fruits, oil from seeds, and coffee from beans. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason. Imagine having fingers that work like a magic wand of extraction. With a flick of your fingers, you could extract any radical out of a kanji too. How could these special fingers not be a reason for you to extract? With these fingers, you can't stop extracting!
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう None None Your magic fingers can even extract the essence out of living things, so you decide to extract some from Chewbacca (ちゅう). You always thought a nice Chewbacca extract could take your cookies to the next level. It'll help offset the sweetness and make them extra chewy (or chewbacca-y!).
