Taste that chewy goodness in every bite. All you need is a dash of Chewbacca extract.

mnemonics.meaning: Faint A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> and a couple <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>s run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">faint</mark> remnant of what was once there. You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
mnemonics.reading: たん あわ None Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well. Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.

mnemonics.meaning: Foundation Cornerstone There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark>. That stone and two trees will make the perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foundation</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cornerstone</mark>, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable. Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
mnemonics.reading: そ いしずえ None After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ). Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!

mnemonics.meaning: Highness <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Compare</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Highness</mark>. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building. Picture Her Highness, high up in her building. Now compare her home and life to yours, you dirt person.
mnemonics.reading: へい None None I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness. Picture His and Her Highness coming out of their huge building and walking by you in your hay pile. "My goodness, Highness, have you ever seen such a dirty, fluffy creature?" "My no, dear, let's move quickly to remove it from our sight!"

mnemonics.meaning: Immersed In the event of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> will all be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">immersed</mark> in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool. Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
mnemonics.reading: しん ひた, つ None Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts. Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful of tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Inferiority The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> members of society without <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> suffer from severe <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inferiority</mark> complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes. Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
mnemonics.reading: れつ おと None Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!” Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!

mnemonics.meaning: Intuition This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark> has the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intuition</mark>. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them. Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
mnemonics.reading: かん None None This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by now, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do. Genghis Khan probably has the strongest intuition of anyone in history. This crab trap is getting close though.

mnemonics.meaning: Isolate A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bully</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">isolate</mark> itself. Building have feelings like people, you know. Picture a single building, isolated from the rest of the city and those mean, bully buildings that live there.
mnemonics.reading: かく へだ None The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it. Picture the sun rising behind an isolated building. A cock lets out a cry from the roof. It's a sad and lonely scene.

mnemonics.meaning: Kick In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, it's tough to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> because you're always getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kick</mark>ed. In the foot capital, you can only use your feet. So petting dogs looks a lot like kicking them.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう け None Imagine yourself kicking a kettle (け). There's nothing that's more satisfying to kick than a good ol' kettle, you know? You just love how a kettle gets dented as you kick it around.

mnemonics.meaning: Mulberry You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, and yet another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and stack them on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mulberry</mark> bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree. Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
mnemonics.reading: そう くわ None Your mulberry tree then produces a quantity (くわ) of mulberries. Yum. Imagine the huge quantity of mulberries growing from your stool tree. Imagine picking them all. What an enormous quantity of mulberries you now have.

mnemonics.meaning: Nun You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nun</mark> as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds. Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
mnemonics.reading: に あま None You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved! Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.

mnemonics.meaning: Pearl The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> takes his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> into his private <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> and is given a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pearl</mark> as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards. Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
mnemonics.reading: しゅ たま None The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls. Oh. I guess the king didn't need your pearl, since he has a pearl chute to get them off his jet before takeoff. You feel silly. And you kind of want to jump into the pearl chute yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Podium On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> trying to cover the number of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">times</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">podium</mark>. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!) This kanji also just... really looks like a podium right? With a guy wearing a graduation cap, pointing toward you, in the crowd.
mnemonics.reading: だん None None You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn! I guess that makes sense. This podium is by the dawn for the dawn.

mnemonics.meaning: Pottery The only type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> you'll be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> is one made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pottery</mark>. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way. Picture the first piece of pottery you ever made. Feel it in your hands. At least you've learned something new while you've been stuck in prison.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least. Selling your prison pottery in とうきょう might even help you get out faster. Yippee!

mnemonics.meaning: Prune Take your greatest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>, hold a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> nice and close to it, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prune</mark> away all the weak and dead bits. All treasures need to be taken care of, no matter what they are. Prune away anything that isn't necessary.
mnemonics.reading: None か None Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off. You want your car to be small and sleek, not a giant truck, so you have to carefully prune it when it grows too much.

mnemonics.meaning: Realize Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> connects to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> different <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouths</mark>, allowing you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">realize</mark> something. You can realize profound truths about the world with these five mouths speaking to your soul. Maybe the five mouths are your five senses, "speaking" information to your soul so you can realize and perceive things about the world. Whoa, dude…
mnemonics.reading: ご さと None Right now those five mouths are helping you to realize something about Godzilla (ご). First you hear Godzilla, then you see him, then you smell him, then you touch him. Finally you taste Godzilla. Now you've realized exactly what kind of thing he is. You truly know Godzilla. You now realize why Godzilla destroys all those buildings: he's warning the Japanese people about the use of new technology and warfare and experimentation. He just wants everyone to realize what the consequences of these new things could be!

mnemonics.meaning: Royal Consort Princess, Queen The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> one has to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> is one's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">royal consort</mark>… You know, assuming one is a member of the royalty. This is a woman who's tied the knot with some royal person and been made into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">queen</mark>. Even if you're royalty, you can't expect to have a woman all to yourself without popping the question. Put a ring on it and make that lady your royal consort!
mnemonics.reading: ひ きさき None You can tell someone's a royal consort by the heat (ひ) she radiates. Royal consorts are all smoking hot… literally, because they have to wear bulky, elaborate dresses that were designed several centuries ago. Those things trap heat like nobody's business. Imagine standing next to a royal consort. She and her fancy, voluminous 17th-century dress are radiating so much heat that even you're starting to sweat.

mnemonics.meaning: Semi Ratify Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> and it will only get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">semi</mark> frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck! Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it! The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.

mnemonics.meaning: Solely The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solely</mark> his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his. Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
mnemonics.reading: ゆい ただ None You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his. Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.

mnemonics.meaning: Sturdy A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sturdy</mark> knife you can find. The reason hill knives are so sturdy is because they are shaped like hills. Very wide, very thick, not so long. So, they don't break and are more sturdy.
mnemonics.reading: ごう None None This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by Grandpa ごういち. Imagine Grandpa ごういち rolling the knife back and forth over various things to cut them. "I love my sturdy hill knife," he says.

mnemonics.meaning: Subjugate If someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">subjugate</mark> them. You can't just let people do whatever they want. If it isn't correct to loiter here, then it IS correct to subjugate them, and force them to do what you want. You control them now. And they're gonna get it!
mnemonics.reading: せい None None You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing. As you swing your saber around, subjugating the loiterers, and making them do as you say, you remind yourself that this is correct. And if it's correct, you have to use your saber to enforce it.

mnemonics.meaning: Vow With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> under an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vow</mark>. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off. Picture the axe hovering above your fingers. Now say the vow. But don't lie. The axe knows when you're lying.
mnemonics.reading: せい ちか None When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers. Imagine what it would be like to slice off your own fingers with the saber you've carried for so long. You better not break that vow.

mnemonics.meaning: Vulgar The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vulgar</mark>. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar. Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
mnemonics.reading: ぞく None None This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes. Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.

mnemonics.meaning: Watered A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> makes sure all of his plants get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">watered</mark>. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami. Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん うるお, うる None These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did. Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.

mnemonics.meaning: Accidentally The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>, Master <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Splinter</mark> (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accidentally</mark> poured ooze on him. Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
mnemonics.reading: ぐう たま None But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake! However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.

mnemonics.meaning: Adept The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> of an under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> will be done by someone who is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adept</mark> at it. And that adept person is you! You're an expert when it comes to constructing underground prisons, so you've been hired for this job. Good luck!
mnemonics.reading: こう うま, たく None Adept at constructing underground prisons, you've caught the eye of Emperor こういち, the royal underground prison enthusiast. With a dignified nod, Emperor こういち entrusts you with the grand project of constructing an underground prison, confident that the adept builder will make prisoners feel right at home in their new subterranean digs. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: Alligator Crocodile A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> with two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s has the number <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> on it because it's in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> (that's its prison number). Who put the poor two-mouthed fish in prison? An <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alligator</mark>. Because alligators hate two-mouthed fish. How the alligator wishes it had a second mouth like the fish with two mouths, prisoner number 2! It believes that with another mouth, it would be the most talked-about predator, so it imprisons the two-mouthed fish out of jealousy.
mnemonics.reading: None わに None The reading is the same as the わに in "WaniKani." Ever heard of it? So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.

mnemonics.meaning: Bundle Grasp Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bed</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grasp</mark> the sheets and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bundle</mark> them up. Now you can do the laundry! Imagine pressing your fingers into the bed, grasping tightly and ripping the sheets free. Then you bundle them up into your arms so you can stuff them into the washing machine.
mnemonics.reading: は, わ None None In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed. The next time you grasp your bedsheets yell "Ha!" as you yank them off. Now chuckle a bit, ha ha ha, as you bundle them up into a ball. You can't beat me, bedsheets.

mnemonics.meaning: Burdensome A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fat</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burdensome</mark> animal. A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
mnemonics.reading: だ, た None None But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ). Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.

mnemonics.meaning: Cave A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cave</mark>. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave! Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
mnemonics.reading: どう ほら None Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう). Also note that the 同 part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. 同 and 洞 have the same readings!

mnemonics.meaning: Chief The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> all in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chief</mark>. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders. Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
mnemonics.reading: はく, お None None The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too. You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!

mnemonics.meaning: China Sudden Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> opens his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">China</mark>!" Why would he say China? It's all very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>. Picture Wolverine shouting "China!" in his canopy all of a sudden. Okay, he only said "China" because someone asked him to name a country, and when he looked at his canopy, it reminded him of a pagoda.
mnemonics.reading: とう から None This sudden urge to shout "China" also came about because Wolverine woke up in とうきょう. Outside of his pagoda-shaped canopy, Wolverine noticed the kanji and assumed he was in China. In Wolverine's defense, he hasn't been learning Japanese like you have, so we can almost forgive him for his mishap. He could do better though. Pretty bad in this day and age to get China and Tokyo mixed up…

mnemonics.meaning: Clear You want to write a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">chapter</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> in your new book so you have to make sure it's really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it. Your writing is so clear and concise that just about everyone does read it. Well, everyone with hair that is.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off. Picture the Shougun angrily yelling at you about his hair disaster! The only good thing he can say about your book is that it gave clear directions.

mnemonics.meaning: Comic A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> crashes into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, which is then caught in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> and tied to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, it sounds really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comic</mark>! That's because it's from that comic book about a pirate you're always reading! Imagine reading this issue of your favorite stretchy pirate boy comic. Lumpy uses his long arms as a net, traps the sun and ties it to the stool right as the tsunami hits. What kind of crazy trouble is he getting into this time?!
mnemonics.reading: まん None None Comics are manga (まん) in Japan, whether they're comic or serious. You've known about Japanese comics or manga for a long time, and now you can read them too. Look how far you've come. Wow, what a journey. I'm just so proud of you, kiddo.

mnemonics.meaning: Consult Watch what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> over, because they hired you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consult</mark> them. The person with the next mouth in the room is waiting for you to open yours to consult them. He'll do whatever you say.
mnemonics.reading: し はか None You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し). He was asking for love advice, so I guess you consulted that he give a sheep to the person he likes? Uh oh. Remind me never to consult with you when I'm feeling unsure about things.

mnemonics.meaning: Courts The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> presides over all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courts</mark>: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner. Picture him sitting above you in the judge's chair in court. He's about to make his judgement.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth. "I hereby sentence you to..." *ploop* "Ooh, this is really good. I hereby sentence..." *ploop* "Wow, are these tater tots? Court dismissed."

mnemonics.meaning: Crab This is an animal with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark>d <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> claw that's filled with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> meat but looks like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>. What kind of animal is that? It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crab</mark>. If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
mnemonics.reading: None かに None The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani. If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!

mnemonics.meaning: Dam A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is making a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dam</mark>. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway. Picture the woman working tirelessly in the hot sun, moving and shaping the dirt around this river into a dam to make a pond.
mnemonics.reading: えん せき None Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows. If you wanna be sexy maybe you should build a dam too.

mnemonics.meaning: Drift If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> while you are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>ing, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drift</mark> out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away! Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: ひょう ただよ None As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough. "Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"

mnemonics.meaning: Eddy A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>s itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eddy</mark>. An eddy requires water to change direction and then twirl around, and when the tsunami hits the roof, that's exactly what it does.
mnemonics.reading: None よど None There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it." Imagine them singing this, emphasizing the "you do" part of the song as they watch the eddy being formed.

mnemonics.meaning: Embankment The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to block the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> is with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embankment</mark>. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again! Imagine an embankment made of dirt, in the correct place, blocking the sun from your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: てい つつみ None Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high. Picture an embankment made of dirt and tater tots. Not like, tater tots just thrown in the embankment, you probably see those all the time. But dirt AND tater tots in the embankment itself.

mnemonics.meaning: Empress You walk out on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, where you find in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">empress</mark> of these lands!" She was buried in the cliff down to her mouth so nobody would find her! You pull her out of the ground and soon what was just a mouth becomes a whole empress!
mnemonics.reading: こう, ご きさき None When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち." It's only natural the empress would want to see her emperor. And right now, the emperor of these lands is Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Epidemic Turn a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark>ness into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and it becomes an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">epidemic</mark>. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply. Imagine if countries decided to make sick weapons that would spread epidemics like this all over part of the world. Let's hope they don't...
mnemonics.reading: えき None None These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further. Picture a single 駅 on a map, bright red. Now watch the red spread to all of the other 駅 on the map, dyeing them red and spreading the epidemic all over your country.

mnemonics.meaning: Flip You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark>ed <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark>. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flip</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flip</mark> over and over. Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
mnemonics.reading: ほん ひるがえ None You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better. Or, maybe you get so good that you write a 本 (ほん) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!

mnemonics.meaning: Gloom Depression A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, but it can also be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">psychopath</mark>. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gloom</mark>. Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
mnemonics.reading: うつ None None Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬. Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.

mnemonics.meaning: Horizon There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming up over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horizon</mark>. Picture the tsunami breaking over the cliff on the horizon. It would be beautiful if it wasn't so frightening.
mnemonics.reading: がい はて None You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone. You wonder who that guy was. You wonder why he was there. You wonder if he's still alive out there, past the horizon.

mnemonics.meaning: Inscription A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">name</mark> on this piece of wood is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inscription</mark> that shows the artist's signature. This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
mnemonics.reading: めい None None The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい. If you need to review 名 go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: Look Up To The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">to look up to</mark>. Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
mnemonics.reading: ぎょう, こう あお None Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう). Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.

mnemonics.meaning: Record Book A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> uses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s to carry out its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark>, which is turning itself into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record book</mark>s. The bamboo tsunami hits the ground and drops of bamboo turn into sheets of paper. The sheets of paper combine to become record books that record what happened here, on this day.
mnemonics.reading: ぼ None None A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it. Bamboo can also become bo staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.

mnemonics.meaning: Restaurant Inn, Pavilion The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">restaurant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">restaurant</mark> kanji are the same! The meaning of this kanji also extends other resting places, like an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inn</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pavilion</mark>. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: てい None None This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No. Imagine going to a restaurant and seeing a menu of all different types and styles of tater tots and nothing else. Even the drinks are tater tot based. Mmm mm.

mnemonics.meaning: Revise What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> needs to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revise</mark>d. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again. Think about all the stupid things you said on the streets today. Do you want those exact phrases, mistakes, and mouth sounds following you around forever? Revise it before you write it down!
mnemonics.reading:
てい None None You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising. "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you banana." Well that's bad. Better revise this so it rhymes. "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you want." Nope, still bad. Revise! "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you clam." Yes. It's gold.

mnemonics.meaning: Robust A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> who can fight with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s on him is more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">robust</mark> than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body? Picture samurai standing in a line. One, two, three... woah. You look up. This guy has icicles growing off him and he's the size of a bus. Now that's a robust samurai.
mnemonics.reading: そう None None You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles. Physical robustness is just a reflection of the strength of your soul!

mnemonics.meaning: Rut There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>s all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rut</mark>. Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
mnemonics.reading: き None None To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button. Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this rut!

mnemonics.meaning: Stirred Up A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is getting all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stirred up</mark>. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up? He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
mnemonics.reading: ふん ふる None While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん). Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

mnemonics.meaning: Summit At the top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark> to tell you you've reached the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summit</mark>. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs. If that signpost wasn't there how would you know you reached the summit? Like, if you were on top of Everest and there was a bad storm... you'd just topple off the other side. Those summit signposts are important!
mnemonics.reading: ほう みね None At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer. Picture your beautiful summit home. You know, George Washington had one of these too. So. That's cool, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Tomb Sticking out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> adorned with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> shells. This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lie under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously. Can you picture this big dirt tomb, with flowers and shellfish decorating it and a cross right on top?
mnemonics.reading: ふん None None This is a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). Decorated with flowers and shellfish shells, it’s not a sad place at all. It's a fun place to remember all the fun times with people you loved. See this tomb, and you'll remember all the fun you had. It's decorated to make sure you feel that fun. Fun fact: when you see 賁 in a kanji, the reading is probably going to be ふん.

mnemonics.meaning: Transport With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> you put some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transport</mark>. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another. Imagine loading a bunch of weapons into a boat and sailing off to transport them somewhere else.
mnemonics.reading: はん None None Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport. Picture yourself as a cool smuggler, transporting stolen... I mean... totally legitimate weapons from one place to another. Just like Han Solo!

mnemonics.meaning: Wicked A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> shows that it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wicked</mark>. Something wicked probably lives in the building too. Not like, wicked cool, but like wicked evil. I see you, New Englanders.
mnemonics.reading: じゃ よこしま None You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you! Imagine being chased around the outside of this wicked fanged building as the wicked fanged jaguar tries to eat you. Ahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: Again You're sitting on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">again</mark>!!? Imagine your super comfy, state-of-the-art stool. You take it everywhere with you, and you're always sitting on it. Again, and again, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">again</mark>. You love that stool.
mnemonics.reading: None また None Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the matter (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican or British accents to make this one fit a bit better! Imagine your friends getting more and more annoyed with your constant stool-sitting habits! They really don't get it. What is the matter with you?! Why can't you just stand like everyone else? Don't you know sitting is the "new smoking"!?

mnemonics.meaning: Agreement Consent We must <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>. That, at least, we can come to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agreement</mark> on. There are a group of people pointing at pictures of the moon coming closer to earth. They are the world's leaders, and although they don't get along normally, this new attack from the moon has united them in agreement: we must stop the moon.
mnemonics.reading: こう がえんじ None "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち. The world has united against the moon, and they have made Emperor こういち their temporary leader.

mnemonics.meaning: Bay If you want to have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>, you need to make sure you have it at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bay</mark>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time. Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
mnemonics.reading: ほ うら None How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent. Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

mnemonics.meaning: Boil If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dollar</mark> the water will instantly start to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boil</mark>! Imagine standing in front of an incoming tsunami. Suddenly in the distance you see someone throwing dollar bills into it and it starts to boil. Ahh!
mnemonics.reading: ふつ わ None The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots. Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really want to know who that jerk was that threw dollars into the tsunami to make it boil!

mnemonics.meaning: Bottle Jar You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> that can hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ten thousand</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drops</mark> of water sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bottle</mark>. The horns are like a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle filled with water. Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
mnemonics.reading: びん かめ None Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know. Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!

mnemonics.meaning: Call Eat The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">call</mark> kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eat</mark>, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?! Call your mom or dad and ask them to go out to eat with you right now.
mnemonics.reading: しょう め None You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone. Imagine getting a call from the Shougun himself. He's come to your house before, but he's never asked you to eat with him. This is huge!

mnemonics.meaning: Chastity You try to put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastity</mark>. "No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
mnemonics.reading: てい さだ None "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind." You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.

mnemonics.meaning: Clear There is a special type of meditation where you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> down to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it. Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
mnemonics.reading: りょう あきらか None Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind. Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

mnemonics.meaning: Collar The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark>s of the two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s you destroyed with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> live on in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collar</mark> you made out of them. You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
mnemonics.reading: きん えり None The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird. Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.

mnemonics.meaning: Corner So my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">splinter</mark>, right in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">corner</mark>. So what? Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
mnemonics.reading: ぐう すみ None That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)? Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.

mnemonics.meaning: County District The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">buddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is in the next <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">county</mark>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy. Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
mnemonics.reading: ぐん こおり None Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county. Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.

mnemonics.meaning: Dry Up Parch There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> next to which you left some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark>, and it has all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dried up</mark>! Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy. Imagine pouring some syrup next to a fire and watching it dry up. Watch as the sides slowly bubble and harden and lose what makes syrup so good in the first place.
mnemonics.reading: そう はしゃ None If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it. Go back to imagining a fire drying up some syrup and watch as a tiny little syrup soul cries and is released into the air. Oh no!

mnemonics.meaning: Explanation If you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sickle</mark> to kill a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> you'll need a really good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">explanation</mark> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation? Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
mnemonics.reading: しゃく, せき す, とく, ゆる None In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain. Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: Fat You ate the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, and then the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> too, but man were they high in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark>! In fact, you wanted to eat them with chopsticks, but they were so greasy with fat that the spoon was your only option. Imagine staring down regretfully at your fat-covered spoon after eating both the moon and the sun. Not only did you eat two really important celestial bodies, but their high fat content made them way less healthy than you expected.
mnemonics.reading: し あぶら None Unbeknownst to you, the moon and sun contained as much fat as an entire adult sheep (し)! Why didn't you check the nutrition facts first??? If you had known you were going to get a whole sheep's worth of fat, you would have just eaten a big platter of mutton chops instead of dooming the entire solar system by eating the moon and sun.

mnemonics.meaning: Fat When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> faces the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark>, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark> in the bodies of people and animals all gets drawn to the surface and we all look weirdly greasy for a little while. You probably knew that the moon exerts a pull on water, but I bet you didn't know it exerted a pull on fat too! Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel all the fat in your body start to get extracted up through your pores, creating this slick, greasy sheen all over your skin. Let's hope this phase of the lunar cycle ends quickly.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None As long as you're covered in fat, you might as well go bowling (ぼう). Imagine how smoothly that bowling ball's going to roll after you slather it with some of this fat! Feel how slippery the bowling ball gets as you smear it with fat. Now close your eyes and imagine pins toppling in every direction as your fat-slathered ball careens into them!

mnemonics.meaning: Greatness The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> is destined for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">greatness</mark>. I mean, they're the leader of Korea already, right? So they have to have a decent chunk of greatness in them already to get that far.
mnemonics.reading: い えら None The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry. Picture the greatness of the scene before you: the leader of Korea, a great eagle overhead, it's so great!!

mnemonics.meaning: Lotus You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>. The flowers you put on them are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lotus</mark> flowers. Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
mnemonics.reading: れん はす, はちす None You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん). You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. It just makes those boring, ugly rental cars and scooters so much prettier!

mnemonics.meaning: Mercy A person with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> has you on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and lets loose two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poops</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Mercy</mark>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say. Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
mnemonics.reading: じ いつく None As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe. Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Mound The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> makes a small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mound</mark>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead. Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
mnemonics.reading: ちょう つか None The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over. Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.

mnemonics.meaning: Plow You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark> and a (water) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark>. These are the two things you need in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plow</mark>. You'd think you'd only need a plow, but you also need water if you're going to plow a field, otherwise what's the point?
mnemonics.reading: こう たがや None Plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use. Thousands and thousands of こういちs, set free unto the world to do all our plowing work.

mnemonics.meaning: Princess Beautiful Woman Everyone knows that when a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> plays <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> she becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark>. Thats how princesses are made. Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
mnemonics.reading: えん ひめ None Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too. Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

mnemonics.meaning: Put Between You run your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>. His horns are what you love to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put between</mark> your fingers. This is one of the perks of having a horned demonic creature for a husband. You can put his horns between your fingers and get a really nice stretch on your finger joints.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, しょう はさ None Why are your husband's horns what you always love to put between your fingers? Because he's a hot sergeant (はさ)! Imagine having a strong, muscular sergeant with horns for a husband — so macho! With a husband like that, you'd be running your fingers through his sexy horns every chance you get. Sir, yes sir!

mnemonics.meaning: Residence Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is breaking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> your new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">residence</mark>. You're all working together to make you a new home! Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
mnemonics.reading: てい やしき None Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan! Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.

mnemonics.meaning: Scream Yell What would your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> do if you got caught in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>? It'd probably get real <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> — in other words, it would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scream</mark>. Picture a prison for legs. It's like a trap that your legs can never escape, basically. And it's pretty painful, so imagine your mouth opening big and wide and letting out a scream.
mnemonics.reading: かん わめ None You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream. Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?

mnemonics.meaning: Seedling Sapling <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that grow in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> only live to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seedling</mark>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings. Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
mnemonics.reading: みょう, びょう なえ, なわ None The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou. Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

mnemonics.meaning: Ship Counter A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ship counter</mark> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow. Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
mnemonics.reading: せき None None Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count. Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

mnemonics.meaning: Skin If you look in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stomach</mark> you'll find a bunch of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark>. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats. Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
mnemonics.reading: ふ はだ None The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way. Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

mnemonics.meaning: Soft A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>ing is really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soft</mark>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car. Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
mnemonics.reading: なん やわ None This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy). Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

mnemonics.meaning: Suburbs If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s together, you have yourself a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suburb</mark>. Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
mnemonics.reading: こう None None "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち. "That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor こういち continues.

mnemonics.meaning: Summit Humbly Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> all the way to that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summit</mark>. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humbly</mark> present the road to the geoduck and bow before it. There is a giant geoduck at the summit of the mountain, and the street will lead you right there. Imagine the grueling climb up the mountain to the summit. Feel it in your legs, and keep looking at that tall, tall geoduck. Now imagine kneeling those same aching legs humbly to the street below the geoduck.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう いただき, いただ None You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry. Anytime you use the street, you're in Mrs. Chou's territory. After detecting you were using her street to reach the geoduck, she started coming after you. Remember, wherever there's a street (radical), Mrs. Chou is not far behind.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, so you ask two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>s to help you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> out for a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wash</mark>. Despite the obvious dangers, a giant wave is the only thing that'll wash a giant turkey, so you have no choice. Imagine how big and heavy this turkey must be. It's so huge so you need the strength of two Wolverines and the magnitude of a whole tsunami to move it around and wash it.
mnemonics.reading: たく すす, ゆす, そそぐ None To make sure your turkey won't get carried away by the tsunami while you wash it, you pin it down with a giant tack (たく). If you're washing a giant turkey inside a giant wave, only a giant tack will guarantee it doesn't get washed away. If you want to wash your turkey, make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast, so you need to tack your turkey to the ground if you don't want the sea to take it.

mnemonics.meaning: Whirlpool If you put two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s on either side of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whirlpool</mark>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them. Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
mnemonics.reading: か うず None The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back! Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

mnemonics.meaning: Wise If you have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you must be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wise</mark>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well. Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
mnemonics.reading: そう さと, みみざと None All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live. Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.

mnemonics.meaning: Wither When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> grows <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wither</mark>. Old trees' roots and leaves grow inefficient, and they can't get enough nutrients. It's only natural for them to wither up a little bit.
mnemonics.reading: こ か None This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree. It gave the 子 its shade, its sap, and eventually its body to build a house. What an awful child, and what a generic giving tree.

mnemonics.meaning: Aromatic Fragrance If you point a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the same <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark>, you'll be able to smell their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aromatic</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fragrance</mark>. The best way to bask in their fragrance is to make them all point in the same direction (preferably straight at you). Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. Their aromatic fragrance coats your body. You smell great now!
mnemonics.reading: ほう かんば None You decide to bring this aromatic fragrance into your home (ほう). To do this, you plant flowers all the way around your home, all facing in toward it. Unfortunately, now when you're at home you're choked by the overwhelming fragrance of flowers, all concentrating their aromas on a single point (your home). Oh… oh no it's too strong. You can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!

mnemonics.meaning: Auspicious When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> lives in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> it becomes the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">auspicious</mark> creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this. Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
mnemonics.reading: しょう きざ, さいわ, つまび, よ None The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared. Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.

mnemonics.meaning: Bath I hope all you're doing in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark> is taking a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bath</mark>. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths! Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
mnemonics.reading: ろ, りょ せぼね None When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ).
