Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath. Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

mnemonics.meaning: Biased The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">biased</mark> person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently. Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
mnemonics.reading: へん かたよ None You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird. "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

mnemonics.meaning: Briar Thorn If you look at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> thing you notice are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">briar</mark>s. You never see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thorn</mark>s first, only after you've looked at the flowers. Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
mnemonics.reading: し, じ いばら None When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You sound funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch! Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

mnemonics.meaning: Cave In This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> was a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">former</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> until the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cave in</mark>. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in. Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
mnemonics.reading: かん おちい, おとしい None You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next! Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.

mnemonics.meaning: Chain The famous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is good for only one thing, and that's being made into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chain</mark>s. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability. Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
mnemonics.reading: さ くさり, とざ None However, the only way to break the chain is to cut it open with a saw (さ). Once the golden triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw. Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

mnemonics.meaning: Compensation Compensate You give a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compensation</mark>. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish. Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
mnemonics.reading: ばい None None Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye." All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

mnemonics.meaning: Constant Always Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> or the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark>. It is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">constant</mark>, never changing. Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
mnemonics.reading: こう つね, つねに None Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years! A constant rule from Emperor こういち means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!

mnemonics.meaning: Design You're sewing something with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> but you and your creation get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">design</mark>. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands. Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: りん あや None As you watch the snowflake design form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name Aya (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern! If you know someone else called Aya, go ahead and use them in this mnemonic! Whoever it is, imagine an Aya watching from afar holding a magic wand, creating this beautiful frosty pattern!

mnemonics.meaning: Die If you figure out how to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> as a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, everyone is going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">die</mark>. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all. Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
mnemonics.reading: ぼつ, もつ おぼ, しず, ない None The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning. You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!

mnemonics.meaning: Embrace Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> grasp this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> and when you raise it you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embrace</mark> the turkey. Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
mnemonics.reading: よう None None As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it! Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.

mnemonics.meaning: Encounter Meet When you ride your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> listening to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you're bound to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encounter</mark> a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meet</mark> you. Picture all of the people you encounter as you ride your scooter, spreading your music around town.
mnemonics.reading: そう あ None Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them. "We love your music, look at our souls!" Uh oh, this is turning into some kind of horror movie. You better scoot a bit faster or you might meet an unfortunate fate.

mnemonics.meaning: Erupt From your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> comes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. It all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">erupt</mark>s from your mouth! Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: ふん ふ None When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん). It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun. Fun fact: when you see 賁 in a kanji, the reading is probably going to be ふん.

mnemonics.meaning: Especially If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> you into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>, things are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">especially</mark> bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad. First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
mnemonics.reading: しゅ こと None You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where! As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!

mnemonics.meaning: Ethics A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> puts their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark>. This is a test in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ethics</mark>. People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
mnemonics.reading: りん None None To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well. Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to the lost and found? Will they ignore it? Will they steal it?

mnemonics.meaning: Exhibit The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhibit</mark>. It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
mnemonics.reading: ちん ひ None Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit. Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.

mnemonics.meaning: Falcon If you tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> you can trick everyone into thinking it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">falcon</mark>. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey. Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
mnemonics.reading: しゅん, じゅん はやぶさ None You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there. Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.

mnemonics.meaning: From What do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> do? They take you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> place to place. Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
mnemonics.reading: ない の, なんじ, すなわ None If you're going from place to place, make sure you have some nori (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy. Imagine yourself going from one place to another with your pockets stuffed full of nori. The smell is starting to get overwhelming. It's making you really hungry (or nauseous, depending on how you feel about nori!).

mnemonics.meaning: Help If you want to have your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you're going to need a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark>. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off. Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
mnemonics.reading: ふ, ほ たす すけ You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early! Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready!

mnemonics.meaning: Hunting There is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> and your horrible <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> is to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hunting</mark> for it. Picture the shape of the animal in the grass, off in the distance. You can't see what kind of animal it is yet, but you know you're hunting it.
mnemonics.reading: りょう かり, か None You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away. You wouldn't be able to go hunting in any other kind of boat—the motor would be too loud. Picture yourself in a row boat with all of your hunting gear. You need to be extra careful not to make any loud splashing sounds with the oars!

mnemonics.meaning: Instigate Beside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is an evil <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> that tries to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instigate</mark> you into saying bad things and starting a riot. It's like the little silken puppet master of your mouth or something. Don't let it instigate you! Imagine this spider controlling your mouth with its web, making you say things you wouldn't dare think of. "Free healthcare for all!" "Pineapple is a legitimate pizza topping!" Man, you gotta stop letting that spider instigate you into saying weird stuff.
mnemonics.reading: さ そそのか, そそ None You want the spider to stop instigating you into saying bad things and starting riots. So you pick up a saw (さ) and start cutting off the silken threads that are controlling your mouth. If this spider's web is strong enough to control your mouth, you will most likely need a saw to cut it off, right?

mnemonics.meaning: Lazy Neglect If you give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> it will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lazy</mark>. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now. Picture a machine with a heart, lying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
mnemonics.reading: たい おこた, なま None The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so. Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.

mnemonics.meaning: Lazy In its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> that's supposed to do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, will be too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lazy</mark> to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done. Picture the lazy narwhal laying on a block of ice in the moonlight. There are tools and other blocks of ice around, but he just can't seem to get up and do any construction work.
mnemonics.reading: だ None None You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right. Picture your lazy dad. Your big, lazy narwhal dad.

mnemonics.meaning: Leadership Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> to prove your excellent <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leadership</mark>. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space! Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
mnemonics.reading: は, はく はたがしら None Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely! Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

mnemonics.meaning: Necessary Shaving the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> before you try to eat it is absolutely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">necessary</mark>. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair. Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
mnemonics.reading: す, しゅ すべから, すべし, ひげ, まつ, もち, もと None It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly. What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

mnemonics.meaning: Offering Sacrifice If you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> you're turning it into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offering</mark>. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often. Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
mnemonics.reading: せい None None You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it. Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Order Regularity If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark>, it needs to be put back in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">order</mark>. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">regularity</mark>. Keeping order is a tough job! Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
mnemonics.reading: ちつ None None You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains. If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Orphan Alone There was once a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark>, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">orphan</mark>. The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
mnemonics.reading: こ None None The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ). That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Pierce Sushi Counter Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>, you place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, then slam the window shut to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pierce</mark> its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise. This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sushi counter</mark>s! Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
mnemonics.reading: かん つらぬ, ぬき, ぬ None Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them. Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

mnemonics.meaning: Provisions The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> that's prepared at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">provisions</mark> for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then. Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
mnemonics.reading: りょう, ろう かて None Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too. Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.

mnemonics.meaning: Quick Sudden If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> it will be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quick</mark> to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up only to be knocked over again, just as quick. Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
mnemonics.reading: さつ, そう さっ, はやて None That quick wind is quicker than you can say Satsuki (さつ). And "Satsuki" is a pretty quick sounding name already. Go ahead, say "Satsuki" as quick as you can right now. Heck, try it a few times. Okay, pretty quick, but this wind is even quicker than that.

mnemonics.meaning: Revive All you need are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> and you've got yourself a potion that can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revive</mark> just about anyone or anything! Just don't forget the ingredients you'll need: flowers, fish, and grain. Imagine yourself throwing them all into a big cauldron and brewing up a potion powerful enough to revive a person!
mnemonics.reading: そ, す よみがえ None This potion able to revive any being just has one small downside: it tastes like soap (そ). As long as you can get over the awful taste of soap, this is some good, powerful stuff! And considering this'll be administered to dead things… the taste is probably not so important.

mnemonics.meaning: Ridicule Laziness If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is acting like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> trapped in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, then people will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ridicule</mark> you for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">laziness</mark>. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving. Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
mnemonics.reading: まん None None When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person. Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.

mnemonics.meaning: Swell Play your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swell</mark>! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell. Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
mnemonics.reading: ぼう ふく None Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits. Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.

mnemonics.meaning: Treatment Encounter Your poor little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">splinter</mark>, so make sure to give it extra nice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">treatment</mark>. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encounter</mark>. Makes sense when you think about how you first have to encounter someone before deciding how you're going to treat them! Also, when this means "treatment," note that it doesn't refer to medical treatment, but rather about how you personally treat or receive people. These are tough times for your scooter, so be patient with it. Try to treat it with understanding and care.
mnemonics.reading: ぐう あ None Give your scooter only the best treatment, so it can feel real gooooood (ぐう). Not just "good", but "gooooood". The long vowel is important here, so try to think of different ways you could make your scooter feel gooooood. Maybe a nice little wash after you’ve removed the splinter will do the trick.

mnemonics.meaning: Admonish If you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark>, it would only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">admonish</mark> you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying. Imagine being admonished by the Death Star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the Death Star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
mnemonics.reading: ゆ さと None Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!" Imagine sitting in your yurt, the home you love, but you can still hear the admonishments from the Death Star in your ears. You feel... bad.

mnemonics.meaning: All How many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>s? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">All</mark> of them! All buildings have at least one scooter. It could be out front, on the roof, in the basement. But all of them have scooters and someone who likes to ride them instead of using a car or a bike.
mnemonics.reading: ずい したが, まにま None All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい). Imagine the sound of the scooter's tiny engine: zuwee zuwee zu zu zuwee. All of them do this, which is why you hate them.

mnemonics.meaning: Barbarian The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barbarian</mark> floating in the sky. Just imagine a huge barbarian (whatever that means to you) floating in the sky, looking down. Some ancient people look up and wave at the old moon barbarian.
mnemonics.reading: こ, う, ご なんぞ きゅう At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from. "You see, my child, the old moon was not like the current moon. It was a giant barbarian in the sky, who would eat children that asked too many questions."

mnemonics.meaning: Board Embark In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> which really <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">board</mark> your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embark</mark>ing on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going. Picture yourself boarding the ship and letting the flowers slip from your fingers, into the crowd of people waving goodbye.
mnemonics.reading: とう None None You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course! Where else would you go at this point? I mean, come on. You've made it 53 levels since you embarked on your kanji journey with us. We know you by now. You want to be in とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: Brocade You weave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> patterns into this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, turning it into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brocade</mark>. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel. Imagine weaving this beautiful brocade fabric out of one of your old towels. Try to actually picture the gold and white patterns you want on there. If you're a crafter, actually do it!
mnemonics.reading: きん にしき None You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing. Imagine using your niche key to open this hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!

mnemonics.meaning: Carp Koi If you're in Japan, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carp</mark>. You may know them as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">koi</mark>, too. Picture your village in Japan. There's a big, still pond full of bright and beautiful giant carp. You hear the village kids giggle as they feed them and their big round mouths pop out of the water.
mnemonics.reading: り こい None A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know? Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.

mnemonics.meaning: Cell Placenta Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> it in a bag and it will look just like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cell</mark>. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening! Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
mnemonics.reading: ほう None None As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere. AHHH CLEAN ALL OF THESE CELLS OUT OF YOUR HOME!

mnemonics.meaning: Cleanse Purify The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">conflict</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cleanse</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purify</mark> the lands of people, homes, and culture. Anything less than a tsunami of conflict would leave something behind. But this much conflict will cleanse the area of everything.
mnemonics.reading: じょう, せい きよ None Who could possibly stop this cleanse of all lands?! The only person capable of this is, of course, Joe (じょう), the local farmhand. He’s so tall and burly that he can stop even the largest of tsunamis… right? Joe has gone through many things during your WaniKani journey, but this might be too much even for him. Either way, he’s going to try his best to stop this tsunami of conflict, threatening to cleanse the lands of everything we know. With his bare hands, of course.

mnemonics.meaning: Commander There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>. A true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commander</mark> can notice little things like this. Imagine a commander carefully looking over everything. They not only notice a drop of something on a towel, but they're able to identify that the drop is a small piece of liquid bear.
mnemonics.reading: すい None None You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい). "Weeee!" says the commander.

mnemonics.meaning: Comprehend Reality If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something the same way they say it in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, everyone in the whole country will be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comprehend</mark> what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it. Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
mnemonics.reading: りょう あきら, まことに None Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home. Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.

mnemonics.meaning: Darkness <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are growing out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and over your pet <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> and it's causing the poor thing to live in total <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">darkness</mark>. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it. Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
mnemonics.reading: もう, ぼう おお, くら, こうむ None To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again. Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pig's eyes, the darkness will last forever!

mnemonics.meaning: Dawn The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is rising and there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> covering <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, who's being forced to watch as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark> appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them. Picture someone tied down in a net as dawn breaks.
mnemonics.reading: しょ あけぼの None The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength. Look at Akebono looking at you as you look at dawn breaking.

mnemonics.meaning: Disaster If you get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> stuck in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> it will be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disaster</mark>! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!! This disaster is ruining your life. You can't eat, sleep, all you can do is panic trying to get the hair out.
mnemonics.reading: さん, ざん みじ, いた, むご None This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san? Santa-san has forsaken you. Your life is a wreck. This is a total disaster just because of one big hair.

mnemonics.meaning: Draft When what you're writing is as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tall</mark> as the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s growing outside, you know you're done with your first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draft</mark>. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains! Imagine holding your draft up outside in a field of grains. You're a couple leaves short. Time to get back to the drawing board.
mnemonics.reading: こう したがき, わら None Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is. Now こういち is out there measuring your draft against the tall grain plants. You better hope it's long enough, because if it isn't, Emperor こういち's probably going to execute you.

mnemonics.meaning: Enlighten If you can find the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> shaped like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enlighten</mark> you. Imagine searching for this special door in the cold wind and snow of winter. The search for enlightenment always has something to do with suffering and searching on your own like this.
mnemonics.reading: けい さと, ひら None The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth." All you need to do to attain enlightenment is to eat this cake... out of this mouth. Eh. Maybe enlightenment isn't worth it.

mnemonics.meaning: Expose Press your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expose</mark> what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable. Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
mnemonics.reading: ひ None None You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat. Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.

mnemonics.meaning: Fiber Slender A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> across special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> to separate the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fiber</mark>s. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves! Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
mnemonics.reading: せん None None You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it... Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.

mnemonics.meaning: Gently Gentle If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of anything, you need to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark> and touch everything <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gently</mark>. Unfortunately it's not specific as to what kind of surplus you're loitering around, so you'll need to imagine a surplus of something memorable to you. Then, just imagine loitering around there, being really gentle with everything.
mnemonics.reading: じょ おもむ None You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine). Imagine Jo-Anne coming back to her surplus, then asking you if you were gentle with the goods. You were, you treated everything very gently.

mnemonics.meaning: Hollyhock <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that are thought to be little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark>s sent from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hollyhock</mark>s. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai! Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
mnemonics.reading: き あおい None Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from. Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the あおい of them match the あおい of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: Inflation While the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is out, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> is riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, yelling about <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inflation</mark>. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same. Picture the gladiator riding his horse in the light of the moon yelling, "Do you have any idea how important it is to increase the average pay rate to account for inflation? All of us gladiators are going to be unable to pay the bills soon because inflation isn't being taken into account! You'll suffer too! Listen to me!"
mnemonics.reading: とう あが, のぼ None Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die). Imagine if you were in this gladiator's place. In five years, you wouldn't be able to afford to eat thanks to the bosses in とうきょう refusing to adjust for inflation. Back in my day, onigiri only cost FIFteen yen!

mnemonics.meaning: Install You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to take down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">install</mark> a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place. Imagine reaching out and grabbing onto the old flag with your fingers. Feel the dirty grime and little holes it's gotten. Now install something new!
mnemonics.reading: きょ す None You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often. Picture a newly installed suit flying in the air on a pole.

mnemonics.meaning: Jasmine You cut the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> off the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. The flowers that fall off are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jasmine</mark> flowers. It's weird that jasmine flowers are growing out of your grain, but that's why you're cutting them off.
mnemonics.reading: り, れい, らい None None The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)! You have a farm that grows grain and reeds. Jasmine flowers are growing out of both of those things, ruining your crops! Perhaps you should become a jasmine tea farmer instead...

mnemonics.meaning: Latitude The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that goes through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">latitude</mark> line splitting up North and South Korea. Why thread? Back in the old days globes were sewn together with cloth and thread, so there was a literal thread dividing the Koreas! Or you can just picture an actual, super long piece of thread going around the entire globe. That works too.
mnemonics.reading: い ぬき, よこいと None The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view. Imagine being an eagle yourself, flying around the entire globe, following the latitude line that splits Korea down the middle.

mnemonics.meaning: Melon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">melon</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
mnemonics.reading: か, け うり None What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see. Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!

mnemonics.meaning: Oppress Whether you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> or <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, the anti-claw regime will want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oppress</mark> you. Too afraid of any potential violent rebellion, this oppressive regime is going to imprison and declaw every single clawed being. Imagine being a tiger or Wolverine and being oppressed just because you have claws. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
mnemonics.reading: ぎゃく しいた None Tigers and other clawed beings like Wolverine are so oppressed, they're forced to cover their claws with Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird silly putty they made us play with as kids? Well, it's now an instrument of anti-Wolverine, anti-tiger oppression. Imagine how silly it would look for Wolverine and these animals to have their claws covered in multicolored goo. Gak is such a humiliating way to oppress someone.

mnemonics.meaning: Receive A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> carrying <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> wants you to go to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> so you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> something from them. You really don't want to receive whatever it is this drunkard wants to give you, and it's even sketchier that they want you to go to a rice paddy together to do it.
mnemonics.reading: たい いただ None Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them. The tie looks harmless enough, but you still receive it skeptically. The drunkard is just holding up his cross and smiling at you. Hmm.

mnemonics.meaning: Rowboat A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> owned by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rowboat</mark>, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around. Picture the Yoga King rowing a rowboat. Maybe he's using his legs. Maybe he's using his butt? You don't know. Yoga people are super flexible, he could be using anything to move this rowboat.
mnemonics.reading: てい None None As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water. Go rent a rowboat and try eating tater tots in it. For fun, throw a bunch of them in the water and watch them float. Maybe you'll catch a fish!

mnemonics.meaning: Rust Colored Red, Sincerity This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark>, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rust colored</mark>. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark>, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words. Picture this broken, rust colored boat. It's a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
mnemonics.reading: たん に None The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match. Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored boat. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!

mnemonics.meaning: Scarlet The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> wears will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scarlet</mark>. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much. Picture a person wearing all scarlet all the time. Don't they give you a criminal-y vibe?
mnemonics.reading: ひ あか, あけ None This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too. Picture a criminal, covered in this scarlet thread, heat radiating off of him.

mnemonics.meaning: Shop Pave You want to have a quaint <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cottage</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>, so you have to go to the cottage wedding <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark> to get everything you need. Unfortunately, there’s no road to the shop, so… you’ll just have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pave</mark> one yourself! Every shop needs a road, so get to paving. Imagine the incredibly laborious task of paving an entire road by yourself, just to get to this cottage wedding shop. You really want your quaint little cottage wedding though, so it’s the only choice you have…
mnemonics.reading: ほ None None You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding. Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.

mnemonics.meaning: Soil Earth A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soil</mark>. Soil generally has more nutrients in it. It makes sense for dirt that's been nursed to become soil.
mnemonics.reading: じょう つち None Soil is a thing that Joe (じょう), the huge farmhand, works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops. That kind of makes Joe a dirt or soil nurse, if you think about it. Not sure he’d like that title, though…

mnemonics.meaning: Speed When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> sees a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> it will start running at a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speed</mark> no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast. Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
mnemonics.reading: しゅん, すん すぐ はやお Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner. Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!

mnemonics.meaning: Surplus There's so much <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you need to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to remove it. Only when there is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surplus</mark> can you put that much grain in your mouth. Imagine seeing so much grain that you can stuff your mouth so full you can't swallow or spit it out. You have to use a knife to remove it. After you get all the grain out, comment on the surplus of grain.
mnemonics.reading: じょう あまつさえ, あま None The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Joe (じょう), the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year. Remember how Joe made the soil better? Perhaps this is some of that work paying off. Thanks to that and everything else, there is a great surplus.

mnemonics.meaning: Tolerance The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tolerance</mark>. These roof flowers only see because they do not judge. They accept everything. We humans can learn a thing or two about tolerance from these roof flowers.
mnemonics.reading: かん くつろ None Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of. You wouldn't expect it, but he actually allowed many types of cultures, religions, and peoples to exist under his reign. The Mongols had an exceptional amount of tolerance for the time.

mnemonics.meaning: Also If you want to wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">also</mark> have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it. Picture all the things you also need. A suit, a tie, a monocle, some shiny shoes. There's also ... something... else. What is it?
mnemonics.reading: しょ, しょう, そ か None You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off. Think about all the things you also need when you wear a top hat. The car is probably the most important addition. Otherwise no one can see the top hat in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: Appear Exist When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes up the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appear</mark>. The spikes don't just come out of the geoduck, they literally appear out of thin air. They didn't even <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exist</mark> before the sun touched them.
mnemonics.reading: けん あきらか, あらわ None You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!" "Thank you sweet geoduck, you have taught me the way of appearing with your spikes."

mnemonics.meaning: Apricot What does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> make that you'd want to put in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>? An <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">apricot</mark>! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth! Picture the mouth sized apricots hanging down off the tree. Imagine using your own mouth to bite them down. Just don't swallow the pit!
mnemonics.reading: あん, きょう, こう あんず None After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore. Imagine trying to eat the bite sized apricot and spitting it out after the taste of anchovies from the zoo fill you up.

mnemonics.meaning: Bookmark <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dry</mark> an already <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bookmark</mark>. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it. To be fair, books are just dry trees in a way, but bookmarks are actually dry, dry trees that have flattened out and turned into chunks.
mnemonics.reading: かん しおり None What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back. What does she owe you? Open the page to your bookmark and see she owes reeds!

mnemonics.meaning: Column Space You see a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s lined up outside of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> and realize they look like perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">column</mark>s. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them. Picture these column trees outside the gate to the east. You end up drawing them in the columns of your graph paper because they fit so well.
mnemonics.reading: らん てすり None Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!" Now draw Randy Savage in the columns on your graph paper. He just seems to fit there now.

mnemonics.meaning: Common All Sorts Who goes into their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> things? The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">common</mark> people! <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">All sorts</mark> of people do it, it's really common. You don't boil things outside, do you? Wait, you're telling me you didn't know it's common to boil things in yurts? Excuse me?
mnemonics.reading: しょ None None Here, the common people all do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, and… Hey, pay attention and watch what I'm showing you! Okay, now that I've shown you what to do, you can fit in with the common people here.

mnemonics.meaning: Crown Cap Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crown</mark>! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit. Imagine someone putting a tape measure around your forehead and taking careful measurements for your crown. They better not mess up, or you'll have them put to death!
mnemonics.reading: かん かんむり None You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements. Why don't you go look up what Genghis Khan's crown/cap looked like. Then try to imagine how it would look atop your head.

mnemonics.meaning: Cruel Unjust If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">announce</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> is illegal you're just being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cruel</mark>. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">unjust</mark>. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink! Imagine if your country's leader announced that there would be no more alcohol. People would be in the streets in seconds calling them cruel and unjust!
mnemonics.reading: こく ひど, むご None After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof. Imagine drinking coke while complaining how unjust it is that you can't add rum to it.

mnemonics.meaning: Describe The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, please <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">describe</mark> it. You have a surplus (extra) stool, and someone wants it. But, they need to know more about it, so you describe it in great detail. Imagine yourself doing just that. Every screw and nubbin is described.
mnemonics.reading: じょ つい, ついで None You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ). Jo-Anne is really excited about this stool. It's the perfect height for her (remember, she's on the shorter side to distinguish じょ from じょう). She pays attention to you describing the stool while sitting on it and spinning around. Have her ask for you to describe it more.

mnemonics.meaning: Deviate Elude Jump on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> yourself from answering a question and you've successfully <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deviate</mark>d from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elude</mark> them pretty well. Imagine excusing yourself by scooting away on a scooter. If they want to get your answer, they'll have to chase you.
mnemonics.reading: いつ そ, はぐ None You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them... Welp, it's too late to turn back now. You've already deviated pretty far, and you're not even sure where you are now. You were too busy trying to elude that person that you didn't look where your scooter was taking you.

mnemonics.meaning: Family Crest You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> to sew our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family crest</mark>. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed. Imagine the thread slowly forming the writing that makes up your family crest. You're making a scarf with your crest on it. It's like a wizarding school house symbol.
mnemonics.reading: もん None None Your family crest is of a monster! (もん) And the writing says "Our Family Monster." What kind of monster is on your family crest? Picture it in your mind right now. Now tweet to us @wanikaniapp because I really want to know what you came up with!!

mnemonics.meaning: Flatter You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say. Flattering buildings is just as nice as flattering people, as long as they're okay with it.
mnemonics.reading: あ, お おもね, くま None The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red. The "ah" the building made was actually quite loud, and since you've never heard a building speak before, it scared you pretty bad. But at least you know the building was flattered by your compliment (I think.)

mnemonics.meaning: Foolish If you give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Splinter</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you'll feel pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foolish</mark> afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu! You were foolish to give your heart away to Splinter. He didn't want it. Also he's a rat, what's wrong with you?
mnemonics.reading: ぐ おろ None Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo. What will you do with your foolish goo heart now?

mnemonics.meaning: Furthermore Esteem A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Furthermore</mark>..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">esteem</mark> that no one ever interrupts him. Imagine this mustachioed triceratops. He probably has a monocle and a fedora too. Every time you think you can talk or leave he says, "Furthermore" again. Come on guy, how much do you have to say?
mnemonics.reading: しょう なお None Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about. "Furthermore!" the mustachioed triceratops points at the Shougun, "He is the best Shougun we'll ever have. And he'll let me talk forever OH OH OH!"

mnemonics.meaning: Kidnap A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> is threatening to cut off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> because they've <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kidnap</mark>ped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers. Imagine you've been kidnapped. And the person who kidnapped you is going to cut off some of your fingers and mail them to your parents if they don't pay the ransom soon enough. You don't want your fingers to be cut off with a sword! Help!
mnemonics.reading: かい None None You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one. If your parents don't send in the kayak to your kidnapper soon, you're gonna lose some fingers. Come on guys, just get the kayak already!!!

mnemonics.meaning: Leisure The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who usually hits you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> finds it in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> to give you some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leisure</mark> time. You fall to your knees, "Oh thank you for not hitting me with your stick and letting me relax!" You haven't had a moment of leisure in ages!
mnemonics.reading: ゆう None None You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO! As the leader leisurely watches, the youths smack you with their sticks. What a cruel world! "Enjoy your leisure time," the leader yells over, "the youths hit much softer than I do. Have fun!"

mnemonics.meaning: Merit You're in a really important position, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it all down to just a few <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">merit</mark>s. Most people in places heavy with power, like the scouts, boil down all of their responsibilities and accomplishments this way into merit badges.
mnemonics.reading: くん いさお None The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits. This is why you never see a military officer or a girl scout leaving their merit badges out in the open. They pin them right onto their clothes. Otherwise the raccoons would come.

mnemonics.meaning: Neglect Sparse A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> will turn into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of sticks if you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neglect</mark> it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sparse</mark> stick. Picture this sparse, neglected coat rack. All of its arms and the coats that were on it have fallen off and are in a big pile on the ground.
mnemonics.reading: そ, しょ うと, まば None You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on. If you neglect something for too long, not even a good soap scrub will bring it back. That goes for humans too. Take care of yourselves. Use soap.

mnemonics.meaning: Noh Chanting Noh Chant Whatever you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark> turns into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Noh chanting</mark>. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least. Say whatever you want and send it up to the satellite. Now imagine listening to it when it comes back and hearing beautiful, deep Noh chanting back!
mnemonics.reading: よう うた None While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work. Watch closely the next time you go to a Noh play. See the man Noh chanting? Watch close enough and you'll see him eat a scoop of yogurt every once in a while.

mnemonics.meaning: Planting A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> gets his hands on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark> and starts <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">planting</mark> right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it. Picture a drunk guy laughing and plowing a field and planting seeds. He wouldn't do this if he was sober, but drunk people can't help themselves.
mnemonics.reading: さい None None He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)! Oh my sweet cyborg child! Is this what they've done with you? You're just a drunkard who's only good for planting? Nooooooo!!
