mnemonics.meaning: Practice Trample Whenever you set <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark>, there's always something new to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">practice</mark>. If you usually drink a lot, you might want to practice moderation for example. Or perhaps you simply want to brush up on your social skills. Either way, plenty of opportunities for practice. Are you the kind to practice flirting with the bartender, or are you more the kind to engage in a bit of small talk with the other patrons? Maybe you're just trying to practice patience while the bartender is talking instead of getting your order ready.
mnemonics.reading: せん ふ None This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar! Picture your centaur foot on the bar as you practice to become a gymnast. It's going to take years and years of this kind of practice, but you're sure you'll make it all the way up there some day! Never give up!

mnemonics.meaning: Present Display The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark>, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present</mark>. That big mouth is always presenting something. Imagine the Mouth King giving a presentation about the importance of mouths. His subjects all flatter him by saying, "Please, please, present to us about mouths again! We truuuuuuly love it!"
mnemonics.reading: てい None None "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots. You pour a bucket of tater tots into his mouth body and he continues his presentation about mouths. "You see, mouths are just orifices..."

mnemonics.meaning: Proud Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> managed to find the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> home using marks in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in the middle of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>. This makes you so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proud</mark>! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader. Imagine how proud you and your whole country feel as your leader comes trudging in through the snow. He made it home. You're (sniff) so (sob) proud!
mnemonics.reading: ごう あなど, おご None This leader you're so proud of is none other than Grandpa ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it. Let's be honest here, Grandpa ごういち isn't getting any younger. You really should be proud of him for surviving this long at all.

mnemonics.meaning: Rapidly Rapid A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark>ness that hits you like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> will do its gross work <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rapidly</mark>. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast. Picture this rapid sickness spreading through your body like a cartoon arrow ricocheting through your body. Yuck!
mnemonics.reading: しつ はや None This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot. Imagine getting sick this rapidly. All of a sudden, there's a shih tzu barking in your head, it hurts! And... oh no, where's the toilet?!

mnemonics.meaning: Repay You took someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>'d it all into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>. Now you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">repay</mark> them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know. Picture yourself dropping the alcohol, drop by drop, into the river. Uh oh, the person just caught up to you, so you better repay them.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう, しゅ, とう むく None In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way. Imagine waiting as this person tries on like twenty different pairs of shoes. They're getting them for free! Why do they have to be picky?! Just let me repay you already!

mnemonics.meaning: Rose Madder Deep Red What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> grow in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">west</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Rose madder</mark> flowers, of course. Don't know what those are? That's okay. Just know their roots are used to make dyes of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep red</mark> color. Red like the rose in their name, but madder, wilder, deeper… And they grow in the west so they can take in those deep red colors of the setting sun. Picture yourself sitting in the west as the red sun sets, smashing those little rose madder roots into a paste to make your deep red dyes. Your fingers turn red from the rose madder too.
mnemonics.reading: せん あかね None As you smash the roots of the rose madder and stain your fingers a deep red, a little girl comes up to you and points. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the rose madder roots and your fingers, and nod. She's right, it is red. Deep red. Hear the little girl say あかね while pointing at the rose madder and your deep red fingers. She's right. And the way she says it is so darn cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Shock You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> coming out of the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> so you go into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shock</mark>. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you. A tree... with... a... mouth? No, it can't be... I... a-. Your face warps into a permanent state of shock.
mnemonics.reading: ほう あき, おろか, ほけ, ぼ None The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy. I'd be shocked if you ever left your home again, honestly. But hey, there's always anime.

mnemonics.meaning: Sickle Scythe You cast the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and attach it to a stick to turn it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sickle</mark>! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this! Imagine wielding your gold Mona Lisa sickle. It's sooo heavy, but it's really shiny and it cuts grass and wheat pretty well!
mnemonics.reading: けん, れん かま None Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can. Hear all the guests say, "Mona Lisa... comma the sickle? WHAT'S HAPPENED HERE?!" As panic ensues. You like your addition and you're very proud.

mnemonics.meaning: Solemn <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> between his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> and straight into some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, all while wearing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solemn</mark> expression on his face. He's probably remembering his dad who died from getting his legs stuck in rice. Just leave the poor solemn creature alone. Putting a stick in some rice is a ritual that Wolverine practices to mark solemn occasions. Shh, listen up! He's probably about to say something solemn and important about his dad.
mnemonics.reading: しゅく, すく つつし None When you first saw how solemn Wolverine was after his dad died, it really shook (しゅく) you. Now you're used to always seeing him emotionally cold and distant. It might be time to shake that solemnity out of him though. Do you think you could shake the solemnness out of someone? Imagine being shooketh so hard, you stop feeling solemn. Wouldn't that be great?

mnemonics.meaning: Stem When you leave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stem</mark>s. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful. Imagine being in a graveyard looking at all the tombstones and seeing nothing but stems on all of them. All the pretty flowery parts have died and blown away.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, けい くき None You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer. Look at all the cookie covered tombstones. Now your bag is full of stems, but you can use them to make more cookies to bring back next time. Don't worry, nobody eats them. Stem cookies are probably poisonous.

mnemonics.meaning: Stupid You're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> because you put an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stupid</mark>. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick. How stupid do you have to be to put arrows into your mouth until it makes you sick? Pretty darn stupid, it seems.
mnemonics.reading: ち おろか, し None The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together. Imagine if everyone knew that cheese cures the stupid out of people. Then maybe we would have more cheese and less stupid in the world!

mnemonics.meaning: Suckle Nurse After your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> you have a baby and it uses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suckle</mark> from your post-wedding boobs. Yes, babies <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nurse</mark> from breasts. Get over it, kids. You waited until your wedding to have your baby and all it seems to do with its mouth is suckle. It doesn't cry, which is nice, but it doesn't laugh or talk either.
mnemonics.reading: ほ ほぐく, ふく None The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time! This hoe has really helped you get through nursing. You think you'll keep this up even after your baby is weaned! Hoeing the garden is your new favorite hobby!

mnemonics.meaning: Villa Clearing his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> returns home to his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">villa</mark>. Picture the samurai's villa. It's in the countryside and covered in flowers and icicles. Even though it's spring, it's still cold, so all the new flowers are very cold.
mnemonics.reading: そう, しょう, ちゃん あごそ, ほうき None Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go. Picture the samurai sitting in a chair in his beautiful villa and breathing his last breath. His soul slowly floats up and out of his still body and dances around the villa, free.

mnemonics.meaning: Whale If you travel to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whale</mark>! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all. Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
mnemonics.reading: げい くじら None The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay. Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Wholesale At <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> to buy <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>s because that's the only time they're being sold at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wholesale</mark> price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares! Imagine yourself stopping at the empty bank at noon, grabbing a handful of wholesale stamps. So many stamps. So few extra charges.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ おろし, おろ None Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too! "Oh Roshi" you say carefully as you hand your stamps over at noon. The guy raises an eyebrow at you, but gives you them wholesale! It worked!

mnemonics.meaning: Accumulate You start growing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accumulate</mark> more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you. Just imagine how much thread you'll accumulate if you can just grow it along with your rice in the rice paddy! So much thread!
mnemonics.reading: るい None None Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it. Your attempts to accumulate more of something by cheating have brought ruin to everything else you were doing. Nice job, dummy.

mnemonics.meaning: Bow Lay When you meet the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bow</mark> to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one. Picture yourself bowing to the leader dog. Leader dog is so cool!
mnemonics.reading: ふく ふ None You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think. Bow even deeper as the dog leader keeps barking what sounds like f**k you. You're pretty sure that's what he's saying at least... but maybe... maybe it's not.

mnemonics.meaning: Captive When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> meets a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">man</mark>, it becomes the man's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">captive</mark>. Men can be pretty mean like that. They see a tiger and they want to put it in a cage, so the poor tiger becomes the man's captive. Picture the sad tiger captive and the man laughing as he pokes at it. Tigers shouldn't be captives, but when men find them they always seem to do this anyway.
mnemonics.reading: りょ, ろ とりく, とりこ None The man takes his new tiger captive to Rio (りょ). Why Rio de Janeiro? Turns out you're allowed to keep tigers captive down in Rio. Now picture this tiger captive in Rio. He's stuck in a cage at home while the man yucks it up along Rio's beaches, bragging to all the locals about his captive tiger.

mnemonics.meaning: Circulation Sequential If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> you better be ready to move in perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circulation</mark> with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool. Imagine this strange circulation of you and the pope up here on a cliff. It's not even like you two are up here for a reason, you're just loitering. But he doesn't want to be hot so he makes you circulate with him.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance. "This circulation is all June's fault," you mutter, walking in a circle with the pope to stay cool.

mnemonics.meaning: Coarse Rough If you find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> it's going to be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coarse</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rough</mark>. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten. Imagine trying to eat the rice you found in a top hat. It's so coarse it feels like it's scratching your teeth. There's probably some dirt in here too. This wasn't the best idea.
mnemonics.reading: そ あら None You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ). If you were trying to make this coarse rice taste like soap, you did it. But if you were trying to make it less coarse, well... sorry, but that's not how anything works.

mnemonics.meaning: Congeal Freeze, Absorbed In If you try to turn something into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> while having <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">doubt</mark>s, it will just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congeal</mark> instead. It will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">freeze</mark>, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice. Imagine looking over water in an ice cube tray. You aren't sure if they'll turn out alright, and you doubt whether ice is even a thing. As you think this, the water congeals and freezes into gross shapes.
mnemonics.reading: ぎょう こ, こご None You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck! Picture frozen, congealed gyoza. Do you want to eat that? I didn't think so.

mnemonics.meaning: Cork Plug The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> that's made from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cork</mark>. It's a big, wooden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plug</mark> that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat. Picture how silly the king looks with this cork on his head. He kind of looks like a fat, plugged up bottle of wine when he yells now.
mnemonics.reading: せん None None It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing. Picture the centaurs drinking and giggling, putting the cork from their wine on their head to imitate the stupid king.

mnemonics.meaning: Crystal The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> (of England, if you remember) has a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crystal</mark>. The king crystal. Picture the king holding this crystal aloft, giggling as the sun shines through it and sparkles.
mnemonics.reading: えい None あき, あきら The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden. Imagine going to England, to the giant acorn in the center of the flowers, and searching for the king's crystal. If you find it, you can probably sell it for a fortune! Or just make a really sweet necklace.

mnemonics.meaning: Dawn The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: たん, だん あきら, あき, あさ, あした, ただし None Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you. Imagine getting a tan at dawn. Ahh. Relaxing and warm.

mnemonics.meaning: Dedicate When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dedicate</mark> your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside. You know how you get. When you can't go outside, you dedicate yourself full force into something else. I mean, you made it to level 55, right? That's some serious dedication. And it probably started because of one particularly dry spring.
mnemonics.reading: ほう, ぶ たてまつ, まつ None You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system. Dedicate yourself to doing things in your home! Haha, who are we kidding, you already did that. We love you, nerd. ♡

mnemonics.meaning: Distant You got off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to load some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> onto it, when it suddenly took off to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distant</mark> place! That's some powerful charcoal. Your scooter is charcoal powered, but it looks like you put too much in there and it drove off somewhere distant without you. If you look really carefully, you can just see it, a distant speck on the horizon.
mnemonics.reading: りょう None None You chase the scooter to that distant place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!! You can still make out the distant shape of your scooter, now on a row boat, fading away and completely out of reach.

mnemonics.meaning: Enclosure You just <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark>d a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, so you want to surround it with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enclosure</mark>. Imagine the building you just received. You want to protect it, so you get started on that enclosure. Imagine building your enclosure with your bare hands.
mnemonics.reading: かく くるわ None The enclosure felt a bit quiet and lonely, so you decided to get yourself a pet cock (かく). Your pet cock is the perfect addition to your new enclosure. Just look at it, pecking happily between the enclosure and that building you received.

mnemonics.meaning: Erase Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">erase</mark> them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful. Imagine your fingers slowly getting closer and closer to the jet's engine. It feels like it's going to suck your whole body in. And you better watch out, because if it does you'll be erased from the planet. And probably from time itself.
mnemonics.reading: まつ None None You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself! Now you're so thankful to the mats. If they weren't there you might have erased your whole body! Thank you mats! I'll never walk on you without thanking you for your service again!

mnemonics.meaning: Excellent Skilled A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets double the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to build on if he's the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excellent</mark> and most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skilled</mark> of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here. Imagine being so excellent at leading, that you get double the dirt that everyone else gets.
mnemonics.reading: か None None This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves. Imagine your own car. Is it as excellent as you?

mnemonics.meaning: Frugal Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> was very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frugal</mark>, which is why you get to have too much in this life! Thank you soul, for being frugal so that I can have so much now.
mnemonics.reading: せき お None You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of. If you want your spouse or S.O. to think you're more sexy, just be more frugal. They'll definitely appreciate it and see you in a different light.

mnemonics.meaning: Grief A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s lower themselves to their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>s in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grief</mark>. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense. Imagine if winter was so brutal that there were only one hundred human foreheads left. You lost all of your friends and family. Feel that grief.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう う, うれ None Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world. Grief for youths is so painful. No one should have to bury their forehead child.

mnemonics.meaning: Grieve Mourn The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> leaves <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark>. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grieve</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourn</mark> for your now-dead toe. Look at your toe. It has no soul. It's dark and shriveled, like a mummy's toe. Grieve and watch your tears drip onto it.
mnemonics.reading: とう いた None You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish. Walk through the streets of とうきょう grieving, with your dead toe flopping onto the pavement.

mnemonics.meaning: Healing Cure The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> needs its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cure</mark>d. If it doesn't get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">healing</mark> soon, it will die. Maybe the Death Star wouldn't be sick if it wasn't so mean to you, yelling at you for living in a yurt, when it was a yurt on the inside the whole time. Wait! I know the cure!
mnemonics.reading: ゆ い, いや None You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside! Hmm, but does this type of yurt healing technology exist?! You'll have to find out to cure it!!

mnemonics.meaning: Horse Chestnut You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> growing on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> and it has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ten thousand</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse chestnut</mark>s growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one. Picture this tree, weighed down by it's own horse chestnuts, leaning over the edge of the cliff.
mnemonics.reading: None とち None You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww! Horse chestnuts taste like nasty toe cheese. Imagine what having one in your mouth would be like.

mnemonics.meaning: Imperial Dragon The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">imperial</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imperial</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means imperial and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
mnemonics.reading: りゅう, りょう, ろう たつ None Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know! Picture Ryu kicking the butts of imperial scum like Bison and Darth Vader.

mnemonics.meaning: Increasing Go from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">increasing</mark> in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow. Imagine increasing your power with a new weapon. What would it be?
mnemonics.reading: び, み や None You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it. Imagine walking down a line of weapons, each one increasing in power from the one before it. Bow, small gun, bigger gun, tank, Yankee's bat. Yup, that sounds right.

mnemonics.meaning: Marrow Bone Marrow Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bone</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> that moves through the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bone marrow</mark> inside them. If you think about it, bone marrow is really just a road for tiny blood scooters.
mnemonics.reading: ずい None None If you put your ear really close to a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there. That's how doctors can tell if there's something wrong with your bone marrow. If they can't hear the zuuwee of the scooters, you're gonna die soon. I mean, maybe, I'm not a doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: Must Not A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark> is something you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">must not</mark> do anything with. Wings are fragile (think bird's wings and butterfly's wings) and sometimes dangerous (like the wings of a plane) and you must not touch them, or even go near them! You MUST NOT. You. MUST. NOT. Imagine a pair of wings with a prohibition sign (a red circle with a red line) on them. And next time you see a wing of any kind, think "I MUST NOT"!
mnemonics.reading: もち None None Apart from staying away from wings, the other thing you must not do is eat mochi (もち). Okay, they're not fragile or dangerous, but I love mochi and I don't want you eating them. Now imagine some mochi with red prohibition circles on them. You MUST NOT eat those, do you hear me? Those mochi are mine!

mnemonics.meaning: Nearby Side The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing funny, facing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nearby</mark>. He can't go far because there's obviously something wrong with his feet. He's stuck nearby, very close to your side. Picture the leader very close to your side. He's looking off into the distance, a distance he'll never get to because all he can do is stand there with his messed up feet.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう かたわ, わき, おか, はた, そば None You decide to bring the leader to a nearby bowling (ぼう) alley. It's really close and you can stay right by his side as he throws bowling balls and gets his anger out. Picture the leader bowling nearby. You keep him close by, you never know when he'll fall over and need your help.

mnemonics.meaning: Pleasant The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> is actually quite <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasant</mark>. And if you think about it, it's the people who control the Death Star that are evil and kill. Picture the Death Star in your mind. As you picture it, its pleasant, smiling soul floats up and out of it. "Oh hello, dear," it says happily, "Didn't see you there!"
mnemonics.reading: ゆ たの None The pleasant soul within the Death Star actually looks like a yurt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball. Yurts are very pleasant structures. They're round and soft and moveable, just like the Death Star's soul.

mnemonics.meaning: Proceed Move On You need to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>s if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proceed</mark> down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">move on</mark> at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run! Imagine trying to proceed down the road by running on your toes. No other part of your foot can touch the ground!
mnemonics.reading: ふ おもむ None If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here! Imagine being called a fool when you can't proceed along the road because running on your toes ends up being super hard to do.

mnemonics.meaning: Prosperous Prosperity The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>s, they can get even more done and it makes them way more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperous</mark> than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperity</mark> because of the two suns. Picture the prosperous planet that has two suns. They get so much work done that no one is ever hungry or tired or without.
mnemonics.reading: しょう さかん None The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the Shougun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need. Picture the Shougun looking over the prosperous world, the two suns at his back.

mnemonics.meaning: Remorse Regret The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feeling</mark> a dead <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will have is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remorse</mark>. Remorse for the people it left behind. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Regret</mark>s for the things it did and didn't do. If you died right now and left your soul behind, do you think you'd have regrets?
mnemonics.reading: かん うら None The soul with the most regrets is Genghis Khan (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now. Picture Genghis Khan looking down at the state of his people, the Mongols, in the modern world. See the remorse in his soul's face. They should be leaders of the modern world. Not reduced to a people struggling in the background.

mnemonics.meaning: Simple Crude You decide to carve a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> into a giant replica of your big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> because you think it will be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simple</mark>. Once you're done though, it looks like a really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crude</mark> attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought. Imagine carving a really simple, crude toe from a tree. It's your first attempt, so I guess you should have known it wouldn't be great.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく えのき, ほう, ほお None You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく! Who carved this simple toe? ぼく!

mnemonics.meaning: Stature Height If you put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> pound weights on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> they'll increase in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stature</mark> when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller! Imagine how much height you'd gain if you spent time lifting weights on the moon!
mnemonics.reading: せき せ, せい None Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh? Imagine how sexy the height of a ten foot tall person would be after just coming back from weight training on the moon.

mnemonics.meaning: The Above That Specifically You want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> in half so that people focus on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the above</mark> text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say! Imagine actually slicing the words you say in the air. The above section is what you want people to pay attention to, so you slice a big gap between the above and the below words.
mnemonics.reading: がい None None As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy! That guy doesn't care if the above is all he's supposed to hear. That guy sucks.

mnemonics.meaning: This This One How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark>. On top of one of the hills is a little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water. You pick it up and say “<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">THIS</mark>… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!” As you look at the drop of water, you note that you found the right thing. Written on it is the word “this."
mnemonics.reading: し これ, の None You collect(これ) this very carefully. You’re going to add this to your drop collection. You’re always collecting drops of water in the hills. It’s your hobby, in fact. But this one is the first one you’ve ever collected with “this” written on it. What a great addition to your drop collection.

mnemonics.meaning: Tranquilize The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reality</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> is that it has the power to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tranquilize</mark> anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up! Imagine being tranquilized by the sweet caress of gold coins. You can't even move. You're in a daze or something.
mnemonics.reading: ちん おさえ, しず None You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich! If you let gold tranquilize you, you'll drool all over your own chin. Maybe the chins of other people too, who knows?

mnemonics.meaning: Urine Pee When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> stuck somewhere in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>. That flag is there so you know it's okay to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pee</mark> in that area of the pool. Everyone knows <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urine</mark> dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water. Imagine swimming over to the flag that's sticking out of the water and peeing there. Yeah, everyone knows what you're doing over there, but it's better than getting out and walking to the bathroom right? Just pee in the water. Just do it.
mnemonics.reading: にょう None None Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad? Imagine your embarrassment when you find out that you aren't supposed to urinate in the water, not even by the pee flag, because a life guard yelled NYOOOOOO and pointed right at you while you did it.

mnemonics.meaning: VIP Guest Between the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. This is because we invited some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">VIP</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guest</mark>s into our home and they ate all our shellfish. The VIPs came into our home (the place between our roof and the ground) where they consumed all our shellfish. Only the best for guests, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: ひん None None These VIP guests are part of a Hindu (ひん) envoy. We are treating these VIP guests extra special because they represent the whole Hindu religion. They get shellfish because of course we weren't going to serve them beef!

mnemonics.meaning: What You're holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> in front of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">What</mark> will you do? A. Stab the building on the left. B. Stab the building on the right. What do you choose? What? Do you think I'm gonna help you make this decision? No way, you need to dig deep and think about what you want to do.
mnemonics.reading: な, だ いかん, なに, なんぞ None A. What is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)! B. What is, stab the building on the right? You stab the building on the right with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)! What?! You got nachos either way. You should be happy, don't ask me any other questions.

mnemonics.meaning: Artisan There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> in it above your house to show that you are an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">artisan</mark>. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things. Imagine looking down your street and seeing caged axes above all of the artisans homes and shops. You want a new chair? You want some pants mended? Go to one of those signs and you'll find the right artisan.
mnemonics.reading: しょう たくみ None Artisans have to be marked this way because the Shougun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system. Picture the Shougun marching angrily down the street. His shoe suddenly snaps in half. With just one glance he'll be able to find the shoe artisan and make them fix his shoe for free.

mnemonics.meaning: Beat You're tapping your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> against a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beat</mark>. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats! Imagine yourself in a completely white room. All you have is the white walls, your fingers, and your beats. When you stop all you're left with is white noise. Yuck! Keep those beats coming!
mnemonics.reading: はく, ひょう None None This beat is sick, but as you tap you realize you're hacking (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area. Imagine hacking the wall apart as you try to keep this beat going. The music is all you have, man! You can't lose the beat now!

mnemonics.meaning: Bind Restrain Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>ping people with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bind</mark>ing them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop! Imagine if your specialty was dropping people by binding them with thread. You'd be such a weird person.
mnemonics.reading: ばく しば None If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs! Imagine how you would bind someone so that when they drop they land on their back instead of somewhere more painful. How would you do that?

mnemonics.meaning: Bored Sated You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> yourself into a ball because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bored</mark>. You're also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sated</mark>, because you ate just the right amount, but now you have nothing to do and it's soooo booooring. Haven't you ever been so bored that you just wrapped yourself up into a boredom ball?
mnemonics.reading: ほう あ None So now you're bored and stuck at home (ほう). You aren't hungry. There's nothing on TV. And you don't want to have to leave your home to do something, even though that would probably solve your boredom problem. Ehhhhhhgggg guys I'm stuck at home and I'm soooo bored. Heeelpp!

mnemonics.meaning: Brushwood Firewood If you could <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>ing water onto that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> we could use it for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brushwood</mark>. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already! We need to use that brushwood to make a fire! So stop spooning water on it!
mnemonics.reading: さい, し しば None You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa? Shiba inu's come from setting brushwood on fire! That must have been how they got their name!

mnemonics.meaning: Butterfly The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> that is amongst all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">butterfly</mark>. They are always hanging around trees, those butterflies. Imagine any tree in the world with different kinds of butterflies fluttering around. Then go to another tree in the world that looks completely different. Once again, butterflies! They really are fluttering around every tree in the world.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう None None As you look at a butterfly, fluttering around a tree, a hand reaches out from the tree and grabs it, then starts plucking the wings off. An evil laugh comes from inside the tree, and you know it's Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She grabs another butterfly and starts pulling off wings again, though this time you can see her evil face looking at you while she does it. "I hate butterflies," she says. "They are always dying in my tea."

mnemonics.meaning: Chord String, Bowstring This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> because it's strung with a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chord</mark>. I guess that makes the chord both a musical instrument <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">string</mark> as well as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bowstring</mark>. Pluck the chord and it shoots an arrow while making a perfect G note. So mysterious! Note: We're using "chord" here as the fancy name for a musical instrument string (like in "the chords of a harp" or "strike a chord"). This kanji covers both musical strings and bowstrings! So this mysterious bow's string is for plucking a one-note tune or launching an attack. Either way, your enemies will be moved to tears.
mnemonics.reading: げん つる None Turns out this bow strung with a mysterious chord belongs to Genji (げん). Of course! Only someone as elegant and dramatic as Genji would own a bow that plays music when you pluck its string. Genji is a lover, not a fighter. Picture Genji, the most handsome and romantic man ever, serenading you with his one-note G-string bow. Swoon! Just hope he doesn't sink an arrow into you too.

mnemonics.meaning: Cold You're trying to open the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> of a manhole that's covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>ing it a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">times</mark> but it's not working because it's just too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time! Imagine if it was sooo cold that no matter how many times you tried to jackhammer the ice of the lid for this manhole, it wouldn't crack open.
mnemonics.reading: りん きびし None Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it. If it wasn't so darn cold you wouldn't have to hear this horrible high pitched ringing sound because there wouldn't even be any ice to jackhammer through!

mnemonics.meaning: Commonplace Under this canopy you have a brush (in its 肀 form) and a task to complete with it. This is totally commonplace. This is a totally commonplace thing for almost every class or job you'll ever have. They sit you down under the canopy, put a brush in your hand, and say, "Here, complete this task. I'll be over there."
mnemonics.reading: よう None None This is so commonplace and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some yogurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back. As you eat the yogurt you think about how commonplace yogurt is too. It's just a normal, plain, boring old food, found in practically everyone's fridge.

mnemonics.meaning: Confused Mixed This was pure <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark>, but now it's not. Someone got <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confused</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mixed</mark> it with something else. You could swear this thing was gold a long time ago. Now it's a mix of different things.
mnemonics.reading: さく, しゃく None None It's mixed (and not pure anymore) because the confused person put it in that sack (さく) filled with various other things. Since it was in that sack for so long, it just ended up getting mixed with the other stuff in that sack. It was gold a long time ago, but now it's mixed with everything else.

mnemonics.meaning: Control When you drive a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, everyone under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is putting their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> in your hands, even if they don't say it with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>—it's still under your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">control</mark>. It's really important to remember how many things are under your control when you operate a vehicle. It isn't just the people in your car either, it's everyone and everything in your way too.
mnemonics.reading: かつ くさび None You have to maintain control of your car or you'll hit a bunch of cats (かつ). The roads are full of cats at all times. And if you lose control of your car for just a second, you'll hit at least two or three cats. If you don't want to think about hitting adorable cats with your car, you better maintain control. You're responsible!

mnemonics.meaning: Delight Joy If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> from bad things you'll always feel <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delight</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">joy</mark>. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can. Imagine guarding yourself from all the bad things in the world. No more politics, religion, internet trolls debating the two, it's all guarded from your precious soul. Ahhh, it's so joyous to be unburdened.
mnemonics.reading: えつ よろこ None The delight you feel is so great that it becomes permanently etched (えつ) in your soul and even your face. Picture joy etched on your own face. No one can get you down.

mnemonics.meaning: Destitute Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> in someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and they'll become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">destitute</mark>. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all. Picture a destitute person wandering in the streets with a hole in their body.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう, きょう きわ None You see this destitute person and decide to give them a cucumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow. Picture a destitute person, sitting on the street, holding a cucumber. Putting the cucumber in their hole. Crying.

mnemonics.meaning: Esteem Praise If when you speak it sounds like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> is coming out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, then people will hold you in high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">esteem</mark>. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices! Imagine hearing someone speak and it's so powerful and loud that it sounds like they have a drum booming out of their mouth. You'll love them! You'll hold them in the highest esteem!
mnemonics.reading: か よい, よみ None You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey! If you hold someone in high esteem you give me your- give them your car. Gimme!

mnemonics.meaning: Evil <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">penguin</mark>s together are always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any. Imagine walking around in the arctic when you stumble upon an evil group of penguins. They'd be cute if they weren't holding papers with "Kill All Humans" on them and tiny guns in their penguin hands.
mnemonics.reading: へい None None The evil penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a haystack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans. Only someone or, in this case, something truly evil would kill someone and hide their remains under some hay. That's really disrespectful and, well, evil.

mnemonics.meaning: Far Off Far Away There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> that is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark>, but it is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far off</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far away</mark>. Look up into the sky. That little moving light is the scooter satellite. It's just scooting along, far away from here.
mnemonics.reading: よう はる None The scooter satellite is far off, but you can still hear it's horn go "har (はる) har har." The scooter satellite's only purpose is to make a "har har har" sound that is audible from far away. It's quite obnoxious.

mnemonics.meaning: Flood A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with another tsunami is going to cause a massive <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flood</mark>. More than one tsunami will definitely result in a flood. Imagine the floody aftermath of more than one tsunami, arriving together.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None After the terrible flood, Emperor こういち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews. "This flood was caused by you! It is because you did not believe in the holy Crabigator! It is because you didn't do your kanji reviews. You have sinned, sinned, sinned!" こういち says to the scared, cold, now homeless people.

mnemonics.meaning: Gentleman Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> and that makes you a perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentleman</mark>. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are. Picture yourself as the perfect gentleman. You may not have a fancy top hat and tie, but you're humble about what you wear and you're kind to everyone.
mnemonics.reading: しん None None Unfortunately, as a gentleman who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the shins (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults). But you're a gentleman, so you don't kick their shins back, you smile and hold in the pain. No matter how bad your shins hurt, you never fight back!

mnemonics.meaning: Give You've learned that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> things to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give</mark> them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love. If you want to give someone something, use a catapult!
mnemonics.reading: ご くれ, く None Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry. You give Godzilla old used cars, chunks of old buildings, and sometimes hamburgers. Godzilla is so happy you're giving him food, he doesn't destroy anymore!

mnemonics.meaning: Grain A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s with his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grain</mark>s will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them. Picture the samurai taking out his weapon and spinning in a lightning fast circle. The forehead grains pop off and come raining into his open mouth.
mnemonics.reading: こく None None Phew, all of this grain is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing Coke (こく). These grains aren't even cooked, they're just hard and raw, so the Coke really helps wash them down.

mnemonics.meaning: In Addition Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark>s when there's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">in addition</mark> to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears! Pretend you're in a class in the mid-20th century, watching a video on bomb explosion safety. In addition to putting your fingers in your ears, you have to do a bunch of other stuff. You can't just stop after the first step!
mnemonics.reading: せつ, しょう おさ, かね, と None In addition to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about! In addition to ears, you have a lot of sets on your body to worry about. Sets of eyes, nostrils, legs, you get the picture.

mnemonics.meaning: Lonely On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark>, is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. Anyone who sits in that stool will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lonely</mark>. Imagine sitting on this small stool, waaaaay up there above the roof. You can't see anyone and you can't talk to anyone. You feel this awful emptiness inside. That's what it's like to be lonely.
mnemonics.reading: じゃく, せき さび, さみ None You're so lonely, you make up an imaginary friend: Jack (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least. You're so busy talking to Jack, you don't hear the voices from below, "Aren't you lonely up there, miss? Do you want us to get a jack to get you down? Hello? I don't think she can hear us..."

mnemonics.meaning: Manager Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> because you're the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manager</mark>. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would). Picture yourself as the manager of a restaurant or a science lab. You have to test all of your managerial methods at home before you can bring them to work. And if you were to lick that roof of yours... it would be spicy from all of your experiments.
mnemonics.reading: さい None None You've finally done it. You're now the manager of a bunch of spicy new cyborgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way. Unfortunately, you couldn't figure out how to make non-spicy cyborgs, but that's okay because you're going to be the best cyborg manager ever! No one will ever take them away from you again.

mnemonics.meaning: Mausoleum Tomb The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> you'll get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> in is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mausoleum</mark>. Mausoleums and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>s weren't made for living people, so they aren't insulated from the cold. No one cares if a dead body gets frostbite. Unfortunately, you're realizing this because you thought a mausoleum would be a good hiding place from the winter cold. Spoilers, it's not.
mnemonics.reading: りょう みささぎ None You need to escape this mausoleum now but the only way out is on a row (りょう) boat over a creepy frozen pond. You've heard of these mausoleum row boats before, and you're pretty sure they're cursed. Imagine taking your frostbitten fingers and trying to get away from the mausoleum in this row boat. It looks like it was made of bones and it is not very seaworthy. But you row with all your might, because you don't want to end up a permanent fixture in this tomb!

mnemonics.meaning: Mediocre You go to buy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> but it looks like it has water damage from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mediocre</mark> table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre. You didn't expect to see water drop damage on this table so now your mood is mediocre too.
mnemonics.reading: ぼん, はん おうよ, およ, すべ None You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do. Imagine having a bone to pick with someone because they're trying to sell you something mediocre and they just won't listen. Now you have a bone to pick with the person who recommended this guy to you!

mnemonics.meaning: Military Officer Military Rank Who loves their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s, and precise <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s? Your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">military officer</mark>! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be? Picture a military officer doing all those things.
mnemonics.reading: い, じょう None None That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for! Picture the military officer saluting as an eagle flies overhead. Majestic.

mnemonics.meaning: Peaceful <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stand</mark> staring up at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> sky and you'll feel more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peaceful</mark> than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk. Imagine how peaceful staring at the blue ocean, the blue sky, or the blue tumblr makes you.
mnemonics.reading: せい やす None Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YAASS (やす)!" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say "YAASS" again! YAASS! Peaceful blue radicals standing in a row. What's that? YAASS you do want more radicals added to the site. Well okay then, if it will keep you at peace, sure!

mnemonics.meaning: Respect When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s of water work <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> they gain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respect</mark> for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too! Imagine being a small drop of water and seeing other drops of water come to help you by working together. You'd really respect them, right?
mnemonics.reading: きょう うやうや None If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees!" (うやうや) with them during each game. Imagine respecting someone so much that you'll cheer ooh yankees over and over even though they're kind of a crappy team.

mnemonics.meaning: Sew You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sew</mark> them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of. Imagine slowly sewing your scooter to the signpost, passing the thread back and forth through the signpost's metal holes and your scooter's handles.
mnemonics.reading: ほう ぬ None You usually only sew at home (ほう), so this is a big exception for you. You're usually worried that if you sew in public people will judge your stitches, so this is a big step for you! Hopefully, if your scooter is still here later you'll be able to start sewing outside of your home more often from now on!

mnemonics.meaning: Ship A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> isn't just a boat, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ship</mark>. Boats don't need to be a bright white color. But, ships do! They're dangerous and big, so they paint them nice and white.
mnemonics.reading: はく None None A white-painted ship is a kind of hack (はく). It makes the ship more visible without costing much. You can also imagine hacking the ship's computer. "Look at me, look at me. You are the hacker now."

mnemonics.meaning: Squeeze If you want to fit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark>, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squeeze</mark> them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door. Imagine what it would be like to squeeze your fingers into a keyhole. Maybe try squeezing one finger really tight first. Did that hurt? Well it's going to be a lot worse in that key hole.
mnemonics.reading: さく しぼ None Once you've squeezed your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your sack (さく). Your stealing sack. You have the ability to squeeze your fingers into locks to open them, so of course you're stealing. And you squeeze those stolen goodies into your sack so you can take them with you.

mnemonics.meaning: Still Yet An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> is drinking our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Still</mark>? You keep checking outside to see if they have stopped, but they are still drinking. They haven't stopped yet.
mnemonics.reading: ゆう, ゆ なお None The animal with horns that is still drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local youths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away. You keep checking, but that youth is still drinking. Of course, you don't know they are a youth, so it's quite impressive an animal can drink this much.

mnemonics.meaning: Suffocate Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> out of its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> and it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suffocate</mark>. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates. Picture a poor little mole suffocating in your hand after you took it out of its hole. Put it back right away! Don't kill that little mole!
mnemonics.reading: ちつ None None As the mole suffocates it cheats (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now. Unfortunately, you can't use cheats on life, and the mole suddenly stiffens and suffocates to death anyway. You should feel bad about what you've done.

mnemonics.meaning: Tombstone A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s from the sky into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and then a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s on top of it. They've combined to form a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tombstone</mark>! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it? Imagine seeing a stone and a cross drop from the sky onto each other to form a tombstone right in front of your eyes!
mnemonics.reading: ひ いしぶみ None Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere! Can you feel the heat radiating off this space tombstone? Maybe there's a space skeleton sizzling under there too...

mnemonics.meaning: Wisdom You shoot an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> so that it will grant you a gift of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wisdom</mark>. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too. Imagine shooting an arrow at the mouth of the sun and then waiting for the wisdom of the world to hit you. Did it work? Will you know when it works? Probably...
