mnemonics.reading: ち None とも You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese! Picture yourself thanking the sun for teaching you that all wisdom comes from cheese. Now take a big bite!

mnemonics.meaning: Blind The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s means that you've gone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blind</mark>. Imagine what it would be like to have one of your eyes die. You'll be blind in that eye forever!
mnemonics.reading: もう めくら None When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything. Imagine a blind person mowing over everyone in their car as they drive on the sidewalk. Eeek. At least they don't have to see this mess.

mnemonics.meaning: Brew An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brew</mark> it. Imagine a nurse brewing alcohol with the same attention they would nurse a human patient. But this brew is much more important than any person's health.
mnemonics.reading: じょう かも None A brew of alcohol is what Joe (じょう) loves most after a long day of working the fields. Imagine what it must be like for Joe, out working on the fields all day long, working up a sweat. I’d say he’s earned a cold alcoholic brew after such a day. Cut the man some slack.

mnemonics.meaning: Concave Hollow The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">concave</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">concave</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: おう くぼ, へこ, ぼこ None If you call someone concave the 王 (おう) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave. Watch your mouth around the 王. Have you ever seen a concave person? Yeah that's because they didn't live through it. 王s aren't very nice, you know.

mnemonics.meaning: Condolence You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condolence</mark>s. Imagine looking at the bow and stick as you slide them over to your deceased friend's family. This won't do enough, but it is a little condolence at least.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう とぶら, とむら None More than a condolence, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set. Imagine her saying, "My condolences," as Mrs. Chou does him in.

mnemonics.meaning: Convex Uneven The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">convex</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">convex</mark> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both. Study your radicals and you'll read good.
mnemonics.reading: とつ でこ None Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex! Tote bags are totes not convex though. Don't mix them up.

mnemonics.meaning: Crow An altered <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crow</mark>! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter! See that bird? Wait, that's not just a bird, it's a crow!
mnemonics.reading: う, お からす None If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool! How many crows have you caressed today?

mnemonics.meaning: Daring An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elf</mark> who ventures outside in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> has a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">daring</mark>. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude. Imagine how much daring it would take to go outside in winter knowing you could be freezing your precious elf ears off.
mnemonics.reading: かん あ None The amount of daring you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis Khan (かん) had. And he was really daring! Do you think you have the same amount of daring as an elf going out in winter and Genghis Khan? Tell the truth.

mnemonics.meaning: Degradation When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> piling up all around them, it's a sign of their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">degradation</mark>. Picture a street where nothing is maintained. The buildings crumble in the dirt, but the people have lost the will to care. It's not just physical, it's spiritual degradation too…
mnemonics.reading: だ お, くず None And who's leading this charge into degradation? Your dad (だ), of course. Your dad isn't just part of the degradation — he's the ringleader. He's sitting in a broken lawn chair, surrounded by empty beer cans, takeout containers, and piles of dirt. He waves his hand, and more junk food wrappers fall around him, almost like he's commanding this lazy, degenerate lifestyle.

mnemonics.meaning: Drum Beat You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> and... well, what else would you do? You would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drum</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beat</mark> them together. A branch is just like a drumstick, so of course you're going to drum them together.
mnemonics.reading: こ つづみ None Who loves to drum things together and make a huge racket? 子s (こ), of course. Kids can't get enough of it. Anything that makes a loud drumming noise or anything they can beat together is fun for them.

mnemonics.meaning: Equilibrium You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and establish a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> right in the middle of it to restore the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equilibrium</mark> of the area. There was a lot of crime right here in this rice paddy, so you just built a big prison right there to lower the crime rate so this region can experience equilibrium once again.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None To restore equilibrium, you throw all the こういち clones into the prison. You might remember from the kanji 耕 that there were こういち clones working in these rice paddy fields. Well, they were the ones disturbing the equilibrium. At least that's what Emperor こういち said. So by throwing them in a prison built right here, the area could once again achieve equilibrium.

mnemonics.meaning: Fell Attack If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your gang is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> he'll try to have you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fell</mark> trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> the trees anyway. Imagine felling trees with a bunch of other guys, yelling things like, "This is what you get for stepping on my turf!" It's a little silly.
mnemonics.reading: ばつ う, き, そむ None You and your gang head out to fell the trees, only to remember that all you have are bats (ばつ). Good luck trying to take down trees with nothing but bats! This is good news for the trees, but your drunken leader isn't going to be happy.

mnemonics.meaning: Fermentation Ferment <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Alcohol</mark> is a good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">teacher</mark> on the process of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fermentation</mark>. Because alcohol is so good and addicting, people will work extra hard to ferment it properly. This makes it a good teacher to learn about fermentation. People are motivated to figure it out!
mnemonics.reading: こう None None Using fermentation, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor こういち. You are fermenting thousands of bottles of alcohol for Emperor こういち's big party.

mnemonics.meaning: Inspection Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to get a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inspection</mark> of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself! Imagine the guard doing his inspection in front of the gate all day long. He should have a nice report for you once he's done.
mnemonics.reading: えつ けみ None His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear! If you hire a guard to stand at your gate and conduct an inspection of your neighborhood, make sure you tell him not to use an etch a sketch!

mnemonics.meaning: Intercept You're riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> toward your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> your water and you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intercept</mark> them. If you manage to intercept them before they can go in there to boil things, you'll be able to pick up all the clothes and comic books you left on the floor. You really don't want anyone to see those.
mnemonics.reading: しゃ さえぎ None You manage to intercept the shaman (しゃ) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him. Phew, you intercepted the shaman in time (though she doesn't look very happy about being scooted into) and now you can clean up your yurt before they go in.

mnemonics.meaning: Intestines The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intestines</mark>. Imagine the moon, then imagine it cross-fading into your big, round tummy. Then, cut it open because you think the moon is easy to cut. And finally, see your intestines as clearly as you can.
mnemonics.reading: ちょう はらわた, わた None All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. Chou (ちょう). This scene was in all the omen radicals you've been seeing about her. If only you could have stopped her, then none of this would have happened, right? Perhaps it was all destiny, you think, as your intestines fall from your stomach and Mrs. Chou cackles over your weakening body.

mnemonics.meaning: Latter B Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nose</mark> isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">latter</mark>. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">B</mark> and C and you'll never forget! Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
mnemonics.reading: おつ, いつ おと, きのと None If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice. Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: Maple A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that does well in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">maple</mark> tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places! Picture a bunch of maple trees being blown by the wind. They don't seem upset, they actually seem really happy.
mnemonics.reading: ふう かえで None When the wind goes through the maple tree you know it's kite day (かえで)! Imagine your kite in the maple tree.

mnemonics.meaning: Membrane If you trap the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> it will grow a creepy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">membrane</mark> around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though. Imagine seeing the moon with a membrane sitting stuffed in a greenhouse. It looks like something out of the Alien movies and you're starting to think putting it in there wasn't a good idea.
mnemonics.reading: まく None None You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon? Can you imagine if the moon had a membrane and it smelled like a big mac? How does that even happen? You should probably go ask that food chain what they use for their ingredients.

mnemonics.meaning: Navy Blue Dark Blue If you want to turn your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> color you just HAVE to go with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">navy blue</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dark blue</mark>. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet. Turn your thread a sweet navy color and people will be reminded of yummy blue raspberry. MmMmm.
mnemonics.reading: こん None None Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest. Imagine a condor stealing your sweet navy thread right after you dyed it, flying off. Lame!

mnemonics.meaning: Pale Blue <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> grown in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> will be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pale</mark>. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors. Imagine walking into a warehouse and seeing hundreds of pale flowers growing in it. It's subtle, but beautiful.
mnemonics.reading: そう あお None When you grow pale flowers like this, they don't grow a soul (そう). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too. Picture a bunch of pale, soulless flowers. You pick one up and it falls apart in your hands.

mnemonics.meaning: Question Mark ? A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">question mark</mark> into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth? Imagine having a drunkard spit a dirty question mark into your hand. You want to say, "Yes, I'm ??? too."
mnemonics.reading: さい や, かな None The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a Yankee's (や) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods. Picture yourself throwing the question mark at the drunkard who only cares about the Yankees. What a waste of time.

mnemonics.meaning: Ravine To the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s you took your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horned</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ravine</mark>. Imagine walking up the mountain in your wedding clothes so you can get married without anyone trying to stop you. Then, because you're still worried, you go into a ravine where you are read your marriage vows.
mnemonics.reading: きょう, こう はざま None The ravine is still in きょうと though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine. This ravine runs right through the middle of きょうと, though most people don't notice it. That makes it the best place for a secret wedding to a horned freak-husband.

mnemonics.meaning: Robber When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> becomes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> and sees a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, they'll become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">robber</mark>. Because they'll steal the cross! Some people make really bad choices when they're drunk, and in this case, when a shellfish gets drunk and sees something it wants it'll just rob people for it.
mnemonics.reading: ぞく None None Once the shellfish has a taste for being a robber, he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles. Picture a robber shellfish in a Bosozoku bike gang. Look at him the wrong way and he and his gang will steal all your stuff next time!

mnemonics.meaning: Rotation Revolution Move your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> in one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> by shooting it with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rotation</mark> going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolution</mark>s, you're probably wrong. Imagine getting your coat rack to make rotations in a circle just by shooting it with a gun!
mnemonics.reading: せん None None As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate. Picture that centaurs angry face. Convince yourself it was the rotation it didn't like.

mnemonics.meaning: Salary The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> says <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> is looking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, so you'll need your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salary</mark> in advance. The leader shows you the number, it's all of your salary for spring. "This way, if things dry up worse, you'll be okay for a while," he says. This is awfully nice, but very suspicious at the same time.
mnemonics.reading: ほう None None Your salary is sent straight to your home (ほう) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here. You're sitting at home, and there is a knock at the door. A man in a suit, hat, and dark sunglasses hands you a briefcase full of money. "Here's your spring salary. Enjoy the dry weather." "T-thanks?" Welp, have fun at home with your stacks of early salary cash.

mnemonics.meaning: Scold If you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> while you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> will appear to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scold</mark> you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun. Imagine trying to reflect some precious sunlight into your prison room with a spoon. Now imagine a mouth appearing in the way of the sunlight and it scolds you.
mnemonics.reading: かつ None None One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's scolding you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of cats (かつ). WHAT KIND OF WORLD IS THIS THAT YOU'RE IN A PRISON WHERE CATS SCOLD YOU?!

mnemonics.meaning: Spread Out Arrange You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> for catching a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>. But, it must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spread out</mark> and you must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrange</mark> it first. The reason you'd use a net made of thread is because it's hard to see. But, it's only that way when you spread out the net. It's important to spread out and arrange your net otherwise the turkey will see it.
mnemonics.reading: ら うすもの None You spread out your net and arrange it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). "Let me out of this net!" says Ra. "You arranged and spread it out just right so I couldn't see it!"

mnemonics.meaning: Sprout You have to put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> place if you want them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprout</mark>. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot. Picture your flowers sprouting out of the ground in the bright spring sun.
mnemonics.reading: ほう きざ, めばえ, も None You want to grow these sprouts in your home (ほう), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest. Take a walk around your home right now. Can you find the best place to sprout flowers? Remember, it has to be nice and bright! Not dark and damp. Don't put them in your closet.

mnemonics.meaning: Tank Vat A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> melts into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> after listening to loud <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> in the hot <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, so you have to find a nice big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tank</mark> to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it. Imagine scooping a melted tree into a tank. It's a very strange sensation.
mnemonics.reading: そう ふね None You're staring at the big tank when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the soul (そう) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it. "Um, okay?" you reply to the soul, and walk away from the tank. "W-wait! Tanks can't move? Come back, let me haunt you with my tree soul!" It's a good thing there weren't wheels on that tank!

mnemonics.meaning: Two Mat Area Tsubo The amount of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> you need to get some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">two mat area</mark>. Two tatami mats, that is. Also called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tsubo</mark>, this is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together. Picture how big a two mat area is. Lie down and feel the peace this much space brings to you.
mnemonics.reading: へい つぼ None A two mat area also happens to be big enough to hold two bodies (つぼ). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies! Try to picture a two mat area with two bodies lying in it. Whether they're alive or dead is up to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Universal Riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">universal</mark> experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter. Scooters and libraries are universally loved by all!
mnemonics.reading: へん あまね None Riding a scooter to the library is so universal, even hens (へん) do it. The next time you scoot to the library look around. There are little hen scooters and hens there with their chicks. They're reading them books about grains and how to hatch eggs. It's a universally adorable thing to see.

mnemonics.meaning: Womb Uterus The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> in your body that is powered by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">womb</mark>, also called your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">uterus</mark>! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do! The next time you're cursing your uterus for making you bleed, curse the moon instead! It's the moon's fault you're in pain.
mnemonics.reading: たい None None It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore. Picture an invisible tie tieing your uterus to the moon. Damn you moon, stop pulling, it hurts!

mnemonics.meaning: Accompany The building clown is the only clown allowed to accompany you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together. I know it's been a long time, but try not to mix this one up with 部, if you can. Remember, the clown building is in another part of town and the clowns aren't supposed to leave. But the building clown is okay to accompany you through the rest of the city.
mnemonics.reading: ばい None None He can only accompany you for so long though and soon it's time to say bye (ばい) again. Wave bye to the clown, he'll accompany you on your building job tomorrow, but right now he has to go home and be with the rest of his clown people. He can't accompany you after dark.

mnemonics.meaning: Aid Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aid</mark> him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right? Imagine rubbing your husband's back with your fingers to aid him. You want him to feel better. You want him to get that comforting feeling that this kind of touching gives.
mnemonics.reading: ふ たす None Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your aid if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him. That's true love, my friend.

mnemonics.meaning: Alternate When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark>, you need to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alternate</mark>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too. You have a scooter that you drive every single day, but if you notice a fault, you need to send it in to get it fixed. That's when you break out your alternate scooter.
mnemonics.reading: てつ None None The alternate scooter is made entirely of 鉄 (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter. Imagine riding on your alternate 鉄 scooter. Feel the hard iron under your bum and the loud sounds it makes as you scoot down the street. I hope your normal scooter is fixed soon.

mnemonics.meaning: Chicken Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> was wearing his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s when he accidentally stepped on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>. Luckily this particular bird is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chicken</mark>, and chickens are really durable! Picture the sad, stepped on chicken. It's angrily clucking and chasing your husband around your yard for what he did.
mnemonics.reading: けい とり, にわとり None The only way to stop the chicken from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the cake (けい) you were making. This cake was for your husband, but now he gets nothing. The chicken gets to eat all of the cake in front of him instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Congratulations The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark>d all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulations</mark> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea. Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
mnemonics.reading: すい, ずい みず, しるし None The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know! Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.

mnemonics.meaning: Dawn <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gambler</mark>s usually only see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark>. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever! Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
mnemonics.reading: きょう, ぎょう あかつき, さと None If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか(red) つき(moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too! Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the あかつき in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!

mnemonics.meaning: Divide A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>s himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?! Instead of dying, the clown divides into slightly thinner clowns.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう None None The clown finally stops trying to divide himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over! The many clowns crash to the floor as the bowling ball plows through their... his(?) divided bodies. You can't bear to look anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Endure If you touch <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> for too long you'll get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> and that's a really hard thing to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark>. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you. Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
mnemonics.reading: りょう しの None The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice. Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!

mnemonics.meaning: Fiefdom You have to reach a certain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s hits to become a legitimate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fiefdom</mark>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom. Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
mnemonics.reading: はん None None The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo! Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.

mnemonics.meaning: Genealogy Score If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineup</mark> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you're really explaining your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">genealogy</mark>. This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score, as in a musical score or sheet music. So if your sheet music <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>s the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">line up</mark> of chords, especially <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>nny notes, that's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">score</mark> of a song. Those sunny notes are loved by your ancestors. Say the line up of your family under the sun, then sing some sunny chords to match. You'll know your genealogy and a musical score!
mnemonics.reading: ふ None None If you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a musical score, you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference. Your family genealogy and a musical score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.

mnemonics.meaning: Glassy The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> wants you to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rocket</mark> that looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">glassy</mark>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve. Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
mnemonics.reading: り None None You take the glassy rocket and try to stuff some thin reeds (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second. Picture the king admiring himself in the glassy surface and then his face contorts. He smashes his fist through the rocket and rips out the reeds. "REEDS AREN'T GLASSY!" he cries, and starts hitting you with them.

mnemonics.meaning: Graceful You can only manage to avoid a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> by standing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> it on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> if you are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">graceful</mark>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else. Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
mnemonics.reading: しゅく しと None No matter how graceful you are, the tsunami still shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down. It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!

mnemonics.meaning: Greatness Excellence The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to show his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">greatness</mark> to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excellence</mark>! "Look upon your leader's greatness!" he shouts, doing a jig around on the branches.
mnemonics.reading: けつ すぐ None If you don't recognize the leader's greatness he will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing. "Oh leader, your greatness is so... great!" you shout up at him. He's holding the ketsup bottle over your head and staring into your eyes as he dances in the tree. He isn't sure if he wants to dump it on you yet. He isn't sure if you really recognize his excellence.

mnemonics.meaning: Husk Shell A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> puts his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> next to his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>. He is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">husk</mark> of his former self. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shell</mark> of a samurai has nothing left. He's just sitting there, he can't even pick up his weapon or raise his head anymore.
mnemonics.reading: かく, こく, ばい から, がら None The only way to bring a husk of a samurai back to life is to have a cock (かく) crow right in his ear. "Co co co co cooooock!" the cock screams, shocking the samurai back into his lifeless shell. You did it!

mnemonics.meaning: Lapis Lazuli The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> will send his men with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>s into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> if you come across <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lapis lazuli</mark>. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants. If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days. Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
mnemonics.reading: る, りゅう None None You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff? Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...

mnemonics.meaning: Lock This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>? Better put a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lock</mark> on it, then. It's only natural that you'd want to put a lock on a gold roof so that nobody could steal it.
mnemonics.reading: じょう None None The person who put the lock on the gold roof was none other than... Joe (じょう)?! How did Joe, a simple farmhand, get hold of such a valuable gold roof? Either way, the lock he’s put on it is incredibly tough, so there’s no way you could make off with his gold roof anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: Mediator A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sits under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and works as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mediator</mark>. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady! Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
mnemonics.reading: ばい なこうど None You go to pay the woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then. Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.

mnemonics.meaning: Muddy Impure If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> gets into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> that's im<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>ing a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s, the insects are going to get all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">muddy</mark>. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff. Picture a net prison full of insects being dragged by a tsunami getting muddier and muddier. Poor buggles!
mnemonics.reading: だく, じょく にご None Unfortunately for the insects, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat! Picture a bunch of muddy ducks munching on some muddy trapped insects, in some muddy leftover tsunami water.

mnemonics.meaning: Pardon If you spill something <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">red</mark> on yourself in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pardon</mark> yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of! Imagine spilling red wine or red paint down your shirt. Quickly pardon yourself and get changed now!
mnemonics.reading: しゃ None None If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked! Imagine not pardoning yourself fast enough and having the winter shaman spirit away whatever you got red on. That's embarrassing.

mnemonics.meaning: Play Throw a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> in a cage with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> and the tiger will have the time of its life <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play</mark>ing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities! If you were the tiger how would you play with the drunkard?
mnemonics.reading: ぎ, げ ざ, じゃ, たわむ None If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore. What would you rather watch? A guillotine at work or a tiger playing like this?

mnemonics.meaning: Receive The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> kanji are exactly the same. Receive this nice, easy kanji with thanks!
mnemonics.reading: きょう, こう う None The best place to receive anything is in きょうと. The city is famous for the quality of everything they make, so if you’re in きょうと, keep your fingers crossed that you’ll receive something. Imagine being in きょうと and receiving something wonderful from a passerby in the street. What did you receive? How does it feel to receive something so great?

mnemonics.meaning: Request Entrust If you want to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mantis</mark> you have to make a formal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark> first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it. Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
mnemonics.reading: しょく たの None After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked! Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...

mnemonics.meaning: Resemblance You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> standing in front of a full <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and you can't help but see a really strong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resemblance</mark>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon! Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
mnemonics.reading: しょう あやか None The first person to see this resemblance was the Shougun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous. Imagine being the Shougun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.

mnemonics.meaning: Resent You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> at its feet and you suddenly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resent</mark> them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you... Picture the soul on the cross, flowers all around it and shellfish at its feet. Feel your resentment grow.
mnemonics.reading: ふん いきどお None You realize you resent them because it looks like they're having fun (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't! You wanna have fun hanging out on a cross with flowers and all the shellfish you can eat. Your resentment grows and grows as you watch the soul having everything you suddenly want. Fun fact: when you see 賁 in a kanji, the reading is probably going to be ふん.

mnemonics.meaning: Rot Decay A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is stuck in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and it's starting to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decay</mark>. Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground in a prison. The water gets all moldy and the tree will rot and die.
mnemonics.reading: きゅう く None You get close to the rotting tree and see some rotten cucumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No! This poor cucumber tree, left in this ground prison to rot. There's nothing worse than eating a rotten cucumber.

mnemonics.meaning: Run Bustle You're walking down the street when you see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run</mark> as fast as you can to get past them. Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
mnemonics.reading: ほん はし None You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street. Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.

mnemonics.meaning: Sail You hoist your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> into the water and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sail</mark> away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat. Imagine sailing out into the open sea, drops of water hitting your face, as the towel sail catches the air and carries you away.
mnemonics.reading: はん ほ None As you sail off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" Han (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water. You sail nervously past Han Solo who also seems to be sailing, though in worse shape than you. But he keeps throwing you finger guns so you figure it's best to just sail on and pretend this never happened.

mnemonics.meaning: Sedge The flowers that grow on your roof that look like a sleeping bear is sedge. Sedge grow all over the world! You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called! Looks like a green sleeping bear bum, right?
mnemonics.reading: かん, けん すげ すが The next time you see a sedge bite into it. It tastes like sugar (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear. Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm.

mnemonics.meaning: Serve Scoop Pour all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">serve</mark> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea! Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
mnemonics.reading: しゃく く None As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool. Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Sigh Deep in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>, you feel like you want to pull your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark>s out by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, but instead you let out a loud <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sigh</mark>. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul. Imagine all of the other people staring and pointing, the kids making fun of you, no one seeing you as equal. And just... sigh. Deep down, you want to get rid of your fangs, but you can't do it.
mnemonics.reading: がい None None You sigh again and say, "I wish I was just a normal guy (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh* Now you're staring in the mirror at yourself. You sigh loudly and take out the pliers. You'll be a guy like everyone else. S-soon. As soon as you can muster up enough strength to stop sighing and rip these fangs out.

mnemonics.meaning: Spine Evergreen Beech This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> has been sitting directly on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spine</mark> for weeks straight. The pain is starting to become unbearable, and it seems like no one wants to help you. Tree turkeys are absolutely huge, and this exceptionally large one has been sitting right on top of your spine for what feels like ages. Imagine the pain of a huge turkey pressing down on your spine for weeks, perhaps months. How are you still holding on?!
mnemonics.reading: つい しい None Just as your spine seems to be getting used to the pressure, the tree turkey unleashes a cry: "TWEET (つい)!" To your horror, a flock of tree turkeys emerge from the trees. You desperately try to escape from the weight of the tree turkey still sitting on top of your spine, but to no avail. The only thing you can see is dozens of tree turkeys approaching to plant themselves firmly on top of your spine, screaming "TWEET, TWEET".

mnemonics.meaning: Steal You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>s just sitting in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> and so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steal</mark> them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right? Imagine seeing seven swords just lying abandoned in a hole. Feel the urge to steal them all. Do it, do it!
mnemonics.reading: せつ ぬす, ひそ None You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal! Imagine your delight as you look up the different sword sets online and realize you happened to steal the best one!

mnemonics.meaning: Sulfur Sulphur There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>s that smell like <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sulfur</mark>. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks. If you haven't smelled sulfur before, it smells a bit like rotten eggs. Something that definitely belongs in the trash.
mnemonics.reading: りゅう None None You throw the sulfur rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there. Ryu looks down at you, holding the sulfurous rock in one hand. Then he uppercuts you with it! Shoryuken!

mnemonics.meaning: Asia Sub- The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both Asia. This can also mean sub-. As in subtropics, subspecies, subhuman… That kind of sub-! When it's not in a place name, 亜 will usually be using its sub- meaning. 亜 is associated with Asia because of its あ reading, but sometimes you might see it used as ateji for other place names as well. And don't forget that sub- meaning!
mnemonics.reading: あ つ None What's the first sound in Asia? It's A (あ). Nice and easy! A is for Asia!

mnemonics.meaning: Barracks The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barracks</mark> kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: とん None None Barracks are pretty big, so they weigh a ton (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build. Imagine trying to lift some barracks. They weigh a ton! How are you supposed to do this? Why would you even try to lift something that obviously weighs a couple tons?!

mnemonics.meaning: Cape You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cape</mark>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live? Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
mnemonics.reading: こう みさき None You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too). The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.

mnemonics.meaning: Cast Casting Take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">three</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> them into a mold to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cast</mark>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right. Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
mnemonics.reading: ちゅう い None You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house. Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!

mnemonics.meaning: Clumsy Unskillful You have to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to make an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> because you're so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clumsy</mark>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave. Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
mnemonics.reading: せつ つたな None After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors! Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!

mnemonics.meaning: Compose Recite If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> how <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> sounds you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compose</mark> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Recite</mark> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it. Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
mnemonics.reading:
えい よ, うた None You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you. Let me recite the acorn poem to you now: Acorns start small
Grow up big and tall
Spread their baby acorns for all
Live on for all eternity

mnemonics.meaning: Congratulate If a pilot manages to land under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> that's pierced with a sideways <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulate</mark> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of! Can you imagine how difficult landing a helicopter is in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
mnemonics.reading: けい よろこ None Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)! Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.

mnemonics.meaning: Dairy You can only give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dairy</mark>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh. Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
mnemonics.reading: らく None None Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away! Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

mnemonics.meaning: Deliberate If someone makes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, you know it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliberate</mark>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo. Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
mnemonics.reading: とく あつ None As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions." Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.

mnemonics.meaning: Despise <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> will come to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">despise</mark> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it. Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
mnemonics.reading: ぶ あなず, あなど None The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people. This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.

mnemonics.meaning: Endure If there is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark>, it's a lot for the crabs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark>. Imagine a little crab getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
mnemonics.reading: かん, たん こら, た None You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck. Imagine yourself putting a collar around the crab's neck, then adding a leash and taking your crab for a walk around your neighborhood.

mnemonics.meaning: Evil Misfortune A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> wearing two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil. Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
mnemonics.reading: か わざわい None You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil! Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.

mnemonics.meaning: Female If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> by putting a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> in its face you'll know it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">female</mark> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay. Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
mnemonics.reading: し めす, め, めん None The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried. Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

mnemonics.meaning: Friendly If you see someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>ing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">friendly</mark> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first. Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく, もく むつ None This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out. Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with ぼく before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

mnemonics.meaning: Guts Gallbladder If you stay up so long that you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> go down and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> come, people will say you have serious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guts</mark>. It takes guts to stay up that late. More specifically, it takes a powerful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gallbladder</mark>. Your gallbladder is sensitive to sleep changes, you know, so you risk a lot by staying up like that. Imagine the guts you'd need to have to stay up so late that you see the moon and the sun switch places! And to risk gallbladder damage?! That takes guts!
mnemonics.reading: たん きも None You stayed awake outside for so long, just to prove you had guts and powerful gallbladder, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! Imagine the deep tan you'd get after staying awake outside for such a long time. Tanning is also bad for your gallbladder! Man, you've really got guts to be getting tans like that.

mnemonics.meaning: Imitate You try to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to cast <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">doubt</mark> on people by using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imitate</mark> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others. Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
mnemonics.reading: ぎ まが, もど None Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation. Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.

mnemonics.meaning: Japanese Birch Birch What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese birch</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">birch</mark>, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch! Imagine licking the trunk of a Japanese birch tree and feeling the heat on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: し あずさ None You can only cut down a Japanese birch using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are. Imagine using a zoo saw to cut down a Japanese birch tree. What's a zoo saw? It's a saw that's used in zoos, to build all the animal enclosures. And to cut down spicy trees.

mnemonics.meaning: Lacquer Varnish A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> protects you from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, but the hat itself is now covered in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lacquer</mark>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected. Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
mnemonics.reading: しつ うるし None You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore! Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!

mnemonics.meaning: Leisure You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leisure</mark> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used. Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
mnemonics.reading: かん None None As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you. But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.

mnemonics.meaning: Lowly Base You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> to the ground in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> down in front of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lowly</mark> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that. Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
mnemonics.reading: ひ いや None The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell? You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

mnemonics.meaning: Marry You meet a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> whose <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">marry</mark>. When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
mnemonics.reading: いん None None You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together! When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.

mnemonics.meaning: Mountain Pass The Worst If there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">below</mark> you, that means you're on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mountain pass</mark>. Imagine yourself walking along a mountain pass. Look up at the mountains above you, and down at the mountains below you.
mnemonics.reading: None とうげ None It's only on this type of mountain pass that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko! Picture yourself hiking along a mountain pass in Tokyo and spotting a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

mnemonics.meaning: Mourning If you only let <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> (yourself) into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you'll end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourning</mark> all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in. Picture yourself all alone. You never let anyone into your heart but yourself, and now you're mourning the life and friends you could have had.
mnemonics.reading: き い None While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning? You try to push the key back into your body. Back into your eye, you even try to swallow it, but it comes back out. Finally you look down at your mourning heart and try the key there. It clicks. And opens.

mnemonics.meaning: Official When under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> makes it out into the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> (the public), it finally becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">official</mark>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts. Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
mnemonics.reading: そう, ぞう つかさ, ともがら, へや None Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too. The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: Recital We want you to say things with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> because it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recital</mark> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite! The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
mnemonics.reading: ぎん None None Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts! Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

mnemonics.meaning: Reef The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> that looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>ing underwater is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reef</mark>. It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes.
