Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
mnemonics.reading: しょう None None The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours. You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.

mnemonics.meaning: Sand People think <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s are only made of water but they have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> pieces of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sand</mark> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in. Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
mnemonics.reading: さ, しゃ すな, よなげる None You already learnt the reading for 砂, the other kanji for sand. It should be easy to remember this one too, since it's also さ! As long as you remember 砂, you can remember さ.

mnemonics.meaning: Scorn Neglect In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s down like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>. There they stay, an icon of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scorn</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neglect</mark>. It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
mnemonics.reading: べつ さげす None Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets (べつ) you I can get up if I want. I bets you I can." You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.

mnemonics.meaning: Select If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's heading for your village is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fat</mark> you should try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">select</mark> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage. Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
mnemonics.reading: た, たい おご, にご, よな None If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco. While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

mnemonics.meaning: Spinning Spin Move <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> and you'll end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spinning</mark> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it! Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
mnemonics.reading: ぼう つむ None While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes. Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Transition Going from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> even for yourself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>), is a huge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transition</mark>. It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
mnemonics.reading: せん うつ, みやこがえ None You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better. A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!

mnemonics.meaning: Very Great Making a mnemonic for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">VERY</mark> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will! How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
mnemonics.reading: じん はなは None You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things. How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

mnemonics.meaning: Wander The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wander</mark> the lands in search of it. You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
mnemonics.reading: ろう None None As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう). Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Worship Revere Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> are people using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worship</mark> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them. Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
mnemonics.reading: すう あが None Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise. You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!

mnemonics.meaning: Annoy Annoying Set <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">annoy</mark> it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly. Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
mnemonics.reading: はん, ぼん うるさ, わずら None You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun. Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.

mnemonics.meaning: Article Sincerity "For the  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>, it is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> that they will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>." That is the latest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">article</mark> of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark> by the government. By writing up new articles and laws they keep taking things away from samurai. First the katana, now jackhammers?
mnemonics.reading: かん None None The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan knew that samurai were a threat to his kingdom, so he took away their secondary weapon, the jackhammer.

mnemonics.meaning: Barbarian If, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, you behave like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, you might as well be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barbarian</mark>. Again and again, these insect-like barbarians are harassing you and your lands. What shall we do, m'lord?
mnemonics.reading: ばん えびす None "BAN (ばん) the barbarians! Ban them, I say!," you loudly declare as the lord of these lands. Picture yourself as the lord of your lands, screaming "BAN them" at the top of your lungs. You'll finally expel these insect-like barbarians that have been plaguing your lands again and again.

mnemonics.meaning: Bargain Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark>, being sold for cheap, what a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bargain</mark>! Look really closely at this Mona Lisa. Hmm, I don't remember her having a mustache, but I guess it is a little dark under this canopy.
mnemonics.reading: れん None None This Mona Lisa is such a bargain because it's just a rental (れん)! No wonder this moustached Mona Lisa is such a bargain. You can really get anything as a rental these days, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Censure If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> out of someone just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">censure</mark> them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested. Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
mnemonics.reading: がい None None Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA! Look at that guy now. What a loser.

mnemonics.meaning: Certain One, That Person If you think a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> looks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> you have to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching. Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
mnemonics.reading: ぼう それがし, なにがし None If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you. So now let me ask you again, are you certain, or would you like to try the bowling ball test?

mnemonics.meaning: Correct Straighten An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow </mark>is shot from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> and hits right between your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">correct</mark> your crooked smile. It also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straighten</mark>s your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you. An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
mnemonics.reading: きょう た None These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky. If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache, just wander around きょうと, staring up at the sky. Then when you see an arrow, run for it and try to catch it with your face!

mnemonics.meaning: Diarrhea Diarrhoea You ate some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s that made you so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> it feels like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diarrhea</mark>. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now. Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
mnemonics.reading: り None None The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you. You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.

mnemonics.meaning: Die If you ride a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">die</mark>. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die. Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
mnemonics.reading: せい い, ゆ None You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead. Wait, no! It shatters. Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.

mnemonics.meaning: Gradually Steadily You're stuck in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> during a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> and all you have to break out is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. You whack and whack but you're only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gradually</mark> making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown. Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
mnemonics.reading: ぜん ようや, やや None As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open. YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!

mnemonics.meaning: Grid Measure You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s lined up like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grid</mark>. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper? Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid system.
mnemonics.reading: しょう ます None As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later! You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!

mnemonics.meaning: Groom Have you heard the tale of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who fell in love with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> during a full <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and made him her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">groom</mark>? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the groom's side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things. Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
mnemonics.reading: せい むこ None Since their wedding happened under the full moon, the groom wore his special moon coat (むこ) to the ceremony. This is the ideal coat for a groom to wear, since they can keep wearing it all through their honeymoon. Try to imagine what this moon coat looks like. Does it glow in the dark like the moon shines at night? Or does it instead have a rugged texture like the moon's surface? Or maybe both?

mnemonics.meaning: Hide This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> side to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hide</mark> the fact that you're in here too. You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
mnemonics.reading: とく かくま None As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?" "N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: Humble Discreet You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boot</mark> when you want to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humble</mark>. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discreet</mark>. Picture yourself trying to be humble. You're down on the ground talking to a pair of boots. You don't dare raise your eyes past that.
mnemonics.reading: きん つつし None You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse! Imagine saying something to the King. Get low down on the ground to be as humble as you can. Whisper into the King's boots. Lick them if you have to.

mnemonics.meaning: Indigo <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark> are always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indigo</mark>. You aren't sure why though... Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
mnemonics.reading: らん あい None Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see! Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.

mnemonics.meaning: Jetty Pier You grab a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to help you reach the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark> out in the ocean, using it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jetty</mark> leading straight to it. Now you can walk out on your makeshift <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pier</mark> and go get drinks without needing a boat or getting wet. Imagine laying your tree into the water to make your own jetty extending out to the floating bar in the ocean. Innovative!
mnemonics.reading: さん, せん かけはし None You also made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, and he wants a refreshing drink after delivering all those presents. You get extra presents for making him a jetty, so win-win. Picture Santa-san coming in from the ocean on his speedboat and docking on your jetty so he can go relax in the bar. Imagine the mountain of presents he lays on the jetty for you as thanks.

mnemonics.meaning: Martyr Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> member in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and he'll become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">martyr</mark> to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison. Imagine all the yakuza coming out into the streets and holding up signs saying this guy was a martyr. A hero to all who do bad stuff in bad groups but don't wanna get caught.
mnemonics.reading: じゅん None None The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer! Really, it's not the fault of the people who put him there that he's become a martyr. It's the month of June. PUNISH JUNE! PUT JUNE IN THE SUN PRISON! (Is what I assume those yakuza are shouting.)

mnemonics.meaning: Pit Hole In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>. You lift it to reveal a deep <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pit</mark>. Why is there a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark> under your table? You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
mnemonics.reading: こう None None When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table. After you've nursed こういち back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone こういち–the very same こういち who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"

mnemonics.meaning: Quit Leave You're in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> but you have the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quit</mark> playing along and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leave</mark> at any time. Your captors think they have you trapped, but you know you can leave whenever you feel like it.
mnemonics.reading: ひ や None You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire. As the heat spreads you decide to leave. You hop out of the net and watch the shock spread in your captors eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: Reckless If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> occurs it's because she was being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reckless</mark>. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right. Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: もう, ぼう みだ None As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it. Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.

mnemonics.meaning: Ripples As the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, it alters the wave, creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ripples</mark>. They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
mnemonics.reading: れん さざなみ None Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami. As you watch the ripples come off your car and scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.

mnemonics.meaning: Seaweed The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that wash up on shore in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s that we make into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seaweed</mark>. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed. Seaweed is the flower of the sea!
mnemonics.reading: そう も None Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul. Feed your soul with seaweed and it will thank you. Promise! <3

mnemonics.meaning: Secrete <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>'s have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> tendency to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secrete</mark> things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving. Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
mnemonics.reading: ひ, ひつ None None Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea. The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secrete? You'll say heat!

mnemonics.meaning: Shamisen Song Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to sing and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shamisen song</mark> just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time! Imagine using your mouth to sing and a shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
mnemonics.reading: ばい うた None A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way! A shamisen song is a song, yay!

mnemonics.meaning: Shore <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Half</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is always on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shore</mark>. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right? Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
mnemonics.reading: はん あぜ, くろ, ほとり None You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lie on the shore with Han!! Imagine lying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!

mnemonics.meaning: Thrifty Frugal The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> tells all of its squid people to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thrifty</mark>. Imagine the leader squid giving a speech about how you shouldn't buy new things, and how you should live with a roommate to save money. Every squid yen counts!
mnemonics.reading: けん つづまやか, つま None Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent. Ken's squid is always shaking his head at Ken the samurai's obsession with wearing all silk. He should visit Thrifty Threads, the second hand shop, and get some cotton clothes that would do the job just fine. Hint: Whenever there's a squid, remember that Ken (けん) the samurai is nearby.

mnemonics.meaning: Torture You put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> to tickle the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> inside. What you're doing is a new form of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">torture</mark>. First, you put them in a coffin to make them think they're going to die. Then you tickle them with your fingers. There is no greater psychological + physical torture than this.
mnemonics.reading: ごう None None The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is none other than old Grandpa ごういち. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled. He keeps screaming: "STOP THIS TICKLE TORTURE. I CAN'T TAKE IT, JUST BURY ME."

mnemonics.meaning: Ugly Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> and you'll see how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ugly</mark> it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face. Picture the drunk demon as its pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
mnemonics.reading: しゅう しこ, みにく None The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes. The demon drinking alcohol out of its nasty shoes is the ugliest scene you've ever seen.

mnemonics.meaning: Underworld Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> is in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, and you start seeing those creatures with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>s for heads and  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> for feet again. Where on earth did they come from? They must have come from the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">underworld</mark>. Nothing like that exists in this life. Imagine the heat of the sun on your forehead as you watch these horrible creatures with lid-heads and fin-feet. There's no doubt that these are creatures from the underworld. You get out of the sun as fast as you can.
mnemonics.reading: めい, みょう None None The sun is unusually hot for the month of May (めい), which must be why those underworld creatures are running around. You make a mental note to always avoid the sun in May.

mnemonics.meaning: Valley The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> swept away one of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> just bought and creates an entire <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valley</mark> with it. Watch as the tsunami rakes your husband's cleat across the mountain, carving a valley and an easier path for itself. Nature is brutal.
mnemonics.reading: けい たに, たにがわ None When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut." Imagine yourself eating cake with your husband in this newly formed valley. You both agree that this should be called Cake Valley!

mnemonics.meaning: Widow Under your own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> jumps out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">widow</mark>. Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
mnemonics.reading: か None None You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over. It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.

mnemonics.meaning: Yearn For Adore You're walking in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> when you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water fall and it makes you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yearn for</mark> the person you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adore</mark>. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing. Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
mnemonics.reading: ぼ した None As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Ugh. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water. Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.
